DOC.HEADLINE: Draw to stimulate consumption in Taipei County to kick off Monday

TEXT.P: A lucky draw aimed at stimulating consumption in Taipei County will formally kick off Feb. 2, the Taipei County government said Saturday.

The Taipei County government said the draw is being held in tandem with the government's distribution of NT$3,600 worth of shopping vouchers to each citizen to help boost consumption amid an economic downturn.
Taipei County Deputy Magistrate Chen Wei-jen said anyone who spends NT$3,600 in the county, whether in cash or government-issued shopping vouchers, will be eligible to take part in the draw.
They could put invoices worth NT$3,600 into an envelop to enter the draw, which has a top prize of NT$3 million (US$895,500) worth of gold.
Chen also said that the county will accept invoices dated Jan. 1 and May 31.
The envelopes could be dropped off at the county's 7-11 convenience stores or in special boxes at the county government and city and township offices.
The draw will be held March 16, April 15, May 15 and June 12. All the invoices will be donated to charity organizations after each draw, according to Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 910kg hog selected as top offering at Zushiye temple

TEXT.P: A hog weighing more than 900 kilograms was selected in a competition as the premier offering at a traditional temple ceremony in Sansia township, Taipei County, Saturday.
On Jan. 6 each year on the lunar calendar, the Qingshui Zushiye Temple in Sansia celebrates the birthday of a deity known as zushiye, who is enshrined at the temple famous for its artistic carvings.
In Chinese, zushiye means the founder of a sect of Buddhism or Taoism.
The Qingshui zushiye was a Buddhist monk who lived in Anxi in the Fujien area in southeastern China 1047-1101 A.D. After his death, the locals deified him as their tutelary god.

When they moved to Taiwan, the Anxi people brought a statue of the god to the island and developed a special religious culture in the Taipei county area covering Sansia, Yingge, Tucheng and Dashi to worship the god.
Every year, "sacred hogs" are selected in a competition and presented as offerings on the birthday of the god.
According to legend, those who touch the sacred hogs are blessed, while those who pull out the hairs of the deified animal will gain wisdom and those who eat the meat will live safely and well.
A total of four hogs were entered in the contest this year, with the top prize winner weighing over 910 kg -- the largest hog in nearly five years, according to the organizer.
The temple was packed Saturday with tourists and people praying for good luck, including Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Feb. 1, 2009

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 1, or seventh day of the first month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1650: Rene Descartes, French mathematician and philosopher known as the "father of French philosophy," dies at the age of 54. His philosophy is based on the rationalistic premise: "I think, therefore I am."
1893: Thomas Edison, the American inventor who patented more than a thousand inventions, opens the first film studio in West Orange, New Jersey.
1901: Clark Gable, American film actor who became an international heart throb, is born. He played Rhett Butler in "Gone With the Wind."
1902: The Ching dynasty orders the lifting of a ban on marriages between the Manchus and the Chinese.
1913: The first Far Eastern Games are held in Manila, the Philippines, with athletes from the Republic of China, Japan and the host country attending.
1924: Britain recognizes the Communist government of the Soviet Union.
1948: The Bank of Taiwan issues a new edition of the 100-dollar bill.
1950: Deputies of the National Assembly respectfully invite Chiang Kai-shek to succeed acting President Lee Tsung-jen as the president of the Republic of China. Lee remained in the United States following the Nationalist government's retreat to Taiwan after being defeated by the Communists in China's civil war.
1951: The U.N. General Assembly condemns the Chinese Communists as aggressors in Korea.
1952: The U.N. General Assembly finds the Soviet Union guilty of violating the 1945 Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1958: The first U.S. satellite, the Vanguard-1, is successfully launched into orbit.
1963: Taiwan's `king of iron and steel' Tang Jung dies at the age of 83.
1967: President Chiang Kai-shek establishes the National Security Council. Vice Premier Huang Shao-ku is named secretary-general of the organization and Ku Shu- tung is named deputy secretary-general.
1973: One hundred and four members of the National Assembly and the Legislative Yuan, 20 mayors and magistrates and the 73 members of the fifth Taiwan Provincial Assembly are sworn in.
1974: An economic mission headed by Economic Affairs Vice Minister Chang Kwang- shih leaves for Saudi Arabia for a five-day visit.
1978: The Central Daily News, the oldest newspaper in the country, marks its 50th anniversary.
1979: Iranian religious leader the Ayatollah Khomeini ends 16 years of exile, returning from Paris to a frenzied welcome at Tehran airport.
1980: Taiwan's North Link (Suao-Hualien) Railway is opened with ceremonies in Nanshenghu, near Ilan, and Hualien. The project cost the government NT$7.3 billion and took six years to complete.
1982: Alfred Britain III, chairman of the Bankers Trust Company of New York, opens the bank's branch office in Taipei.
1990: South African President F.W. de Klerk announces the legitimacy of the African National Congress and other political organizations. He also promises the unconditional release of jailed ANC leader Nelson Mandela within two weeks.
1991: An earthquake rocks Pakistan and Afghanistan, killing more than 1,200 people.
1992: U.S. President George Bush and Russian President Boris Yeltsin sign the Camp David declaration stating that their two countries no longer regard each other as adversaries.
1995: Communist Vietnam and the United States begin a new chapter in their relationship by opening liaison offices in each others' capitals.
1995: The World Trade Organization passes a resolution to accept the Republic of China as an observer country.
2000: Premier Vincent Siew presides over a ceremony to unveil the name plaque of the newly established Coast Guard Administration and swear in CGA Director- General Yao Kao-chiao.
2001: Nobel laureate Gao Xingjian, at the invitation of the Taipei City Government's Cultural Affairs Bureau, arrives in Taiwan from Hong Kong.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In my method of teaching, I always wait for my student to make an effort himself to find his way through a difficulty, before I show him the way myself. I also make him find his own illustrations before I give him one of my own. When I have pointed out the bearing of a subject in one direction and found that my student cannot himself see its bearings into other directions, I do not then repeat my lesson."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Hu's six-point overture will guide China's ties with Taiwan: MAC

TEXT.P: The six-point overture on the peaceful development of cross-strait ties that Chinese President Hu Jintao spelled out recently can be seen as a framework for China's policy toward Taiwan in the year to come, an official said Sunday.

Hu's six-point overture, however, indicates that the "one-China" principle remains Beijing's bottom line, from which it will never budge an inch, said Chao Chien-min, a vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).

In a Dec. 31 statement marking the 30th anniversary of the adoption of China's "peaceful reunification" policy toward Taiwan, Hu renewed the call for the two sides to negotiate under the "one-China" principle to end cross-strait hostilities and to sign a peace accord.
He suggested the political basis for promoting peaceful development of the cross-strait relations should rest on the concept that "both the mainland and Taiwan belong to one China."
Hu also proposed closer economic cooperation and reasonable arrangements to address Taiwan's efforts to join international organizations.

Chao said Hu's six-point overture will definitely be the major plank in shaping China's policies toward Taiwan in the future, adding that it appears that the eight-point proposal made by Hu's predecessor, Jiang Zemin, on the development of cross-strait relations has already been swept into the dust of history.
"It's only a matter of time before the 'Hu six-point overture' is written into the charters of the Communist Party of China, " Chao forecast.
Meanwhile, President Ma Ying-jeou's office has not yet made a concise or concrete response to Hu's proposals.

In its initial response on Jan. 1, the Presidential Office commented positively on the "new mindset and pragmatism" of the Chinese authorities, but stressed that as a pluralistic society, Taiwan's people have diverse views about the country's future and that different political views and expressions have to be respected.

The Presidential Office reiterated the "1992 consensus, " which allows Taipei and Beijing to agree to disagree on the meaning of "one China, " and the principle of "mutual non-denial" as a reminder to China about Taiwan's stance on cross-strait relations.
On Jan. 6, Ma said Taiwan has to learn more about the connotations of the policy implications for Taiwan in China's latest cross-strait proposal.
The Ma administration has also called for economics to take precedence over politics at this time and reiterated the island's desire to participate in international organizations.

Meanwhile, Tsai Wei, a professor at Chinese Culture University's Sun Yat-sen Graduate Institute, said from Hu's overture one can discern that China has not and will never let go of its "one-China" principle as far as cross-Taiwan Strait relations are concerned.
"Hu's proposals could at best be viewed as a change in the way Beijing is articulating its 'one-China' principle," Tsai said.

"Hu's call for both sides to open up 'international space, ' end cross-strait hostilities and build mutual trust could be seen as new approach that nonetheless still lacks concrete, positive action, " Tsai contended.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan needs a newspaper that reflects people's voices: ex-VP

TEXT.P: Former Vice President Annette Lu, who held her first fundraiser Sunday for a proposed midday newspaper, said that Taiwan needs a publication that reflects the views of the people, as there is perception abroad that the whole country is on board with the new government's policies.

Lu made the remarks at the first luncheon to raise funds for the midday paper, which will be called the Formosa Post, or Yushan (Mt. Jade) noon paper in Chinese. The event was attended by some 60 guests, including former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, Taiwan Solidarity Union Chairman Huang Kun-huei, and former Judicial Yuan Vice President Cheng Chung-mo.

Lu said that during a recent trip to Washington D.C. to attend the inauguration of U.S. President Barack Obama, she was disconcerted to learn that the United States thinks there is no need to worry about cross-Taiwan Strait affairs now that the new Taiwan government is leaning toward China.

She said she got a strong message from her friends in the U.S. that the government there has the impression that everything the Taiwan administration does has the approval of the population, as there is no conflict between Taiwan and China and there are no dissenting voices among the Taiwan people.
"Therefore, based on the basic principles of the Taiwan Relations Act, the U.S. does not have to mind that (cross-strait) business too much," Lu quoted her friends as saying.
However, the former vice president stressed that while there are diverse views in Taiwan, they are not loud or clear enough to be heard.

"Washington is under the impression that, like an obedient child, Taiwan is gradually marching toward China," Lu said. "As long as there are no other voices, the U.S. has nothing to be concerned about."

Cross-strait relations between Taiwan and China have improved significantly since President Ma Ying-jeou took office May 20, 2008 and adopted a series of pragmatic policies to open economic exchanges with Beijing.
However, the DPP has expressed fears that the strategic shift by the government to prioritize its partnership with China may come at the expense of Taiwan's sovereignty and national interests.

"My trip to Washington solidified my resolution to establish the Formosa Post, as Taiwan needs a newspaper to unify people who love Taiwan, so as to normalize, globalize and enrich the country," the former vice president said.
"Together we can make it," she added.

Noting that Obama would not have been the president were it not for the sound democratic system in the U.S., Lu said Taiwan has many new challenges to face, as its democracy is not yet fully developed or perfect.

She urged people to join and subscribe to her midday paper, which she said will serve as a launch pad for a "civic journalists' movement" in Taiwan, to bring hope in times of despair and to show the world a better Taiwan.
According to Lu, the newspaper, which will go on sale at 3 p.m. daily, will focus on local and international politics, culture, science and technology, as well as on other events and values.

DOC.HEADLINE: 46% of office workers in Taiwan affected by unpaid leave: survey

TEXT.P: The practice of sending workers on unpaid leave has been growing among production companies in Taiwan since October last year, and the domestic job market may see another wave of layoffs in the first quarter of 2009, the Internet-based 1111 Job Bank warned Sunday.

Ryan Wu, chief operating officer of 1111 Job Bank, said an online survey conducted recently by his organization showed that 46 percent of Taiwan's office workers had been told to take up to 10 days of unpaid leave each month since October.

According to the survey, office workers sent on unpaid leave have seen their monthly wages reduced by one-third on average. Some 20 percent have thought of looking for another job, and 80 percent appeared to be depressed about the situation, the survey found.

Noting that some enterprises have asked some of their employees to take an additional month of unpaid leave following the nine-day Lunar New Year holiday, Wu said it seems unlikely that the strategy will be dropped by the end of March, as many people are hoping.

Meanwhile, the results of the latest survey conducted by the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs showed that among those enterprises that have a workforce of over 200 people, 18 percent have resorted to unpaid leave as a means of coping with their difficulties caused by the ongoing global economic downturn and financial crisis. It was estimated that more than 200,000 office workers had been affected.

Earlier statistics released by the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) in late December showed that as a result of the unpaid leave practice, 741,000 people were working fewer than 35 hours per week in November, an increase of 205,000 people over October's total of 536,000.

Other DGBAS figures showed that the number of unemployed people in Taiwan totaled 549,000 in December 2008, the highest since October 2003. The figure represented an increase of 4.64 percent over October last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourism bureau chief confident about domestic tourist market

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top tourism official expressed confidence Sunday in the domestic tourist market, saying that she believes it can spur economic development despite the global financial crisis, and that the tourism industry will eventually help turn the tide if it perseveres.

Noting that the government has been putting a lot of effort into promoting international and domestic tourism over the years, Tourism Bureau Director- General Janice Lai told the Central News Agency that the government's recent shopping voucher program will help to create a virtuous business cycle.

Some 91 percent of eligible Taiwan citizens had picked up their NT$3,600 (US$107) worth of vouchers by Jan. 18. The vouchers are the business end of an NT$85.7 billion program that is part of the government's economic stimulus package.

With every city and county in Taiwan launching various promotion drives to encourage people to spend their vouchers, the program is expected to help expand Taiwan's economic growth by about 0.66 percentage points or more, according to Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chen Tain-jy recently.
"While the tourism industry might be suffering amid the economic downturn, springtime will soon come, as long as we hang in there and wait out the bitter winter," Lai said.

Noting that during the 10-year bubble economy in the late 1980s Japan still managed to create many successful hot spring businesses, Lai said "as long as one has good products, there is no need to worry about reduced purchasing power."

She cited the example of a Japanese karaoke club owner who bought up many hot spring hotels that were close to bankruptcy during the bubble economy and launched a low-price self-service accommodation package that attracted many customers because of the good value of the product.

Urging the public to travel more within the country, Lai said she hoped that the various tourism packages being offered by county and city governments will serve to restore confidence in the domestic travel market.

On the regional front, the number of Japanese tourists to Taiwan has been declining recently, as more Japanese are choosing to travel to South Korea because the yen remains strong against the weakening South Korean won.

Lai, however, expressed confidence in Taiwan's tourism market, saying that Taiwan remains an attractive tourism destination for Japanese visitors because it offers high quality travel packages and great tourism spots.

As for tourism from China, Lai said six months after the Taiwan government opened up to allow more Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan, the number of Chinese visitors has been gradually increasing and is expected to continue to grow.
Another important tourism market is Southeast Asia, Lai said, adding that the government will try to relax the visa process to attract more tourists from countries like Singapore and Malaysia.
According to Lai, there were some 3.84 million visitors to Taiwan in 2008, a number that fell short of the goal of the "Tour Taiwan Years 2008-2009" program.

The program, which was launched Feb. 15, 2008, aimed to attract four million international tourists in 2008 and 4.25 million in 2009. However, according to the top tourism official, the decreased number of Japanese tourists was the main reason for the failure to reach the target. She vowed to work all out to attain the goal of attracting four million international tourists this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese box office hit to premiere in China
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Feb. 1 (CNA) 02/01/09 17:21:20 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese box office hit "Cape No. 7" will premiere in China in mid- February, giving Chinese movie goers some insight into Taiwanese culture and way of thinking, a movie source said Sunday.

The film was to be shown in China before the Lunar New Year holiday, but the screening was postponed due to censor procedures. However, Chinese authorities recently gave the green light for it to premiere there around Feb. 14, Valentine's Day, which is also considered in the movie industry as a major box- office season.
"Cape No. 7, " released in 2008, is the highest grossing locally produced movie of all time in Taiwan.

As one of the promotional tie-ins, millet wine, which is seen many times in the film, will be offered at theaters in 12 cities around China Feb. 15-28, said Qian Junyan, a vice president of Wanda International Cinema, Shanghai. The 12 Chinese cities are Beijing, Harbin, Huizhou, Jinjiang, Shanghai, Dongguan, Nanchang, Nanning, Ningbo, Chengdu, Changsha and Nanjing, Qian said.

Preferential tickets will be sold at the Shanghai Wanda International Cinema seven days in advance of the premiere in a promotional strategy to spur competition for tickets and thus make "Cape No. 7" more popular, Qian added.

Meanwhile, according to Qian, ticket buyers will have a chance to take part in a lucky draw for a five-day travel package to Taiwan to see in person the filming locations in the southern county of Pingtung.

The prize will be awarded to 10 winners, who will travel from Beijing to Taiwan and spend one day in Kaohsiung, two days in Pingtung and two days in Taiwan's only landlocked county of Nantou, Qian said.
Meanwhile, "Cape No. 7" is also expected to premiere at the 15th Vesoul International Film Festival of Asian Cinema slated for Feb. 10-17 in France.

"Cape No. 7" has been nominated in the unreleased feature films section of the "Faces of Asian Contemporary Cinema" category, and will compete with other films from China, South Korea, India, Indonesia, Iran, Kazakhstan, the Philippines and Sri Lanka, according to Jean-Marc Therouanne, the founder of the film festival.
Therouanne told the Central News Agency recently that "Cape No. 7" has been shortlisted because it is an interesting film that has become very popular not only in Taiwan but also in Southeast Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: 96-hour run around Taiwan concludes in Taichung

TEXT.P: A four-day round-the-island marathon relay aimed at praying for blessings for Taiwan concluded Sunday in Shalu in the central county of Taichung.
A total of 52 runners, including seven females, participated in the round-the- clock 966-kilometer marathon relay in four teams.

The run began Jan. 28 from the square in front of the Taiwan High Speed Rail's Taichung Station, then the runners headed south on provincial highway No. 1 and passed through Kaohsiung, Taitung, Hualien, Keelung and Taipei, then back to Taichung where the race ended Sunday morning.

Along the route, the running teams attracted some 200 enthusiasts who joined them. The event also drew great attention from passersby on the route through Hung Kuang University in Shalu township, Taichung County.
Afer 96 hours on the road, the runners returned to the starting point at the Taichung Station around 9: 40 a.m. and were warmly greeted with fireworks and firecrackers.

The youngest runner was a 20-year-old man, and the oldest was a 61-year-old retired police officer Chen Chien, who participated in a 7-day super marathon in Greek last year and was ranked 24th among 45 competitors from various countries.

The run around Taiwan was the second of its kind organized by the Taiwan Bigfoot Long Run Association, a civic group founded in 2000 and which now has 466 members. The association's first round-the-island marathon was held in 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pingsi sky lantern festival to soar on Feb. 9

TEXT.P: Following the launch of the 15-day 2009 Pingsi International Lantern Festival on Jan. 26, the annual event is set to reach its climax on Feb. 9, with the release of thousands of sky lanterns carrying wishes written by people in the hope of bringing good luck and happiness to their loved ones in the new year.

Pingsi township in the northern county of Taipei has been the center of sky lantern activities in the last few years, attracting around 30,000 foreign and local visitors each year on Lantern Festival day, which is celebrated 15 days after the Lunar New Year.

Thanks to the Taipei county government which first organized the grand celebration of the festival 10 years ago, the Pingsi festivities have become the most representative Lantern Festival event in northern Taiwan.

According to folklore, the lanterns, which are actually miniature hot-air balloons, bring good luck to the people who launch them. The higher a lantern rises, the more good luck it brings, the legend claims.
A local Pingsi elder surnamed Chen told the Central News Agency that there are three different stories about the origins of sky lanterns.

"According to one popular story, the sky lantern, or Kongming Lantern, was invented for the purpose of military communication by Zhuge Kongming -- a noted sage and military strategist in Shu Han during the Three Kingdoms period in 220-280 A.D.," Chen said. "It was called Kongming Lantern because the shape of it resembled the hat that Zhuge Kongming was traditionally shown to be wearing."

Others have said that the tradition dates back to the Qing Dynasty in the late 18th century when village watchmen would release the lanterns to tell people in the mountain areas that they were safe from bandits.
The tradition was brought to Pingsi and Shihfen townships in Taipei County by immigrants from Fujian Province in China and was also known as "lantern for blessings," Chen said.

Another story regarding the origins of the sky lantern is that in 1928 when Shihfen township was occupied by the Japanese army, people would release lanterns into the sky to signal those taking refuge in the mountains that it was safe to return.

The Taipei county government has a total of 10,000 ox-shaped sky lanterns, in celebration of the Year of the Ox, to hand out to visitors who wish to send their New Year's wishes to the gods, according to the county's Tourism Bureau.
This year's sky lantern celebrations began on Chinese New Year's Day, Jan. 26, and will run through Feb. 9, Lantern Festival day.

The celebrations feature three main events -- a smaller event at Chingtung Elementary School on Jan. 31 and larger-scale extravaganzas at Pingsi Junior High School on Feb. 7 and at "Sky Lantern Square" in Shihfen township on Feb. 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opening hours at Taipei Zoo back to normal

TEXT.P: The Taipei Zoo decided Sunday to revert to its normal opening hours, from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. daily, beginning Monday, after seven consecutive days of extended service during the Chinese New Year holiday.

The zoo had extended its opening hours to between 8: 45 a.m. and 5: 30 p.m. for seven days to accommodate a record number of visitors, as it debuted its two giant pandas -- Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan -- from Sichuan province in southwestern China.
Under a daily quota system, 22,000 people per day visited the panda house in the 7-day period starting Jan. 26 to watch the two rare bamboo-eating animals, said Jason Yeh, head of the zoo.
The free shuttle buses between the zoo and a MRT station, which were operating during the Lunar New Year holiday, will also be suspended from Monday, Yeh said.
According to Yeh, tallies show that a total of 175,386 people visited the Taipei Zoo in the first six days of the New Year holiday, marking a 100 percent increase year-on-year.
Yeh estimated that some 40,000 people would have been visiting the zoo Sunday, the last day of the Lunar New Year holiday, although only a maximum of 22,000 would be allowed to see the pandas.

Since their arrival in Taiwan Dec. 23, 2008, Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan have triggered a media frenzy befitting the arrival of a major world leader or rock star, with many in Taiwan hardly able to contain their excitement.
The male Tuan Tuan and female Yuan Yuan, both four years old, were not put on public display until Jan. 26 because they had to remain in quarantine for at least a month.
The two rare animals were a gift from Beijing that many critics said was part of its strategy to unify China and Taiwan. The combined name of the two pandas -- Tuan Yuan -- means reunion in Chinese.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP plans to set up social movements department

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) plans to set up a department of social movements and to conduct an overall assessment of the government's performance, as part of its effort to push for reform, a DPP official said Sunday.

In line with the DPP's designation of 2009 as the year of social movements, DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen recently instructed a party reform team to study issues related to the establishment of a social movements department, a party official said.
This would require revising the party's organization law to prepare for constant engagement in street protests, according to the official.

Under Tsai's reform plan, for the first five months of this year the DPP will focus on soliciting opinions from all sectors of the society and forging consensus through discourse and discussion, the official added.

During this period, the DPP will hold a civic conference on national affairs to educate local citizens on their right to assemble peacefully and to vote in referendums, and also to instill the concept of Taiwan's national sovereignty.
The party might also hold a rally for the unemployed on May 1, Labor Day.
Tsai called on reform-minded youths aged 30 to 40 to join the preparatory meetings for the national affairs conference and to contribute their ideas for reform of the party and of the country.
In the second phase of the plan, the DPP will assess the performance of President Ma Ying-jeou's administration before the end of its first year in power on May 20, the official said.

With the ruling Kuomintang and its allies holding nearly three-fourths of the seats in the legislature, the DPP has no other option but to resort to street demonstrations to carry out its function of providing checks and balances and to guard against abuse of power, according to the official.
The concept of establishing a social movements department was the brainchild of former Premier Frank Hsieh, the official added.
In related news, an academic said Sunday that the DPP chairwoman, while seeking reform on many fronts, should come up with solutions to the crises and problems the country is facing.

Describing Tsai's move to solicit public opinions as just a starting point for party reform, Soochow University political science professor Lo Chih-cheng said that she should work hard to strengthen communication and build mutual trust with civic groups by demonstrating her sincerity.
Lo said that in pushing for reform, Tsai will inevitably have to demonstrate her political power by leading her party to win elections.

This includes the two legislative by-elections slated to be held in Miaoli County March 14 and in Taipei City's Daan district March 28, and the year-end elections for county magistrates and city mayors around the country, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't working to reduce alcohol abuse among indigenous people

TEXT.P: The government will continue promoting its policy to help reduce alcohol abuse among the country's aboriginal people, after initial signs of progress in this area, said officials at the Cabinet-level Council of Indigenous Peoples Sunday.

Last year, 12 of the more than 30 aboriginal townships across the country joined the council's efforts and succeeded in bringing down alcohol use among their residents to 53.1 percent, an average reduction of 7.6 percent compared to the 2007 ratio, said Council Minister Chang Jen-hsiang.

Chang called for greater participation by indigenous people in her council's efforts so as to help decrease the number of injuries and accidents among them resulting from alcohol use and to take better care of their health.

The mortality rate among Taiwan's aboriginal peoples is four to five times than that of the rest of the population, and the leading causes of death among the indigenous people are malignant tumor, liver diseases and accidents -- all of which are closely related to alcohol abuse, Chang said.

National Yang Ming University professor Kuo Shien-wen, who is in charge of a project launched by the council in 2005 to curb alcohol abuse among the indigenous people, said 12 aboriginal townships joined the project in 2007, while four withdrew and another four later entered the program.

Last year, seven of the eight townships actively participating in the program posted an average decline of 7.6 percent in the number of alcohol consumers among their residents from a year ago, recording a 53.1 percent alcohol use for 2008, he said.

Wulai township in northern Taiwan's Taipei County had the largest annual decrease of 24.9 percent in 2008, followed by Heping township in central Taiwan's Taichung County with 17.6 percent, and Namasia township in southern Kaohsiung County with 16 percent, he added.
Kuo said there is room for greater efforts to be made in this regard, as there are over 800 aboriginal tribes scattered throughout more than 30 townships across the country.
"So far, the anti-alcohol program has been advocated in a dozen townships nationwide," he said.
In 2009, the Council of Indigenous Peoples will allocate an some NT$10 million (US$298,000) -- an increase of NT$7 million from last year -- to continue the program, he added.
Due to long-term disadvantages encountered in the society, a large percent of aboriginal people of both genders, have developed the habit of drinking alcohol as a way of dealing with their problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: New legislative session to focus on economy-related bills

TEXT.P: The current legislature's third session, scheduled to begin Feb. 20, will focus on bills aimed at reviving the national economy and addressing issues related to people's livelihood, the legislative caucus of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) indicated Sunday.

Legislator Yang Chiung-ying, a whip of the KMT legislative caucus, told reporters that the first and foremost item on the legislative agenda will be the special budget bill for the government's expanded public construction program.
Under the investment plan devised by the Cabinet, she noted, NT$500 billion (US$14.85 billion) will be spent over a four-year period on public construction.
The legislature will screen the special budget bill item by item in the hope of completing the process soon so as to help revitalize the nation's economy, she added.
According to Yang, other draft bills marked as priority for the new legislative session include one for rural regeneration and another for the development of renewable energy.

Two other pieces of legislation that the lawmaking body plans to pass are a draft amendment to the Securities Transaction Tax Act that features a provision related to insider trading, and a draft amendment to the Employment Insurance Act that would grant allowances to female workers on maternity leave without pay, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2009 Taipei International Book Exhibition to open Feb. 4

TEXT.P: The 2009 Taipei International Book Exhibition, Asia's largest book fair, will open Feb. 4 at the Taipei World Trade Center for a six-day run, with hundreds of publishers from Taiwan and abroad displaying their latest publications.

According to the Taipei Book Fair Foundation, the organizer of the annual event, the exhibitors will operate some 2,000 booths in the three exhibition halls of the Taipei World Trade Center, with Hall 1 reserved for international publishers, Hall 2 for cartoon and animation books, and Hall 3 for children's books.

The United States, Germany, France and Thailand will all have a major presence at the exhibition. Thailand, which will run a theme pavilion, will send a delegation of more than 80 members from its publishing industry to the event, said Paulina Lin, director of the Taipei Book Fair Foundation.
Other countries taking part in the exhibition include Belgium, Canada, the Czech Republic, Greece, Finland, Poland, Russia, Sweden, Turkey and Mexico.

The organizer has invited many renowned writers and cartoonists from Germany, France, Japan, Thailand and China to the exhibition to introduce their latest works to local readers. Some of the writers will also speak at forums and attend book-signing events.

Admission to the exhibition is NT$100 per person, but visitors traveling to Taipei by high speed rail will be granted free admission by exchanging their rail ticket receipt for a VIP entry voucher at the exhibition's information booth.
All servicemen are entitled to a 50 percent discount on the admission fees.

The first day of the exhibition is reserved for professionals in the publishing industry and people with physical disabilities, and from Feb. 5-9 the fair will be open to the general public, according to the organizer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Month-long Jade Mountain tranquility festival begins

TEXT.P: A month-long festival of tranquility kicked off Sunday on Yushan, Taiwan's highest peak, during which mountain climbing activities will not be allowed on any of the peaks that form the imposing mountain range.

The tranquility festival followed a three-day mountain cleanup drive that began Jan. 30, with environmentalists and mountain climbing enthusiasts cleaning up major mountain trails from Tataka Anbu/Saddle entrance to the main peak of Yushan, also known as Jade Mountain.

The Yushan National Park Administration staged a Tsou aboriginal mountain deity worshipping rite at the Tataka Anbu/Saddle entrance to Yushan at around noon to symbolize the start of the month-long closure of the mountain range to any hiking or mountain climbing activities.
It marked the fifth consecutive year that a one-month tranquility festival was being observed as part of efforts to protect the natural environment, ecology and wildlife of Taiwan's sacred mountain.

At an elevation of 3,952 meters, Yushan is the highest peak not only in Taiwan, but also in East Asia. The mountain range in central-southern Taiwan has 22 peaks that rise higher than 3,000 meters and 12 of them are listed among Taiwan's top 100 peaks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tobacco surcharge hike will help smokers quit habit: official

TEXT.P: Although smokers are complaining over an impending increase in the tobacco surcharge from NT$10 (US$0.29) to NT$20 per packet after a recent law amendment, a government official said Sunday that the higher price should spur smokers to quit the habit.

Department of Health (DOH) Vice Minister Cheng Shou-shia said he thinks that the higher surcharge, which will raise the price of cigarettes from the current NT$55 to NT$70 per pack, will push some people to stop smoking in these hard economic times.
The current average price of cigarettes in Taiwan is quite low compared to other countries or areas like Hong Kong, Singapore, South Korea and Australia, Cheng noted.
Despite the planned surcharge hike, cigarette prices in Taiwan will remain lower than most other countries in Asia, he said.
The tobacco surcharge increase is expected to help generate an additional NT$18 billion per year in national revenue, pulling in about NT$38 billion this year, he said, citing DOH estimates.

Ninety percent of that NT$38 billion will go toward the estimated NT$45 billion spent annually on treating smoking-related diseases included in the national health insurance program, while nine percent will be allotted for the DOH's cancer prevention campaigns and its vaccine injection projects and medical care programs in remote areas, he explained.
All the above-mentioned measures are expected to benefit some 500,000 people, including rare disease patients, underprivileged and elderly citizens and toddlers, according to the DOH vice minister.
The remaining 1 percent of revenue from the surcharge will go toward supporting government crackdowns on the smuggling of tobacco products, in line with the law, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prospects for cross-strait tourism seen as uncertain

TEXT.P: Although both Taiwan and China took concrete steps last year to upgrade cross- Taiwan Strait tourism, the number of tourist arrivals from China has fallen short of the average daily target of 1000 people, casting doubts over the future prospects of the business, industry sources said Sunday.

According to Chang Chih-yuan, owner of E Trip tour agency based in central Taiwan's Taichung City, the problem is rooted in the many restrictions imposed by the governments on both sides, rather than in the global economic downturn.

Taiwan government restrictions, such as the condition that only groups of more than five members are allowed to visit and that they must enter and depart the country at the same time, have discouraged many individual Chinese businessmen who are most likely to visit Taiwan and to spend heavily, he said.

The Taiwan government's stipulation of the type and price of accommodation that Chinese tourists must take is another obstacle to the free development of the market, Chang noted, adding that free market competition will settle the issue itself.
What the government should do is set up a sound system to monitor business practices, instead of imposing such regulations, he suggested.

In line with the terms of an accord signed by Taiwan and China last November, the two sides agreed to operate a maximum of 108 charters each week, based on a framework established in July when they began allowing non-stop cross-strait charters on weekends.

Taiwan opened eight of its airports to local and China-based airlines plying the daily cross-strait charter flights, but the aviation companies have concentrated most of their business on four of the airports. These are Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and Taipei Songshan Airport in northern Taiwan, Taichung Chingchuankang Airport in central Taiwan and Kaohsiung International Airport in the south.
In China, the number of destinations for the direct cross-strait charters were increased from five to 21 when the flight service was upgraded to a daily one in mid-December last year.

However, he added, only a small number of 33 Chinese travel agencies have been given permission to arrange tours to Taiwan and the limited number of direct charter flights between popular destinations on the two sides have dampened the interest of many people who were keen to cash in on the business.
Too many unnecessary government restrictions will only hamper market mechanisms, Chang contended.
With the governments on both sides interfering in the market, it is difficult to predict when cross-strait tourism would fully take off, he said.
In addition, Taiwan is facing a long-existing gap in cross-strait tourism revenue, which Chang said has become a thorny issue for all concerned.

Taiwanese people make more than 2 million visits to China every year, while less than 10 percent of Chinese tourists traveling abroad come to Taiwan, he said. "This is a serious issue that both Taiwan government authorities and the private sector must address."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung City offers subsidy for LPG vehicle conversion

TEXT.P: The Taichung city government announced Sunday that this year it will offer another 300 vehicles owners a subsidy of NT$30,000 each to remodel their cars to run on liquefied petroleum gas (LPG).
However, only owners of vehicles less than five years old are allowed to apply to modify their cars for LPG, said Lee Li-de, director of the city's Bureau of Environmental Protection.
He noted that 90 percent of the vehicles in the city that are under five years old have already been remodeled to run on LPG, with the help of the city subsidy.

The growing popularity of LPG vehicles is reflected in the volume of fuel sales, according to Lee, who said that the two LPG filling stations in the city sold a total of 9,158 kiloliters of fuel last year, which represented an increase of 91 percent from the 2007 level.

Because of the high number of LPG-fueled vehicles in the city, carbon dioxide emissions dropped by 2,708 tons last year from the 2007 level, Lee said, adding that the reduction was equivalent to what would be absorbed by 225,694 trees.
Lee said that given the growing popularity of LPG vehicles, it is expected that more LPG filling stations will be established in the city.

Last year, licenses were granted for the opening of three private LPG filling stations, one of which will become operational around the middle of this year to relieve the inconvenience that LPG car drivers have endured, he added.
The subsidy program is aimed at encouraging more vehicle owners to switch to LPG to help reduce air pollution, Lee said.

He noted the cost of running a vehicle on LPG fuel is NT$0.38/per kilometer less than on unleaded gasoline because the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) has been subsidizing the cost of LPG vehicle fuel to the tune of NT$2 per liter. This means that LPG vehicle owners can save fuel costs of around NT$20,000 a year, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier calls inter-agency meeting on job openings

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan presided Sunday over an inter-ministerial brainstorming session aimed at pooling the resources of various government agencies to create more jobs and alleviate the soaring unemployment rate amid the lingering global economic downturn.

Executive Yuan sources said the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) was expected to come up with a report on the current job market situation at the meeting, which was attended by top officials from the Council of Labor Affairs, the Ministry of the Interior, the Ministry of Transportation and communications, the Ministry of the Interior and the Public Construction Commission.
Also high on the agenda were conclusions reached at a similar inter-agency meeting chaired by Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung Saturday.
Premier Liu will report to President Ma Ying-jeou Monday on any concrete programs devised at the Sunday session, the sources said.
According to the sources, Liu has kept close tabs on Taiwan's job situation since the domestic unemployment rate broke the 5 percent psychological barrier last December.

"The premier has repeatedly reminded relevant agencies to gear up to address the issue, as he believes that the worst is yet to come, " said an Executive Yuan official who spoke on condition of anonymity.

Under a short-term job promotion program, the government offered 47,000 job openings late last year, and 22,000 additional job openings are expected to be up for grabs this year. Nevertheless, the official said, the premier is not satisfied with the number and has demanded more.

According to the official, Liu has asked the Ministry of National Defense and the National Science Council -- the two agencies believed to have relatively more resources -- to create more openings for positions such as administrative and cleaning work at military hospitals and contract research assistant positions for the newly unemployed.

Meanwhile, media reports said the government plans to carry out various small- and medium-size public construction projects ahead of original schedules in oder to create more job openings as soon as possible.

The government originally plans to inject up to NT$500 billion in public infrastructure construction projects over the next four years as part of its economic stimulus package. As some of those projects my take long time to prepare for open tender after the legislature passes relevant special budget bills, the reports said the Executive Yuan is now mulling to focus on small- and medium-size projects first, such as urban landscaping, commercial zones facelift, sidewalk improvement and refurbishment of major tourist attractions.

Anyway, the reports said, the government wants to focus on projects that can be completed in two years, which government officials believe will be able to maximize the public investment effects in creating new jobs and curtailing a further rise in the unemployment rate.
According to a CEPD estimate, at least 70,000 new job openings should be created if the domestic jobless rate will be lowered to 4.5 percent from December's 5.03 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't working to reduce alcohol abuse among indigenous people

TEXT.P: The government will continue promoting its policy to help reduce alcohol abuse among the country's aboriginal people, after initial signs of progress in this area, said officials at the Cabinet-level Council of Indigenous Peoples Sunday.

Last year, 12 of the more than 30 aboriginal townships across the country joined the council's efforts and succeeded in bringing down alcohol use among their residents to 53.1 percent, an average reduction of 7.6 percent compared to the 2007 ratio, said Council Minister Chang Jen-hsiang.

Chang called for greater participation by indigenous people in her council's efforts so as to help decrease the number of injuries and accidents among them resulting from alcohol use and to take better care of their health.

The mortality rate among Taiwan's aboriginal peoples is four to five times than that of the rest of the population, and the leading causes of death among the indigenous people are malignant tumor, liver diseases and accidents -- all of which are closely related to alcohol abuse, Chang said.

National Yang Ming University professor Kuo Shien-wen, who is in charge of a project launched by the council in 2005 to curb alcohol abuse among the indigenous people, said 12 aboriginal townships joined the project in 2007, while four withdrew and another four later entered the program.

Last year, seven of the eight townships actively participating in the program posted an average decline of 7.6 percent in the number of alcohol consumers among their residents from a year ago, recording a 53.1 percent alcohol use for 2008, he said.

Wulai township in northern Taiwan's Taipei County had the largest annual decrease of 24.9 percent in 2008, followed by Heping township in central Taiwan's Taichung County with 17.6 percent, and Namasia township in southern Kaohsiung County with 16 percent, he added.
Kuo said there is room for greater efforts to be made in this regard, as there are over 800 aboriginal tribes scattered throughout more than 30 townships across the country.
"So far, the anti-alcohol program has been advocated in a dozen townships nationwide," he said.
In 2009, the Council of Indigenous Peoples will allocate an some NT$10 million (US$298,000) -- an increase of NT$7 million from last year -- to continue the program, he added.
Due to long-term disadvantages encountered in the society, a large percent of aboriginal people of both genders, have developed the habit of drinking alcohol as a way of dealing with their problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: New legislative session to focus on economy-related bills

TEXT.P: The current legislature's third session, scheduled to begin Feb. 20, will focus on bills aimed at reviving the national economy and addressing issues related to people's livelihood, the legislative caucus of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) indicated Sunday.

Legislator Yang Chiung-ying, a whip of the KMT legislative caucus, told reporters that the first and foremost item on the legislative agenda will be the special budget bill for the government's expanded public construction program.
Under the investment plan devised by the Cabinet, she noted, NT$500 billion (US$14.85 billion) will be spent over a four-year period on public construction.
The legislature will screen the special budget bill item by item in the hope of completing the process soon so as to help revitalize the nation's economy, she added.
According to Yang, other draft bills marked as priority for the new legislative session include one for rural regeneration and another for the development of renewable energy.

Two other pieces of legislation that the lawmaking body plans to pass are a draft amendment to the Securities Transaction Tax Act that features a provision related to insider trading, and a draft amendment to the Employment Insurance Act that would grant allowances to female workers on maternity leave without pay, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2009 Taipei International Book Exhibition to open Feb. 4

TEXT.P: The 2009 Taipei International Book Exhibition, Asia's largest book fair, will open Feb. 4 at the Taipei World Trade Center for a six-day run, with hundreds of publishers from Taiwan and abroad displaying their latest publications.

According to the Taipei Book Fair Foundation, the organizer of the annual event, the exhibitors will operate some 2,000 booths in the three exhibition halls of the Taipei World Trade Center, with Hall 1 reserved for international publishers, Hall 2 for cartoon and animation books, and Hall 3 for children's books.

The United States, Germany, France and Thailand will all have a major presence at the exhibition. Thailand, which will run a theme pavilion, will send a delegation of more than 80 members from its publishing industry to the event, said Paulina Lin, director of the Taipei Book Fair Foundation.
Other countries taking part in the exhibition include Belgium, Canada, the Czech Republic, Greece, Finland, Poland, Russia, Sweden, Turkey and Mexico.

The organizer has invited many renowned writers and cartoonists from Germany, France, Japan, Thailand and China to the exhibition to introduce their latest works to local readers. Some of the writers will also speak at forums and attend book-signing events.

Admission to the exhibition is NT$100 per person, but visitors traveling to Taipei by high speed rail will be granted free admission by exchanging their rail ticket receipt for a VIP entry voucher at the exhibition's information booth.
All servicemen are entitled to a 50 percent discount on the admission fees.

The first day of the exhibition is reserved for professionals in the publishing industry and people with physical disabilities, and from Feb. 5-9 the fair will be open to the general public, according to the organizer.

DOC.HEADLINE: 150,000 jobs to be created to keep unemployment at bay: spokesman

TEXT.P: More than 150,000 new jobs will be created this year to keep the annual jobless rate below 4.5 percent, Executive Yuan spokesman Su Jun-pin said late Sunday.

Su, who doubles as Government Information Office minister, made the announcement after an inter-ministerial brainstorming session aimed at pooling government resources to create more jobs and alleviate the soaring unemployment rate amid the lingering global economic recession.

During the two-hour meeting chaired by Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, several conclusions, including expanding public infrastructure construction budget, were reached with unanimous support of the participants, Su said.

Against this backdrop, Su said, the government's economic stimulus package for 2009 will be adjusted to increase public sector investment to NT$130 billion (US$3.88 billion) from the original NT$100 billion.

The budget increase and adjustment of priority investment targets will be able to generate more than 150,000 job openings this year to help drive the unemployment rate down to below 4.5 percent from a high of 5.03 percent recorded in December 2008, Su explained.

Meanwhile, Minister-without-Portfolio Tsai Hsung-hsiung, who also attended the extra brainstorming session, said the Executive Yuan will unveil within a week details about the 150,000 new jobs set to be generated this year.

Of the projected new jobs, 120,000 to 140,000 openings will be created through the launch of public infrastructure construction projects, Tsai said, adding that the public sector is also expected to offer 20,000-plus service jobs.
Moreover, Tsai said the government will actively seek private enterprises' cooperation in cutting foreign laborers to increase 30,000 jobs for local wage earners.

Responding to Premier Liu's concerns about high unemployment rate among university graduates, Ministry of Education officials said the ministry will collaborate with private enterprises in arranging internship programs for university graduates.

Top officials from the Council for Economic Planning and Development, the Council of Labor Affairs, the Ministry of the Interior, the Ministry of Transportation and communications, the Ministry of the Interior, the Public Construction Commission and the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics attended the Sunday meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 2, or the eighth day of the first month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1535: The Argentine city of Buenos Aires is founded by Spanish explorer Pedro de Mendoz.
1556: An earthquake rocks the provinces of Shensi, Henan and Shansi in mainland China, killing an estimated 830,000 people.
1665: A British fleet captures New Amsterdam, the center of the Dutch colony in North America and the flourishing trading settlement on the island of Manhattan, renaming it New York in honor of the Duke of York.
1848: Mexico, according to a treaty signed after the U.S.-Mexico War, cedes Texas, New Mexico and California to the United States.
1878: Greece declares war on Turkey.
1913: The world's biggest railroad station, New York's Grand Central Station, is formally opened.
1915: Germany begins U-boat blockades of British waters, while the United States warns Germany against attacking American ships.
1926: Valery Giscard d'Estaing, French president from 1974 to 1981, is born.
1943: German troops surrender to the Soviet Union in Stalingrad.
1946: Taipei's Yuanshan Zoo is opened.
1953: The U.S. government announces it will no longer block Chinese Nationalist troops in their raids against mainland Chinese troops stationed along the mainland coastline during the period of the Nationalist-Communist struggle.
1967: Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle is elected president of Nicaragua.
1970: China Airlines launches ROC-U.S. flight services with its inaugural flight, by a Boeing 707, to San Francisco.
1970: British philosopher and Nobel Prize-winner Bertrand Russel dies at the age of 98.
1972: Protesters in Dublin burn down the British Embassy in an act of revenge for the "Bloody Sunday" shooting in Londonderry the previous weekend in which British troops killed 13 Catholic youths and wounded another 17.
1975: Gen. Gamad Shumaimari, chief of the general staff of the armed forces of Saudi Arabia, arrives in Taipei for a 10-day visit.
1979: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini returns from 14 years in exile in Paris to rule Iran. He succeeded the Shah of Iran who fled to Egypt 15 days prior to Khomeini's return after failing to resist mounting opposition masterminded by Khomeini.
1986: Oscar Arias Sanchez is elected president of Costa Rica.
1989: A coup in Paraguay topples President Alfredo Stroessner who ruled the South American country for 35 years.
1989: The last of the Soviet troops withdraw from Afghanistan, ending a nine- year occupation of the country by Communist forces.
1994: Rafael Caldera is sworn in as president of Venezuela.
1994: The Republic of China and Burkina Faso announce the restoration of diplomatic relations, which were suspended for 21 years.
1998: A Cebu Pacific Air DC-9 crashes into a mountainside 65 kilometers northeast of Cagayan de Oro airport in the Philippines, killing all 104 people on board.
2000: The U.S. House of Representatives passes the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, a bill aimed at strengthening military ties with Taiwan, despite warnings from Beijing and the White House.
2001: Exiled mainland Chinese-born Nobel laureate writer Gao Xingjiang meets with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.
2003: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian offers condolences over the loss of space shuttle Columbia and the seven astronauts aboard.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If there were a sure way of getting rich, even though one had to be a groom and keep horses, I would be willing to pursue it. But as there is really no sure way of getting rich, I prefer to follow the pursuits congenial to me."
