DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Hubei co. to operate direct cross-strait shipping business

TEXT.P: A shipping company from China's Hubei Province is scheduled to launch direct shipping operations between Taiwan and China around mid-February, marking the first of such links operated by a shipping company from central China, a Hubei- based daily newspaper reported Monday.

The Wuhan-based Datong Industrial Co. is expected to dispatch a 2,000-ton asphalt ship from a seaport in Vietnam for Taiwan's southern port city of Kaohsiung Feb. 11, followed by a 5,000-ton asphalt ship from Shanghai for Kaohsiung on Feb. 20, according to the Chutian Metropolis Daily.

Vessels owned and operated by Datong are allowed to make port calls at Taiwan's three largest seaports -- Kaohsiung, Keelung and Hualien -- under an agreement on direct cross-strait shipping links that was sealed by Taiwan and China Nov. 4, 2008, the daily reported.
Direct cross-Taiwan Strait shipping links were inaugurated Dec. 15, 2008 in accordance with the agreement.

The launch of direct shipping links between Taiwan and China has helped cut transport time and operational costs for shippers, as vessels from both sides no longer have to pass through a third country en route to each other's ports.
Altogether, 63 Chinese seaports and 11 Taiwanese seaports are authorized to take part in the cross-strait shipping links under the agreement.

DOC.HEADLINE: The Executive Yuan deserves applause: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that the Executive Yuan deserves to be applauded for the timely policies it has launched to cope with the effects of the global financial crisis.

Ma made the remarks during a speech at the Kuomintang's (KMT's) Lunar New Year reception. The event was presided over by KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung, and was attended by dignitaries and party heavyweights, including Premier Liu Chao- shiuan, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and Economics Minister Yiin Chii- ming.

The president said that while it may have been somewhat "unfortunate" that his administration had to face rising oil, electricity and commodity prices and a global economic downturn as soon as it took office in May last year, these challenges can also serve as test of the government, which has taken a series of measures to cope with the problems.

"The efficacy of these measures is gradually emerging and even the foreign media has given a nod to our policies because we mitigated the external pressure by designing effective measures, which might help us to turn things around," Ma said.
"We should all applaud the Executive Yuan," he added.

Citing last month's shopping voucher program as an example of the Executive Yuan's hard work, the president said that the initiative has become the hottest topic over the past two months and indeed has had a strong positive effect on the economy as the distribution of the vouchers was timed just before the Chinese New Year.

"The effects of the shopping voucher program might be short-term, but at least every one was able to have a good Chinese New Year," Ma said. "The program was a humanitarian one and a response to public opinion."

Some 91 percent of eligible Taiwan citizens had picked up their NT$3, 600 (US$107) worth of vouchers by Jan. 18. The vouchers are the business end of an NT$85.7 billion program that is part of the government's economic stimulus package.

The president also praised the Executive Yuan for taking further steps to cope with the soaring unemployment rate right before the first working day after the Chinese New Year holiday, saying that the government is working non-stop to create more opportunities at a difficult time to improve people's lives.

More than 150,000 new jobs will be created this year to keep the annual jobless rate below 4.5 percent, Executive Yuan spokesman Su Jun-pin announced Sunday after an inter-ministerial brainstorming session aimed at pooling government resources to create more jobs amid the lingering global economic recession.
Speaking at the reception, Wu pledged that the KMT will offer full support to Ma and his administration, and urged every KMT member to join the battle against unemployment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumer confidence index hits new low in January: survey

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer confidence index for January slid 0.18 points to 48.95, its lowest level since National Central University's Research Center for Taiwan Economic Development (RCTED) began conducting the monthly surveys in 2001.

Although three of the survey's six sub-indices -- which reflect consumers' expectations of economic conditions over the next six months -- rose from the previous month's levels, the "job opportunities" category continued to slide, the pollsters said.

The sharpest drop recorded in January was in the category of "job opportunities, " which dived 6.95 points to 39.3, followed by the outlook for buying stocks in the first half of the year, which fell 1.5 points to 46.2, and the outlook for buying durable goods in the first six months of the year, which dropped 2.3 points to 82.9.
In the survey, a score of between 0-100 for a sub-index is classified as "pessimistic, " while a score of 100-200 is considered "optimistic, " according to the RCTED classification system.

The category of "price levels" registered the largest increase in January, up 5.65 points to 35.05, followed by "family economic conditions, " which rose 2.6 points to reach 46.3, and "domestic economic conditions over the next six months, " which rose 1.4 points to 43.95, according to the survey.
The survey was conducted by telephone among randomly selected adults aged 20 or older between Jan. 19-22, with a total of 2,214 valid samples collected.
It had a 95 percent confidence level and a margin of error of 2.1 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei city to provide training courses for the unemployed

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government will coordinate with the local service industry to provide professional training courses for the unemployed in order to ease the rapidly rising unemployment rate, Taipei City Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Monday.

Speaking at the Taipei City Government's Lunar New Year reception, Hau said that the government cannot ignore the fact that the worsening economic situation in the country has resulted in an escalation of the unemployment rate.
"Rather than giving fish to people in need, we want to give them the means to be self-sufficient by teaching them to fish," said Hau.

According to Hau, the Taipei City Government is planning to coordinate with labor-intensive local companies, especially the service industries, to provide the unemployed with professional training courses aimed at reintroducing them into the nation's workforce.
In addition, Hau said, Taipei City's Bureau of Labor and Department of Social Welfare will also provide assistance to low income families and the unemployed.

With the new school year about to start, the Taipei City Government will provide financial assistance through its Bureau of Education to low income families that cannot afford to pay tuition and lunch costs for their children, he promised.

Asked about an earlier proposal to distribute NT$5,000 in food vouchers to each of 10,000 families in March, Hau said that the City's Bureau of Civil affairs is currently engaged in an evaluation process to select eligible households.

"The food vouchers will be issued on March 1, once the social workers have finalized the selection process," said Hau, adding that the food voucher plan will at least give some temporary relief to low income families.

The Taipei City Government's food voucher plan came in the wake of a similar program implemented by the Kaohsiung City Government earlier this year. The Kaohsiung City Government issued NT$1,500 worth of food vouchers to each of 300 low-income families in January.

DOC.HEADLINE: Personnel changes possible at state oil, power companies: minister

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming indicated Monday that personnel changes may be on the cards for the state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) and Taiwan Power Company (Taipower), as his ministry decided last year to restructure the two companies.
Yiin, who made the remarks in response to reporters' questions after the Kuomintang's Lunar New Year reception, stressed that the plan, if implemented, would not target any specific individual.
He said the Ministry of Economic Affairs decided last year to restructure CPC and Taipower, and that a personnel reshuffle could be part of the process.

According to the local daily Liberty Times, the ministry will this year launch a "state-owned businesses reform program" that would involve a full-scale review of CPC and Taipower in areas such as company image, company culture, personnel, financial status and production process.
The ministry does not exclude the possibility of replacing the chairmen of the two companies, the report quoted Yiin as saying.

Stressing that organization reform usually includes cuts and changes in personnel, the top economic official said "what I meant by personnel reshuffle is this -- it would not target the chairmen in particular."

However, when asked to confirm the report that the chairmen of CPC and Taipower are likely to be replaced, Yiin said anything is possible, adding that he cannot disclose any more details since the reform program has not yet been fully developed.

As to whether he has already contacted any possible candidates for the chairmen positions, Yiin said he thinks that any restructuring should involve changes at the senior management level in general, rather than pinpoint the chairmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Labor council forecasts fast-growing unemployment rate

TEXT.P: Taiwan is likely to see a sharp rise in unemployment after the Chinese New Year holiday, Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Minister Wang Ju-hsuan said Monday.
Speaking at the CLA's Chinese New Year reception, Wang said that this year the economic slowdown and the unemployment rate will most likely worsen.
"Last year was bad, but this year it's only going to get worse," she forecast. "Amid the global economic downturn, public servants should do their best to help and serve the citizens of the nation."

According to Wang, public servants and officials hold a relatively stable job compared to people working in private companies, and are therefore the "lucky and happy ones who have been least affected by the recent economic downturn."

"It's hard to design a perfect plan to assist all those in need, and in these desperate times the public will complain about almost anything we do, " she said, urging that despite the public's complaints, government officials and public servants should not give up.

"I was a lawyer before I become a public servant, " said Wang, adding that she gave up the chance of making "tons of money" because there is nothing more meaningful in life than providing assistance to the needy.

Anticipating an increase in the number of people seeking jobs through the CLA after the Chinese New Year holiday, Wang said, she and her staff went to work early Monday to prepare to deal with the public.
"With things getting worse for the citizens of this country, we the government officials and public servants should never stop fighting for the welfare of our citizens," said Wang.
She gave the assurance that the CLA will continue to do its best to serve the public no matter how tough the situation becomes in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government should create jobs with `substantive meaning:' DPP chair

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Monday that the government should create job opportunities that have "substantive meaning" and are linked to the industrial structure rather than providing just short-term openings.

Tsai, who was greeting DPP staff on the first working day after the Lunar New Year holiday, made the remarks in response to reporters' questions on the government's latest measure to battle the soaring unemployment rate.

More than 150,000 new jobs will be created this year in an effort to keep the annual jobless rate below 4.5 percent from a high of 5.03 percent recorded in December 2008, Executive Yuan spokesman Su Jun-pin announced a day earlier after an inter-ministerial brainstorming session aimed at pooling government resources to create more jobs amid the global economic recession.

Of the projected new jobs, 120,000 to 140,000 openings will be created through the launch of public infrastructure construction projects while the public sector is also expected to offer 20,000-plus service jobs, according to the Executive Yuan.

In addition, the government will seek private enterprise cooperation in cutting the number of much cheaper foreign laborers in the hope that so doing would provide a further 30,000 jobs for local workers.
"Most of these jobs are short-term openings that do not have any substantive meaning and are as if they were social assistance, " Tsai contended.

"The government should create jobs that have substantive meaning. Spending big money on creating short-term jobs not only fails to address the problem but is also a waste of national resources, " she argued.
Noting that the DPP is obligated to point out problems to the government, Tsai predicted that the unemployment issue will severely impact social stability after the Lunar New Year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese birds seen threatening Taiwan endemic species

TEXT.P: Local wildlife conservationists have expressed growing concerns about an increase in the number of sightings in Taiwan of a wild bird species from China.

In a wetland forest in the eastern county of Taitung, the frequent sightings of a couple of garrulax canorus -- a Formosan hwamei, a species endemic to Taiwan, and a Chinese hwamei -- has caused worry among local bird watchers that mating of the two species may eventually compromise the pedigree of the Formosan hwamei.
The Formosan hwamei, also known as the melodious laughing-thrush, has been listed as an endemic species entitled to special protection.

A wild bird watcher, surnamed Chuang, said garrulax canorus cannot fly from the Chinese mainland to Taiwan and that the Chinese hwamei spotted in Taiwan's forests could have escaped from or been released by their owners.
Chuang said he was worried that the Chinese hwamei may have already mated with endemic Taiwan birds and produced offspring.

DOC.HEADLINE: Baseball legend arrives in Taiwan for visit

TEXT.P: Japan's "home-run king" of baseball Sadaharu Oh arrived in Taiwan Monday for a six-day visit.

During his stay, the baseball legend, who is of Chinese heritage and is known in Taiwan as Wang Chen-chih, will meet with President Ma Ying-jeou and visit the Cabinet-level Sports Affairs Council and the Chinese Taipei Baseball Association (CTBA) for talks on the development of local baseball.
Asked what he will say when he meets the president, Oh said he will tell Ma to keep up his good work.

Speaking of his health, the 69-year-old former manager of the Yomiuri Giants in Japan's professional baseball league, who underwent surgery in July 2006 to remove his stomach after being diagnosed with stomach cancer, said: "I am very well."

Oh is the son of a Chinese father and a Japanese mother and holds Republic of China citizenship. He set the world record for home runs at the professional level with a score of 868 before retiring from the Yomiuri Giants in 1980 at the age of 40.
He had planned to come to Taiwan last month at the CTBA's invitation but was forced to postpone the trip due to the death of his older brother.
Shortly after his arrival, Oh went to the Taoyuan County grave of the late founder of the Formosa Plastics Group, Wang Yung-ching, to pay his respects to his old friend.

Oh maintains a close relationship with Taiwan's baseball community and has contributed his services to the sport's development here. He enjoys the respect of baseball players and administrators all over the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA cuts back on value of gifts to foreign dignitaries: minister

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Francisco H. L. Ou said Monday that cooperation programs will serve as a more effective tool than gifts to strengthen Taiwan's relations with other countries.

Speaking after a Lunar New Year reception held by his ministry, Ou said that gifts should simply symbolize friendship with and respect for the recipient, and therefore "handing out high-priced presents" would not be an appropriate (foreign policy) approach.
"The money should be spent on cooperation initiatives instead, " he said.
According to a local media report, leaders of Taiwan's diplomatic allies often ask for expensive gifts such as diamonds, furniture and computers when they are on state visits to Taiwan.
To curb the practice of "money diplomacy, " President Ma Ying-joeu, after taking office last May, made it clear that the value of any gifts to foreign visitors should not exceed NT$5,000 (US$148).
Ou said that his ministry is following Ma's directive, but that in the past the MOFA did not have "much of a standard" regarding gifts.

Now, based on the guidelines it has been given, the MOFA selects gifts worth no more than NT$10,000 for president-level guests, NT5,000 for ministerial-level officials, and NT$3,000 for visitors at the deputy minister level, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC defends government's cross-strait policy

TEXT.P: Brushing off disapproval from some members of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Monday that the closer cross-Taiwan Strait ties since President Ma Ying- jeou was inaugurated last May do not jeopardize Taiwan's sovereignty.

On allegations by some DPP politicians that Ma's administration has tilted excessively toward China at the expense of Taiwan's sovereignty, the MAC said in a press release that it has always acted under the preconditions of safeguarding Taiwan's sovereignty and the interests of the people.
"Taiwan's cross-strait economic liberalization policies are aimed at improving Taiwan's investment environment and boosting the country's economic development," the press statement said.

"Our China policy has in no way put Taiwan's sovereignty at risk," said the MAC, adding that it will continue to conduct cross-strait policy with a view of creating a mutually beneficial outcome for both sides.

In addition, it reiterated its stance that the inauguration of direct cross- strait shipping links and the launch of expanded cross-strait air links last December do not symbolize Taiwan "paying tribute to the Chinese leadership," as some detractors have alleged.

The press release also emphasized that under the Constitution, Taiwan will pursue a policy of maintaining the cross-strait status quo, under which Taiwan will not seek unification or independence and will not foment war against China.
"The Taiwanese government will continue conducting its cross-strait policy that it believes is in tune with mainstream public opinion," the MAC said.
It further said that maintaining close dialogue and economic cooperation with China can help improve the cross-strait situation and lessen military and security concerns.

"By improving bilateral cross-strait relations, we have also been able to improve our ties with Japan and the United States, " said the MAC, adding that developing mutually beneficial economic ties with China is the centerpiece of the present Taiwan-China relations until such time as the two sides can discuss political issues.

Since President Ma Ying-jeou took office May 20 last year, his administration has prioritized the policy goals of restoring cross-strait talks and pursuing the normalization of cross-strait economic relations, said the MAC, adding that the government will continue to act on the principle of minimizing the threat and maximizing the advantage.

Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) held two rounds of high-level talks June 13 and Nov. 14 last year, in which they signed six agreements covering direct cross-strait charter flights, Chinese tourist visits to Taiwan, direct cross- strait air and sea cargo transport, postal cooperation and a food safety mechanism.
The SEF and ARATS are semi-official intermediary bodies responsible for cross-strait dealings in the absence of official contacts between the two sides. The MAC supervises SEF operations.
According to private sector estimates, the establishment of direct transport links can save Taiwan up to US$90 million per year in flight and shipping costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: More Taitung custard apples exported to China

TEXT.P: Fruit growers in the eastern county of Taitung were busy Monday packing 15 tons of pineapple custard apples, a variety of the fruit native to Taitung, for export to China.

A full container of the fruit was scheduled to be shipped from southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung Harbor bound for Guangzhou in southern China, taking advantage of the direct cross-Taiwan Strait shipping links that were opened last Dec. 15.

The Taitung Farmers Association has received orders from China for a total of 200 tons of pineapple custard apples, with deliveries scheduled to be made prior to the Lantern Festival, which falls on Feb. 9 this year and is a traditional holiday, so that sales are expected to boom, said association chief Lee Kun-ho.
Lee said exports of the fruit topped 1,200 tons between Dec. 1, 2008 and Jan. 31, representing a three-fold increase year-on-year.
The export markets included China, Singapore and Canada, with China taking the bulk of the shipments.
Lee said the fruit's high season is usually in the first and second months of the lunar calendar, with output averaging about 60 tons per week.
"Exports have contributed to easing a glut of the fruit on the domestic market," Lee noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait improvements make WHA issue easier to resolve: MOFA

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou said Monday that a high level of international support for Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Assembly (WHA) as an observer and the improvement in cross-Taiwan Strait relations should "make it easier to find a solution" to the issue.
Taiwan will also seek assistance from its diplomatic allies to boost the country's efforts to join the WHA -- the decision-making arm of the World Health Organization (WHO), he added.

Ou said that based on the responses of Chinese officials to Taiwan's attempts to seek international space on several occasions on which representatives from the two sides met, "we felt that the other side has shown more willingness to resolve the issue through cross-strait negotiations."
However, he went on, as no actual details have been discussed in the dialogues, it is still too early to say whether Taiwan will accept "Chinese Taipei" as the name for WHA representation.

Due to Beijing's obstruction, Taiwan has been barred from taking part in international organizations or activities that require statehood, including the United Nations and the U.N.-affiliated WHO and WHA.
President Ma Ying-jeou reiterated last November in a TV interview that securing observer status for Taiwan in the WHA was his administration's top diplomatic priority.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices flat on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices finished slightly higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 12.01 points, or 0.28 percent, to close at 4,259.98.
The local bourse opened at 4,277.10 and fluctuated between 4,285.12 and 4,240.08. A total of 2.40 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$50.35 billion (US$1.49 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 3.7 percent. Plastics and chemicals stocks surged 1.4 percent, machinery and electronics shares gained 1.3 percent, construction stocks advanced 0.9 percent, and paper and pulp issues increased 0.5 percent.
The other three major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff stocks losing the most at 3.4 percent. Banking and financial issues dropped 2.9 percent, and textile shares shed 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 889 to 626, with 219 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$317 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't seeking to create jobs for college graduates

TEXT.P: Creating job opportunities for higher- education graduates will be the government's top priority this year in its efforts to spur employment and to push the country's jobless rate below 4.5 percent, officials of the Cabinet- level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Monday.
To achieve that goal, the government will offer subsidies to enterprises to encourage them to employ large numbers of interns with college and university degrees, according to the officials.
Public agencies will also create more vacancies for positions such as research assistants, to provide work for university graduates in these hard economic times, the officials said.
Funding for the job-creation programs will come from the NT$500 billion (US$14.9 billion) special budget drawn up by the Executive Yuan for a four-year public works construction program, they said.

The Executive Yuan is set to approve the NT$500 billion program in its weekly meeting next week, and will submit the bill to the Legislative Yuan for screening as soon as the new legislative session opens.
Premier Liu Chao-shiuan presided over an inter-agency conference Sunday, the last day of the nine-day Lunar New Year holiday season, to find ways to curb the country's rising unemployment.

It was decided during the meeting that an additional NT$30 billion will be included in this year's budget to fund the upgrading of infrastructure, which would bring the total 2009 infrastructure budget to NT$130 billion and help create some 150,000 jobs.

Heads of government agencies, including the Ministry of Education and National Science Council, agreed to jointly make available thousands of research assistant jobs for qualified college and university graduates.
The government sector will also offer subsidies to private companies and ask them to provide training opportunities for internees with higher education.
Education Minister Cheng Jui-cheng said Monday that the precise number and type of projects will be made public after discussions with the National Science Council (NSC).
NSC Deputy Minister Chen Cheng-hung said later Monday that the council could create as many as 10,000 placements for part-time and full-time research assistants.

DOC.HEADLINE: Business sector responds to government's job-boost drive

TEXT.P: Eight major industrial and business groups voiced their support Monday for the administration's efforts to help generate over 150,000 new jobs this year in an effort to keep the country's annual jobless rate below 4.5 percent.

The groups, led by the National Association of Small and Medium Enterprises of the Republic of China, are scheduled to endorse Feb. 6 a campaign to respond to the government's job-boosting drive by calling upon private companies to keep their redundancy rates at under 1 percent.

Association chief Lin Ping-pin said some 1,000 members of the association are expected to take part in the endorsement, although he added that he has no idea yet exactly how many companies around Taiwan will step forward to support the low-redundancies call.

The industrial and business groups made the decision in response to an announcement by the Executive Yuan the previous day that it plans to pool government resources to create more jobs and alleviate the soaring unemployment rate amid the global economic recession.

Executive Yuan spokesman Su Jun-pin announced that the government's economic stimulus package for 2009 will be adjusted to increase public sector investment to NT$130 billion (US$3.88 billion) -- up from the original NT$100 billion -- and that the budget increase and adjustment of priority investment targets will generate more than 150,000 jobs this year, which in turn will help bring the unemployment rate down to below 4.5 percent from a high of 5.03 percent recorded in December 2008.
Meanwhile, Council of Labor Affairs Minister Wang Ju-hsuan warned that Taiwan is likely to see a sharp rise in unemployment after the Chinese New Year holiday.
"Last year was bad, but this year it's only going to get worse," Wang said, forecasting that the economic downturn and the jobless rate will most likely worsen this year compared to last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, falling NT$0.052 to close at NT$33.749.
A total of US$509 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.900 and fluctuated between NT$33.698 and NT$33.900.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were marginally higher Monday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for February advancing 26 points to end at 4,161, with 50,688 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for March gained 25 points to finish at 4,128, with 254 contracts traded, while June futures increased 23 points to end at 4,101, with 15 contracts traded.
September futures were up 20 points to close at 3,914, with 23 contract transactions, while December futures fell 12 points to end at 3,873, with eight contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 4,135 for February, 4,103 for March, 4,078 for June, 3,894 for September, and 3,885 for December.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index increased 12.01 points to finish at 4,259.98, on turnover of NT$50.35 billion (US$1.49 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

February TE futures gained 2.8 points to close at 165, with 3,666 contracts traded, while March TE futures advanced 0.6 points to finish at 164.15, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

February TF futures were down 9.6 points to close at 479.8, with 2,709 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures decreased 18.6 points to finish at 475, with six contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for the other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung seeking central government aid for construction projects

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu said Monday that she is seeking central government support for seven major construction projects in her southern port city, including extending the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit (MRT) system to neighboring counties.
Chen disclosed that she handed a letter to President Ma Ying-jeou Jan. 31 in which she urged the central government to help Kaohsiung with its construction projects.

The Kaohsiung MRT system has two lines. The 28.3-km Red Line has its northernmost station at Chiaotou in Kaohsiung County and ends at Linhai Industrial District in the south of the city, connecting with the Kaohsiung International Airport.
The east-west Orange Line is 14.4-km-long and runs from National Sun Yat-sen University in the west to Daliau in Kaohsiung County in the east.

In its 12 prioritized public construction projects, the central government has already included a plan to extend the Red Line further north to Lujhu township in Kaohsiung County, and the Orange Line further east to Pingtung County. The 12 projects would cost NT$3.99 trillion (US$122 billion) over eight years from 2009 to 2016.

Noting that the Cabinet is working on another plan to spend NT$500 billion (US$14.85 billion) over a four-year period on an expanded public construction program, Chen suggested that the Kaohsiung MRT system's extension plan and a Kaohsiung airport cargo transport system improvement plan be included in the central government's new program, so that Taiwan's second-largest city can have a full-fledged mass transport system.

Other major construction projects for which the mayor is seeking central government help include a plan to move all railway lines in Kaohsiung underground, a plan to build a pop music center in the Kaohsiung Harbor area, a proposed new highway to relieve the increased traffic caused by the High Speed Rail around the Zuoying district, and a plan to improve the access road system for the harbor.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Business as usual' on talks between U.S., China leaders: MOFA

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Francisco H. L. Ou said Monday that "we will adopt a `business as usual' attitude" toward a recent phone conversation between U.S. President Barack Obama and Chinese President Hu Jintao in which Taiwan was not mentioned.
Ou said Taiwan and the U.S. have enjoyed good relations since President Ma Ying- jeou assumed office last May, with mutual trust and smooth communication channels rebuilt between the two countries.

With positive cross-Taiwan Strait developments since Ma took office, Ou went on, his ministry has been focusing more on how to strengthen Taiwan-U.S. ties as well as how to further thaw cross-strait tensions rather than on whether Taiwan is mentioned in talks between the American and Chinese leaderships.
According to the White House, Obama phoned Hu last Friday and exchanged views on how to fight the current world economic crisis, among other issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shopping vouchers trigger travel wave around Taiwan during holiday

TEXT.P: The distribution of the government-issued shopping vouchers has proved successful in stimulating domestic consumption amid the recession, creating a NT$22.54 billion (US$668 million) domestic travel boom during the nine-day Lunar New Year holiday.

According to a statement released by the Tourism Bureau Monday, the number of sightseeing visits to tourist spots around Taiwan totaled 11.33 million between Lunar New Year's Day -- Jan. 26 -- and Feb. 1, the end of the holiday.
The figure represents a growth of 92 percent compared with the previous Lunar New Year holiday, which was only five days long, and a rise of 11.2 percent from the eight-day holiday in 2007.
The bureau said that most of the tours on offer around the island began between the third and fifth days of the holiday.

It estimated that some 2.26 million people visited tourist spots Thursday -- the fourth day of the holiday -- marking the highest daily figure in terms of the number of visits during the holiday, the statement said.

Bureau official Huang Ching-hui, who is responsible for domestic tourism affairs, said the most popular tourist spots were those that charged no entrance fee or that offered attractive discounts for visitors.
On average, 20 percent-30 percent of the income received by each tourist spot was generated by the shopping vouchers, Huang noted.
According to Tourism Bureau statistics, the low-priced or free attractions drew nearly 9.78 million visits during the holiday period.
The 23 major amusement parks around Taiwan, meanwhile, attracted some 850,000 visitors last week, representing a 54 percent increase from the same period of 2008.
The parks generated total revenues of NT$510 million during the Jan. 26-Feb. 1 period, marking a year-on-year growth of 38 percent.

The bureau attributed the growth to discount packages for visitors, as well as the shopping vouchers that the government distributed to every citizen around the country before the Lunar New Year holiday as part of efforts to stimulate domestic spending.

Around 27 percent of the average spending at the amusement parks during the holiday was in the form of shopping vouchers, the bureau went on, adding that 75 percent of the turnover at the Yeliou Ocean World on the northeastern coast was generated on the back of the shopping vouchers, thanks to the park's offer of privileged treatment for shopping voucher spenders.

In the various hot spring resorts around the country, the bureau estimated that hostel and hotel occupancy reached 85 percent-90 percent last week and that the hot spring sector generated revenue of NT$1.25 billion during the holiday, marking a rise of 7 percent year on year.

Tourist numbers were also boosted by 509 tour groups comprising 13,400 tourists from China that visited Taiwan during the holiday, according to the bureau, which added that the most popular tourist spots among the Chinese tourists were Sun Moon Lake in Nantou County, central Taiwan, and Alishan in southern Chiayi County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Environmental group to set up gene bank of native water plants

TEXT.P: A Taipei County-based environmental protection association promoted a project to establish Taiwan's first gene bank of native aquatic and wetland plants in the county's Wugu township by holding an ecological tour of the area Sunday.

The Taipei County Sustainable and Environmental Development Association floated the concept of setting up a gene bank of this type in line with the theme for World Wetlands Day 2009 -- Upstream- Downstream: Wetlands Connect Us All -- according to association President Chen Mu-cheng.

Chen said the association hopes the establishment of the gene bank will help arouse public awareness of the fact that Taiwan's aquatic plants are fast- disappearing and help increase people's understanding of the relationship between wetlands and humans.
The ecology tour of the Chunyuan Wetland -- the proposed site of the gene bank -- was attended by representatives of nine ecology conservation groups, Chen said.

Hsu Yuan-tai, a professor at National Taiwan University's Biodiversity Research Center, said there is a need for such a gene bank, as many indigenous aquatic plants are at risk due to habitat loss triggered by changes in land use and extensive use of insecticides and pesticides, as well as the intrusion of alien water plant species.

The gene bank will be used not only for the collection and conservation of a wide variety of endangered native water and wetland plant species but also for the cultivation of many other native aquatic plants.

In the future, workshops will be set up to train professionals in the sphere of ecological management and a series of courses on wetlands will be launched to educate the public on the importance of wetland protection.

DOC.HEADLINE: Job seekers swarm employment service centers around Taiwan

TEXT.P: Government-operated employment service centers around the country were packed by job seekers Monday, the first workday after the Lunar New Year holiday that began on Jan. 25.
In the Taoyuan City center, more than 1,200 unemployed submitted their applications for government unemployment benefits while over 700 of them also applied for jobs.
Over 100 people lined up outside the center before it opened Monday morning, with many of them workers who were laid off by a big computer manufacturer just two days before Lunar New Year's Eve.
One of those waiting on line to apply for unemployment benefits was a 41-year- old mother surnamed Lin, who holds a bachelor's degree in tourism.

Lin complained she was laid off without any warning and could not accept being fired because the only explanation given her by the company was that she was no longer suitable for the position she held.

Noting that many senior workers at the same company were also laid off, Lin speculated that the company's strategy was to first get rid of high-paid employees under the pretext of operational difficulties amid the recession, and then hire new workers through the government's employment incentives program.
The workers could not do anything to stop the scheme, she said, sighing "that's life."
Similar long lines of job seekers were also observed Monday at unemployment service centers in Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties in southern Taiwan, and Taipei County in the north.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourists inject NT$850 million into economy

TEXT.P: Some 13,400 Chinese visitors contributed NT$850 million (US$25.3 million) to Taiwan's economy over the Lunar New Year holiday period from Jan. 26 - Feb. 1, the Tourism Bureau reported Monday.
Bureau officials estimated that the Chinese tourists, scattered among 509 tour groups, spent NT$9,000 per day during their average 7-day stays.
Most of the Chinese tourists were from Guangdong province and the cities of Beijing and Shanghai, bureau statistics showed.
It was the first time that most Chinese tourists could spend their Lunar New Year holiday in Taiwan, thanks to tourism opening measures adopted last year by the governments on both sides.

Over 3,000 Chinese tourists arrived in Taiwan Jan. 26 on Lunar New Year's Day, reaching the daily target of 3,000 persons set by the bureau for the first time since more Chinese were allowed to arrive in Taiwan in mid-July.

Sun Moon Lake in central Taiwan's Nantou County and the Alishan Mountain resort in southern Taiwan's Chiayi County were the most popular attractions, drawing 12,647 and 10,690 Chinese visitors, respectively.
Hualien County in eastern Taiwan and Kending in southern Taiwan's Pingtung County were also popular among Chinese tourists, bureau officials said.
A woman identified by the surname Chang praised Taiwan as "small and beautiful" and hailed the hospitality of Taiwan's people and the scenery along the country's northeastern coast.

Hung Wen-neng, chief of Nantou County's tourism bureau, said that while Sun Moon Lake was widely visited by the Chinese visitors, most did not spend the night in the area or in the county because hotel rooms in the county had already been booked by Taiwanese tourists.
He said most local businesses in the county benefited little from the short stays of the Chinese tour groups, at most earning NT$150 to NT$300 per person for a meal or a boat ride on the lake.
The major challenge for the county now, Hung said, is how to craft in-depth travel itineraries to lure Chinese tourists throughout the entire year, not just during the Lunar New Year holidays.

He noted, however, that the number of Taiwanese visitors to the Sun Moon Lake area grew markedly during this year's Lunar New Year holiday compared to previous years, and attributed the growth to the longer nine-day holiday period, the distribution of shopping vouchers and falling gasoline prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008-2009 Taiwan Hakka Exposition draws 500,000 visitors

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Hakka Exposition being held at the Taipei County Hakka Museum in Sansia Township has attracted more than half a million visitors since its opening Dec. 27, according to the event's organizer, the Cabinet-level Council for Hakka Affairs.
Officials at the council pointed out Monday that the more than 500,000 people included 230,000 who visited the expo during the Lunar New Year holiday.
The officials said they expect more large crowds to visit the show before it ends Feb. 15, as the final two weeks coincides with the Lantern Festival and Valentine's Day.
They added that there will be special festivities over the next two weekends to allow visitors to celebrate the two special occasions at the showground.

The event is a showcase of all aspects of life of the Hakka people, one of Taiwan's largest sub-ethnic groups, including their culture, history and way of life. The Hakkas account for about 15 percent of Taiwan's 23 million people.

The expo includes an exhibition of photos, some of which date back to the Qing dynasty, to tell the stories of the Hakka people's migration from China to Taiwan, their culture and way of life. Other exhibits include their traditional costumes and various publications regarding Hakka history and the Hakka dialect.
Other related activities include a Hakka film festival, daily concerts and stage performances by Hakka artists.

Visitors can savor Hakka cuisine in a food court catered by 20 selected Hakka restaurants from around Taiwan. They can also buy farm produce, specialty products, handicrafts and other souvenirs from well-known Hakka businesses and farmers's associations from around Taiwan.
The Hakka Museum in Sansia is open Tuesdays to Fridays from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. and Saturdays and Sundays from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. Entry to the exposition is free.
Free shuttle bus services to the museum are available from nearby Yingge Railway Station, as well as three of Taipei's MRT stations -- Banciao, Yongning and Jingan.

The Hakkas are a unique ethnic group of Han Chinese, who originally lived in central China but gradually migrated south during different dynasties and settled in Jiangxi, Fujian and Guangdong provinces to flee from war and famine.
They were called Hakka, which literally means "guest families," by the locals when they first settled in.
The Hakka are conservative in keeping their cultural traditions. One of their outstanding characteristics is that they are willing to venture into other parts of the world to establish themselves.
During the last hundred years, the Hakka have migrated to countries in Southeast Asia, East Africa, Europe and North and South America. EDNITEM/ls

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH calls for vigilance against influenza

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) on Monday urged the public to be wary of influenza, saying that it was still the high season for the virus.
According to statistics from the DOH's Centers for Disease Control (CDC), the number of parainfluenza cases increased during the Chinese New Year holiday.

The CDC noted that more than 150 medical institutions provided emergency medical services during the nine-day holiday that ended Sunday and that on the first day of the Lunar New Year, which fell on Jan. 26, 28,000 people sought emergency treatment.
The number surged to 32,000 on Jan. 27, and another 27,000 people sought emergency treatment on Jan. 28, the CDC said.

CDC Deputy Director General Chou Jih-haw said that local people traditionally refrain from visiting hospitals unless absolutely necessary, and those who sought medical treatment are mostly cases of acute gastroenteritis and influenza.

Chou said individuals suffering from parainfluenza who sought emergency treatment accounted for 33 percent of the total number of people visiting emergency wards, significantly higher than the 23 percent during the same period last year.
Chou called for the public to be on guard, especially after they return to their posts and work in closed office spaces.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education coupons in the works to help lower joblessness: CEPD

TEXT.P: The country's top economic planning agency came up with a plan Monday to help reduce the unemployment rate among highly educated citizens by issuing education coupons for them to return to school to refresh their minds and study.

Chen Tain-jy, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said the plan is aimed at helping at least 100,000 unemployed tertiary academic degree holders return to schools for various study programs or to teach at vocational schools.
Taiwan's jobless rate soared to a high of 5.03 percent last December, with 549,000 people out of work, according to government statistics.

Worse still, Chen said, about 220,000 of the unemployed were university graduates and those with even higher academic degrees. Moreover, many of them were high-tech professionals with rich working experience.

Under the CEPD-drafted plan, the government will issue education coupons for highly educated unemployed people to return to schools to attend specially designed study programs, Chen said, adding that the plan will span no more than two years at an estimated cost of NT$20 billion (US$597 million).

The funds needed for the education coupon plan will come from a special economic stimulus package under which the government will inject NT$500 billion over the next four years into public construction projects, Chen explained.

Under the plan, new college graduates will be advised to remain in school to undertake vocational or job-related research projects. In addition, Chen said, the government will arrange for new graduates to join internship programs at private corporations.

Even though Taiwan has not been spared by the global economic downturn, Chen said, some local companies are still faring fairly well. "We'll seek their cooperation to offer internship openings for new graduates," he added.

According to Chen, the Ministry of Education is working on regulations governing qualifications to enjoy education coupon benefits. Basically, he said, the government will offer full subsidies for qualified recipients to undertake study programs, but will set a ceiling for the amount an individual recipient can receive.
Chen further said the Executive Yuan is expected to approve the plan next week. "And the CEPD looks forward to seeing the education coupon plan launched in the first half of this year," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Grand pardon' offered to China-based Taiwan businessmen

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on Monday eased penalties on Taiwanese businesses with unapproved investments in China, saying it would impose only the minimum fine on most violators if they reported their unlawful investment and made new investments at home.
The newly modified regulations generally treat all violators indiscriminantly, regardless of the scale of their investment in China, if they invested money there before March 10, 2008.
The businesses must also meet the two conditions and must not have invested in product categories "banned" by Taiwan's authorities to be eligible for the minimum fine.

Businesses that made unreported investments in China after March 10, 2008, will be fined depending on the size of investment. Still, the rule change will treat them more leniently than under revisions to the regulations made by the previous government on that day, MOEA officials said.

The major aim of the change is to encourage Taiwanese businessmen to return home by removing the possibility of being assessed potentially onerous fines, and generate new investment in the domestic market in the process.
In response to the MOEA's announcement, some Taiwanese businessmen operating in China contended that the ministry's overture was not "very meaningful."
Chuang Fu-chih, chairman of the Taiwan businessmen's association in Fuzhou City, Fujian province, said only a sound investment climate would lure Taiwanese businesspeople back home.
"Businessmen should not be punished for their investment in China, because it is a misguided policy, " he said. "Moreover, the number of violators is low."

DOC.HEADLINE: 79 companies approved to invest in Kaohsiung Software Park in 2008

TEXT.P: The Export Processing Zone Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Monday it granted permission to 79 companies to set up shop in the Kaohsiung Software Technology Park in 2008, with a combined investment of NT$2.27 billion (US$67.19 million).

Administration officials said they will continue to invite more software companies to move into the park to help strengthen its identity as a unique venue for research and development in creative technology industries.

They pointed out that the most prominent of the 79 companies that received the green light to move into the park is the Hon Hai Group, whose chairman, Terry Gou, has promised to invest at least NT$1 billion to create 3,000 jobs for software engineers in five years.
Hon Hai, which has had people man its office in the software park since October last year, has set a target of hiring 500 software engineers by May this year.

According to the officials, the Institute for Information Industry -- a nongovernment organization -- also moved into the Kaohsiung Software Technology Park, with a plan to invest NT$400 million (US$11.85 million) over five years to set up a technology incubation center.

A 40-strong staff from two of the institute's departments -- the Innovative Digitech-Enabled Applications and Services and the Southern Information Service -- will man its office in the software park in the initial stage.
By the end of 2009, the institute's workforce in the park will be increased to more than 65 people.

The officials said that the presence of the institute is expected to draw more software companies to use the park as its development base, which will help strike a balance between northern and southern Taiwan in terms of technological development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of people applying for unemployment benefits soars

TEXT.P: The number of people applying for unemployment benefits on the first workday following the Lunar New Year holiday was 30 times as high as last year, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Monday.

The CLA has initially estimated that the number confirmed to be eligible for unemployment subsidies at 11 major employment service centers across Taiwan Monday totaled 12,854, compared with only 441 last year.
The centers were reportedly inundated with 16,000 people, with some seeking jobs but the vast majority applying for unemployment benefits.
With the long lines, some centers had to extend their service hours, a CLA official said.
The official attributed the sharp increase in the number to the long nine-day new year's holiday and the seriousness of Taiwan's unemployment problem.
The jobless rate stood at 5.03 percent at the end of December, the highest level in Taiwan since October 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: Defense ministry announces high-level military reshuffle

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) announced a high-level military reshuffle Monday, with Deputy Defense Minister Adm. Lin Chen-yi promoted to the post of chief of the General Staff.

Lin, a graduate of the country's naval academy who rose through the ranks of the Navy to reach its top office before assuming his current post, will fill the position to be vacated by Gen. Hou Shou-yeh, who has been tapped to serve as a strategic adviser to President Ma Ying-jeou.
Meanwhile, Army Commanding General Chao Shih-chang will succeed Lin as deputy defense minister.
The post to be vacated by Chao will be filled by Yang Tien-hsiao, incumbent head of the MND's General Political Warfare Bureau.
According to an MND statement, all personnel changes will take effect Feb. 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Tuesday, moving up 40.58 points at 4,300.56 on a turnover of NT$1.44 billion (US$42.67 million).
The weighted price index gained 12.01 points, or 0.28 percent, to close at 4,259.98 Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was lower against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Tuesday.
The greenback was trading at NT$33.667 at 9:30 a.m. on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.082 from Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 3, or the ninth day of the first month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1468: Johann Gutenberg, a German goldsmith who developed the letterpress printing method and oil-based inks, dies in obscurity. His "Mazarin Bible" (1455) is believed to be the first book printed with such type.
1488: Portuguese explorer Bartolomeu Diaz, after rounding the Cape of Good Hope, lands on Africa's eastern coast. He is the first European to land on African soil.
1830: Greece is declared independent under the protection of Britain, France, and Russia at a London conference.
1867: Prince Mutsuhito becomes Emperor Meiji at the age of 14. His reign in Japan lasted until 1912.
1913: The 16th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution is ratified, giving the government the power to impose and collect taxes on income.
1919: The League of Nations holds its first meeting in Paris with U.S. President Woodrow Wilson presiding.
1924: Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president of the United States and winner of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1919, dies at the age of 67.
1930: Ho Chi Minh establishes the Vietnamese Communist Party in Hong Kong.
1931: An earthquake jolts Hawks Bay in New Zealand, killing 256 people.
1943: British bombers pound the German city of Hamburg.
1945: U.S. troops recover Manila in the Philippines from Japanese forces during World War II.
1960: British Prime Minister Harold Macmillan tells the astonished white politicians in the Cape Town parliament that they should accept racial equality.
1966: The unmanned Soviet spaceship Luna IX lands on the moon and sends signals back to Earth.
1969: Yasser Arafat is elected as the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1973: Fighting in Vietnam comes to a halt when a cease-fire goes into effect.
1974: Dr. Arthur A. Kimball, director of the International Training Section of the U.S. Agency for International Development, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The Indian Ocean satellite communications ground station in Taiwan begins operations, providing improved telephone service to Europe and Africa.
1974: The ROC's agricultural technical cooperation with Honduras is extended for two years.
1977: China Steel Corp.'s Kaohsiung mill begins operations.
1978: The European Economic Community and Communist China initial their first trade agreement.
1989: P.W. Botha resigns as chief of South Africa's ruling party.
1989: A military coup topples strongman Alfredo Stroessner in Paraguay, ending his eight successive presidential terms and 35 years of rule.
1992: A fight breaks out in a camp for Vietnamese boat refugees in Hong Kong, resulting in 18 deaths.
1994: U.S. President Bill Clinton announces the lifting of the United States' trade embargo against Vietnam.
1996: An earthquake rocks Lijiang in southwestern China, killing more than 302 people.
2000: An A300-600R airbus of China Airlines, carrying 225 passengers, departs Taipei for Manila, formally resuming direct air links between Taiwan and the Philippines after they had been suspended for four months.
2001: One hundred and fifty practitioners and supporters of Zhong Gong, a form of Chinese kung fu which emphasizes the use of inner strength to toughen one's body, stage a parade around Guam to call for the release of founder Zhang Hongbao.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Living upon the poorest fare with cold water for drink and with my bent arms for a pillow, I could yet find pleasure in such a life, whereas riches and honors acquired through the sacrifice of what is right would be to me as unreal as a mirage."
