DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative speaker leaves for Europe

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng departed late Monday for a 10-day visit to Europe during which he will address the European Parliament, which is holding its plenary session in Strasbourg, France.
Wang is also expected to call on European Parliament President Hans-Gert Pottering.
The trip will also take Wang to Belgium and Italy, where he will meet with parliamentary leaders of those two nations, and to the Holy See, where he will meet with Pope Benedict XVI.

DOC.HEADLINE: 79 companies approved to invest in Kaohsiung Software Park in 2008

TEXT.P: The Export Processing Zone Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Monday it granted permission to 79 companies to set up shop in the Kaohsiung Software Technology Park in 2008, with a combined investment of NT$2.27 billion (US$67.19 million).

Administration officials said they will continue to invite more software companies to move into the park to help strengthen its identity as a unique venue for research and development in creative technology industries.

They pointed out that the most prominent of the 79 companies that received the green light to move into the park is the Hon Hai Group, whose chairman, Terry Gou, has promised to invest at least NT$1 billion to create 3,000 jobs for software engineers in five years.
Hon Hai, which has had people man its office in the software park since October last year, has set a target of hiring 500 software engineers by May this year.

According to the officials, the Institute for Information Industry -- a nongovernment organization -- also moved into the Kaohsiung Software Technology Park, with a plan to invest NT$400 million (US$11.85 million) over five years to set up a technology incubation center.

A 40-strong staff from two of the institute's departments -- the Innovative Digitech-Enabled Applications and Services and the Southern Information Service -- will man its office in the software park in the initial stage.
By the end of 2009, the institute's workforce in the park will be increased to more than 65 people.

The officials said that the presence of the institute is expected to draw more software companies to use the park as its development base, which will help strike a balance between northern and southern Taiwan in terms of technological development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education coupons in the works to help lower joblessness: CEPD

TEXT.P: The country's top economic planning agency came up with a plan Monday to help reduce the unemployment rate among highly educated citizens by issuing education coupons for them to return to school to refresh their minds and study.

Chen Tain-jy, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said the plan is aimed at helping at least 100,000 unemployed tertiary academic degree holders return to schools for various study programs or to teach at vocational schools.
Taiwan's jobless rate soared to a high of 5.03 percent last December, with 549,000 people out of work, according to government statistics.

Worse still, Chen said, about 220,000 of the unemployed were university graduates and those with even higher academic degrees. Moreover, many of them were high-tech professionals with rich working experience.

Under the CEPD-drafted plan, the government will issue education coupons for highly educated unemployed people to return to schools to attend specially designed study programs, Chen said, adding that the plan will span no more than two years at an estimated cost of NT$20 billion (US$597 million).

The funds needed for the education coupon plan will come from a special economic stimulus package under which the government will inject NT$500 billion over the next four years into public construction projects, Chen explained.

Under the plan, new college graduates will be advised to remain in school to undertake vocational or job-related research projects. In addition, Chen said, the government will arrange for new graduates to join internship programs at private corporations.

Even though Taiwan has not been spared by the global economic downturn, Chen said, some local companies are still faring fairly well. "We'll seek their cooperation to offer internship openings for new graduates," he added.

According to Chen, the Ministry of Education is working on regulations governing qualifications to enjoy education coupon benefits. Basically, he said, the government will offer full subsidies for qualified recipients to undertake study programs, but will set a ceiling for the amount an individual recipient can receive.
Chen further said the Executive Yuan is expected to approve the plan next week. "And the CEPD looks forward to seeing the education coupon plan launched in the first half of this year," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Grand pardon' offered to China-based Taiwan businessmen

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on Monday eased penalties on Taiwanese businesses with unapproved investments in China, saying it would impose only the minimum fine on most violators if they reported their unlawful investment and made new investments at home.
The newly modified regulations generally treat all violators indiscriminantly, regardless of the scale of their investment in China, if they invested money there before March 10, 2008.
The businesses must also meet the two conditions and must not have invested in product categories "banned" by Taiwan's authorities to be eligible for the minimum fine.

Businesses that made unreported investments in China after March 10, 2008, will be fined depending on the size of investment. Still, the rule change will treat them more leniently than under revisions to the regulations made by the previous government on that day, MOEA officials said.

The major aim of the change is to encourage Taiwanese businessmen to return home by removing the possibility of being assessed potentially onerous fines, and generate new investment in the domestic market in the process.
In response to the MOEA's announcement, some Taiwanese businessmen operating in China contended that the ministry's overture was not "very meaningful."
Chuang Fu-chih, chairman of the Taiwan businessmen's association in Fuzhou City, Fujian province, said only a sound investment climate would lure Taiwanese businesspeople back home.
"Businessmen should not be punished for their investment in China, because it is a misguided policy, " he said. "Moreover, the number of violators is low."

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of people applying for unemployment benefits soars

TEXT.P: The number of people applying for unemployment benefits on the first workday following the Lunar New Year holiday was 30 times as high as last year, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Monday.

The CLA has initially estimated that the number confirmed to be eligible for unemployment subsidies at 11 major employment service centers across Taiwan Monday totaled 12,854, compared with only 441 last year.
The centers were reportedly inundated with 16,000 people, with some seeking jobs but the vast majority applying for unemployment benefits.
With the long lines, some centers had to extend their service hours, a CLA official said.
The official attributed the sharp increase in the number to the long nine-day new year's holiday and the seriousness of Taiwan's unemployment problem.
The jobless rate stood at 5.03 percent at the end of December, the highest level in Taiwan since October 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: Defense ministry announces high-level military reshuffle

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) announced a high-level military reshuffle Monday, with Deputy Defense Minister Adm. Lin Chen-yi promoted to the post of chief of the General Staff.

Lin, a graduate of the country's naval academy who rose through the ranks of the Navy to reach its top office before assuming his current post, will fill the position to be vacated by Gen. Hou Shou-yeh, who has been tapped to serve as a strategic adviser to President Ma Ying-jeou.
Meanwhile, Army Commanding General Chao Shih-chang will succeed Lin as deputy defense minister.
The post to be vacated by Chao will be filled by Yang Tien-hsiao, incumbent head of the MND's General Political Warfare Bureau.
According to an MND statement, all personnel changes will take effect Feb. 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
President names envoy to attend St. Lucia independence celebration

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has named Judicial Yuan President Lai In-jaw as his special envoy to attend the 30th Independence Day celebration of St. Lucia, one of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in the Caribbean, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.

Speaking at a press briefing, Diego Chou, deputy director-general of MOFA's Department of Central and South American Affairs, said the delegation that will attend the Feb. 22 celebration will include Deputy Foreign Minister Javier C.S. Hou and is slated to depart for St. Lucia Feb. 19.
According to the ministry, Lai will be the highest official from Taiwan to visit the Caribbean island nation since the two countries restored diplomatic links in April 2007.
St. Lucia established official relations with Taiwan in 1984 but the friendship was terminated in 1997 when St. Lucia's government at the time switched diplomatic recognition to China.

Since the resumption of diplomatic ties between Taiwan and St. Lucia 10 years later, the two countries have launched a series of cooperation programs that include public construction, academic exchanges and tourism, the ministry said.
A psychiatry hospital for which Taiwan provided funding is also expected to begin operating in the Caribbean nation later this year, according to the MOFA.

First named by Columbus, who sighted the island on St. Lucy's day in 1502, St. Lucia has changed hands many times. Independence for the tiny island state was achieved in 1979 from the United Kingdom and is commemorated with parades across the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: NGOs to participate in 2009 Taipei International Book Exhibition

TEXT.P: A group of local non-government organizations (NGOs) announced Tuesday that they will participate in the 2009 Taipei International Book Exhibition (TIBE) to share their ideals and values with the public.

The Taiwan Labor Front (TLF), the Green Formosa Front, the Legal Aid Foundation, the Taiwan Thinktank, and various other local NGOs will take part in this year's TIBE under the collective name "Taiwan NGOs," a TLF representative said.

According to the TLF, the NGOs will present a wide variety of topics, including law, the environment, labor, democracy, human rights, financial justice and other social issues in the form of books, CDs, DVDs and T-shirts.

"This is the third time we have participated in the TIBE, " said the representative, adding that through the participation in Taipei's annual book fair during the past three years, the NGOs have had close contact and interaction with people from different sectors of society.
"Most of the people that we have had contact with did not previously entirely understand the purpose and functions that NGOs have in our society, " said the representative.
He added that after being introduced to their work, the public has shown great support in what the NGOs are trying to do for society.

"According to our past experiences, the public is not simply indifferent to certain social issues, " he went on, adding that most members of the public do not show concern for many social issues due to a lack of information and knowledge.
The representative thanked the Cabinet-level Government Information Office for providing the low-budget local NGOs with a free booth at this year's TIBE.
The TIBE will take place Feb. 4-9, with around 2,000 booths and over 300 forums, book-signing events, musical performances and other activities to be held during the six-day event.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education coupon plan to be flexible: CEPD

TEXT.P: A plan to help reduce unemployment among white collar workers by issuing education coupons that will subsidize their return to school so they can upgrade their qualifications and increase their competitiveness will remain as flexible as possible, the country's top economic planning agency said Tuesday.

Liao Yao-tsung, chief secretary of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , said the two-year plan, which is estimated to cost NT$20 billion (US$525 million) and is expected to be approved by the Executive Yuan next week, is designed exclusively for highly educated white collar workers who have lost their jobs during the recent economic downturn.

"We welcome colleges, universities and other private establishments to design courses for these degree holders wishing to return to school," said Liao, adding that the education coupons will not be distributed until the proposed classes have passed an evaluation process.
According to Liao, the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) launched a similar employment and vocational training plan in 2005, which achieved results that were better than expected.

"Although the CLA's plan targets individuals who are already in the workforce instead of unemployed highly educated white collar workers, the education coupons plan will use it as a reference, " said Liao.

In addition, Liao went on, the classes that will be provided under the new plan will be similar to those offered by the vocational training plan and will include subjects such as information technology, foreign language, management, professional skills, innovation and professional development.

CLA officials said that same day that the council does not rule out the possibility of pushing for the integration of the two plans once the framework of the CEPD plan has been drawn up, adding that integration could be more beneficial to the public and more cost-effective for the government.

According to government statistics, the jobless rate increased to a high of 5.03 percent last December, with 549,000 people out of work, about 220,000 of whom were university graduates or higher in terms of education and experience.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former first lady's friends plead guilty to money laundering

TEXT.P: Two friends of former first lady Wu Shu-jen pleaded guilty to helping Wu launder ill-gotten gains, as the Taipei District Court on Tuesday continued its trial of corruption and money laundering cases involving the former first family.

Tsai Ming-che and Tsai Ming-chieh are among the names on a long list of intermediaries allegedly used by Wu to wire and secretly stash huge sums of money overseas. They are both the brothers of Tsai Mei-li, a former classmate of the former first lady, who also allegedly played a role in the money-laundering schemes.

The plea by Tsai Ming-che and Tsai Ming-chieh followed a similar one by Wu Shu- jen's son Chen Chih-chung, daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching and elder brother Wu Ching-mao during the last court session held Jan. 21.

Prosecutors probing the cases found that Tsai Ming-che allegedly helped the former first family solicit bribes and lined his own pockets with a portion of the money in a land deal between the government-run Hsinchu Science Park and Dayu Development Corp. -- a subsidiary under the Koo Group.

While the former first family allegedly received NT$300 million (US$8.96 million) in kickbacks from a total payoff of NT$400 million by Taiwan Cement Group Chairman Leslie C. Koo, Tsai Ming-che obtained NT$70 million. The rest of the bribe allegedly went to James Lee, then-chief of the Hsinchu Science Park Administration.

As Tsai Ming-che confessed his role in the case and offered, while being questioned by prosecutors, to turn all the illicit funds, the prosecutors in their Dec. 12 indictment recommended that he be given a light sentence or set free.
The prosecutors also asked the court to be lenient on Tsai Ming-chieh.
Former President Chen Shui-bian and his wife are accused of siphoning off NT$104 million from a special Presidential Office discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000 to May 2008.

In addition to accepting bribes worth a total of NT$300 million in connection with the land procurement deal, they are also charged with receiving another NT$90.93 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project.
The couple is still being probed on suspicion of helping several financial conglomerates acquire financial holding companies in return for "political contributions."

DOC.HEADLINE: Shopping voucher plan boosts sales in Taipei City

TEXT.P: The positive effects of a government-initiated shopping voucher program to spur domestic consumption are becoming apparent in Taipei City, as the number of people entering a prize draw that is tied to voucher spending broke the 100,000 mark, according to figures released Tuesday by the city's Department of Economic Development.

The statistics show that more than NT$200 million worth of vouchers has been used by people who registered to participate in the draw held by the city, with each shopper spending NT$1,800 on average, Liu Chia-chun, a department official said Tuesday.

The draw, which is aimed at encouraging spending and creating a multiplier effect of the shopping voucher plan, allows consumers who spend NT$300 or more in vouchers to compete for a wide range of prizes, Liu added.
Meanwhile, more than 1,000 franchise stores in the city are offering special deals to voucher spenders, Liu said.

According to the official, sales in various commercial districts in the city during just before the Chinese Year holiday increased an average 20-30 percent. In the Bade commercial circle, a market dedicated to computers, communications and consumer electronics products, the increase in sales was 40 percent, he added.
Thousands of prizes were given out during the first round of the draw, and many more, including a sedan car valued at NT$600,000, will be up for grabs during the next round on March 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet submits administrative guidelines to legislature

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has submitted its 2009 administrative guidelines to the Legislative Yuan for consideration before the next legislative session opens Feb. 20, a Cabinet official said Tuesday.

The goals of the guidelines are to enhance the country's competitiveness, expand care for disadvantaged groups, ensure energy and food security, and listen to the voice of the people, the official said.
According to the guidelines, the government will work to rebuild Taiwan's national competitiveness through deregulation and making inroads into the global market.

It will also move to improve relations with China, push for regulatory relaxation and tax reforms, increase investment, expand the implementation of public construction projects and raise the integrity, competency and efficiency of the government.
The government will push the use of bio-fuel vehicles by offering incentives to encourage taxi drivers to remodel or purchase vehicles that can run on both liquefied petroleum gas and gasoline.
It will also promote electric scooters and energy-efficient light bulbs, and will work to rejuvenate fallow land to increase rice stocks.

Reviewing the effect of education reforms, helping youths to bridge the gap between education and employment, and promoting cooperation between business and academic circles are also major points in the guidelines.
Premier Liu Chao-shiuan is slated to give a policy report Feb. 20 at the Legislative Yuan to provide further details of the guidelines.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices surged Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 112.83 points, or 2.64 percent, to close at 4,372.81.

Posting a gain for the second consecutive day, the local bourse opened higher at 4,300.56 and fluctuated between 4,389.87 and 4,295.26. A total of 2.92 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$59.59 billion (US$1.77 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 5.6 percent. Construction stocks gained 4.4 percent, banking and financial shares advanced 3.2 percent, foodstuff shares and machinery and electronics issues both rose 2.7 percent, textile stocks rose 1.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares gained 1.3 percent, and paper and pulp issues rose 1.0 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,419 to 210, with 133 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$1.08 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Job bank, local borough chiefs work to help job seekers

TEXT.P: With the ranks of the unemployed swelling after the nine-day Lunar New Year holiday, an online manpower services provider said Tuesday that it will work with nearly 8,000 borough chiefs around the country to help job seekers put their resumes online.

The borough chiefs will help those who do not know how to use the Internet to fill out job application forms, then the 104 Job Bank will circulate the forms on the Web, said Chiu Wen-jen, an executive at the employment brokerage company.
The effort is expected to result in efficient matching of applicants with the current 180,000 work opportunities posted on the Internet, whether or not the applicants live in remote areas, Chiu said.
According to a 104 Job Bank survey, many job seekers are trying to upgrade their employability by acquiring a second vocational skill or a professional certificate.

The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics reported last month that Taiwan's unemployment rate had increased to 5.03 percent in December, representing the highest single-month record in more than five years.
Compared with the previous month, the unemployment rate grew by 0.39 percentage points, the government agency said.
The rising unemployment rate was attributed to the global recession caused by a financial storm affecting most countries around the world.
According to another online survey conducted Jan. 6-13 by 104 Job Bank among its member enterprises, 58 percent of the companies expect the economy to start pulling out of the slump this year.
Meanwhile, 54 percent of them said that they began recruiting new employees immediately after the Lunar New Year holiday.
Noting that many enterprises appear optimistic about the outlook for 2009 -- the Year of Ox on the lunar calendar -- Chiu urged job seekers to be patient and wait for the worst to pass.

DOC.HEADLINE: Revised rule will help lure capital back to Taiwan: officials

TEXT.P: The government's decision to lighten the penalties on Taiwan businessmen who have invested in China without the required approval will help lure Taiwanese capital back home, officials at the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Tuesday.

Commission officials made the remarks after the MOEA announced Monday that under newly revised regulations, Taiwan businessmen who invested in China after March 10, 2008 without government approval will be fined a minimum of NT$50,000 (US$1,492) , as long as they adhere to the specified conditions.

The conditions state that the rogue investments in China must be valued at less that NT$100 million, that the businessmen must report their investments to the Taiwan government and that they make new investments at home. In addition, the businesses must not have invested in product categories banned by Taiwan's authorities.
The penalties have also been reduced for Taiwanese businessmen who invested more than NT$100 million in China without approval of the the Taiwan government.

According to Investment Commission officials, a similar move implemented on March 10 last year by the Taiwan government helped to lure Taiwanese firms to report some 309 unregistered China investment cases, totaling US$1.58 billion.
During that period, some 309 cases of unregistered investment in China were reported, and the business people involved made new investment in Taiwan, the officials said.
Among them were a case worth over US$77 million, one worth US$59 million and two valued at more than US$50 million, the commission's statistics showed.
The more lenient rules announced by the MOEA Monday will take effect under a revisions to the regulations that were introduced by the previous government on March 10 last year, MOEA officials said.

The main aims of the revised regulations are to encourage Taiwanese business people to return home without fear of facing onerous fines, and to generate new investment in the domestic market, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, falling NT$0.029 to close at NT$33.720.
A total of US$834 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.750 and fluctuated between NT$33.620 and NT$33.750.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for February advancing 116 points to end at 4,275, with 77,589 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for March gained 109 points to finish at 4,237, with 578 contracts traded, while June futures rose 105 points to end at 4,206, with 15 contracts traded.
September futures gained 93 points to close at 4,007, with 35 contract transactions, while December futures increased 93 points to end at 3,966, with 11 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 4,159 for February, 4,128 for March, 4,101 for June 3,914 for September, and 3,873 for December.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index increased 112.83 points to finish at 4,372.81, on turnover of NT$59.59 billion (US$1.77 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.
February TE futures gained 4.4 points to close at 169.5, with 3,487 contracts traded, while March TE futures advanced 4.3 points to finish at 168.45, with 35 contracts traded.
June TF futures fell 0.3 points to close at 164.9, with three contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for September and December.

February TF futures were up 16.2 points to close at 496.2, with 4,082 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures increased 18.4 points to finish at 493.4, with 21 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for the other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF head optimistic about third round of cross-strait talks

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China have tentatively agreed to discuss four major bilateral cooperative ventures in their coming round of talks, and concrete agreements are likely to be forged in the meeting, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said Tuesday.

According to Chiang, the SEF has been authorized by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) to discuss joint crime fighting, financial cooperation, regular flights and shipping links and two-way investment, in the third round of cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations.
Chiang made the remarks at an SEF-sponsored Lunar New Year gathering with China- based Taiwan businessmen in Tainan City in southern Taiwan.
MAC oversees the operations of the semi-official SEF, which is responsible for dealing with China through its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).
Chiang, however, said the venue and date for the next round of cross-strait talks have not yet been decided.
"The SEF is waiting on a response from ARATS before a final decision could be made," he added.

Chiang and ARATS President Chen Yunlin met for the first time in June 2008 in Beijing and clinched accords on tourism opening and transportation links, marking a historical breakthrough in the decades-old icy relations between the governments on the two sides.
Chiang and Chen held their second meeting in Taipei last November and signed agreements to put two-way daily charter flights in place and launch shipping services between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Oil cooperation scheme will strengthen ties with Belize: MOFA

TEXT.P: An oil cooperation scheme between a local state-owned petroleum company and Belize, one of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America, will help improve economic ties between the two countries, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.

With Taiwan focusing more on political and diplomatic exchanges with Belize, the oil exploration agreement they signed in January will complement the Taiwan government's efforts to build substantial economic cooperation between the two countries, said Diego Chou, deputy director-general of MOFA's Department of Central and South American Affairs.

Chou said the pact gives the Taiwan-based CPC Corporation full rights to explore an area of around 4,800 square kilometers off the coast of Belize, which is widely believed to be rich in oil and natural gas resources.
CPC will station a technical team in the Central American country to conduct geological research and make other pre-drilling preparations, Chou added.
As part of CPC's efforts to diversify its oil sources, it has also signed similar deals with countries such as Kenya and Indonesia, according to the ministry.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP calls for dismissal of ex-legislator over citizenship issue

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) pressed the Legislative Yuan Tuesday to formally dismiss former Kuomintang Legislator Lee Ching-an, despite her resignation last month, for failing to prove the loss of her U.S. citizenship by the legally mandated deadline of Jan. 31.
Also, the party urged prosecutors to continue an investigation into alleged fraud by Lee and demanded that the Central Election Commission (CEC) spell out its legal opinion on the matter.

"The case must not be closed in such a precipitate manner. The legislature, CEC and judicial authorities must fulfill their duties and give the public a full explanation, " said DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang during a news conference.

Lee, who was sworn in for a fourth legislative term Feb. 1, 2008, was found the following month to have never formally renounced her U.S. citizenship, even though she had held public office in Taiwan since 1994.

The Nationality Act requires public officials holding dual citizenship to surrender their foreign citizenship before assuming public office and to obtain a certificate as proof within one year of taking office.
The law also requires that those officials who retain foreign citizenship be removed from their posts.

Calls for Lee to be formally relieved of her seat mounted after the U.S. authorities, in response to an inquiry from Taiwan, confirmed in late 2008 that she "has previously been documented as a U.S. citizen with a U.S. passport and that no subsequent loss of U.S. citizenship has been documented."

Lee insisted that she was awaiting a retroactive ruling by U.S. authorities on her U.S. citizenship status based on the fact that she was holding public office in another country, a legal cause for loss of U.S. citizenship.

Although Lee said she was confident there would be a resolution of the matter by Jan. 31, she resigned Jan. 8 just as DPP politicians were promoting a campaign to recall her and pro-DPP civic groups were preparing to besiege the legislature to protest the lawmaking body's failure to act against her.
A group of DPP legislators have filed a complaint with the Taipei District Prosecutors Office accusing Lee of forgery and fraud.

The legislators alleged that by holding dual citizenship while in public office, Lee defrauded the public coffers of over NT$100 million in salary as a Taipei City councilor between 1994 and 1998 and as a legislator from 1999 to 2009, and they demanded that she return the "illicit gains."
The CEC is scheduled to meet Friday to discuss whether Lee's election to public office prior to 2008 should be nullified.

DOC.HEADLINE: Venerable Dharma Master Sheng Yen dies at age 80

TEXT.P: Venerable Dharma Master Sheng Yen died of renal disease at National Taiwan University Hospital Tuesday at the age of 80, hospital sources said.

Sheng Yen, who founded the Dharma Drum Mountain Foundation in 1989 to promote humanistic Buddhism, had his left kidney removed a few years ago after he developed a malignant tumor. Three years ago, he began having dialysis three times a week because he lost the function of his right kidney.
According to media reports, Sheng Yen was diagnosed with urinary tract cancer late last year and had been hospitalized since Jan.5.
Dharma Drum Mountain Foundation officials are scheduled to hold a news conference at Nungchan Temple in suburban Taipei at 8 p.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lu to miss Davis Cup tie against Kazakhstan

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top tennis player Lu Yen-hsun, who reached a career-high 58 in the world rankings on Monday following a breakthrough performance at the Australian Open, will miss this weekend's Davis Cup tie against Kazakhstan because of an inflamed knee.
The announcement came as Taiwan's team for the Feb. 6-8 tie at Sinjhuang Gymnasium in Taipei County was introduced Tuesday.

Lu suffered discomfort to his right knee during his stunning five-set upset of 10th seed David Nalbandian of Argentina in the second round of the Australian Open, and further aggravated it last week during a Challenger series event in Heilbronn, Germany.

Doctors there suggested that Lu remain in Germany to treat the knee rather than play in Taiwans 2009 Davis Cup opener to prevent the inflammation from growing worse and jeopardizing his participation in upcoming ATP Tour events.

Lu will be missed against Kazakhstan, whose top three players -- Andrey Golubev, Mikhail Kukushkin and Yuri Schukin, all ranked in the world's top 200 -- played for Russia before changing their nationalities last year.

The Feb. 6-8 tie was made necessary because the Davis Cup Asia/Oceania Zone Group 1 has nine teams entered this year. Taiwan and Kazakhstan were drawn to compete for the final spot in the official eight team draw, which begins competition in earnest March 6-8.

If Taiwan beats Kazakhstan this weekend, it will host India in March. A win over India and either Australia or Thailand in May would send Taiwan to the elusive World Group playoffs for the first time ever, a prospect Lu would surely relish.

The oft-injured 25-year-old risked playing in Germany to try and cover ranking points he was about to lose, but the gamble did not pay off when the knee acted up during a second round 6-2, 6-0 loss to Karol Beck of Slovakia, said Lu Wei- ru, Lu's older brother who helps manage his younger brother's affairs.

Not treating the injury now could have financial consequences. Lu has already signed up to play at four ATP tournaments in the U.S. beginning Feb. 9, but will be fined by tennisorganizing body, the ATP (Association of Tennis Professionals) if he misses more than one of them due to injury, Lu Wei-ru told the Central News Agency.
In Lu's absence, Taiwan will likely depend on Wang Yeu-tzuoo and Chen Ti in the four singles matches played on Friday and Sunday. A pivotal doubles is played Saturday.

Wang, ranked as high as 85th in the world in 2006, is hoping to restart his career this weekend after being sidelined for most of 2008 with an assortment of ailments, the most serious a persistent wrist injury.
He has played in only five ATP Tour event qualifying tournaments since last years Australian Open, winning just one set in the five appearances.
Wang told the Central News Agency he spent most of 2008 conditioning his body and had only begun hitting balls in earnest at the end of November.

Asked if he was worried about his lack of match competition or that the wrist injury might still hamper him during the Davis Cup best-of-five set matches, Wang deadpanned: I am worried about so many things that I've decided not to worry about any them.
Wang, whose natural talent was in evidence when he reached the finals of the US Open boys singles at the age of 16 in 2001, felt he had recovered his basic skills and was physically fit.

But confidence can only come from tournaments. There's no way you can get confidence from just practicing, It's not possible," said Wang, whose confidence and match toughness are likely to be challenged against Kazakhstan.
Chen Ti, who has remade his game, from his grip to his serve, in the last six weeks, will be testing how much he's absorbed.
Although the world No. 375 Chen is ranked below Kazakhstan's top three players, he said he was more confident than when he played Australia's Lleyton Hewitt in a Davis Cup tie last February.
"Last year when I played Hewitt, I was just hoping to play well. This year, I'm playing to win."

DOC.HEADLINE: CowParade stampedes Taipei

TEXT.P: An international series of art exhibitions "CowParade" has arrived in Taipei and officially kicked off Tuesday under the name "CowParade Taipei 2009," featuring 107 painted ox and cow sculptures scattered throughout the city.
Taipei is honored to be chosen to host the CowParade exhibition, which provides a great opportunity for us to market the city," Taipei Mayor Hau Lung- bin said at the opening ceremony.

In Chinese culture, cattle have special meaning because they represent good luck, and this is exactly what the city hopes the exhibit, the biggest of its kind in Asia, will bring to the country and its people, the mayor added.
CowParade started out in Zurich in 1998 as an innovative idea by artistic director Walter Knapp to hold an international exhibition to raise money for charity.

In the U.S., Chicago followed up on the idea in 1999 and New York in 2000, and CowParade has since become the largest public art campaign and the most outstanding city marketing and charity event in the world, attracting more than half a billion visitors to date.

CowParade is celebrating its 10th anniversary in Taipei City -- the 65th city to host the event -- to coincide with the celebration of the Year of the Ox on the Chinese calendar and the famous Taipei Lantern Festival.

Jerry Elbaum, president of the CowParade Holdings Corporation that is organizing the art campaign, said at the opening ceremony that Taiwanese artists have outdone most of the artists in the rest of the world and that the Taipei exhibit has surpassed anything he has ever seen in New York, Chicago, or Moscow.
He told the Central News Agency that CowParade Taipei 2009 is unique and that what amazes him most is that every piece of work is "extremely well-executed."
"Everything I see here is so creative, so well thought out, and so well put together -- this is great art," Elbaum said. "Taiwan is a country of tremendous creativity and artistry."
He noted that every piece on display in the Taipei exhibition is a new creation by local artists, which reflects the culture, history, personality and art of the local community.

Organized by the Taipei City government's Department of Cultural Affairs and FUN Capital International Co., Ltd., CowParade Taipei 2009 features 107 painted cows and oxen made from fiberglass, grazing in 12 areas of the city, including the Civic Plaza, Taipei 101, Chanti Boulevard and Anhe Market Place.

In addition to integrating local themes such as kung fu and indigenous art, the exhibit in Taipei also include novelties such as an ox named "Ben (galloping) " on the top of the 508-meter skyscraper Taipei 101. This is the highest elevation at which a piece has ever been exhibited in the event.
CowParade Taipei 2009 is being held from Feb. 3-March 31.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic indicators drop to lowest level in over seven years

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy is liking to continue feeling the pinch in the coming months, as its leading indicators in December fell to their lowest level since December 2001, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported Tuesday.

The monitoring indicators for December registered a 9, two points lower than for the previous month, while flashing a "blue" signal for the fourth consecutive month, indicating that the economy is still in recession, the CEPD said.

The CEPD uses five colors to measure domestic economic health, with "red" indicating serious overheating, "yellow-red" for light overheating, "green" for steady growth, "yellow-blue" for a slowdown, and "blue" for recession.
Among the monitoring indicators' nine separate components, direct and indirect finance, and non-agricultural employment each lost one point, changing their indicators from yellow-blue to blue.

The signals for the other components -- monetary aggregate M1B, the stock prices index, the industrial production index, customs-cleared exports, imports of machineries and electrical equipment, manufacturing sales and sales indexes of wholesale, retail and food services -- remained unchanged, flashing blue.

At a press conference Tuesday, Huang Jui-bin, director-general of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, reported that the composite index of leading indicators -- a barometer for the economy's outlook in the coming three months -- dropped by 2.3 percent from November to 93.
The annualized six-month rate of change of the leading indicators index fell by 2 points to minus 17.2 percent, falling for the 14th consecutive month, Huang said.

All leading indicators contributed negatively to the index, hit hard by declines in export orders, average monthly overtime in industry and services, building permits, and book-to-bill ratios in the semiconductor machinery industry, the official elaborated.

The index of coincident indicators, which represents the current economic situation, stood at 81.6 in December, down 8.2 percent from the previous month. Its trend-adjusted index decreased by 8.4 percent to 75.4, the 10th consecutive decline since last March.
Huang warned the recession might be more protracted than the one Taiwan experienced in 2001 when the Internet bubble burst.

During the Internet bubble crisis, the monitoring indicators signal flashed blue for 15 consecutive months from December 2000, with the monitoring score remaining at a low of 9 for six months in 2001.
This period of economic contraction would pose a bigger challenge than in 2001, Huang said, because the latest rececssion has battered both Taiwan's export and domestic markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: Closer ties with China have fortified Taiwan's sovereignty: Ma

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that the normalization of bilateral relations between Taiwan and China has contributed to the consolidation of Taiwan's sovereignty and enabled the country to make significant gains in foreign relations and national defense.

Speaking at the 2009 Taiwan Businessmen in China Lunar New Year Reception held in Tainan, Ma asserted that closer ties with China have allowed Taiwan to play a more active role in the international arena and played a vital role in Taiwan's economic structure.

"Taiwanese entrepreneurs know better than the government if they should go invest in China, " said Ma, but it was the government's responsibility to provide an efficient platform to facilitate logistics operations and protect Taiwanese investment in China.
Surrounded by the biggest economies in the world, Taiwan is in an economically vital strategic position in Southeast Asia that better ties with China could help Taiwan exploit.

"Across the Pacific lies the United States, which is the biggest economy in the world today, and not far from us to the north is Japan, the second biggest economy in the world. The third largest global economic entity is located just across the Taiwan Strait, " Ma said.
The president suggested, however, that Taiwan has not been able to make good use of its advantageous position in the area due to political conflicts and constraints.

"The most important job of my administration is to eliminate all obstacles that limit Taiwan from taking advantage of its geographical advantages and achieving steady and prosperous economic development," the president asserted.

Ma said that although the normalization of bilateral ties with China has not gone as smoothly as expected, the launching of the "direct three links" has increased the "bargaining chips" of Taiwanese investors in China amid the global economical downturn.

"The air and sea transportation sectors have not been the only beneficiaries of the launch of the links, " Ma said. "The recent economic cooperation between the two sides has also given Taiwanese investors in China a chance to re-evaluate their method of operations."

The president also rebuffed accusations that his administration has tilted excessively toward China at the expense of Taiwan's sovereignty and that the United States and Japan share the same concerns.
He said the economic liberalization policies adopted by the government are aimed at improving Taiwan's investment environment and boosting the country's economic development.
In addition, Ma said, the improved cross-strait relations has been universally welcomed by all of Taiwan's allies around the world.
Asked why Taiwan was not mentioned during the recent dialogue between the United States and China, Ma said that, "no news is good news," adding that it is normal that Taiwan wasn't mentioned.
"If Taiwan is mentioned and discussed all the time, it would be bad for Taiwan's investment environment," said Ma.

Ma also said Taiwan's goal is to seek peace and stability in the area, and that the exclusion of the "Taiwan issue" in the recent dialogue between the U.S. and China is the best proof that improved ties are accepted and welcomed by all parties.
According to Ma, the improvement and normalization of cross-strait ties is the best way to restore mutual trust with the U.S. government.
"The U.S. government approved arms sales to Taiwan last September due to Taiwan's determination to become a problem solver instead of a troublemaker on cross-strait issues, " he said.

Since the Kuomintang (KMT) returned to power last May, Ma's administration has committed itself to improving relations with Beijing and forging links across the Taiwan Strait, particularly on the economic front.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agriculture council will release more jobs next month

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) will be able to provide more job openings after the Executive Yuan's NT$500 billion (US$14.93 billion) economic stimulus package clears the legislature, the council said in a statement Tuesday.
The Cabinet is scheduled to submit a budget bill authorizing financing for the package to the Legislative Yuan later this month.

Once the bill is passed, the statement said, about NT$19 billion of the fund will be allocated to the COA for various forestation and rural development projects as part of government efforts to spur domestic demand amid the global economic recession.
With the new funding, the official said, the COA will be able to generate more than 4,000 short-term and long-term jobs, with average daily wages ranging between NT$800 and NT$1,000.
Most of these job openings will be related to forest cultivation, weeding, and national park tour services as part of the COA Forestry Bureau's forestation project, the statement said.

As the legislature has passed a rural rejuvenation statute to facilitate rural development, the COA will also hire more people to conduct rural environment surveys, the statement indicated, with some of the job openings to be created under this project requiring at least a college-level education.
Meanwhile, the COA plans to recruit more research assistants with tertiary academic degrees.
Other job openings to be provided by the COA include livestock slaughterhouse cleaning, but not the actual sluaghtering of livestock, the statement said.
Late last year, the COA opened 1,647 positions under the government's short-term job creation plan, with 1,100 vacancies having being filled, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nantou lantern festival features agricultural images

TEXT.P: Nantou City will celebrate the traditional Lantern Festival this year by focusing on local themes such as its agricultural products and a migrant bird that winters there every year.

At ceremony held in the Yungxing community on Mt. Baqua in the central Taiwan city Tuesday, the city lit a theme lantern that depicted cattle, pineapples, ginger, Chinese yam, tea, lychees, and gray-faced buzzard eagles.

The lantern designer, Wu Chang-ping, who is a teacher at Fengming Junior High School, said that he, the students and all the other teachers at the school spent nine days crafting the theme lantern for the city's festival which is scheduled to begin Feb. 7.
Wu said he drew inspiration for the three-meter tall theme lantern from the abundant variety of local agricultural products and the spectacular natural environment.
He said he hopes that, like the eagle depicted in his lantern, sales of Nantou products will soar in 2009, the Year of the Ox on the lunar calendar.
The 2009 Lantern Festival falls on Feb. 9, the 15th day of the Lunar New Year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei book fair to feature various country themes

TEXT.P: The Taipei International Book Exhibition (TIBE), which will open Wednesday, will highlight four countries in particular -- Thailand, Germany, France and the U.S. -- as prominent authors gather in the city to introduce their latest works and new trends in literature, the event's organizer said Tuesday.

Speaking at a pre-opening press conference, Taipei Book Fair Foundation Chairman Linden Lin said that the TIBE, considered the world's second largest book fair, is known for its lively literary and business exchanges as well as the special activities usually held in tandem with the event, and thus attracts publishers and authors worldwide.

For instance, he said, France will be represented by a 16-member group -- the largest in years -- while Thailand, the fair's theme country this year, will send a record 100 people to participate in the exhibition.

Tawara Siripipat, a 23 year-old Thai writer and R&B singer known as "Dr. Pop," said that he hopes his science fiction works will inspire readers to "liberalize (their) imaginations" from moral, traditional, religious and political boundaries.

Siripipat, who started writing at the age of 14 and published his first book at 17, also expressed the hope that he could serve as a role model for young aspiring writers in Taiwan and inspire them to pursue their dreams.

Risuan Aramcharoen, president of the Publishers and Booksellers Association of Thailand, made mention of three other visiting authors -- Chart Korbjitti, who has won two Southeast Asian Writers Awards, a Buddhist philosopher writer W. Vajiramedhi, and Suwadee Chongsatitwatana, a three-time winner of Thailand's literary awards -- who will be at the fair.

In addition, Risuan said a variety of activities will be staged at the Thailand pavilion, including a puppet performance, cooking and handicraft demonstrations, lectures, and quick Thai language instructions.

At the German pavilion, Ulrich Janetzki, president of Literarisches Colloquium Berlin, said that Taiwanese readers will be able to gain a different perspective on what he described as normally "serious" German literature by reading the works of Jan Boettcher, who uses irony to discuss philosophical issues.
Anthony Chaumuzeau, an Institut Francais de Taipei official, said that France will showcase children's literature and photography arts this year.

In a demonstration of its literary scope, the United States this year will have 300 independent publishers at the fair, the organizer said, adding that the U.S. contingent will also hold forums on the latest developments in digital content.
The TIBE will be held at the Taipei World Trade Center from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Feb. 4-9, with extended opening hours to 10 p.m. from Feb. 6-8, according to the organizer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local governments move to tackle unemployment

TEXT.P: In the face of rising unemployment around the country, several local governments have come up with initiatives to help alleviate the jobless situation in their municipalities.

The Kaohsiung City government on Tuesday launched a low interest loan program under which enterprises and stall vendors certified by the local government may apply for loans of NT$300,000 to NT$50,000 at an interest rate of around 2.625 percent.

The city government and the Small and Medium Enterprise Credit Guarantee Fund of Taiwan will each allocate NT$20 million to fund the program, which is expected to result in total financing of NT$400 million through a multiplier effect. The loans will be made available to some 1,000 companies and vendors in the city.

Also on Tuesday, Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu announced that the city government will offer a number of short-term jobs in the areas of street cleaning, dengue fever prevention and promotion of the 2009 Kaohsiung World Games. It will also create jobs for research and survey professionals, she said.
Chen added that the southern city will seek at least 10,000 job openings for its residents among the 150,000 short-term jobs the central government has promised to supply.
The mayor advised job hunters in the city to first try to land a job, then seek to find a better one.
Chen her government plans to open a series of courses for the unemployed to sharpen their professional skills.

Meanwhile, the Kaohsiung county government submitted an employment promotion program Tuesday to the county council for review, under which a total of 502 six-month jobs will be offered to local citizens.

The county government will provide some NT$61.46 million in subsidies to employers for salaries and labor insurance fees for these short-term workers over six months, according to Sung Ting-tung, director general of the county's Labor Affairs Bureau.
The subsidies will cover NT$800 per day for each ordinary worker and NT$900 per day for each executive for a maximum of 22 days a month, he added.

In a different approach to the unemployment problem, Chiayi Magistrate Chen Ming-wen led local government officials in a religious rite Tuesday to pray to the gods to help the unemployed weather the difficult times.

DOC.HEADLINE: Baseball legend optimistic about Taiwan's pro baseball future

TEXT.P: Baseball legend Sadaharu Oh said Tuesday that despite recent gambling scandals in Taiwan's Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) , he is confident that the local baseball community can find a way to win back the hearts and minds of once loyal fans.

Known in Taiwan as Wang Chen-chih, baseball's all-time home run king said at a press conference in Taipei that the association of professional baseball players with gamblers has been a bad influence on the country's youth and a terrible disappointment for fans.
He contended that professional athletes should not only entertain the public but also serve as role models.
"Japan had the same problem over 40 years ago, " Oh recalled, saying it took years for Japan's government and members of Japan's baseball community to regain the trust and support of the public.

Emphasizing that the mere act of using baseball as a money-making tool is not only shameful but also disrespecful to all baseball lovers, Oh said that professional baseball players should never betray the trust and support of their fans by involving themselves in illegal or immoral activities.
"If Taiwan's baseball community works hard enough to win back the hearts and minds of their supporters, I don't see why the CPBL can't have a bright future," Oh said.

Meanwhile, Oh said that despite of his many commitments in Japan, he will do his best to promote baseball in Taiwan in order to let young players understand the virtues that can be developed while practicing the game.
"Baseball is a game of teamwork and discipline, which I believe they will need when they grow up," Oh said.

Asked what he would recommend for Taiwanese players who want to pursue a professional baseball career in Japan, Oh said it was vital for young players to be mentally and physically prepared since the baseball season in Japan is a little bit longer than in Taiwan, running from February to November.

Asked if he is anxious to meet President Ma Ying-jeou later this week, Oh said that he respects Ma's efforts to help the nation cope with the recent economic crisis and is very much looking forward to meet this "beautiful man."
Oh was referring to Ma's good looks and his penchant for exercising, a rare habit among Asian leaders, Oh remarked.
Oh, who retired from the Yomiuri Giants in 1980 at the age of 40, hit 868 home runs during his career, the most hit by a player in any professional league around the world.
The son of a Chinese father and a Japanese mother and a Republic of China citizen, Oh has never forgotten his Chinese heritage despite spending most of his life in Japan.
He has always maintained a close relationship with Taiwan's baseball community and has contributed his services to the sport's development here.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yunlin officials investigating questionable infant formulas

TEXT.P: Yunlin County health officials took new samples from a factory run by Wei Chuan Corp. to determine whether infant formula it exported to China may have been tainted by a bacteria that can be lethal if it infects infants.

Wu Ying-lang, a section chief at Yunlin's health bureau, said samples of three infant formulas sold exclusively in Taiwan will be sent to the Bureau of Food and Drug Analysis under the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) for in- depth testing to ease local consumer concerns over food safety.

It was the second day in a row that Yunlin County officials collected samples from the company after local media reported on Monday that three infant formulas shipped from Wei Chuan's Douliou plant were found by Chinese customs agents in Shenzhen on Oct. 30 to be contaminated with the bacteria Enterobacter sakazakii.
The shipment of 200 cartons totaling 9.264 tons of infant formula was said to be destroyed on the spot by Chinese inspectors the same day.

According to Wei Chuan executives, the three exported infant formulas were not sold in Taiwan, but operations at the company's Douliou plant have been temporarily suspended pending the result of the DOH tests.
The news has sent Wei Chuan shares down 9.6 percent to NT$18.80 over the past two days, despite a rebound for food shares in general on Tuesday.

According to Wu, county officials have poured through the Douliou factory's inspection records over the past year to help determine whether the food producer's quality control process was in any way flawed.
So far, he said, Yunlin County officials have not found any evidence that the company's raw materials, finished products, or manufacturing facilities were contaminated with the bacteria.
The rod-shaped Enterobacter sakazakii bacteria is capable of causing meningitis and enteritis and has a fatality rate of more than 50 percent when infecting newborns.
Wei Chuan, one of Taiwan's biggest food processing companies, has been trying to penetrate the Chinese market and exported the suspect shipment in October through an agent in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flu vaccines not as effective this year as in the past: DOH

TEXT.P: Influenza vaccines that proved to be effective late last year have failed to live up to expectations early this year, the Department of Health (DOH) said Tuesday.
Chou Jih-haw, deputy director general of DOH's Centers for Disease Control, said more than 3.2 million free flu shots were given to the public in autumn and winter last year.
"Judging from the number of influenza cases in the fourth quarter of 2008, it was significantly lower than in the same period the previous year," Chou said.
"But this year, tests of flu viruses on the patients showed that the results have not been as good as expected," he continued.

Chou said influenza vaccines given in autumn 2008 and this winter should be effective against the H1N1 and H3N2 viruses, and tests taken from patients who were inoculated last year proved their effectiveness.

But in January, tests found the vaccines did not work on 70 percent of those with H1N1 viruses and 40 percent of those with the H3N2 virus. A vaccine is considered effective if it controls the virus in 80 percent to 90 percent of those inoculated.

Chou would not categorize the vaccines as ineffective, however, because influenza viruses are "prone to mutation, " meaning that the virus formula for producing vaccines must be changed on a yearly basis.
A former CDC director suggested Tuesday that part of the problem may be that flu viruses tend to strike Taiwan between six months and two years earlier than European countries and the United States.

Su Ih-jen, director of the Division of Clinical Research of the National Health Research Institutes, said that because of the time lag, influenza vaccines produced by European and American pharmaceutical makers based on data provided by the World Health Organization could not keep up with the outbreak of flu in Asia.
Su noted that with close exchanges between Taiwan and China, Taiwan has become an outpost of influenza outbreaks.
The World Health Organization began to address the issue of different prevalent viruses in Asia and Europe last April.
Currently, two out of five major vaccine manufacturers have made inroads into China, and the production of Asian influenza vaccines "has become a trend," he said.
Su suggested that the virus in every influenza outbreak is slightly different, and that "it can show major changes about every five years, so the effectiveness of vaccines can diminish."

DOC.HEADLINE: Former Taiwanese member of International Olympic Committee dies

TEXT.P: Henry H. Hsu, a former member of the International Olympic Committee from Taiwan, passed away at Veterans General Hospital here Tuesday at the age of 96.
A spokesman for the hospital said Hsu died from heart failure Tuesday afternoon, six months after he was admitted to the hospital for uremia and pneumonia.
Hsu made a name for himself as an athlete by winning a gold medal in volleyball at the 9th Far East Games in Tokyo in 1930 and in football at the 10th Far East Games in 1934.
He later became a successful hotel tycoon.
Hsu headed the Republic of China Olympic Committee between 1973 and 1974 and was elected to the International Olympic Committee in 1970 and retired from it in 1988, according to the IOC's Web site.

His contribution to the country's sports development earned him a Special Contribution Elite Award from the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, the forerunner of the Sports Affairs Council, in 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chan Buddhist Master Sheng Yen dies at 78

TEXT.P: Ven. Master Sheng Yen, founder of the Dharma Drum Mountain Monastery in northern Taiwan, died Tuesday at the age of 78.

Sheng Yen, recognized as one of the foremost contemporary Buddhist masters teaching Chan Buddhism, had suffered from kidney problems in recent years. He had a dysfunctional left kidney removed in 2006, and doctors also found his right kidney seriously calcified.
He declined the doctors' suggestion that he have a kidney transplant and insisted that he should accept the natural result in life.
Sheng Yen once told his disciples, "I am too old, and it would be such a waste to have a good kidney transplanted to me."
Sheng Yen was a 72nd generation descendant of Bodhidharma, the first patriarch of Chan Buddhism, and a 67th generation descendant of Hui-Neng (638-713), the sixth patriarch of Chan Buddhism.
He was born on a farm near Shanghai in early l931 and joined a nearby Buddhist Chan temple as a monk at 13.

Unhappy that he was assigned to do mainly ordinary chores every day in the first two years, he ran away and joined the Buddhist Academy at Ching-an Monastery in Shanghai, where he had his first chance to hear inspiring teachings from Chan Master Xu Yun and Master Tai Xu when they visited Shanghai.
In 1949, shortly after the Communist takeover of China, he was conscripted into the Nationalist Army and moved to Taiwan. He was a warrant officer then and served as a telegraph operator.
In the army, he continued his studies in Buddhism and meditated daily. He also used his leave to visit various monasteries.
After 10 years of military service, he retired from the army and resumed monastic life in 1959 at the Buddhist Culture Center in Beitou, in suburban Taipei.
In that year, he met his first real master, Ling Yuan, in southern Taiwan and learned the methods of experiencing peace, tranquility and happiness in life.

He was a disciple for two years under Master Tung Chu, a heir to both the Lin Chi and Tsao Tung sects of Chan Buddhism, before going into solitary retreat in the mountains for six years from 1961 to 1968.

At 38, he went to Japan to pursue further education to pave the way for future Dharma preaching. He received a master's degree in 1971 and a doctorate in Buddhist literature in 1975 from Rissho University.

In 1975 he formally received transmission from Chan Master Dong Chu of the Tsao Dong sect, and in 1978 he also received transmission from Chan Master Ling Yuan of the Lin Chi tradition. From then on, he became the Dharma heir in the two lineages of Chan Buddhism.
Two years later, he became the abbot of The Temple of Enlightenment in New York and started to teach Buddhism in the United States.

In the following years, he conducted more than 140 group meditation retreats in the United States, the United Kingdom and Europe, using his teachings to help practitioners achieve peace and harmony of the body, the mind, the family and their careers.
Each year, he would spend half of his time in the United States and the other half in Taiwan.

He traveled extensively to China, Hong Kong, Singapore, the Philippines, Japan, Malaysia, Russia, The United Kingdom, Poland, Germany, Belgium, Italy, the Czech Republic, Croatia, Argentina, Costa Rica and Brazil to preach the dharma.

In 1978 Sheng Yen became a professor at Chinese Culture University and president of the Chung-Hwa Buddhist Cultural Institute in Taipei. The next year, he became the abbot of Nung Chan Monastery in Beitou. He founded the Chan Meditation Center and the Institute of Chung-Hwa Buddhist Culture in New York in 1980, and five years later, he set up the Chung-Hwa Institute of Buddhist Studies in Taipei.

With more than 1 million followers worldwide, Master Sheng Yen began to feel the need for a permanent, spacious monastery, called Dharma Drum Mountain. After spending eight years looking for a construction site, he finally succeeded in 2000.

The Dharma Drum Mountain Monastery, located in Jinshan township, Taipei County, was inaugurated in October 2005. His wish fulfilled, the master's health showed signs of deterioration. In his final years, his devotion to Buddhist teaching never faded, and he was still planning to build a Dharma Drum University.

Master Sheng Yen received many awards from different governments in recognition of his humanitarian, cultural, and academic contributions. In August 2000, he was one of the keynote speakers in the Millennium World Peace Summit of Religious and Spiritual Leaders held in the United Nations.

He was the author of some 90 books in Chinese and over a dozen books in English. Some of his books have been translated into more than 12 languages, including French, German, Japanese, Italian, Polish, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish and Vietnamese.
In spite of his achievements, Master Sheng Yen maintained his usual humbleness, insisting that he was just an ordinary person living a monastic life.

DOC.HEADLINE: 43 schoolchildren from Taiwan attending an arts camp in Shanghai
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/09 23:19:45 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Forty-three elementary school pupils from Taiwan have joined some 30 Chinese counterparts in attending a week-long camp in Shanghai to learn various forms of arts related to Chinese culture.
The camp opened Tuesday with a ceremony attended by local government officials and Taipei City Councilor Hou Kuan-chiung, who is serving as the head of the program.
The Taiwanese schoolchildren are all from low-income families, with 29 students from 12 elementary schools in Taipei and 14 pupils from Taiwu Elementary School in the southernmost county of Pingtung.
They will learn painting, traditional opera, martial arts and various other forms of arts to familiarize themselves with different aspects of Chinese culture.
The camp was made possible by a donation of 400,000 Chinese yuan (NT$1.97 million) from the owner of a Taiwanese restaurant, Lucky Plaza, in Shanghai.
While in Shanghai, the Taiwanese and Chinese children will also visit scenic spots and places of interest, and release sky lanterns together to pray for peace and prosperity in both Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Feb. 4, 2009

TEXT.P: 2. Event: Opening of the Taipei International Book Exhibition Date and Time: 11 a.m., Wednesday, Feb. 4, 2009. Place: Exhibition Hall 1, Taipei World Trade Center, No.1, Xinyi Road, Section 5, Taipei City. Host and/or main speakers: President Ma Ying-jeou Organizers: Taipei Book Fair Foundation.
