TEXT.P: Yunlin County health officials took new samples from a factory run by Wei Chuan Corp. to determine whether infant formula it exported to China may have been tainted by a bacteria that can be lethal if it infects infants.

Wu Ying-lang, a section chief at Yunlin's health bureau, said samples of three infant formulas sold exclusively in Taiwan will be sent to the Bureau of Food and Drug Analysis under the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) for in- depth testing to ease local consumer concerns over food safety.

It was the second day in a row that Yunlin County officials collected samples from the company after local media reported on Monday that three infant formulas shipped from Wei Chuan's Douliou plant were found by Chinese customs agents in Shenzhen on Oct. 30 to be contaminated with the bacteria Enterobacter sakazakii.
The shipment of 200 cartons totaling 9.264 tons of infant formula was said to be destroyed on the spot by Chinese inspectors the same day.

According to Wei Chuan executives, the three exported infant formulas were not sold in Taiwan, but operations at the company's Douliou plant have been temporarily suspended pending the result of the DOH tests.
The news has sent Wei Chuan shares down 9.6 percent to NT$18.80 over the past two days, despite a rebound for food shares in general on Tuesday.

According to Wu, county officials have poured through the Douliou factory's inspection records over the past year to help determine whether the food producer's quality control process was in any way flawed.
So far, he said, Yunlin County officials have not found any evidence that the company's raw materials, finished products, or manufacturing facilities were contaminated with the bacteria.
The rod-shaped Enterobacter sakazakii bacteria is capable of causing meningitis and enteritis and has a fatality rate of more than 50 percent when infecting newborns.
Wei Chuan, one of Taiwan's biggest food processing companies, has been trying to penetrate the Chinese market and exported the suspect shipment in October through an agent in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flu vaccines not as effective this year as in the past: DOH

TEXT.P: Influenza vaccines that proved to be effective late last year have failed to live up to expectations early this year, the Department of Health (DOH) said Tuesday.
Chou Jih-haw, deputy director general of DOH's Centers for Disease Control, said more than 3.2 million free flu shots were given to the public in autumn and winter last year.
"Judging from the number of influenza cases in the fourth quarter of 2008, it was significantly lower than in the same period the previous year," Chou said.
"But this year, tests of flu viruses on the patients showed that the results have not been as good as expected," he continued.

Chou said influenza vaccines given in autumn 2008 and this winter should be effective against the H1N1 and H3N2 viruses, and tests taken from patients who were inoculated last year proved their effectiveness.

But in January, tests found the vaccines did not work on 70 percent of those with H1N1 viruses and 40 percent of those with the H3N2 virus. A vaccine is considered effective if it controls the virus in 80 percent to 90 percent of those inoculated.

Chou would not categorize the vaccines as ineffective, however, because influenza viruses are "prone to mutation, " meaning that the virus formula for producing vaccines must be changed on a yearly basis.
A former CDC director suggested Tuesday that part of the problem may be that flu viruses tend to strike Taiwan between six months and two years earlier than European countries and the United States.

Su Ih-jen, director of the Division of Clinical Research of the National Health Research Institutes, said that because of the time lag, influenza vaccines produced by European and American pharmaceutical makers based on data provided by the World Health Organization could not keep up with the outbreak of flu in Asia.
Su noted that with close exchanges between Taiwan and China, Taiwan has become an outpost of influenza outbreaks.
The World Health Organization began to address the issue of different prevalent viruses in Asia and Europe last April.
Currently, two out of five major vaccine manufacturers have made inroads into China, and the production of Asian influenza vaccines "has become a trend," he said.
Su suggested that the virus in every influenza outbreak is slightly different, and that "it can show major changes about every five years, so the effectiveness of vaccines can diminish."

DOC.HEADLINE: Former Taiwanese member of International Olympic Committee dies

TEXT.P: Henry H. Hsu, a former member of the International Olympic Committee from Taiwan, passed away at Veterans General Hospital here Tuesday at the age of 96.
A spokesman for the hospital said Hsu died from heart failure Tuesday afternoon, six months after he was admitted to the hospital for uremia and pneumonia.
Hsu made a name for himself as an athlete by winning a gold medal in volleyball at the 9th Far East Games in Tokyo in 1930 and in football at the 10th Far East Games in 1934.
He later became a successful hotel tycoon.
Hsu headed the Republic of China Olympic Committee between 1973 and 1974 and was elected to the International Olympic Committee in 1970 and retired from it in 1988, according to the IOC's Web site.

His contribution to the country's sports development earned him a Special Contribution Elite Award from the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, the forerunner of the Sports Affairs Council, in 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chan Buddhist Master Sheng Yen dies at 78

TEXT.P: Ven. Master Sheng Yen, founder of the Dharma Drum Mountain Monastery in northern Taiwan, died Tuesday at the age of 78.

Sheng Yen, recognized as one of the foremost contemporary Buddhist masters teaching Chan Buddhism, had suffered from kidney problems in recent years. He had a dysfunctional left kidney removed in 2006, and doctors also found his right kidney seriously calcified.
He declined the doctors' suggestion that he have a kidney transplant and insisted that he should accept the natural result in life.
Sheng Yen once told his disciples, "I am too old, and it would be such a waste to have a good kidney transplanted to me."
Sheng Yen was a 72nd generation descendant of Bodhidharma, the first patriarch of Chan Buddhism, and a 67th generation descendant of Hui-Neng (638-713), the sixth patriarch of Chan Buddhism.
He was born on a farm near Shanghai in early l931 and joined a nearby Buddhist Chan temple as a monk at 13.

Unhappy that he was assigned to do mainly ordinary chores every day in the first two years, he ran away and joined the Buddhist Academy at Ching-an Monastery in Shanghai, where he had his first chance to hear inspiring teachings from Chan Master Xu Yun and Master Tai Xu when they visited Shanghai.
In 1949, shortly after the Communist takeover of China, he was conscripted into the Nationalist Army and moved to Taiwan. He was a warrant officer then and served as a telegraph operator.
In the army, he continued his studies in Buddhism and meditated daily. He also used his leave to visit various monasteries.
After 10 years of military service, he retired from the army and resumed monastic life in 1959 at the Buddhist Culture Center in Beitou, in suburban Taipei.
In that year, he met his first real master, Ling Yuan, in southern Taiwan and learned the methods of experiencing peace, tranquility and happiness in life.

He was a disciple for two years under Master Tung Chu, a heir to both the Lin Chi and Tsao Tung sects of Chan Buddhism, before going into solitary retreat in the mountains for six years from 1961 to 1968.

At 38, he went to Japan to pursue further education to pave the way for future Dharma preaching. He received a master's degree in 1971 and a doctorate in Buddhist literature in 1975 from Rissho University.

In 1975 he formally received transmission from Chan Master Dong Chu of the Tsao Dong sect, and in 1978 he also received transmission from Chan Master Ling Yuan of the Lin Chi tradition. From then on, he became the Dharma heir in the two lineages of Chan Buddhism.
Two years later, he became the abbot of The Temple of Enlightenment in New York and started to teach Buddhism in the United States.

In the following years, he conducted more than 140 group meditation retreats in the United States, the United Kingdom and Europe, using his teachings to help practitioners achieve peace and harmony of the body, the mind, the family and their careers.
Each year, he would spend half of his time in the United States and the other half in Taiwan.

He traveled extensively to China, Hong Kong, Singapore, the Philippines, Japan, Malaysia, Russia, The United Kingdom, Poland, Germany, Belgium, Italy, the Czech Republic, Croatia, Argentina, Costa Rica and Brazil to preach the dharma.

In 1978 Sheng Yen became a professor at Chinese Culture University and president of the Chung-Hwa Buddhist Cultural Institute in Taipei. The next year, he became the abbot of Nung Chan Monastery in Beitou. He founded the Chan Meditation Center and the Institute of Chung-Hwa Buddhist Culture in New York in 1980, and five years later, he set up the Chung-Hwa Institute of Buddhist Studies in Taipei.

With more than 1 million followers worldwide, Master Sheng Yen began to feel the need for a permanent, spacious monastery, called Dharma Drum Mountain. After spending eight years looking for a construction site, he finally succeeded in 2000.

The Dharma Drum Mountain Monastery, located in Jinshan township, Taipei County, was inaugurated in October 2005. His wish fulfilled, the master's health showed signs of deterioration. In his final years, his devotion to Buddhist teaching never faded, and he was still planning to build a Dharma Drum University.

Master Sheng Yen received many awards from different governments in recognition of his humanitarian, cultural, and academic contributions. In August 2000, he was one of the keynote speakers in the Millennium World Peace Summit of Religious and Spiritual Leaders held in the United Nations.

He was the author of some 90 books in Chinese and over a dozen books in English. Some of his books have been translated into more than 12 languages, including French, German, Japanese, Italian, Polish, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish and Vietnamese.
In spite of his achievements, Master Sheng Yen maintained his usual humbleness, insisting that he was just an ordinary person living a monastic life.

DOC.HEADLINE: 43 schoolchildren from Taiwan attending an arts camp in Shanghai
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/03/09 23:19:45 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Forty-three elementary school pupils from Taiwan have joined some 30 Chinese counterparts in attending a week-long camp in Shanghai to learn various forms of arts related to Chinese culture.
The camp opened Tuesday with a ceremony attended by local government officials and Taipei City Councilor Hou Kuan-chiung, who is serving as the head of the program.
The Taiwanese schoolchildren are all from low-income families, with 29 students from 12 elementary schools in Taipei and 14 pupils from Taiwu Elementary School in the southernmost county of Pingtung.
They will learn painting, traditional opera, martial arts and various other forms of arts to familiarize themselves with different aspects of Chinese culture.
The camp was made possible by a donation of 400,000 Chinese yuan (NT$1.97 million) from the owner of a Taiwanese restaurant, Lucky Plaza, in Shanghai.
While in Shanghai, the Taiwanese and Chinese children will also visit scenic spots and places of interest, and release sky lanterns together to pray for peace and prosperity in both Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday Feb. 4, or the 10th day of the first month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1789: George Washington is elected as the first president of the United States.
1793: France abolishes slavery in all its te0ritories.
1810: Tsar Alexander I of Russia refuses to grant Napoleon I his sister Anna's hand in marriage. The Russian tsar's plans to liberalize the government were forestalled by wars with Napoleon I.
1899: Fighting breaks out in the newest U.S. protectorate, the Philippines, which declared itself a republic the previous month.
1902: Charles Lindbergh, the American aviator who made the first solo flight over the Atlantic Ocean, is born.
1904: The Russo-Japanese war breaks out.
1906: The New York Police Department adopts fingerprint lifting methods to collect evidence in criminal cases.
1922: China signs an agreement with Japan in Washington, D.C. to settle the Shantung dispute.
1938: Joachim von Ribbentrop becomes foreign minister of Germany while Hitler assumes the office of war minister.
1945: Leaders of the United States, Britain, and the Soviet Union meet in Yalta, USSR and reach the so-called "Yalta secret agreement." According to the pact, Soviet troops enter the war against Japan on the condition that its former land rights in China, taken by Japan in 1904, are to be restored later.
1948: Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) gains independence from Britain.
1949: Taiwan Provincial Governor Chen Cheng publicizes the practice of the Farm Rental Reduction Program, which was put into force on April 12 of the same year.
1966: An All Nippon Airway plane crashes at Tokyo's Haneda airport, killing all 133 people aboard.
1969: Liao Ho-shu, Communist China's charge d'affaires in the Netherlands, arrives in the United States and requests political asylum.
1973: The Asian Relations Association opens its Japan office in Tokyo.
1976: Dr. Raymond Jallow, senior vice president of the United California Bank, Los Angeles, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1976: A disastrous earthquake measuring 7.5 on the Richter scale jolts Guatemala, claiming more than 22,000 lives.
1976: Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs H.K. Yang decorates Dr. Tare Takemi, president of the Japan Medical Association, with the Order of Brilliant Star with Special Cordon.
1978: Junius Jayawardene becomes the first president of Sri Lanka.
1978: Fan Yuan-yen, the defecting Communist Chinese pilot who flew a MiG-19 to Taiwan the previous July, writes an open letter to the United Nations condemning human rights violations by the Beijing regime.
1980: Abolhassan Bani-Sadr becomes the first elected president of Iran. He is expected to follow the line of the country's de facto ruler, religious leader Ayatollah Khomeini.
1986: Twelve political dissidents jailed in Taiwan for the Formosa magazine incident are released on parole. The incident occurred in 1979 when political dissidents clashed with police while celebrating the anniversary of the publication of the magazine.
1988: The Executive Yuan passes a bill allowing high school graduates to study abroad.
1992: The Republic of China's Fair Trade Law goes into effect.
1997: Two military helicopters collide in mid-air in a storm in northern Israel, killing 73 Israeli soldiers.
1998: A strong earthquake measuring 6.1 on the Richter scale hits northern Afghanistan, killing 4,000 and leaving more than 15,000 homeless.
2000: Three Indonesian workers at the sixth naphtha cracking plant owned by Taiwan Plastic Corp. are killed in an accident while cleaning gas pipelines.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I am not the one born with understanding. I am only the one who has given himself to the study of antiquity and is diligent in seeking for understanding in such studies."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Exports to China down 38.8% year-on-year in November 2008

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports to China plunged for the third consecutive month in November 2008, throttled by declining demand due to the global economic downturn, according to a report released Tuesday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Exports to China fell by 38.8 percent year-on-year in November to a three-year monthly low of US$4.16 billion, the largest-ever decrease recorded for a single month, said the ministry's Bureau of Foreign Trade.
For November 2008, exports to China contributed 24.8 percent to Taiwan's total exports, down 6.3 percentage points from the same month of the previous year.

All export items were affected by the shrinkage, with the most serious fall seen in optical products, organic chemicals, copper and related products, miscellaneous chemicals and mineral fuels -- all of which experienced declines of over 50 percent.
Exports to China of electrical machinery, equipment and parts -- Taiwan's largest export item -- also fell by 31.9 percent.
Meanwhile, the sharp fall in exports dragged Taiwan's trade surplus with China down to US$1.96 billion for the month.

The amount marked a decrease of 55.1 percent year-on-year and was the lowest level recorded for a single month over the past five years, after months affected by the Chinese New Year holiday were excluded.
The bureau predicted Taiwan's exports to China will remain slow through the first half of 2009 as the global recession has not yet bottomed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan butterflies brighten up dark Scandinavian winter days
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/09 13:05:12 (By Lin Yu-li and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Formosan butterflies, which were flown to Sweden in paper and styrofoam cases in their "previous life" as pupae, have brightened up Sweden's dark winter days with their full-of-life colors, shapes and movement, Swedish media reported Tuesday.

A total of 900 butterflies from Taiwan that have emerged from their cocoons at a Stockholm butterfly house over the past month are said to have attracted capacity crowds from around Sweden since being unveiled in the unprecedented exhibition that opened Jan. 10.

The Taipei Zoo flew the Formosan butterflies while they were still in their pupal state on three separate flights to the Stockholm Butterfly House in early January for the exhibition, bringing tropical warmth to people in the Scandinavian country.
Over 1,000 people visited the butterfly house this past weekend alone, according to a report by Sweden's public television station Sveriges monitored in Berlin Tuesday evening.

"Not many people would connect Taiwan to butterflies, but actually Taiwan is one of the countries in the world that have the greatest number of butterfly species, and Taiwan has often been nicknamed as a 'butterfly kingdom,'" the TV channel reported.

In an interview with Sveriges Television, Taiwan's representative in Sweden Chiu Chung-jen said that there are a wide variety of butterfly species in Taiwan and the ongoing display of Formosan butterflies at the Stockholm Butterfly House could serve as a window for Swedish people to catch a glimpse of Taiwan's wildlife.
The Formosan butterfly display will run until the end of March, according to Government Information Office officials posted in Stockholm.

DOC.HEADLINE: Effects of stimulus package may not be felt until third quarter

TEXT.P: The stimulative effect of a massive public works program pushed by the government is not likely to be felt until the third quarter because of the varying scale of the projects, the Cabinet-level Public Construction Commission said Wednesday.

The planned public works include large-scale projects, such as railway, highway, seaport and airport renewal and the rebuilding of sewage systems and bridges, and medium- and small-scale projects, including flood prevention measures and the renovation of old or dangerious school buildings, the commission said.

While medium- and small-scale public construction projects are expected to create job opportunities immediately or in the near term, large-scale projects need a longer period to plan and prepare, a commission official said, making it unlikely that the plan will deliver concrete results until the third quarter of this year.
The Executive Yuan is expected to approve the package of public works projects next week.
The plan will funnel some NT$500 billion (US$14.88 billion) over the next four years into infrastructure projects to try to pull Taiwan's battered economy out of recession.

DOC.HEADLINE: Davis Cup spotlight falls on players looking to revive careers

TEXT.P: With Lu Yen-hsun ruled out of Taiwan's Davis Cup tie against Kazakhstan this weekend in Taipei County, the host's hopes could rest on one player who has lost all of his ranking points and another who has relearned the game from scratch over the past six weeks.

Wang Yeu-tzuoo and Chen Ti have been away from competitive tennis for months, and how they will perform under Davis Cup pressure against Kazakhstan's top-200 Russian transplants makes an already important Feb. 6-8 tie truly intriguing.
As insignificant as the opening Asia/Oceania Zone Group I tie of the year -- and one being played simply to fill out the zone's eight-team draw -- might seem, the stakes cannot be underestimated.

When Taiwan reached Asia/Oceania Zone Group 1 in 2003, it expected that with legitimate top-100 players in Lu and Wang, it would regular finish in the top two in the zone's annual competition and qualify for the World Group playoffs -- the gateway to the World Group, the pinnacle of Davis Cup tennis.
The hopes never materialized, however, derailed by injuries and turmoil between the players and local tennis authorities.

With Wang and Lu now older, and Taiwan likely to play most of its ties in the next few years on the road, this year may be the team's last best chance for a while to sparkle in the premier international team tennis competition.

Kazakhstan, which has been pouring some of its oil wealth into tennis and wants to become an Asian power in the sport, could be a formidable opponent with Russian imports No. 118 Andrey Gobulev, No. 145 Mikhail Kukushkin and No. 180 Yuri Schukin.

The central Asian country nearly beat Taiwan (led by Lu and Chen) in a Davis Cup relegation playoff in Almaty in April last year with only Schukin at its disposal, and it will now have reinforcements to take on players who have not played a lot of matches recently.
Chen Ti, who has fallen to 375 in the world rankings, last played competitively in three Challengers last November that included a 6-2, 6-2 loss to Golubev.

Though he may be rusty, he says he is rejuvenated and much improved after working with former French player Tarik Benhabiles on the advice of a friend on the ATP Tour, even if Benhabiles' initial appraisal of the 25-year-old who turned pro in 2002 was brutal.
"He said everything I was doing was wrong, Chen recalls.Even the way I was holding the racket was wrong. I felt like a young kid who was learning the game for the first time.
Chen spent three weeks with Benhabiles in August and another six weeks at his Florida academy from mid-December to the end of January overhauling his game.
"We worked on everything, starting with physical conditioning and core strength, doing 200 to 300 sit-ups to start the day,Chen said. "He also changed my grip, but the big change was to the serve.

To get Chen to serve in one fluid motion rather than the stop-start motion he was used to, Benhabiles had him first practice throwing a ball as far as he could and build up his shoulder strength before even letting him touch a racket.
The French coach, who counts Andy Roddick, Richard Gasquet and Gael Monfils as among those he has helped, also went back to basics to tweak Chen's ground strokes.
"We worked a lot on fundamentals like staying lower and rotating the body more, Chen said, admitting that the experience was an eye opener.
"I never really had formal training from the time I was young. I relied mostly on observing others and doing what they did. I've finally learned how to do things the right way.

If team captain Lien Yu-hui is right, and Chen has added 20 miles per hour to his serve, it could be a real boost to a player whose serve has always been a liability, and even identified as such by Lleyton Hewitt after he beat Chen last February in straight sets in an Asia/Oceania Zone Group I Davis Cup tie.

"I've had trouble holding my serve, so having a better serve will really help me. If I'm serving well, everything else seems to fall into place,said Chen, whose highest ranking in a journeyman career was 255 in 2005.

The question now is whether he has had enough time with his new game to make it work this weekend. Although Lien will not identify who will play Friday's two singles matches until Thursday, the odds are good he will go with Chen and the talented Wang, who was sidelined for most of 2008 with a persistent wrist injury and has zero ranking points to his name.
Wang, a natural showman who plays better the more raucous the home crowd, is hoping the home court advantage will overcome his lack of match preparation.
I really hope there will be a big crowd, because it will help our confidence,Wang said.
The tie is being held at the Sinjhuang Gymnasium Feb. 6-8. Admission is free. Friday's two singles matches, Saturday's doubles and Sunday's reverse singles all begin at 1 p.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Special Olympics team ready to leave for Winter Games

TEXT.P: Local athletes who will participate in the 2009 Special Olympics World Winter Games will depart later in the day for the United States, where the competition is being held, the Sports Affairs Council (SAC) said Wednesday.

Speaking at the flag presentation ceremony, President Ma Ying-jeou expressed the hope that Taiwan's athletes will help extend the country's people-to-people diplomacy and allow them to better understand Taiwan from a sports perspective.

Though Taiwan does not have an ideal environment to train for the Winter Games, the leader of Taiwan's delegation Pai Hsiu-hsiung said local athletes have been able to hone their skills in places such as beaches to make up for the lack of snow and ice.

According to the SAC, the 59-member delegation, including 36 young athletes with mental disabilities and 10 coaches, will compete in four events -- speed skating, figure skating, snowshoeing and floor hockey -- under the name ofChinese Taipei.
Taiwan won 20 gold medals, 13 silvers and 10 bronzes in the previous Special Olympics held in the Japanese city of Nagano, the SAC said.

An estimated 2,500 athletes from 85 countries will participate in this year's competition in Boise, Idaho from Feb. 7-13. Alpine skiing, cross-country skiing and snowboarding will also be featured events.

Similar to the Olympic Games, the Special Olympics takes place every four years and includes summer and winter versions. The first Special Olympics Summer Games were held in the U.S. city of Chicago in 1968, while the first Winter Games were held in 1977 in Steamboat Springs, also in the U.S..
The delegation is slated to leave the U.S. on Feb. 15 and to return to Taiwan on Feb. 17, the SAC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President inaugurates Taipei International Book Exhibition

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Wednesday opened the 2009 Taipei International Book Exhibition (TiBE) , the second largest book fair in the world, and praised Taiwan's publishing industry for being a vital source of the country's "soft power."

Speaking at the book fair's opening ceremony, at which he also presented awards to winners of the 2nd Taipei International Book Exhibition Prize, Ma also urged the public to read more to enrich themselves amid a weak global economy.

Ma said Taiwan's publication of over 40,000 new books last year, compared to 200,000 in China, which has 56 times more people, highlights the significant "soft power" Taiwan possesses in the global Chinese community.

"The TiBE serves as an important channel for Taiwan to communicate with countries around the world," Ma said. "Through reading, we can make a lot of friends and enrich the profundity of our culture and way of thinking."

The president said that despite a stagnant economy, people should not save money when it comes to buying books, as reading is a source of personal enrichment that can come in handy in difficult times.
Taipei Book Fair Foundation Chairman Linden Lin said that the 2009 TiBE serves as a platform for international publishers and authors to exchange ideas on publishing and share the passion of reading.

Featuring some 2,000 booths from a total of 41 countries, the TiBE will be held in the three exhibition halls of the Taipei World Trade Center, with Hall 1 reserved for international publishers, Hall 2 for cartoon and animation books, and Hall 3 for children's books.
The fair will be open from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Feb. 4-9, with extended opening hours to 10 p.m. from Feb. 6-8, according to the organizer.
The first day will be reserved for professionals in the publishing industry and people with physical disabilities while the fair will be open to the general public from Feb. 5-9.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma unlikely to visit Africa in the near term: MOFA

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou is unlikely to visit Africa in the near future given the situation at home and abroad, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Henry Chen said Wednesday.

Taiwan's four diplomatic allies in Africa, including Gambia and Swaziland, have planned to invite Ma for state visits to their countries, but the president is presently focusing his time and energy on bolstering the domestic economy and has no plans to travel abroad, Chen said.
The MOFA will make an overall assessment of the situation at home and abroad before making plans for an overseas visit by the president, Chen added.

The spokesman indicated that in the face of a global economic recession that has hit Taiwan hard, the president will remain at home to oversee government efforts to revive the battered domestic economy.

Chen made the remarks in response to a Liberty Times report Wednesday which said that four of Taiwan's African allies have invited Ma for state visits and Ma may make the visits this year, although the MOFA has yet to make any arrangements.

DOC.HEADLINE: First lady has no plans to visit China: Presidential Office

TEXT.P: First lady Chow Mei-ching has no plans to visit China in the present or the future, Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said Wednesday.

Wang was responding to a report published in the latest issue of Next magazine, a weekly tabloid, which said that Chow -- honorary president of the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China -- would visit China's earthquake-striken Sichuan province to donate NT$1.52 billion (US$45.1 million) to help with post- quake reconstruction.
Wang said the report was determined to be untrue after the office conducted an internal verification process and checked with the Red Cross Society.
Meanwhile, Red Cross Society Deputy Secretary-General Lin Hsiu-fen said her group is not involved in any plans or arrangements for the first lady to visit China.
Steven Chen, the organization's secretary-general, who the report said is orchestrating the so-called cross-Taiwan Strait diplomacy, described the report as "far-fetched."
Chen said he has never put forth any such idea because cross-strait diplomacy is an issue too sensitive for the Red Cross Society to handle.

DOC.HEADLINE: Spring calls, flowers blossoming on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei

TEXT.P: Cherry blossoms and camellias have been seen blossoming in the mountains north of Taipei recently, a clear indication that Yangmingshan's flower season, and its many related activities, is on the way.
The Floriculture Experimental Center, located on the main road leading to Yangmingshan, invited the public Wednesday to visit the center from Feb. 6-15 to see the camellias it has cultivated.

Operated by the Taipei City Parks and Street Lights Office, the center said in a statement Wednesday that its camellia show will consist of an exhibition of various camellia strains and a display of pressed-flower art paintings created with dry materials taken from camellia plants.

Meanwhile, the annual flower season on Yangmingshan is scheduled to kick off Feb. 20. The office said many hillside cherry trees have already begun to blossom, with the blossoms most evident along Hushan Road, the office noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ties with China play essential role in Taiwan's economy: SEF head

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said Wednesday that closer ties with China is essential for Taiwan's economic development, as it is the source of Taiwan's biggest trade surplus.

Speaking at a seminar on international trade and economy organized by Taiwan's China Youth Corps., Chiang told the young elites from local universities that relations with China affects Taiwan's economy and politics in a significant way.

"As Taiwanese businesses have invested a cumulative total of more than US$74.4 billion in China, it has already become Taiwan's primary trade partner, export market, trade surplus source and business investment destination," Chiang said.

Lauding President Ma Ying-jeou's efforts to make restoring talks with China and pursuing the normalization of cross-strait economic and trade relations top policy priorities since taking office May 20, Chiang said the new direct links launched Dec. 15 have not only paid off, but fulfilled long-held expectations.
"The present administration has adjusted the unreasonable restrictions imposed by the former Democratic Progressive Party administration," Chiang argued.

According to the SEF chairman, the gradual lifting of those constraints has allowed Taiwan to push for the normalization of economic and trade ties with China, which will in time allow Taiwan to boost its economic development and investment environment.
"A country's political, economic and social stability is essential to attracting foreign investment, " Chiang said, adding that nobody would want to risk their investment in an unstable country.

Asked about the benefits of the direct shipping and air links with China, Chiang said travelers no longer have to transit in Hong Kong on their way to China, which has shortened travel times between Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and Shanghai from five hours to 82 minutes.

As for the direct shipping links, Chiang said that vessels no longer need to sail to China via a third territory, which saves an estimated 27 hours per voyage across the Taiwan Strait and cut shipping costs by 15 percent to 30 percent.

In addition, Chiang said direct shipping and air links will serve not only to greatly reduce the cost of transporting people and goods across the Taiwan Strait, but also to help restore Taiwan's strategic advantage among Asian and Asia-Pacific economies.

"Surrounded by the biggest economies in the world, Taiwan is in an economically vital strategic position in Southeast Asia that better ties with China could help Taiwan exploit, " Chiang quoted President Ma as saying.
"We must make good use of this precious advantage," he added.

Chiang warned, however, that Taiwan cannot afford to lose its competitive edge in the high-tech and innovation sectors, as Taiwan will face a serious crisis once China no longer needs to rely on Taiwan to obtain high-tech skills and products.

Taiwan's SEF and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) held two rounds of high-level talks June 13 and Nov. 4 last year, at which they signed six agreements covering weekend charter flights, Chinese tourist visits to Taiwan, direct air, shipping and postal links, and food safety.
The SEF and ARATS serve as semi-official intermediary bodies in the absence of official contacts between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses from cold weather top NT$67 million

TEXT.P: The cold weather right before and during last month's Chinese New Year holiday caused losses of more than NT$67.83 million (US$2.01 million) to Taiwan's agricultural sector, according to statistics released Wednesday by the Council of Agriculture.
The amount included more than NT$51.11 million in crop damage and nearly NT$16.72 million in aquaculture damage.

Twenty percent of the crops on a total of 509 hectares of farmland were lost, mainly bell fruit, tea, tangerines, bananas, pineapples, musk melons, rice and betel nuts in Hsinchu, Nantou, Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties.
Meanwhile, aquaculture operations in five counties and cities were hammered by the cold spell.
They included milkfish, tilapia and shrimp farms in Yunlin and Chiayi counties, as well as milkfish farms in Tainan and Kaohsiung counties and in Tainan City.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opposition legislator questions feasibility of education coupons

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Chen Ting-fei questioned Wednesday the purpose and feasibility of a recent proposal by the government to offer education coupons to unemployed well-educated white collar workers and urged the Executive Yuan not to "waste taxpayer's money."

The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD)-proposed plan is aimed at helping unemployed highly educated white collar workers to return to school to attend various study programs or to teach at vocational schools.
Speaking at a press conference at the Legislative Yuan, Chen described the education coupons as not only a waste of taxpayers' money but also impractical.

The Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) launched a similar employment and vocational training plan in 2005 to elevate university students' skills and abilities to satisfy the needs of the job market, said Chen.
"Why should our government spend an extra NT$30 billion (US$895 million) on a plan that will show little or no effect on lowering the unemployment rate?" she asked.
In addition, Chen went on, the government should not use the money to help the dozens of poorly operated local universities to increase their student admittance levels through the education coupons.

"Instead of giving the highly educated unemployed workers education coupons, should our educational system not instead evaluate the reasons why the elite of the country are losing their jobs? " she asked.
What the university students and the unemployed need are jobs, not education coupons, said Chen.

Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus leader Yang Chiung-ying said, however, that the Executive Yuan has not presented any details of the plan to the Legislative Yuan, so that any rhetoric about the issue is mere speculation.

According to government statistics, the jobless rate increased to a high of 5.03 percent last December, with 549,000 people out of work, about 220,000 of whom were university graduates or higher in terms of education and experience.
The Executive Yuan forecast earlier this month that the launch of the education coupon plan could help drive the unemployment rate down to below 4.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Bus Station near completion: city mayor

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Hau Lung-bin on Wednesday inspected the Taipei Bus Station, a mammoth BOT (build-operate-transfer) project under construction that is set to serve as a new highway bus transit center in Taiwan's capital city when it is completed in a few months.

Hau expressed the hope that the new bus station, being built by Radium Life Tech Co. at a cost of NT$10.9 billion (US$324.4 million), will become operational sooner rather than later and will meet the requirements of safety and convenience.

Hau said the Taipei city government has not set a timetable for the opening of the new bus station, but he estimated that with construction scheduled to be completed in March, the bus station could open to traffic around late June.
Radium Life Tech won an open bid in January 2005 to build the bus station and operate it for 50 years.

The Taipei Bus Station, a massive 24-story building, will be centered around a four-story bus station that will have 30 ticket booths on its ground floor and a total of 50 platforms on the second, third and fourth floors.
The complex will also include a business hotel, several cinemas, a shopping mall, offices, private residential suites, and 946 parking spaces.
It is estimated that the station will generate some NT$21 billion in profits for the Taipei city government during the 50-year operation by Radium Life Tech.
When completed, the Taipei Bus Station will be a major transport nerve center in northern Taiwan, connecting railways, long-haul highway bus services, Taipei MRT systems and Taipei city bus services.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Airlines to operate Taipei-Shizuoka charter flights
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/09 17:46:14 (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: In tandem with the slated inauguration of Japan's Shizuoka Airport on June 4, the Taipei-based China Airlines (CAL) will operate four charter flights in the first half of the month between the two cities, starting that day, a CAL executive said Wednesday.

Yang Chen, the CAL executive responsible for the Japanese market, told the CNA that he visited Shizuoka Governor Yoshinobu Ishikawa Tuesday and that Ishikawa expressed his pleasure and appreciation over CAL's decision to initially offer two-way charter flights between the two cities on June 4, June 7, June 10 and June 13.

According to Yang, CAL and its affiliate, Mandarin Airlines, have been encouraging Taiwanese tourists to use the new airport if they plan to travel to Mount Fuji or other tourist spots within the vicinity.
The CAL executive said he suggested to Ishikawa that both sides launch promotional activities to boost exchanges.
Yang expressed the hope that the Taipei-Shizuoka charter flight service would be upgraded gradually to regular charters and then to regular commercial flights.
"I expect that Taiwanese passengers will account for 70 percent of business on the route, while Japanese travelers will make up 30 percent," Yang said.

CAL plans to operate at least two monthly charter flights between Taipei and Shizuoka from July to pave the way for regular commercial fights, while Mandarin Airlines is planning to provide charter flights between Taichung in central Taiwan and Shizuoka Prefecture from late June, he added.
Yang said he has invited Ishikawa to fly to Taipei on board the June 4 CAL charter flight and return to Shizuoka from Taichung on a Mandarin charter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung to recruit 10,625 people to ease unemployment

TEXT.P: A Kaohsiung city government official said Wednesday that the city has outlined an enrollment program that will offer 10,625 jobs in an effort to ease unemployment in the face of the continuing recession.

City government Secretary-General Hao Chien-sheng said the jobs on offer will be in various city departments, including the Department of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, the Department of Land Administration and the Bureau of Public Works.
The local government will also train some of the newly enrolled staff to take on work such as gardening, land surveys and other field surveys for special programs.
The southern port city boasts 342 community parks and there is room for the city to improve them, Hao said, adding that some of the new hires will be assigned to tend these areas.

According to the city government, the program was proposed based on the central government's economic stimulation programs that include a plan to provide 150,000 jobs to help those laid off by companies struggling as a result of the global recession.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices rose Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 17.16 points, or 0.39 percent, to close at 4,389.97.

Posting a gain for the third consecutive day, the local bourse opened at the day's high of 4,422.56 and dropped to a low of 4,366.41. A total of 3.04 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$61.5 billion (US$1.83 billion).

Four major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff stocks moving up the most at 3.6 percent. Cement stocks gained 0.7 percent, machinery and electronics issues advanced 0.6 percent and textile stocks rose 0.2 percent.

Four other stock categories lost ground, with construction shares moving down the most at 0.8 percent, followed by plastics and chemicals shares at 0.6 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.4 percent and paper and pulp stocks at 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 745 to 719, with 286 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$770 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese-language school in Israel welcomes returning students: MOFA

TEXT.P: A Chinese-language school in Israel held a welcome-back ceremony recently, as part of its efforts to pass on the language among the offspring of Taiwanese expatriates in the Middle East country, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Wednesday.

The school, founded by overseas Taiwanese living in Israel and located in the town of Modiin near Tel Aviv, holds regular Chinese classes on weekends, from elementary to junior-high level, for the children of Taiwanese expatriates, said Ali Young, deputy director-general of MOFA's Department of West Asian Affairs.

He said the textbooks are usually provided by the Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission and the Ministry of Education, and that the more than 20 students are taught the traditional Chinese writing system.
Currently, there are about 30 Taiwanese living in Israel, most of whom are marriage immigrants, Young said.
A similar Chinese-language school in Jordan also offers classes on weekends, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, falling NT$0.05 to close at NT$33.67.
A total of US$592 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high at NT$33.720 and dropped to a low of 33.602.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's dependence on China not necessarily bad: SEF head

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said Wednesday that Taiwan's economic dependence on China is not necessarily bad and that such a bilateral relationship shows that China still needs Taiwan's highly competitive high-tech sector.

During a keynote speech at a seminar on international trade and economy organized by the Taipei-based China Youth Corps., Chiang told local university students that there is great interdependence in cross-Taiwan Strait economic relations, as Taiwanese entrepreneurs need China's abundant supply of cheap labor while China needs Taiwan's high-tech skills and products.
"I would not say Taiwan is dependent on China, as both sides depend on each other, " said Chiang, adding that the economic interdependence between the two sides is mutually beneficial.

"In the past, Taiwan's exports relied heavily on the U.S. market, but now that such exports have been greatly reduced, China has taken over the role as Taiwan's primary export market, " said Chiang, who added that this role has been bolstered by the large amount of Taiwanese capital invested in China's economy.

"Taiwanese investors in China import Taiwanese and foreign raw and primary materials they need to make their products and then export the finished goods to the European and U.S. markets, " said Chiang.
According to Chiang, the cross-strait economic interdependence is in Taiwan's favor, as China relies so heavily on Taiwan's high-tech and innovation sectors.

"A great part of China's economic development success can be attributed to Taiwanese investors in China, as they have contributed greatly to all sectors of the Chinese economy over the past 20 years," said Chiang.
He warned, however, that Taiwan cannot afford to lose its competitive edge in the high-tech and innovation sectors should China no longer need to rely on Taiwan for high-tech skills and products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to set priorities for liberalization of China investment

TEXT.P: The government will set priorities for its policy on liberalizing the regulations governing China-bound investment, although extensive liberalization is not an option during the present economic downturn, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Wednesday.

According to Fan Liang-tung, executive secretary of the Investment Commission under the ministry, the first phase of liberalization will target investment categories with urgent need, as well as those that have little impact on Taiwan's economy.

As part of its efforts to identify these categories, the MOEA is holding a series of seminars with academics and industrial representatives to gather their opinions, Fan said during a meeting with a group of China-based Taiwanese businessmen.

Data from the commission shows that among the large number of Chinese investment categories that remain on a government list of items in which investment is banned, 101 are related to the manufacturing sector, including IC manufacturing, mid-level and high-level IC packaging and testing, and the array and cell processes of thin film transistor liquid crystal display (TFT-LCD) panels larger than four inches.

In addition, 13 infrastructure projects -- roads, hydraulic facilities, railway systems, harbors, tap water systems, sewage systems, airports, subway systems, garbage incinerators, power plants, power transmission networks, electricity distribution and industrial parks -- are forbidden areas for investment.
Four service categories -- postal services, telecom services, financial services and IC design -- are also off-limits for Taiwanese investors, along with 436 categories in the agriculture sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Energization program' to train 43,500 workers in central Taiwan

TEXT.P: An "energization program" offered by the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) at its Central Training Center in Taichung will provide in-service training for more than 40,000 private sector employees, labor officials said Wednesday.

The officials at the Central Training Center under the CLA's Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training urged private enterprises in central Taiwan to make use of the program to "add extra value" to their workers.

Under the program, the central government will allow a maximum subsidy of NT$10,000 per month for each trainee, and it is estimated that the program will benefit 1,450 companies by helping them train 43,500 workers, the officials said.
In-service training is re-education for employees to help them develop more skills in a specific discipline or occupation.

The Central Training Center, located in Taichung's industrial zone, is said to be the largest of its kind in East Asia. It has been providing free training to job hunters and in-service training to employees in various disciplines since 1976.

DOC.HEADLINE: Thai Puppet show to open Taipei Lantern Festival

TEXT.P: The 2009 Taipei Lantern Festival will feature a touch of Thai culture, as this year's event will open with a traditional Thai puppet show.

The Thai Trade and Economic Office (TTEO) announced Wednesday that the renowned traditional Thai puppet theater, Joe Louis, will perform at the plaza in front of the Taipei city government to mark the start of the 10-day Taipei Lantern Festival on Feb. 6.

"The traditional Thai puppet performance is not only known to every family and household in Thailand, but is also richly artistic, which makes it a national treasure, " the TTEO said in a press release.

The traditional Thai puppet show is unlike most puppet performances, as the the puppeteers do not remain behind screens during the performance, but rather are an integral part of the show, according to the TTEO.
It added that the performance, which will include the epic Indian tale Ramayana (or Ramakien in Thai), will be laden with all kinds of intriguing plots.

The Joe Louis puppet theater company, the only troupe of Thai theatrical puppeteers in existence, won the award for the best traditional performance at the 10th World Festival Puppet Art 2006 in Prague, the Czech Republic.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for February advancing 74 points to end the day at 4,351, with 68,218 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for March gained 77 points to close at 4,316, with 542 contract transactions, while June futures increased 75 points to end at 4,281, with 154 contract transactions.
September futures gained 59 points to close at 4,066, with 39 contract transactions, while December futures increased 59 points to end at 4,025, with seven contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 4,277 for February, 4,239 for March, 4,206 for June 4,007 for September and 3,966 for December.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index increased 17.16 points to finish at 4,389.97, on turnover of NT$61.5 billion (US$1.83 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.
February TE futures gained 3.25 points to close at 171.85, with 3,495 contracts traded, while March TE futures advanced 4.3 points to finish at 172.75, with 35 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.
February TF futures were up 2.6 points to close at 499.6, with 3,630 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures increased 0.6 points to finish at 494, with 36 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hong Kongers also want shopping vouchers
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/09 19:11:18 (By Mandy Wong and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: More than half of Hong Kong residents responding to a recent opinion poll would like to see their government give free shopping vouchers to them as Taiwan's government has done for Taiwanese people, pollsters said Wednesday.

The academic, non-profit Hong Kong Research Association conducted the survey Jan. 25 - Feb. 1 to gauge Hong Kong residents' expectations on how the Hong Kong government, faced with an economic downturn, should spend public money this year.

Fifty-three percent of the respondents support the idea that Hong Kong emulate Taiwan to distribute shopping vouchers to all the citizens in the special administrative region as a means to spur consumption and help revive the flagging domestic economy, according to the association.
Another 31 percent of the respondents disagreed with the idea, according to poll.

Meanwhile, the poll found that 32 percent of the respondents hope that the new budget plan would help enable Hong Kong's economy to continue to flourish; and 21 percent hope that the new year's budget could be spent to help with the disadvantaged groups.

Nineteen percent of the respondents hope that the budget will help create jobs; 9 percent hope the budget could be used to support medium- and small-sized enterprises; and 9 percent hope that the money could be used for educational purposes.

Taiwan's government on Jan. 18 distributed shopping vouchers worth NT$3,600 to Taiwanese citizens and permanent residents in a NT$85.7 billion program that is part of an economic stimulus package to boost domestic consumption.

DOC.HEADLINE: World's 2nd biggest book fair in Taipei focuses on Thailand

TEXT.P: For the first time in its history, the Taipei International Book Exhibition (TIBE) -- considered the world's second largest book fair -- is featuring Thailand as the theme country -- a move which organizers said will help promote cultural exchanges between Taiwan and the Southeast Asian country.

National award-winning books, royal classical works, historical books, prize- winning children's books, and best sellers - all from Thailand - are being displayed at the Thailand pavilion in the week-long book fair at the Taipei World Trade Center, said Risuan Aramcharoen, president of the Publishers and Booksellers Association of Thailand.

While Taiwan and Thailand have maintained close relations in trade and business development over the years, Taiwanese people have been relatively underexposed to Thai literature, according to the TIBE organizer Wednesday.
Seizing the opportunity to promote its culture as well as its literature, Thailand opened its pavilion at the book fair Wednesday with a traditional Thai puppet show.

Taipei Book Fair Foundation Chairman Linden Lin said that it is meaningful for Thailand to be selected as the theme country after Taiwan was invited to take part in the Bangkok International Book Fair as the theme country three years ago.

Exchanges of publications between the two countries will help bilateral relations become closer, Lin said, noting that books telling the history and culture of Thailand help Taiwanese people better understand their neighboring country. So far, most Taiwanese people view Thailand mainly as a vacation destination.

In addition to the book display, a variety of activities will also be staged at the Thai pavilion, including cooking and folk handicraft demonstrations, lectures, and quick Thai language lessons, Risuan said.
The 2009 TIBE has attracted 578 foreign publishers, 200 more than the previous year.
Lin said he expects the number of visitors to grow by 20 percent this year. The 2008 TIBE drew 410,000 visitors.
The TIBE opens from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Feb. 4-9, with extended opening hours to 10 p.m. from Feb. 6-8, according to the organizer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 12,000 Chinese tourists visit Taiwan during holiday: NIA

TEXT.P: The number of Chinese tourists who visited Taiwan during the Lunar New Year holiday from Jan. 24 to Feb. 1 totaled 12,702, a government agency said Wednesday.

According to the National Immigration Agency (NIA) under the Ministry of the Interior, the peak days were Jan. 26, 27 and 28, with the number of tourists from China recorded at 2,695, 2,477 and 2,080, respectively.
The number of arrivals from China on Feb. 1 dropped to 532 as the nine-day holiday was drawing to an end, the NIA said.

For the month of January, Chinese visitor arrivals totaled 19,085, with 59 percent taking direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights, the agency said. The percentage of Chinese travelers to Taiwan who took the charters in 2008 was 34 percent, it noted.
In January this year, 6,955 Chinese visitors chose to travel to Taiwan on commercial flights, while 843 made the trip via the "mini-three links" -- by boat to one of Taiwan's outlying isles.

The number of Chinese visitors to Taiwan in the period June to December last year totalled 53,267, with 18,705 arriving on direct air charters, 31,570 on commercial flights, and 2,992 via the mini-three links, according to the agency's statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City to issue food coupons to needy families in early March

TEXT.P: Taipei City is slated to start issuing food coupons to families in urgent need of economic assistance from March 1, the municipal Bureau of Civil Affairs announced Wednesday.

The bureau is planning to deliver coupons worth NT$5,000 each to about 10,000 households in the initial stage of a program that will last until Dec. 31, bureau officials said, adding that more families with economic difficulties could be included in the follow-up stages.

Families residing in Taipei City, not necessarily those with their households registered here, would be entitled to receive the food vouchers as long as they are reported by their local borough chief to the city's civil affairs bureau and recognized as being "in need of assistance" after family interviews by city officials and respected social figures.
Each household is allowed to receive the coupons once.
The coupons can only be spent on food, such as lunch boxes, bread or rice balls, at the Family Mart chain convenience stores, which means cigarettes, alcoholic products or magazines are excluded.
The ongoing economic downturn has caused many people in Taiwan to lose their jobs, with parents who have children going to school being the worst affected.

Meanwhile, Pingtung County in southern Taiwan will implement a new after-school program in the new semester and issue food vouchers in the coming summer vacation to assist the county's impoverished elementary school and junior high school students, officials said Wednesday.

In addition to an after school academic assistance program already in place, the new after-school program will offer free child care for children from underprivileged families, said Kuo Wen-jui, deputy chief of the county's education department.
The new program will also create job opportunities for the unemployed, Kuo added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economy expected to bottom out in Q2

TEXT.P: A senior economic policy planner forecast Wednesday that Taiwan's sliding economy is likely to bottom out in the second quarter of this year, before beginning a slow recovery.

Hu Chung-ying, deputy chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , made the comment after the Hong Kong-based brokerage house CLSA Asia-Pacific Markets predicted that Taiwan will see a decline of 11 percent in its gross domestic product (GDP) in 2009.
Hu described the prediction "a little too much, " saying there is still a chance that Taiwan would record positive GDP growth this year.

The official said that he would not be as pessimistic as CLSA in predicting Taiwan's economic outlook for 2009, given the the government's launch of a series of stimulus measures, including the shopping voucher program.
While he forecast a drop in GDP growth in the first quarter of the year, Hu said he expects a slow recovery to begin in the third quarter, or in a worst-case senario, in the fourth quarter.
Hu said that the CLSA forecast was the most pessimistic among all those made by international institutions.

For example, he said, the Global Insight forecast in late 2008 predicted that Taiwan's economy will contract by 1.8 percent in 2009, while the International Monetary Fund predicted a growth of 2.2 percent. The Citigroup Global Markets forecast a growth of 1.5 percent, Goldman Sachs forecast a negative growth of 3 percent, and the Economist predicted a negative growth of 2.9 percent, he added.
In Taiwan, the latest prediction, which came from the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research on Jan. 23, forecast the economy would grow by 0.89 percent in 2009.
The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) has predicted the 2009 economy would grow by 2.12 percent while the CEPD set a 2.5 percent growth rate as the national goal.
The DGBAS is scheduled to review its forecast on Feb. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: More young, middle-aged workers applying for unemployment benefits

TEXT.P: The number of young and middle-aged people applying for unemployment benefits has increased since the global financial crisis became apparent last September, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Wednesday.

The CLA said that about half of those who have filed for unemployment benefits for the first time since September are persons who have college education or higher, and nearly 70 percent of them are under 40 years old.
This is largely reflective of the fact that most of the recent layoffs have been among high- and mid-level white collar workers, according to the CLA.
The CLA said that some 64,764 people filed for unemployment benefits for the first time between September and December last year, with the figures showing almost equal numbers of men and women.
The largest number of applicants, some 15,135, were in the age group 25-29, while 44,049 were under 40, accounting for 68 percent of the total.

CLA officials said that since the government's Employment Insurance Law took effect in 2003, the applicants for unemployment benefits had been mostly people with lower education levels and middle-aged or older workers.
The officials attributed the large number of young and middle-aged workers now applying for unemployment benefits to the latest round of layoffs mostly in the high-tech sector.
Also, young people are generally not the breadwinners in their families and would not balk at the idea of filing for unemployment benefits, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA encouraging farmers to resume cultivation of fallow land

TEXT.P: The government will be offering bigger incentives to encourage farmers restart cultivation of fallow lands, the Agriculture and Food Agency under the Cabinet- level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Wednesday.
The plan is aimed at securing the country's food supply and stabilizing food prices on the domestic market in view of the high prices on the world market, said the agency.
Officials of the agency said that, with immediate effect, it will guarantee landowners an income of NT$45,000 (US$1,339) or more per hectare for each harvest.
If the owners lease their farmlands for food crop cultivation for three years in a row, the agency will guarantee an income of over NT$50,000 per hectare for each harvest, the officials said.
The agency will also offer a subsidy of NT$20,000 per hectare to farmers who grow feed corn, while farmers devoted to organic farming will be entitled to NT$15,000 per hectare.

Landowners who cannot resume cultivation of their farms or find tenants to lease them, and instead plant green organic fertilizer, will be granted NT$45,000 per hectare by the agency, according to the officials.
The agency is preparing to hold a series of information sessions in different regions of the country soon to explain the plan to farmers, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA reaffirms sovereignty over Spratlys in South China Sea

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) issued a statement Wednesday reiterating the Republic of China's historical claim to islands and reefs in the South China Sea, including the Spratlys.

The MOFA statement came after the two chambers of the Philippine legislature -- the Senate and House of Representatives -- passed bills Jan. 28 and Feb.2, respectively, to annex some isles and reefs of the Spratly Islands (better known as Nansha in Chinese) and Macclesfield Bank Islands (known locally as Jhongsha) as part of the Philippines' territory.

The MOFA stated that Taiwan's sovereignty claim is beyond doubt and challenge, stressing that all four groups of islands in the South China Sea -- Nansha, Jhongsha, Dongsha (Pratas) Islands and Sisha (Paracel) Islands -- and their surrounding waters are Taiwan's territories from a historical, geographical, factual and international law perspective.
The ministry further said the ROC government will not recognize any move by any other country that occupies or claims sovereignty over any of the four island groups.

Moreover, the MOFA called on the Philippines to negotiate with Taiwan on the South China Sea sovereignty dispute under the principles and in the spirit of the United Nations Charter, the U.N. convention on the Law of Sea and the Declaration on the Conduct of Parties in the South China Sea to resolve the conflicting claims peacefully.

The Spratlys consist of about 180 barren islets, reefs and atolls dotting the world's busiest shipping lanes in the South China Sea. Vietnam, China, Taiwan, the Philippines, Malaysia and Brunei each claim all or part of the low-lying islands, believed to be rich in oil, gas and fishery resources.
Taiwan's effective jurisdiction includes the Dongsha Islands and Taiping Island in the Spratlys.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three export processing zones in Taiwan being refurbished

TEXT.P: A land renewal program to rejuvenate three of Taiwan's export processing zones was 33.28 percent complete as of the end of December last year, the Export Processing Zone (EPZ) Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs indicated Wednesday.

Officials with the EPZ Administration pointed out that the export processing zones in Kaohsiung, Nanzih, and Taichung are nearly 40 years old, and that most of the buildings in the three zones cannot meet the needs of high technology industries.

The administration started the land renewal program in 2006, and as of the end of December last year, 98 buildings in the three zones had been renovated and four others were torn down for reconstruction, representing a 33.28 percent renewal rate.

According to the officials, the EPZ Administration hopes that the renewal program will be over 40 percent complete by the end of 2010, with more than 60 percent of the land plots planted with trees and lawns, so that the three zones will become more attractive to high-tech industries, including the integrated circuit industry and the liquid crystal display industry.
Taiwan has nine export processing zones covering 577.2 hectares. Seven of them are located in southern Taiwan, and all of them are designated tax-bonded zones.
The oldest one, the Kaohsiung EPZ, was partially opened for use in 1966, followed by the Nanzih EPZ in suburban Kaohsiung and the Taichung EPZ in Tanzih township in Taichung County in 1971.
The Siaogang Air Freight Logistics EPZ in Kaohsiung became operational in 2004 and the Chungkang EPZ was inaugurated in early 2006, while the Pingtung EPZ was completed at the end of 2007.
The three smaller ones are Chenggong Logistics EPZ, the Kaohsiung Software Park, and the Linguang EPZ.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hong Kongers also want shopping vouchers
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Feb. 4 (CNA) 02/04/09 19:11:18 (By Mandy Wong and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: More than half of Hong Kong residents responding to a recent opinion poll would like to see their government give free shopping vouchers to them as Taiwan's government has done for Taiwanese people, pollsters said Wednesday.

The academic, non-profit Hong Kong Research Association conducted the survey Jan. 25 - Feb. 1 to gauge Hong Kong residents' expectations on how the Hong Kong government, faced with an economic downturn, should spend public money this year.

Fifty-three percent of the respondents support the idea that Hong Kong emulate Taiwan to distribute shopping vouchers to all the citizens in the special administrative region as a means to spur consumption and help revive the flagging domestic economy, according to the association.
Another 31 percent of the respondents disagreed with the idea, according to poll.

Meanwhile, the poll found that 32 percent of the respondents hope that the new budget plan would help enable Hong Kong's economy to continue to flourish; and 21 percent hope that the new year's budget could be spent to help with the disadvantaged groups.

Nineteen percent of the respondents hope that the budget will help create jobs; 9 percent hope the budget could be used to support medium- and small-sized enterprises; and 9 percent hope that the money could be used for educational purposes.

Taiwan's government on Jan. 18 distributed shopping vouchers worth NT$3,600 to Taiwanese citizens and permanent residents in a NT$85.7 billion program that is part of an economic stimulus package to boost domestic consumption.

DOC.HEADLINE: World's 2nd biggest book fair in Taipei focuses on Thailand

TEXT.P: For the first time in its history, the Taipei International Book Exhibition (TIBE) -- considered the world's second largest book fair -- is featuring Thailand as the theme country -- a move which organizers said will help promote cultural exchanges between Taiwan and the Southeast Asian country.

National award-winning books, royal classical works, historical books, prize- winning children's books, and best sellers - all from Thailand - are being displayed at the Thailand pavilion in the week-long book fair at the Taipei World Trade Center, said Risuan Aramcharoen, president of the Publishers and Booksellers Association of Thailand.

While Taiwan and Thailand have maintained close relations in trade and business development over the years, Taiwanese people have been relatively underexposed to Thai literature, according to the TIBE organizer Wednesday.
Seizing the opportunity to promote its culture as well as its literature, Thailand opened its pavilion at the book fair Wednesday with a traditional Thai puppet show.

Taipei Book Fair Foundation Chairman Linden Lin said that it is meaningful for Thailand to be selected as the theme country after Taiwan was invited to take part in the Bangkok International Book Fair as the theme country three years ago.

Exchanges of publications between the two countries will help bilateral relations become closer, Lin said, noting that books telling the history and culture of Thailand help Taiwanese people better understand their neighboring country. So far, most Taiwanese people view Thailand mainly as a vacation destination.

In addition to the book display, a variety of activities will also be staged at the Thai pavilion, including cooking and folk handicraft demonstrations, lectures, and quick Thai language lessons, Risuan said.
The 2009 TIBE has attracted 578 foreign publishers, 200 more than the previous year.
Lin said he expects the number of visitors to grow by 20 percent this year. The 2008 TIBE drew 410,000 visitors.
The TIBE opens from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Feb. 4-9, with extended opening hours to 10 p.m. from Feb. 6-8, according to the organizer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 12,000 Chinese tourists visit Taiwan during holiday: NIA

TEXT.P: The number of Chinese tourists who visited Taiwan during the Lunar New Year holiday from Jan. 24 to Feb. 1 totaled 12,702, a government agency said Wednesday.

According to the National Immigration Agency (NIA) under the Ministry of the Interior, the peak days were Jan. 26, 27 and 28, with the number of tourists from China recorded at 2,695, 2,477 and 2,080, respectively.
The number of arrivals from China on Feb. 1 dropped to 532 as the nine-day holiday was drawing to an end, the NIA said.

For the month of January, Chinese visitor arrivals totaled 19,085, with 59 percent taking direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights, the agency said. The percentage of Chinese travelers to Taiwan who took the charters in 2008 was 34 percent, it noted.
In January this year, 6,955 Chinese visitors chose to travel to Taiwan on commercial flights, while 843 made the trip via the "mini-three links" -- by boat to one of Taiwan's outlying isles.

The number of Chinese visitors to Taiwan in the period June to December last year totalled 53,267, with 18,705 arriving on direct air charters, 31,570 on commercial flights, and 2,992 via the mini-three links, according to the agency's statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City to issue food coupons to needy families in early March

TEXT.P: Taipei City is slated to start issuing food coupons to families in urgent need of economic assistance from March 1, the municipal Bureau of Civil Affairs announced Wednesday.

The bureau is planning to deliver coupons worth NT$5,000 each to about 10,000 households in the initial stage of a program that will last until Dec. 31, bureau officials said, adding that more families with economic difficulties could be included in the follow-up stages.

Families residing in Taipei City, not necessarily those with their households registered here, would be entitled to receive the food vouchers as long as they are reported by their local borough chief to the city's civil affairs bureau and recognized as being "in need of assistance" after family interviews by city officials and respected social figures.
Each household is allowed to receive the coupons once.
The coupons can only be spent on food, such as lunch boxes, bread or rice balls, at the Family Mart chain convenience stores, which means cigarettes, alcoholic products or magazines are excluded.
The ongoing economic downturn has caused many people in Taiwan to lose their jobs, with parents who have children going to school being the worst affected.

Meanwhile, Pingtung County in southern Taiwan will implement a new after-school program in the new semester and issue food vouchers in the coming summer vacation to assist the county's impoverished elementary school and junior high school students, officials said Wednesday.

In addition to an after school academic assistance program already in place, the new after-school program will offer free child care for children from underprivileged families, said Kuo Wen-jui, deputy chief of the county's education department.
The new program will also create job opportunities for the unemployed, Kuo added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economy expected to bottom out in Q2

TEXT.P: A senior economic policy planner forecast Wednesday that Taiwan's sliding economy is likely to bottom out in the second quarter of this year, before beginning a slow recovery.

Hu Chung-ying, deputy chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , made the comment after the Hong Kong-based brokerage house CLSA Asia-Pacific Markets predicted that Taiwan will see a decline of 11 percent in its gross domestic product (GDP) in 2009.
Hu described the prediction "a little too much, " saying there is still a chance that Taiwan would record positive GDP growth this year.

The official said that he would not be as pessimistic as CLSA in predicting Taiwan's economic outlook for 2009, given the the government's launch of a series of stimulus measures, including the shopping voucher program.
While he forecast a drop in GDP growth in the first quarter of the year, Hu said he expects a slow recovery to begin in the third quarter, or in a worst-case senario, in the fourth quarter.
Hu said that the CLSA forecast was the most pessimistic among all those made by international institutions.

For example, he said, the Global Insight forecast in late 2008 predicted that Taiwan's economy will contract by 1.8 percent in 2009, while the International Monetary Fund predicted a growth of 2.2 percent. The Citigroup Global Markets forecast a growth of 1.5 percent, Goldman Sachs forecast a negative growth of 3 percent, and the Economist predicted a negative growth of 2.9 percent, he added.
In Taiwan, the latest prediction, which came from the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research on Jan. 23, forecast the economy would grow by 0.89 percent in 2009.
The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) has predicted the 2009 economy would grow by 2.12 percent while the CEPD set a 2.5 percent growth rate as the national goal.
The DGBAS is scheduled to review its forecast on Feb. 19.
