DOC.HEADLINE: Pope Benedict meets with ROC legislative speaker
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Feb.4 (CNA) 02/05/09 02:34:06 (By Lin Yu-li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Pope Benedict XVI said Wednesday he has been paying close attention to the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait and is pleased with Taiwan's efforts to promote cross-strait peace.
Benedict made the remarks while meeting with Taiwan's Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng in the Vatican's Paul VI Audience Hall.
Wang, who arrived in Rome Tuesday on the first leg of a European tour that will also take him to France and Belgium, is the first ROC legislative head ever to meet with Pope Benedict.
ROC Ambassador to the Vatican Larry Wang told the CNA in a telephone interview that Wang Jin-pyng's meeting with the pope is of great significance to the country's relations with the Holy See.

According to the ambassador, Wang Jin-pyng conveyed President Ma Ying-jeou's regards for Benedict and expressed Taiwan people's gratitude for the pontiff's long-term blessing for Taiwan and concern for cross-strait ties.

Wang Jin-pyng also briefed Benedict on the Ma administration's pragmatic policy toward cross-strait relations and its strenuous efforts to maintain peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and entire Asia.
Wang further reminded the pope that if he visits Asia in the future, the itinerary should include a stop in Taiwan.
For his part, Benedict praised the ROC government's efforts to improve relations with China and to foster cross-strait amity and trust.
At the end of the meeting, Wang presented a glassware symbolizing peace and joy to the pontiff.
Wang was accompanied by Larry Wang and 10 other legislators during the audience with Benedict.
Larry Wang said Benedict has consistently kept close tabs on cross-strait relations.
According to the ambassador, the pope took the initiative to publicly commend a thaw in the once icy cross-strait ties when he met with 177 foreign diplomats stationed in the Vatican Jan 8.

The Vatican is the only European country that maintains formal diplomatic ties with Taiwan. Former President Chen Shui-bian attended the funeral of Pope John Paul II four years ago, making him the first ROC president to visit the Vatican since the two countries forged diplomatic ties in 1942.
On the first day of their current European tour, Wang Jin-pyng and other lawmakers visited the Italian Senate where they were greeted by thunderous applause from Italian senators.
Italian Senate Speaker Renato Schifani held talks with Wang and briefed him on Italian legislative operations.
A pro-Taiwan group in the Italian parliament, headed by Valter Zanetta, hosted a dinner in honor of the ROC legislative delegation.
Following the Vatican visit, the delegation will travel to Sicily to take part in religious festive celebrations.
Later on, Wang will address the European Parliament, which is holding its plenary session in Strasbourg, France.
Wang is also expected to call on European Parliament President Hans-Gert Pottering.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 5, or the 11th day of the first month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1596: Japanese Shogun Hideyoshi Toyotomi puts 26 Catholic converts to death in Nagasaki after he banned Christianity earlier in the year.
1792: Tippo of Mysore, India is defeated and cedes half of Mysore to the British.
1788: Sir Robert Peel, British prime minister and founder of the Metropolitan Police, is born.
1900: Adlai Stevenson, American statesman and ambassador whose liberal views caused him trouble during the McCarthy witch hunts, is born.
1914: Andreas Papandreou, Greek prime minister, is born.
1917: Mexico becomes a federated republic of 28 states.
1922: The first issue of the U.S. magazine Reader's Digest rolls off the presses.
1924: French automaker Renault launches an epoch-marking car safari in the Sahara.
1929: The Nationalist government changes the name of Fengtien province to Liaoning province.
1945: Gen. Douglas MacArthur and U.S. troops enter Manila. On Oct. 20, 1944, MacArthur and his forces landed on the Philippine island of Leyte, fulfilling his pledge to return to the Philippines.
1955: U.S. President Dwight Einsenhower instructs the Seventh Fleet to assist Nationalist troops in withdrawing from the island of Tachen, opposite mainland China's Chechiang province.
1959: The Republic of China's Executive Yuan adopts a resolution to open Hualien port in eastern Taiwan as an international port.
1959: The Ilan branch of Taiwan's East-West Highway is formally opened to traffic.
1962: A total solar eclipse occurs in the morning.
1962: President Charles de Gaulle of France calls for independence for Algeria.
1971: U.S. Apollo 14 astronauts land on the moon.
1974: Thirteen-year-old Mats Wermelin of Sweden scores all 272 points in a basketball game.
1976: A major earthquake rocks Guatemala, killing nearly 23,000 people.
1977: Brazilian soccer star Pele arrives in Taiwan for a three-day visit.
1990: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev indicates that the Communist Party must abandon its monopoly on power.
1990: Rafael Calderon Fournier wins the presidential election in Costa Rica.
1996: Rene Preval succeeds Jean-Bertrand Aristide in a peaceful transfer of power in Haiti.
1997: Switzerland's three banking giants announce the creation of a 100 million Swiss franc Holocaust memorial fund.
1999: Marshall Islands President Imata Kabua and his wife Hiromi Kabua arrive in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1999: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou awards a plaque to popular movie star Andy Lau in honor of his appointment as "Taipei Rapid Transit Ambassador," which includes the right to travel on the Taipei MRT for free for the rest of his life.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When three men meet together, one of them who is anxious to learn can always learn something from the other two. He can profit by the good example of the one and avoid the bad example of the other."

DOC.HEADLINE: Deaflympics Taipei 2009 expected to draw over 10,000 foreign visitors

TEXT.P: The Deaflympics 2009, scheduled to be held in September in Taipei, is expected to attract over 10,000 foreign visitors, the city government said Wednesday.
The visitors will include 3,600 athletes from 81 countries, as well as their coaches and families, said Taipei Deputy Mayor Wu Ching-chi.
He said Taipei is very honored to have the opportunity to host the games, which he said will "let Taiwan embrace the world and the world embrace Taiwan."
The event will also help Taipei become more disabled-friendly, he added.
The deputy mayor made the remarks in a news conference held to introduce the Deaflympics lantern zone at the upcoming annual Taipei Lantern Festival.

This year's festival -- celebrating the Year of the Ox -- is slated for February 6-15 at several venues, including the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall, Taipei City Hall, and the section between Civic Plaza and the Renai Traffic Circle.
In addition to the Deaflympics, the festival will feature a variety of other themes, including tradition, happiness, prayer, love and global scenery.

The CLA said that some 64,764 people filed for unemployment benefits for the first time between September and December last year, with the figures showing almost equal numbers of men and women.
The largest number of applicants, some 15,135, were in the age group 25-29, while 44,049 were under 40, accounting for 68 percent of the total.

CLA officials said that since the government's Employment Insurance Law took effect in 2003, the applicants for unemployment benefits had been mostly people with lower education levels and middle-aged or older workers.
The officials attributed the large number of young and middle-aged workers now applying for unemployment benefits to the latest round of layoffs mostly in the high-tech sector.
Also, young people are generally not the breadwinners in their families and would not balk at the idea of filing for unemployment benefits, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA encouraging farmers to resume cultivation of fallow land

TEXT.P: The government will be offering bigger incentives to encourage farmers restart cultivation of fallow lands, the Agriculture and Food Agency under the Cabinet- level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Wednesday.
The plan is aimed at securing the country's food supply and stabilizing food prices on the domestic market in view of the high prices on the world market, said the agency.
Officials of the agency said that, with immediate effect, it will guarantee landowners an income of NT$45,000 (US$1,339) or more per hectare for each harvest.
If the owners lease their farmlands for food crop cultivation for three years in a row, the agency will guarantee an income of over NT$50,000 per hectare for each harvest, the officials said.
The agency will also offer a subsidy of NT$20,000 per hectare to farmers who grow feed corn, while farmers devoted to organic farming will be entitled to NT$15,000 per hectare.

Landowners who cannot resume cultivation of their farms or find tenants to lease them, and instead plant green organic fertilizer, will be granted NT$45,000 per hectare by the agency, according to the officials.
The agency is preparing to hold a series of information sessions in different regions of the country soon to explain the plan to farmers, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three export processing zones in Taiwan being refurbished

TEXT.P: A land renewal program to rejuvenate three of Taiwan's export processing zones was 33.28 percent complete as of the end of December last year, the Export Processing Zone (EPZ) Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs indicated Wednesday.

Officials with the EPZ Administration pointed out that the export processing zones in Kaohsiung, Nanzih, and Taichung are nearly 40 years old, and that most of the buildings in the three zones cannot meet the needs of high technology industries.

The administration started the land renewal program in 2006, and as of the end of December last year, 98 buildings in the three zones had been renovated and four others were torn down for reconstruction, representing a 33.28 percent renewal rate.

According to the officials, the EPZ Administration hopes that the renewal program will be over 40 percent complete by the end of 2010, with more than 60 percent of the land plots planted with trees and lawns, so that the three zones will become more attractive to high-tech industries, including the integrated circuit industry and the liquid crystal display industry.
Taiwan has nine export processing zones covering 577.2 hectares. Seven of them are located in southern Taiwan, and all of them are designated tax-bonded zones.
The oldest one, the Kaohsiung EPZ, was partially opened for use in 1966, followed by the Nanzih EPZ in suburban Kaohsiung and the Taichung EPZ in Tanzih township in Taichung County in 1971.
The Siaogang Air Freight Logistics EPZ in Kaohsiung became operational in 2004 and the Chungkang EPZ was inaugurated in early 2006, while the Pingtung EPZ was completed at the end of 2007.
The three smaller ones are Chenggong Logistics EPZ, the Kaohsiung Software Park, and the Linguang EPZ.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Lawyer hails AIT response to ex-lawmaker's citizenship issue

TEXT.P: The lawyer of former ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lee Ching-an said Wednesday that the latest U.S. explanation of its laws concerning loss of citizenship backs Lee's claim that she legally lost her U.S. citizenship when she took public office in Taiwan more than a decade ago.

Lee Yung-jan was referring to a Jan.16 letter from the head office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) that stated loss of U.S. citizenship occurs when a citizen "voluntarily commits a statutorily defined potentially expatriating act with the intention of relinquishing U.S. citizenship."
The AIT is a quasi-official U.S. institution authorized to handle relations with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

According to Lee Yung-jan, Lee Ching-an's taking of an oath of allegiance to the Republic of China when she assumed office as a Taipei city councilor in 1994 and her use of her ROC passport to enter and exit the United States since then were concrete acts that proved her intent to give up her U.S. citizenship.
"We believe that the latest AIT letter marks a favorable development in the case," Lee Yung-jan said.
The Central Election Commission (CEC) is scheduled to meet Friday to discuss Lee's alleged "dual citizenship" and whether her election to public office prior to 2008 should be nullified.
It remains to be seen whether the latest AIT explanation will inform the CEC commissioners' findings on Lee Ching-an's citizenship status before 2008.

Lee Ching-an, who was sworn in for a fourth legislative term Feb. 1, 2008, was found the following month to have never formally renounced her U.S. citizenship, even though she had held public office in Taiwan since 1994.

She resigned Jan. 8 just as opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) politicians were promoting a campaign to recall her and pro-DPP civic groups were preparing to besiege the legislature to protest the lawmaking body's failure to act against her.

Taiwan's Nationality Act requires public officials holding dual citizenship to surrender their foreign citizenship before assuming public office and to obtain a certificate as proof within one year of taking office.
The law also requires that those officials who retain foreign citizenship be removed from their posts.

Calls for Lee to be formally relieved of her seat mounted after U.S. authorities, in response to an inquiry from Taiwan, confirmed in late 2008 that she "has previously been documented as a U.S. citizen with a U.S. passport and that no subsequent loss of U.S. citizenship has been documented."

But in a letter dated Nov. 22, 2008 to Taiwan's representative office in Washington, D.C., AIT Managing Director Barbara Schrage also wrote that U.S. citizens serving in a foreign government "may have committed an expatriating act if they do so with the intent to relinquish their U.S. nationality."

Schrage further wrote that while the U.S. Department of State has not made any determination regarding loss of citizenship for any individual Taiwanese lawmaker, "it could do so based on evidence that he or she committed a potentially expatriating act with the intention of relinquishing U.S. nationality."

CEC Secretary-General Teng Tien-yow said earlier this week that the commission has received a response from the AIT to an inquiry regarding U.S. laws and regulations on the acquisition and loss of U.S. citizenship.

According to Teng, the CEC had asked the U.S. to clarify whether Taiwanese lawmakers or city councilors would automatically lose their status as U.S. citizens once they take the oath of office in Taiwan, and whether or not they need to apply to relinquish their citizenship or have U.S. authorities invalidate their citizenship.

Schrage replied in a terse letter Jan. 16 that as stated in her previous letter, "loss of U.S. citizenship occurs when a citizen voluntarily commits a statutorily defined potentially expatriating act with the intention of relinquishing U.S. citizenship," political sources said.
A group of DPP legislators have filed a complaint with the Taipei District Prosecutors Office accusing Lee of forgery and fraud.

The legislators alleged that by holding dual citizenship while in public office, Lee defrauded the public coffers of over NT$100 million in salary as a Taipei City councilor between 1994 and 1998 and as a legislator from 1999 to 2009, and they demanded that she return the "illicit gains."
Lee has been barred from leaving Taiwan pending prosecutorial investigations into fraud and forgery allegations against her.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three business tycoons to attend regional conference: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan will be represented by three business tycoons at this year's first meeting of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation Business Advisory Council (ABAC) , which will take place in New Zealand next week, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.

Paul W. L. Chang, director general of MOFA's Department of International Organizations, said the delegation will be comprised of Jeffrey Koo, chairman & CEO of the Chinatrust Financial Holding Co., Theodore M.H. Huang, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce, and Henry Kao, vice chairman of I-Mei Foods Co.

The ABAC, established in 1995, is a group of high-level businessmen drawn from the private sector. It meets four times a year to prepare its annual report that advises APEC leaders on specific business sector priorities such as trade and investment liberalization.
APEC is the acronym of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation, a forum for 21 Pacific Rim countries or regions to discuss regional economy, cooperation, trade and investment.

This year's first meeting, which will be held in Wellington from Feb. 9-12, is expected to focus on the global economic and financial crisis and ways in which economies could mitigate its effects, according to the organizer.
Other items on the agenda will include accelerating regional economic integration, championing a model of sustainable growth, and enhancing connectivity, the organizer said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education coupon plan still in the works: CEPD

TEXT.P: Brushing off media speculation that the government has aborted its recently proposed education coupon program, the country's top economic planning agency said Thursday that the plan is still alive and its details are being worked out by the relevant government agencies.

Liao Yao-tsung, chief secretary of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , said the Ministry of Education (MOE) is working on the regulations that will determine eligibility for the benefits under the two-year plan, which will cost an estimated NT$20 billion (US$525 million) and is being designed exclusively for highly educated white collar workers who have lost their jobs during the recent economic downturn.
"We urge the public to be patient and not to make speculations before the details of the plan are finalized, " said Liao.
According to Liao, specifics of the program, such as the amount of money to each recipient and the name of the program, are still being discussed.

Once the details are finalized, the government will offer subsidies for the re- training of eligible white-collar workers, but will set a ceiling on the amount each individual could receive, he added.
"The plan is part of a special economic stimulus package under which the government will inject NT$500 billion over the next four years into public infrastructure projects," said Liao.

In addition, Liao said that the education plan is not only aimed at helping to re-train the country's approximately 100,000 unemployed educated white collar workers, but is also designed to improve the level of education in the country and nurture a new generation of highly trained professionals.

According to the CEPD, the jobless rate rose to a five-year high of 5.03 percent last December, which translated into 549,000 jobless people, 220,000 of whom were graduates of higher education institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan needs to minimize China threat: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou reiterated Thursday that Taiwan needs to minimize the threat posed by China in order to uphold the country's best interests.

In line with this goal, Ma said, the government has adopted a China policy that is aimed at maintaining cross-Taiwan Strait stability and promoting regional peace to safeguard the security of the Taiwan people.

Alongside the recent improvements in relations with China, Ma said, his administration will seek further progress by encouraging the two sides to continue to put aside their political differences and work more closely together to create a "win-win" situation.

While doing so, Taiwan's military must not relax its vigilance, but rather should maintain its readiness, Ma said, noting that strong defense preparedness was what has protected Taiwan from possible attacks by China over the past decades.
According to the president, the purpose of defense is to achieve peace, rather than to wage war.
However, Taiwan's efforts to avoid war with China does not mean it is afraid of war, the president stressed.
In the coming year, Ma said, his administration will continue working toward its goals of introducing a voluntary military service system and streamlining and modernizing the country's armed forces.
Ma made the remarks while presiding over a military promotion ceremony.

In the latest military personnel reshuffle, Deputy Defense Minister Adm. Lin Chen-yi was promoted to the post of chief of General Staff, replacing Gen. Hou Shou-yeh, who has been appointed as a strategic adviser to the president.

Meanwhile, Army Commanding General Chao Shih-chang succeeded Lin as deputy defense minister, and the post vacated by Chao was filled by Yang Tien-hsiao, formerly head of the General Political Warfare Bureau under the Ministry of National Defense.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shares lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices dropped Thursday, with the Taiwan stock exchange's weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 26.72 points, or 0.6 percent, to close at 4,363.25.
The local bourse opened at 4,380.80 and fluctuated between 4,422.41 and 4,363.25. A total of 2.85 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$55.55 billion (US$1.52 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile shares advancing 0.8 percent.

The other seven major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff stocks moving down the most at 1.4 percent. Machinery and electronics stocks fell 1.0 percent, construction shares and banking and financial stocks both dropped 0.7 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks shed 0.5 percent, and cement issues as well as paper and pulp issues both lost 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 987 to 537, with 225 stocks remaining unchanged. Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$876 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices mostly lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Thursday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for February falling 82 points to close at 4,270, with 82,296 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for March lost 81 points to finish at 4,234, with 524 contracts traded, while June futures rose 16 points to end at 4,297, with 21 contracts traded.
September futures fell 66 points to close at 4,000, with 32 contract transactions, while December futures lost 95 points to finish at 3,930, with 23 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 4,352 for February, 4,315 for March, 4,281 for June, 4,066 for September and 4,025 for December.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 26.72 points to finish at 4,363.25, on turnover of NT$55.55 billion (US$1.52 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.
February TE futures fell 4.55 points to close at 168.35, with 3,768 contracts traded, while March TE futures lost 5.75 points to finish at 167, with 30 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

February TF futures were down 8 points to close at 492.2, with 3,483 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures decreased 6.8 points to finish at 487.2, with 25 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHA observer status 'necessary first step' for Taiwan: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's admission to the World Health Assembly (WHA) -- the top decision-making arm of the World Health Organization -- as an observer would be "a necessary first step" to safeguarding the health rights of the Taiwanese people, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.

Gaining observer status could also serve as an initial step to Taiwan's participation in the mechanisms and activities of the WHO, such as meetings of experts, Paul W. L. Chang, director general of MOFAs Department of International Organization, said at a press briefing.
However, as Taiwan and China have not yet held formal negotiations on the issue, Chang said, the MOFA is under pressure to find a mutually acceptable resolution before the WHA convenes in May.

Since Taiwan's participation in international organizations in the past has been achieved by means of "special arrangements, " Chang said the stance of Beijing officials will again play apivotal role when the WHA issue is raised.

The ministry is currently studying all possible proposals that would not only help to achieve the country's goal of joining the WHA this year as an observer, but would also ensure Taiwan's full rights if it admitted into the assembly, he added.
According to MOFA spokesman Henry Chen, the government will first seek to negotiate with China via non-official channels because the WHA issue is a political one.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD still working on feasibility study on cross-strait bridge

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) has been authorized to study the feasibility of building a bridge between Taiwan's outlying Kinmen island and China's port city of Xiamen, Executive Yuan spokesman Su Jun-pin said Thursday.

Su said the CEPD has no timetable to complete the study on the feasibility of building a bridge connecting Kinmen and the Dadeng Island outside Xiamen City, and that the results will be publicized when the study is finished.

Su discounted a United Daily News report on the matter, saying it was false. The UDN reported that President Ma Ying-jeou directed the Executive Yuan Wednesday to come up with a plan soon for building the bridge, being called the "Jin-Deng Bridge."
Su explained that Ma was just inquiring about progress in the CEPD's feasibility assessment, but was not pushing for a speedy completion of the study.
Meanwhile, Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng said Ma's directive on the matter is welcome and inspirational to Kinmen's residents.
"It demonstrates that Ma is a trusted leader whose campaign promises were not lip-service and that he attaches equal importance to the development of Taiwan proper and the offshore areas, " Lee said.
Lee expressed the hope that the CEPD study will be completed sooner rather than later.

According to Lee, the Kinmen county government in 2004 began to study the possibility of building of a bridge between Kinmen and Xiamen. The county government has drafted three plans for the proposed project, he said.
Plan A is a 10.3-km bridge that would span Wulungshan on the Kinmen's side, China's Xiaodeng Island and Jiaoyu Isle, and Xiamen's Dadeng Island.
Plan B is a straight-line 8.6 km-bridge connecting Wulungshan and Dadeng Island, the shortest structure of the three on the drawing board.
Plan C is a 11.4-km bridge between Wulungshan and Fujian Province's Lienhe City.
The costs of the three plans range from NT$12.7 billion (US$377.98 million) to NT$16.6 billion, Lee said.

Lee said the Kinmen county government would suggest that the Cabinet use Plan B if indeed a cross-strait bridge is to be built, given that the second plan is the least costly and the bridge is the shortest.
Meanwhile, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) blasted the cross- strait bridge proposal by the Ma administration.

Panning the decision as "premature, " DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said what the administration should be doing now in the face of global economic recession is working to revive the flagging domestic economy, rather than bringing Taiwan into China's fold step-by-step.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan sticks to target of 2.5% GDP growth for 2009: CEPD

TEXT.P: The government's target to attain a 2.5 percent economic growth for 2009 has remained unchanged despite prevailing pessimism about the economic outlook, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Thursday.
Liao Yao-tzung, chief secretary of the council, explained that economic targets are always higher than predictions because they represent objectives that the government is working toward.

Liao made the comment in the wake of a media report that the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), in light of the worsening economic situation in the country, is likely to revise its economic growth projection downward when it releases its latest forecast on Feb. 19.

While the DGBAS has previously predicted that Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) will increase by 2.12 percent in 2009, the report cited a DGBAS official as saying that growth of over 2 percent has now appeared unlikely and that actual growth may stand at just over 1 percent.
The Hong Kong-based brokerage firm CLSA Asia-Pacific Markets recently predicted that Taiwan's GDP will decline by 11 percent in 2009.
Liao, however, said forecasts by brokerage firms tend to be "extreme."

He said the forecast by CLSA was based solely on Taiwan's performance in exports and private investment, which could be misleading because it did not take into account efforts made by the government and possible increase in domestic demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan makers to cash in on China's rural home appliance project

TEXT.P: Taiwan's electronics manufacturers operating in China are expected to benefit from the expansion of a subsidy program launched by the Chinese government to help farmers buy home appliances, the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) said Thursday.

In an effort to jumpstart the consumer economy and lift the living standard of the rural population, China's Ministry of Commerce introduced a scheme Dec. 1, 2008 under which the government is subsidizing 13 percent of the cost of color TV sets, mobile phones, refrigerators and washing machines purchased by farmers in 14 provinces.
The scheme was further expanded this month to include the whole country and four other products -- computers, water heaters, motorbikes and air-conditioners.

According to China's Ministry of Commerce estimates, the subsidy scheme will generate sales of 150 billion yuan (US$21.99 billion) per year on average, and the expansion will spur an additional 60 billion yuan in annual sales.

According to the IDB under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Sampo Corp., one of Taiwan's main appliance makers, has been cashing in on the policy, as it has won a big order for the supply of refrigerators.
The IDB said Taiwan's information technology industry, which is a worldwide leader, is likely to win the bid to supply computers to China's rural regions.

In addition, Taiwan's contract manufacturers, with their excellent cost control ability, can collaborate with China's electronics product distributors to bid for computer manufacturing services in rural China.

Upstream suppliers of electronics components are also likely to make inroads into the Chinese market as a result of the policy. Several China TV makers have already placed orders for LCD panels produced by Taiwan's Chi Mei Optoelectronics. To date, Chi Mei has obtained 100 percent of the orders for 26-inch LCD TV panels and 60 percent of those for 22-inch panels, under the program, according to the IDB.

AU Optronics and Chi Mei have signed supply deals with nine major color TV manufacturers in China, under which the two major flat-panel makers will supply more than 12 million units to Chinese companies. This will translate into NT$72.2 billion in sales revenue, the IDB added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2009 Miss Taiwan Beauty Contest to be launched in April

TEXT.P: The first round of competition in the 2009 Miss Taiwan Beauty Contest will be launched in April, organizers said Thursday.

Speaking at a press conference in Taipei, Lina Pan, president of the Republic of China Beauty Consultation and Development Association, said the first round of competition is scheduled to be held at the beginning of April, while finals will take place in July at the Grand Hotel in Taipei.
"We will select suitable candidates during the preliminary stage of the contest from the northern, central and southern areas of the country," said Pan.
Aspiring contestants must be between the ages of 18 and 30, taller than 160 cm, unmarried, must never have given birth, and must have high-school education or higher, Pan said.
The organizing committee will accept registrations for the contest until March 15, she said.
"In the Miss Taiwan Beauty Contest, which is held once every two years, we are very particular about the transparency of the judging process," said Pan.
The organizing committee has always done its best to make sure that the judges' decisions are fair and objective, she added.
Pan said that in light of the tight economic situation, the organizing committee has lowered the registration fee for the beauty contest from the usual NT$3,000 (US$90) to NT$1,000.
According to Pan, in a new segment that has been added to this year's competition, the contestants will be required to wear a costume that represents their own heritage.
"The costumes can range from traditional Chinese dresses to indigenous outfits," said Pan, adding that the new category was designed to promote Taiwan's rich and diverse culture.

According to the event's organizers, the winner of this year's Miss Taiwan Beauty Contest will receive a prize of NT$300,000 (US$8,892) and will have a chance to participate in local and international charity and cultural exchange events.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, increasing NT$0.035 to close at NT$33.705.
A total of US$588 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.772 and fluctuated between NT$33.590 and NT$33.772.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan keen to be listed as foot-and-mouth disease free country

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to be listed as a country free from food-and-mouth disease (FMD) by the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) next year, if no new suspicious cases are reported during this transitional year, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Thursday.

Under OIE guidelines, Taiwan is entitled to apply for the status as a FMD-free country with the OIE before its annual meeting slated for May 2010 should no more suspicious cases erupt in the country and no vaccines are given to the animals from now until May of next year, COA officials said.

As an outbreak of the disease would impact a country's meat exports, the OIE imposes very strict regulations in approving a country's application to be listed as a FMD-free country, the officials said.

Once a country has an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease, it could take up to 40 years for it to eventually be listed as a FMD-free country, as was the case in some European countries, officials noted.
After the first FMD case broke out in Taiwan on March 20, 1997, Taiwan has been trying to stamp out the disease as quickly as possible, they added.
Since then, all pig farms and slaughter houses around Taiwan have continuously conducted disinfections to maintain a clean environment and prevent the spread of viruses.

At the same time, the percentage of pigs at nationwide hog farms receiving anti- FMD vaccine injections has dropped from 50 percent last November to the current level of less than 10 percent on average at each farm, moving toward a zero injection rate so as to meet the OIE's requirements, according to the COA officials.

They said the COA will step up efforts to monitor relevant practices regarding vaccine injections in coming months, and that Taiwan will be able to apply for the FMD-free status with the OIE in May next year if no fresh suspicious cases of the disease are reported in Taiwan from the current critical time until next May.

Taiwan used to raise as many as 12 million pigs per year in the peak years, with 7 million exported to Japan annually, according to the COA officials. Taiwan now raises only about 6.4 million pigs a year, mainly for local consumption, the officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Intriguing matches to open Davis Cup tie against Kazakhstan

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Wang Yeu-tzuoo and Chen Ti, both players in transition, will try to make up for the loss of the country's best player when Taiwan hosts Kazakhstan in a preliminary Asia/Oceania Zone Group I Davis Cup tie that begins Friday.

Taiwan's top player Lu Yen-hsun, now ranked a career best 58 after reaching the third round of the Australian Open, will miss the tie with a knee injury, dealing a potentially severe blow to the team.

His absence means Wang, who was ranked as high as 85th in 2006 but has been sidelined for most of the past year with a persistent wrist injury, and Chen, who has completely overhauled his game in the past six weeks, including changing his grip, will play singles for Taiwan.

In Friday's opening matches, beginning at 1 p.m. at the Sinjhuang Gymnasium in Taipei County, world No. 375 Chen will take on 145th-ranked Mikhail Kukushkin, followed by Wang against world No. 119 Andrey Golubev, who beat Marat Safin late last year and is capable of playing with the world's best if he gets hot.

Taiwan has tentatively paired Yang Tsung-hua, the top-ranked junior in the world in 2008 and Yi Chu-huan, a doubles specialist added to the lineup after Lu pulled out, in Saturday's doubles, which also begin at 1 p.m., but that could change depending on the outcome of Friday's singles matches.

Both Wang and Chen will likely be rusty, having not played competitively in the past few months. Wang has played a mere five tournaments since last year's Australian Open, and only began hitting balls at the end of November when he felt his wrist was better.
Chen last played matches in November, but hopes the improvement he has made to his serve will make up for any lack of match toughness against a foe reputed for his steadiness.

Although the tie may not be an attractive match-up on paper, it is full of intrigue. Kazakhstan has never been known as a tennis power, but the country has invested heavily in the game recently and enlisted the services of three Russians, including the 21-year-old Golubev and Kukushkin, to represent it in international play.

Taiwan earned promotion to Group I in 2004, but despite the presence of top-100 talents Lu Yen-hsun and Wang, it has failed over the past five years to get a crack at the World Group playoffs, the gateway to the World Group, the top level of Davis Cup.
With both Lu and Wang in their mid-20s and most future ties likely to be played on the road, this year's competition was seen as the best opportunity for Taiwan to finally achieve a breakthrough.
But that was before Lu injured his knee. And being drawn to play Kazakhstan in the preliminary round, necessary because Group I needed to narrow its nine-team field to eight, has not helped.

Taiwan beat Kazakhstan 3-2 in Almaty last year in a relegation round playoff behind Lu and Chen, but neither Golubev or Kukushkin played in that tie because they had yet to gain Kazakhstan citizenship.

Now the stakes are higher and the competition tougher, but if Taiwan beats Kazakhstan, it will host India March 6-8, when this year's Davis Cup competition begins in earnest. A win over India and then over either Australia or Thailand in May would send Taiwan into the World Group playoffs later in the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwans youth delegation ready to depart for Japan: MOFA

TEXT.P: A Taiwan youth delegation will depart for Japan Friday for a goodwill visit, as part of efforts by the two countries to further enhance bilateral ties, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Thursday.

Speaking at a pre-departure press conference, Foreign Minister Francisco H. L. Ou said that the youth program, part of the Special Taiwan-Japan partnership framework for 2009, will extend the traditional friendship between the two countries from ayoung stage.

Ou expressed his hope that the 108 high school students in the delegation, who will be accompanied by 20 journalists, will serve as competent young diplomats and introduce Taiwans culture to Japanese youngsters.
As Japan expanded the size of the delegation invited to visit the country this year, Ou promised that Taiwan will do the same in return.

In addition, Ou said, the government will push for the signing of a reciprocal "working holiday" deal with Japan, which would allow young adults from each country to travel to the other on working vacations. This, in turn, would enhance mutual understanding among the younger generations of the two countries, said Ou.

Meanwhile, Saito Masaki, chief representative of the Japan Interchange Association's Taipei Office, which acts as the de-facto Japanese embassy in Taiwan, said that in order to maintain good Japan-Taiwan ties, mutual understanding and trust should be built among young adults of the two countries.

He hoped that after the visit to Japan, the young delegates will not only gain a better understanding of the neighboring country, but will also reflect on their own culture and deepen their knowledge of Taiwan s culture and history.
Taiwan has designated 2009 as the year for bolstering its special partnership with Japan, focusing on trade and investment, culture, tourism, student exchanges and dialogue, according to MOFA.

DOC.HEADLINE: President decorates baseball legend

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou conferred the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on baseball legend Sadaharu Oh Thursday in recognition of his contributions to the sport of baseball and to promoting friendship between Taiwanese and Japanese people.
Upon receiving the prestigious medal, Oh, known in Taiwan as Wang Chen-chih and baseball's all-time home run king, said it was the greatest honor of his life to be decorated by President Ma.
Oh, who retired from the Yomiuri Giants in 1980 at the age of 40, hit 868 home runs during his career, the most hit by a player in any professional league around the world.

He said he has been involved in baseball for five decades and baseball has left him a lot of beautiful memories. Because of baseball, Oh has been able to gain fame and meet famous people from all sectors.

Oh, the son of a Chinese father and a Japanese mother and a Republic of China citizen who has never forgotten his Chinese heritage despite spending most of his life in Japan, said he anticipates spending more time in his retirement to promote the love of baseball among youths and children.
Ma also played host to Oh over a luncheon at the Presidential Office Thursday.
Later in the day, Oh paid a courtesy call on ruling Kuomintang Chairman Wu Po- hsiung, with whom Oh has been well acquainted over the past two decades.

Wu gave two photos to Oh as souvenirs -- one depicting Oh bringing the torch into a Taipei arena to symbolize the opening of the national games in Taiwan in 1989 and the other showing Wu, in his capacity as Taipei city mayor, presenting Oh with a certificate of honorary citizen of Taipei. Wu served as Taipei mayor from 1988-1990.
In return, Oh presented Wu with a baseball bearing his signature.
The two agreed to meet again in May when Oh will once again set foot in Taiwan for another baseball promotion event.

DOC.HEADLINE: 13,392 foreign workers remain employed in Kaohsiung City

TEXT.P: A total of 13,392 foreign workers remain employed in Kaohsiung City in southern Taiwan, and companies forcing local workers to take unpaid leave will be targeted by the city to help ease the rising jobless rate, the city's Bureau of Labor Affairs said Thursday.
The local manufacturing industry has the largest number of foreign workers, 6,502, followed by the care giving sector with 5,896 employees, according to statistics compiled by the bureau.
In terms of nationality, the highest number of foreign workers, 5,666, are from Indonesia, followed by the Philippines with 5,003, Vietnam with 2,365, and Thailand with 1,358, the figures show.

To fight a growing jobless rate brought about by the current economic downturn, the city's labor affairs bureau has demanded that companies employ more local workers to fill new job vacancies, and that they repatriate foreign workers upon expiration of their contracts, bureau deputy director Hsieh Lee-li said.
Several high-tech companies repatriated their foreign workers at the beginning of the year, based on this order, Hsieh noted.
Last year, a total of 10,229 Kaohsiung citizens filed claims for unemployment benefits.
Kaohsiung is Taiwan's second-largest city and relies heavily on manufacturing businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two more plead guilty to helping ex-first family launder money

TEXT.P: Two more defendants pleaded guilty to helping former President Chen Shui-bian and his family launder money, as the trial of corruption and money laundering cases involving the former first family continued Thursday at the Taipei District Court.

The latest to plead guilty were Chen Chun-ying, a sister-in-law of former first lady Wu Shu-jen, and Kuo Chuan-ching, former chairman of Rich Development Inc., who allegedly gave bribes to the former first family.

Prior to this, five others had also pleaded guilty, namely the former president son's Chen Chih-chung and daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching, the former first lady's elder brother Wu Ching-mao, and her friends Tsai Ming-che and Tsai Ming- chieh. Their names were all on a long list of intermediaries allegedly used by Wu to wire and secretly stash huge sums of money overseas.
Kuo was listed as defendant in the case because he allegedly paid Wu US$2.73 million in kickbacks to help him win a tender to build the Nangang Exhibition Hall between 2002 and 2003.

Prosecutors probing the case found that instead of giving the money directly to Wu, Kuo first deposited the funds in a bank account held by his sister Kuo Shu- jen before transferring it to another account held by Tsai Ming-che. The money was later transferred to another account held by Lin Pi-ting, another intermediary, before it was wired into an overseas account created under the name of Wu Ching-mao, according to the investigators.
The former first couple is accused of siphoning off NT$104 million (US$3.1 million) from a special Presidential Office discretionary fund during Chen Shui-bian's presidency from 2000 to May 2008.
They are also charged with accepting bribes worth a total of NT$300 million in connection with a land deal between the Hsinchu Science Park and Dayu Development Corp.
The couple is still being probed on suspicion of helping several financial conglomerates acquire financial holding companies in return for "political contributions."

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese herbal medicines found to contain Western drug ingredients

TEXT.P: Some 14.7 percent of 150 Chinese herbal medicine samples tested in 2008 were found to contain Western drug ingredients, a slightly lower ratio than the previous year's 15.8 percent, the Consumers' Foundation reported Thursday.
The foundation said it received a total of 167 samples of Chinese herbal medicines from consumers in February, June and October last year to be tested for Western medicine or heavy metal content.

The results of the tests showed that 22 of 150 samples were adulterated with Western medicine elements, while 71 of the 167 samples totally were found to contain lead, 61 contained mercury, and 40 contained cadmium, according to the foundation.

Martial arts studios around the country were the primary source of Chinese herbal treatments adulterated with Western medicine, with four out six samples from those establishments found to contain the elements.

Seven of the 15 samples of "counterfeit Chinese medicine" were from mainland China, while five of the 17 adulterated medicines were acquired by consumers from their friends or relatives, the foundation added.

According to the foundation, it is also worth noting that some traditional Chinese medicine products sold at local herbal medicine clinics and pharmacies and herbal stores were also found to contain western drug ingredients.

A total of 23 types of such ingredients were detected, including the anti- inflammatory and analgesic drugs indomethacin and acetamiophen, as well as caffeine, hydrochlorothiazide, thiamine disulfide, and acetaminophen, the foundation said.
Warning that an accumulation of heavy metals could cause chronic heavy metal poisoning, the foundation urged consumers not to buy Chinese herbal medicine of unknown origin.

DOC.HEADLINE: Too soon to speculate on Kinmen-Xiamen bridge: MAC

TEXT.P: It is too early to speculate on the construction of a bridge connecting the Taiwan-controlled island of Kinmen and the nearby Chinese city of Xiamen, despite increasing exchanges between the two sides, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Thursday.

MAC Deputy Chairman Liu Teh-hsun said during a routine press conference that despite recent significant improvements in cross-Taiwan Strait relations, there has been no policy formed on whether or not such a link should be constructed.

"The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) is still evaluating the feasibility of constructing such a bridge, " Liu said, adding that the issue has turned out to be more complex than originally expected.
The bridge would not only be a transport issue but would also be related to the nation's economy and national defenses, said Liu.

Commenting on rumors that it was President Ma Ying-jeou who proposed the Kinmen- Xiamen bridge construction plan, Liu pointed out that the plan was in fact proposed by the Kinmen county government last August as part of efforts to promote economic development on the outlying island.
Ma, Liu went on, adopted an open attitude toward the plan when he inspected the planned site for the bridge during a visit he made to Kinmen last August.

"We are optimistic about the plan, " said Liu, adding that once the bridge is built, it could lure many foreign tourists to visit Kinmen and would also have important significance on the issue of cross-strait peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung reaffirms ROC sovereignty over Spratlys

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government reaffirmed the Republic of China's historical claim to islands and reefs in the South China Sea Thursday, describing them as having been Chinese territory since the Han Dynasty (206 B.C.- A.D. 220).

Officials from the Kaohsiung Marine Bureau said the ROC's sovereignty claim is beyond doubt and challenge, adding that all four groups of islands in the South China Sea -- the Spratly Islands (known as Nansha in Chinese) , the Macclesfield Bank Islands (known locally as Jhongsha) , the Pratas Islands (Dongsha) and the Paracel Islands (Sisha) -- along with their surrounding waters, are ROC territories from a historical, geographical, factual and international law perspective.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has also issued statements many times to reiterate ROC sovereignty over these areas, the Marine Bureau officials noted.
They said the Ministry of the Interior contracted the city government Feb. 24, 1990 to administer Nansha (including Taiping Island) and Dongsha under the jurisdiction of the city's Cijin district.
The ROC has stationed personnel on Taiping Island, the largest coral atoll in the Nansha Islands, since the 1940s, and they rely on supplies from Taiwan for their operations and daily necessities.
On March 3, 2007, the city government designated Taiping Island as a breeding and conservation area for sea turtles, making it a haven for marine wildlife and marine studies, the officials went on.

They made the remarks after two chambers of the Philippines legislature -- the Senate and House of Representatives -- passed bills Jan. 28 and Feb. 2, respectively, to annex some of the islets and reefs of the Spratly Islands and Macclesfield Bank Islands as part of the Southeast Asian country's territory.

The MOFA called on the Philippines Wednesday to negotiate with Taiwan on the South China Sea sovereignty dispute under the principles and in the spirit of the United Nations Charter, the U.N. Convention on the Law of Sea and the Declaration on the Conduct of Parties in the South China Sea to resolve the conflicting claims peacefully.

The Spratlys consist of about 180 barren islets, reefs and atolls dotting the South China Sea, one of the world's busiest shipping lanes. Vietnam, China, Taiwan, the Philippines, Malaysia and Brunei each claim all or part of the low- lying islands, believed to be rich in oil, gas and fishery resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China universities to jointly develop biomedical technology

TEXT.P: National Chiao Tung University (NCTU) in Taiwan's Hsinchu City and Shanghai Jiao Tong University in China have signed an agreement to jointly develop biomedical engineering technology, an official of the northern Taiwan university said Thursday.
The agreement was signed during a visit by a delegation led by NCTU President Wu Chung-yu to the Shanghai university from Feb. 3-4.

Under the agreement, NCTU will provide electronic engineering expertise and send Taiwan's medical professionals to conduct clinical trials in Shanghai Jiao Tong University to advance biomedical research, the official said.

NCTU has been known in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park and the U.S. Silicon Valley circles for its expertise in electronic engineering, especially in the areas of communication, semiconductor, and IC design, but without a medical school or an affiliated hospital, it is facing a bottleneck in making fast progress in biomedical engineering, according to the official.

In comparison, after a merger with Shanghai Second Medical University n 2005, Shanghai Jiao Tong University at present has 12 affiliated hospitals with 12,000 beds, an outpatient volume of about 600 million people and a surgery volume of 200,000 patients annually, the official said.
Therefore, the two universities decided to work together to develop the biomedical technology industry by making good use of their respective advantages and resources.

In the initial phrase, the two universities will build a certification system for stem cell tissue banks and laboratories in Taiwan and China and set up a technology platform for both sides to develop medical implant chips and components for the use in clinical trials. The Shanghai university will also provide funding and patients for the trials, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Little Kinmen decides to hold referendum on casinos

TEXT.P: Little Kinmen, or Lieyu, an islet township just west of Taiwan's outlying island of Kinmen, has decided to hold a referendum in April to allow its residents to determine whether casinos should be built on their small island, sources from Kinmen said Thursday.

Speaking at a Kinmen county government meeting, Lieyu township chief Lin Chin- liang announced that the referendum will be held April 4 to gauge residents' opinions on whether the 16.23 square km-islet should be developed into a casino resort.
Lin said the number of eligible voters on Lieyu totals about 5,000, who will cast their referendum ballots at five polling stations around the township.

If the number of supporters of the motion exceeds half of the ballots cast, the township office will refer the referendum results to the Kinmen county government to be used as reference when it considers pushing for casino resort development on Kinmen, Lin said.
Lin said he favors the passage of the casino plan in the referendum so that Lieyu, which has an area about the size of Macao, could be developed into a "Little Macao."
He added that his office conducted a public opinion poll among Lieyu residents last July and found that 92 percent favored the idea of building casinos.
The legislature passed a draft amendment Jan. 12 legalizing gambling on Taiwan's outlying islands.
According to the amendment, referendums should be held on the outlying islands to allow residents to determine whether casinos should be built in their areas.
Casino building plans require "yes" votes from over half of the total ballots cast in the referendums, according to the just-enacted amendment.

Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng welcomed Lieyu's referendum plan, saying that the township is following a good administrative tradition by taking residents' opinions into consideration when shaping township policies.
He said the Kinmen county government will render all possible assistance to facilitate the referendum.

Lee also suggested during the meeting that more issues should be included in the referendum to probe opinions on other matters involving the community, including whether a bridge should be built connecting Kinmen and Lieyu, whether Kinmen should be completely demilitarized, and whether a bridge should be built between Lieyu and nearby Xiamen City in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA continues recall of tainted pet food

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) said Thursday that it has continued to recall a batch of tainted pet food that recently caused the deaths of a large number of dogs.

Hsu Tien-lai, director of the COA's Department of Animal Husbandry, said stray dog shelters in Taipei and Kaohsiung counties reported that around 400 dogs have died since early January after eating dog food contaminated with aflatoxin.
All the tainted dog food was supplied by a Yunlin County-based company, Jitai Feed, that allegedly used aflatoxin-contaminated corn from Pakistan in its production process.
Aflatoxin is produced by mold and can cause fatal liver damage.
Hsu said the department last year checked 150 samples of retail pet food, including some from Jitai Feed, all of which showed levels of aflatoxin below the specified acceptable 20 ppm limit.

However, a large number of dogs died earlier this year in Taipei County and the COA found that all of them had been fed from the batch of pet food produced by Jitai between October and November using the Pakistani corn as one of its ingredients.
Since the deaths, the COA has asked local governments to recall the pet food produced by Jitai during that period.
In addition, the COA also asked local governments and relevant agencies to conduct comprehensive checks on pet foods sold in their localities, Hsu said.
He added that all 106 samples of pet food tested this year -- 94 dog food and 12 cat food samples -- had aflatoxin content within the acceptable limit.

Some 300 dogs died at two animal shelters in Taipei County in early January, while another 100 perished at a shelter in Kaohsiung County during the recent Chinese New Year holiday after eating the contaminated dog food.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's forex reserves fourth-largest in world

TEXT.P: Taiwan has the fourth-largest foreign exchange reserves of any country in the world, trailing only China, Japan and Russia, the Central Bank of the Republic of China (CBC) said Thursday.
Taiwan's foreign currency reserves stood at US$292.676 billion at the end of January, up US$969 million over the figure posted at the end of last December, the CBC said.
Lin Sun-yuan, director-general of the bank's Department of Foreign Exchange, attributed the increase to interest earned on foreign exchange reserve investments.
China's forex reserve holdings totaled US$1.946 trillion at the end of December, while Japan's amounted to US$1.003 trillion and Russia's stood at US$406.2 billion, the CBC said.
India came behind Taiwan in terms of foreign reserve holdings as of Jan. 23, with US$238.3 billion, marking a decline of US$7.3 billion month-on-month, the CBC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President outlines diplomatic agenda with economy as top priority

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that Taiwan's pragmatic diplomacy will focus on economic themes this year in the face of the global economic recession.

"Seeking niche markets for businesses and removing trade barriers with our major trading partners will be prioritized in our diplomatic work in the Year of the Ox, " Ma said at a spring banquet organized by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in honor of members of the Taipei Diplomatic Corps at the start of the lunar new year.
In addition to beefing up Taiwan's trade and economic relations with other countries, Ma said, Taiwan's diplomatic agenda will also prioritize aid to countries that lack resources.
Since assuming office last May, Ma went on, Taiwan has encountered a host of tests and challenges it has rarely had to face before.

Nevertheless, the president said proudly that with concerted efforts from the public and private sectors, the country has managed to complete many unprecedented tasks and to score remarkable achievements on various fronts, particularly in the diplomatic and national defense fields and in relations across the Taiwan Strait.

He cited in particular several prominent events to highlight his administration's accomplishments over the past eight months, including the United States' nod to the sale of a package of advanced weapons to Taiwan and a visit to Taiwan by China's top cross-strait negotiator Chen Yunlin last November during which four agreements were signed on direct air, shipping and postal links, and food safety cooperation.

Last December, he continued, Taiwan was admitted to the Government Procurement Agreement affiliated with the World Trade Organization, while in January, the country was included in the International Health Regulations mechanism under the World Health Organization. In addition, the United States also removed Taiwan from its Special 301 watch list in recognition of the improvements it has made in intellectual property rights protection.

Combined, these events showcase the government's achievements in improving relations with China and maintaining peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait while fostering better bilateral and multilateral relations with countries around the world, Ma said.

Even more encouraging is that the government has not compromised on Taiwan's national sovereignty and dignity in completing those missions, Ma said, attributing the accomplishments to his "modus vivendi" diplomatic approach.
Looking forward to the coming year, Ma continued, such a pragmatic diplomatic approach should carry a new focus.

"We should expand our detente or reconciliation with China into the arena of international relations, " Ma said, adding that major countries around the world have praised the diplomatic truce between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait over the last half-year.

With sensitive cross-strait relations stabilizing and warming up, Ma said Taiwan should now devote more energy to practical issues, such as trade, investment, environmental protection and immigration, which also play vital roles in international relations and can help cement bilateral amity and cooperation.

Warning that the continuing economic downturn could herald the rise of protectionism, Ma quoted from a poem penned by British poet John Donne -- "No man is an island, entire of itself; every man is a piece of the continent" -- to emphasize the necessity of interdependence, co-existence and co-prosperity among countries.

With reinvigorating the economy as a priority task for his administration, Ma encouraged Taiwan's diplomatic staff to help local enterprises explore new markets and business opportunities, and to make "promoting bilateral economic and trade relations part of their work routines."

Among the guests at the banquet were Burkina Faso Ambassador Jacques Sawadogo and Masaki Saito, head of the Taipei Office of the Japan Interchange Association, senior government officials and prominent business executives.
This year's spring banquet featured world elements in cuisine, as well as in music and film presentations, integrating the cultures of Taiwan and those of various countries on the five continents.

Last December, he continued, Taiwan was admitted to the Government Procurement Agreement affiliated with the World Trade Organization, while in January, the country was included in the International Health Regulations mechanism under the World Health Organization. In addition, the United States also removed Taiwan from its Special 301 watch list in recognition of the improvements it has made in intellectual property rights protection.

Combined, these events showcase the government's achievements in improving relations with China and maintaining peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait while fostering better bilateral and multilateral relations with countries around the world, Ma said.

Even more encouraging is that the government has not compromised on Taiwan's national sovereignty and dignity in completing those missions, Ma said, attributing the accomplishments to his "modus vivendi" diplomatic approach.
Looking forward to the coming year, Ma continued, such a pragmatic diplomatic approach should carry a new focus.

"We should expand our detente or reconciliation with China into the arena of international relations, " Ma said, adding that major countries around the world have praised the diplomatic truce between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait over the last half-year.

With sensitive cross-strait relations stabilizing and warming up, Ma said Taiwan should now devote more energy to practical issues, such as trade, investment, environmental protection and immigration, which also play vital roles in international relations and can help cement bilateral amity and cooperation.

Warning that the continuing economic downturn could herald the rise of protectionism, Ma quoted from a poem penned by British poet John Donne -- "No man is an island, entire of itself; every man is a piece of the continent" -- to emphasize the necessity of interdependence, co-existence and co-prosperity among countries.

With reinvigorating the economy as a priority task for his administration, Ma encouraged Taiwan's diplomatic staff to help local enterprises explore new markets and business opportunities, and to make "promoting bilateral economic and trade relations part of their work routines."

Among the guests at the banquet were Burkina Faso Ambassador Jacques Sawadogo and Masaki Saito, head of the Taipei Office of the Japan Interchange Association, senior government officials and prominent business executives.
This year's spring banquet featured world elements in cuisine, as well as in music and film presentations, integrating the cultures of Taiwan and those of various countries on the five continents.
