DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 6, or the 12th day of the first month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1643: Abel Janszoon Tasman, Dutch mariner and explorer who was the first European to discover Tasmania and New Zealand in 1642, discovers the Fiji Islands in the Pacific.
1665: Queen Anne, last Stuart ruler of Britain, is born.
1778: Britain declares war on France.
1788: Massachusetts becomes the sixth state in the Union of American States.
1804: Joseph Priestley, British chemist moted for work on the isolation of gases and his discovery of oxygen (1774), dies at the age of 71.
1819: The East India Company, represented by Stamford Raffles, sets up its settlement at Singapore.
1840: Britain annexes New Zealand.
1895: Babe Ruth (George Herman), American baseball player with a tremendous batting record, is born.
1899: The Treaty of Paris is ratified, whereby Spain cedes Cuba, Puerto Rico, Guam and the Philippines to the United States for US$20 million.
1911: Ronald Reagan, an actor turned politician and the 40th president of the United States, is born.
1917: British women over 30 get the vote.
1922: The Washington Conference ends with the United States, Britain, France, Italy and Japan agreeing on restricting the use of poison gas and submarine warfare.
1932: Japanese troops capture Harbin in northeastern China.
1932: The ROC National Military Council is established.
1938: The ROC National Military Council sets up a Political Department, with Chen Cheng serves as director and Chou En-lai (Zhou Enlai) and Huang Chi-hsiang as deputy directors.
1941: Erwin Rommel, a German general known as "the Desert Fox" who committed suicide after his implication in the July Plot to assassinate Hitler in 1944, becomes the supreme commander of German forces in Africa.
1945: American General Douglas MacArthur announces the retaining of Manila and the rescuing of more than 5,000 prisoners of war.
1952: King George VI of Britain dies peacefully at Sandringham. He was succeeded by his eldest daughter Princess Elizabeth.
1957: Taiwan's textile industry enters the age of chemical fibers, as a man-made fiber company's plant in Toufen begins production.
1958: The Manchester soccer team of Britain, one of the best teams in Europe, is virtually wiped out in an air crash in Munich.
1983: Klaus Barbie, known as "the Butcher of Lyon" during World War II, is charged in Lyon, France, with crimes against humanity.
1983: Lee Mei-hsu, noted Taiwanese painter, dies at the age of 82.
1999: The Taipei District Court sentences Hong Kong business tycoon Lin Por-yen to three years and two months in prison for his role in a bribery scandal.
1999: Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski says that despite pressure from mainland China, his government will not change its decision to establish diplomatic ties with the Republic of China.
2000: Tarja Halonen becomes first woman president of Finland.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Holy, sainted men I do not expect to see; if I could only meet with wise and good men I would be satisfied."

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumer price index rises 1.59% in January

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) in January rose 1.59 percent from the same month of last year but dropped 0.27 percent from the previous month, indicating continued moderation of inflation, according to a report released Thursday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

Wu Chao-ming, a DGBAS section chief in charge of national statistics, noted that consumer prices in Taiwan have been decreasing since reaching a peak last July, while the inflation rate for the year stood at 3.52 percent.

Wu said consumer prices were slightly lower in January than in December, mainly because of a fall in vegetable and clothing prices, which were down 5.11 percent and 2.83 percent month-on-month, respectively.
Compared with the same month of last year, food prices as well as travel and babysitting fees were higher in January, resulting in an increase in the CPI, according to Wu.
For the same month, the wholesale price index (WPI) went down by 10.43 percent year-on-year, the greatest contraction recorded since April 1975, the DGBAS report shows.
Domestic sales, excluding imports, dropped 10.15 percent, while import and export prices calculated in new Taiwan dollars were down 11.91 percent and 9.19 percent, respectively.
Wu attributed the sharp fall in wholesale prices to a recent plunge in international agricultural and industrial commodities.
However, it could take three to six months for the wholesale price reduction to be reflected in consumer prices because of the complex production and retail processes, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opposition leader discredits education subsidy plan

TEXT.P: The government's education and training subsidy plan is designed to merely disguise the high unemployment level and President Ma Ying-jeou's administration should not try to resolve every problem by throwing vouchers or subsidies at it, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Friday.

Tsai said at a news conference before attending a seminar in the central city of Taichung that Ma should "cool down and stop wasting the country's financial and human resources on impractical and badly designed policies."

"The NT$20 billion (US$587 million) plan is a waste of money, and will have little effect on the soaring unemployment rate" Tsai predicted, adding that Ma's administration tends to use ill-conceived programs to cover the government's inability to solve the nation's problems.

According to Tsai, instead of pushing for plausible solutions to save the nation's ailing economy, the government has continuously found ways to seek cures without conducting careful planning or evaluation.

"They think they can solve the unemployment problem by keeping the people who have lost their jobs or who are about to lose their jobs in school, " said Tsai, adding that the subsidies will only provide temporary assistance to the unemployed and fail to tackle the root of the problem.
The plan is part of a special economic stimulus package under which the government will inject NT$500 billion over the next four years into public infrastructure projects.

According to government statistics, the jobless rate rose to a five-year high of 5.03 percent last December, which translated into 549,000 jobless people, 220,000 of whom were graduates of higher education institutions.
The government has also promised to create more than 100,000 jobs by focusing on public construction projects and hopes to keep the unemployment rate below 4.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
KMT candidate nomination to be decided via primary
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 5 (CNA) 02/06/09 13:25:13 (By Chiehyu Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The nomination of a ruling Kuomintang (KMT) candidate for the year-end election of the Taipei county magistrate will be based on the result of a party primary, KMT Vice Chairman Wu Den-yih said in Washington, D.C. Thursday.

Wu, who is leading a Taiwan delegation to attend the U.S. National Prayer Breakfast slated for Feb. 4-6, said the KMT will have to field the candidate with the best chance of winning as the party cannot afford to lose the election in Taipei County, the largest and most representative battlefield in the year- end city mayoral and county chief elections.

Wu said that according to KMT election norms, incumbents do not enjoy preferential treatment, meaning that if incumbent Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei wants to run for re-election, he will have to take part in the KMT primaries and seek nomination.
Wu made the remarks during a news conference held at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Washington.

Meanwhile, on the U.S. business sector's calls for Taiwan to increase imports of U.S. meat products and grain as a means to spur U.S. consumption in the face of the global economic recession, Wu said any imports of food products will be based on scientific standards. For instance, he noted, if there are still concerns that mad cow disease still threatens U.S. beef, exports will have to be monitored via scientific standards.
Declining to make any promises on the issue, Wu said he will pass the word to the administration when he returns to Taiwan.

Taiwan's top representative to the United States, Jason Yuan, supplemented Wu's remarks by saying that U.S. meat exporters have been pushing for increased sales of beef on the bone to Taiwan, since boneless beef is already allowed to be shipped to Taiwan.

During the news conference, Wu said the 2009 U.S. National Prayer Breakfast, with over 4,000 political and business leaders from 160 countries taking part, was particularly meaningful as it was the first of its kind in the middle of the worst global economic crisis since the Great Depression and since the election of African American Barack Obama as U.S. president.
Wu's delegation included Wang Yu-ting, minister of the National Youth Commission, and Yang Tai-shun, a political science professor with Chinese Culture University.

DOC.HEADLINE: Second stage of consumer voucher distribution slated for Feb. 7

TEXT.P: The second stage of consumer voucher distribution will start Feb. 7, whereby eligible people who have not yet received their shopping vouchers can pick them up at designated post offices around the country, the Ministry of the Interior (MIO) said Friday.
The MIO reminded recipients to pick up their vouchers from designated post offices near their residences.

Recipients must present their national identification card, personal stamp and notification letter in order to receive the vouchers, the MOI said, adding that those who do not wish to pick up their vouchers in person can give their ID and personal stamp to someone else who can collect the vouchers on their behalf.
Post offices around the nation will issue the vouchers from 1: 30 p.m-5:30 p.m Feb. 7, and from 8 a.m-5:30 p.m the following day, said the MOI.
Eligible persons can also pick up their consumer vouchers between Feb. 17 and April 30 at the designated post offices, after which date no more vouchers will be issued, said the MOI.
According to the MOI, close to 21 million people received their shopping vouchers during the first stage distribution process before the Chinese Lunar New Year.
As Taiwan's total population is close to 23 million, at least 2 million people have not yet claimed their vouchers, said the MOI.
Aimed at spurring consumer spending and boosting the economy, the shopping vouchers were distributed for the first time Jan. 18 to certain Taiwan residents.
Under the project, every citizen, including newborns and foreign spouses, can receive NT$3,600 (US$107) -worth of shopping vouchers that will remain valid until Sept. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economics ministry proposes construction projects to create 5,000

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) was scheduled to submit a public infrastructure construction program package to the Executive Yuan Friday that is expected to create 5,000 jobs and secure 90,000 existing ones, a ministry official said that day.

The package, which covers eight medium and small construction and renewal projects, is aimed at helping revive the sagging economy and curbing the soaring unemployment rate, according to the official.

The MOEA plans to allocate a public affairs budget of NT$9.62 billion (US$285.8 million) and a special budget of NT$17.75 billion to fund the projects slated to be implemented over the next two years, the official said.

The package include four projects initiated by the MOEA's Industrial Development Bureau to rejuvenate old industrial zones -- pavement construction, repair and maintenance, a project of beautification and greening of public spaces, a public sign improvement plan and an ecological enhancement plan for the Linyuan Industrial Park in Kaohsiung County, according to the official.
Also covered in the programs is a project to improve river environments and another on flood prevention and dredging work, both of which have been filed by the ministry's Water Resources Agency.
The MOEA's central Taiwan office also proposed a traditional market renewal plan that is projected to create 4,600 jobs and secure 86,000 existing ones, the official said.

Meanwhile, the Department of Commerce has come up with a commercial circle improvement project that is likely to create 500 jobs, boost sales to the tune of NT$750 million and increase private investment of NT$15 million, the official went on.

DOC.HEADLINE: President inaugurates `Tour Taiwan Year 2009'

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou pledged Friday to set up a NT$30 billion (US$891.7 million) fund to boost the development of Taiwan's tourism industry as he inaugurated the "Tour Taiwan Year 2009."
Ma said the Executive Yuan will earmark NT$1 billion for the fund this year and will gradually increase the amount each year to encourage investment in the tourism industry,
He said that although the number of foreign visitors to Taiwan is equal to only 16 percent of the country's population, there was a 3.5 percent increase in visitor arrivals in 2008.
The growth is encouraging given the fact that departures dropped by 5.5 percent during the year, Ma said.

According to the president, after the opening of direct air and shipping links with China late last year, Taiwan is no longer subject to any restrictions in terms of its transport and connection to the outside world. Therefore, the country should take advantage of its favorable geographic position in East Asia to promote tourism, he added.

Meanwhile, Ma went on, the government is seeking to negotiate with the United States for visa-free entry for Taiwanese citizens, and he also raised the possibility of the European Union granting visa-free entry to Taiwanese citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices surged Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 108 points, or 2.47 percent, to close at 4,471.25.

Rebounding strongly from a slight loss the previous day, the local bourse opened at 4,438.3 and fluctuated between 4,507.3 and 4,432.16. A total of 3.50 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$71.81 billion (US$2.13 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 3.3 percent. Machinery and electronics issues advanced 3.2 percent, textile stocks rose 2.0 percent, banking and financial shares gained 1.9 percent, plastics and chemicals shares moved up 1.8 percent, construction issues surged 0.9 percent, foodstuff shares rose 0.7 percent and paper and pulp stocks advanced 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,184 to 396, with 210 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$7.51 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor to visit U.S. for World Games promotion

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu will depart for the United States Feb. 14 for a visit to the U.S. Department of State and the Department of Homeland Security, as well as to promote the 2009 Kaohsiung World Games and solicit investment in the southern port city, a city official said Friday.

Making the 13-day trip at the invitation of the U.S. State Department, Chen and her delegation will also visit the U.S. Senate and House of Representatives, the Director of National Intelligence and the Department of Commerce, according to the official.

During her visit to the Department of Homeland Security, Chen will seek its help with anti-terrorism information and solicit suggestions on her city's anti- terrorism measures planned for the 2009 Kaohsiung World Games, the official said.

In addition, she will call a press conference and make a speech in New York to promote the World Games, as well as meeting with research fellows at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a Washington think tank.

To raise Kaohsiung's profile and seek cooperation partners, the mayor will call on the mayors of San Francisco and San Jose and will visit Internet portal Yahoo Inc. and network equipment maker Cisco Systems Inc. to discuss issues related to the development of digital technology.
She will also meet with several Taiwanese businessmen in the U.S. and invite them to visit Kaohsiung to assess the overall investment environment there.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA vows to prioritize economic issues in conducting diplomacy

TEXT.P: With President Ma Ying-jeou calling for Taiwan's diplomacy to prioritize economic issues, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday it will create incentives for local businesses to invest in countries that do not have diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
Speaking at a banquet for members of the diplomatic corps Thursday, Ma said that Taiwan's pragmatic diplomacy will focus on economic themes this year in the face of the global economic slowdown.

The president also encouraged Taiwan's diplomats to help local enterprises explore new markets and business opportunities, and make "promoting bilateral economic and trade relations part of their work routines.

Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou told the Central News Agency that Ma's new foreign policy focus made sense in the face of challenges resulting from the global financial crisis, and said his agency will inform all foreign offices of the shift in emphasis.
The present diplomatic policy not only includes consolidating friendship with diplomatic allies but should also involve developing economic and trade relations with non allies,Ou said.

The foreign minister said that if diplomats can create a good investment environment and deepen friendships with countries that do not have diplomatic relations with Taiwan, Taiwanese businesses would then have the incentive and willingness to invest in those places.

Given the global recession and improved cross-Taiwan Strait ties, now is a great time for Taiwan to cultivate economic and trade relations with non-allied countries, especially those in the Association of Southeast Asian NationsOu said.

According to existing law, however, incentives are provided only to Taiwanese businesses investing in allied nations, and Ou said the foreign ministry will try to amend the law to include investment in non-allied countries in the incentive program to reflect the administration's new diplomatic approach.

Echoing Ou's view, a high-level MOFA official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that it is a matter of course to focus the country's diplomacy on commercial issues, as the two are inseparable.

The foreign ministry's role will only become less and less important if we only focus on political issues, the official said, citing Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and South Korea's Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade as examples of other government's efforts to combine diplomatic and economic affairs.
Very often the government does not have to spend money when it comes to conducting diplomatic affairs, but rather can play a role as a matchmaker,the official said.
The government can assist Taiwanese businesses tap into new markets and help them seek better benefits from local governments to create a win-win-win situation,he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Price of liquefied petroleum gas to increase: CPC

TEXT.P: The state-run petroleum refiner CPC Corp., Taiwan (CPC) announced Friday that it will increase the wholesale price of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) by NT$3.1 (US$0.09) per kilogram with effect from Saturday.

As a result, the retail price of household LPG will be raised by NT$62 per 20kg cylinder. This will translate into an increased cost of NT$93 per month to the average family, based on an estimated consumption of 1.5 cylinders of LPG per month.
Currently the retail LPG price was at around NT$620 per cylinder.
The price hike is expected to heavily affect street food vendors, most of whom use LPG for cooking. It is estimated that each food stand uses an average five cylinders of LPG per month.
The CPC said in a statement that the international LPG contract price rose to US$505 per ton in February -- a hike of US$125 per ton, or 32.9 percent, from the previous month.

According to the company's calculation, the domestic price of LPG would have be increased by NT$5.15 per kg to reflect the international cost. However, in light of the economic slump, the domestic price will be adjusted to reflect only 60 percent of the international cost, in consideration of the effect on people's lives, CPC said.
It is the second consecutive month that the price of household LPG has increased, with the hike over the last two months averaging 17.36 percent.
According to the CPC statement, the pre-tax wholesale price of LPG will be raised to NT$20.96 per kg, which nonetheless will be lower than in South Korea where the cost is NT$37.91 per kg.
Meanwhile, the CPC will also raise the price of LPG for vehicles by NT$1.7 per liter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for February advancing 172 points to end the day at 4,443, with 94,505 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for March gained 155 points to close at 4,388, with 1,003 contract transactions, while June futures increased 149 points to end at 4,340, with 25 contract transactions.
September futures gained 133 points to close at 4,133, with 15 contract transactions, while December futures increased 155 points to end at 4,085, with 19 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 4,271 for February, 4,233 for March, 4,191 for June 4,000 for September and 3,930 for December.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index increased 108 points to finish at 4,471.25, on turnover of NT$71.81 billion (US$2.13 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

February TE futures gained 8.45 points to close at 176.7, with 4,512 contracts traded, while March TE futures advanced 8.35 points to finish at 175.35, with 88 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor seeks central government subsidies for World Games

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu sought subsidies from the central government for the holding of the Kaohsiung 2009 World Games during a visit to the Executive Yuan Friday, according to a city official.

Under the city government's plan, it will earmark NT$1.98 billion (US$58.67 million) for the international sports event slated to open on July 26, with the central and local governments each sharing half of the cost, the official said.
However, the central government has yet to pay NT$730 million to meet its share, according to the official.

Therefore, Chen paid a visit to Premier Liu Chao-shiuan to brief him on the city's budget allocation and preparation for the event and urged the Cabinet to pay the remaining amount, the official added.
Emily Cho-chuan Hsu, chief executive officer of the World Games 2009 Kaohsiung Organizing Committee (KOC) , and many other KOC staff members were also present at the meeting.

Of the total budget for the Games, the KOC plans to spend NT$520 million on promoting local culture and tourism, NT$330 million on sports competitions, NT$310 million for promotion and public relations affairs, NT$280 million for logistics support, and NT$210 million for management affairs, the official said.

The KOC estimated that some NT$23 million will be generated from the sales of advertisements and tickets related to the World Games. Other revenues would include NT$78 million from donations, NT$9.3 million from relevant products, NT$5.02 million from royalty or licence fees, and other business incomes of NT$22 million, the official added.
According to the KOC rule, all countries will participate in the World Games on the status of non-state entities without the use of their national anthem, flag or official name, the official said.

Around 3,200 athletes from nearly 100 countries are expected to participate in the World Games, the official said, adding that the KOC will reserve 25 hotels in the city to accommodate the participants and prepare 200 buses to transport them.
The city government has set up a special task force for anti-terrorism and will mobilize 33,000 policemen to maintain order during the event, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan students attend Chinese culture study camp in Shanghai
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Feb. 6 (CNA) 02/06/09 18:22:56 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: A group of 280 students and faculty members from 40 universities in Taiwan is in Shanghai to attend a three-day winter camp to study Chinese culture and the urban development of Shanghai.
The group will learn about China's economic development and reform, the urban development of Shanghai and the planning for the 2010 Shanghai World Expo.
The Taiwanese college professors and students will also engage in exchanges with their counterparts in Tongji University in Shanghai.

The program is organized by the Taiwan Sustainable Development Institute in collaboration with Tongji University. Lu Yung-chang, executive director of the institute, is serving as the head of the group.
Of the 280 members of the group, 120 are from Chinese Culture University, and 80 are from National Chengchi University, with the others from 38 other universities around Taiwan.

On Feb. 8, the group will begin a four-day tour of scenic and historical places in Jiangsu and Zhejiang provinces, including West Lake and Zhouzhuang, a famous water township noted for its well-preserved ancient residential houses and the elegant scenery.
The group is scheduled to return to Taiwan on Feb. 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA looking to establish offices in Sapporo, Istanbul

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday that as part of its work of reviewing the functions and performance of its foreign representative offices, it expects to open new offices in Sapporo, Japan and Istanbul, Turkey in the first half of the year.
Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou told the Central News Agency that his ministry is also considering closing underperforming overseas offices, such as the one in Bangladesh.

The Republic of China currently has 122 embassies and representative offices around the world, which require staffing by a relatively large number of diplomats compared to the number posted abroad by South Korea and Singapore, according to the foreign ministry.
"In light of Taiwan's frequent people-to-people exchanges with Japan and Turkey, the MOFA is considering establishing offices in Sapporo and Istanbul," Ou said.

In principle, the Japan and Turkey governments have both agreed to the idea," the foreign minister said. "As far as the administrative process is concerned, the Executive Yuan is hoping that the MOFA will first look at the required budget and the size of the diplomatic staff for the proposed offices, but the foreign ministry estimates that the plan will be realized within the first half of the year."

Ou said that setting up new representative offices and assigning diplomatic service personnel abroad not only require the consent of the host governments, but must also consider the actual needs of the host countries and their ties with Taiwan.
"Given that bilateral relations between Taiwan and China are improving, the establishment of new representative offices abroad should now be smoother," the foreign minister predicted.

As for closing underperforming representative offices, Ou said the Foreign Ministry is being very cautious, as it takes considerable effort to set up new offices, and closing them without careful review might impact negatively on bilateral relations.
"However, people have to understand that diplomatic resources are limited and the ministry needs to ensure that every penny is spent wisely," the foreign minister said.

According to Ou, the MOFA will evaluate whether to close representative offices based on factors such as whether the ministry already has too many offices in one country and whether the countries in question are friendly toward Taiwan.
"Any decision to close representative offices would have absolutely nothing to do with a 'diplomatic truce' (with China), but rather would be made after careful evaluation," Ou stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 80% of workers interested in entrepreneurship: survey

TEXT.P: With more and more workers in Taiwan seeing their livelihoods threatened by rising unemployment, entrepreneurship is being seen as a new way out, according to the results of arecent survey released Friday by the online employment broker 104 Job Bank.
The survey found that 81.6 percent of workers are interested in starting a business, 7.6 percent of whom are determined to do so.

Of these potential entrepreneurs, 15.2 percent said they are thinking of making a change because their employment situation is not good. However, the two reasons the respondents mentioned most frequently for wanting to start a business were a desire to live the life they want and to realize their dreams.

The results showed that older workers, especially those in their 50s, are most likely to turn to entrepreneurship because of unemployment, with 26.6 percent of workers in this age group saying that losing their jobs was what gave them the urge to start a business.

Some 23.3 percent of respondents interested in entrepreneurship plan to move in that direction within one year, 22.5 percent intend to do so in one to two years, 19.9 percent in two to three years, and 34.4 percent in three years or more, according to the survey.
The survey also revealed that older workers tend to be more proactive in trying to put the idea into practice.

More than 53 percent of respondents in their 40s and 40 percent of those in their 50s are planning to start a business within one year, compared to 24.6 percent of those in their 30s and 15.1 percent of those in their 20s.
On average, the potential entrepreneurs would require NT$565,300 in startup funds, the survey found.

As to the kinds of business they what to run, 39.4 percent expressed interest in coffee shops, restaurants or snack bars, and 39.1 percent indicated a preference for operating an online business such as an online auction or online store.
Nearly 40 percent of the potential entrepreneurs are optimistic that they can make a profit in six to 12 months after start-up, and 23.7 percent expect a gain within six months.
Meanwhile, among the respondents who have no desire to go into business, 61.5 percent think starting a venture in times of economic recession is a risky undertaking.
Other reasons mentioned by this group of respondents included a lack of capital, lack of personal qualities to run a business, and lack of any special expertise.
The survey was conducted Jan. 19-23 among 7,632 members of the job bank. It had a margin of error of 1.12 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei city gets aid to expand help to the needy

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Friday that the city government has just received NT$2 billion (US$59.35 million) from the Executive Yuan to increase its assistance to the needy amid the current economic downturn.

Hau said that in addition to food coupons, the Taipei City Department of Labor Affairs is planning to expand vocational training programs and employment services to help former blue-collar workers who have been on unpaid leave or have lost their jobs as a result of corporate cost-cutting, downsizing or closing.

The department is also planning to increase the amount of educational subsidies for children of low-income families in Taipei in an attempt to help working class families survive the ongoing economic recession, Hau added.
Hau made the remarks during a Lunar New Year celebration organized by the Union of Taipei Vocational Associations.

He exhorted union members to keep close contact with the Taipei city government on the plight of the working class, saying that no city government officials know better than union members about problems facing grassroots-level workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Jan. applications for unemployment benefits exceed 70,000A

TEXT.P: The number of people applying for unemployment benefits in January totalled 72,548, an increase of 4,000 over December, according to statistics released Friday by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA).
Some 33,000 of those who filed for unemployment benefits in January were first- time applicants, the CLA said.

Prior to September 2008 when the global financial crisis hit, the number of applications for unemployment benefits remained steady at less than 30,000 per month, the figures showed. However, in October 2008 the number rose to 36,072, and by December had hit 67,842. This translated into NT$6.6 billion (US$195.56 million) in unemployment benefits paid by the government last year.

Under the unemployment benefit program, workers who lose their jobs through no fault of their own and fail to find new ones within 14 days of registering with a government-run employment service can receive 60 percent of their insured wages for up to six months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bridge talks again bring Kinmen in spotlight

TEXT.P: CNA staff writer

Renewed talk of building a bridge to connect Taiwan-held Kinmen Island with China's port city of Xiamen has put the sparsely populated island county in the spotlight, as it fights to promote a project that seems to have little if any support from the central government or the opposition.

A local newspaper reported on Thursday that President Ma Ying-jeou had given the order to start the project, but presidential spokesman Wang Yu-chi clarified that Ma had simply asked about the progress of a feasibility assessment on building the bridge.
A Cabinet spokesman later said there was no timetable to complete the feasibility study, a clear indication the government is in no rush to move forward on the ambitious project.
Even ruling Kuomintang legislators worry the bridge's construction would divert local taxpayer funds to help China develop Xiamen.

And if the government appears less than enthusiastic about building a bridge to China, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party downright hates the idea, branding it as another step to send Taiwan into China's fold.
Yet Kinmen's residents want their island, Taiwan's former front line against China during the Cold War, to be transformed into a new frontier for peace by building a road link to China.

Support for the project, called the Kindeng Bridge, is especially strong among those over 60 who experienced the month-long artillery bombardment of the island by the Chinese army in 1958 that killed over 600 servicemen and civilians and injured more than 2,600.

Most of those baptized under fire now dream of "driving a car from Kinmen to Xiamen in a day, " said Yen Chung-cheng, a Kinmen native who once served as a vice commander-in-chief of the Republic of China Army.

During his stint as Fukien governor, a now-defunct position once responsible for Kinmen and Matsu, another Taiwan-held island off China's coast, Yen listed the building of a bridge connecting Kinmen and Xiamen as one of the three major "projects of hope" in the region.

According to a public opinion poll conducted by the National Kinmen Institute of Technology in April 2007, building a bridge to Xiamen was the issue of second greatest concern to the county's residents, trailing only the need for improved health and emergency care.

The 83.9 percent of respondents who felt it was an important issue believed it was necessary to further cement ties with China, around which many of the lives of the 50,000 people who reside in Kinmen revolve.

Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng is firmly behind the project, saying Kinmen has served as a bridge connecting the two sides of the Taiwan Strait since direct ferry services to Xiamen and other Chinese ports were launched in early 2001.
"The building of the Kindeng Bridge will not only help hone Taiwan's bridge building technologies, it will also help boost development in Kinmen itself," Lee said.

"The Kindeng Bridge will facilitate the building of water pipes and electricity transmission cables between Kinmen and Xiamen, allowing Kinmen to import fresh water and electricity from China -- moves that would also manifest Taiwan's sincerity in pursuing peace and co-prosperity with China," he added.

According to the Kinmen County government, 974,000 people traveled between Kinmen and Xiamen in 2008, up from the 21,000 who used the ferry service in its inaugural year, an indication, it says, of the island county's crucial role as a gateway to China.

Yet that role has been threatened since direct air and sea links were opened between Taiwan and China last December, prompting Kinmen residents to seek further breakthroughs in its ties with China, particularly Xiamen, said Kinmen County Council Speaker Hsieh Yi-chang.
According to Lee, the Kinmen County government began studying the possibility of building of a bridge between Kinmen and Xiamen in 2004 and has since proposed three different projects.
Plan A is a 10.3-kilometer bridge that would connect Wulongshan in Kinmen, to Jiaoyu and Xiaodeng islets and on to Dadeng Island, which sits west-northwest of Xiamen Island and northeast of Kinmen.
Plan B, the Kindeng Bridge plan, would span 8.6 kilometers and directly connect Wulongshan and Dadeng Island.
Plan C is a 11.4-km bridge between Wulongshan and Fujian province's Lianhe, which lies further north of Xiamen.
The costs of the three plans range from NT$12.7 billion (US$377.98 million) to NT$16.6 billion, Lee said.
Lee said Kinmen County prefers the second option because it is the most direct and the least costly.

If the bridge were built, it would take less than 30 minutes to drive from Kinmen to the island on which the center of Xiamen lies, by way of Dadeng, a land bridge to Xiangan north of Xiamen and then a tunnel currently under construction from Xiangan to Xiamen, County Speaker Hsieh said.

A bridge would only further tie the Taiwan-held island to the major Chinese port city. Even with slower ferry service, Kinmen residents visit Xiamen as casually as taking a stroll outside after dinner.
An increasing number of Kinmen youths have also chosen to attend schools in Xiamen rather than traveling to Taiwan proper for studies after the ferry service was opened.
Moreover, as their children went to Xiamen to get an education, parents in Kinmen began to purchase houses or invest in real estate in Xiamen.

According to Chen Cheng-huan, formerly president of the Junior Chamber International Kinmen and now owner of a realty company in Xiamen, Kinmen residents have purchased at least 7,600 homes in Xiamen and many more in the nearby Chinese cities of Zhangzhou and Quanzhou.
"Have you bought a house in Xiamen yet? " has now become a greeting phrase when Kinmen people meet on the streets, Chen said jokingly.
The Kinmen County Council speaker says the bridge will turn Kinmen into a Xiamen suburb, giving Kinmen residents more convenient links to their big city.
"A genuine one-day traffic zone between Kinmen and Xiamen would be created," Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Singapore to jointly train talent for casino business

TEXT.P: A tourism college in eastern Taiwan signed an agreement with a foreign institute Friday to train Taiwanese hoping to work in the gambling industry.

Lee Ming-hui, principal of the Taiwan Hospitality and Tourism College (THTC) in Hualien, signed the training program agreement with James Kong, a representative of the U.S.-based Galaxy Training Institute (GTI).
Under the agreement, a three-stage training program will be offered with basic courses pertaining to the gambling industry taught in Taipei in the first phase.

In the second phase, courses on professional dealing at casinos will be taught at the THTC campus in Hualien, eastern Taiwan, and in the final phase, training modules on casino dealing and management will be offered in Singapore.
The 300-hour training program will begin formally at the end of March, with tuition costs expected to range between NT$100,000 and NT$130,000.

Kong noted that although there are other qualification requirements for applicants to the training program, the main assets of potential workers in the casino business are "English and math ability and physical fitness."

Under the terms of a recently passed bill that paved the way for the opening of casinos in Taiwan, the gambling industry will "integrate tourism and entertainment" and there will be more to it than just gambling, Lee said.
More importantly, there will be satellite business opportunities in areas such as a holiday village, transportation network, upscale boutiques and conventions and exhibitions, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's opposition to assess President Ma on May 19: DPP chairwoman

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Friday that May 19 -- the first year anniversary of President Ma Ying-jeou taking office -- is the best time to assess Mas administration, indicating that the DPP will decide then whether to try and unseat Ma, based on the results of the examination.

Tsai made the remarks in Taichung at the regional preparation meeting for the 2009 Taiwan Citizen Conference on National Affairs, in which she said that the DPP will fully examine Mas performance from political and economic aspects by holding the conference to examine his administration's policies and its ability to execute them.
Taiwan's main opposition party will also make concrete suggestions on policies, Tsai added.

The DPP has been concerned about and criticizing a series of measures Ma has taken to improve relations with China after assuming office on May 20, 2008. These measures include the signing of four agreements to open up direct air and sea links with China and adopting the practice ofdiplomatic truceto end the longstanding tug-of-war with Beijing to win over each othersallies.
DPP officials and lawmakers have accused the Ma administration of sacrificing Taiwans national interests.

Citizen Conference on National Affairs can truthfully reflect the voice of the people, Tsai said.President Ma and Premier Liu Chao-shiuan should attend the conference to listen to what people have to say and if they do not do so, they would be turning the peoplesvoice down.
Tsai contended that all citizens are obligated to assemble civil organizations and to expand such organizations to a kind of social force to check and balance Mas administration.

At Fridays preparatory meeting, a total of 24 people took the podium to criticize Ma and his policies and contended that concrete actions should be taken to fight against Ma. However, some also argued that the DPP should reflect on itself so that it will not make the same mistakes when it retakes the reins of government.

The DPP came into power in 2000 after half a century of dominance by the Kuomintang (KMT), but lost its political power to the KMT last year due to widespread public dissatisfaction over the state of the economy, and the corruption scandals plaguing the former President Chen Shui-bians administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local museums to hold year-round 'Darwin Now Exhibition'

TEXT.P: With the cooperation of the British Council in Taipei, museums around the nation will take turns holding the "Darwin Now Exhibition" in 2009 to celebrate the 200th anniversary of evolutionist biologist Charles Darwin's birth, the museums announced Friday.

During a joint press conference held at the National Taiwan Museum in Taipei, the museums and the British Council said that to celebrate the landmark anniversary of the most influential evolutionist in human history, they have collaborated to launch the first Formosa Science Festival around the theme of "Darwin Now".
According to the organizer, the Darwin Now Exhibition will be held in five different museums located in the northern, central and southern parts of the island in 2009.

The exhibition will open its doors to the public in Kaoshiung's National Science and Technology Museum from April to June, in Taichung's National Museum of Natural Science from July to August, in Pingtung's National Museum of Marine Biology and Aquarium from July to September, and will finally make its debut in Taipei's National Taiwan Museum and Taitung's National Museum of Prehistory from September to December.

Christine Skinner, the director of the British Council in Taipei, said she was pleased to see so many Taiwanese scholars and museum lovers have show so much support to the commemoration of perhaps the greatest evolutionist biologist of all time on the 200th anniversary of his birth.

In addition, Skinner said that the British Council in Taipei and participating museums will choose three outstanding teenage leaders, between 16 to 18 years of age, to represent Taiwan in London's Natural History Museum's International Student Summit about Darwin from June 30 to July 2.
The British Council is the United Kingdom's international cultural relations organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC approves first direct cross-strait cruise service

TEXT.P: After many twists and turns, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) finally approved Friday an application by Star Cruises to operate direct cruises to China without having to stop in a third territory.
It marked the first time that Taiwan has given the green light to the operation of direct cross-Taiwan Strait cruise service.
The MOTC said in a press statement that the one-year license for Star Cruises was issued on a case-by-case basis in terms of the regulations governing direct cross-strait shipping links.

According to a schedule listed in the Star Cruises application, the largest cruise line in the Asia-Pacific will launch direct cruise service between Keelung Harbor in northern Taiwan and Xiamen in the southeastern Chinese province of Fujian in the first half of this year.
Despite Taiwan's nod, MOTC officials said Star Cruises will still have to obtain China's consent before the proposed Keelung-Xiamen service can begin.

Star Cruises filed the application with the Keelung Harbor Bureau in December last year to serve the route, but the screening process has turned out to be a frustrating experience for the company, as government officials and the cruise line's executives disagree over the nature of the service.

MOTC officials believed then that that regular cruises between Keelung and Xiamen would amount to marine passenger services, which only Taiwanese vessels or vessels owned by Taiwanese-Chinese joint ventures are allowed to operate under local regulations.
The Hong Kong-based Star Cruises contended, however, that ordinary people are unlikely to use expensive cruises as "passenger services."
At one point, the company said it might consider withdrawing from the Taiwan market if Taiwanese authorities rejected its application to operate direct Keelung-Xiamen cruise services.

Star Cruises entered Taiwan's maritime tourism market in 1997, sailing primarily between Keelung and Japan's Okinawa. The cruise line stopped sailing this route in October 2005, but resumed the service in June 2007.

The company has been the major player in Taiwan's cruise market, taking local tourists on cruises to the Japanese islands of Okinawa, Ishigaki and Yonaguri, Taiwan's Penghu islands and Hong Kong. When the weather turns cold, its ships leave Taiwan to serve Star Cruises' other Asian routes.

At the time when Star Cruises resumed homeporting in Keelung, Star Cruises' Taiwan manager Andy Lew openly indicated that from a long-term point of view, Star Cruises wanted to launch services from Taiwan to Shanghai and Xiamen -- two of China's port cities.
Taiwan and China reached agreements last November to lift a six-decade ban on direct sea and postal links between the two sides and expand air links.
Foreign cruise ships visiting Taiwan now no longer need to sail to a third territory, usually Hong Kong, before they can visit a Chinese port, or vice versa.
Star Cruises contributes at least NT$7 million (US$207,715) in harbor fees ayear to the Keelung Harbor Bureau from its homeporting on 80 cruises between March and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Scholar calls for law to protect coral reefs

TEXT.P: An Academia Sinica researcher suggested Friday that the government introduce legislation to protect the country's coral reefs, which he said are the largest marine structures and are more important than pandas.
Chen Chao-lun, an associate research fellow at the Biodiversity Research Center, made the call while releasing the findings of a 2008 research project on the state of Taiwan's coral reefs.
Chen warned that Taiwan's coral reefs are being threatened by the so-called "black disease, " or attacks from a kind of black sponge that co-exists with algae.
Apart from that, he said the development of the coral-centered marine ecology was found to be seriously unbalanced due to over-fishing.
Researchers failed to find any large coral reef fish like groupers, parrotfish, lobsters or large sea snails called triton in Taiwan's coastal waters, he added.

According to Chen, coral plays a far more important role in the ecologic system than "star animals" like pandas and whales. Coral reefs should be protected by law, especially as there is no legislation banning the harvesting of marine life or prohibiting human activities that might threaten their survival, Chen said.
The marine biologist suggested that coral reefs should be regarded as a life form, instead of as rocks or stones.
In addition, "coral reef fish and sea snails should be listed as protected wild animals, instead of seafood," he said.

Chen also suggested that the government pay attention to the threat to Taiwan's coral reefs posed by global climate change, and advised swifter action to cut carbon dioxide emissions in order to slow down the impact of global warming on coral reefs.
The whole marine ecology would be destroyed if coral reefs vanished from the sea, he warned.

The research on coral reefs in Taitung county, southeastern Taiwan, and the Penghu archipelago off southwestern Taiwan proper was launched in 2008 by the non-profit Taiwan Marine Environment Education Promotion Association (TAMEE) and the Taiwan Environmental Information Association.
The report stated that a kind of black sponge that co-exists with algae is attacking coral reefs around the islets of Green Island and Lanyu off southeastern Taiwan proper.
"The coral dies once it is covered by the sponge, " said Yang Sung-ying, an assistant to Chen.
According to Chen, currently little is known in academic circles about the sponge, except that it is spreading fast and posing a serious threat to the marine ecology.

The findings of the survey around Green Island showed that the sponge grew by 20 percent in the 2007-2008 period, he said. In Lanyu, the divers working on the survey project found signs of black sponge at almost every dive location, he added.

The coverage was 10 percent on average, with the greatest spread reaching 26 percent, the scholar said, adding that further investigation is needed to determine what is causing the spread of the disease.

Meanwhile, in the marine areas that were surveyed, including waters off Taitung's Shanyuan and Penghu's Dongyuping where the coral reef coverage is 70 percent, there were few signs of reef fish, he said.

This means that "while the marine ecology appears healthy, actually it is not, " Chen said, expressing worry that any further negative impact on the reefs would be "the straw that breaks the camel's back."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Kazakhstan even on controversial Davis Cup opening day

TEXT.P: For the better part of two sets, Kazakhstan's Mikhail Kukushkin grumbled about some of the line calls that were going against him.

But it was Taiwan's Chen Ti who had the biggest reason to gripe about dubious officiating during a heartbreaking 6-7 (9), 5-7, 6-1, 7-5, 6-4 loss to the former Russian in the opening match of the Asia/Ocean Zone Group I tie in Sinjhuang Gymnasium on Friday.

Fortunately for the host, Wang Yeu-tzuoo brushed off plenty of rust and spotty play to overcome Kazakhstan's top-ranked player, Andrey Golubev in surprisingly easy fashion, 7-6 (4), 6-3, 6-2, to even the tie at one.

Wang and Chen, who came into the tie with question marks hanging over them, were forced to carry the load against Kazakhstan's Russian imports because Taiwan's top player, Lu Yen-hsun pulled out of the encounter earlier in the week with a knee injury.

As truly remarkable as Wang's win was, considering he had been sidelined for most of the past year with a wrist injury and did not seriously hit balls until late November, the sheer drama and intensity of the day's opening match proved even more memorable.
The 375th-ranked Chen had not played competitively since November, preferring to spend six weeks at a tennis academy in Florida to overhaul his game.

The worked clearly paid off, as against an opponent ranked 230 places higher than him, Chen showed off a more fluid serve that was actually a weapon rather than a liability, and unprecedented passion for attacking tennis.
He saved two set points in an 11-9 tiebreaker to win the first set and two break points in the final game of the second set to take a two set to none lead.

Meanwhile, Kukushkin, who complained repeatedly about line calls and held a healthy ongoing conversation with himself the first two sets, suddenly turned on his powerful serve and forehand to run away with the third set.
The Russian who became a Kazakhstan citizen last year then broke Chen's serve at 5-5 in the fourth and held serve easily to even the match.

Chen hurt the right side of his abdomen and needed treatment before double faulting on the final point in the fourth set's pivotal 11th game, and his movement was clearly hindered in the deciding set.

Yet Chen held his first two service games and seemed to be regaining some of his earlier momentum against the tiring Kukushkin when the match's Indian referee decided to cast his shadow over the affair with a decision that left the 25 -year-old Taiwanese incensed.

Serving at 2-2 and 30-15, Chen won a rally to go up 40-15, but the referee penalized Chen a point for unsportsmanlike conduct, apparently for motioning with his racket that a ball was out before it was called.

The incredibly rare call came after Chen had been given an earlier warning for such behavior and reverted the game score to 30-30. Unable to regain his poise, the agitated 25-year-old Taiwanese lost the next two points and the game.
Kukushkin made the break stand up, winning his final three service games with relative ease to clinch the match.

Chen was again left furious, however, when, with Kukushkin serving at 30-0 in the match's final game, the chair umpire overturned an out call on a serve that television replays showed landed beyond the service line.
The normally mild-mannered Chen was so angry that he did not show up for the post match press conference.

In the nightcap, Wang showed some of the form that propelled him to a ranking of 85 in 2006, but Golubev, reputed to be a big hitter who can be somewhat erratic, helped with an impatient hit-or-miss strategy that saw him spray the ball around the court without any consistency.
After taking the first set tiebreaker with relative ease, Wang was rarely troubled and effectively allowed the world No. 119, who also became a Kazakhstan citizen last year, to self-destruct.

Taiwan has tentatively scheduled the top ranked junior in 2008, Yang Tsung-hua, to partner with doubles specialist Yi Chu-huan against Kazakhstan's Yuri Schukin and Alexey Kedryuk in Saturday's pivotal doubles.
The team captains can change the pairings up until one hour before the 1 p.m. starting time.

The tie is a preliminary Davis Cup encounter that will narrow Asia/Oceania Zone Group I to eight teams. The winner of this weekend's tie, which will also feature two singles matches on Sunday, will face India March 6-8, when Davis Cup competition begins in earnest.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commerce with China to be weak in first half: official

TEXT.P: There is no reason to be optimistic over the development of economic relations with China in the first half of the year, a top security official suggested Friday.

Kao Chang, deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council, made the remarks in an article on the outlook of the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, which appeared in the latest edition of a monthly journal published by the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), a quasi-official body set up to deal with China in the absence of formal ties.
"China's own economic situation and its policy toward Taiwan are the key factors affecting the development of cross-strait economic relations," Kao said.
"We have no reason to be optimistic in the first half of the year due to the global financial crisis and China's economic slowdown," he said.
"The development of the economic development in the second half will depend on the global situation and China's economic situation, " he added.

Kao said that China, in response to changes at home and abroad, has unveiled since the beginning of 2007 new financial measures such as the Enterprise Tax Law and Labor Contract Law, which he said has raised costs for Taiwanese businessmen operating in China and squeezed their margins.
Some Taiwanese businessmen have been forced to relocate or close their plants, he said.
He noted that the global economic slowdown has yet to bottom out, and the situation could even be exacerbated by the re-emergence of protectionism.
"Since both Taiwan and China are export-oriented economies, they will not be immune from the global economic slowdown," he added.
Kao said that both Taiwan and China have taken a slew of measures to mitigate the impact of the global economic tsunami.

Taiwan and China have signed six major agreements, including opening Taiwan to more Chinese tourists and direct passenger and cargo charter flights, but the impact of those deals will still be influenced by the world economic situation, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei County to lure zoo visitors with free shuttle bus services

TEXT.P: The Taipei County government said Friday it will provide free shuttle bus service on weekends from Feb. 7 to March 1 to take visitors to the Taipei Zoo to six scenic areas in the county.

The free shuttle bus program is apparently intended to take advantage of the "panda fever" generated by a pair of giant pandas, "Tuan Tuan" and "Yuan Yuan," -- a gift to Taiwan from China -- to boost local tourism.
Since Jan. 26, the first day of the Lunar New Year -- the Year of the Ox -- nearly 20,000 visitors from around Taiwan have flocked to the Taipei Zoo each day to see the pair of giant pandas.

To encourage the zoo visitors to see scenic spots in Taipei County after seeing the pandas, the county government will offer free shuttle bus services to take them to six popular destinations: Shenkeng, Shihding, Pingsi, Pinglin, Wulai and Bitan (Green Lake) in Sindian City.
Shenkeng is a small town of 50,000 people located south of Taipei City. It is famous for a variety of tofu dishes and snacks.
Shihding is a scenic mountain township in southern Taipei County. It is renowned for hot springs, tea drinking, and a clean, beautiful river flowing through the town.

The rural township of Pingsi lies in the eastern part of Taipei County and is served by the Pingsi Line of the Taiwan Railway Administration. The scenic area has gained fame for the annual release of sky lanterns that takes place there, but it is also well-known for tea drinking and the delicacies in local restaurants.
Pinglin, another rural township located in a mountainous area in southeastern Taipei County, is the most famous place in Taiwan for producing Pouchong tea and has the world's largest tea museum.
Wulai is a mountain town in southern Taipei County renowned for its hot springs, beautiful sceneries and aboriginal culture.
Green Lake, located in Taipei County's Sindian City, is a good place for people to relax and enjoy their weekend and is suitable for boating, fishing, and barbecuing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Caddie training camp latest strategy to fight unemployment

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung county government has recently opened a "caddie training camp" as part of its efforts to find jobless people in the county work and began accepting applications for the program Friday.
The training camp, which will be held from March 2 to April 9, was founded in cooperation with private golf course operators in the southern Taiwan county.

Those who participate in the training program and are certified will be offered work at the courses, according to a county government statement released Friday. There are currently 20 vacancies at five golf courses in the county.
The trainees who perform well in the five-week training program will be able to begin work immediately at the golf course they live closest to upon graduation, the statement said.

New caddies normally have to accept training for one or two months before starting paid work at a salary of between NT$25,000 (US$741) and NT$35,000 per month, the statement said. Senior caddies can earn up to NT$45,000 per month.
Those who sign up for the camp only have to pay NT$2,989 for the course, with the government subsidizing the balance of NT$14,947 in training fees.
The trainees will be taught golf etiquette and the rules of the game and will learn about golf courses, golf clubs, and how to keep physically fit.
Unemployed individuals with a household registration in the county are eligible to apply for the caddie training program, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: The 2009 Taipei Camellia Flower Exhibition opens

TEXT.P: The 2009 Taipei Camellia Flower Exhibition opened Friday at the Floriculture Experimental Center in the Yangmingshan National Park in suburban Taipei and will last for 10 days until Feb. 15.

Li Mu-ching, director of the center, told reporters that because the exhibition will coincide with Valentine's Day on Feb. 14, the center has used a lot of pink-colored camellia varieties to build a landscape in order to present a romantic atmosphere.
He said visitors entering the center's garden will be greeted by a "camellia flower tunnel" formed by 5,000 blooming camellia plants grown by the center.
There will also be a display of potted camellias, and experts will be on hand on Valentine's Day to explain how to grow them and use them for home decorations.
During the exhibition, the center will give away 50 pots of camellia seedlings to visitors at 10 a.m. and another 50 at 2 p.m. each day.

The camellia flower exhibition is one of five major flower shows in Taipei every year, the other four being the flower season at Yangmingshan National Park from February to March, the calla lily flower season at Yangmingshan's Zhuzi Lake in March and April, the Chrysanthemum Exhibition in the garden of the former presidential residence in Taipei's Shihlin District in November, and the Taipei Flower Exhibition in December.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-lawmaker's elections formally annulled over citizenship issue

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) formally revoked Friday its declarations of former Kuomintang Legislator Lee Ching-an's previous election wins after determining that she held dual citizenship between 1991 and Feb. 1, 2005.

The commission revoked its declaration of Lee's election as a member of the seventh Taipei City Council and of the fourth, fifth and sixth Legislative Yuan and annulled all relevant election certificates she received.
CEC commissioners met in the afternoon to discuss Lee's suspected "dual citizenship" and whether her election to public offices prior to 2008 should be nullified.

According to CEC Secretary-General Teng Tien-yow, commissioners were divided on Lee's citizenship status and a vote was held as the last resort, in which eight commissioners voted against Lee and three voted otherwise.

As to whether the CEC will ask the city council and the legislature to demand Lee return to the national coffers over NT$100 million she received in compensation, Teng said the CEC is not authorized to do so and that the issue should be left to the two institutions to decide.
Teng further said that if Lee disagrees with the CEC's ruling, she is entitled to seek administrative remedies.

Lee Ching-an, who was sworn in for a fourth legislative term Feb. 1, 2008, was found the following month to have never formally renounced her U.S. citizenship, even though she had held public office in Taiwan since 1994.

She resigned Jan. 8 as a member of the seventh Legislative Yuan just as opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) politicians were promoting a campaign to recall her and pro-DPP civic groups were preparing to besiege the legislature to protest the lawmaking body's failure to act against her.

In addition to obtaining U.S. documents related to Lee's U.S. citizenship, Teng said the CEC also asked the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) about U.S. laws and regulations concerning the acquisition and loss of U.S. citizenship.

Moreover, Teng said, the CEC asked the U.S. Department of State through the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in December about Lee's U.S. citizenship status and the ministry passed the State Department's response to the CEC Thursday.

According to Teng, the State Department has completed an administrative screening of Lee's status as a U.S. citizen and concluded that Lee did not fulfill her obligation of committing an expatriating act with the intent of relinquishing her U.S. citizenship when she first assumed public office in Taiwan back in 1994.
At Friday's meeting, the CEC presented all three documents to commissioners for reference.

Lee Ching-an's lawyer Lee Yung-jan attended the CEC meeting, in which he reiterated his client's claim that her U.S. citizenship was automatically canceled when she took the oath of allegiance to the Republic of China by assuming the post of Taipei City councilor in 1994.

Moreover, Lee Yung-jan argued that the CEC is not eligible to nullify Lee's previous election certificates because her previous terms of office already expired. The attorney insisted that only judicial authorities are entitled to judge on the controversy over Lee's citizenship dispute.

Calls for Lee to be formally relieved of her seat mounted after U.S. authorities, in response to an inquiry from Taiwan, confirmed in late 2008 that Lee "has previously been documented as a U.S. citizen with a U.S. passport and that no subsequent loss of U.S. citizenship has been documented."

Taiwan's Nationality Act requires public officials holding dual citizenship to surrender their foreign citizenship before assuming public office and to obtain a certificate as proof within one year of taking office.
The law also requires that those officials who retain foreign citizenship be removed from their posts.
A group of DPP legislators have filed a complaint with the Taipei District Prosecutors Office accusing Lee of forgery and fraud.

The legislators alleged that by holding dual citizenship while in public office, Lee defrauded the public coffers of over NT$100 million in salary as a Taipei City councilor between 1994 and 1998 and as a legislator from 1999 to 2009, and they demanded that she return the "illicit gains."
Lee has been barred from leaving Taiwan pending prosecutorial investigations into fraud and forgery allegations against her.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet pledges to create more jobs with new stimulus plan

TEXT.P: The Cabinet expects to create more jobs this year to help combat the rising number of the unemployed, an economic planning official said Friday.

San Gee, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said the number of created jobs will be increased to 330,000 this year as he unveiled the details of a new economic stimulus plan discussed in a meeting presided over by Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung.
San noted that the Cabinet has mapped out its economic stimulus plan based on four considerations -- reducing layoffs, increasing employment and domestic demand, and caring for the underprivileged.
"Under the economic stimulus plan, the Cabinet is expected to spend NT$715.1 billion between 2009 and 2012, " San said, with spending in 2009 set at NT$330 billion.

The 2009 funding will be primarily earmarked for new public construction projects, short-term jobs, consumption vouchers, subsidies for low wage earners, tax cuts and training courses for those on unpaid leave.
The estimated outlay for increased public construction projects will be NT$133.1 billion.
The Cabinet recently said that its economic stimulus plan can create 150,000 additional job opportunities, but the number was increased to 330,000 Friday.
San said a program to cultivate superior manpower will add 69,000 new jobs alone.
"The program is aimed at solving the unemployment problem for college graduates," he added.
Under the scheme, college graduates will receive training in enterprises, conduct research projects and take part in public services.
The program will offer 35,000 internships in local enterprises for unemployed college graduates who got their degrees between 2006 and 2008, at a monthly salary ranging from NT$22,000 to NT$35,000.
The Ministry of Economic Affairs and the National Science Council will offer the same monthly pay to college graduates serving as assistants in research projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 7, or the 13th day of the first month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1478: Sir Thomas More, English Lord Chancellor who was executed by Henry VIII for refusing to deny the Pope's authority, is born.
1685: King Charles II, king of England, Scotland, and Ireland known as the "merry monarch" who reigned during the Restoration, dies at the age of 55.
1792: Austria and Prussia sign a military pact against France.
1812: Charles Dickens, the great English novelist who wrote a number of well- loved classics like "Oliver Twist" and "David Copperfield," is born.
1816: Italian missionary Giovanni Lantrua of Triora is executed by the Chinese.
1870: Alfred Adler, Austrian psychoanalyst who introduced the concept of the inferiority complex, is born.
1885: Sinclair Lewis, U.S. novelist and Nobel Prize winner who wrote "Main Street," is born.
1886: George Walker, an English carpenter, strikes gold in the Transvaal in South Africa while building a cottage for a prospector.
1948: Liaoning Province falls into the hands of Communist Chinese troops.
1950: Vietnam splits in two, with the Soviet Union recognizing the provisional government of Ho Chi Minh and the United States and Britain endorsing the French-backed government of Emperor Bao Dai.
1955: Republic of China government troops begin to evacuate the Tachen Islands.
1960: Israeli archaeologists unearth a number of Dead Sea Scrolls.
1968: The ROC's Ministry of Education agrees to the establishment of National Central University in Chungli, Taoyuan County.
1971: Switzerland grants women the right to vote.
1973: Former Kaohsiung City Mayor Yang Chin-hu and his wife are arrested for suspected involvement in a bribery case during his term in office.
1974: Grenada gains independence, with Eric Gairy as its first prime minister.
1976: Emanuel O. Gardiner, Liberian deputy minister of planning and economic affairs, and Lafayette Kwie Johnson Jr., assistant minister of the Ministry of Industry, Commerce, and Transportation, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1982: Luis Alberto Monge becomes president of Costa Rica.
1985: The Executive Yuan approves the project to make Yushan into a National Park.
1986 Self-styled "President for Life" Jean Claude "Baby-Doc" Duvalier flees Haiti with his loot, bound for exile in France in the face of a national uprising.
1986: Both Ferdinand E. Marcos and his chief election opponent, Corazon Aquino, claim victory in the Philippine presidential election. The National Assembly would later rule that Marcos won the election.
1990: The Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party votes for a package of reforms that will end its monopoly on power.
1991: In its most daring daylight raid to date, the Irish Republican Army fires three mortar bombs at British Prime Minister John Major's residence at No. 10 Downing Street.
1992: Ministers of Europe formally sign the Maastricht Treaty of the European Union.
1996: A Boeing 757 passenger jetliner on its way from the Dominican Republic to Frankfurt crashes into the Atlantic Ocean, killing all 189 aboard.
1999: Crown Prince Abdullah becomes the king of Jordan following King Hussein's death from cancer.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Perfectly honest men I do not expect to see; if I could only meet with scrupulous men I would be satisfied. But in a state of society in which men must pretend to possess what they really do not possess; pretend to have plenty, when they have really nothing; and pretend to be in affluence when they are in actual want -- in such a state of society, it is difficult to be even a scrupulous man."

DOC.HEADLINE: The 2009 Taipei Camellia Flower Exhibition opens

TEXT.P: The 2009 Taipei Camellia Flower Exhibition opened Friday at the Floriculture Experimental Center in the Yangmingshan National Park in suburban Taipei and will last for 10 days until Feb. 15.

Li Mu-ching, director of the center, told reporters that because the exhibition will coincide with Valentine's Day on Feb. 14, the center has used a lot of pink-colored camellia varieties to build a landscape in order to present a romantic atmosphere.
He said visitors entering the center's garden will be greeted by a "camellia flower tunnel" formed by 5,000 blooming camellia plants grown by the center.
There will also be a display of potted camellias, and experts will be on hand on Valentine's Day to explain how to grow them and use them for home decorations.
During the exhibition, the center will give away 50 pots of camellia seedlings to visitors at 10 a.m. and another 50 at 2 p.m. each day.

The camellia flower exhibition is one of five major flower shows in Taipei every year, the other four being the flower season at Yangmingshan National Park from February to March, the calla lily flower season at Yangmingshan's Zhuzi Lake in March and April, the Chrysanthemum Exhibition in the garden of the former presidential residence in Taipei's Shihlin District in November, and the Taipei Flower Exhibition in December.
