DOC.HEADLINE: Commerce with China to be weak in first half: official

TEXT.P: There is no reason to be optimistic over the development of economic relations with China in the first half of the year, a top security official suggested Friday.

Kao Chang, deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council, made the remarks in an article on the outlook of the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, which appeared in the latest edition of a monthly journal published by the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), a quasi-official body set up to deal with China in the absence of formal ties.
"China's own economic situation and its policy toward Taiwan are the key factors affecting the development of cross-strait economic relations," Kao said.
"We have no reason to be optimistic in the first half of the year due to the global financial crisis and China's economic slowdown," he said.
"The development of the economic development in the second half will depend on the global situation and China's economic situation, " he added.

Kao said that China, in response to changes at home and abroad, has unveiled since the beginning of 2007 new financial measures such as the Enterprise Tax Law and Labor Contract Law, which he said has raised costs for Taiwanese businessmen operating in China and squeezed their margins.
Some Taiwanese businessmen have been forced to relocate or close their plants, he said.
He noted that the global economic slowdown has yet to bottom out, and the situation could even be exacerbated by the re-emergence of protectionism.
"Since both Taiwan and China are export-oriented economies, they will not be immune from the global economic slowdown," he added.
Kao said that both Taiwan and China have taken a slew of measures to mitigate the impact of the global economic tsunami.

Taiwan and China have signed six major agreements, including opening Taiwan to more Chinese tourists and direct passenger and cargo charter flights, but the impact of those deals will still be influenced by the world economic situation, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Caddie training camp latest strategy to fight unemployment

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung county government has recently opened a "caddie training camp" as part of its efforts to find jobless people in the county work and began accepting applications for the program Friday.
The training camp, which will be held from March 2 to April 9, was founded in cooperation with private golf course operators in the southern Taiwan county.

Those who participate in the training program and are certified will be offered work at the courses, according to a county government statement released Friday. There are currently 20 vacancies at five golf courses in the county.
The trainees who perform well in the five-week training program will be able to begin work immediately at the golf course they live closest to upon graduation, the statement said.

New caddies normally have to accept training for one or two months before starting paid work at a salary of between NT$25,000 (US$741) and NT$35,000 per month, the statement said. Senior caddies can earn up to NT$45,000 per month.
Those who sign up for the camp only have to pay NT$2,989 for the course, with the government subsidizing the balance of NT$14,947 in training fees.
The trainees will be taught golf etiquette and the rules of the game and will learn about golf courses, golf clubs, and how to keep physically fit.
Unemployed individuals with a household registration in the county are eligible to apply for the caddie training program, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan calls for EU support for WHO bid
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Feb. 6 (CNA) 02/07/09 12:48:46 (By P.C. Tang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative to the European Union and Belgium called on the group Friday to support Taiwan's bid to take part in the World Health Organization (WHO) and allow the country to contribute its part to the international community.

Making the call during a speech to the Association of European Journalists, Shen Lyushun said Taiwan should at least be granted observer status in the WHO in order to substantiate its "meaningful participation" in the world body.
Shen told his audience that despite its small size, Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) is half as much as that of Canada.
Its GDP is also one-eighth that of China, despite China being many times larger than Taiwan, he noted.

Further pointing to Taiwan's role in international trade, Shen said Taiwan is the 13th-largest trade partner of the European Union behind South Africa and EU's 12th-largest source of imports behind India.

According to Shen, following the recent improvement in Taiwan's relations with China and the establishment of several important agreements between them, Taiwan can play a role in helping the Europen Union advance its ties with China.

Taiwan, which enjoys preferential trade treatment from China in certain areas and is very familiar with China's way of doing business, can also provide assistance to EU enterprises intending to do business in China, he said.
Meanwhile, Shen stressed his mission is to build up mutual trust and mutual understanding between Taiwan and the European Union, rather than causing trouble between the European Union and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Young Taiwanese hiker conquers Mt. Aconcagua

TEXT.P: A 21-year-old Taiwanese hiker has completed a solo expedition to the top of Mount Aconcagua recently, making him the youngest Taiwanese climber to have conquered the highest peak in the Americas on his own, Taiwan's representative office in Argentina said Saturday.

Lin Cheng-han, who arrived in the Argentine province of Mendoza Jan. 11 and began his adventure Jan. 14, successfully reached the top of the 6,962-meter mountain at 2 p.m. on Jan. 25, overcoming severe snow storm and frostbite, according to a statement released by the office.
The statement quoted Lin as saying that the experience made him realize that "you will eventually succeed as long as you have the will to do one thing and take it seriously."
Also, Lin said he is planning to climb Mount Everest -- the world's highest mountain -- in May 2010 as part of his bid to conquer the highest mountains in each of the world's seven continents.
Lin's latest expedition to Mount Aconcagua was filmed for a documentary that will be released in December during the annual Miasan Mountain Film Festival in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Millet wine a hit in China before movie that made it famous
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Feb.7 (CNA) 02/07/09 15:07:35 (By Kuo Mei-lan & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The "Ma La Sun" millet wine made famous by Taiwan's blockbuster hit "Cape No. 7" has made inroads into China's market even before the movie opens there on Feb. 14.

The millet wine producer, the Shinyi Hsiang Farmers' Association from Nantou County in central Taiwan, has already begun exporting the liquor to a Xiamen- based trading company that is serving as its exclusive distributor in China.

Jin Jun, the deputy general manager of the trading company, told the Central News Agency Saturday that the company hopes "Cape No. 7," which recounts the unwavering pursuit of music, dreams and love and showcases the breathtaking landscape of southern Taiwan, can also rock the hearts of Chinese audiences.
The Ma La Sun millet wine went on sale in China on Jan. 8 and proved to be a hit in the market over the traditional Lunar New Year holiday, Jin said.

The limited number of available bottles triggered panic buying among local stores and enterprises, he said, and he hoped that the movie's premiere in China on Feb. 14 would launch a second wave of demand.
The popular millet wine, a traditional beverage among Taiwan's indigenous people, costs 380 yuan (NT$1,870 or US$55.6) per 500 ml bottle.
The low-budget Cape No. 7 unexpectedly became the most popular Taiwanese- produced movie in history, pulling in more than NT$530 million in Taiwan's theaters.
Apart from the millet wine, a handcrafted necklace made of glass beads featured in the movie also has proved popular with Taiwan's consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Grant provided to local publishers to translate German books

TEXT.P: A visiting German official said Saturday that his government is providing financial aid to local publishers to get German books translated into Chinese, in an effort to raise the visibility and popularity of German literature worldwide.

Speaking at the Taipei International Book Exhibition, Clemens-Peter Hasse, head of the Literature and Translation Department of the Munich-based Goethe Institute, said that under the "Book Translation Grant, publishers will receive subsidies of 50 percent to 90 percent of their translation costs for translations of German books published in Taiwan.

Although all types of books are welcome, he stressed that contemporary German literature and topics such as contemporary German history, cultural aspects of the ongoing European unification and current regional and global issues will receive preference when considering grants.
Whether the authors of the chosen books enjoy fame in Germany and whether they can be distributed in Hong Kong and China will also be taken into consideration, Hasse said.

In addition to the import of German literature into Taiwan, Hasse said the export of Taiwan's literary culture to Germany is equally important and can happen through means such as inviting Taiwanese writers to visit the European country for a cultural dialogue.

According to the German Cultural Center, the Goethe Institute's representative in Taiwan, four German books have been translated and introduced to the local market under the program over the past two years, including the workSchilf, " written by Juli Zeh and translated by Wei Tang.
The Taipei-based German Cultural Center encourages publishers who are interested in applying for the grant to log onto the Web site www.goethe.de/uebersetzungsfoerderung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Guest House to open Sunday: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Baroque-style Taipei Guest House, a century-old national historic landmark, will be open to the public from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. Sunday to coincide with the upcoming Lantern Festival, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Saturday.
Foreign Minister Francisco H. K. Ou will also send out new year's greetings on behalf of the ministry by distributing small lanterns to visitors there at 2:30 p.m., according to the MOFA statement.

The ministry said that visitors are required to present identification documents and submit to security checks in order to be allowed entry, and are advised to show up before 3: 30 p.m., the cutoff time for admission to the building.
Photography in the guest house will be prohibited and certain areas will also be off-limits to visitors, the ministry warned, adding that traffic controls in the surrounding area will be imposed.
The Taipei Guest House, designed by Japanese architects and completed in 1901, served as the residence of the governor-general during the Japanese occupation.
The building's name was changed to Taipei Guest House in 1950, and it is now used to receive state guests or hold national banquets, meetings or other events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Fed Cup team preserves Group I status

TEXT.P: Taiwan's women held on to their position in the Federation Cup's Asia/Oceania Group I Saturday after defeating India 3-0 in a relegation battle.
Taiwan's Hwang I-hsuan defeated Rushmi Chakravarthi 6-2, 7-5 in the day's opening singles and Chan Chin-wei clinched the victory with a 7-5, 6-1 thumping of Ankita Bhambri.
In the inconsequential doubles match, Chan and Chuang Chia-jung easily toppled Ankita Bhambri and her sister Sanaa 6-4, 6-2 to complete the whitewash.

With the loss, India will be relegated to the Fed Cup's Asia/Oceania Group II in next year's competition, while Taiwan will remain in Group I, where it has resided every year but one (1996) since the competition adopted its current structure in 1992.

Much like the Davis Cup, the Federation Cup is divided into tiers, with countries vying for promotion to a higher tier on a yearly basis in the hope of reaching the competition's highest level, the World Group, and the second highest level, World Group II.
Asia/Oceania Group 1, composed of eight teams, was divided into two groups this past week in Perth, Australia, with each four-country group playing round robins.
The winners of the two groups then battled Saturday for a chance to advance to the World Group II playoffs, while the losers faced a relegation battle.
Having lost 3-0 to Thailand and Australia and 2-1 to South Korea in Group B round robin play, Taiwan needed to defeat India, the last-place finisher in Group A, to remain in Asia/Oceania Group I.
Both Taiwan and India were missing their top players, with Chan Yung-jan and Hsieh Su-wei pulling out with injuries for Taiwan, and Sania Mirza and Sunitha Rao missing for India.
In the group winners final, Australia beat New Zealand 3-0 to advance to the World Group II playoffs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-legislator to appeal CEC ruling on her dual citizenship status

TEXT.P: Former Kuomintang Legislator Lee Ching-an will appeal the Central Election Commission's (CEC's) recent ruling to annul four of her previous election wins because she held dual citizenship, Lee's attorney said Saturday.

Lawyer Lee Yung-jan argued that the ruling was "illegal" because only a court, rather than the CEC, has the jurisdiction to make a judgment on a dual citizenship dispute involving an elected official.

On a demand by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) that Lee Ching- an be ordered to return the compensation she received during her time in public office, her lawyer argued that this was not an issue because the money was paid for her services in office, not "illicit gains" as the opposition has claimed.

On Friday, the CEC revoked its declaration of Lee Ching-an's election as a member of the seventh Taipei City Council and of the fourth, fifth and sixth Legislative Yuan and annulled all relevant election certificates she received from 1994 to 2005.

The CEC action, however, did not cover her election to the seventh Legislative Yuan in 2008, a post she resigned amid mounting public pressure on Jan. 8, 2009 -- nearly one year after it was discovered that she had never formally relinquished her U.S. citizenship.
Taiwan's Nationality Act requires those holding dual citizenship to surrender their foreign citizenship before assuming public office.

Lee Ching-an insisted that she was awaiting a retroactive ruling by U.S. authorities on her status, after contending that holding public office in another country was an expatriating act that automatically nullified her U.S. citizenship.
A group of DPP legislators have filed a complaint with the Taipei District Prosecutors Office accusing Lee of forgery and fraud.

The legislators alleged that by holding dual citizenship while in public office, Lee defrauded public coffers of over NT$100 million in salary as a Taipei City councilor between 1994 and 1998 and as a legislator from 1999 to 2009, and they demanded that she return the "illicit gains."
Lee has been barred from leaving Taiwan pending prosecutorial investigations.
Lai Ching-te, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, said Saturday that his caucus will continue to press the Legislative Yuan to reclaim Lee's salary based on the CEC ruling.

However, Yang Chiung-ying, a leader of the KMT caucus that holds a two-thirds majority in the lawmaking body, argued that the Legislative Yuan is not in a position to deal with the matter now that Lee Ching-an is no longer a legislator.
Meanwhile, Taipei City Council Speaker Wu Pi-chu said the council will not take the initiative to reclaim the salary Lee Ching-an received while serving in that body more than a decade ago.
The council would do so only if the Executive Yuan, based on the CEC ruling, decided that the salary should be returned and requested the council to help recover the sum, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Young duo puts Taiwan on brink of Davis Cup victory

TEXT.P: Youth -- and a helpful line umpire -- overcame experience Saturday as Taiwan moved to within one win of taking a preliminary round Davis Cup Asia/Oceania Zone Group I tie against Kazakhstan.

Taiwan's 21-year-old Yi Chu-huan and 17-year-old Yang Tsung-hua, with a combined six Davis Cup matches between them, held off the stubborn challenge of veteran Alexey Kedryuk, who was playing in his 98th Davis Cup match, and 29-year-old Russian import Yuri Schukin, 6-7 (5), 7-6 (6), 7-6 (4), 6-4.

The rare doubles win, only Taiwan's second in nine Davis Cup ties since 2005, gives the host a huge advantage ahead of Sunday's reverse singles, in which it will only have to take one of the two matches to capture the best-of-five match tie.

On a fast surface that clearly favored the server, Saturday's match was decided by a brilliant performance from Yi, who aside from losing two points on his serve in the first tiebreaker, delivered at crucial moments.
Yi was only on the squad as a replacement for the injured Lu Yen-hsun, but team captain Lien Yu-hui made him responsible for leading the younger Yang through the match, a responsibility Yi welcomed.
"I focused hard on every single point, " said the normally easily distracted Yi, none more so than with Taiwan down 2-5 in the second set tiebreaker and the match seemingly sliding away.

After getting a huge gift when Schukin pushed out an easy forehand volley that would have given the Kazakhs four set points, Yi hit a service winner and then pulled his side even with a gorgeous topspin lob that froze the Kazakhs at the net.

Kedryuk then gave the visitors a set point with an overhead, but two consecutive winners at the net by an aggressive Yi reversed the tide, and Taiwan took the set when Schukin could not handle an Yi return of serve.

"At that point in the second set, I figured we had nothing to lose and just decided to go for it, " said Yi, who has endured a frustrating two years of poor results, in part because of a lack of dedication, and is hoping Saturday's win will get his young career back on track.
But after Kazakhstan lost the third set tiebreaker, it seemed ready to reverse the momentum by putting pressure on Yang's serve in the first game of the ensuing set.

Facing his second break point in the game, Yang sent a backhand passing shot that seemed to hit just beyond the baseline according to television replays, but the ball was called in, giving Taiwan's duo new life.
An agitated Kedryuk immediately protested to the chair umpire that Yang's shot was out by a foot -- about an 11 1/2 inch exaggeration -- but the chair umpire did not overturn the call.

Considering that there had been no breaks of serve and only four break points to that point in the match, the call was a huge blow to Kazakhstan, and left the team outraged, similar to Taiwan's Chen Ti aday earlier after being done in by an unusual penalty point against him.
Still, the Kazakhs earned another break opportunity in the game, saved by Yang with a blistering serve that Schukin could not return.
It was not until the final game of the match that either team had its serve broken.

Kedryuk, who surpassed the talent for histrionics displayed by teammate Mikhail Kukushkin a day earlier with his accomplished racket throwing and gestures of anguish at every missed shot, was broken at love when Schukin volleyed a return by Yi long.

In Sunday's reverse singles, beginning at 1 p.m. at Sinjhuang Gymnasium in Taipei County, Wang Yeu-tzuoo will face Kukushkin. If he does not win, it will be up to Chen Ti to come through against world No. 119 Andrey Golubev, who was wildly erratic against Wang on Friday.
The winner of the tie will face India in March.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC representative to Singapore attends spring gathering
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Feb. 7 (CNA) 02/07/09 19:28:30 (By Charles Kang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative to Singapore on Saturday expressed the hope that Taiwanese businessmen in the city state will return to Taiwan to invest there.

Vanessa Yea-ping Shih noted that President Ma Ying-jeou's administration has announced a series of policies to ease trade restrictions with China, which has led to a thaw in cross-Taiwan Strait ties that grew chilly under the previous administration.

Ma's administration has also implemented several pro-business policies and measures to encourage investment, Shih said, and she expressed the hope that the businessmen would relocate and set up their headquarters in Taiwan.
Shih made the remarks when she met with Taiwanese expatriates during a spring gathering sponsored by the Taipei Business Association in Singapore.
The former head of the Government Information Office lauded the expatriates for serving as "unofficial diplomats" in promoting bilateral relations.
On the diplomatic front, Shih said that she would adopt a "pragmatic and positive" manner in strengthening bilateral ties between Taiwan and Singapore.
She also handed out red envelopes with a written greeting from President Ma Ying-jeou and Vice President Vincent Siew, saying that Ma had asked her to distribute them prior to her departure.
Ma told her that he had visited Singapore eight times before and each time had been warmly received by Taiwanese expatriates, Shih said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Once a local god, Master Handan now a protected cultural asset

TEXT.P: There are many unverifiable legends to explain why Taitung County people celebrate the annual Lantern Festival by throwing firecrackers at a shirtless man playing "Master Handan, " but what is certain is that the ritual has evolved into a tresured cultural event.

The county government registered the ritual of "bombarding Master Handan" -- held to coincide with the Lantern Festival -- as an intangible cultural asset in 2008, after it was recognized as a local folk activity that contributes significantly to tourism.

Taitung's firecracker blitzkrieg has become one of the most representative traditional ceremonies marking the end of the Lunar New Year season in Taiwan, along with the launch of sky lanterns in Taipei County's Pingsi township and the setting off of a beehive of firecrackers in Yanshuei township in Tainan County.
What is known is that shirtless locals have been bombarded with firecrackers since the Japanese colonial era, but how the ritual gained traction is the stuff of legend.
One version claims that it grew popular by helping rid Taitung of infectious diseases plaguing the area during that time.

After Master Handan was brought out at Lantern Festival time to expel evil spirits while offering blessings to believers, the epidemics came under control, leading to the yearly ritual worshiping of the deity.
Scientists believe that the heat and thick smoke filling the sky from the bombardment of firecrackers may have actually stemmed the spread of dangerous bacteria.
But who is Master Handan?

According to some cultural historians, Handan is a god of wealth who cannot resist the cold. Throwing firecrackers at him can drive the chill from his body during his procession, and the more firecrackers onlookers set off, the more successful and wealthy they will become.

During the ceremony, a chosen person (normally a male) dressed up as Master Handan but bare-chested, stands on a sedan chair in a parade, waiting for worshipers to throw firecrackers at him. The man can only use a banyan branch to protect himself.
Another version of history suggests Master Handan was the god of gangsters and hooligans, who used firecrackers to demonstrate his power.

In the 1970s and 1980s, the Handan role was often assumed by a local organized crime head, with some suggesting that the "bombarding Handan" ritual actually turned into a contest among leaders of rival factions to decide who would become the big boss.
Whoever endured the bombardment the longest took over as gang leader.
That practice, however, drew Taitung police to ban the ritual in 1984, and leaders of local gangs were then sent to jail during raids on organized crime syndicates.
In 1989, then Legislator Yao Eng-chi pushed to revive the traditional celebration, and since then, the ceremony has been transformed from a power struggle among gangsters into an economic indicator.

Business owners have used the activity to demonstrate the success of their enterprise over the past year, with some spending up to NT$200,000 on firecrackers used to bombard Master Handan when he passes their stores.

Now one of Taitung County's main draws, the unique ceremony has had diverse meanings in different eras, but the ceremony itself has remained the same over time, making it one of Taiwan's most enduring displays of local folklore.

DOC.HEADLINE: Don't sacrifice character to the pursuit of victory: KMT chief

TEXT.P: Winning an election is very important, but candidates should not pursue victory at the cost of their characters, Kuomintang Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung said Saturday.

He made the remarks at a Chinese New Year reception hosted by the party's Taipei Chapter at a time when five KMT Taipei City councilors are vying for the party's nomination in a legislative by-election in the city's Daan District.
Three of the five hopefuls showed up at the reception to solicit votes in the party's primary, which will be held Sunday to help choose the party's nominee.

The notable absentee was Councilor Ching Li-fan, who has had a libel complaint filed against her by KMT colleague Lin Yi-hua after Ching claimed that Lin engaged in vote-buying during the primary campaign.
Wu urged the party members to unite together in the by-election, and urged them not to "do anything to the detriment of your beloved and to the pleasure of your foes."
"Taipei voters are quiet knowledgeable and won't buy dirty tricks. We can't afford to win the election at the cost of our characters." Wu said.
After a political career spanning several decades, Wu said he had seen many candidates betrayed by their selfishness and evil in fierce election campaigns.

Wu noted that he was forced to give up his attempt to run for the post of Taiwan provincial governor in 1994 after the KMT fielded party bigwig James Soong in the race, "but I have kept my friendship with James Soong intact."
Soong who was elected governor that year, was widely believed to have earned the KMT nomination because of behind the scenes support from then-KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui.

Soong later fell out of Lee's graces and ran against Lee's hand-picked successor, Lien Chan, in the 2000 presidential election, only to yield victory to DPP candidate Chen Shui-bian by splitting KMT supporters.

"Now, I'm not any worse off than he is, " Wu said, referring to Soong who left the KMT to found his own People First Party after 2000 and quit politics after 2008 after incorporating his party into the KMT.

Pan Jia-sen, chief of the KMT Taipei Chapter, urged the party members at the reception to "forgive whatever grief which might have been caused during the primary campaign and unite behind the candidate who emerges victorious.

Sunday's primary vote will only account for 30 percent of the candidates' overall support in the selection of the KMT nominee, with the other 70 percent decided by an opinion pole carried out between Feb. 5-7.
The winner will be announced by the KMT Taipei Chapter on Feb. 9 and will be nominated on Feb. 11 after being approved by the party authorities.

The by-election, to be held on March 28, will choose a lawmaker to fill the vacancy left by KMT Legislator Lee Ching-an, who quit her post on Jan. 8 after she was reported to hold U.S. citizenship. Elected officials in Taiwan are not allowed to hold dual nationality.
Given that Daan District is a traditional KMT stronghold, whoever wins the nomination will be a heavy favorite on election day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Culture is Taiwan's largest value: godfather of hotel business

TEXT.P: Culture is Taiwan's most important value, hotelier Stanley Yen said Saturday as he urged people to work to maintain Taiwan's culture while embracing the country with heart and devotion.

Yen, known as the godfather of the hotel service industry and currently group president of Landis Hotels and Resorts, made the appeal in a speech at the Taipei International Book Exhibition, being held at the Taipei World Trade Center.
Yen's book "The Future I Saw, " published in March 2008, has been recognized by the book fair as the best non-fiction work.
Apart from the speech, Yen also held an autograph session for the book, attracting over 300 fans.

In the speech, Yen described Taiwan as one of the most civilized Chinese communities in the world. He said, however, that local students can obtain only 20 percent of the knowledge and proper training in school that will make them a leader in any professional sector.
A leader must have the spirit of tolerance, communicating ability and devotion, he said, noting that he believes most learning comes from society, the environment and culture.
He stressed that it is essential for people here to develop a deep knowledge of Taiwan and their own personal values.

DOC.HEADLINE: President wishes for economic turnaround at Lantern Festival

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou expressed his hope Saturday for an economic turnaround for Taiwan as he released a big lantern with the inscription "brighten up the world" at the Pingsi International Sky Lantern Festival.
Another 200 smaller lanterns released by foreign diplomatic staff stationed in Taiwan and other visitors headed toward the heavens alongside the lantern released by Ma.

Addressing the festival, Ma said that after the lanterns floated high in the air like the eyes of the sky, he hoped Taiwan would also be blessed from above and turn into awarm, prosperous and safe society.

The Sky Lantern Festival in Pingsi Township has been celebrated for some 100 years. Like Ma, people write prayers for family and friends on the lanterns, and as the lanterns slowly rise into the sky, make wishes for their prayers to come true in the New Year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 8, or the 14th day of the first month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1517: Spanish explorer Capt. Francisco Hernandez de Cordoba sets sail from Cuba and later "discovers" Mexico.
1587: Mary, Queen of Scots, who had been found guilty of plotting to assassinate England's Queen Elizabeth I, is beheaded.
1725: Peter the Great of Russia dies. He would be succeeded by his wife Catherine.
1902: The eruption of a volcano on the French island of Martinique in the Lesser Antilles kills more than 26,000 people.
1904: Japanese warships launch a surprise night attack against Lushun (Port Arthur) in northern China, destroying three Russian warships and causing the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War.
1906: A strong typhoon hits Tahiti in the South Pacific, killing about 10,000 people.
1910: The Boy Scouts of America organization, a cousin to the movement founded by Sir Robert Baden-Powell in Britain two years earlier, is inaugurated.
1924: The gas chamber as a method of execution is used for the first time in Carson City, Nevada, when Gee Jon, a Chinese gang member, is put to death.
1926: American archaeologists discover relics from the Mayan civilization in the jungles of Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula near the Caribbean coast.
1931: More than 3,000 miners are killed in an accident at the Fushun mine run by a Japanese company of the Southern Manchuria Railway in Liaoning province, northeastern China.
1931: James Dean, the U.S. film actor and cult hero who died at the age of 24 in a road accident while driving his Spider convertible, is born.
1946: A provisional people's council is set up in Soviet-occupied North Korea, with Kim Il Sung serving as chairman.
1949: The National Central Library moves to Taiwan from the Chinese mainland.
1954: More than 14,000 Communist Chinese prisoners of war in Korea who refuse to return to the Chinese mainland begin to undergo job training in Tahu, Siahu, and Yangmei in Taiwan.
1955: Nikolai Bulganin becomes premier of the Soviet Union, replacing Georgi Malenkov.
1962: The U.S. military council is set up in South Vietnam.
1963: President Abdel-Karim Kassem of Iraq is overthrown and killed in a military coup.
1964: Princess Irene of Holland renounces her right to the throne in order to marry Spanish Prince Carlos Hugo of Bourbon-Parma.
1965: British Health Minister Kenneth Robinson announces that cigarette ads will be banned from television.
1966: The Republic of Vietnam and the United States issue the Declaration of Honolulu, outlining their aims for Vietnam.
1974: Dr. George L.B. Pratt, director of the Office of Education and Manpower, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1974: Chinese investors in Taiwan and Gulf Oil Corporation officials agree on the establishment of a joint company to produce low-density polyethylene.
1976: Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan decorates Dr. Harry Bodan Shields, visiting vice minister of foreign affairs of the Republic of Nicaragua, with the Grand Cordon of the Order of Brilliant Star.
1976: Guatemalan Ambassador Agustin Donis Kesler calls on Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan to thank the government for helping earthquake victims.
1980: Louis Vorster, new ambassador of the Republic of South Africa, presents his credentials to President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1984: Athletes from the Republic of China re-enter the Olympic Games, taking part in the 1984 Winter Olympic Games in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia under the name "Chinese Taipei."
1995: The U.S. liaison office in Vietnam begins business operations, marking the first step in the return to normal relations between the two countries.
2000: President Lee Teng-hui says the ROC and the Vatican should join hands to strive for freedom and democracy for the enslaved people in mainland China and other parts of the world.
2001: Chen Li-fu, a member of the presidium of the opposition Kuomintang Central Advisory Committee, dies at the age of 103.
2001: Two reporters from mainland China's Xinhua News Agency who have been granted permission to be stationed in Taiwan arrive in Taipei, marking a new milestone for news exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are, perhaps, men who propound theories they themselves do not understand. That is a thing I never do. I read and learn everything and, choosing that which is excellent, I adopt it; I see everything and take note of what I see: that is, perhaps, next to having a great understanding."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
New private investment in 2008 beats target: economics ministry

TEXT.P: New investment commitments from the private sector last year exceeded the government target of NT$1.08 trillion (US$32.09 billion) by 0.76 percent, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Sunday.
As of the end of last December, a total of 1,427 new investment projects worth NT$1.0882 trillion were approved by the ministry for the whole of 2008, according to the MOEA.
Some NT$1.13 trillion in investment projects were actually completed during the year, part of that from ventures committed to in 2007.

The government has set a slightly lower target for new private investment in 2009 at NT$1.001 trillion, hoping measures approved last year to relax investment restrictions and increase incentives for new ventures will spur private investment amid a weak economy, MOEA officials said.

President Ma Ying-jeou has promoted 12 major national development projects in the past year that the government also hopes will stimulate private sector investment and sustain growth to help Taiwan snap out of the recession.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan promotes tourism at New York Times Travel Show
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 7 (CNA) 02/08/09 16:51:10 (By Lillian Lin and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is hoping that its presence at the 2009 New York Times Travel Show, being held until Feb. 8 at Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, will help counter a slowdown in international travel that is hurting the tourism industry.

Held in early-February every year, the show is one of the most important travel exhibitions in the world. This year, it has brought together exhibitors from more than 100 countries to man over 500 booths.
The Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications has a presence at the show, showcasing Taiwan's tourist attractions in three booths covering 100 square feet.
To give viewers an insight into Taiwan's culture, the bureau has arranged special events during the show, including a folk dance performance and demonstrations of tea brewing and paper cutting.
A group of New York-based Taiwanese teenagers is slated to stage a dance on Feb. 7 and Feb. 8, respectively, to help attract visitors to the Taiwan booths.
With unique souvenirs from around the world a main attraction for many show visitors, the bureau has also prepared 100 ox-shaped lanterns marking the Year of the Ox as giveaways.

Local carriers China Airlines and EVA Airways and major tour operators Asia Pacific Delight Tours, Celebrity Tours and SITA World Tours are also offering a wide array of travel packages and discounts to catch the attention of visitors.

Moreover, the Tourism Bureau's New York office has invited U.S. travel columnist Barry Goldsmith, who just concluded a visit to Taiwan, to share his experience and introduce Taiwan's arts, natural beauty, folklore, customs and cuisine in a Q&A format.

The World Tourism Organization reported last week that global tourism could decline by up to 2 percent in 2009 amid the global slowdown. It said tourist arrivals worldwide during 2008 rose to 924 million, 2 percent higher than the previous year.

The downturn nonetheless had a negative effect on the sector in 2008 as the 2 percent growth rate fell far below the 7 percent average annual growth seen between 2004 and 2007, according to the organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP names Taipei City councilor to run in by-election

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) announced Sunday that Taipei City Councilor Chou Po-ya will represent the party in a legislative by-election to fill the seat vacated by a ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislator over a dual citizenship controversy.

DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Chou, who is well versed on education and financial issues, is the right choice for the legislative by-election in Taipei City's Daan district, where education and financial issues have been key points of debate and attention.

Tsai said she appreciated Chou's personality traits, pointing out that he is "constantly progressive, " concerned about human rights and environmental protection, and always keeps up with changes, but never blindly follows a crowd.
For his part, Chou said he feels honored to be nominated by the DPP but considers it a major responsibility.

Noting that the DPP does not hold any of the eight seats representing Taipei City in the legislature, Chou said the Daan district by-election comes at a crucial juncture for the DPP and gives Taipei residents a chance to make a new, fresh choice.

He contended that in the face of the KMT's one-party dominance in the legislature, the DPP must "stand out" courageously and not miss any chance to optimize the DPP's influence as an opposition party.
If Chou wins the by-election, he will increase the number of DPP seats in the legislature to 28.
There are currently 111 legislators in the lawmaking body. A by-election will be held on March 14 in Miaoli County to fill a seat vacated by a KMT legislator convicted of vote buying.
Once Lee's former seat is filled in the March 28 by-election, the legislature will be returned to its full complement of 113 lawmarkers.
The ruling KMT is holding a primary this weekend to determine its candidate to oppose Chou in the pro-KMT stronghold.
Lee, a KMT legislator from 1999 to 2009, announced her resignation from the legislature Jan. 8, citing the dispute over her alleged dual citizenship.
Her resignation came after DPP politicians promoted a campaign to recall her and pro-DPP civic groups prepared to besiege the legislature to protest the lawmaking body's failure to act against her.

According to the current Public Officials Election and Recall Law, a by-election has to be held in Taipei City's Daan district within three months to elect a replacement to fill the position vacated by Lee.

Lee, who was sworn in for a fourth legislative term Feb. 1, 2008, was found the following month to have never formally renounced her U.S. citizenship, even though she had held public office in Taiwan since 1994.

Taiwan's Nationality Act requires public officials holding dual citizenship to surrender their foreign citizenship before assuming public office and to obtain a certificate as proof within one year of taking office.
The law also requires that those officials who retain foreign citizenship be removed from their posts.
Lee has been barred from leaving Taiwan pending an investigation into fraud and forgery allegations against her.

DOC.HEADLINE: President pushes to boost tourism in Taiwan's indigenous areas

TEXT.P: Concerned over the development of tourism in Taiwan's indigenous areas, President Ma Ying-jeou asked government agencies Sunday to work with travel agents and arrange for more Chinese tourists to visit local tribes.

Ma instructed the Cabinet-level Council of Indigenous Peoples and the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to help Taiwan's indigenous tribes incorporate their unique and colorful designs and cultural elements in tourism facilities, such as inns and restaurants, to lure more visitors, including those from China.
He asked the Tourism Bureau to organize a meeting in Taipei with representatives of indigenous peoples and travel agents to explore ways to achieve the goal.

Ma issued the call while attending a seminar at the Sun Moon Lake National Scenic Area Administration in central Taiwan's Nantou County after representatives from the local Thao, Bunun and Sediq tribes complained that indigenous areas had not benefited from last year's expansion of transportation and tourism links with China.

Chuan Wen-sheng, a former legislator from the Bunun Tribe, suggested authorities include indigenous villages near Sun Moon Lake into the area's development plan to help boost tourism in indigenous areas.

Stressing that he fully supports indigenous tribes' keen desire to boost local tourism, the president said he would set a deadline to push relevant authorities to come up with concrete plans and strategies through close monitoring.

Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Kung Wen-chi urged the central government to work on the issue, as so far none of the Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan had visited or purchased handicraft items in any tribal areas across the country.
Sun Moon Lake is one of Taiwan's top tourist destinations that enjoy widespread popularity among Chinese visitors. Several tribes, including the Thaos, reside in the adjacent areas to the lake.

Apart from Sun Moon Lake, famous Hsitou Forest Recreation Park, Shanlinshi Forest Recreation Park, Yushan National Park, Mt. HeHuan and DongPu Hot Spring Scenic Spot are also located in Nantou County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumer vouchers boost sales of energy-saving appliances: BOE

TEXT.P: Shopping vouchers distributed by the government have significantly boosted the purchase of locally made energy-saving electric appliances, the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Sunday.

The MOEA launched a program last October that provides an NT$2,000 subsidy to local consumers when purchasing Taiwan-made appliances bearing energy-saving labels, such as washing machines, air conditioners, and refrigerators.

Before the consumer vouchers were issued on Jan. 18, the MOEA had received 99,178 applications for the NT$2,000 subsidy, but in just three days after the launching of the shopping vouchers program, another 12,759 applications had been received, according to bureau figures.
That translates to 4,253 applications per day, a stark contrast to the 910 requests per day received prior to the issuing of the shopping vouchers, bureau figures indicate.

"Consumers have made good use of the two policies that have been designed by the government to boost domestic consumption, " the bureau said in a statement, adding that it was happy to see consumers so eager to replace old appliances with far more energy-saving devices.

According to the bureau, air conditioners, refrigerators and washing machines with its energy-saving label, can save 20.8 percent, 19.1 percent, and 43.5 percent of energy respectively, compared to conventional domestic electrical appliances.

The government's NT$530 million (US$15.8 million) plan hopes to boost the sales of domestically produced househould electric appliances from 122,000 units to 265,000 units in six months, which will represent an estimated NT$9 billion in domestic spending.
The energy-saving appliances subsidy program is expected to last until March 31 this year.
The energy-saving label is granted by the bureau for products with energy efficiencies that are 10 percent to 50 percent higher than normal standards.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese women attempting to transit to U.S. with fake papers nabbed

TEXT.P: Three young Chinese women attempting to transit through Taiwan to the United States using fake Republic of China passports were nabbed at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport Saturday, the National Immigration Agency (NIA) said Sunday.
The three Chinese women, all aged over 18, were discovered at an airport gate using bogus ROC passports and fake boarding passes carrying counterfeit departure stamps, the agency said.
After a preliminary investigation, airport police discovered that the three flew to Taiwan from Hong Kong Saturday with travel documents indicating they were transiting to Palau on holiday.

The police found that the three canceled their airplane tickets for Palau immediately upon landing in Taiwan, and were given the fake passports and travel documents for flights destined for the United States by intermediaries.
Believing that the Chinese women were supported by a "snake head" human trafficking ring, NIA officials have referred them to the Taoyuan District Prosecutors Office for further investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma praises Taiwanese for being grateful for others' compassion

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Sunday praised the people of Taiwan for showing their thanks to those who have helped them in time of need.
Traveling to the Jhushan township in the landlocked county of Nantou, Ma praised Taiwan's people during a visit to Zinan Temple, a Taoist shrine famous for having loaned cash to followers in need.

The manager of the temple told Ma that more than 430,000 people borrowed a total of NT$250 million (US$7.42 million) from the land god worshipped at Zinan Temple last year to allow them to ride out financial difficulties.

The borrowers, however, repaid NT$300 million to the temple, Ma was told, and the president saluted the honesty and gratitude demonstrated by the borrowers, saying the traits are important values of the country.

After being repaid with interest by the borrowers, the temple authorities then used the extra money to bolster its charity and public interest drives, including giving out scholarships and subsidies to youths from low-income families, financially supporting care for the elderly, and other social programs.
Zinan Temple, a shrine-like place with a small area of less than 33 square meters, has a 300-year history, according to temple authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City zoo to close for renovation

TEXT.P: The Shoushan Zoo in the southern port city of Kaohsiung said Sunday it is scheduled to close Monday for a renovation project that is planned to take half a year to complete, but denied it was related to housing two white tigers from China.
The zoo has appropriated NT$150 million (US$3.45 million) to fund the renovation project aimed at revamping the entire facility, including parking lots, zoo authorities said.

Noting that the zoo needs an overhaul after having not been revamped for 30 years, they denied that the renovation will be carried out to create a new place to house two white tigers that the zoo plans to import from China in June.

Meanwhile, Kaohsiung City Tourism Bureau Director Lin Kun-shan said it is still unclear whether the Shoushan Zoo will bring in the white tigers from Guangzhou, adding that the city government is still assessing the possibility.
The official's denial contradicted what another city official said last December concerning the tiger import plan.
Tang Cheng-juei, director of the Kaohsiung City Scenic Area Administration, said Dec. 17, 2008 that a pair of white tigers are scheduled to be placed in the Shoushan Zoo in June 2009.
Tang said the rare animals are a gift of the Guangzhou Xiangjiang Safari Park in southern China to promote friendship between Guangzhou and Kaohsiung.
The zoo has appropriated NT$118 million to fund a renovation project aimed at creating a space at the zoo to house the two white tigers, he added.
The tigers are expected to attract an increased number of visitors to the zoo, which draws nearly 500,000 persons a year, he forecast at the time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's population exceeds 23.04 million

TEXT.P: Taiwan's population stood at 23,046,177 as of the end of January, an increase of 79,718 people compared to the year earlier figure, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) reported Sunday.

The ministry said that according to household registry statistics, the number of registered households in Taiwan reached 7,657,870 at the end of last month, an increase of 1.85 percent, or 139,309 households, over the same period last year.

By city and county, Taipei County had the greatest number of households, totaling 1,340,934 households, or 17.51 percent of the nation's total. Trailing Taipei County was Taipei City, with 957,954 households, or 12.51 percent of the country's total, the ministry said.
The outlying island county of Kinmen saw the highest rate of population growth over the past year, followed by Hsinchu City and Hsinchu County.
The highest rate of decline came in Lienchiang County, which includes the island of Matsu, followed by Taitung County, according to the ministry.
A total of 13,469 babies were born in January, for an average of one birth every 3.3 minutes, while 9,689 people died in January, an average of one death every 4.6 minutes.
A total of 15,166 couples tied the knot in January, while 3,064 couples divorced in the month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet to submit budget bill for NT$500 billion stimulus package

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will submit a special budget bill for an NT$500 billion (US$14.84 billion) economic stimulus package to the Legislative Yuan by Feb. 19 and hopes it will clear the legislative floor by the end of March, a Cabinet official said Sunday.

Following passage of the "Special Statute for Stimulating the Economy via Expanding Infrastructure Investment" in the Legislative Yuan Jan. 15, the Cabinet will submit the budget plan once it is reviewed by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning And Development at a meeting slated for Feb. 9 and is approved by the Cabinet between Feb. 12-19, according to the official.
If everything goes as expected, the bill to authorize the financing for the stimulus plan, will be passed as scheduled, the official added.
The plan calls for an investment of NT$500 billion over four years in infrastructure projects to bolster the sagging economy and curb unemployment.
Under the scheme, NT$133.1 billion will be spent this year, including NT$103.9 billion to expand public works projects and another NT$29.2 billion to sponsor a job creation program.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most anti-smoking violations in workplace: foundation

TEXT.P: The non-profit John Tung Foundation has received 142 complaints since a law banning smoking in public indoor areas took effect nearly a month ago, the anti- smoking group said Sunday.

Speaking at a news conference at the foundation's headquarters, foundation CEO Yao Shi-yuan said that to many people's surprise, as many as 80 percent of the alleged cases, or 110, took place in the workplace, including in offices of superiors, stairwells or bathrooms.

According to Yao, the finding confounded the expectations of foundation workers, who thought most violations would occur at coffee shops, restaurants, bus or train stations and outdoor areas surrounding hospitals.

Yao blamed the Bureau of Health Promotion under the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) -- the agency in charge of enforcing the anti-smoking amendment -- and its misguided interpretation of the law and lax law enforcement for the high rate of violations.

Under an amendment to the Tobacco Hazards Prevention Act, which took effect Jan. 11, smoking is forbidden in offices manned by three or more people as well as in the indoor areas of most public premises, including roofed transportation stations, KTV parlors, passageways, and staircases.
Only four kinds of establishments -- hotels, restaurants, shopping malls and nursing homes for the elderly -- are allowed to set up smoking rooms under certain strict requirements.
The law stipulates a fine of up to NT$10,000 (US$300) for those who smoke in facilities where it is prohibited and up to NT$50,000 for the owners of these premises.
Under the law, the only public places in which smoking is allowed indoors are night clubs or bars that do not admit patrons under the age of 18 and open after 9 p.m.
According to Sun Lee-chun, the chairman of the monthly Consumers News magazine, the public's participation is the most important factor in stamping out smoking in places where smoking is banned.
Sun suggested that all city and county governments provide incentives to people for reporting unlawful smokers as they have done to encourage citizens to crack down on cigarette littering.

To date, 21 out of Taiwan's 25 cities and counties are offering rewards of 5 percent to 50 percent of the fines imposed on violators to people who report illegal cigarette littering to local authorities, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taekwondo athlete promotes her first book at TIBE 2009

TEXT.P: Taiwan's outstanding taekwondo athlete Su Li-wen introduced her new book, "The Undefeatable Child, " at the 2009 Taipei International Book Exhibition on Tuesday, hoping to share her experiences as a taekwondo Olympian with Taiwanese youth.

Despite being defeated by Croatia's Martina Zubcic 4-5 in the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games bronze medal match in the women's under 57 kilogram class, Su's preseverance drew praise and cheers from people in both Beijing and Taipei.

The highly determined athlete refused to give up after crumbling to the ground in agony 11 times during the three bouts she fought because the left knee she injured in her first bout could not support her weight.

"I had never dreamed of being able to write a book about my past experiences, " said Su, but after being encouraged by her family and friends, she decided to share her experiences as a female taekwondo athlete.

Su said an athlete's attitude is vital to the outcome of any competition, and that at the most trying moments during her bronze medal bout, all she could think of was winning a medal for Taiwan and her father.

"I made a deal with my father before departing for the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games, " Su said. She promised her father that she would do her very best to bring home a medal if her father was willing to continue fighting his gradually worsening oral cancer.
According to Su, her father played a vital role in her career as a taekwondo athlete, as he taught her the importance of self-confidence, self-discipline and determination.

Asked if she ever thought about quitting during her Olympic bouts, Su proudly said that giving up is against the core value of any athlete who respects himself, adding that it would have been an honor to "fight to the death at the Olympic Games."
Encouraging Taiwan's youth, Su stressed that, "you must never give up in order to succeed, no matter what your profession is, as the key elements for success are universally similar."
Asked if she intends to represent Taiwan again in future international competitions, Su said she is very happy with her teaching position at National Taiwan Sport University.
"I don't want to speculate about the possibility of participating in future events as I'm still recovering from the injuries I sustained at last year's Olympic Games, " she said.

Meanwhile, Chi Cheng, who won a bronze medal in the 80-meter low hurdles in the 1968 Summer Olympics and obliterated, 44 Asian and 10 world records, said that she broke into tears when she saw Su fall during the bronze medal bout in Beijing.

"She is definitely one of the best athletes in Taiwan's history," said Chi, adding that Su's spirit and undying determination had much greater meaning than that of an Olympic gold medal to Taiwanese citizens.
In addition, Chi urged the public to continue supporting outstanding athletes like Su in order to help promote a better environment for molding and training future professional athletes.
Su won the gold medal at the 2006 Asian Games in Doha, the 2007 World University Games in Bangkok and the 2008 Asian Taekwondo Championship.
Before the opening of the 2008 Beijing Olympics, Su was the only Taiwanese athlete predicted to win a gold medal at the Games by the United States-based Sports Illustrated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan overcomes Kazakhstan behind unheralded Chen in Davis Cup

TEXT.P: Bring on India!

During a week when the absence of Taiwan's top player Lu Yen-hsun and Kazakhstan's three top-200 Russian imports threatened to become the main storylines of their Asia/Oceania Zone Group I Davis Cup tie, unheralded Chen Ti had the last laugh.

Playing an unexpected foe who defeated him last year in five sets in a Davis Cup tie in Almaty, Chen returned the favor Sunday, defeating world No. 180 Yuri Schukin 4-6, 6-3, 2-6, 7-6 (3), 6-1 to give Taiwan an unassailable 3-1 lead in a 4-1 victory over the visitors.

"When I played Schukin last year, I saw he was ranked pretty high and figured he would be tough to beat. But this time I played knowing I could win, " the world No. 375 Chen said. "I never thought I would lose at any point during the match."
Chen won the deciding point in a 3-2 win over Pakistan in February 2006, but he had never played such an impressive match under pressure against such a high- ranked opponent.
"You don't get many chances to shine on a big stage, so I wanted to take advantage of the opportunity," Chen said.
The victory was a nice birthday present to Wang Yeu-tzuoo, who turned 24 on Sunday.

Wang, trying to relaunch his career this weekend after sitting out most of 2008, was spared the pressure of a best-of-five set match and defeated world No. 145 Mikhail Kukushkin 2-6, 6-3, 6-3 to complete Taiwan's 4-1 triumph.
Taiwan needs to win two more ties if it hopes to reach the World Group playoffs, the gateway to the Davis Cup's top tier, for the first time in its history.
It will host India on March 6-8, and a win there would pit it against the winner of either Australia or Thailand.
Taiwan entered Sunday needing only to win one of the day's two reverse singles.
Chen was supposed to play world No. 119 Andrey Golubev in Sunday's opener, but Kazakhstan went with Schukin instead of Golubev, who was wildly erratic in a straight set loss to Wang Friday.
For three sets, it appeared to be a good move, as the 29-year-old Schukin's consistency, angled shots from the baseline and accurate passing shots kept Chen off balance.
Chen seemed to pick up momentum after breaking Schukin at love to take a 4-3 lead in the fourth set, but gave it back three games later when he was broken serving for the set.
Another two games later, down 5-6 and serving to stay in the match, Chen faced his biggest test.
An ace that would have put him up 40-30 was overturned by the chair umpire after Schukin complained the line umpire signaled the ball out.

The 25-year-old Taiwanese, who completely lost his cool in a similar situation in the fifth set of his loss to Kukushkin Friday, this time accepted the call, and prompted by a roar of encouragement from the crowd, defiantly pounded two service winners to clinch the game.
"I vowed before the match not to let any decision by the umpires bother me. And when the crowd got into it, it really pumped me up, " Chen said.

Helped by two Schukin unforced errors, Chen slammed an overhead and made two winning forays to net to take a 5-2 lead in the tiebreaker and then sent the crowd into a frenzy with a half volley off a Schukin overhead that trickled over the net out of his stunned opponent's reach.
Two points later, he clinched the tiebreaker with a big serve.

Once Chen broke a tiring Schukin in the second game of the final set, victory seemed assured, a victory that gave Chen newfound confidence that he could finally rise beyond his career best 255 ranking, accomplished in 2005.
"Staying with guys ranked in the 100s this weekend was important, because if I hadn't been able to, I would have asked myself what the point was of continuing to compete on tour, " said Chen.
After two strong performances this weekend, he no longer has to ask.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei County spends NT$12.5 million on performances countywide

TEXT.P: The Taipei county government has allocated NT$12.5 million (US$370,920) to fund a series of cultural performances being staged until March 27 around the county's 29 townships and cities, a county official said Sunday.

The initiative is designed to bring more cultural entertainment to local residents in an attempt to bridge the cultural divide between Taipei City and Taipei County, according to Wei Ting-lung, an official in the county's Bureau of Cultural Affairs.

Local residents are welcome to view the weekend shows free of charge, Wei said, adding that many famous troupes have been included in the program, including the Ming Hwa Yuan Taiwanese Opera Company, which he estimated would attract 5,000 people to each show it staged.

To meet the different needs of audiences in various localities, the county government met with representatives from the 29 townships and cities to discuss the selection of performing groups, Wei said.
The series of shows covers many cross-disciplinary performances, including puppet shows, folk dances and songs, dramas and acrobatics.

The recruited performers include famous 1970s pop singer Betty, I Wan Jan Puppet Theater, the Ju Percussion Group, Song Song Song Children's and Puppet Theater, Formosa-Zephyr Opera Troupe and Yi-Sin Taiwanese Opera Troupe.
Moreover, 12 senior Taiwanese folk song singers will stage concerts on Feb. 21 in Pinglin township and Feb. 27 in Shulin.

DOC.HEADLINE: 560,000 received shopping vouchers in second stage of distribution

TEXT.P: More than 560,000 people picked up their shopping vouchers Saturday, the first day that those who did not get their vouchers on Jan. 18 could collect them, a Chunghwa Post Co. official said Sunday.
"Unlike Saturday, there were no incidents of overcrowding during the second day of the second stage of distributing the vouchers," the official said.

According to the official, close to 21 million people collected their vouchers on Jan. 18, and of the remaining 2.01 million who did not pick them up that day, 560,000 showed up at local post offices around the country Saturday.

Post office employees worked overtime to issue the vouchers from 1: 30 p.m-5: 30 p.m. Feb. 7, and from 8 a.m-5: 30 p.m Feb. 8, the official said, adding that the designated post offices will no longer provide extended hours of service starting from Feb. 9.
"Those who have not yet claimed their shopping vouchers can pick them up at designated post offices around the nation during regular office hours between Feb. 9 and April 30, " the official said.
Aimed at spurring consumer spending and boosting the economy, NT$3,600 in shopping vouchers are being distributed to all of Taiwan's citizens. The vouchers can be used until Sept. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: Veteran city councilor wins KMT primary for by-election nomination

TEXT.P: A veteran Taipei city councilor won a five-way race Sunday to become ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) nominee in a legislative by-election to fill the seat vacated by a KMT legislator over a dual citizenship controversy.

Chiang Nai-hsin, a seven-term city councilor, beat four other contenders in not only a primary vote by KMT members residing in the capital city's Daan district held Sunday but also in two rounds of public opinion polls conducted between Feb. 5-7.
According to the KMT primary regulations, the vote accounted for 30 percent of the candidates' support and the opinion poll accounted for the other 70 percent.
Chiang defeated the other four fellow city councilors in both the vote and the opinion polls by comfortable margins.
In the primary vote, Chiang garnered 1,221 ballots or 54.815 percent of the total valid votes, far surpassing the 518 ballots won by runner-up Lin Yi-hua, also a city councilor.

According to KMT Taipei City chapter data, 6,261 party members were eligible to vote in the primary, but only 2,198 valid ballots were cast at five polling stations erected in the district for a voter turnout of 35.32 percent.
The results of public opinion polls conducted by Shih Hsin University and TVBS public opinion survey centers showed Chiang with 54.3 percent support, well ahead of Lin's 21.2 percent.
The public support rates for the three other contenders -- Lee Ching-yuan, Chin Li-fang and Lee Hsin -- were 10.9 percent, 7.8 percent and 5.2 percent, respectively.

After disclosing the results of the vote and opinion polls at a news conference, Pan Chia-sen, head of the KMT Taipei chapter, announced that Chiang will represent the KMT in the March 28 legislative by-election.

Three losing contestants -- Lee Ching-yuan, Lee Hsin and Chin Li-fang -- showed up at the KMT Taipei City office to throw their support behind Chiang, who rushed to the office after learning of his primary win.
Chiang, 59, who has served as a city councilor for 28 years, said he will pay a visit to Lin Yi-hua, the only loser who was absent from the post-primary morale- boosting gathering.
Lin campaigned fiercely in the primary and was accused of vote-buying by Chin.
As Daan district is a KMT stronghold, Chiang is widely seen as a heavy favorite in the by-election now that he has won the KMT nomination.
Nevertheless, Chiang said he will still need the united support of KMT politicians and rank-and-file members to claim a final victory in the by- election.
Chiang will face another veteran Taipei City councilor, Chou Po-ya of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party, in the by-election.
There are currently 111 legislators in the lawmaking body. A by-election will be held on March 14 in Miaoli County to fill a seat vacated by Lee E-ting, a KMT legislator convicted of vote buying.
Once Lee Ching-an's former seat is filled in the March 28 by-election, the legislature will be returned to its full complement of 113 lawmarkers.

Lee, a KMT legislator from 1999 to 2009, announced her resignation from the legislature Jan. 8, citing the dispute over her alleged dual citizenship. Her resignation came after DPP politicians promoted a campaign to recall her and pro-DPP civic groups prepared to besiege the legislature to protest the lawmaking body's failure to act against her.

According to the current Public Officials Election and Recall Law, a by-election has to be held in Taipei City's Daan district within three months to elect a replacement to fill the position vacated by Lee.

Lee, who was sworn in for a fourth legislative term Feb. 1, 2008, was found the following month to have never formally renounced her U.S. citizenship, even though she had held public office in Taiwan since 1994.

Taiwan's Nationality Act requires public officials holding dual citizenship to surrender their foreign citizenship before assuming public office and to obtain a certificate as proof within one year of taking office.
The law also requires that those officials who retain foreign citizenship be removed from their posts.

Calls for Lee to be formally relieved of her seat mounted after U.S. authorities, in response to an inquiry from Taiwan, confirmed in late 2008 that Lee "has previously been documented as a U.S. citizen with a U.S. passport and that no subsequent loss of U.S. citizenship has been documented."

In a recent response to an inquiry by Taiwan's Central Election Commission, the U.S. State Department further concluded that Lee did not fulfill her obligation of committing an expatriating act with the intent of relinquishing her U.S. citizenship when she first assumed public office in Taiwan back in 1994.
Lee has been barred from leaving Taiwan pending an investigation into fraud and forgery allegations against her.

DOC.HEADLINE: Large Chinese tourism delegation arrives for visit

TEXT.P: A 127-member Chinese tourism delegation, headed by Li Yabai, director of the Travel and Tourism Bureau of Henan Province in China, arrived in Taipei Sunday to see for themselves colorful Lantern Festival celebrations in Taiwan.
According to local tour promoters, the delegation is the largest of its kind since Beijing authorities allowed more Chinese citizens to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan late last year.

Attracted by Taiwan's now internationally renowned Lantern Festival celebrations, Li said the group will travel to Yilan City on northeastern coast Monday where a series of festive activities will be launched in the evening to celebrate the festival, which falls on the 15th day of the first lunar month.

"Taiwan is known to be versed in merging tradition and innovation in organizing traditional festive activities and we hope to learn more about Taiwan's achievements in this regard during our current visit," Li said.
Moreover, Li said, the group, composed of provincial tourism officials and travel service operators, will tour major signseeing spots to appreciate Taiwan's natural scenery.
During its eight-day stay, the delegation will also visit local institutions in charge of travel promotion and service quality certification as well as relevant administrative agencies.

In addition to the central government-organized Taiwan Lantern Festival activities in Yilan City, many other festive events that integrate tradition and innovation will also take place in many other parts of the country to celebrate the Lantern Festival.

Local tourist officials said they will introduce special features of those activities to the Chinese delegation for their reference in organizing tour packages for ordinary Chinese tourists in the future.

The most special celebration activities include the firecracker blitzkrieg known as "bombarding Master Handan" in Taitung County, the release of airborne paper lanterns known as "sky lanterns" in Pingsi township in Taipei County and the setting-off of a beehive of firecrackers in Yanshuei township in Tainan County, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA mulling financial subsidy to encourage franchise stores

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is planning to offer financial subsidies to help wage earners launch their own ventures by joining retail franchises, an official said Sunday.
According to the official, the ministry plans to offer each new franchise store NT$50,000 (US$1,483.68) in subsidy.

A recent survey by the online job broker 104 Job Bank found that 81.6 percent of the respondents are interested in starting a business and that on average, the potential entrepreneurs would require NT$565,300 in startup funds.
The MOEA official said if 3,000 new franchise stores are launched under the program, the government will offer up to NT$150 million in subsidy for those new ventures.

If the program succeeds in inspiring entrepreneurship, the official said it will be able to help increase private investment by an estimated NT$18.4 billion, create 46,000 job openings and generate NT$50 billion in business opportunities.
"If all goes well, the subsidy program will also be effective in resolving the worsening unemployment issue, " the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Feb. 9, 2009

TEXT.P: 2. Event: Lighting ceremony for the 2009 Taiwan Lantern Festival. Date and Time: 06:30 p.m., Monday, Feb.9, 2009. Place: Yilan Sports Park, No.755, Zhongshan Road, Sec.1, Yilan City. Host and/or main speakers: President Ma Ying-jeou. Organizers: Tourism Bureau. Press Contact: Tel. 2311-3731 & 2349-1500.
