The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: President pushes to boost tourism in Taiwan's indigenous areas

TEXT.P: Concerned over the development of tourism in Taiwan's indigenous areas, President Ma Ying-jeou asked government agencies Sunday to work with travel agents and arrange for more Chinese tourists to visit local tribes.

Ma instructed the Cabinet-level Council of Indigenous Peoples and the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to help Taiwan's indigenous tribes incorporate their unique and colorful designs and cultural elements in tourism facilities, such as inns and restaurants, to lure more visitors, including those from China.
He asked the Tourism Bureau to organize a meeting in Taipei with representatives of indigenous peoples and travel agents to explore ways to achieve the goal.

Ma issued the call while attending a seminar at the Sun Moon Lake National Scenic Area Administration in central Taiwan's Nantou County after representatives from the local Thao, Bunun and Sediq tribes complained that indigenous areas had not benefited from last year's expansion of transportation and tourism links with China.

Chuan Wen-sheng, a former legislator from the Bunun Tribe, suggested authorities include indigenous villages near Sun Moon Lake into the area's development plan to help boost tourism in indigenous areas.

Stressing that he fully supports indigenous tribes' keen desire to boost local tourism, the president said he would set a deadline to push relevant authorities to come up with concrete plans and strategies through close monitoring.

Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Kung Wen-chi urged the central government to work on the issue, as so far none of the Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan had visited or purchased handicraft items in any tribal areas across the country.
Sun Moon Lake is one of Taiwan's top tourist destinations that enjoy widespread popularity among Chinese visitors. Several tribes, including the Thaos, reside in the adjacent areas to the lake.

Apart from Sun Moon Lake, famous Hsitou Forest Recreation Park, Shanlinshi Forest Recreation Park, Yushan National Park, Mt. HeHuan and DongPu Hot Spring Scenic Spot are also located in Nantou County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumer vouchers boost sales of energy-saving appliances: BOE

TEXT.P: Shopping vouchers distributed by the government have significantly boosted the purchase of locally made energy-saving electric appliances, the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Sunday.

The MOEA launched a program last October that provides an NT$2,000 subsidy to local consumers when purchasing Taiwan-made appliances bearing energy-saving labels, such as washing machines, air conditioners, and refrigerators.

Before the consumer vouchers were issued on Jan. 18, the MOEA had received 99,178 applications for the NT$2,000 subsidy, but in just three days after the launching of the shopping vouchers program, another 12,759 applications had been received, according to bureau figures.
That translates to 4,253 applications per day, a stark contrast to the 910 requests per day received prior to the issuing of the shopping vouchers, bureau figures indicate.

"Consumers have made good use of the two policies that have been designed by the government to boost domestic consumption, " the bureau said in a statement, adding that it was happy to see consumers so eager to replace old appliances with far more energy-saving devices.

According to the bureau, air conditioners, refrigerators and washing machines with its energy-saving label, can save 20.8 percent, 19.1 percent, and 43.5 percent of energy respectively, compared to conventional domestic electrical appliances.

The government's NT$530 million (US$15.8 million) plan hopes to boost the sales of domestically produced househould electric appliances from 122,000 units to 265,000 units in six months, which will represent an estimated NT$9 billion in domestic spending.
The energy-saving appliances subsidy program is expected to last until March 31 this year.
The energy-saving label is granted by the bureau for products with energy efficiencies that are 10 percent to 50 percent higher than normal standards.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese women attempting to transit to U.S. with fake papers nabbed

TEXT.P: Three young Chinese women attempting to transit through Taiwan to the United States using fake Republic of China passports were nabbed at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport Saturday, the National Immigration Agency (NIA) said Sunday.
The three Chinese women, all aged over 18, were discovered at an airport gate using bogus ROC passports and fake boarding passes carrying counterfeit departure stamps, the agency said.
After a preliminary investigation, airport police discovered that the three flew to Taiwan from Hong Kong Saturday with travel documents indicating they were transiting to Palau on holiday.

The police found that the three canceled their airplane tickets for Palau immediately upon landing in Taiwan, and were given the fake passports and travel documents for flights destined for the United States by intermediaries.
Believing that the Chinese women were supported by a "snake head" human trafficking ring, NIA officials have referred them to the Taoyuan District Prosecutors Office for further investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma praises Taiwanese for being grateful for others' compassion

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Sunday praised the people of Taiwan for showing their thanks to those who have helped them in time of need.
Traveling to the Jhushan township in the landlocked county of Nantou, Ma praised Taiwan's people during a visit to Zinan Temple, a Taoist shrine famous for having loaned cash to followers in need.

The manager of the temple told Ma that more than 430,000 people borrowed a total of NT$250 million (US$7.42 million) from the land god worshipped at Zinan Temple last year to allow them to ride out financial difficulties.

The borrowers, however, repaid NT$300 million to the temple, Ma was told, and the president saluted the honesty and gratitude demonstrated by the borrowers, saying the traits are important values of the country.

After being repaid with interest by the borrowers, the temple authorities then used the extra money to bolster its charity and public interest drives, including giving out scholarships and subsidies to youths from low-income families, financially supporting care for the elderly, and other social programs.
Zinan Temple, a shrine-like place with a small area of less than 33 square meters, has a 300-year history, according to temple authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City zoo to close for renovation

TEXT.P: The Shoushan Zoo in the southern port city of Kaohsiung said Sunday it is scheduled to close Monday for a renovation project that is planned to take half a year to complete, but denied it was related to housing two white tigers from China.
The zoo has appropriated NT$150 million (US$3.45 million) to fund the renovation project aimed at revamping the entire facility, including parking lots, zoo authorities said.

Noting that the zoo needs an overhaul after having not been revamped for 30 years, they denied that the renovation will be carried out to create a new place to house two white tigers that the zoo plans to import from China in June.

Meanwhile, Kaohsiung City Tourism Bureau Director Lin Kun-shan said it is still unclear whether the Shoushan Zoo will bring in the white tigers from Guangzhou, adding that the city government is still assessing the possibility.
The official's denial contradicted what another city official said last December concerning the tiger import plan.
Tang Cheng-juei, director of the Kaohsiung City Scenic Area Administration, said Dec. 17, 2008 that a pair of white tigers are scheduled to be placed in the Shoushan Zoo in June 2009.
Tang said the rare animals are a gift of the Guangzhou Xiangjiang Safari Park in southern China to promote friendship between Guangzhou and Kaohsiung.
The zoo has appropriated NT$118 million to fund a renovation project aimed at creating a space at the zoo to house the two white tigers, he added.
The tigers are expected to attract an increased number of visitors to the zoo, which draws nearly 500,000 persons a year, he forecast at the time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's population exceeds 23.04 million

TEXT.P: Taiwan's population stood at 23,046,177 as of the end of January, an increase of 79,718 people compared to the year earlier figure, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) reported Sunday.

The ministry said that according to household registry statistics, the number of registered households in Taiwan reached 7,657,870 at the end of last month, an increase of 1.85 percent, or 139,309 households, over the same period last year.

By city and county, Taipei County had the greatest number of households, totaling 1,340,934 households, or 17.51 percent of the nation's total. Trailing Taipei County was Taipei City, with 957,954 households, or 12.51 percent of the country's total, the ministry said.
The outlying island county of Kinmen saw the highest rate of population growth over the past year, followed by Hsinchu City and Hsinchu County.
The highest rate of decline came in Lienchiang County, which includes the island of Matsu, followed by Taitung County, according to the ministry.
A total of 13,469 babies were born in January, for an average of one birth every 3.3 minutes, while 9,689 people died in January, an average of one death every 4.6 minutes.
A total of 15,166 couples tied the knot in January, while 3,064 couples divorced in the month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet to submit budget bill for NT$500 billion stimulus package

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will submit a special budget bill for an NT$500 billion (US$14.84 billion) economic stimulus package to the Legislative Yuan by Feb. 19 and hopes it will clear the legislative floor by the end of March, a Cabinet official said Sunday.

Following passage of the "Special Statute for Stimulating the Economy via Expanding Infrastructure Investment" in the Legislative Yuan Jan. 15, the Cabinet will submit the budget plan once it is reviewed by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning And Development at a meeting slated for Feb. 9 and is approved by the Cabinet between Feb. 12-19, according to the official.
If everything goes as expected, the bill to authorize the financing for the stimulus plan, will be passed as scheduled, the official added.
The plan calls for an investment of NT$500 billion over four years in infrastructure projects to bolster the sagging economy and curb unemployment.
Under the scheme, NT$133.1 billion will be spent this year, including NT$103.9 billion to expand public works projects and another NT$29.2 billion to sponsor a job creation program.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most anti-smoking violations in workplace: foundation

TEXT.P: The non-profit John Tung Foundation has received 142 complaints since a law banning smoking in public indoor areas took effect nearly a month ago, the anti- smoking group said Sunday.

Speaking at a news conference at the foundation's headquarters, foundation CEO Yao Shi-yuan said that to many people's surprise, as many as 80 percent of the alleged cases, or 110, took place in the workplace, including in offices of superiors, stairwells or bathrooms.

According to Yao, the finding confounded the expectations of foundation workers, who thought most violations would occur at coffee shops, restaurants, bus or train stations and outdoor areas surrounding hospitals.

Yao blamed the Bureau of Health Promotion under the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) -- the agency in charge of enforcing the anti-smoking amendment -- and its misguided interpretation of the law and lax law enforcement for the high rate of violations.

Under an amendment to the Tobacco Hazards Prevention Act, which took effect Jan. 11, smoking is forbidden in offices manned by three or more people as well as in the indoor areas of most public premises, including roofed transportation stations, KTV parlors, passageways, and staircases.
Only four kinds of establishments -- hotels, restaurants, shopping malls and nursing homes for the elderly -- are allowed to set up smoking rooms under certain strict requirements.
The law stipulates a fine of up to NT$10,000 (US$300) for those who smoke in facilities where it is prohibited and up to NT$50,000 for the owners of these premises.
Under the law, the only public places in which smoking is allowed indoors are night clubs or bars that do not admit patrons under the age of 18 and open after 9 p.m.
According to Sun Lee-chun, the chairman of the monthly Consumers News magazine, the public's participation is the most important factor in stamping out smoking in places where smoking is banned.
Sun suggested that all city and county governments provide incentives to people for reporting unlawful smokers as they have done to encourage citizens to crack down on cigarette littering.

To date, 21 out of Taiwan's 25 cities and counties are offering rewards of 5 percent to 50 percent of the fines imposed on violators to people who report illegal cigarette littering to local authorities, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taekwondo athlete promotes her first book at TIBE 2009

TEXT.P: Taiwan's outstanding taekwondo athlete Su Li-wen introduced her new book, "The Undefeatable Child, " at the 2009 Taipei International Book Exhibition on Tuesday, hoping to share her experiences as a taekwondo Olympian with Taiwanese youth.

Despite being defeated by Croatia's Martina Zubcic 4-5 in the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games bronze medal match in the women's under 57 kilogram class, Su's preseverance drew praise and cheers from people in both Beijing and Taipei.

The highly determined athlete refused to give up after crumbling to the ground in agony 11 times during the three bouts she fought because the left knee she injured in her first bout could not support her weight.

"I had never dreamed of being able to write a book about my past experiences, " said Su, but after being encouraged by her family and friends, she decided to share her experiences as a female taekwondo athlete.

Su said an athlete's attitude is vital to the outcome of any competition, and that at the most trying moments during her bronze medal bout, all she could think of was winning a medal for Taiwan and her father.

"I made a deal with my father before departing for the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games, " Su said. She promised her father that she would do her very best to bring home a medal if her father was willing to continue fighting his gradually worsening oral cancer.
According to Su, her father played a vital role in her career as a taekwondo athlete, as he taught her the importance of self-confidence, self-discipline and determination.

Asked if she ever thought about quitting during her Olympic bouts, Su proudly said that giving up is against the core value of any athlete who respects himself, adding that it would have been an honor to "fight to the death at the Olympic Games."
Encouraging Taiwan's youth, Su stressed that, "you must never give up in order to succeed, no matter what your profession is, as the key elements for success are universally similar."
Asked if she intends to represent Taiwan again in future international competitions, Su said she is very happy with her teaching position at National Taiwan Sport University.
"I don't want to speculate about the possibility of participating in future events as I'm still recovering from the injuries I sustained at last year's Olympic Games, " she said.

Meanwhile, Chi Cheng, who won a bronze medal in the 80-meter low hurdles in the 1968 Summer Olympics and obliterated, 44 Asian and 10 world records, said that she broke into tears when she saw Su fall during the bronze medal bout in Beijing.

"She is definitely one of the best athletes in Taiwan's history," said Chi, adding that Su's spirit and undying determination had much greater meaning than that of an Olympic gold medal to Taiwanese citizens.
In addition, Chi urged the public to continue supporting outstanding athletes like Su in order to help promote a better environment for molding and training future professional athletes.
Su won the gold medal at the 2006 Asian Games in Doha, the 2007 World University Games in Bangkok and the 2008 Asian Taekwondo Championship.
Before the opening of the 2008 Beijing Olympics, Su was the only Taiwanese athlete predicted to win a gold medal at the Games by the United States-based Sports Illustrated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan overcomes Kazakhstan behind unheralded Chen in Davis Cup

TEXT.P: Bring on India!

During a week when the absence of Taiwan's top player Lu Yen-hsun and Kazakhstan's three top-200 Russian imports threatened to become the main storylines of their Asia/Oceania Zone Group I Davis Cup tie, unheralded Chen Ti had the last laugh.

Playing an unexpected foe who defeated him last year in five sets in a Davis Cup tie in Almaty, Chen returned the favor Sunday, defeating world No. 180 Yuri Schukin 4-6, 6-3, 2-6, 7-6 (3), 6-1 to give Taiwan an unassailable 3-1 lead in a 4-1 victory over the visitors.

"When I played Schukin last year, I saw he was ranked pretty high and figured he would be tough to beat. But this time I played knowing I could win, " the world No. 375 Chen said. "I never thought I would lose at any point during the match."
Chen won the deciding point in a 3-2 win over Pakistan in February 2006, but he had never played such an impressive match under pressure against such a high- ranked opponent.
"You don't get many chances to shine on a big stage, so I wanted to take advantage of the opportunity," Chen said.
The victory was a nice birthday present to Wang Yeu-tzuoo, who turned 24 on Sunday.

Wang, trying to relaunch his career this weekend after sitting out most of 2008, was spared the pressure of a best-of-five set match and defeated world No. 145 Mikhail Kukushkin 2-6, 6-3, 6-3 to complete Taiwan's 4-1 triumph.
Taiwan needs to win two more ties if it hopes to reach the World Group playoffs, the gateway to the Davis Cup's top tier, for the first time in its history.
It will host India on March 6-8, and a win there would pit it against the winner of either Australia or Thailand.
Taiwan entered Sunday needing only to win one of the day's two reverse singles.
Chen was supposed to play world No. 119 Andrey Golubev in Sunday's opener, but Kazakhstan went with Schukin instead of Golubev, who was wildly erratic in a straight set loss to Wang Friday.
For three sets, it appeared to be a good move, as the 29-year-old Schukin's consistency, angled shots from the baseline and accurate passing shots kept Chen off balance.
Chen seemed to pick up momentum after breaking Schukin at love to take a 4-3 lead in the fourth set, but gave it back three games later when he was broken serving for the set.
Another two games later, down 5-6 and serving to stay in the match, Chen faced his biggest test.
An ace that would have put him up 40-30 was overturned by the chair umpire after Schukin complained the line umpire signaled the ball out.

The 25-year-old Taiwanese, who completely lost his cool in a similar situation in the fifth set of his loss to Kukushkin Friday, this time accepted the call, and prompted by a roar of encouragement from the crowd, defiantly pounded two service winners to clinch the game.
"I vowed before the match not to let any decision by the umpires bother me. And when the crowd got into it, it really pumped me up, " Chen said.

Helped by two Schukin unforced errors, Chen slammed an overhead and made two winning forays to net to take a 5-2 lead in the tiebreaker and then sent the crowd into a frenzy with a half volley off a Schukin overhead that trickled over the net out of his stunned opponent's reach.
Two points later, he clinched the tiebreaker with a big serve.

Once Chen broke a tiring Schukin in the second game of the final set, victory seemed assured, a victory that gave Chen newfound confidence that he could finally rise beyond his career best 255 ranking, accomplished in 2005.
"Staying with guys ranked in the 100s this weekend was important, because if I hadn't been able to, I would have asked myself what the point was of continuing to compete on tour, " said Chen.
After two strong performances this weekend, he no longer has to ask.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei County spends NT$12.5 million on performances countywide

TEXT.P: The Taipei county government has allocated NT$12.5 million (US$370,920) to fund a series of cultural performances being staged until March 27 around the county's 29 townships and cities, a county official said Sunday.

The initiative is designed to bring more cultural entertainment to local residents in an attempt to bridge the cultural divide between Taipei City and Taipei County, according to Wei Ting-lung, an official in the county's Bureau of Cultural Affairs.

Local residents are welcome to view the weekend shows free of charge, Wei said, adding that many famous troupes have been included in the program, including the Ming Hwa Yuan Taiwanese Opera Company, which he estimated would attract 5,000 people to each show it staged.

To meet the different needs of audiences in various localities, the county government met with representatives from the 29 townships and cities to discuss the selection of performing groups, Wei said.
The series of shows covers many cross-disciplinary performances, including puppet shows, folk dances and songs, dramas and acrobatics.

The recruited performers include famous 1970s pop singer Betty, I Wan Jan Puppet Theater, the Ju Percussion Group, Song Song Song Children's and Puppet Theater, Formosa-Zephyr Opera Troupe and Yi-Sin Taiwanese Opera Troupe.
Moreover, 12 senior Taiwanese folk song singers will stage concerts on Feb. 21 in Pinglin township and Feb. 27 in Shulin.

DOC.HEADLINE: 560,000 received shopping vouchers in second stage of distribution

TEXT.P: More than 560,000 people picked up their shopping vouchers Saturday, the first day that those who did not get their vouchers on Jan. 18 could collect them, a Chunghwa Post Co. official said Sunday.
"Unlike Saturday, there were no incidents of overcrowding during the second day of the second stage of distributing the vouchers," the official said.

According to the official, close to 21 million people collected their vouchers on Jan. 18, and of the remaining 2.01 million who did not pick them up that day, 560,000 showed up at local post offices around the country Saturday.

Post office employees worked overtime to issue the vouchers from 1: 30 p.m-5: 30 p.m. Feb. 7, and from 8 a.m-5: 30 p.m Feb. 8, the official said, adding that the designated post offices will no longer provide extended hours of service starting from Feb. 9.
"Those who have not yet claimed their shopping vouchers can pick them up at designated post offices around the nation during regular office hours between Feb. 9 and April 30, " the official said.
Aimed at spurring consumer spending and boosting the economy, NT$3,600 in shopping vouchers are being distributed to all of Taiwan's citizens. The vouchers can be used until Sept. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: Veteran city councilor wins KMT primary for by-election nomination

TEXT.P: A veteran Taipei city councilor won a five-way race Sunday to become ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) nominee in a legislative by-election to fill the seat vacated by a KMT legislator over a dual citizenship controversy.

Chiang Nai-hsin, a seven-term city councilor, beat four other contenders in not only a primary vote by KMT members residing in the capital city's Daan district held Sunday but also in two rounds of public opinion polls conducted between Feb. 5-7.
According to the KMT primary regulations, the vote accounted for 30 percent of the candidates' support and the opinion poll accounted for the other 70 percent.
Chiang defeated the other four fellow city councilors in both the vote and the opinion polls by comfortable margins.
In the primary vote, Chiang garnered 1,221 ballots or 54.815 percent of the total valid votes, far surpassing the 518 ballots won by runner-up Lin Yi-hua, also a city councilor.

According to KMT Taipei City chapter data, 6,261 party members were eligible to vote in the primary, but only 2,198 valid ballots were cast at five polling stations erected in the district for a voter turnout of 35.32 percent.
The results of public opinion polls conducted by Shih Hsin University and TVBS public opinion survey centers showed Chiang with 54.3 percent support, well ahead of Lin's 21.2 percent.
The public support rates for the three other contenders -- Lee Ching-yuan, Chin Li-fang and Lee Hsin -- were 10.9 percent, 7.8 percent and 5.2 percent, respectively.

After disclosing the results of the vote and opinion polls at a news conference, Pan Chia-sen, head of the KMT Taipei chapter, announced that Chiang will represent the KMT in the March 28 legislative by-election.

Three losing contestants -- Lee Ching-yuan, Lee Hsin and Chin Li-fang -- showed up at the KMT Taipei City office to throw their support behind Chiang, who rushed to the office after learning of his primary win.
Chiang, 59, who has served as a city councilor for 28 years, said he will pay a visit to Lin Yi-hua, the only loser who was absent from the post-primary morale- boosting gathering.
Lin campaigned fiercely in the primary and was accused of vote-buying by Chin.
As Daan district is a KMT stronghold, Chiang is widely seen as a heavy favorite in the by-election now that he has won the KMT nomination.
Nevertheless, Chiang said he will still need the united support of KMT politicians and rank-and-file members to claim a final victory in the by- election.
Chiang will face another veteran Taipei City councilor, Chou Po-ya of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party, in the by-election.
There are currently 111 legislators in the lawmaking body. A by-election will be held on March 14 in Miaoli County to fill a seat vacated by Lee E-ting, a KMT legislator convicted of vote buying.
Once Lee Ching-an's former seat is filled in the March 28 by-election, the legislature will be returned to its full complement of 113 lawmarkers.

Lee, a KMT legislator from 1999 to 2009, announced her resignation from the legislature Jan. 8, citing the dispute over her alleged dual citizenship. Her resignation came after DPP politicians promoted a campaign to recall her and pro-DPP civic groups prepared to besiege the legislature to protest the lawmaking body's failure to act against her.

According to the current Public Officials Election and Recall Law, a by-election has to be held in Taipei City's Daan district within three months to elect a replacement to fill the position vacated by Lee.

Lee, who was sworn in for a fourth legislative term Feb. 1, 2008, was found the following month to have never formally renounced her U.S. citizenship, even though she had held public office in Taiwan since 1994.

Taiwan's Nationality Act requires public officials holding dual citizenship to surrender their foreign citizenship before assuming public office and to obtain a certificate as proof within one year of taking office.
The law also requires that those officials who retain foreign citizenship be removed from their posts.

Calls for Lee to be formally relieved of her seat mounted after U.S. authorities, in response to an inquiry from Taiwan, confirmed in late 2008 that Lee "has previously been documented as a U.S. citizen with a U.S. passport and that no subsequent loss of U.S. citizenship has been documented."

In a recent response to an inquiry by Taiwan's Central Election Commission, the U.S. State Department further concluded that Lee did not fulfill her obligation of committing an expatriating act with the intent of relinquishing her U.S. citizenship when she first assumed public office in Taiwan back in 1994.
Lee has been barred from leaving Taiwan pending an investigation into fraud and forgery allegations against her.

DOC.HEADLINE: Large Chinese tourism delegation arrives for visit

TEXT.P: A 127-member Chinese tourism delegation, headed by Li Yabai, director of the Travel and Tourism Bureau of Henan Province in China, arrived in Taipei Sunday to see for themselves colorful Lantern Festival celebrations in Taiwan.
According to local tour promoters, the delegation is the largest of its kind since Beijing authorities allowed more Chinese citizens to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan late last year.

Attracted by Taiwan's now internationally renowned Lantern Festival celebrations, Li said the group will travel to Yilan City on northeastern coast Monday where a series of festive activities will be launched in the evening to celebrate the festival, which falls on the 15th day of the first lunar month.

"Taiwan is known to be versed in merging tradition and innovation in organizing traditional festive activities and we hope to learn more about Taiwan's achievements in this regard during our current visit," Li said.
Moreover, Li said, the group, composed of provincial tourism officials and travel service operators, will tour major signseeing spots to appreciate Taiwan's natural scenery.
During its eight-day stay, the delegation will also visit local institutions in charge of travel promotion and service quality certification as well as relevant administrative agencies.

In addition to the central government-organized Taiwan Lantern Festival activities in Yilan City, many other festive events that integrate tradition and innovation will also take place in many other parts of the country to celebrate the Lantern Festival.

Local tourist officials said they will introduce special features of those activities to the Chinese delegation for their reference in organizing tour packages for ordinary Chinese tourists in the future.

The most special celebration activities include the firecracker blitzkrieg known as "bombarding Master Handan" in Taitung County, the release of airborne paper lanterns known as "sky lanterns" in Pingsi township in Taipei County and the setting-off of a beehive of firecrackers in Yanshuei township in Tainan County, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA mulling financial subsidy to encourage franchise stores

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is planning to offer financial subsidies to help wage earners launch their own ventures by joining retail franchises, an official said Sunday.
According to the official, the ministry plans to offer each new franchise store NT$50,000 (US$1,483.68) in subsidy.

A recent survey by the online job broker 104 Job Bank found that 81.6 percent of the respondents are interested in starting a business and that on average, the potential entrepreneurs would require NT$565,300 in startup funds.
The MOEA official said if 3,000 new franchise stores are launched under the program, the government will offer up to NT$150 million in subsidy for those new ventures.

If the program succeeds in inspiring entrepreneurship, the official said it will be able to help increase private investment by an estimated NT$18.4 billion, create 46,000 job openings and generate NT$50 billion in business opportunities.
"If all goes well, the subsidy program will also be effective in resolving the worsening unemployment issue, " the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Monday, surging 91.43 points at 4,562.68 on a turnover of NT$3.732 billion (US$111.07 million).
The weighted price index gained 108 points, or 2.47 percent, to close at 4,471.25 Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was lower against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Monday.
The greenback was trading at NT$33.629 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.121 from Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 9, or the 15th day of the first month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1775: Hostilities between Britain and the American colony of Massachusetts become imminent as the British Parliament announces the state is in rebellion and approves new laws to control the situation.
1799: The U.S. Navy draws first blood in a war with France.
1801: France signs the Peace of Luneville with Austria, dissolving the Holy Roman Empire.
1825: John Quincy Adams, an American politician who helped formulate the Monroe Doctrine and who advocated antislavery measures, is elected the sixth president of the United States, defeating Andrew Jackson.
1830: Explorer Charles Stuart discovers the source of Australia's longest river, the Murray.
1881: Feodor Mikhailovich Dostoevski, Russian writer who wrote such great novels as "Crime and Punishment," "The Idiot," "The Possessed," and "The Brother Karamazov," dies at the age of 60.
1899: The Boxer Uprising breaks out in China. Sparked by popular discontent with internal misgovernment and anti-foreign sentiment aroused by unequal treaties, the boxers lay siege to the foreign legion in Peking, where a combined force of Japanese, French, British, Russians, and American troops held out for over a month.
1921: The Living Buddha of Outer Mongolia proclaims "independence" after Mongolian and Russian communists gain control of Outer Mongolia. They established the Mongolian People's Republic in 1924, after the Living Buddha died.
1942: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek visits India after assuming office as supreme commander of the China Theater of War on Jan. 2, 1942.
1945: Mia Farrow, the American actress who first made her name in the television series Peyton Place and went on to make many films, notably comedies with Wooden Allen, is born.
1955: The U.S. Senate approves the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty by a vote 64-6.
1957: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China advocates independence for the Ryukyus. China and Japan both claimed the Ryukyus until 1874, when the Ching court signed a treaty recognizing Japanese rule. After Japan's defeat in World War II, the U.S. took over the Ryukyus. In 1953, the U.S. returned the islands north of Okinawa to Japan. Okinawa and the southern Ryukyus were returned in 1972.
1962: The Taiwan Stocks Exchange formally begins operations.
1964: Beatlemania hits the United States as 73 million Americans watch four lads from Liverpool appear on the Ed Sullivan Show.
1973: H.E. Hisham Muhiuddin Nazer, state minister of Saudi Arabia, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1974: Six winners of the Second Cathay Children's Music Contest leave Taipei for Hong Kong to attend the Arts Festival.
1981: General Wojciech Jaruzelski, Poland's defense minister, becomes prime minister and chief of the Polish Communist Party.
1993: President Francois Mitterrand visits Vietnam, ending Vietnam's isolation in the international community. He was the first Western head of state to visit the communist country since 1966.
1994: President Lee Teng-hui leaves for the Philippines, Indonesia, and Thailand on an eight-day visit.
1999: A 352-page collection of news photographs depicting historic moments in ROC diplomacy over the past six decades is published by the Central News Agency, which was founded in 1924.
1999: The Republic of the Marshall Islands opens an embassy in the Republic of China, heralding a new era in relations between the two countries.
2000: The Taiwan Stock Exchange performs well on the first trading session after the Chinese New Year holiday, with the market's weighted price index breaking the 10,000 point level at the close.
2001: Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) Deputy Director-General Francis K.H. Liang, leaves Taipei for Beijing to attend a senior officials meeting of the Asia- Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Why should one be too severe? When a man reforms and comes to me for advice, I accept his present reformation without inquiring what his past life has been. I am satisfied if I find that, for the present, he has really reformed, without being able to guarantee that he will not relapse again. But why should one be too severe?"
