DOC.HEADLINE: 76% of science park workers forced to take unpaid days off

TEXT.P: About 100,000 workers and operators at the Hsinchu Science Park (HSP) -- Taiwan's "Silicon Valley" -- are being sent on unpaid leave days each week as a result of the global economic recession, the HSP Administration said Monday.

A survey conducted by the HSP Administration at the beginning of February found that 56 companies in HSP, or 12 percent of the total number of companies operating in HSP, have given more than 100,000 workers total unpaid days off since late last year.
The 100,000 employees constitute 76 percent of the total number of workers and operators in the whole HSP, according to the park administration.
Of the 56 companies, 49 have asked all of their employees to take unpaid days off, while the other seven companies have asked some of their staff to do so.
The number of unpaid leave days averages one to two days per week, the survey found.

Meanwhile, according to tallies compiled by the HSP Administration, 1,050 HSP employees were laid off in January, representing a decline of 46 percent from December 2008, when 1,950 workers were retrenched.
The figure, however, was a steep increase of 5.56 times the number in January 2008.

The Cabinet-level Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics reported in January that the number of unemployed people in Taiwan totaled 549,000 in December 2008, the highest since October 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economics before politics remains Taiwan's cross-strait policy: SEF
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Feb. 9 (CNA) 02/09/09 13:46:51 (By Luis Yu & S. J. Kang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has not changed its "economy first, politics later" stance in its cross- Taiwan Strait policy, Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said in an interview carried Monday in Singapore newspaper, Lianhe Zaobao.

However, Chiang said in the interview conducted in Taipei before the Chinese New Year that despite the Taiwanese government's hopes to tackle economic issues before political ones, some political controversies with China may surface sooner or later in the process of building closer cross-strait ties.

Nonetheless, at this time, the discussion of some less sensitive issues with China may not necessarily result in a political standoff in Taiwan, he added, noting that, for example, the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) both want Taiwan to participate in this year's World Healthy Assembly (WHA) as an observer.

As for the fears expressed by the DPP that negotiations and the closer ties with China will jeopardize Taiwan's sovereignty, Chiang said that there only two ways to consolidate Taiwan's sovereignty. The first is through the adoption and practice of democracy, and the second is through stable and prosperous economic development, he said.
Saying that actions speak louder than words, Chiang expressed the view that the opposition party cannot protect Taiwan's sovereignty just by advocating independence for the island.

"If Taiwan can one day become a highly democratic country, a free and just nation ruled by the law, governed by the people, a country that is free of any violent and radical activities, I am sure that the people of China will not only respect us but will also envy our political maturity." Chiang said.
In addition, Taiwan must achieve economic prosperity before it can hope to provide assistance to the developing nations of the world
or to obtain the support and approval of the international community, he suggested.
"The main goals of the KMT and the DPP are similar, as both parties hope to provide a stable and harmonious living environment for Taiwan's people," Chiang said.

However, while the two parties share similar goals, they have chosen different ways to achieve them, Chiang noted. The KMT has chosen to maintain the status quo in cross-strait relations, while the DPP has insisted that the only way to achieve harmony and stability in the society is by establishing a new nation free of any ties to China, he said.

Taiwan's SEF and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) serve as semi-official intermediary bodies in the absence of official contact between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: City, county integration plan hinges on law amendment: official

TEXT.P: The realization of a plan to merge Taichung city and county into special municipality hinges on the passage of an amendment to the existing Law on Local Government Systems, a Ministry of the Interior (MOI) official said Monday.

Huang Li-hsing, director of the MOI Department of Civil Affairs, said that the amendment should be passed into law before April so as to provide a legal basis for the integration of Taichung city and county in central Taiwan as a municipality by the end of 2010.
"If the amendment is passed before April, it would also have less of an impact on candidates running in the upcoming mayoral and county chief elections slated for the end of the year," Huang added.

Minister of the Interior Liao Liou-yi has said that the Taichung integration plan is a complicated political process involving several issues such as the terms of the magistrate and mayor and the status of village and township chiefs in the proposed special municipality.
However, Liao said, the plan will be nothing but empty talk if the relevant legislation is not passed.

Under the law amendment, Taichung city and county will become the first adjoining city and county to merge into a larger administrative district. The merger will also serve as a litmus test for similar plans in northern and southern Taiwan.

A government plan also proposes that Taipei city, county and the neighboring Keelung city be integrated into a special municipality in northern Taiwan and that Kaohsiung city and county in southern Taiwan be merged into a third special municipality in the country.

Meanwhile, Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu confirmed Monday that he had traveled with Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng to Taipei City several days ago to seek the support of ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Wu Po-hsiung for the passage of the proposed amendment. The KMT holds over two-thirds seats of the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lots thrown by shopping voucher users hit 183,800 in Taichung

TEXT.P: Taichung City has collected more than 183,800 lots from shopping voucher users since it began a series of lucky draws last month to encourage consumption in the central Taiwan city, a local government official said Monday.

Chu Huei-lan, head of the city's department of economic development affairs, said in a briefing to Taichung Mayor Jason Hu that the value of the shopping voucher consumption in Taichung had reached nearly NT$820 million (US$24.4 million) as of Saturday.
Expressing delight with the result, Hu said nevertheless that he hoped the Feb. 2-15 Lantern Festival celebrations will attract even more visitors to the city.

The city is offering a variety of luxury prizes for winners of the lucky draws, including a luxury apartment, three SUVs and five round-trip flight tickets between Taichung and the Chinese city of Hangzhou.
Anyone spending at least NT$3,000-worth of vouchers in the city is eligible to take part in the draws that began Feb. 2 and will be held again Feb. 15, March 1, March 15, March 22 and March 29.
The winner of the top prize -- the apartment -- will be announced March 29, according to the city government.

The vouchers were distributed Jan. 18 to various categories of resident, with each receiving NT$3,600-worth of vouchers, as part of a NT$85.7 billion economic stimulus package intended to boost consumer spending and spur economic growth in the face of the current economic downturn.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU Center to open in May: EETO head

TEXT.P: The top European Union representative in Taiwan announced Monday that the first European Union Center (EU Center) will open in Taipei in May in a collaborative effort by Taiwan's top academic institutions to promote Taiwan-EU relations.

Guy Ledoux, head of the Taipei-based European Economic and Trade Office (EETO), told the Central News Agency in an exclusive interview that the contract to set up the EU Center was signed Dec. 31, 2008 between National Taiwan University (NTU) and the EETO, which serves as the de facto EU embassy in Taiwan.

He added that an inaugural conference of the EU Center is scheduled to be held in May to celebrate both the opening of the center and the fall of the Berlin Wall 20 years ago, which made possible the 2004 expansion of the EU to include 10 new member states.
The EU Center network in the Asia Pacific region spans South Korea, Japan, Australia and New Zealand. Taiwan will be the third East Asian country to join the network.

This is the third cycle (2005-2008) of the EU Centers program, which was launched in 1998. The EU Centers program will help create a foothold for EU studies in Taiwan's higher education circles and serve as an information resource for a broad Taiwan audience.

Noting that NTU will lead a group of six other universities to jointly operate the EU Center in Taiwan, Ledoux said it is a very "interesting" and "unique" arrangement, as there are no other EU Centers in the world that are run by seven universities.
"It's very unique because it launched the basis for a better understanding in the new generation of Taiwanese about the EU, " Ledoux said.
"It is useful that Taiwanese students and Taiwanese scholars can better understand what the EU is about and the influence the EU has on international affairs," he added.

According to Ledoux, in addition to a grant of NT$47 million (US$1.4 million) that the EU has agreed to provide over the next four years, NTU, along with National Chengchi University, National Chung Hsing University, National Sun Yat- sen University, National Dong Hwa University, Tamkang University and Fu Jen Catholic University, will contribute another NT$19 million to the program.

The top EU representative in Taiwan said that other than the inaugural seminar in May, the main activities of the EU Center during the first year will include regular workshops and seminars on EU policies and summer school for high school teachers to learn more about the EU and thus help younger Taiwanese gain a better understanding of the EU.
All seven universities will also launch their own EU study programs, whether at the bachelor's or master's level, he added.

Ledoux said that with the general work plan already approved by Brussels, an advisory committee will be assembled, and that he, a representative of the presidency of the EU, and representatives of the seven universities will fine tune the details of each program.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices rose Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 23.34 points, or 0.52 percent, to close at 4,494.59.

Posting a gain for the second consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 4,562.68 and fluctuated between 4,574.74 and 4,494.59. A total of 3.62 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$79.83 billion (US$2.37 billion).

Three major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff stocks moving up the most at 1.5 percent. Machinery and electronics issues advanced 1.3 percent and plastics and chemicals stocks rose 0.6 percent.

Five stock categories lost ground, with cement shares moving down the most at 2.0 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 1.3 percent, paper and pulp stocks at 0.6 percent, construction issues at 0.5 percent, textile stocks at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 794 to 780, with 212 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$8.7 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei, Shanghai planning 'twin city' forum in June

TEXT.P: Taipei and Shanghai are slated to jointly organize a "twin city" forum in Taipei in July, Taipei City Mayor Hau Lung-bin announced Monday.

As the two cities have had similar development experience and both have the need to boost their high-tech industries, they share a lot of common ground for joint collaboration, said Hau during a meeting with visiting Shanghai Deputy Mayor Tang Dengjie on a tour of the Neihu Industry Park in suburban Taipei.

With Taipei set to hold an international flower exhibition in 2010 and Shanghai to host the 2010 world exposition, the forum will serve as a platform that will allow the two cities to learn from each other and sharpen competitiveness to increase their global visibility, Hau contended.
With direct air links established between Taipei and Shanghai last year, two-way trade, cultural, commercial and technology exchanges will become even closer, he added.
Hau also asked Tang to relay an invitation to Shanghai Mayor Han Zheng to join the forum in Taipei in June. The Taipei mayor visited Shanghai in June last year.
Agreeing that there is ample room for the two sides to step up bilateral cooperation, Tang responded positively to Hau's proposals and said that Han had been preparing to take part in the forum.
Han told an international news conference in January that he would like to visit Taiwan as soon as possible.
Tang arrived in Taipei Sunday, at the head of a 13-member delegation, for a week-long visit at the invitation of the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries.
The Chinese delegation will also travel to Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Miaoli, Tainan and Kaohsiung for tourism purposes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for February advancing 17 points to end at 4,456, with 71,142 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for March gained 17 points to finish at 4,406, with 1,013 contracts traded, while June futures increased 10 points to end at 4,350, with 14 contracts traded.
September futures were up 13 points to close at 4,146, with 44 contract transactions, while December futures rose 8 points to end at 4,093, with 28 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 4,439 for February, 4,389 for March, 4,340 for June, 4,133 for September, and 4,085 for December.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index increased 23.34 points to finish at 4,494.59, on turnover of NT$79.83 billion (US$2.37 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

February TE futures gained 2.75 points to close at 179.5, with 3,809 contracts traded, while March TE futures advanced 2.3 points to finish at 177.65, with 52 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

February TF futures were down 6.4 points to close at 503, with 3,268 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures decreased 5.2 points to finish at 498, with 88 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for the other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, rising NT$0.211 to close at NT$33.961.
A total of US$885 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.750 and fluctuated between NT$33.602 and NT$33.961

DOC.HEADLINE: 2009 to be busy year for Education Ministry: minister

TEXT.P: Minister of Education Cheng Jei-cheng said Monday that 2009 will be a busy year for the Ministry of Education (MOE) with some NT$20 billion (US$595 million) allocated by the Cabinet for the ministry's implementation of various education-related programs.

The ministry is obligated to use the NT$20 billion to fund a variety of programs this year, including revamping or rebuilding old or dilapidated school buildings, strengthening the environment for digital education, creating 9,000-10,000 short-term jobs in the education sector and helping those students to return to school who have dropped out or are planning to do so because of their parents' economic situations, Cheng said.

He asked for assistance from local government officials in charge of education affairs to help the MOE make decisions on whether and how much extra budget should be allocated to the local governments so that the programs can be implemented.

Other priority programs that the ministry will push this year include bolstering international education in elementary and junior high schools, improving teaching quality in rural areas, integrating kindergarten and nursery operations and providing computerization for the special education sector, Cheng added.

The NT$20 billion plan is part of a special economic stimulus package under which the government will inject NT$500 billion over the next four years into public infrastructure projects in the face of the global economic recession.

DOC.HEADLINE: English testing to be included in most civil service exams

TEXT.P: Starting from next year, all civil service exams apart from a few will include English proficiency tests, the top official in charge of the civil service system said Monday.
John Kuan, president of the Examination Yuan, made the remarks during a spring gathering with the media along with the top officials of the Examination Yuan.
The move is aimed at ensuring that the country's civil servants embrace the world and possess an international viewpoint, Kuan said.
"English proficiency tests will be one of the priority tasks this year, " he said, adding that from next January, the tests will start being included in civil service exams in stages.
"If you can't use English, you will be constrained in many ways and your ability to absorb new information will be limited, " Kuan said.

Minister of Examination Yung Chaur-shin noted that except for three kinds of civil service exams -- for the disabled, aborigines and the lowest-ranking civil servants in the Ministry of Transportation and Communications -- which will have their English proficiency tests postponed to a later date, all other civil service exams will include the tests.
Kuan noted that the inclusion of English proficiency tests is a continuation of existing government policy.

"To upgrade their competitive edge and their knowledge of world affairs, 22 out of the 30 kinds of civil service exams have included English proficiency tests over the past three years," he pointed out.
The remaining eight exams, apart from the three categories already mentioned, will also include English proficiency tests from next January, he said.

He added that the assessment system for the performance of civil servants will be revised over the next year and that those who have performed well will be rewarded, while those who have performed poorly will be phased out.

He noted that the assessment system for civil servants has been no more than a formality in past years, with many considering that a civil servant position is a well-protected "iron rice bowl" job with no fear of being sacked.

Although Kuan did not specify the ratio of civil servants that should be phased out, he stressed that "the direction is set," adding that "without the phase-out mechanism, the civil service will be like a stagnant pond, and this is something we do not wish to see continue."

DOC.HEADLINE: January exports down 44.1 percent: MOF

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export trade amounted to US$12.37 billion in January, representing a decline of 44.1 percent year-on-year, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported Monday.
The country's import trade, meanwhile, totaled US$8.97 billion in the first month of 2009, marking a negative growth of 56.5 percent over that posted in the same month of 2008, the MOF said.
As a result, Taiwan posted a trade surplus of US$3.4 billion for January, marking a year-on-year increase of 124.6 percent, the MOF said.

A MOF official said that if the eight-day Chinese New Year holiday is excluded, Taiwan's exports totaled US$9.36 billion in the first 23 days of January, marking a year-on-year fall of 34.9 percent. The fall represented a mild improvement compared to December 2008, when Taiwan's export trade declined 41.9 percent, the official noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU representative praises Taiwan's shopping voucher program

TEXT.P: One of Taiwan's economic stimulus measures, the distribution of shopping vouchers to citizens, was lauded by the top European Union (EU) representative in Taiwan Monday as a non-discriminatory and non-protectionist program.

Noting that governments all over the world have instituted fiscal packages to stimulate domestic consumption, Guy Ledoux, head of the Taipei-based European Economic and Trade Office (EETO) , told the Central News Agency in an exclusive interview that the danger is that some stimulus packages could include protectionist elements.
However, Ledoux said that he was pleased to see that Taiwan's consumption voucher program does not specify the purchase of locally produced goods over imported products.
"I welcome the fact that it isn't discriminatory. It's not a protectionist measure," Ledoux said. "Taiwanese can go to a Taiwanese restaurant or buy a Gucci bag if they want."

Some 91 percent of eligible Taiwan citizens had picked up their NT$3, 600 (US$107) worth of vouchers by Jan. 18. The vouchers are the business end of an NT$85.7 billion program that is part of the government's economic stimulus package.
Some critics have expressed worry that the global financial crisis might give rise to trade protectionism, as many countries are trying to protect their domestic markets and industries.

The concerns escalated when the U.S. House of Representatives last month passed a US$819 billion economic stimulus package, which included a "Buy American" clause that requires public works projects that receive money from the package to use U.S.-made iron, steel and manufactured goods.

Noting that 70 percent of Taiwan's GDP is export-oriented and has been suffering as a result of the steep drop in export demand, Ledoux said the shopping voucher program is "certainly the right measure, " as expanding the domestic market and continuing to stimulate consumption are what should be done when the export market is shrinking.

Taiwan enjoys an edge over other economies, as its financial sector has not been drastically affected by the global economic downturn and it has the fourth- largest foreign exchange reserves in the world, trailing only China, Japan and Russia, the EU representative noted.
"Taiwan's financial situation is very secure -- it can afford to continue its stimulus packages without putting the economy at risk, " he said.
As to the prospects of the global economy in 2009, Ledoux said that "everybody hopes that sometime in the very near future, we will see the end of the tunnel and the economy will pick up again."
The EETO serves as the de facto embassy in Taiwan, promoting bilateral economic and trade exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly 20,000 Chinese Amway members to visit Taichung for meeting

TEXT.P: More than 17,000 Chinese members of the global direct sales company Amway will arrive in Taichung in March and April for a major conference - providing the central Taiwanese city a chance to earn tourist revenue, officials said Monday.

Anna Wang, director of the city government's Industrial Development and Investment Promotion Committee, confirmed that more than 17,000 sales representatives and other members of Chinese Amway (China) Co., Limited are slated to visit Taiwan from mid-March in eight groups.

Taichung City edged out other cities, including those in Japan, Singapore and South Korea, to host the large number of Chinese visitors, thanks to its large conference centers and outdoor squares, Wang said.

Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu on Monday expressed hope that the city's success in winning this opportunity to host such a high number of visitors would help inject greater momentum into Taichung's local economy.
Wang said the precedent is set to mark a major breakthrough that could help the city win the chance to host similar large-scale conferences and incentive tours in the future.
Three other Chinese companies have shown a high degree of interest in organizing overseas conferences and travel for their workers in Taiwan, Wang added.

For the upcoming event, all walks of life in Taichung City will launch full preparations to seize handsome business opportunities expected to be worth more than NT$ 100 million that would arise from the Chinese visitors, Wang said.

The Amway (China) employees will arrive from Shanghai in eight groups on board cruise ships and will first make a stop at Keelung Harbor in northern Taiwan and then proceed to Haulien Harbor in eastern Taiwan before finally reaching Taichung Harbor in central Taiwan.
The first batch of the Chinese visitors is slated to visit Taichung on March 18, with subsequent groups to arrive on March 22, March 28, April 3, April 9 and April 17 and later dates.

DOC.HEADLINE: Museum delegation to depart for historic China visit

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based National Palace Museum (NPM) announced Monday that it will send a delegation to visit China's Palace Museum in Beijing Saturday, marking the first official contact between the two museums in 60 years.

Speaking at a Lunar New Year luncheon, NPM Director Chou Kung-shin said that under the "cross-Taiwan Strait Palace Museum scheme, " the NPM and its Beijing counterpart will discuss the possibility of cooperation in the areas of exhibition arrangements, publicity campaigns and publications, as well as academic and staff exchanges. The NPM delegation will also visit the Shanghai Museum for similar discussions during the trip, she added.

With politics set aside, Chou expressed hope that through such cultural exchanges, people from both sides of the Taiwan Strait will gain a better understanding of each other so that mutual trust can be built.

In the area of joint exhibitions, Chou said that while the NPM has prepared 180 items chosen from its own collection for an exhibition on Emperor Yung-cheng -- the fourth ruler of the Ching Dynasty -- which is slated to open in Taiwan in October, she will discuss with Beijing the possibility of borrowing some artifacts relating to the emperor.

She said Beijing's exhibits in Taiwan will be guaranteed a safe return under the country's 1992 Statute on Encouraging and Rewarding Cultural and Art Enterprises, which stipulates that foreign art and cultural objects will be exempt from seizure or any legal entanglement over ownership.
She added, however, that before any of Taiwan's treasures can be displayed in China, a similar statute has to be put in place by the other side of the strait to grant the same protection.

Similar guarantees have been practiced worldwide over the past 20 years for exhibit exchanges, she went on, adding that highlights of the NPM's collection have been showcased in the United States, France, Germany and Austria thanks to agreements with those countries.
It is also the lack of legislative protection that hinders the NPM lending exhibits to Belgium and Japan, although both those nations have expressed strong interest in cooperation, she added.

Chou said that in keeping with the increasing cross-strait tourism exchanges, she will discuss cooperation with the Beijing museum on launching publicity campaigns in the hope of attracting more visitors to both museums.
In addition, as personnel from the two museums enjoy advantages in different research fields, she said cooperation in academic exchanges will also result in benefits for both sides.
She mentioned that there will not be any agreements or memorandums of understanding signed during the trip, as the main purpose of the visit is to exchange views.

The delegation, which is comprised of Chou, NPM Deputy Director Feng Ming-chu and other museum officials, will depart for Beijing Feb. 14 and continue on to Shanghai three days later, returning to Taiwan Feb. 19.
Representatives of the Shanghai Museum will pay a return visit in late February, while Beijing museum officials will do so in early March.
The NPM -- one of the world's most famous museums -- has the world's largest collection of Chinese historical artifacts totaling 650,000 pieces.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF head thanks Singapore for support in cross-strait ties
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 9 (CNA) 02/09/09 19:54:26 (By Luis Yu and S.J. Kang)

TEXT.P: The government is grateful for the great support Singapore has always given Taiwan in its efforts to improve cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said in an interview carried Monday in the Lianhe Zaobao, a Singapore newspaper.
"Singapore is one of the few nations in the international community to have made great contributions to the recent improved cross-strait ties," said Chiang.

According to Chiang, Singapore played a vital role and served as a communications channel before cross-strait dialogue was interrupted by Taiwan's assertions that Taiwan and China were separate states beginning in the 1990s.

However, asked if Singapore will continue to serve as a platform or channel of communication for future cross-strait negotiations, Chiang said the city-state's role in cross-strait relations will diminish, as Taiwan's SEF and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) have already re- opened cross-strait dialogues.
Chiang said it is more important for Taiwan and Singapore to look ahead and find ways to combat the worsening effects of the global economic crisis.
In addition, he went on, Taiwan will continue to do its best to contribute to peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region.

Cross-strait relations tend to be much more complex and delicate than those between other countries or regions, but Taiwan will continue to have dialogue with China to seek peace and stability in the area, said the SEF chairman.
He also promised that the SEF will continue to keep Singapore informed about the newest developments in cross-strait relations.

"We are extremely grateful for the high level of support Singapore has given us, and when the right time comes Taiwan also hopes to promote closer ties with Singapore and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN)," Chiang noted.
"Bilateral relations between Taiwan and Singapore have always been close and we should try to maintain this kind of cooperation in the future," he said.

Asked if the future negotiations between the SEF and the ARATS will be held in a third country, Chiang said the chances are slim, as the negotiation mechanism between the two sides has already been re-established.
The SEF and ARATS serve as semi-official intermediary bodies responsible for cross-strait affairs in the absence of official contact between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan is no longer a U.S. liability: President Ma

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that Taiwan is no longer a liability to the United States as the recent improvement in relations with China have contributed to peace and stability in the region and led to liberalization in trade and commerce.

Speaking at the 2009 Lunar New Year Reception organized by local commercial and industrial associations held in Taipei, Ma asserted that closer ties with China has allowed Taiwan to be less reliant on the United States, reducing the pressure on Washington.

"At a time when the situation in the Korean Peninsula is worsening, the improvement in cross-Taiwan Strait ties with China has significantly reduced the burden of the United States in the region," Ma said.

Lauding the benefits of closer cross-strait ties, Ma said that the U.S government approved arms sales to Taiwan last September due to Taiwan's determination to become a problem solver instead of a troublemaker on issues related to China.

Also, in recognition of Taiwan's efforts to seek the normalization of cross-strait economic ties in the spirit of trade liberalization advocated by the World Trade Organization (WTO) , the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative (USTR) removed Taiwan from the Special 301 Watch List on Jan. 16, Ma contended.

Meanwhile, the president explained that the launching of direct sea and air links will gradually improve Taiwan's investment environment and boost the country's economic development and competitiveness.

Lowering tensions with China has also allowed Taiwan to play a more active role in the international arena, having been admitted in recent months to the WTO's Government Procurement Agreement (GPA) , and the World Health Organization's (WHO) International Health Regulations (IHR).

As for the recent rapid rise in unemployement, Ma said that the government has already adopted various measures to help the unemployed, and pledged that the government would continue to seek methods to assist those who have fallen on hard times.
According to Ma, the government's plans to reduce unemployment and combat the recent economic downturn has had a positive impact on the nation's economy.
"Taiwan is defeating the economic downturn, " Ma quoted the U.S.-based magazine Global Finance as saying.

Ma said that Taiwan successfully survived the first and second oil crises, the 1997 Asian Financial Crisis and the bursting of the dot. com bubble at the beginning of this decade and expressed confidence that by uniting the will and power of the government, the private sector and the people, Taiwan will prevail in its attempts to ride out the current global economic storm.

DOC.HEADLINE: Golden turtle gives Penghu a Lantern Festival high

TEXT.P: A turtle-shaped piece of solid gold weighing over 8 kilograms raised annual Lantern Festival celebrations to a fever pitch in Penghu County Monday, with locals hoping for a chance to take the golden turtle home in the belief it will bring them wealth.

Every year for over two centuries, residents of the island archipelago off Taiwan's southwestern coast had prayed that they would win a turtle-shaped cake -- a charm believed to bring good luck and a peaceful new year -- at local temples on the 15th day of the first month on the lunar calendar.
To bring the turtle-shaped cake home, worshipers had to receive the approval of the god enshrined in the temple through the successful throwing a pair of half- moon shaped divinatory blocks.
The tradition required that those blessed by the gods and allowed to take the cakes home had to bring back bigger ones to their respective temples the following year.

In one particular temple in Magong City, the tradition got out of hand. The cake made of rice flour, sugar and maltose grew increasingly enormous every year until 1988, when one man sought a compromise after winning a super turtle rice cake weighing 7,680 kilograms.
He eventually agreed with the temple to return the following year with a golden turtle worth more than it would have cost to make an 8-ton cake.
It marked the end of the "rice turtle cake competition" and began a "golden turtle age" that other temples emulated, according to local cultural historian Wang Wen-lian.
The 8-kg "golden turtle king, " won last year by Weng Chin-lai at another Magong temple and now worth NT$8.5 million, was the biggest prize sought after by Penghu residents Monday.

Weng's wife said their business improved after winning the turtle last year, and Weng displayed it in his store Sunday, giving other villagers the chance to touch it and hope some of its luck rubbed off on them before a new winner was found a day later.
Forced to bring a bigger turtle back to the temple this year, Weng decided to return the "golden turtle king" and another golden turtle weighing 750 grams.
For those Lantern Festival worshipers who do not come away with the big prize, they will still be able to win smaller turtle-shaped rice cakes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's palace museum aims to serve as creative center: official

TEXT.P: Taiwan's famed National Palace Museum (NPM) is aiming to become the country's engine for developing cultural and creative industries, starting with the establishment of an educational center in the near future, an NPM official said Monday.

Speaking at a New Years luncheon, NPM Director Chou Kung-shin said that prior to the centers planned operation in 2012, the museum, with its rich cultural heritage, will first launch a series of initiatives to boost the countrys capacity in the area.

For instance, she said that the NPM will engage firms that have business ventures with it to provide weekly training courses starting in the middle of the year for their design teams on how to transform the museums numerous collection items into creative products and maximize their potential business values.
Taiwans creative industry as a whole will benefit from the program, Chou said, adding that the image of those companies and the quality of their products will also be elevated.

In addition to courses, workshops and hardware facilities such as showcase rooms and digital classrooms, the center will also come equipped with a hotel, a restaurant and a tea house, all adorned in the classical Chinese style, Chou said.

Meanwhile, she said the NPM is also considering launching an exhibition on the Ching Dynastys Kang-hsi emperor and his contemporary European counterpart Louis XIV in a collaborative effort with Frances Versailles Museum in the near future.

Other areas that the NPM is working on, she explained, include a renovation plan slated to begin in April to re-design the visiting order of the museums galleries as well as to lower the noise level observed in them, making the museum an even more pleasant place to visit.

The museum is also crafting various educational programs targeting different age groups, Chou added. For example, it has launched a volunteer camp for youngsters after the Chinese New Year, in the hope of fostering the ability to appreciate arts in the countrys younger generation, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wei Chuan infant formulas safe: Department of Health

TEXT.P: Three Wei Chuan Corp. infant formulas tested by the Department of Health (DOH) were not tainted with a lethal bacteria that China said was present in infant formulas exported by the company to southern China last year, a government official announced Monday.

Wang Che-chiao, spokesman for the Cabinet-level DOH, said the three infant formulas that Wei Chuan produced at its Douliou plant in Yunlin County, southern Taiwan were determined to be free from the bacteria Enterobacter sakasakii following an in-depth analysis by the DOH.

Wang indicated, however, that the DOH will soon officially demand that Taiwan's food producers include tests for the bacteria in their quality control processes to ease consumer concern over food safety.

Yunlin County officials collected samples of Wei Chuan's S1, S2 and S3 infant formulas produced by its Douliou plant Feb. 3, a day after local media reported that three different kinds of infant formula shipped by Wei Chuan from its Douliou plant were found by Chinese customs agents in Shenzhen on Oct. 30 to be contaminated with the bacteria Enterobacter sakazakii.

The shipment of 200 cartons totaling 9.264 tons of the three infant formulas exclusively sold in the Chinese market was said to be destroyed on the spot by Chinese inspectors that same day, making it impossible for local officials to verify the Chinese claims.
According to Wei Chuan executives, the three exported infant formulas were not sold in Taiwan, but operations at the company's Douliou plant were suspended pending the result of the DOH tests.

Before receiving the DOH's confirmation Monday, Yunlin County officials previously said on Feb. 3 that the county's tests had not found any evidence that the company's raw materials, finished products, or manufacturing facilities were contaminated with the bacteria.
The rod-shaped Enterobacter sakazakii bacteria is capable of causing meningitis and enteritis and has a fatality rate of more than 50 percent when infecting newborns.
From 1998-2005, there were only 46 such infection cases around the world, DOH officials said, citing data provided by the U. S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
Wei Chuan, one of Taiwan's biggest food processing companies, has been trying to penetrate the Chinese market and exported the suspect shipment in October through an agent in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shopping vouchers help increase visits to book fair: organizer

TEXT.P: The Taipei International Book Exhibition (TIBE) closed Monday after drawing 500,000 visitors since it opened Feb. 4, Taipei Book Fair Foundation Chairman Linden Lin said, attributing the strong turnout to the government's shopping voucher program.
Lin said the vouchers' impact was especially noticeable in the stationary, children's book and comic book pavilions that were constantly packed with young visitors and reported sales growth.

According to the foundation, 906 publishers from Taiwan and 41 other countries joined the 2009 book fair held at the Taipei World Trade Center. During the six- day fair, 300 seminars and new book launch sessions took place.
The number of visitors to the fair far exceeded the 410,000 people who showed up last year and the 400,000 who attended the fair in 2007, said foundation CEO Lin Wen-chih.

Unlike previous years, the 2009 fair featured national themes, arranging publishers by nationality. The strategy proved successful, Lin said, noting that the U.S. pavilion alone attracted 25,000 visitors, and drew 210 publishers seeking to obtain publication copyrights.

At the closing ceremony, Lin touted the book fair -- the world's second largest -- as playing a unique role in international cultural exchanges. He said Brazil, which was absent from this year's fair, has already asked to participate next year.
In addition, the TIBE arranged for the Munich-based Goethe Institute to cooperate with Taiwan's Council for Cultural Affairs in translating German works into Chinese, Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Labor officials admit they are powerless on unpaid leave issue

TEXT.P: Labor officials admitted Monday that they are powerless to stop the increasingly common practice of forcing workers to take unpaid leave taken by private enterprises to lower their costs during the global economic slowdown.

The officials at the Department of Labor Standards under the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) told reporters that although they have been busy handling complaints about unpaid leave since the fourth quarter of 2008, they have not been able to nail any businesses for violating the labor law.
"It is extremely difficult to establish whether a specific case of unpaid leave amounts to a violation of the labor law," said one official who declined to be named.

According to the officials, many employees sent home on unpaid leave signed agreements on the arrangement under pressure from their employers because they feared that failure to do so might cost them their jobs.
Once an employee has inked the document agreeing to taking unpaid leave, it is impossible to accuse the employer of forcing him or her to take mandatory unpaid leave, the officials said.

The results of a survey conducted recently by the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs showed that among those enterprises that have a workforce of over 200 people, 18 percent have resorted to unpaid leave, affecting more than 200,000 workers.

Meanwhile, the administration in charge of the Hsinchu Science Park -- Taiwan's "Silicon Valley" -- reported that some 100,000 employees, accounting for 76 percent of the total number of workers in the park, were being affected by unpaid leave.
Earlier statistics compiled by the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) showed that as of late December 2008, 741,000 people were affected by unpaid leave nationwide.

In addition to those on unpaid leave, unemployment is also on the rise. The number of unemployed in Taiwan rose to 549,000 in December 2008, the highest level since October 2003, DGBAS figures showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former first lady to apologize to public after appearance in court

TEXT.P: Former first lady Wu Shu-jen will apologize to the public for her role in a corruption and money-laundering case implicating the former first family after her appearance in a pre-trial court session Tuesday.
The wheelchair-bound former first lady will be accompanied by her son Chen Chih- chung, who was also indicted in the same case, a staff member of former President Chen Shui-bian's office said Monday.
The spokesman said that Wu had a cold, but it would not affect her appearance at the Taipei District Court Tuesday.
"Wu will issue a statement after her appearance in court, expressing her sorrow for causing social disturbances and confrontation in the wake of the high- profile case," he said.
"Whether she will read the statement herself or ask others to read it on her behalf will hinge on her physical condition at that time," he added.
The former first lady was indicted in November 2006 for misappropriating NT$14.8 million (US$440,000) in "state affairs funds" at the discretionary use of then-president Chen Shui-bian.
Wu, however, nearly fainted during a break on the trial's first day on Dec. 15, 2006 and was rushed to the hospital. She has since missed 17 consecutive hearing dates despite repeated summons.

Tuesday's pre-trial session will focus on new indictments against her and the former first family, on charges of embezzling NT$104.15 million from the state affairs fund, taking bribes in a land deal and an exhibition hall tender and laundering nearly half a billion Taiwan dollars in ill-gotten funds overseas.
Meanwhile, National Taiwan University Hospital said it has prepared one ambulance and four medical professionals at the request of the Taipei District Court for Wu's court session.

A hospital spokesman said the Taipei District Court will foot the bill for the presence of the health care workers and the ambulance. Based on previous experience, the cost of the mission will be around NT$20,000, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei traffic police to clamp down on moving road violations

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Police Department confirmed Monday that it has acquired 15 video cameras which will be mounted in patrol cars to help clamp down on moving road violations within the city.
Officials at the department's Traffic Division said the multifunctional in- car camcorders will be put in service as soon as they pass test runs.

The new equipment will allow traffic police to record traffic violations committed by motorists while their vehicles are in motion, including speeding, weaving through traffic, failing to indicate a turn, and crossing a double solid line that indicates the separation between lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions.
Moving violations are usually classified as misdemeanors, but serious violations can constitute felonies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Low passenger volume leads to NT$2.2 billion in KRTC losses

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung mass rapid transit system lost NT$2.2 billion (US$63.58 million) in 2008 due to weak passenger demand, an official of the company responsible for the subway system's operations said Monday.
Yen Pang-chieh, president of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp., noted that actual losses were NT$100 million less than the originally estimated NT$2.3 billion.
He noted that since the inauguration of the Red and Orange lines of the rapid transit system in March and September last year, the operation's finances have suffered because of low passenger volume.
"To make up the financial shortfall, the company plans to increase passenger volume by 30 percent and cut operating costs by 10 percent," he added.

The company has estimated that it has annual costs, including personnel expenses, interest payments and depreciation, of between NT$4.5 billion and NT$4.7 billion, while revenues from ticket sales and related businesses are around NT$2.4 billion.
The KRTC estimated passenger volume on the two lines since their inaugurations at 30.57 million, and hoped the number would rise to 40 million this year.
The Kaohsiung MRT was constructed on a build-operate-transfer (BOT) basis at a total cost of NT$181.3 billion.
Covering a total of 42.7 kilometers, the MRT system in the southern Taiwan port city is comprised of two lines -- the east-west Orange Line and the north-south Red Line.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dutch diplomat makes root-seeking visit to indigenous communities

TEXT.P: The Netherlands representative to Taiwan led a group of Dutch expatriates to visit two indigenous communities in the southernmost county of Pingtung Monday to meet with descendants of Dutch and indigenous Rukai people who married centuries ago.

Menno Goedhart, head of the Netherlands Trade and Investment Office (NTIO) in Taipei, said he has planned to organize the trip since he came to learn four years ago that there were intermarriages between the Dutch and Rukais back in the 17th century when Taiwan was under Holland's colonial rule.

The group, composed of members of 14 Dutch families in Taiwan as well NTIO's Taiwanese staff and wives of the Danish and Czech Republic representatives to Taipei, visited the mountainous townships of Wutai and Jilu, home to the Rukai tribe.

Jilu residents, all of whom are older than 60, decked out and staged a series of traditional rituals, including killing a pig and presenting head jewelry and tribal costumes, to welcome the guests. They also performed tribal dances to show their hospitality.

In addition, Rukai elders allowed Goedhart and his wife to perform a "strike and feel pottery teapot" rite to symbolize their acceptance by Rukai ancestors. Traditionally, only Rukai chieftans are eligible to perform the rite.

Goedhard, who is writing a book to introduce Taiwan's indigenous tribes and their cultures to foreign readers, said the root-seeking trip was inspired by a story he heard during a visit to Sandimen, another indigenous community in Pingtung County, three months ago.
At the time, he came to learn that the owner of a Sandimen restaurant where he was having lunch, identified as Yen Mei-kuei, was a fifth generation descendant of a Dutch man and a Rukai princess.

More than 100 years ago, the Dutch man met the Rukai princess in Wutai township and they later married. The man later left Taiwan and returned to the Netherlands, leaving the Rukai princess to raise their son on her own.
On Monday, Yen Mei-kuei presented three photos of the son of the Dutch man to Goedhart as a souvenir.

Rukai elders said that for years Jilu residents were unwilling to have Yen disclose her family's Dutch origin. As times have changed, they said, the residents finally came to believe that the taboo should be broken.

Moreover, Rukai elders said they looked forward to the Dutch visitors' assistance in spreading Rukai culture to the world and help foreigners better understand Taiwan's indigenous people and their history, customs and cultural traditions.

The Dutch guests presented 50 quilts as well as stationery, toys and other articles to Jilu residents, but he was surprised to find that the village didn't have any children as the young people had all emigrated to cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Golden turtle gives Penghu a Lantern Festival high

TEXT.P: A turtle-shaped piece of solid gold weighing over 8 kilograms raised annual Lantern Festival celebrations to a fever pitch in Penghu County Monday, with locals hoping for a chance to take the golden turtle home in the belief it will bring them wealth.

Every year for over two centuries, residents of the island archipelago off Taiwan's southwestern coast had prayed that they would win a turtle-shaped cake -- a charm believed to bring good luck and a peaceful new year -- at local temples on the 15th day of the first month on the lunar calendar.
To bring the turtle-shaped cake home, worshipers had to receive the approval of the god enshrined in the temple through the successful throwing a pair of half- moon shaped divinatory blocks.
The tradition required that those blessed by the gods and allowed to take the cakes home had to bring back bigger ones to their respective temples the following year.

In one particular temple in Magong City, the tradition got out of hand. The cake made of rice flour, sugar and maltose grew increasingly enormous every year until 1988, when one man sought a compromise after winning a super turtle rice cake weighing 7,680 kilograms.
He eventually agreed with the temple to return the following year with a golden turtle worth more than it would have cost to make an 8-ton cake.
It marked the end of the "rice turtle cake competition" and began a "golden turtle age" that other temples emulated, according to local cultural historian Wang Wen-lian.
The 8-kg "golden turtle king, " won last year by Weng Chin-lai at another Magong temple and now worth NT$8.5 million, was the biggest prize sought after by Penghu residents Monday.

Weng's wife said their business improved after winning the turtle last year, and Weng displayed it in his store Sunday, giving other villagers the chance to touch it and hope some of its luck rubbed off on them before a new winner was found a day later.
Forced to bring a bigger turtle back to the temple this year, Weng decided to return the "golden turtle king" and another golden turtle weighing 750 grams.
For those Lantern Festival worshipers who do not come away with the big prize, they will still be able to win smaller turtle-shaped rice cakes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's palace museum aims to serve as creative center: official

TEXT.P: Taiwan's famed National Palace Museum (NPM) is aiming to become the country's engine for developing cultural and creative industries, starting with the establishment of an educational center in the near future, an NPM official said Monday.

Speaking at a New Years luncheon, NPM Director Chou Kung-shin said that prior to the centers planned operation in 2012, the museum, with its rich cultural heritage, will first launch a series of initiatives to boost the countrys capacity in the area.

For instance, she said that the NPM will engage firms that have business ventures with it to provide weekly training courses starting in the middle of the year for their design teams on how to transform the museums numerous collection items into creative products and maximize their potential business values.
Taiwans creative industry as a whole will benefit from the program, Chou said, adding that the image of those companies and the quality of their products will also be elevated.

In addition to courses, workshops and hardware facilities such as showcase rooms and digital classrooms, the center will also come equipped with a hotel, a restaurant and a tea house, all adorned in the classical Chinese style, Chou said.

Meanwhile, she said the NPM is also considering launching an exhibition on the Ching Dynastys Kang-hsi emperor and his contemporary European counterpart Louis XIV in a collaborative effort with Frances Versailles Museum in the near future.

Other areas that the NPM is working on, she explained, include a renovation plan slated to begin in April to re-design the visiting order of the museums galleries as well as to lower the noise level observed in them, making the museum an even more pleasant place to visit.

The museum is also crafting various educational programs targeting different age groups, Chou added. For example, it has launched a volunteer camp for youngsters after the Chinese New Year, in the hope of fostering the ability to appreciate arts in the countrys younger generation, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wei Chuan infant formulas safe: Department of Health

TEXT.P: Three Wei Chuan Corp. infant formulas tested by the Department of Health (DOH) were not tainted with a lethal bacteria that China said was present in infant formulas exported by the company to southern China last year, a government official announced Monday.

Wang Che-chiao, spokesman for the Cabinet-level DOH, said the three infant formulas that Wei Chuan produced at its Douliou plant in Yunlin County, southern Taiwan were determined to be free from the bacteria Enterobacter sakasakii following an in-depth analysis by the DOH.

Wang indicated, however, that the DOH will soon officially demand that Taiwan's food producers include tests for the bacteria in their quality control processes to ease consumer concern over food safety.

Yunlin County officials collected samples of Wei Chuan's S1, S2 and S3 infant formulas produced by its Douliou plant Feb. 3, a day after local media reported that three different kinds of infant formula shipped by Wei Chuan from its Douliou plant were found by Chinese customs agents in Shenzhen on Oct. 30 to be contaminated with the bacteria Enterobacter sakazakii.

The shipment of 200 cartons totaling 9.264 tons of the three infant formulas exclusively sold in the Chinese market was said to be destroyed on the spot by Chinese inspectors that same day, making it impossible for local officials to verify the Chinese claims.
According to Wei Chuan executives, the three exported infant formulas were not sold in Taiwan, but operations at the company's Douliou plant were suspended pending the result of the DOH tests.

Before receiving the DOH's confirmation Monday, Yunlin County officials previously said on Feb. 3 that the county's tests had not found any evidence that the company's raw materials, finished products, or manufacturing facilities were contaminated with the bacteria.
The rod-shaped Enterobacter sakazakii bacteria is capable of causing meningitis and enteritis and has a fatality rate of more than 50 percent when infecting newborns.
From 1998-2005, there were only 46 such infection cases around the world, DOH officials said, citing data provided by the U. S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
Wei Chuan, one of Taiwan's biggest food processing companies, has been trying to penetrate the Chinese market and exported the suspect shipment in October through an agent in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 10, or the 16th day of the first month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1763: The Treaty of Paris is signed, ending seven years of war and heralding Britain's emergence as the leading world power. Britain gained both Canada and Florida and established dominance in the East.
1840: Queen Victoria of Britain and Ireland and empress of India, whose sense of duty and strict moral code had great influence on 19th-century British society, marries her first cousin, Prince Albert.
1846: British forces defeat Sikhs at Sobranhan, India.
1890: Boris Pasternak, the Russian author famed for his prize-winning novel "Doctor Zhivago," is born.
1894: Harold Macmillan, British statesman and Conservative prime minister, is born.
1904: The Russo-Japanese war breaks out after Japan formally declares war on Russia.
1923: William Rontgen, the German physicist who discovered X-rays and developed X-ray photography, thereby revolutionizing medical diagnosis, dies in Munich at the age of 77.
1939: Haikuo falls after Japanese troops land on Hainan Island in southern China.
1946: In the first Jakarta (Batavia) meeting between the two sides, the Netherlands government bows to the inevitable and agrees to let Indonesia become independent, on the condition that Indonesia forms a confederation of states.
1955: Thousands of armed South African police begin evicting 60,000 black people from their homes in Sophiatown near Johannesburg, with bulldozers flattening the township in their wake.
1955: All 14,483 residents of the Republic of China-held Tachen Islands near mainland China's Chekiang Province are evacuated to Taiwan.
1962: In an historic exchange, captured U.S. spy-plane pilot Gary Powers starts walking to freedom from the communist side of a Berlin bridge, while the highest-ranking Russian spy ever caught, KGB Colonel Rudolf Abel, sets off from the American side.
1964: The government of the ROC recalls its envoy from France and announces the severance of diplomatic relations with the European country.
1964: More than 80 people die as HMAS Voyager, a destroyer of the Royal Australian Navy, sinks after a collision with HMAS Melbourne.
1974: An all-star women's basketball team leaves Taipei for a tour of the United States.
1976: Work begins on an elevated road across the North Gate area of Taipei, in a move designed to relieve traffic congestion.
1980: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces severance of diplomatic relations with Colombia.
1981: King Juan Carlos names Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo as prime minister of Spain.
1981: The 32 new ROC Control Yuan members are sworn in.
1982: President Chiang Ching-kuo sends a congratulatory message to President- elect Luis Alberto Monge Alvarez of the Republic of Costa Rica.
1985: The ROC Ministry of Finance orders the 10th Credit Cooperative of Taipei to stop transactions for three days for violating operating regulations.
1996: On the Japanese island of Hokkaido, a landslide crushes a highway tunnel, killing 20 people.
1998: Former French Foreign Minister Maurice Schumann dies. He is considered a founding father of the European Union.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui and Marshall Islands President Imata Kabua sign a joint communique reaffirming their commitment to further expanding bilateral cooperation.
2001: Fan Liqing and Zhen Binhua, the first two mainland Chinese reporters allowed to be stationed in Taiwan, cover their first story, with themselves being the center of attention among the local press.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Is moral life something remote or difficult? If a man only wishes to live a moral life -- there and then his life becomes moral."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's legislative speaker arrives in Belgium
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Feb. 9 (CNA) 02/10/09 11:21:30 (By P.C. Tang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng arrived in Belgium Monday on the final leg of his current European visit that has taken him to Italy and the Vatican.
The highlights of his stay in Belgium will be a speech he will deliver in the European Parliament Wednesday and his meeting with Hans-Gert Pottering, president of the lawmaking body.

Wang is also expected to confer a medal on Graham Watson, leader of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe, and Georg Jarzembowski, head of the European Parliament-Taiwan Friendship Group, to mark their contributions to promoting parliamentary diplomacy with Taiwan.

Jilu residents, all of whom are older than 60, decked out and staged a series of traditional rituals, including killing a pig and presenting head jewelry and tribal costumes, to welcome the guests. They also performed tribal dances to show their hospitality.

In addition, Rukai elders allowed Goedhart and his wife to perform a "strike and feel pottery teapot" rite to symbolize their acceptance by Rukai ancestors. Traditionally, only Rukai chieftans are eligible to perform the rite.

Goedhard, who is writing a book to introduce Taiwan's indigenous tribes and their cultures to foreign readers, said the root-seeking trip was inspired by a story he heard during a visit to Sandimen, another indigenous community in Pingtung County, three months ago.
At the time, he came to learn that the owner of a Sandimen restaurant where he was having lunch, identified as Yen Mei-kuei, was a fifth generation descendant of a Dutch man and a Rukai princess.

More than 100 years ago, the Dutch man met the Rukai princess in Wutai township and they later married. The man later left Taiwan and returned to the Netherlands, leaving the Rukai princess to raise their son on her own.
On Monday, Yen Mei-kuei presented three photos of the son of the Dutch man to Goedhart as a souvenir.

Rukai elders said that for years Jilu residents were unwilling to have Yen disclose her family's Dutch origin. As times have changed, they said, the residents finally came to believe that the taboo should be broken.

Moreover, Rukai elders said they looked forward to the Dutch visitors' assistance in spreading Rukai culture to the world and help foreigners better understand Taiwan's indigenous people and their history, customs and cultural traditions.

The Dutch guests presented 50 quilts as well as stationery, toys and other articles to Jilu residents, but he was surprised to find that the village didn't have any children as the young people had all emigrated to cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Low passenger volume leads to NT$2.2 billion in KRTC losses

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung mass rapid transit system lost NT$2.2 billion (US$63.58 million) in 2008 due to weak passenger demand, an official of the company responsible for the subway system's operations said Monday.
Yen Pang-chieh, president of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp., noted that actual losses were NT$100 million less than the originally estimated NT$2.3 billion.
He noted that since the inauguration of the Red and Orange lines of the rapid transit system in March and September last year, the operation's finances have suffered because of low passenger volume.
"To make up the financial shortfall, the company plans to increase passenger volume by 30 percent and cut operating costs by 10 percent," he added.

The company has estimated that it has annual costs, including personnel expenses, interest payments and depreciation, of between NT$4.5 billion and NT$4.7 billion, while revenues from ticket sales and related businesses are around NT$2.4 billion.
The KRTC estimated passenger volume on the two lines since their inaugurations at 30.57 million, and hoped the number would rise to 40 million this year.
The Kaohsiung MRT was constructed on a build-operate-transfer (BOT) basis at a total cost of NT$181.3 billion.
Covering a total of 42.7 kilometers, the MRT system in the southern Taiwan port city is comprised of two lines -- the east-west Orange Line and the north-south Red Line.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former first lady to apologize to public after appearance in court

TEXT.P: Former first lady Wu Shu-jen will apologize to the public for her role in a corruption and money-laundering case implicating the former first family after her appearance in a pre-trial court session Tuesday.
The wheelchair-bound former first lady will be accompanied by her son Chen Chih- chung, who was also indicted in the same case, a staff member of former President Chen Shui-bian's office said Monday.
The spokesman said that Wu had a cold, but it would not affect her appearance at the Taipei District Court Tuesday.
"Wu will issue a statement after her appearance in court, expressing her sorrow for causing social disturbances and confrontation in the wake of the high- profile case," he said.
"Whether she will read the statement herself or ask others to read it on her behalf will hinge on her physical condition at that time," he added.
The former first lady was indicted in November 2006 for misappropriating NT$14.8 million (US$440,000) in "state affairs funds" at the discretionary use of then-president Chen Shui-bian.
Wu, however, nearly fainted during a break on the trial's first day on Dec. 15, 2006 and was rushed to the hospital. She has since missed 17 consecutive hearing dates despite repeated summons.

Tuesday's pre-trial session will focus on new indictments against her and the former first family, on charges of embezzling NT$104.15 million from the state affairs fund, taking bribes in a land deal and an exhibition hall tender and laundering nearly half a billion Taiwan dollars in ill-gotten funds overseas.
Meanwhile, National Taiwan University Hospital said it has prepared one ambulance and four medical professionals at the request of the Taipei District Court for Wu's court session.

A hospital spokesman said the Taipei District Court will foot the bill for the presence of the health care workers and the ambulance. Based on previous experience, the cost of the mission will be around NT$20,000, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Labor officials admit they are powerless on unpaid leave issue

TEXT.P: Labor officials admitted Monday that they are powerless to stop the increasingly common practice of forcing workers to take unpaid leave taken by private enterprises to lower their costs during the global economic slowdown.

The officials at the Department of Labor Standards under the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) told reporters that although they have been busy handling complaints about unpaid leave since the fourth quarter of 2008, they have not been able to nail any businesses for violating the labor law.
"It is extremely difficult to establish whether a specific case of unpaid leave amounts to a violation of the labor law," said one official who declined to be named.

According to the officials, many employees sent home on unpaid leave signed agreements on the arrangement under pressure from their employers because they feared that failure to do so might cost them their jobs.
Once an employee has inked the document agreeing to taking unpaid leave, it is impossible to accuse the employer of forcing him or her to take mandatory unpaid leave, the officials said.

The results of a survey conducted recently by the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs showed that among those enterprises that have a workforce of over 200 people, 18 percent have resorted to unpaid leave, affecting more than 200,000 workers.

Meanwhile, the administration in charge of the Hsinchu Science Park -- Taiwan's "Silicon Valley" -- reported that some 100,000 employees, accounting for 76 percent of the total number of workers in the park, were being affected by unpaid leave.
Earlier statistics compiled by the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) showed that as of late December 2008, 741,000 people were affected by unpaid leave nationwide.

In addition to those on unpaid leave, unemployment is also on the rise. The number of unemployed in Taiwan rose to 549,000 in December 2008, the highest level since October 2003, DGBAS figures showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shopping vouchers help increase visits to book fair: organizer

TEXT.P: The Taipei International Book Exhibition (TIBE) closed Monday after drawing 500,000 visitors since it opened Feb. 4, Taipei Book Fair Foundation Chairman Linden Lin said, attributing the strong turnout to the government's shopping voucher program.
Lin said the vouchers' impact was especially noticeable in the stationary, children's book and comic book pavilions that were constantly packed with young visitors and reported sales growth.

According to the foundation, 906 publishers from Taiwan and 41 other countries joined the 2009 book fair held at the Taipei World Trade Center. During the six- day fair, 300 seminars and new book launch sessions took place.
The number of visitors to the fair far exceeded the 410,000 people who showed up last year and the 400,000 who attended the fair in 2007, said foundation CEO Lin Wen-chih.

Unlike previous years, the 2009 fair featured national themes, arranging publishers by nationality. The strategy proved successful, Lin said, noting that the U.S. pavilion alone attracted 25,000 visitors, and drew 210 publishers seeking to obtain publication copyrights.

At the closing ceremony, Lin touted the book fair -- the world's second largest -- as playing a unique role in international cultural exchanges. He said Brazil, which was absent from this year's fair, has already asked to participate next year.
In addition, the TIBE arranged for the Munich-based Goethe Institute to cooperate with Taiwan's Council for Cultural Affairs in translating German works into Chinese, Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former legislator apologizes over citizenship issue

TEXT.P: Former Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lee Ching-an apologized to the public Tuesday for the turmoil triggered by a dispute over her dual citizenship status as she was again summoned by prosecutors for questioning as part of their investigation into the case.
Also, Lee told the media that she was sorry about the harm caused to her supporters and the KMT.
Lee said she will cooperate with prosecutors in the hope that the judiciary will help prove her innocence.

The former lawmaker refused to say, however, if she will return the compensation she received during her time in public office, now that four of her election wins to public office have been nullified by the Central Election Commission (CEC).
Lee stressed that she took her past public service very seriously and will devote the rest of her life to helping more needy individuals.

Last Friday, the CEC revoked its declaration of Lee's election as a member of the seventh Taipei City Council and of the fourth, fifth and sixth Legislative Yuans and annulled all relevant election certificates she received from 1994 to 2005, after determining that she held U.S. citizenship during that period.

The CEC action did not cover her election to the seventh Legislative Yuan in 2008, a post she resigned amid mounting public pressure on Jan. 8, 2009, nearly one year after it was discovered that she had never formally relinquished her U.S. citizenship.
Taiwan's Nationality Act requires those holding dual citizenship to surrender their foreign citizenship before assuming public office.

Lee insisted that she was awaiting a retroactive ruling by U.S. authorities on her status, after contending that holding public office in another country was an expatriating act that automatically nullified her U.S. citizenship.
Prosecutors are conducting an investigation into alleged forgery and corruption involving Lee, based on a complaint filed by a group of Democratic Progressive Party legislators in March 2008.

The legislators alleged that by holding dual citizenship while in public office, Lee defrauded public coffers of over NT$100 million in salary as a Taipei City councilor between 1994 and 1998 and as a legislator from 1999 to 2009, and they demanded that she return the "illicit gains."

DOC.HEADLINE: EU representative praises Taiwan's EU visa waiver program

TEXT.P: The top European Union (EU) representative in Taiwan said Taiwan'se-Passportsand broadened visa exemptions for some EU member countries provide a good foundation on which the EU can initiate a discussion on making a reciprocal offer to Taiwan.

Guy Ledoux, head of the Taipei-based European Economic and Trade Office (EETO) , made the remarks in an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency Monday, the same day the British government announced that starting March 3, holders of Republic of China (Taiwan) passports are eligible for visa-free entry to the United Kingdom for a maximum stay of six months.

Ledoux, who serves as the de facto EU ambassador in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations, said the EU very much welcomed the steps taken by Taiwan last year to eliminate visa requirements for citizens of some EU member states and issue electronic passports, which are difficult to forge.
These two steps will certainly help put in place an appropriate background to launch a discussion on this issue in Europe, Ledoux said.

The foreign ministry began issuing e-Passports Dec. 30, 2008, making Taiwan the 60th country in the world to do so. The electronic passport contains a contactless chip and antenna embedded in its back cover, with the bearer's biographical data and facial image stored on the chip.

On visa exemptions, the foreign ministry on Oct. 1, 2008 extended visa waivers to citizens of Poland and Slovakia for a maximum stay of 30 days, and holders of passports from Hungary were also given visa-free entry starting Nov. 1, 2008.

At present, 23 of the EU's 27 member countries are included in Taiwan's visa waiver program, with Slovenia scheduled to be included Feb. 15, according to Anne Hung, director-general of the ministry's Department of European Affairs.

Noting that the EU has faced an influx of illegal immigrants from many parts of the world that makes granting visa-free entry a very sensitive issue, Ledoux said no meeting has been scheduled yet to discuss reciprocal treatment for Taiwanese travelers to the EU, even if illegal immigrants arenot an issuewith Taiwan.

Asked whether the UK's decision to grant Taiwanese visa-free entry could serve as a reference for the United States' visa waiver program, American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) spokesman Thomas Hodges remained non-committal.

He told the CNA Tuesday that his agency's position on the issue remains the same as remarks made by AIT Director Stephen Young in his biannual press conference last November and the speech he made in a luncheon held by the American Chamber of Commerce last December.

Young said that while the U.S. is well aware of Taiwan's interest in a visa waiver and recognizes that Taiwanese are law-biding travelers, there remained a number of issues that needed to be resolved before Taiwan could be considered for the visa waiver program.
One issue he mentioned was that Taiwan needed to enhance efforts to ensure that its passports are issued only to those qualified to obtain them.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former first lady arrives at Taipei District Court

TEXT.P: Former first lady Wu Shu-jen waved and smiled at onlookers as she arrived at the Taipei District Court Tuesday afternoon for a pre-trial hearing on the corruption and money-laundering charges she faces.
Accompanied by her son Chen Chih-chung, who has also been indicted in the same case, the wheelchair-bound Wu arrived about 18 minutes before the hearing's scheduled 2:30 p.m. start.

Considering her physical condition, the court will allow a 10-minute break after questioning her for 30 minutes. The prosecutors will also shorten the time they devote to their statements to allow the former first lady more time to state her case.

Tuesday's pre-trial session will focus on new indictments against her and the former first family that charge them with embezzling NT$104.15 million from the state affairs fund, taking bribes in a land deal and an exhibition hall tender and laundering nearly half a billion Taiwan dollars in ill-gotten funds overseas.

Wu was previously indicted in 2006 for embezzling over NT$10 million from the presidential state affairs fund while her husband Chen Shui-bian was still in office. She has been absent from 17 consecutive hearings in that trial because of health issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: First German-Taiwan film premieres at Berlin film festival
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Feb. 8 (CNA) 02/10/09 15:13:20 (By Lin Yu-li and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: "Ai-Mei, " the first ever German-Taiwanese collaboration on a film about lesbians, drew a capacity crowd of 600 at its world premiere as an official entry in the Berlin International Film Festival's Panorama section in Berlin Feb. 7.

The feature film, also known as "Ghosted, " which tells of a mysterious love story between two lesbians in Hamburg and Taipei, is the latest project of German director Monika Treut, who is highly regarded for treatment of lesbian and gender issues on the big screen.

After the film's screening, Treut said that aside from her attempt to explore the differences between the two cultures through the main characters' emotional connections, her fascination with Taiwanese culture was also another important motivation behind the production of the film.
Noting that the project was inspired by Taiwanese ghost myths, the feminist filmmaker said her curiosity was piqued by the German version of Taiwan novelist Li Ang's novel "the Invisible Ghost."
