The novel compelled her to try to make a movie based on the concept of using a doppelgaenger, or ghostly double of a living person.

The cast includes German film and theater actress Inga Busch, who played the role of the German artist Sophie Schmitt, and Taiwan's Ke Huan-ru, who acted as Schmitt's Taiwanese lover, and Ke's doppelgaenger Judy Hu.

Drawing a stark contrast between Taiwan and Germany, the film juxtaposes Taiwan's colorful religious rituals, strong family cohesion, a respect for the dead and natural beauty with images of coldness and loneliness in Germany and alienation among family members.
Treut said "the fear of death" mind-set is widespread across Europe, and for most Europeans, visiting tombs is a solemn affair.

To her astonishment, however, Taiwanese people customarily burn a considerable amount of paper money as offerings to the dead during Ghost Month -- the seventh lunar month of every year -- and often hold a dialogue with the dead during religious rituals, she added.
The director also described Taiwan as an amazing nation where modern and traditional elements as well as Chinese, American and Japanese cultures co- exist.
"Taiwan would be crowded with tourists if they were aware of such a place," she added.
The two leading actresses from Taiwan, Ke Huan-ru and Judy Hu, were also present at the premiere.
Hu said she was surprised by Treut's in-depth understanding of Taiwan, which enabled her to portray matters related to Taiwan.

With the support of Filmfoerderung Hamburg GmbH, the German Federal Government and Taiwan's Government Information Office, "Ai Mei, " was co-produced by Treut's production company Hyena Films in Hamburg and Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen (Second German Television) and Taiwan's Chi & Company and Taiwan Public Television Service.
Treut previously directed two documentaries on Taiwan -- Tigerwomen Grow Wings, about three generations of women, and Made in Taiwan, a portrait of a 17 -year-old dance student.
The two films reflect growing tensions between parents and children during a period of rapid social and political change in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Morgan Stanley says Taiwan's economy to shrink by 6% in 2009

TEXT.P: Morgan Stanley Taiwan predicted Tuesday that Taiwan will continue to be battered by the global economic slowdown in 2009, with the economy contracting by 6 percent and exports falling by 23 percent.

The gloomy forecast was the second in the last week by a multinational investment firm, after CLSA Asia-Pacific Markets predicted Feb. 4 that Taiwan's economy would contract by 11 percent because of a major slump in exports.

The forecasts contrast sharply with an estimate issued by Taiwan's Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics last Nov. 20 pegging Taiwan's 2009 economic growth at 2.12 percent. The agency is expected to issue a revised forecast Feb. 19.

Morgan Stanley Taiwan, which had previously pegged Taiwan's economic growth at 0.5 percent for 2009, said the country's gross domestic product (GDP) would contract by between 1.5 percent and 8.8 percent for the year, and expected GDP to decline another 2.2 percent in 2010.

Global investment firms' recent reports contend that Taiwan's export-oriented economy will not be able to maintain positive growth in the face of a severe drop-off in exports caused by the global recession.

In Tuesday's report, Morgan Stanley Taiwan predicted the Taiwan's exports would shrink by 23 percent in 2009. On Monday, the country reported a fall of 44.1 percent drop in exports in January due to the nine-day Lunar New Year holiday, the biggest monthly decline in history.

The firm also predicted that Taiwan's benchmark stock exchange index, the Taiex, would fluctuate between 3,350 points and 5,400 points in the coming 12 months, with the most likely level 4,200 points.
It advised investors to increase their investments in telecommunications, domestic consumption, and blue chip technology shares.

In response to the forecast, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reiterated that the government has proposed and carried out many measures to pump up the economy to try and maintain economic growth in 2009 at 2.5 percent.
The economic situation should not be as dire as the foreign firm's prediction indicates, a CEPD official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices rose Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, advancing 31.51 points, or 0.7 percent, to close at 4,526.10.

Posting a gain for the third consecutive day, the local bourse opened higher at 4,524.05 and fluctuated between 4,533.95 and 4,491.84. A total of 2.98 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$59.32 billion (US$1.76 billion).

Five major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial stocks moving up the most at 1.2 percent. Machinery and electronics issues gained 0.7 percent, construction shares and plastics and chemicals stocks both advanced 0.4 percent, and cement stocks rose 0.3 percent.
Textile stocks remained unchanged.
Two stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff shares dropping the most at 0.9 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 888 to 629, with 234 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyer of shares worth NT$922 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: 180,000 workers on unpaid leave: labor council

TEXT.P: At least 180,000 workers across Taiwan are on unpaid leave, with those in the high-tech sector the most likely to be given extra days off, the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) reported Tuesday.

The council said the estimate is based on reports on unpaid leave practices submitted to the CLA from more than 400 companies across the country between Dec. 23 and Jan. 31, with the aggregate number of affected workers totaling around 180,000.
The CLA has required local enterprises since January to report the number of their workers on unpaid leave, to better monitor the impact of falling exports on Taiwan's labor market.

The CLA acknowledged that some companies with workers on unpaid leave may not have reported their situation to the council, but because the 180,000 worker estimate is similar to the result of an earlier survey conducted in last December, the council believes compliance with the reporting system is quite high.

Based on a random survey of companies with over 200 workers conducted in December, the council estimated that 202,000 workers were being forced by management to take an average of four days of unpaid leave in that month alone.

Meanwhile, the number of workers on full or partial unpaid leave in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan has reached over 100,000, accounting for 77 percent of the park's total work force.

Amid a global economic tsunami that has battered enterprises across the world, companies in Taiwan's high-tech, financial and conventional sectors have all been hard hit, with many forced to scale down or shut down their operations.

Some companies, however, have withstood the strain and tried hard to retain their work forces, using flexible measures such as cutting salaries and forcing workers to take paid or unpaid leave instead of laying them off.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seminar in Taipei to focus on investment opportunities in Indonesia

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce will hold a seminar Wednesday to allow Taiwanese entrepreneurs to familiarize themselves with investment opportunities in Indonesia.
The seminar is scheduled to take place from 2 p.m. to 4:30 p.m. in the auditorium of the Taipei Farmers Association on Fuxing South Road.

According to a news release posted on the association's Web site, Johny F. Djafar, director of the Investment Department of the Indonesian Economic and Trade Office to Taiwan, will brief the participants on the most current investment opportunities in Indonesia.
Chiang Ching-cheng, secretary general of the Indonesia Taiwan Chamber of Commerce, will also speak at the seminar to share his experience of investing in Indonesia.

Wu Fu-cheng, deputy director of the international affairs division of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, will present a research paper on Indonesia's economic recovery and challenges ahead. His paper will also offer suggestions to help Taiwan's production industries make inroads into the Indonesian market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Drug abuse among Taiwan students beginning at younger ages: MOE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) called the public attention Tuesday to what it said was a worrying trend of drug abuse among Taiwan students beginning at younger ages, even as early as in senior year of elementary school.

Also, unlike in the past when drug abuse was mainly found among students with more pocket money, the problem has now spread to those from disadvantaged families who have no pocket money, said Wang Fu-lin, head of the ministry's Department of Military Training Education.

The findings by the MOE revealed that instead of buying drugs with their own money, these students gain access to illicit substances because their unemployed parents have turned to drug use to try to lighten their moods, Wang said.
He reminded teachers to pay closer attention to any students who appear unusually ecstatic or lethargic or who doze off frequently in classes.
Due to the ministry's efforts to step up its monitoring of drug abuse among students, a total of 815 offenders were found in 2008, a sharp increase from the 294 recorded the previous year, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for February advancing 43 points to end at 4,497, with 60,156 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for March gained 42 points to finish at 4,450, with 1,511 contracts traded, while June futures rose 28 points to end at 4,378, with 33 contracts traded.
September futures gained 21 points to close at 4,167, with 52 contract transactions, while December futures increased 21 points to end at 4,114, with seven contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 4,454 for February, 4,408 for March, 4,350 for June 4,146 for September, and 4,093 for December.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index increased 31.51 points to finish at 4,526.10, on turnover of NT$59.32 billion (US$1.76 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

February TE futures gained 1.45 points to close at 180.8, with 3,159 contracts traded, while March TE futures advanced 1.5 points to finish at 179.2, with 48 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.
February TF futures were up 9.6 points to close at 513.2, with 3,308 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures increased 10 points to finish at 508, with 59 contracts traded.
September TF furtures fell 12 points to finish at 475, with one contract changing hands. No transactions were recorded for June and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, increasing NT$0.006 to close at NT$33.967.
A total of US$867 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$34.010 and fluctuated between NT$33.798 and NT$34.015.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fertilizer supply sufficient for spring planting: agency

TEXT.P: A full supply of fertilizer for spring cultivation will be available soon, so that rice farmers can begin planting, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Tuesday.

Yu Sheng-feng, deputy director-general of the COA's Agriculture and Food Agency, said the agency has been coordinating with fertilizer companies and grassroots farmers' associations to ensure a full supply of ammonium sulfate -- an inorganic chemical compound commonly used as a fertilizer in spring rice cultivation.

With some 159,000 hectares of rice paddies across the country expected be plowed to plant the crop in the coming peak season in March -- a similar acreage as last year -- it is estimated that about 90,000 metric tons of ammonium sulfate will be needed, agency officials said, noting that as much as 100,000 metric tons of the fertilizer will be in supply.
Meanwhile, the agency announced last week that with immediate effect, it will be offering bigger incentives to encourage farmers to restart cultivation of fallow lands.
The plan is aimed at securing the country's food supply and stabilizing food prices on the domestic market in view of the high prices on the world market, said the agency.
The agency will guarantee landowners an income of NT$45,000 (US$1,339) or more per hectare for each harvest.
If the owners lease their farmlands for food crop cultivation for three years in a row, the agency will guarantee an income of over NT$50,000 per hectare for each harvest, the officials said.
The agency will also offer a subsidy of NT$20,000 per hectare to farmers who grow feed corn, while farmers devoted to organic farming will be entitled to NT$15,000 per hectare.

Landowners who cannot resume cultivation of their farms or find tenants to lease them, and instead plant green organic fertilizer, will be granted NT$45,000 per hectare by the agency, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei County provides schools with 80,000 masks against flu

TEXT.P: The Taipei County government began distributing more than 80,000 masks to elementary schools around the county Tuesday to prevent influenza outbreaks, after the county's first case of severe influenza was reported, a county official said Tuesday.

The local government took the step after it was confirmed that a 27-year-old woman, surnamed Lee, in Sanchung City had severe complicated influenza, according to Lin Kuo-ning, an official of the county's Public Health Bureau.
The woman sought medical treatment at a local hospital after falling ill and showing symptoms of lack of appetite, fever, sore throat, and difficulty breathing, Lin said.
The case was identified by the Department of Health's Centers for Disease Control (CDC) as the county's first severe flu infection this year, Lin added.
Lee did not get an influenza vaccine last year, and her mother who lives with her also developed mild flu symptoms, according to the bureau's investigation.

As of Feb. 6, 11 cases of severe influenza had been reported in the county for the year, a sharp increase compared with five cases recorded in the same period of last year, according to statistics compiled by the bureau.
The CDC data also shows a continuing rise in the number of emergency room visits for parainfluenza around the country, Lin added.

With the winter break about to end, the county's Public Health Bureau began handing out 86,800 masks to 217 schools in the county for use by school children who have flu symptoms, in an effort to reduce the risk of influenza virus infections on campuses, Lin said.

Given that young children are at high risk for influenza complications, such as pneumococcal lung infection, Lin urged that children aged 2-5 who have been registered as county residents and have not had the pneumococcal vaccine be urgently taken to health centers and medical institutions for free flu shots.

He also reminded people who have parainfluenza symptoms, such as a fever, cough and sore throat, to immediately seek medical treatment and get plenty of rest to avoid developing serious, life-threatening complications such as pneumonia and encephalitis.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-first lady pleads guilty to forgery

TEXT.P: Former first lady Wu Shu-jen pleaded guilty to forgery, and not guilty to the other charges against her during a court hearing Tuesday.

Wu, who showed up at the Taipei District Court after missing 17 consecutive court hearings over 785 days, admitted that she used invoices from other people to claim reimbursement from a government fund set aside for the use of her husband, former President Chen Shui-bian, during his term as head of state.
However, she denied that she embezzled public funds and said she was not guilty of the other charges against her.
Wu was first indicted along with three of Chen's former aides on Nov. 3, 2006 for siphoning off NT$14.8 million from the state affairs fund.

The prosecutors brought additional charges of corruptions money laundering against her, her husband, her son Chen Chih-chung, her daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching, the three aides above and seven others on Dec. 12, 2008.

She fainted during her first appearance in court during the trial on Dec. 15, 2006, and missed all the subsequent hearings, despite being summoned by the court. She claimed that her fragile physical condition would not allow her to stand trial.
In preparation for Wu's appearance in court, an ambulance and a team of four medial workers from National Taiwan University Hospital remained on standby at the court Tuesday.

Wu admitted she received money from some businessmen and stashed it in overseas bank accounts, as the prosecutors stated in their indictment against her, but said that the funds were political donations rather than bribes, and were much less than the amount stated in the indictment.

Among the donations was a sum of US$2.2 million -- not NT$2.7 million as the prosecutors claimed in their indictment -- from a contractor who won a government contract to build an exhibition hall in Nangang, Taipei City thanks to her influence, Wu said.

The hearing lasted for about two hours and the presiding judge granted Wu's request to postpone Wednesday's hearing to March 3 and 5 because she cannot physically hold up in court for two days in a row.
After the hearing, Wu read a statement to journalists waiting outside the court room, apologizing for implicating "so many innocent people" in the case and for stirring up so much social turmoil.
"I will face trial and investigation openly, and will appear before the court or prosecutors whenever I am summoned, as long as my physical condition allows." Wu said.
Of the 14 defendants, only the former president is still being held in custody.
Many of these indicted, including Wu's son Chen chih-chung and her daughter-in- law Huang Jui-ching, have pleaded guilty to money laundering charges.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA welcomes Taiwan's acceptance to U.K.'s visa-free program

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Tuesday welcomed the U.K. government's decision to include Taiwan in its visa-waiver program with effect from early March, saying this will help expand exchanges between the two countries.

The U.K. office in Taiwan announced earlier in the day that Taiwanese passport holders who wish to visit the European country for less than six months for business, study or tourism will no longer require visas, beginning March 3.

Speaking at a press conference, Deputy Foreign Minister David Lin noted that the U.K. will become the first western powerhouse to lift visa requirements for Taiwanese citizens. He expressed the hope that the U.K.'s decision will influence the other European Union countries, the United States and Canada to move in a similar direction.

It is hoped that the inclusion in the British visa waiver program will put Taiwan on a better footing to push for admission to other visa-free programs, especially in the Commonwealth countries such as Australia and New Zealand, he added.

With the U.K allowing Taiwanese six-month visa-free access for the purposes of tourism, business, study and family visits, this is Taiwan's most favorable visa-free treatment to date, compared to similar privileges granted by other countries, Lin noted.

Lo Yu-chung, director general of the ministry's Bureau of Consular Affairs (BOCA) , said that the U.K.'s decision demonstrated that Taiwan's efforts to prevent passport fraud by issuing ePassports late last year have been recognized, as this has greatly reduced the number of bogus Republic of China (R.O.C.) passports used by mainland Chinese.
It also showed that Taiwanese crime and overstaying rates in the U.K. is low, as this would have been part of the strict evaluation criteria for the visa waiver program, he added.

Based on statistics that showed over 40,000 Taiwanese visited the U.K. last year, it is estimated that Taiwan will save up to NT$300 million (US$8.83 million) in British visa fees alone, Lo said, adding that several administrative procedures such as fingerprinting will also be simplified.

Taiwan currently allows 30-day visa-free entry for British nationals visiting the island, but the BOCA will consider providing reciprocal visa treatment for them in light of the U.K.'s visa waiver decision, he said.
According to MOFA, 31 countries worldwide, including Japan, South Korea and Singapore, currently allow visa-free entry to Taiwan passport holders.
In 2007, the U.K. was Taiwan's third largest trading partner in Europe and 17th biggest in the world, according to MOFA.
There are around 15,000 Taiwanese students currently studying in the European country, the ministry added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC, UMC report drop in revenues for January

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) and United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC), Taiwan's two biggest contract chip manufacturers, on Tuesday both posted a decline in business revenue in January.

TSMC's consolidated revenue in January totaled about NT$13.13 billion (US$387 million), representing a 9 percent decrease from the previous month, and a big drop of 57.8 percent year-on-year. The figure marked a new record low since the company began to publish reports on its consolidated revenue, according to a report released by the company.

UMC reported that its revenue in January declined by 31.6 percent from the previous month to NT$3.15 billion, setting a new monthly low over a period of nearly nine years and representing a plunge of 61.62 percent year-on-year.
TSMC also forecast a big drop in its consolidated revenue for February and March. The average revenue for the two months is projected at between NT$9.44 billion and NT$10.94 billion.

UMC Chief Executive Sun Shih-wei forecast at a news briefing Tuesday that the company's sales will continue to slide in February but the downturn will bottom out in the first quarter. Sun said according to the report, the company's consolidated revenue is expected to rebound in March and reach NT$4 billion by that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Unemployment among college graduates hits 400,000: DPP

TEXT.P: The number of jobless college and university graduates has hit 400,000 amid the global recession that has battered Taiwan's export-oriented economy, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Youth Director Chao Tian-lin said Tuesday.

Chao made the claim at a workshop organized by the DPP, in which 1111 Job Bank Vice General Manager Ryan Wu, Dean Ray Dawn of the Taipei-based China University of Technology College of Business and representatives of unemployed young people were invited to discuss the current situation of jobless young graduates.
According to Chao, the vast unemployment figure was worked out based on both the government statistics and 1111 Job Bank survey results.

He said that while official tallies show 220,000 graduates are jobless, the 1111 Job Bank's survey results suggest that there are another 150,000 youths who have failed to find a job within a year of graduation, while others have found only temporary work.
Citing 1111 Job Bank tallies, Wu said 45 percent of college and university graduates did not join the labor insurance system last year.
Based on the fact that Taiwan produces 320,000 graduates every year, they speculated that about 150,000 graduates have never worked since graduation.
Those people are in the group of the "invisible unemployed," said Wu, adding his personal opinion that the nationwide unemployed population might have reached nearly 1.3 million.

Criticizing the government's plan to subsidize private enterprises to hire people who have been jobless for at least three months as a failed policy, Wu claimed it is not possible for the government to lower the unemployment rate to below 4.5 percent this year.

At the workshop, Mai Chung-chiang, a student at the Department of Finance of Taipei County-based Jinwen University of Science and Technology, complained that he sent out over 200 job applications over the past six months, none of which were answered.
His financial straits forced him to drop out of school, Mai added.

Huang Chung-you, who is studying at National Taiwan University's Graduate Institute of National Development, said most of his classmates are worried that they will not be able to find work after graduation.

DOC.HEADLINE: BTCO head confident that Taiwan can combat passport fraud

TEXT.P: In the wake of London's announcement Monday that Taiwanese visitors will be granted visa-free entry to the United Kingdom, the top British representative in Taiwan on Tuesday expressed confidence in the Taiwan authorities' ability to combat the problem of fraudulent documentation.

David Campbell, who assumed office a week ago as the director of the Taipei- based British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) , told the Central News Agency that the problem of false documentation is a worldwide one. The U.K. addresses that issue by maintaining very close links with immigration authorities around the world, including in Taiwan, he said.

"We have very good and regular contacts with the immigration authorities here, and I would expect that only to further strengthen with the announcement yesterday," said Campbell, who is the de facto British ambassador to Taiwan.

Following Britain's first global review of visa requirements for travel there, British Home Secretary Jacqui Smith announced in a statement Monday that starting March 3, holders of Republic of China (Taiwan) passports will be eligible for visa-free entry to the United Kingdom for a maximum stay of six months.
Britain is the first major Western country to include Taiwan in its visa waiver program.

Asked whether the British government is worried that Taiwanese passports will become an attractive tool for Chinese gangsters, Campbell said that as Taiwan has taken a number of steps, such as the introduction of electronic passports, to combat misuse of documentation, his office is confident that "the risks as such can be managed."
The new BTCO director said that the visa waiver decision will benefit the economic, trade and people-to-people exchanges between the U.K. and Taiwan.
Taiwan was the only country to be granted visa exemption in the U.K.'s two-year visa review, while stricter requirements will
now be introduced for visitors from Bolivia, Lesotho, South Africa,
Swaziland and Venezuela.

The BTCO received over 28,000 visa applications in 2008. After March 3, that figure is expected to fall to 6,000-8,000 a year, according to the BTCO, which serves as the de facto British embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-legislator's campaign subsidies will not be reclaimed: CEC

TEXT.P: The campaign subsidies received by former Kuomintang Legislator Lee Ching-an between 1994 and 2005 will not be reclaimed, even though her election to public office during that period have been nullified due to her illegally holding dual citizenship, the Central Election Commission (CEC) said Tuesday.

According to the CEC, the Public Officials Election and Recall Act does not forbid those with dual citizenship from running for public office, although they are required to surrender their foreign citizenship before assuming office.
A campaign subsidy of NT$30 per vote is provided to any eligible candidate, regardless of whether they are elected or not, the CEC said.

On Feb. 6, the CEC revoked its declaration of Lee's election as a member of the seventh Taipei City Council and of the fourth, fifth and sixth Legislative yuans and annulled all relevant election certificates she received from 1994 to 2005, after determining that she held U.S. citizenship.

The CEC action does not cover Lee's election to the seventh Legislative Yuan in 2008, because the jurisdiction for handling dual citizenship involving a legislator was transferred to the Legislative Yuan following a 2007 amendment to the Public Officials Election and Recall Law.

Although Lee had held public office in Taiwan for so many years, it was not until March 2008 that she was found to have never relinquished her U.S. citizenship. She resigned from her latest legislative post amid mounting public pressure Jan. 8, following confirmation by the U.S. authorities in late 2008 that she "has previously been documented as a U.S. citizen with a U.S. passport and that no subsequent loss of U.S. citizenship has been documented."

DOC.HEADLINE: Spain's Compania Nacional de Danza to perform in Taipei

TEXT.P: As part of the 2009 Taiwan International Festival, Spain's Compania Nacional de Danza (CND) will perform the work "Alas" at Taipei's National Theater Concert Hall (NTCH) March 3-8, NTCH artistic director Liu Chung-shu announced Tuesday.

"We are highly anxious to experience the visual flair and passion of Spain's most celebrated dance company and would like to urge Taiwan's dance lovers to take advantage of this rare opportunity," said Liu.
Alas, which means wings in Spanish, is the first collaborative work between CND's acclaimed director Nacho Duato and Slovenian theater director Tomas Pandur, said Liu.
According to Liu, Alas is a deeply poetic and visually stunning mediation on one of the most influential films of the 20th century.

"Alas was inspired by the Wim Wenders 1987 film, 'Wings of Desire,' which is the story of an angel wandering in post-war Berlin, who wishes for mortality in order to experience the joys of everyday life." Liu said.
For his text, Pandur chooses short fragments of Peter Handke's script for the film, said Liu, adding that nevertheless, Duato's choreography does not explicitly parallel the movie.
Liu said one of the highlights of the presentation is that Duarto himself dances and recites a series of monologues in the central role of Damiel, the ever watchful angel.
The collaboration between the two artists is a match made in heaven, as Pandur uses his bold sense of theater to reinforce Duato's choreography, said Liu.
The music will be original compositions by Pedro Alcalde and Sergio Caballero, both of whom have previously composed for CND, Liu added.
Moreover, Duato will also work with a long-time collaborator, Brad Fields, who is responsible for lighting, said Liu.

According to the information provided by the CND, having worked under Jiri Kylian at Nederlands Dans Theater, Nacho Duato has developed a modern style based on classical ballet that challenges contemporary dance trends.
Considered one of the most internationally renowned scenic contemporary creators, Duato has created dramatically charged works of overwhelming beauty, it stated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Parliamentary supervision can fortify democracy: Swedish ombudsman

TEXT.P: Parliamentary supervision can contribute to the consolidation of often-imperfect democratic mechanisms, visiting Swedish Chief Parliamentary Ombudsman Mats Melin said Tuesday.

During a speech titled "200 Years of Parliament" delivered at the Control Yuan, Melin said that according to Sweden's experience, parliamentary supervision can fortify a nation's democracy and help its development.

Parliamentary supervision promotes an excellent social environment, said Melin, adding that in recognition of its importance, Sweden will launch a series of activities to celebrate the 200th anniversary of the establishment of the Swedish Parliamentary Ombudsmen.
Melin said that his main job is to supervise judges and government officials and to expose public servants who have committed crimes or who have failed to fulfill their responsibilities.
Control Yuan chief Wang Chien-shien said the government supervision mechanism is like a "preservative" that prevents government departments and agencies from "rotting."
In recognition of Melin's status in the international arena, Wang presented him with a First Class Supervision medal.

According to Wang, the Control Yuan will send representatives to participate in the ninth international ombudsman institute world conference, which will be held in the Swedish capital of Stockholm June 9-12.
Melin, who is visiting Taiwan Feb. 10-14, will also meet with President Ma Ying- jeou to share his experience in parliamentary supervision.
The Control Yuan has the powers of impeachment, censure and audit. In addition, it can take corrective measures against government departments and agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Computer Association to launch Consumer Voucher Exhibition

TEXT.P: The Taipei Computer Association (TCA) announced Tuesday that it will launch a consumer voucher exhibition Feb. 12-16 in order to boost the sale of 3C products through voucher spending.
"We want to provide more business opportunities to the 3C industry amid the recent economic downturn," TCA officials said.
According to the TCA, unlike the other major computer exhibitions in Taiwan, this one will offer a variety of attractive deals to consumers who purchase 3C products with their shopping vouchers.

"This is the first time the government has issued shopping vouchers and we do not want to miss the opportunity to exploit the great business opportunities associated with the government's consumption stimulation plan," said the officials.

Participating companies will offer discounts on notebooks, digital cameras, computer peripherals and upgrades, electronic dictionaries, LCD monitors, LCD televisions, refrigerators and other 3C products, according to the officials.

More than 2 million people have yet to claim a total of NT$7.2 billion (US$212 million) -worth of vouchers, the officials said, adding that now is the perfect time to launch a consumer voucher exhibition, as students will need various 3C items when they return to school after the winter vacation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Central Taiwan drug rehab center uses music as therapy

TEXT.P: The Taichung Drug Abuse Treatment Center has succeeded in using violin lessons over the past six months to help with the treatment and rehabilitation of 40 drug abusers, center director Chou Hui-huang said Tuesday.

According to Chou, the violin class was first offered last July. Under the guidance of violinist Wu Wen-tung, a former conductor of the Chi Mei Mandolin Orchestra, 20 drug abusers attended a three-hour class every week and learned the rudiments of the instrument in three months.

The students gave a successful concert at the end of the program and the overwhelming public response to the music therapy program prompted the center to invite the teacher to conduct a second class, taking on 20 more drug abusers undergoing rehabilitation.

The students in the second class marked the conclusion of their three months of training with a concert Tuesday and family members were elated to see the results and share the joy in their achievements.
Chou said that in learning how to play the violin, the drug abusers have built new values in life and have found the spiritual strength to help them overcome drug addiction.
He added that the center will continue to use violin lessons to help with the rehabilitation of drug abusers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese depart Taiwan after getting remuneration for fraud

TEXT.P: A group of Chinese visitors left Taiwan Tuesday after staging a protest at the airport and getting a combined NT$1.7 million (US$50,000) -- equivalent to their combined tour fee -- paid by a local travel agent for what they described as a fraud scheme they encountered while in Taiwan.

Before taking a flight back to China from the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, the 34 Chinese visitors refused to board but instead staged a noisy protest against the swindle to which they were subjected.
The tourists entered Taiwan Feb. 5 and were scheduled to leave Feb. 10. They visited Sun Moon Lake and Alishan Mountain in central and southern Taiwan during their six-day stay.

The results of an initial investigation by airport police show that the Chinese visitors were apparently cheated into participating in a so-called "global Chinese art contest" held at a technology company in Taipei City, because an invitation card that the Chinese visitors showed to them was apparently fake.
Huang Yen, one of the tourists, said they felt cheated as they did not get any cash award from the contest and because their itinerary in Taiwan was not the same as the one listed on their contracts.
According to Huang, they reported the case to police in Taipei County, but they refused to handle the case, telling them instead that the case was "not established."
"We want our rights to be served before we leave Taiwan and we want those in charge to return our tour fees," Huang said.
Each of the 34 tourists paid from 8,100-8,800 Chinese yuan for the tour.
The travel agency that hosted the tourists claimed to know nothing about the contest and said the deal was brokered through a local man surnamed Cheng.
Taipei city government spokesman Yang Siao-dong later confirmed that the invitation card given to the tourists was forged.
Yang expressed regret over the incident and said it might hobble cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges at a time when Taiwan and China are committed to bolstering two-way activity.
He urged local organizations and individuals to be on guard against similar cases and to verify any such invitations with the city government before accepting them.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung to get another high-tech industrial park

TEXT.P: The Export Processing Zone Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Tuesday that it has completed the screening of a plan to establish a new industrial park in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
Officials at the EPZ Administration said the MOEA will submit the plan to the Cabinet in March for approval.
They added that under the plan, all infrastructure projects in the park will be completed by mid-2010 in order to allow high-tech industries to move in.

The 8.48-hectare tract of land for the proposed park is the site of a former Veterans Plastics Work factory opposite the Nanzih Export Processing Zone in Kaohsiung's Nanzih district. The project to develop the park will cost about NT$1.8 billion (US$31.81 million).

According to the officials, once the park is completed, it is expected to attract investment totaling NT$10 billion from high-tech industrial companies and create some 2,700 jobs, with an annual business turnover of NT$15 billion.

Meanwhile, the EPZ Administration is continuing with a land renewal program that started in 2006 to rejuvenate three 40-year-old export processing zones in Kaohsiung, Nanzih and Taichung to meet the needs of high technology industries, including the integrated circuit industry and the liquid crystal display industry.

As of the end of last year, 98 buildings in the three zones had been renovated and four others torn down for reconstruction, representing a 33.28 percent renewal rate, according to the administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Feb. 11, 2009

TEXT.P: 2. Event: Premier Liao Chao-shiuan presides over the meeting of woman rights promotion committee under the Executive Yuan. Date and Time: 2.30 p.m., Wednesday, Feb. 11, 2009 Place: No. 1, ChongXiao East Road, Section 1, Taipei City. Executive Yuan. Host and/or main speakers: Premier Liao Chao-shiuan. Organizers: Executive Yuan. Press Contact: 3356-6500
Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Morgan Stanley says Taiwan's economy to shrink by 6% in 2009

TEXT.P: Morgan Stanley Taiwan predicted Tuesday that Taiwan will continue to be battered by the global economic slowdown in 2009, with the economy contracting by 6 percent and exports falling by 23 percent.

The gloomy forecast was the second in the last week by a multinational investment firm, after CLSA Asia-Pacific Markets predicted Feb. 4 that Taiwan's economy would contract by 11 percent because of a major slump in exports.

The forecasts contrast sharply with an estimate issued by Taiwan's Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics last Nov. 20 pegging Taiwan's 2009 economic growth at 2.12 percent. The agency is expected to issue a revised forecast Feb. 19.

Morgan Stanley Taiwan, which had previously pegged Taiwan's economic growth at 0.5 percent for 2009, said the country's gross domestic product (GDP) would contract by between 1.5 percent and 8.8 percent for the year, and expected GDP to decline another 2.2 percent in 2010.

Global investment firms' recent reports contend that Taiwan's export-oriented economy will not be able to maintain positive growth in the face of a severe drop-off in exports caused by the global recession.

In Tuesday's report, Morgan Stanley Taiwan predicted the Taiwan's exports would shrink by 23 percent in 2009. On Monday, the country reported a fall of 44.1 percent drop in exports in January due to the nine-day Lunar New Year holiday, the biggest monthly decline in history.

The firm also predicted that Taiwan's benchmark stock exchange index, the Taiex, would fluctuate between 3,350 points and 5,400 points in the coming 12 months, with the most likely level 4,200 points.
It advised investors to increase their investments in telecommunications, domestic consumption, and blue chip technology shares.

In response to the forecast, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reiterated that the government has proposed and carried out many measures to pump up the economy to try and maintain economic growth in 2009 at 2.5 percent.
The economic situation should not be as dire as the foreign firm's prediction indicates, a CEPD official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices rose Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, advancing 31.51 points, or 0.7 percent, to close at 4,526.10.

Posting a gain for the third consecutive day, the local bourse opened higher at 4,524.05 and fluctuated between 4,533.95 and 4,491.84. A total of 2.98 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$59.32 billion (US$1.76 billion).

Five major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial stocks moving up the most at 1.2 percent. Machinery and electronics issues gained 0.7 percent, construction shares and plastics and chemicals stocks both advanced 0.4 percent, and cement stocks rose 0.3 percent.
Textile stocks remained unchanged.
Two stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff shares dropping the most at 0.9 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 888 to 629, with 234 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyer of shares worth NT$922 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: 180,000 workers on unpaid leave: labor council

TEXT.P: At least 180,000 workers across Taiwan are on unpaid leave, with those in the high-tech sector the most likely to be given extra days off, the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) reported Tuesday.

The council said the estimate is based on reports on unpaid leave practices submitted to the CLA from more than 400 companies across the country between Dec. 23 and Jan. 31, with the aggregate number of affected workers totaling around 180,000.
The CLA has required local enterprises since January to report the number of their workers on unpaid leave, to better monitor the impact of falling exports on Taiwan's labor market.

The CLA acknowledged that some companies with workers on unpaid leave may not have reported their situation to the council, but because the 180,000 worker estimate is similar to the result of an earlier survey conducted in last December, the council believes compliance with the reporting system is quite high.

Based on a random survey of companies with over 200 workers conducted in December, the council estimated that 202,000 workers were being forced by management to take an average of four days of unpaid leave in that month alone.

Meanwhile, the number of workers on full or partial unpaid leave in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan has reached over 100,000, accounting for 77 percent of the park's total work force.

Amid a global economic tsunami that has battered enterprises across the world, companies in Taiwan's high-tech, financial and conventional sectors have all been hard hit, with many forced to scale down or shut down their operations.

Some companies, however, have withstood the strain and tried hard to retain their work forces, using flexible measures such as cutting salaries and forcing workers to take paid or unpaid leave instead of laying them off.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seminar in Taipei to focus on investment opportunities in Indonesia

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce will hold a seminar Wednesday to allow Taiwanese entrepreneurs to familiarize themselves with investment opportunities in Indonesia.
The seminar is scheduled to take place from 2 p.m. to 4:30 p.m. in the auditorium of the Taipei Farmers Association on Fuxing South Road.

According to a news release posted on the association's Web site, Johny F. Djafar, director of the Investment Department of the Indonesian Economic and Trade Office to Taiwan, will brief the participants on the most current investment opportunities in Indonesia.
Chiang Ching-cheng, secretary general of the Indonesia Taiwan Chamber of Commerce, will also speak at the seminar to share his experience of investing in Indonesia.

Wu Fu-cheng, deputy director of the international affairs division of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, will present a research paper on Indonesia's economic recovery and challenges ahead. His paper will also offer suggestions to help Taiwan's production industries make inroads into the Indonesian market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Drug abuse among Taiwan students beginning at younger ages: MOE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) called the public attention Tuesday to what it said was a worrying trend of drug abuse among Taiwan students beginning at younger ages, even as early as in senior year of elementary school.

Also, unlike in the past when drug abuse was mainly found among students with more pocket money, the problem has now spread to those from disadvantaged families who have no pocket money, said Wang Fu-lin, head of the ministry's Department of Military Training Education.

The findings by the MOE revealed that instead of buying drugs with their own money, these students gain access to illicit substances because their unemployed parents have turned to drug use to try to lighten their moods, Wang said.
He reminded teachers to pay closer attention to any students who appear unusually ecstatic or lethargic or who doze off frequently in classes.
Due to the ministry's efforts to step up its monitoring of drug abuse among students, a total of 815 offenders were found in 2008, a sharp increase from the 294 recorded the previous year, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for February advancing 43 points to end at 4,497, with 60,156 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for March gained 42 points to finish at 4,450, with 1,511 contracts traded, while June futures rose 28 points to end at 4,378, with 33 contracts traded.
September futures gained 21 points to close at 4,167, with 52 contract transactions, while December futures increased 21 points to end at 4,114, with seven contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 4,454 for February, 4,408 for March, 4,350 for June 4,146 for September, and 4,093 for December.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index increased 31.51 points to finish at 4,526.10, on turnover of NT$59.32 billion (US$1.76 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

February TE futures gained 1.45 points to close at 180.8, with 3,159 contracts traded, while March TE futures advanced 1.5 points to finish at 179.2, with 48 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.
February TF futures were up 9.6 points to close at 513.2, with 3,308 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures increased 10 points to finish at 508, with 59 contracts traded.
September TF furtures fell 12 points to finish at 475, with one contract changing hands. No transactions were recorded for June and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, increasing NT$0.006 to close at NT$33.967.
A total of US$867 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$34.010 and fluctuated between NT$33.798 and NT$34.015.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fertilizer supply sufficient for spring planting: agency

TEXT.P: A full supply of fertilizer for spring cultivation will be available soon, so that rice farmers can begin planting, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Tuesday.

Yu Sheng-feng, deputy director-general of the COA's Agriculture and Food Agency, said the agency has been coordinating with fertilizer companies and grassroots farmers' associations to ensure a full supply of ammonium sulfate -- an inorganic chemical compound commonly used as a fertilizer in spring rice cultivation.

With some 159,000 hectares of rice paddies across the country expected be plowed to plant the crop in the coming peak season in March -- a similar acreage as last year -- it is estimated that about 90,000 metric tons of ammonium sulfate will be needed, agency officials said, noting that as much as 100,000 metric tons of the fertilizer will be in supply.
Meanwhile, the agency announced last week that with immediate effect, it will be offering bigger incentives to encourage farmers to restart cultivation of fallow lands.
The plan is aimed at securing the country's food supply and stabilizing food prices on the domestic market in view of the high prices on the world market, said the agency.
The agency will guarantee landowners an income of NT$45,000 (US$1,339) or more per hectare for each harvest.
If the owners lease their farmlands for food crop cultivation for three years in a row, the agency will guarantee an income of over NT$50,000 per hectare for each harvest, the officials said.
The agency will also offer a subsidy of NT$20,000 per hectare to farmers who grow feed corn, while farmers devoted to organic farming will be entitled to NT$15,000 per hectare.

Landowners who cannot resume cultivation of their farms or find tenants to lease them, and instead plant green organic fertilizer, will be granted NT$45,000 per hectare by the agency, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei County provides schools with 80,000 masks against flu

TEXT.P: The Taipei County government began distributing more than 80,000 masks to elementary schools around the county Tuesday to prevent influenza outbreaks, after the county's first case of severe influenza was reported, a county official said Tuesday.

The local government took the step after it was confirmed that a 27-year-old woman, surnamed Lee, in Sanchung City had severe complicated influenza, according to Lin Kuo-ning, an official of the county's Public Health Bureau.
The woman sought medical treatment at a local hospital after falling ill and showing symptoms of lack of appetite, fever, sore throat, and difficulty breathing, Lin said.
The case was identified by the Department of Health's Centers for Disease Control (CDC) as the county's first severe flu infection this year, Lin added.
Lee did not get an influenza vaccine last year, and her mother who lives with her also developed mild flu symptoms, according to the bureau's investigation.

As of Feb. 6, 11 cases of severe influenza had been reported in the county for the year, a sharp increase compared with five cases recorded in the same period of last year, according to statistics compiled by the bureau.
The CDC data also shows a continuing rise in the number of emergency room visits for parainfluenza around the country, Lin added.

With the winter break about to end, the county's Public Health Bureau began handing out 86,800 masks to 217 schools in the county for use by school children who have flu symptoms, in an effort to reduce the risk of influenza virus infections on campuses, Lin said.

Given that young children are at high risk for influenza complications, such as pneumococcal lung infection, Lin urged that children aged 2-5 who have been registered as county residents and have not had the pneumococcal vaccine be urgently taken to health centers and medical institutions for free flu shots.

He also reminded people who have parainfluenza symptoms, such as a fever, cough and sore throat, to immediately seek medical treatment and get plenty of rest to avoid developing serious, life-threatening complications such as pneumonia and encephalitis.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-first lady pleads guilty to forgery

TEXT.P: Former first lady Wu Shu-jen pleaded guilty to forgery, and not guilty to the other charges against her during a court hearing Tuesday.

Wu, who showed up at the Taipei District Court after missing 17 consecutive court hearings over 785 days, admitted that she used invoices from other people to claim reimbursement from a government fund set aside for the use of her husband, former President Chen Shui-bian, during his term as head of state.
However, she denied that she embezzled public funds and said she was not guilty of the other charges against her.
Wu was first indicted along with three of Chen's former aides on Nov. 3, 2006 for siphoning off NT$14.8 million from the state affairs fund.

The prosecutors brought additional charges of corruptions money laundering against her, her husband, her son Chen Chih-chung, her daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching, the three aides above and seven others on Dec. 12, 2008.

She fainted during her first appearance in court during the trial on Dec. 15, 2006, and missed all the subsequent hearings, despite being summoned by the court. She claimed that her fragile physical condition would not allow her to stand trial.
In preparation for Wu's appearance in court, an ambulance and a team of four medial workers from National Taiwan University Hospital remained on standby at the court Tuesday.

Wu admitted she received money from some businessmen and stashed it in overseas bank accounts, as the prosecutors stated in their indictment against her, but said that the funds were political donations rather than bribes, and were much less than the amount stated in the indictment.

Among the donations was a sum of US$2.2 million -- not NT$2.7 million as the prosecutors claimed in their indictment -- from a contractor who won a government contract to build an exhibition hall in Nangang, Taipei City thanks to her influence, Wu said.

The hearing lasted for about two hours and the presiding judge granted Wu's request to postpone Wednesday's hearing to March 3 and 5 because she cannot physically hold up in court for two days in a row.
After the hearing, Wu read a statement to journalists waiting outside the court room, apologizing for implicating "so many innocent people" in the case and for stirring up so much social turmoil.
"I will face trial and investigation openly, and will appear before the court or prosecutors whenever I am summoned, as long as my physical condition allows." Wu said.
Of the 14 defendants, only the former president is still being held in custody.
Many of these indicted, including Wu's son Chen chih-chung and her daughter-in- law Huang Jui-ching, have pleaded guilty to money laundering charges.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA welcomes Taiwan's acceptance to U.K.'s visa-free program

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Tuesday welcomed the U.K. government's decision to include Taiwan in its visa-waiver program with effect from early March, saying this will help expand exchanges between the two countries.

The U.K. office in Taiwan announced earlier in the day that Taiwanese passport holders who wish to visit the European country for less than six months for business, study or tourism will no longer require visas, beginning March 3.

Speaking at a press conference, Deputy Foreign Minister David Lin noted that the U.K. will become the first western powerhouse to lift visa requirements for Taiwanese citizens. He expressed the hope that the U.K.'s decision will influence the other European Union countries, the United States and Canada to move in a similar direction.

It is hoped that the inclusion in the British visa waiver program will put Taiwan on a better footing to push for admission to other visa-free programs, especially in the Commonwealth countries such as Australia and New Zealand, he added.

With the U.K allowing Taiwanese six-month visa-free access for the purposes of tourism, business, study and family visits, this is Taiwan's most favorable visa-free treatment to date, compared to similar privileges granted by other countries, Lin noted.

Lo Yu-chung, director general of the ministry's Bureau of Consular Affairs (BOCA) , said that the U.K.'s decision demonstrated that Taiwan's efforts to prevent passport fraud by issuing ePassports late last year have been recognized, as this has greatly reduced the number of bogus Republic of China (R.O.C.) passports used by mainland Chinese.
It also showed that Taiwanese crime and overstaying rates in the U.K. is low, as this would have been part of the strict evaluation criteria for the visa waiver program, he added.

Based on statistics that showed over 40,000 Taiwanese visited the U.K. last year, it is estimated that Taiwan will save up to NT$300 million (US$8.83 million) in British visa fees alone, Lo said, adding that several administrative procedures such as fingerprinting will also be simplified.

Taiwan currently allows 30-day visa-free entry for British nationals visiting the island, but the BOCA will consider providing reciprocal visa treatment for them in light of the U.K.'s visa waiver decision, he said.
According to MOFA, 31 countries worldwide, including Japan, South Korea and Singapore, currently allow visa-free entry to Taiwan passport holders.
In 2007, the U.K. was Taiwan's third largest trading partner in Europe and 17th biggest in the world, according to MOFA.
There are around 15,000 Taiwanese students currently studying in the European country, the ministry added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC, UMC report drop in revenues for January

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) and United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC), Taiwan's two biggest contract chip manufacturers, on Tuesday both posted a decline in business revenue in January.

TSMC's consolidated revenue in January totaled about NT$13.13 billion (US$387 million), representing a 9 percent decrease from the previous month, and a big drop of 57.8 percent year-on-year. The figure marked a new record low since the company began to publish reports on its consolidated revenue, according to a report released by the company.

UMC reported that its revenue in January declined by 31.6 percent from the previous month to NT$3.15 billion, setting a new monthly low over a period of nearly nine years and representing a plunge of 61.62 percent year-on-year.
TSMC also forecast a big drop in its consolidated revenue for February and March. The average revenue for the two months is projected at between NT$9.44 billion and NT$10.94 billion.

UMC Chief Executive Sun Shih-wei forecast at a news briefing Tuesday that the company's sales will continue to slide in February but the downturn will bottom out in the first quarter. Sun said according to the report, the company's consolidated revenue is expected to rebound in March and reach NT$4 billion by that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Unemployment among college graduates hits 400,000: DPP

TEXT.P: The number of jobless college and university graduates has hit 400,000 amid the global recession that has battered Taiwan's export-oriented economy, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Youth Director Chao Tian-lin said Tuesday.

Chao made the claim at a workshop organized by the DPP, in which 1111 Job Bank Vice General Manager Ryan Wu, Dean Ray Dawn of the Taipei-based China University of Technology College of Business and representatives of unemployed young people were invited to discuss the current situation of jobless young graduates.
According to Chao, the vast unemployment figure was worked out based on both the government statistics and 1111 Job Bank survey results.

He said that while official tallies show 220,000 graduates are jobless, the 1111 Job Bank's survey results suggest that there are another 150,000 youths who have failed to find a job within a year of graduation, while others have found only temporary work.
Citing 1111 Job Bank tallies, Wu said 45 percent of college and university graduates did not join the labor insurance system last year.
Based on the fact that Taiwan produces 320,000 graduates every year, they speculated that about 150,000 graduates have never worked since graduation.
Those people are in the group of the "invisible unemployed," said Wu, adding his personal opinion that the nationwide unemployed population might have reached nearly 1.3 million.

Criticizing the government's plan to subsidize private enterprises to hire people who have been jobless for at least three months as a failed policy, Wu claimed it is not possible for the government to lower the unemployment rate to below 4.5 percent this year.

At the workshop, Mai Chung-chiang, a student at the Department of Finance of Taipei County-based Jinwen University of Science and Technology, complained that he sent out over 200 job applications over the past six months, none of which were answered.
His financial straits forced him to drop out of school, Mai added.

Huang Chung-you, who is studying at National Taiwan University's Graduate Institute of National Development, said most of his classmates are worried that they will not be able to find work after graduation.

DOC.HEADLINE: BTCO head confident that Taiwan can combat passport fraud

TEXT.P: In the wake of London's announcement Monday that Taiwanese visitors will be granted visa-free entry to the United Kingdom, the top British representative in Taiwan on Tuesday expressed confidence in the Taiwan authorities' ability to combat the problem of fraudulent documentation.

David Campbell, who assumed office a week ago as the director of the Taipei- based British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) , told the Central News Agency that the problem of false documentation is a worldwide one. The U.K. addresses that issue by maintaining very close links with immigration authorities around the world, including in Taiwan, he said.

"We have very good and regular contacts with the immigration authorities here, and I would expect that only to further strengthen with the announcement yesterday," said Campbell, who is the de facto British ambassador to Taiwan.

Following Britain's first global review of visa requirements for travel there, British Home Secretary Jacqui Smith announced in a statement Monday that starting March 3, holders of Republic of China (Taiwan) passports will be eligible for visa-free entry to the United Kingdom for a maximum stay of six months.
Britain is the first major Western country to include Taiwan in its visa waiver program.

Asked whether the British government is worried that Taiwanese passports will become an attractive tool for Chinese gangsters, Campbell said that as Taiwan has taken a number of steps, such as the introduction of electronic passports, to combat misuse of documentation, his office is confident that "the risks as such can be managed."
The new BTCO director said that the visa waiver decision will benefit the economic, trade and people-to-people exchanges between the U.K. and Taiwan.
Taiwan was the only country to be granted visa exemption in the U.K.'s two-year visa review, while stricter requirements will
now be introduced for visitors from Bolivia, Lesotho, South Africa,
Swaziland and Venezuela.

The BTCO received over 28,000 visa applications in 2008. After March 3, that figure is expected to fall to 6,000-8,000 a year, according to the BTCO, which serves as the de facto British embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-legislator's campaign subsidies will not be reclaimed: CEC

TEXT.P: The campaign subsidies received by former Kuomintang Legislator Lee Ching-an between 1994 and 2005 will not be reclaimed, even though her election to public office during that period have been nullified due to her illegally holding dual citizenship, the Central Election Commission (CEC) said Tuesday.

According to the CEC, the Public Officials Election and Recall Act does not forbid those with dual citizenship from running for public office, although they are required to surrender their foreign citizenship before assuming office.
A campaign subsidy of NT$30 per vote is provided to any eligible candidate, regardless of whether they are elected or not, the CEC said.

On Feb. 6, the CEC revoked its declaration of Lee's election as a member of the seventh Taipei City Council and of the fourth, fifth and sixth Legislative yuans and annulled all relevant election certificates she received from 1994 to 2005, after determining that she held U.S. citizenship.

The CEC action does not cover Lee's election to the seventh Legislative Yuan in 2008, because the jurisdiction for handling dual citizenship involving a legislator was transferred to the Legislative Yuan following a 2007 amendment to the Public Officials Election and Recall Law.

Although Lee had held public office in Taiwan for so many years, it was not until March 2008 that she was found to have never relinquished her U.S. citizenship. She resigned from her latest legislative post amid mounting public pressure Jan. 8, following confirmation by the U.S. authorities in late 2008 that she "has previously been documented as a U.S. citizen with a U.S. passport and that no subsequent loss of U.S. citizenship has been documented."

DOC.HEADLINE: Spain's Compania Nacional de Danza to perform in Taipei

TEXT.P: As part of the 2009 Taiwan International Festival, Spain's Compania Nacional de Danza (CND) will perform the work "Alas" at Taipei's National Theater Concert Hall (NTCH) March 3-8, NTCH artistic director Liu Chung-shu announced Tuesday.

"We are highly anxious to experience the visual flair and passion of Spain's most celebrated dance company and would like to urge Taiwan's dance lovers to take advantage of this rare opportunity," said Liu.
Alas, which means wings in Spanish, is the first collaborative work between CND's acclaimed director Nacho Duato and Slovenian theater director Tomas Pandur, said Liu.
According to Liu, Alas is a deeply poetic and visually stunning mediation on one of the most influential films of the 20th century.

"Alas was inspired by the Wim Wenders 1987 film, 'Wings of Desire,' which is the story of an angel wandering in post-war Berlin, who wishes for mortality in order to experience the joys of everyday life." Liu said.
For his text, Pandur chooses short fragments of Peter Handke's script for the film, said Liu, adding that nevertheless, Duato's choreography does not explicitly parallel the movie.
Liu said one of the highlights of the presentation is that Duarto himself dances and recites a series of monologues in the central role of Damiel, the ever watchful angel.
The collaboration between the two artists is a match made in heaven, as Pandur uses his bold sense of theater to reinforce Duato's choreography, said Liu.
The music will be original compositions by Pedro Alcalde and Sergio Caballero, both of whom have previously composed for CND, Liu added.
Moreover, Duato will also work with a long-time collaborator, Brad Fields, who is responsible for lighting, said Liu.

According to the information provided by the CND, having worked under Jiri Kylian at Nederlands Dans Theater, Nacho Duato has developed a modern style based on classical ballet that challenges contemporary dance trends.
Considered one of the most internationally renowned scenic contemporary creators, Duato has created dramatically charged works of overwhelming beauty, it stated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Parliamentary supervision can fortify democracy: Swedish ombudsman

TEXT.P: Parliamentary supervision can contribute to the consolidation of often-imperfect democratic mechanisms, visiting Swedish Chief Parliamentary Ombudsman Mats Melin said Tuesday.

During a speech titled "200 Years of Parliament" delivered at the Control Yuan, Melin said that according to Sweden's experience, parliamentary supervision can fortify a nation's democracy and help its development.

Parliamentary supervision promotes an excellent social environment, said Melin, adding that in recognition of its importance, Sweden will launch a series of activities to celebrate the 200th anniversary of the establishment of the Swedish Parliamentary Ombudsmen.
Melin said that his main job is to supervise judges and government officials and to expose public servants who have committed crimes or who have failed to fulfill their responsibilities.
Control Yuan chief Wang Chien-shien said the government supervision mechanism is like a "preservative" that prevents government departments and agencies from "rotting."
In recognition of Melin's status in the international arena, Wang presented him with a First Class Supervision medal.

According to Wang, the Control Yuan will send representatives to participate in the ninth international ombudsman institute world conference, which will be held in the Swedish capital of Stockholm June 9-12.
Melin, who is visiting Taiwan Feb. 10-14, will also meet with President Ma Ying- jeou to share his experience in parliamentary supervision.
The Control Yuan has the powers of impeachment, censure and audit. In addition, it can take corrective measures against government departments and agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Computer Association to launch Consumer Voucher Exhibition

TEXT.P: The Taipei Computer Association (TCA) announced Tuesday that it will launch a consumer voucher exhibition Feb. 12-16 in order to boost the sale of 3C products through voucher spending.
"We want to provide more business opportunities to the 3C industry amid the recent economic downturn," TCA officials said.
According to the TCA, unlike the other major computer exhibitions in Taiwan, this one will offer a variety of attractive deals to consumers who purchase 3C products with their shopping vouchers.

"This is the first time the government has issued shopping vouchers and we do not want to miss the opportunity to exploit the great business opportunities associated with the government's consumption stimulation plan," said the officials.

Participating companies will offer discounts on notebooks, digital cameras, computer peripherals and upgrades, electronic dictionaries, LCD monitors, LCD televisions, refrigerators and other 3C products, according to the officials.

More than 2 million people have yet to claim a total of NT$7.2 billion (US$212 million) -worth of vouchers, the officials said, adding that now is the perfect time to launch a consumer voucher exhibition, as students will need various 3C items when they return to school after the winter vacation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Central Taiwan drug rehab center uses music as therapy

TEXT.P: The Taichung Drug Abuse Treatment Center has succeeded in using violin lessons over the past six months to help with the treatment and rehabilitation of 40 drug abusers, center director Chou Hui-huang said Tuesday.

According to Chou, the violin class was first offered last July. Under the guidance of violinist Wu Wen-tung, a former conductor of the Chi Mei Mandolin Orchestra, 20 drug abusers attended a three-hour class every week and learned the rudiments of the instrument in three months.

The students gave a successful concert at the end of the program and the overwhelming public response to the music therapy program prompted the center to invite the teacher to conduct a second class, taking on 20 more drug abusers undergoing rehabilitation.

The students in the second class marked the conclusion of their three months of training with a concert Tuesday and family members were elated to see the results and share the joy in their achievements.
Chou said that in learning how to play the violin, the drug abusers have built new values in life and have found the spiritual strength to help them overcome drug addiction.
He added that the center will continue to use violin lessons to help with the rehabilitation of drug abusers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese depart Taiwan after getting remuneration for fraud

TEXT.P: A group of Chinese visitors left Taiwan Tuesday after staging a protest at the airport and getting a combined NT$1.7 million (US$50,000) -- equivalent to their combined tour fee -- paid by a local travel agent for what they described as a fraud scheme they encountered while in Taiwan.

Before taking a flight back to China from the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, the 34 Chinese visitors refused to board but instead staged a noisy protest against the swindle to which they were subjected.
The tourists entered Taiwan Feb. 5 and were scheduled to leave Feb. 10. They visited Sun Moon Lake and Alishan Mountain in central and southern Taiwan during their six-day stay.

The results of an initial investigation by airport police show that the Chinese visitors were apparently cheated into participating in a so-called "global Chinese art contest" held at a technology company in Taipei City, because an invitation card that the Chinese visitors showed to them was apparently fake.
Huang Yen, one of the tourists, said they felt cheated as they did not get any cash award from the contest and because their itinerary in Taiwan was not the same as the one listed on their contracts.
According to Huang, they reported the case to police in Taipei County, but they refused to handle the case, telling them instead that the case was "not established."
"We want our rights to be served before we leave Taiwan and we want those in charge to return our tour fees," Huang said.
Each of the 34 tourists paid from 8,100-8,800 Chinese yuan for the tour.
The travel agency that hosted the tourists claimed to know nothing about the contest and said the deal was brokered through a local man surnamed Cheng.
Taipei city government spokesman Yang Siao-dong later confirmed that the invitation card given to the tourists was forged.
Yang expressed regret over the incident and said it might hobble cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges at a time when Taiwan and China are committed to bolstering two-way activity.
He urged local organizations and individuals to be on guard against similar cases and to verify any such invitations with the city government before accepting them.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung to get another high-tech industrial park

TEXT.P: The Export Processing Zone Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Tuesday that it has completed the screening of a plan to establish a new industrial park in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
Officials at the EPZ Administration said the MOEA will submit the plan to the Cabinet in March for approval.
They added that under the plan, all infrastructure projects in the park will be completed by mid-2010 in order to allow high-tech industries to move in.

The 8.48-hectare tract of land for the proposed park is the site of a former Veterans Plastics Work factory opposite the Nanzih Export Processing Zone in Kaohsiung's Nanzih district. The project to develop the park will cost about NT$1.8 billion (US$31.81 million).

According to the officials, once the park is completed, it is expected to attract investment totaling NT$10 billion from high-tech industrial companies and create some 2,700 jobs, with an annual business turnover of NT$15 billion.

Meanwhile, the EPZ Administration is continuing with a land renewal program that started in 2006 to rejuvenate three 40-year-old export processing zones in Kaohsiung, Nanzih and Taichung to meet the needs of high technology industries, including the integrated circuit industry and the liquid crystal display industry.

As of the end of last year, 98 buildings in the three zones had been renovated and four others torn down for reconstruction, representing a 33.28 percent renewal rate, according to the administration.

The weighted price index gained 31.51 points, or 0.7 percent, to close at 4,526.10 Tuesday.
