DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 11, or the 17th day of the first month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1810: French Emperor Napoleon I, a brilliant military strategist whose military and political might gripped Continental Europe, marries Marie-Louise, daughter of the first emperor of Austria, Francis I.
1847: Thomas Alva Edison, the American who invented the incandescent light bulb and patented more than a thousand other inventions, is born. He patented his motion picture projector on his birthday in 1909.
1889: A constitution is granted in Japan with a two-chamber Diet, with the Emperor retaining extensive powers.
1920: The League of Nations convenes its first council meeting in London.
1922: A treaty for securing China's independence and maintaining an "open door" is signed in Washington by nine powers.
1929: Pope Pius XI and the Italian government of Benito Mussolini sign the Lateran Treaty, which gives Vatican City the status of an independent sovereign state.
1944: American war planes strike heavy blows against Japanese positions in the Marshall Islands.
1945: The Yalta Conference ends with an agreement for the establishment of the United Nations as well as plans for the defeat of Germany.
1946: U.S. Secretary of State James Byrnes makes public the Yalta Secret Agreement. With victory in the war with Germany virtually assured, the three allied leaders, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Winston Churchill, and Joseph Stalin, met on Feb. 4, 1945 at a secret meeting in the Black Sea resort of Yalta to map out Europe's future.
1964: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with France.
1967: Military rule is imposed in Beijing.
1968: Communist troops execute 300 civilians in South Vietnam during fighting for the city of Hue.
1970: Japan successfully launches its first satellite into orbit.
1970: The Taiwan Provincial Bureau of Mines is established with Tien Wei-wu serving as the first director-general.
1971: The United States and the Soviet Union sign a treaty in Washington banning underwater nuclear testing.
1973: Lic. Raimundo Guerrero, president of the Mexican Chapter of the World Anti-Communist League, arrives in Taipei for a brief visit.
1974: Archbishop Domenico Enrici, roving ambassador of the Holy See, arrives in Taipei on an inspection tour. He had served in the Apostolic Internunciature in Taipei 20 years earlier.
1974: Nineteen top Chinese golfers, including Melbourne World Cup Champions Lu Liang-huan and M.N. Hsieh, leave for Manila for the Asian circuit.
1974: U.S. Army Assistant Secretary Eugene E. Berg and a party of 2 arrive in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1975: For the first time in its 300 year history, Britain's Conservative Party names a woman as its leader when Margaret Thatcher defeats four rivals to succeed Edward Heath.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives the visiting Dr. N. B. Sommer, the first vice president of U.S. Cyanamid Corporation, and W. A. Liffers, the Pacific area general manager.
1979: Islamic revolutionaries take control of Iran's government after the shah, Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, fled Iran the previous month after strikes, riots, and mass demonstrations against his rule.
1990: South Africa's Nelson Mandela is freed after being imprisoned for 27 years for his anti-apartheid activities.
1991: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev sends a letter to government leaders of the Warsaw Pact nations proposing that the military structure be disbanded by April 1.
1994: Japanese Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa and U.S. President Bill Clinton fail to reach a critical trade deal.
2000: Liu Shao-tang, publisher of the Chinese-language monthly Biographical Literature, dies at the age of 80 after a long illness.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the knowledge of letters and arts, I may perhaps compare myself with other men. But as for the character of a good and wise man who carries out in his personal conduct what he professes -- that is something which I have not yet attained."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan joins charity drive in Ireland
DOC.DATELINE: London, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/09 12:04:20 (By Jennifer Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's diplomatic corps in Ireland took part in a charity drive in Dublin Tuesday aimed at raising funds for musical healing for physically and mentally challenged children.

A Taiwan delegation, lead by Taiwan's representative in Ireland Lee Nan-yang, was among 20-odd countries taking part in the fund-raising drive that was organized by the International Women's Club of Dublin.

Taiwan's fund-raising booth, featuring earthenware vases and cups, duplicates of Tang Dynasty tricolor glazed pottery horses, and reproductions of works displayed at Taipei's National Palace Museum, was one of the most-visited booths and raised a significant amount for the charity.

Nathaly Leers, president of the International Women's Club of Dublin, met with Lee during the event and voiced her appreciation to Taiwan for once again participating in a charity drive organized by the club.
The Taipei Representative Office in Ireland took part in a similar function in 2008 to support a suicide prevention campaign.

This year's drive is aimed at raising funds to financially assist a musical healing project for severely disabled children at a rehabilitation hospital in Dun Laoghaire, a seaport town in suburban Dublin, Leers said.

The International Women's Club of Dublin is one of the most active social organizations in Ireland with over 400 people, including diplomatic corps members posted in Ireland and executives of foreign companies operating in the country as well as their dependents, as its members.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Export-oriented currency depreciation might trigger protectionism

TEXT.P: Irrational depreciation of currencies by countries hoping to boost exports might trigger protectionism and global disputes, the head of a nonprofit training and research foundation warned Wednesday.

Shea Jia-dong, chairman of the Taiwan Academy of Banking and Finance, said that in the face of the global economic recession, government efforts to stimulate the economy by accelerating exports is not a commendable practice.

"Competing to depreciate currencies as a means to drive up exports will not only unleash international disputes, it might also trigger protectionism, which will do the faltering world economy a great disservice eventually," Shea said.

He said Taiwan's exports have slumped significantly over the past several months, and with the prospects for exports bleak in 2009, many outside observers are pessimistic about the country's economic growth because Taiwan's economy is heavily dependent on exports.
Amid the onslaught of the global financial "tsunami, " exports have been the hardest-hit sector," Shea said.
"Yet Taiwan is not a hopeless cause if it strives to stimulate economic growth by bolstering domestic consumption, " Shea commented, adding that the administration has been active in this area.

Although Taiwan's exports to China have slid noticeably, China still maintains the world's highest economic growth rate while continuing to shore up domestic consumption, observed Shea, who suggested that Taiwanese companies still have a competitive edge over others in exploiting China's market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government revenues down 40.1% year-on-year in January

TEXT.P: Tax revenues received by the government amounted to NT$74.7 billion (US$2.2 billion) in January, a decrease of 40.1 percent from the same month of last year, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Ministry of Finance.

The fall, the largest monthly decline since March 2007, was mainly the result of the economic downturn and a decrease in work days because of the Lunar New Year holiday, said Lin Li-chen, chief of the ministry's Department of Statistics.

All forms of tax revenue plunged in January. Sales tax revenue fell NT$25.2 billion, or 53.7 percent, year-on-year, securities transaction tax revenue declined by NT$6.9 billion, or 67.9 percent, and excise tax revenue was down NT$6.6 billion, or 60.7 percent.
Revenue from income tax fell by NT$5.1 billion, or 17.6 percent; and property value increment tax revenue slid by NT$3.3 billion, or 55.8 percent, Lin said.

If NT$17.1 billion in sales tax revenue and NT$3.2 billion in excise tax revenue that was collected but not added to the government's accounts because of the Lunar New Year holiday are included, the decrease in the two categories of revenue will narrow to 17.2 percent and 31.2 percent, respectively, she said.

If these revenues were included in the monthly total, the January year-on-year drop-off would have been 23.8 percent. Instead, the uncounted revenues will be added to the government's February accounts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan youth conventional in love relationships: poll

TEXT.P: Young men and women in southern Taiwan still maintain the conventional concept that boys should take the initiative when dating, and 37 percent said they hope to start a relationship, according to the results of a poll published Wednesday.

The survey, which polled students at 6 Tainan City high schools and vocational schools and 7 colleges and universities on their views toward love and relationships, found that 37 percent of the respondents hoped to build a relationship because they wanted to be loved by someone.
As many as 90 percent, however, said they did not know how to interact with the person they were interested in.
After beginning a relationship, 60 percent of the students surveyed cited a "change of heart" or "cheating" as the leading reason behind couple breakups, the poll found.
However, 31 percent said they would be willing to resume the relationship if the problem is resolved.

More than 70 percent said they would not carry on relationships with two people at the same time, while some 70 percent of female students said they would not build a relationship with someone living far away.
As many as 96 percent of the women responding to the poll said they cared about the height of their boyfriends, saying their boyfriends should be taller than they are.

When on a date, 30 percent of the respondents said the spending should be evenly split, while 48 percent believed that it depended on the situation. But 80 percent of the male students said they should foot the bill.

Sixty-four percent of both male and female students agreed that a married couple should rear children, while some of them said they would sign a pre-marital agreement to guarantee priority issues in their marriages.
The poll, conducted by Tainan City's family education center between Jan. 1-10, received 989 valid responses out of 1,100 questionnaires issued.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS official undecided on Tainan trip for court hearing
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/11/09 16:09:54 (By Chou Hui-ying and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The number two man of China's intermediary body for negotiations with Taiwan, who was mobbed and suffered slight injuries during a trip to southern Taiwan last October, is undecided on whether he will visit Tainan City for a court hearing slated for April on the incident.

Zhang Mingqing, vice president of the Beijing-based semi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , said during a telephone interview with CNA recently that he had not made a decision on the matter.

The Tainan District Court announced Monday that a pre-trial hearing on the incident will be held April 8, when Wang Ting-yu, a Tainan City councilor of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, who has been indicted as the person who fomented the attack, along with six other people, will be summoned to appear at the hearing.

The court has also written to Zhang -- who cut short his visit to Taiwan Oct. 21, 2008 after he was humiliated by the Tainan mob -- to ask whether he would be interested in coming back to Tainan City to attend the hearing or in taking part via teleconference, according to Tainan District Court spokesman Chen Hsien- jung.

Meanwhile, Fan Liqing, spokeswoman of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, called on Taiwan at a regular news conference Wednesday to handle the incident impartially so as to help maintain normal exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

Fan said that Zhang has fully expressed his feelings and opinions on the incident during his stay in Taiwan, adding that the violent attack was not only witnessed in person by many of the Tainan public but was also documented by the media.
She skirted questions from reporters as to whether Zhang will go to the hearing.

Zhang fell to the ground while being besieged by a melee of pro-independence protesters in the southern city. He fell as he was being grabbed and jostled by the demonstrators during a visit last Oct. 21 to the city's Confucius Temple.

Zhang arrived in Taiwan Oct. 19 at the head of a 22-member delegation to take part in an academic conference in Tainan in his capacity as dean of the school of journalism at Xiamen University in Fujian Province.

DOC.HEADLINE: President supports sacking of poorly performing civil servants

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou expressed support Wednesday for a proposed civil service reform that is aimed at weeding out government employees who perform poorly.
Ma said such reform is essential to enhancing the competitiveness of civil servants and thus Taiwan's global competitiveness.

"We will make government employees realize that the civil service is not an `iron rice bowl' and that they must keep moving forward, " Ma said while receiving a group of civil servant representatives selected for their excellent performance.
The president urged civil servants to increase their efficiency to help achieve the implementation of government policies and upgrade the government's public image.
He also encouraged them to do as much as they can in the interests of the people and not to be afraid of innovation.

The proposal to reform the performance evaluation system for civil servants was first unveiled Monday by Examination Yuan President John Kuan, who argued that government employees will be like a "pool of stagnant water" unless a mechanism is set up whereby poorly performing ones can be ejected from the service, traditionally seen as a "safe" occupation with very little chance of being fired.

According to officials, a draft plan being reviewed in the Ministry of Civil Service would require any civil servant who gets a "C" rating for two consecutive years to be dismissed or forced to retire.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agriculture council committed to greening Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) is committed to planting trees on 60,000 hectares of flat land across Taiwan in eight years, COA Minister Chen Wu- hsiung announced Wednesday.

Speaking at a news conference to mark an annual "tree-planting month" activity, Chen said the COA is planning to capitalize on its forestation program from 2009 as part of its efforts to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide and create job opportunities.
Under the program, Chen said, the COA will this year invite residents of 400 communities to help plant trees on 5,060 hectares of land and to adopt 56,686 hectares of forest to make Taiwan greener.
Owners of sloping or flat lands who participate in the program will receive a subsidy of NT$120,000 (US$3,529) per hectare in the first year, according to the COA.
People who join the tree plantation program for flat lands will be entitled to NT$210,000 per hectare in subsidies in the first year, it said.

Last year, a total of 459 residential communities participated in the tree- planting activity with the help of COA subsides, completing plantation of 1,558.5 hectares of land and adopting 58,815 hectares of forest.

The COA estimated that if each of Taiwan's 23 million citizens plants at least one tree in his or her lifetime, the forestation program would help create a green space of 10.7 square meters for each person in 10 years' time and generate business revenue worth NT$30 billion in 20 years.

In addition, the Forestry Bureau is planning to build three large ecology recreational parks over 1,000 hectares in southern Taiwan's Chiayi and Pingtung counties as well as in Hualien County in eastern Taiwan over the coming four years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Global recession impact affecting science parks, schools

TEXT.P: More and more victims are emerging from the turmoil of the 2008 global recession that has battered not only three state-run science parks -- Taiwan's major economic pillars -- but also students attending expensive private colleges.

According to statistics released by the National Science Council (NSC) Wednesday, the total turnover generated by the high-tech parks it administers contracted by 6.55 percent to NT$1.84 trillion (US$54 billion) in 2008 compared with the previous year, marking the first drop in business volume since 2001.

The NSC pointed out in a statement that the parks still enjoyed an average growth of 3.62 percent in turnover as of the end of last October, but like a roller coaster ride, the turnover fell suddenly and sharply in the following two months due to a sudden contraction in global economic growth caused by the financial storm.

Among the six major industrial sectors in the science parks -- which are home to most of the country's leading manufacturers -- the integrated circuit industry generated the highest turnover of NT$922 billion in 2008, accounting for 50.06 percent of the total and representing an annual decline of 6.54 percent.

The opto-electronics industry registered NT$752.4 billion in turnover, a slide of 6.74 percent from the previous year, while the computer and peripheral products manufacturing sector reported a turnover of NT$79.1 billion, representing a drop of 17.52 percent.
The communications industry sector recorded turnover of NT$34.8 billion, showing a year-on-year drop of 10.31 percent, according to the NSC statement.

However, the precision machine manufacturing sector reported turnover of NT$40.5 billion, representing growth of 26.96 percent last year, despite the global recession, while the biotechnology industry recorded turnover of NT$7.4 billion, representing yearly growth of 10.31 percent.
According to the NSC, as of last Dec. 31 there were a total of 699 businesses operating in the NSC-run industrial parks in Hsinchu, Taichung and Tainan, 95 of which were foreign companies.
In 2008, the parks attracted 86 new investors, whose investments totalled NT$51.89 billion, while 66 existing tenants increased their investments, the NSC said.

Meanwhile, Chen Chen-kuei, president of the Taichung-based Ling Tung University, said Wednesday that the school began its summer term Feb. 5 but that so far, 20 percent of the students have failed to pay their tuition.

Chen, who also serves as chairman of the Association of Private Universities and Colleges of Technology, revealed that similar cases have occurred in other private schools and noted that the university management has launched measures to help students in financial straits to stay in school.
Chen said many of the 550,000 students studying in the country's 73 private universities and colleges of technology are often socially disadvantaged.

In normal times, there are usually around 10 percent of students unable to afford the expensive tuition fees, and these often receive assistance from the their school, including offering part-time work at the school or allowing them to pay their tuition in installments.
However, he went on, the number of such students has increased this year as a result of the recession.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former deputy mayor to organize new TV station for Next Media

TEXT.P: Former Taipei Deputy Mayor King Pu-tsung has reportedly been invited by the founder of Next Media, the largest listed media company in Hong Kong, to establish a new television station in Taiwan.

Jimmy Lai, founder of Next Media and Giordano, one of Asia's largest clothing retailers, said in a report carried in the latest issue of the Taiwan edition of Next Magazine that King is well-versed in mass media operations and norms and that with his management talent and ability, is set to unveil a new era in Taiwan's TV sector.
Lai noted that there are already many TV stations in Taiwan but said that the best ones would cost a great deal of money to acquire.
"We will acquire two at most and hope that the new channel will become operational by the end of this year or early next year, " Lai was quoted as saying in the report.

Yeh Yi-chien, head of the Taiwan Next Magazine, confirmed Wednesday that Lai, a billionaire entrepreneur ranked 962 on the Forbes billionaires list, has decided to expand his publishing empire into the arena of television, and he confirmed the Lai-King engagement.
Yeh confirmed during an interview with CNA that Lai and Next Magazine have talked with executives of several Taiwanese cable TV stations about the acquisition plan.
"Some have no intention of selling and some are priced too high. If necessary, Next Magazine will establish a new TV station on its own," Yeh said.

King, who served as former Mayor Ma Ying-jeou's deputy from 2004-2007, was one of the top brains in Ma's presidential election campaign, but he had sworn that he would not serve in Ma's administration nor at the Presidential Office after Ma was elected president in March 2008.
Instead, he traveled to Hong Kong in the summer of 2008 to take up a six-month teaching position at a Hong Kong university as a visiting professor.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should never let down guard against China: U.S. scholars

TEXT.P: Two noted American scholars expressed confidence Wednesday in President Ma Ying-jeou's handling of cross-Taiwan Strait affairs, but advised that the Ma administration should never let down its guard against China's intention to reunite with Taiwan.

Christopher C. DeMuth and Arthur C. Brooks, respectively the former and incumbent presidents of the renowned U.S. think tank American Enterprise Institute (AEI) , made the remarks at a media seminar in Taipei that wrapped up their four-day visit to Taiwan.

Noting that it is a "wonderful thing" for Taiwan and China to build closer links through commercial, cultural and people-to-people exchanges, DeMuth urged Taiwan not to "ever to put down your guard because we know how the People's Republic of China (PRC) wants this to end."

He suggested that the Taiwan government take advantage of all opportunities and look for ways to build closer ties with Beijing, but to be also very wary of China's intentions to do things that are harmful and would restrict Taiwan's freedom.
"I think he (Ma) is highly cognizant of the reality of the kind of the government that exists over there, " DeMuth said when asked whether he thinks Ma is aware of the PRC's intentions.
"I think that he has no intention of letting his country fall under the sway of a government such as that, " added the respected scholar who served as AEI president for 22 years.

Asked whether the AEI is concerned about the Ma administration leaning too much toward China by entering into a truce with Beijing to end the long-standing diplomatic tug-of-war between the two sides as some critics and the opposition parties have charged, DeMuth said that the AEI is not concerned about that.
Brooks said that positions are not important, but rather principles are, and that is the basis of successful diplomacy.

He added that the government needs to bear in mind what Taiwan wants, noting that according to Ma, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and everybody else, "peace, prosperity and freedom" are the goals.

"If something helps prosperity, it should be entertained," Brooks said. "Staying free is also important and that's where the balance lies, not losing autonomy just for the sake of trade, but not passing up opportunities for people to become more prosperous."

Asked if Taiwan has anything to worry about with the scheduled visit of the newly appointed U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton to Asia, both scholars said that the U.S. government does not give enough attention to Taiwan and does too little for the country.

Brooks said that Taiwan should always be worried when anybody from the U.S. State Department is talking to the PRC about Taiwan because the State Department is strongly biased toward big powerful important countries and the status quo across the Taiwan Strait.

"Our State Department has given far too little attention to the strategic importance of Taiwan and far too much attention to simply the convenience of the people across the table from them who are from the PRC," he said.
DeMuth said that the U.S. has not done as much as it should have to help Taiwan defend itself against the buildup of military threats from the PRC.
"What should we do to help make sure that Taiwan can defend itself... we have not done nearly as much in terms of providing you with important defensive weaponry," he said.

They both urged that the American government lift the ban on visits by high- level military officials to the U.S. because there is no reason to do the job indirectly and inefficiently, adding that the U.S. should stand up for its principles and help its ally.

DOC.HEADLINE: Control Yuan asks for removal of two prosecutors from probe panel

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan, the country's supreme watchdog body, asked Wednesday for two prosecutors to be removed from the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office.

In a corrective measure passed earlier that day, the Control Yuan said Chu Chao- liang and Wu Wen-chung should be dropped from the division, which is probing the alleged corruption of former President Chen Shui-bian and members of his family.

Control Yuan member Li Ful-dien said the leading reason behind the measure is that both of them had private contacts with Chen when the division's probe into the ex-president was still ongoing, meeting with him during a memorial service for a Buddhist master at a temple in Miaoli July 27 last year.

Furthermore, Lee went on, Chu had seven telephone conversations about the Chen case with a woman who claimed to be a friend of the former head of state, and the woman let Chen talk directly with Chu during at least one of the calls.

Although the Control Yuan is not in a position to disclose the contents of the phone conversations, they were confirmed by Prosecutor-General Chen Tsung-ming in a Feb. 5 interview as having taken place, Lee said.
"The two obviously violated the guidelines for prosecutors' work," he said.

In the same corrective measure, the Control Yuan also asked the Supreme Prosecutors Office -- which is currently operating at half-strength with only eight prosecutors -- to fill the remaining eight vacancies.
The Control Yuan's corrective measure runs counter to an investigation conducted by the Supreme Prosecutors Office last Dec. 12 in which the office said Chu and Wu had broken no laws or regulations.
The Supreme Prosecutors Office said in its investigation that the meeting between the two prosecutors and Chen took place during a social occasion and that the investigation was not mentioned.

Local press had speculated that the meeting was premeditated by Chen, whose aide even took a picture of it and released it afterward in an attempt to discredit Chu and Wu, who are leading members of the investigation against Chen.

The Special Investigation Division has not yet completed its investigation of the ex-president, although it indicted Chen, various members of his family and several former aides on charges of corruption and money laundering Dec. 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA to come up with DRAM industry consolidation package soon

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will come up with a DRAM industry consolidation initiative by the end of February, an official said Wednesday.
The Executive Yuan official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the package in the works will allow the consolidated DRAM industry to stay competitive in the global market.

As the DRAM industry plays a crucial role in Taiwan's semiconductor supply chain, the official said, the government has consistently kept close tabs on the problems faced by local DRAM makers amid the current worldwide economic recession.

In addition to coordinating relevant agencies to assist DRAM makers in acquiring bailout funds, the MOEA has also been working on a plan to help them integrate with their foreign cooperative partners in the long run, the official added.
Noting that the local DRAM industry does not have home-grown key technology, the official said establishing a self-sufficient DRAM industry is the top goal of the government's bailout move.

"The government intends to inject bailout funds into the local DRAM industry under two conditions -- some industry consolidation should occur and makers must show their commitment to home-grown technological development, " the official explained. From the government's standpoint, the rescue project is aimed at sharing benefits between Taiwan's DRAM makers and their international partners, since the former lack self-developed technologies and the latter are in need of new capital sources, the official added.

According to the official, local DRAM makers' foreign partners, including Japan's Elpida, the U.S.-based Micron and South Korea's Hynix, have approached the MOEA on possible collaboration opportunities.
Major domestic DRAM makers, such as Nanya Technology, Inotera Memories, Powerchip, Rexchip, ProMOS and Winbond, have also presented various integration initiatives or proposals, the official said.
On Feb. 6, the official said, the Formosa Plastics Group's Nanya Technology, Inotera Memories and their U.S. partner Micron presented a plan to the MOEA on Taiwan's DRAM industry development.

"The MOEA has begun assessing the feasibility of the project, " the official said, adding that if all goes well, the ministry will unveil a DRAM industry consolidation and development package at the end of this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Business prospects remain grim for 1st half year: SPIL head

TEXT.P: Business prospects in Taiwan will remain gloomy in the first half of the year but are expected to improve after that, Bough Lin, chairman of the Siliconware Precision Industries Co. Ltd. (SPIL), forecast Wednesday.

The Taichung County-based SPIL is one of the world's leading IC packaging and testing service providers, employing 15,000 people. It held a business presentation Wednesday that attracted many mutual fund managers and representatives of financial institutions.

In his address, Lin said he expects the production value of the semiconductor sector to drop by between 15 percent and 30 percent this year, and that the IC packaging industry will see a similar decline of output value due to the global recession.
The general IC packaging sector could expect a drop in production value of between 15 percent and 35 percent in the first quarter of the year, Lin forecast.
The entrepreneur also predicted that computer output will fall by 10 percent this year, and the output of mobile phones will also post a decline of 10 percent in 2009.

The SPIL announced Wednesday that its revenue for the fourth quarter of 2008 was NT$12.449 billion (US$365.6 million) , which represented a 27.8 percent decline from the previous quarter and a 29.8 percent drop year-on-year.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2,992 Chinese tourists visit Taiwan via outlying islands

TEXT.P: A total of 115 Chinese tour groups, composed of 2,992 members, had visited Taiwan for sightseeing via the country's three outlying islands as of the end of last year, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) reported Wednesday.

As part of the Taiwan government's efforts to normalize personnel and commercial exchanges and shipping services across the Taiwan Strait, Chinese people have been allowed to visit Taiwan proper via its outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu since early last September.

Since then, Chinese citizens have also been permitted to make pleasure trips to Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu, another of Taiwan's outlying islands, with the use of landing visas or multiple entry/exit permits.

Thanks to these open-door measures, the MAC said in a statement, the number of Chinese tourists who traveled to Taiwan via direct ferry services -- commonly known as the mini-three links" -- between Taiwan-held Kinmen/Matsu and Xiamen/Mawei in China's southeastern Fujian Province has continued to increase and had hit 2,992 as of the end of 2008.
Meanwhile, the statement said, another 3,330 Chinese citizens made sightseeing trips to Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu with landing visas or multiple entry/exit permits during the same four-month period.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tolerance, conciliation key to overcoming differences: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that the two peaceful transitions of power in Taiwan demonstrated that the Taiwanese people have learned to overcome differences through tolerance and conciliation, which are not only applicable to relations with China but are also important in reconciling different political views within the country.

He made the remarks at a function hosted by the non-governmental Lincoln Society and co-sponsored by the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) and the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) to celebrate the 200th anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln, the 16th president of the United States.

Ma said that in the last decade there were two peaceful transitions of powers in Taiwan, which showed that people in Taiwan have, to some degree, come to understand the need to learn how to co-exist through tolerance and conciliation.
"This principle of tolerance and conciliation is applicable not only to cross- strait relations but also to internal political party relations in Taiwan today," Ma said.
He said that conflicts and disagreements may be inevitable but playing on them is not the way to establish a national identity.

Since Ma assumed office May 20, 2008, he has take a number of steps to improve relations with China -- an approach criticized by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party and pro-independent groups as sacrificing Taiwan's sovereignty and national interests.
Describing Lincoln as a "giant in the history of democracy, " Ma paid homage to late U.S. president's political legacy of government of the people, by the people and for the people.
"I believe this is the true meaning of power in a democratic system," the president said.

Noting that Lincolns philosophy was an inspiration to Dr. Sun Yat-sen in setting out the principles on which the Republic of China (ROC) was founded, Ma said that newly established democracies like the Republic of China on Taiwan can learn a truly valuable lesson from the United States.
"America's experience in building a democratic state tells us one thing -- we must seek consensus in the spirit of tolerance and conciliation," he said.
The Lincoln Society is a non-political organization founded in Taipei in 1984 by a group of retired ROC ambassadors and U.S. expatriates to foster the democratic and humanitarian ideals of Lincoln.

DOC.HEADLINE: Matsu worshipers to sail from Chiayi to Meizhou in Fujian

TEXT.P: A group of over 400 worshipers of Matsu -- known as the Chinese Goddess of Sea or Empress of Heaven to believers around the world -- will sail directly from Budai Port in southern Taiwan's Chiayi County to Meizhou Island in China's Fujian Province Thursday.

The pilgrimage, organized by the Tienhou Temple in Chiayi City, dedicated to Matsu, will take the visitors to the Tienhou Temple in Meizhou Island, which is the ancestral temple for the large number of Matsu followers across the globe, including those in Taiwan.

A big ceremony to offer sacrifices to the sea was slated to be held at Budai Port at 9: 00 p.m. Thursday, before the worshipers set sail. The ship from Budai will sail into Meizhou Port in a traditional ritual on a trip of about six and a half hours.
It will be the first religious pilgrimage between Budai Port and the Chinese side since direct cross-Taiwan Strait air and shipping links were opened in December last year.

Wang Kuang-li, a manager of Chiayi's Tienhou Temple, said the direct voyage will help save a lot of travel time compared to the past when most Taiwanese worshipers had to sail via one of Taiwan's offshore islands, Kinmen, to China on what is known as "the mink links." A trip between Taiwan and Fujian Province's Meizhou via the mini links takes at least one day, Wang noted.
At the same time, some 200 other Matsu worshipers will board a flight from Kaohsiung International Airport to Fujian's Xiamen airport en route to Meizhou.
The two groups of over 600 Matsu believers from 26 temples across Taiwan will meet in Meizhou and then proceed to the Tienhou Temple in Quangzhou in Fujian Province to worship Matsu through Feb. 18.

Meizhou is the native land where Matsu, whose given name was Lin Mo-liang, was born over 1,000 years ago. After her death, the people began to pray to her as they would to a deity. Matsu gradually became one of the most important folk deities for people living in China's coastal regions and Taiwan. It is estimated that half of Taiwan's 23 million people are worshipers of the Chinese Goddess of the Sea, and it is believed that her prayers guide ships safely though the Taiwan Strait.
According to unofficial estimates, Taiwanese make more than 100,000 visits to Meizhou's Tienhou Temple every year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Oversupply of cabbages to be curbed to stabilize prices

TEXT.P: The government has set a target of turning the crops of cabbage and Chinese cabbage crops on 110 hectares of farmland around Taiwan into green fertilizer in a bid to prevent overproduction, agriculture officials disclosed Wednesday.

The officials at the Agriculture and Food Agency under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture said the measure is necessary to curb an imminent oversupply of cabbage and Chinese cabbage -- two of the most widely grown leafy vegetable crops in Taiwan -- in order to stabilize their prices.
Farmers who are willing to join the program are entitled to a subsidy of NT$70,000 (US$2,056) per hectare in compensation for their losses, according to the officials.
The program will continue until Feb. 13, with the aim of shredding 80 hectares of cabbage and 30 hectares of Chinese cabbage and convert the crops into organic fertilizer.
The program is intended to protect the interests of the farmers by preventing a glut of the produce that could cause a market collapse, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese tourist arrivals forecast to grow 4% to 5%

TEXT.P: Despite the current global economic downturn, the number of Japanese tourist arrivals is expected to increase by 4 percent to 5 percent this year, Tourism Bureau Director General Janice Lai said Wednesday.
According to Lai, the steep appreciation of the Japanese yen has made it cheaper to travel to Taiwan on pleasure trips.
Moreover, she said, the fuel oil surcharge has fallen from a high of 20,000 yen (US$222.10) last year to the current 8,000 yen and may further drop to 3,000 yen in March.
All these advantages, coupled with geographic proximity and the Taiwanese people's hospitality, will help to attract more Japanese tourists to Taiwan, Lai explained.

Japan has been Taiwan's most important tourism source. Affected by skyrocketing fuel oil surcharges last year and a global financial tsunami, the number of Japanese tourist arrivals fell to 1.08 million in 2008, marking a 6.8 percent year-on-year decline.
Lai made the remarks after signing an agreement with Nippon Travel Agency, the fourth largest Japanese travel agency, on attracting more Japanese people to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan in 2009.
Under the agreement, Lai said, the Japanese travel agency promises to send 40,000 holidaymakers to Taiwan this year, up 33 percent from the 30,000 figure recorded in 2008.

Lai said the Tourism Bureau plans to sign similar pacts with four other top Japanese travel agencies to organize more Japanese tour groups to Taiwan. If the Japanese signatories reach their service targets, the Tourism Bureau will offer advertising and manpower training subsidies in line with the contract terms.

On Wednesday, Japan's JTB travel agency sent a 1,300-member tour group to Taipei. All of the visitors are diamond-class managing members of the noted Japanese direct sale cosmetic brand Pola and are known for their luxury purchasing power.

All the Pola tour group members will attend a citation ceremony at the Taipei International Convention Center Thursday where they will be honored for their outstanding sales records over the past year. Starting Saturday, they will split up into smaller groups and tour duty-free shops and visit major tourist attractions in suburban Taipei, including the National Palace Museum, Danshui and Wulai.
Given their deep pockets, the group is expected to bring an estimated NT$50 million-worth of business opportunities to local luxury good stores and tourism- related services, Lai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tycoon involved in Rebar Group embezzlement case released on bail

TEXT.P: Former Eastern Multimedia Group Chairman Gary Wang who has been found guilty of collaborating with his father to embezzle funds from the family's publicly listed Rebar Asia Pacific Group, was released on NT$350 million (US$10.29 million) bail Wednesday.
Wang was taken back into custody Jan. 21, three weeks after he was found guilty by the Taipei District Court of collaborating with his father to siphon off funds from the Rebar group.

On Feb.9, the Taiwan High Court revoked the lower court decision and demanded that it return a new ruling, pointing out that the lower court had not summoned a former lawmaker, who was key figure in the matter, to testify.

In response, a collegial panel of judges at the district court decided to release Wang on bail Wednesday after the former legislator, Tsai Hau, testified before the court that he had no intention of helping Wang flee Taiwan from Penghu, as was rumored.
Nevertheless, Wang is barred from changing his residence or leaving Taiwan. He is also required to report to a police station every evening and to the district court every Wednesday.

Wang was first taken into custody by prosecutors in June 2007 following the exposure of the Rebar Group's financial woes and was released in May 2008 on NT$350 million (US$10.45 million) bail, the highest in Taiwan's judicial history.
On Dec. 31, 2008, the district court sentenced Wang to 18 years in jail and fined him NT$700 million. He has appealed his case in the Taiwan High Court, which has not yet begun hearing the matter.
Six of Gary Wang's siblings were also found guilty of collaborating with their father -- Rebar Group founder Wang You-theng -- to loot funds from various of the conglomerate's subsidiaries.
Wang You-theng has remained on the run since he fled overseas in December 2006, soon after the Rebar Group applied for bankruptcy protection.
Aside from Wang and his siblings, another 116 individuals were convicted of various offenses in the court's mammoth 4,000-page verdict.

The major irregularities identified by the court included the hollowing out of Chia Hsin Food & Synthetic Fiber Co., Great Chinese Bills Finance Corp. and Asia Pacific Broadband Telecom Co. (APBT) ; illegal lending by The Chinese Bank and Union Insurance Co.; and a fake transaction to siphon off funds between the Eastern Multimedia Group and APBT.
The total amount of funds siphoned off from the group was estimated at more than NT$42.78 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Feb. 12, 2009

TEXT.P: 2. Event: Chou Po-ya, an opposition DPP Taipei city councilor, registering his candidacy for the Daan district legilsative by-election. Date and Time: 09:30 a.m., Thursday, Feb.12, 2009. Place: Taipei City Election Commission, 9F, No.15, Xinyi Road, Sec.5, Taipei City. Press Contact: Tel.2723-3372. 3. Event: Chiang Nai-hsin, a ruling KMT Taipei city councilor, registering his candidacy for the Daan district legislative by-election. Date and Time: 10:00 a.m., Thursday, Feb.12, 2009. Place: Taipei City Election Commission. Press Contact: Tel.2723-3372.
Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Global recession impact affecting science parks, schools

TEXT.P: More and more victims are emerging from the turmoil of the 2008 global recession that has battered not only three state-run science parks -- Taiwan's major economic pillars -- but also students attending expensive private colleges.

According to statistics released by the National Science Council (NSC) Wednesday, the total turnover generated by the high-tech parks it administers contracted by 6.55 percent to NT$1.84 trillion (US$54 billion) in 2008 compared with the previous year, marking the first drop in business volume since 2001.

The NSC pointed out in a statement that the parks still enjoyed an average growth of 3.62 percent in turnover as of the end of last October, but like a roller coaster ride, the turnover fell suddenly and sharply in the following two months due to a sudden contraction in global economic growth caused by the financial storm.

Among the six major industrial sectors in the science parks -- which are home to most of the country's leading manufacturers -- the integrated circuit industry generated the highest turnover of NT$922 billion in 2008, accounting for 50.06 percent of the total and representing an annual decline of 6.54 percent.

The opto-electronics industry registered NT$752.4 billion in turnover, a slide of 6.74 percent from the previous year, while the computer and peripheral products manufacturing sector reported a turnover of NT$79.1 billion, representing a drop of 17.52 percent.
The communications industry sector recorded turnover of NT$34.8 billion, showing a year-on-year drop of 10.31 percent, according to the NSC statement.

However, the precision machine manufacturing sector reported turnover of NT$40.5 billion, representing growth of 26.96 percent last year, despite the global recession, while the biotechnology industry recorded turnover of NT$7.4 billion, representing yearly growth of 10.31 percent.
According to the NSC, as of last Dec. 31 there were a total of 699 businesses operating in the NSC-run industrial parks in Hsinchu, Taichung and Tainan, 95 of which were foreign companies.
In 2008, the parks attracted 86 new investors, whose investments totalled NT$51.89 billion, while 66 existing tenants increased their investments, the NSC said.

Meanwhile, Chen Chen-kuei, president of the Taichung-based Ling Tung University, said Wednesday that the school began its summer term Feb. 5 but that so far, 20 percent of the students have failed to pay their tuition.

Chen, who also serves as chairman of the Association of Private Universities and Colleges of Technology, revealed that similar cases have occurred in other private schools and noted that the university management has launched measures to help students in financial straits to stay in school.
Chen said many of the 550,000 students studying in the country's 73 private universities and colleges of technology are often socially disadvantaged.

In normal times, there are usually around 10 percent of students unable to afford the expensive tuition fees, and these often receive assistance from the their school, including offering part-time work at the school or allowing them to pay their tuition in installments.
However, he went on, the number of such students has increased this year as a result of the recession.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former deputy mayor to organize new TV station for Next Media

TEXT.P: Former Taipei Deputy Mayor King Pu-tsung has reportedly been invited by the founder of Next Media, the largest listed media company in Hong Kong, to establish a new television station in Taiwan.

Jimmy Lai, founder of Next Media and Giordano, one of Asia's largest clothing retailers, said in a report carried in the latest issue of the Taiwan edition of Next Magazine that King is well-versed in mass media operations and norms and that with his management talent and ability, is set to unveil a new era in Taiwan's TV sector.
Lai noted that there are already many TV stations in Taiwan but said that the best ones would cost a great deal of money to acquire.
"We will acquire two at most and hope that the new channel will become operational by the end of this year or early next year, " Lai was quoted as saying in the report.

Yeh Yi-chien, head of the Taiwan Next Magazine, confirmed Wednesday that Lai, a billionaire entrepreneur ranked 962 on the Forbes billionaires list, has decided to expand his publishing empire into the arena of television, and he confirmed the Lai-King engagement.
Yeh confirmed during an interview with CNA that Lai and Next Magazine have talked with executives of several Taiwanese cable TV stations about the acquisition plan.
"Some have no intention of selling and some are priced too high. If necessary, Next Magazine will establish a new TV station on its own," Yeh said.

King, who served as former Mayor Ma Ying-jeou's deputy from 2004-2007, was one of the top brains in Ma's presidential election campaign, but he had sworn that he would not serve in Ma's administration nor at the Presidential Office after Ma was elected president in March 2008.
Instead, he traveled to Hong Kong in the summer of 2008 to take up a six-month teaching position at a Hong Kong university as a visiting professor.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should never let down guard against China: U.S. scholars

TEXT.P: Two noted American scholars expressed confidence Wednesday in President Ma Ying-jeou's handling of cross-Taiwan Strait affairs, but advised that the Ma administration should never let down its guard against China's intention to reunite with Taiwan.

Christopher C. DeMuth and Arthur C. Brooks, respectively the former and incumbent presidents of the renowned U.S. think tank American Enterprise Institute (AEI) , made the remarks at a media seminar in Taipei that wrapped up their four-day visit to Taiwan.

Noting that it is a "wonderful thing" for Taiwan and China to build closer links through commercial, cultural and people-to-people exchanges, DeMuth urged Taiwan not to "ever to put down your guard because we know how the People's Republic of China (PRC) wants this to end."

He suggested that the Taiwan government take advantage of all opportunities and look for ways to build closer ties with Beijing, but to be also very wary of China's intentions to do things that are harmful and would restrict Taiwan's freedom.
"I think he (Ma) is highly cognizant of the reality of the kind of the government that exists over there, " DeMuth said when asked whether he thinks Ma is aware of the PRC's intentions.
"I think that he has no intention of letting his country fall under the sway of a government such as that, " added the respected scholar who served as AEI president for 22 years.

Asked whether the AEI is concerned about the Ma administration leaning too much toward China by entering into a truce with Beijing to end the long-standing diplomatic tug-of-war between the two sides as some critics and the opposition parties have charged, DeMuth said that the AEI is not concerned about that.
Brooks said that positions are not important, but rather principles are, and that is the basis of successful diplomacy.

He added that the government needs to bear in mind what Taiwan wants, noting that according to Ma, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and everybody else, "peace, prosperity and freedom" are the goals.

"If something helps prosperity, it should be entertained," Brooks said. "Staying free is also important and that's where the balance lies, not losing autonomy just for the sake of trade, but not passing up opportunities for people to become more prosperous."

Asked if Taiwan has anything to worry about with the scheduled visit of the newly appointed U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton to Asia, both scholars said that the U.S. government does not give enough attention to Taiwan and does too little for the country.

Brooks said that Taiwan should always be worried when anybody from the U.S. State Department is talking to the PRC about Taiwan because the State Department is strongly biased toward big powerful important countries and the status quo across the Taiwan Strait.

"Our State Department has given far too little attention to the strategic importance of Taiwan and far too much attention to simply the convenience of the people across the table from them who are from the PRC," he said.
DeMuth said that the U.S. has not done as much as it should have to help Taiwan defend itself against the buildup of military threats from the PRC.
"What should we do to help make sure that Taiwan can defend itself... we have not done nearly as much in terms of providing you with important defensive weaponry," he said.

They both urged that the American government lift the ban on visits by high- level military officials to the U.S. because there is no reason to do the job indirectly and inefficiently, adding that the U.S. should stand up for its principles and help its ally.

DOC.HEADLINE: Control Yuan asks for removal of two prosecutors from probe panel

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan, the country's supreme watchdog body, asked Wednesday for two prosecutors to be removed from the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office.

In a corrective measure passed earlier that day, the Control Yuan said Chu Chao- liang and Wu Wen-chung should be dropped from the division, which is probing the alleged corruption of former President Chen Shui-bian and members of his family.

Control Yuan member Li Ful-dien said the leading reason behind the measure is that both of them had private contacts with Chen when the division's probe into the ex-president was still ongoing, meeting with him during a memorial service for a Buddhist master at a temple in Miaoli July 27 last year.

Furthermore, Lee went on, Chu had seven telephone conversations about the Chen case with a woman who claimed to be a friend of the former head of state, and the woman let Chen talk directly with Chu during at least one of the calls.

Although the Control Yuan is not in a position to disclose the contents of the phone conversations, they were confirmed by Prosecutor-General Chen Tsung-ming in a Feb. 5 interview as having taken place, Lee said.
"The two obviously violated the guidelines for prosecutors' work," he said.

In the same corrective measure, the Control Yuan also asked the Supreme Prosecutors Office -- which is currently operating at half-strength with only eight prosecutors -- to fill the remaining eight vacancies.
The Control Yuan's corrective measure runs counter to an investigation conducted by the Supreme Prosecutors Office last Dec. 12 in which the office said Chu and Wu had broken no laws or regulations.
The Supreme Prosecutors Office said in its investigation that the meeting between the two prosecutors and Chen took place during a social occasion and that the investigation was not mentioned.

Local press had speculated that the meeting was premeditated by Chen, whose aide even took a picture of it and released it afterward in an attempt to discredit Chu and Wu, who are leading members of the investigation against Chen.

The Special Investigation Division has not yet completed its investigation of the ex-president, although it indicted Chen, various members of his family and several former aides on charges of corruption and money laundering Dec. 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA to come up with DRAM industry consolidation package soon

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will come up with a DRAM industry consolidation initiative by the end of February, an official said Wednesday.
The Executive Yuan official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the package in the works will allow the consolidated DRAM industry to stay competitive in the global market.

As the DRAM industry plays a crucial role in Taiwan's semiconductor supply chain, the official said, the government has consistently kept close tabs on the problems faced by local DRAM makers amid the current worldwide economic recession.

In addition to coordinating relevant agencies to assist DRAM makers in acquiring bailout funds, the MOEA has also been working on a plan to help them integrate with their foreign cooperative partners in the long run, the official added.
Noting that the local DRAM industry does not have home-grown key technology, the official said establishing a self-sufficient DRAM industry is the top goal of the government's bailout move.

"The government intends to inject bailout funds into the local DRAM industry under two conditions -- some industry consolidation should occur and makers must show their commitment to home-grown technological development, " the official explained. From the government's standpoint, the rescue project is aimed at sharing benefits between Taiwan's DRAM makers and their international partners, since the former lack self-developed technologies and the latter are in need of new capital sources, the official added.

According to the official, local DRAM makers' foreign partners, including Japan's Elpida, the U.S.-based Micron and South Korea's Hynix, have approached the MOEA on possible collaboration opportunities.
Major domestic DRAM makers, such as Nanya Technology, Inotera Memories, Powerchip, Rexchip, ProMOS and Winbond, have also presented various integration initiatives or proposals, the official said.
On Feb. 6, the official said, the Formosa Plastics Group's Nanya Technology, Inotera Memories and their U.S. partner Micron presented a plan to the MOEA on Taiwan's DRAM industry development.

"The MOEA has begun assessing the feasibility of the project, " the official said, adding that if all goes well, the ministry will unveil a DRAM industry consolidation and development package at the end of this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Business prospects remain grim for 1st half year: SPIL head

TEXT.P: Business prospects in Taiwan will remain gloomy in the first half of the year but are expected to improve after that, Bough Lin, chairman of the Siliconware Precision Industries Co. Ltd. (SPIL), forecast Wednesday.

The Taichung County-based SPIL is one of the world's leading IC packaging and testing service providers, employing 15,000 people. It held a business presentation Wednesday that attracted many mutual fund managers and representatives of financial institutions.

In his address, Lin said he expects the production value of the semiconductor sector to drop by between 15 percent and 30 percent this year, and that the IC packaging industry will see a similar decline of output value due to the global recession.
The general IC packaging sector could expect a drop in production value of between 15 percent and 35 percent in the first quarter of the year, Lin forecast.
The entrepreneur also predicted that computer output will fall by 10 percent this year, and the output of mobile phones will also post a decline of 10 percent in 2009.

The SPIL announced Wednesday that its revenue for the fourth quarter of 2008 was NT$12.449 billion (US$365.6 million) , which represented a 27.8 percent decline from the previous quarter and a 29.8 percent drop year-on-year.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2,992 Chinese tourists visit Taiwan via outlying islands

TEXT.P: A total of 115 Chinese tour groups, composed of 2,992 members, had visited Taiwan for sightseeing via the country's three outlying islands as of the end of last year, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) reported Wednesday.

As part of the Taiwan government's efforts to normalize personnel and commercial exchanges and shipping services across the Taiwan Strait, Chinese people have been allowed to visit Taiwan proper via its outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu since early last September.

Since then, Chinese citizens have also been permitted to make pleasure trips to Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu, another of Taiwan's outlying islands, with the use of landing visas or multiple entry/exit permits.

Thanks to these open-door measures, the MAC said in a statement, the number of Chinese tourists who traveled to Taiwan via direct ferry services -- commonly known as the mini-three links" -- between Taiwan-held Kinmen/Matsu and Xiamen/Mawei in China's southeastern Fujian Province has continued to increase and had hit 2,992 as of the end of 2008.
Meanwhile, the statement said, another 3,330 Chinese citizens made sightseeing trips to Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu with landing visas or multiple entry/exit permits during the same four-month period.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tolerance, conciliation key to overcoming differences: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that the two peaceful transitions of power in Taiwan demonstrated that the Taiwanese people have learned to overcome differences through tolerance and conciliation, which are not only applicable to relations with China but are also important in reconciling different political views within the country.

He made the remarks at a function hosted by the non-governmental Lincoln Society and co-sponsored by the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) and the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) to celebrate the 200th anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln, the 16th president of the United States.

Ma said that in the last decade there were two peaceful transitions of powers in Taiwan, which showed that people in Taiwan have, to some degree, come to understand the need to learn how to co-exist through tolerance and conciliation.
"This principle of tolerance and conciliation is applicable not only to cross- strait relations but also to internal political party relations in Taiwan today," Ma said.
He said that conflicts and disagreements may be inevitable but playing on them is not the way to establish a national identity.

Since Ma assumed office May 20, 2008, he has take a number of steps to improve relations with China -- an approach criticized by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party and pro-independent groups as sacrificing Taiwan's sovereignty and national interests.
Describing Lincoln as a "giant in the history of democracy, " Ma paid homage to late U.S. president's political legacy of government of the people, by the people and for the people.
"I believe this is the true meaning of power in a democratic system," the president said.

Noting that Lincolns philosophy was an inspiration to Dr. Sun Yat-sen in setting out the principles on which the Republic of China (ROC) was founded, Ma said that newly established democracies like the Republic of China on Taiwan can learn a truly valuable lesson from the United States.
"America's experience in building a democratic state tells us one thing -- we must seek consensus in the spirit of tolerance and conciliation," he said.
The Lincoln Society is a non-political organization founded in Taipei in 1984 by a group of retired ROC ambassadors and U.S. expatriates to foster the democratic and humanitarian ideals of Lincoln.

DOC.HEADLINE: Matsu worshipers to sail from Chiayi to Meizhou in Fujian

TEXT.P: A group of over 400 worshipers of Matsu -- known as the Chinese Goddess of Sea or Empress of Heaven to believers around the world -- will sail directly from Budai Port in southern Taiwan's Chiayi County to Meizhou Island in China's Fujian Province Thursday.

The pilgrimage, organized by the Tienhou Temple in Chiayi City, dedicated to Matsu, will take the visitors to the Tienhou Temple in Meizhou Island, which is the ancestral temple for the large number of Matsu followers across the globe, including those in Taiwan.

A big ceremony to offer sacrifices to the sea was slated to be held at Budai Port at 9: 00 p.m. Thursday, before the worshipers set sail. The ship from Budai will sail into Meizhou Port in a traditional ritual on a trip of about six and a half hours.
It will be the first religious pilgrimage between Budai Port and the Chinese side since direct cross-Taiwan Strait air and shipping links were opened in December last year.

Wang Kuang-li, a manager of Chiayi's Tienhou Temple, said the direct voyage will help save a lot of travel time compared to the past when most Taiwanese worshipers had to sail via one of Taiwan's offshore islands, Kinmen, to China on what is known as "the mink links." A trip between Taiwan and Fujian Province's Meizhou via the mini links takes at least one day, Wang noted.
At the same time, some 200 other Matsu worshipers will board a flight from Kaohsiung International Airport to Fujian's Xiamen airport en route to Meizhou.
The two groups of over 600 Matsu believers from 26 temples across Taiwan will meet in Meizhou and then proceed to the Tienhou Temple in Quangzhou in Fujian Province to worship Matsu through Feb. 18.

Meizhou is the native land where Matsu, whose given name was Lin Mo-liang, was born over 1,000 years ago. After her death, the people began to pray to her as they would to a deity. Matsu gradually became one of the most important folk deities for people living in China's coastal regions and Taiwan. It is estimated that half of Taiwan's 23 million people are worshipers of the Chinese Goddess of the Sea, and it is believed that her prayers guide ships safely though the Taiwan Strait.
According to unofficial estimates, Taiwanese make more than 100,000 visits to Meizhou's Tienhou Temple every year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Oversupply of cabbages to be curbed to stabilize prices

TEXT.P: The government has set a target of turning the crops of cabbage and Chinese cabbage crops on 110 hectares of farmland around Taiwan into green fertilizer in a bid to prevent overproduction, agriculture officials disclosed Wednesday.

The officials at the Agriculture and Food Agency under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture said the measure is necessary to curb an imminent oversupply of cabbage and Chinese cabbage -- two of the most widely grown leafy vegetable crops in Taiwan -- in order to stabilize their prices.
Farmers who are willing to join the program are entitled to a subsidy of NT$70,000 (US$2,056) per hectare in compensation for their losses, according to the officials.
The program will continue until Feb. 13, with the aim of shredding 80 hectares of cabbage and 30 hectares of Chinese cabbage and convert the crops into organic fertilizer.
The program is intended to protect the interests of the farmers by preventing a glut of the produce that could cause a market collapse, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese tourist arrivals forecast to grow 4% to 5%

TEXT.P: Despite the current global economic downturn, the number of Japanese tourist arrivals is expected to increase by 4 percent to 5 percent this year, Tourism Bureau Director General Janice Lai said Wednesday.
According to Lai, the steep appreciation of the Japanese yen has made it cheaper to travel to Taiwan on pleasure trips.
Moreover, she said, the fuel oil surcharge has fallen from a high of 20,000 yen (US$222.10) last year to the current 8,000 yen and may further drop to 3,000 yen in March.
All these advantages, coupled with geographic proximity and the Taiwanese people's hospitality, will help to attract more Japanese tourists to Taiwan, Lai explained.

Japan has been Taiwan's most important tourism source. Affected by skyrocketing fuel oil surcharges last year and a global financial tsunami, the number of Japanese tourist arrivals fell to 1.08 million in 2008, marking a 6.8 percent year-on-year decline.
Lai made the remarks after signing an agreement with Nippon Travel Agency, the fourth largest Japanese travel agency, on attracting more Japanese people to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan in 2009.
Under the agreement, Lai said, the Japanese travel agency promises to send 40,000 holidaymakers to Taiwan this year, up 33 percent from the 30,000 figure recorded in 2008.

Lai said the Tourism Bureau plans to sign similar pacts with four other top Japanese travel agencies to organize more Japanese tour groups to Taiwan. If the Japanese signatories reach their service targets, the Tourism Bureau will offer advertising and manpower training subsidies in line with the contract terms.

On Wednesday, Japan's JTB travel agency sent a 1,300-member tour group to Taipei. All of the visitors are diamond-class managing members of the noted Japanese direct sale cosmetic brand Pola and are known for their luxury purchasing power.

All the Pola tour group members will attend a citation ceremony at the Taipei International Convention Center Thursday where they will be honored for their outstanding sales records over the past year. Starting Saturday, they will split up into smaller groups and tour duty-free shops and visit major tourist attractions in suburban Taipei, including the National Palace Museum, Danshui and Wulai.
Given their deep pockets, the group is expected to bring an estimated NT$50 million-worth of business opportunities to local luxury good stores and tourism- related services, Lai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tycoon involved in Rebar Group embezzlement case released on bail

TEXT.P: Former Eastern Multimedia Group Chairman Gary Wang who has been found guilty of collaborating with his father to embezzle funds from the family's publicly listed Rebar Asia Pacific Group, was released on NT$350 million (US$10.29 million) bail Wednesday.
Wang was taken back into custody Jan. 21, three weeks after he was found guilty by the Taipei District Court of collaborating with his father to siphon off funds from the Rebar group.

On Feb.9, the Taiwan High Court revoked the lower court decision and demanded that it return a new ruling, pointing out that the lower court had not summoned a former lawmaker, who was key figure in the matter, to testify.

In response, a collegial panel of judges at the district court decided to release Wang on bail Wednesday after the former legislator, Tsai Hau, testified before the court that he had no intention of helping Wang flee Taiwan from Penghu, as was rumored.
Nevertheless, Wang is barred from changing his residence or leaving Taiwan. He is also required to report to a police station every evening and to the district court every Wednesday.

Wang was first taken into custody by prosecutors in June 2007 following the exposure of the Rebar Group's financial woes and was released in May 2008 on NT$350 million (US$10.45 million) bail, the highest in Taiwan's judicial history.
On Dec. 31, 2008, the district court sentenced Wang to 18 years in jail and fined him NT$700 million. He has appealed his case in the Taiwan High Court, which has not yet begun hearing the matter.
Six of Gary Wang's siblings were also found guilty of collaborating with their father -- Rebar Group founder Wang You-theng -- to loot funds from various of the conglomerate's subsidiaries.
Wang You-theng has remained on the run since he fled overseas in December 2006, soon after the Rebar Group applied for bankruptcy protection.
Aside from Wang and his siblings, another 116 individuals were convicted of various offenses in the court's mammoth 4,000-page verdict.

The major irregularities identified by the court included the hollowing out of Chia Hsin Food & Synthetic Fiber Co., Great Chinese Bills Finance Corp. and Asia Pacific Broadband Telecom Co. (APBT) ; illegal lending by The Chinese Bank and Union Insurance Co.; and a fake transaction to siphon off funds between the Eastern Multimedia Group and APBT.
The total amount of funds siphoned off from the group was estimated at more than NT$42.78 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open little changed

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened little changed Thursday, moving up 5.35 points at 4,581.30 on a turnover of NT$2.08 billion (US$61.18 million).
The weighted price index gained 49.85 points, or 1.1 percent, to close at 4,575.95 Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 12, or the 18th day of the first month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1809: Abraham Lincoln, the U.S. president who was assassinated a few days after the end of the American Civil War, is born.
1851: Fortune hunters rush to the town of Bathurst in the Blue Mountains of New South Wales, Australia, in search of gold.
1895: Japan scores an impressive victory at Weihaiwei in northern China when Japanese forces quickly breach Chinese defenses and sink most of its northern navy in the war between the Ching court and Japan which broke out in 1894.
1899: Germany purchases the Marianas Islands, the Caroline Islands, and Palau from Spain.
1908: The first global Grand Prix is inaugurated at Times Square in New York.
1912: Henry Pu Yi abdicates as emperor of China, ending the rule of the Manchu dynasty.
1941: A group of researchers led by Howard Florey of Australia and Ernst Chain of Germany develop a method of extracting and purifying small amounts of penicillin, which was first used by physicians to treat a human a day later when the drug was given to a British policeman suffering from blood poisoning.
1960: The Council of Grand Justices of the Judicial Yuan announces that the total membership of the Republic of China National Assembly, under the period of national emergency, shall be 1,576.
1964: Japanese Premier Shigeru Yoshida arrives in the ROC to confer with President Chiang Kai-shek.
1970: Express trains collide north of Hsinchu, in northern Taiwan, killing 10 and injuring 47.
1974: Chang Kwang-shih, ROC vice minister of economic affairs, returns from Saudi Arabia, where he signed a memorandum of economic coorperation.
1974: Soviet Nobel Prize winner Alexander Solzhenitsyn is arrested in Moscow and exiled the following day.
1974: Raimundo Guerrero, chairman of the World Anti-Communist League, arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1975: The people of South Korea vote to adopt a new constitution that gives the president almost unlimited power and permits him to serve an unlimited number of terms.
1976: Six hundred members of the ROC's National Federation of Industries Association, National Federation of Businesses Association, and the Industrial and Business Association meet and pledge to support government economic policy.
1976: The first Sino-Japanese exhibition of modern painting opens, with more than 52 works by contemporary Japanese artists on display.
1980: Hong Kong's subway is formally inaugurated.
1987: The U.S. Air Force successfully launches "Titan 3B" missiles into orbit above the North and South Poles.
1992: Mongolia's new non-communist constitution takes effect.
1996: Yasser Arafat becomes the first president of Palestine.
1996: Faced with threatening military maneuvers undertaken by Beijing, the ROC Executive Yuan sets up a temporary policymaking task force to closely follow developments and coordinate the actions of various agencies to respond to the situation.
1997: Hwang Jang Yop, a confidant of North Korean leader Kim Jong Il, defects in Beijing and seeks asylum in South Korea.
1999: The U.S. Senate votes against removing President Bill Clinton from office in the Monica Lewinsky scandal.
2000: Taiwan doctor Chen Chiu-huang wins the 2000 award of the Foundation de Enterprise Montblanc de la Culture of Britain.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Extravagance leads to excess; thrift to meanness; but it is better to be mean than to be guilty of excess."
