TEXT.P: Despite the current global economic downturn, the number of Japanese tourist arrivals is expected to increase by 4 percent to 5 percent this year, Tourism Bureau Director General Janice Lai said Wednesday.
According to Lai, the steep appreciation of the Japanese yen has made it cheaper to travel to Taiwan on pleasure trips.
Moreover, she said, the fuel oil surcharge has fallen from a high of 20,000 yen (US$222.10) last year to the current 8,000 yen and may further drop to 3,000 yen in March.
All these advantages, coupled with geographic proximity and the Taiwanese people's hospitality, will help to attract more Japanese tourists to Taiwan, Lai explained.

Japan has been Taiwan's most important tourism source. Affected by skyrocketing fuel oil surcharges last year and a global financial tsunami, the number of Japanese tourist arrivals fell to 1.08 million in 2008, marking a 6.8 percent year-on-year decline.
Lai made the remarks after signing an agreement with Nippon Travel Agency, the fourth largest Japanese travel agency, on attracting more Japanese people to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan in 2009.
Under the agreement, Lai said, the Japanese travel agency promises to send 40,000 holidaymakers to Taiwan this year, up 33 percent from the 30,000 figure recorded in 2008.

Lai said the Tourism Bureau plans to sign similar pacts with four other top Japanese travel agencies to organize more Japanese tour groups to Taiwan. If the Japanese signatories reach their service targets, the Tourism Bureau will offer advertising and manpower training subsidies in line with the contract terms.

On Wednesday, Japan's JTB travel agency sent a 1,300-member tour group to Taipei. All of the visitors are diamond-class managing members of the noted Japanese direct sale cosmetic brand Pola and are known for their luxury purchasing power.

All the Pola tour group members will attend a citation ceremony at the Taipei International Convention Center Thursday where they will be honored for their outstanding sales records over the past year. Starting Saturday, they will split up into smaller groups and tour duty-free shops and visit major tourist attractions in suburban Taipei, including the National Palace Museum, Danshui and Wulai.
Given their deep pockets, the group is expected to bring an estimated NT$50 million-worth of business opportunities to local luxury good stores and tourism- related services, Lai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Oversupply of cabbages to be curbed to stabilize prices

TEXT.P: The government has set a target of turning the crops of cabbage and Chinese cabbage crops on 110 hectares of farmland around Taiwan into green fertilizer in a bid to prevent overproduction, agriculture officials disclosed Wednesday.

The officials at the Agriculture and Food Agency under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture said the measure is necessary to curb an imminent oversupply of cabbage and Chinese cabbage -- two of the most widely grown leafy vegetable crops in Taiwan -- in order to stabilize their prices.
Farmers who are willing to join the program are entitled to a subsidy of NT$70,000 (US$2,056) per hectare in compensation for their losses, according to the officials.
The program will continue until Feb. 13, with the aim of shredding 80 hectares of cabbage and 30 hectares of Chinese cabbage and convert the crops into organic fertilizer.
The program is intended to protect the interests of the farmers by preventing a glut of the produce that could cause a market collapse, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's legislative speaker calls for closer ties with EU
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/12/09 14:41:08 (By P.C. Tang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng called for closer ties between his country and the European Union Wednesday during his first visit to the European Parliament headquarters in the Belgian capital of Brussels.
In particular, Wang suggested that the European Parliament help push for Taiwan citizens to have visa-free access to EU countries to further bilateral cooperation and exchanges.

Belgium is the final leg of Wang's current European trip that has taken him to Italy and the Vatican. Wang last visited the European Parliament seven years ago at its official seat in Strasbourg, France.

During this latest visit, Wang was invited to deliver a speech on Taiwan's relations with the European Union and with China, at a luncheon hosted by the European Parliament-Taiwan Friendship Group in the parliament building.

Wang told his audience that since the inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou last May, the new government has adopted a flexible and pragmatic approach toward foreign and cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

Such an approach has effectively improved the originally tense relations between Taiwan and China over the past eight months, with the two sides having signed six important agreements, including those on the launch of direct cross-strait air and shipping links, to pave the way for expanded exchanges and cooperation, Wang noted.
Wang stressed that through continued dialogue with China under the new administration led by President Ma, Taiwan has emerged as a contributor to world peace, rather than a troublemaker.
The EU integration experience, in which countries respect each other and pursue common goals, sets a good example for the two governments across the Taiwan Strait, he said.

As far as Taiwan's foreign relations are concerned, Wang said participating in international organizations such as the World Health Organization remains one of the government's priorities, and he expressed gratitude to the European Parliament for adopting an amendment last week in support of Taiwan's observer status in global groups such as the International Labor Organization.

Meanwhile, pointing out that Taiwan and the European Union maintain close trade ties and share a common desire for world peace and stability, Wang urged the European Union to offer substantive support for Taiwan by assisting the country in broadening its international participation.
He also expressed the hope that the two sides could enhance their exchanges and cooperation in the areas of energy development, global warming and ecological conservation.

To further promote trade, cultural exchanges, investment and tourism, Wang urged, the European Parliament should support visa waivers for Taiwanese citizens, who make approximately 260,000 trips to Europe each year.

At the end of the speech, Georg Jarzembowski, head of the European Parliament- Taiwan Friendship Group, presented an award to Wang, who is also chairman of Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, in recognition of his contribution to promoting Taiwan's democracy and human rights.
In return, Wang conferred a medal on Jarzembowski to honor his contribution to promoting parliamentary diplomacy with Taiwan.
A similar medal was later presented on a separate occasion to Graham Watson, leader of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe, who is known for his long-term support for Taiwan.
Watson has announced his bid to run for the presidency of the European Parliament, which will be re-elected in June.

Meanwhile, during a separate meeting with incumbent European Parliament President Hans-Gert Pottering, Wang again expressed his appreciation to the lawmaking body for its support of Taiwan's bid to participate in international organizations.
Also, he repeated his proposal that the European Parliament help promote visa waiver treatment for Taiwanese citizens.
Wang is scheduled to return to Taiwan Friday after wrapping up his European visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Temple painting a fading art as artists' links with gods severed

TEXT.P: On a recent sunny winter morning, Huang Yo-chien, one of the few remaining traditional temple painters in Taiwan, was filled with nostalgia as he began painting door gods on the main entrance to the Dongjia Beijhih Temple in Taiwan's outlying archipelago Penghu.
It was at this centuries-old temple that the 77-year-old painter of temple wall and door decorations began his career 60 years ago, as an apprentice to his artisan father.

The temple in the Dongjia district of Magong, Penghu County's capital, was undergoing a major renovation at the time, and his father, Huang Wen-hua, was in charge of the temple's decorations, including paintings and carvings.

Six decades later, Huang is doing the same work as his father -- painting door gods on the temple's main entrance and refreshing the colors of its paintings -- but there are few left to carry on this highly respected traditional art form that painters like Huang have seen as a way of respecting local gods.

Driven by pressures to earn more money and complete jobs quickly, fewer young people are entering the profession, even if the 11,651 temples in Taiwan are still places of central importance in Taiwanese society.
The art of temple painting was once learned through patience and years of practice, said Chiang Shao-ying, a professor at Taipei National University of the Arts.

But the current business environment deters the meticulous learning of the craft, as temple paintings and decorations have become just another component in bids for complete temple construction projects.

With project budgets cut to the bone, contractors often allocate only a tiny share of the overall budget for the paintings, leaving artisans unwilling to do the painstaking work of their predecessors, Chiang lamented.

Temple painters were once relatively well paid compared to other professions, but nowadays, they may earn only NT$200,000 (US$5,935) to NT$300,000 for each project, which normally takes weeks or even months to complete.
The lower budgets have also spurred changes in temple decoration techniques that have discouraged the cultivation of temple artists.

Over the past decade, nearly all newly-built temples in Taiwan have been adorned with bas reliefs, with door gods cut into the surface of their wooden gates by machines rather than being painted, shortening construction time and saving touch-up costs.
As the nature of the business and the work has changed, so has the attitude of the painters.

While once truly devoted to their profession and seeing themselves as fulfilling a commitment to the gods, today they are mere contractors without any spiritual or emotional attachment to the job they have been hired to do.

That attachment compelled masters of the trade like Huang and his father to take an uncompromising approach to their work, but Huang also credits his father's open-mindedness for his artistic development.
"He allowed his apprentices to develop innovative painting skills and foster their own styles, " Huang remembered.

His father, he said, accepted his experimentation with Western oil painting and incorporating oil painting techniques into temple painting, innovative techniques that enabled him to stand out and start a new trend in the field.

Now considered one of the most renowned door god painters in Penghu and Taiwan, Huang's works can be seen throughout Taiwan -- including at Sanfu Wangye Temple in Keelung's Hepingdao and Yitien Templ in Taipei County's Sanchung -- but his main body of work is in Penghu, which boasts Taiwan's highest temple density.
At least 70 percent of Penghu's roughly 200 temples are decorated with Huang's character paintings.
The most difficult part of temple painting lies with painting the door gods, whose role is to protect the temple and its worshippers from evil spirits, and their facial expressions.
"If your master dares to allow you to paint a door god's face, it means that your professional skills have reached a level of maturity and that your apprenticeship may come to an end," Huang said.

Wang Wen-liang, a fine arts teacher at Magong Senior High School who is versed in Penghu's temple art development, said Huang is a master at capturing door gods' facial expressions, the eyes in particular.

"The details of his craftsmanship and the vividness of the expressions of the characters in his works demonstrate Huang's extraordinary artistry, " Wang said. "Each character painted by him usually has a unique and interesting facial expression."

Huang himself is most satisfied with his work at Chenghuang Temple in Magong. The gestures of the pair of door gods on the temple's front gate are filled with power and their facial expressions and postures express strong heroism.

Huang regrets that the temple painting profession is fading fast in Penghu and even in Taiwan, especially as there is nobody to follow in his footsteps and Dongjia Beijhih Temple will be forced to contract artisans from Taiwan proper for door and wall painting work in the future.
Huang says age has caught up with him, and the Dongjia Beijhih Temple door gods will be his last work.
"I'll retire when it is completed, " said Huang, who estimates he has painted more than 150 temples over his six-decade-long career.
It is a fitting final assignment for Huang, as his career started and will end at one of Taiwan's oldest temples that bears witness to the long history and development of the art form.
A temple official said Huang was a natural choice for the job.

"The door gods on the main gate were painted by Huang Yo-chien's father when the temple underwent a major facelift 60 years ago. His son's redoing the temple symbolizes a continuation of the temple's history," the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet approves special budget for public works projects

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan in its weekly meeting Thursday approved a special four-year budget of NT$500 billion (US$14.7 billion) for a public work expansion program as part of its stimulus package to pull the economy out of its current slump.

Premier Liu Chao-shiuan urged all government agencies to do their best to push through the package, which contains 20 prime investment projects and 64 plans to serve six major goals. Liu also asked them step up communication with legislators to seek support for quick passage of the bill.

The six main goals are to upgrade the transportation network, build a safe and anti-disaster environment, enhance cultural and living standards, strengthen national competitiveness and infrastructure, improve transport facilities on the outlying islands, and foster high-end talent and stabilize the job market, said Chen Tain-jy, minister of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, at the meeting.

Of the NT$500 billion total, NT$150.6 billion will be earmarked in 2009 for the creation 190,000 to 220,000 job opportunities and to help Taiwan's gross domestic product grow by 0.97 percentage points this year, Chen said. It is projected that a total of NT$160.6 billion will be allocated in 2010, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Export woes drive NT dollar to 4-year low

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar fell past the 34 mark against the U.S. dollar to a four- year low of 34.001 Wednesday as Taiwan's central bank tried to maintain a weaker currency and low domestic interest rates to prop up the sluggish economy.
The NT dollar, which depreciated 1.27 percent against the greenback last year, has further dropped some 3.4 percent over the past 25 trading days, on concern that exports may slump further.
The central bank bought U.S. dollars over the past few sessions in an effort to help exporters tide over an exports slump brought about by the global economic recession.

Taiwan's exports totaled US$12.37 billion in January, a sharp drop of 44.1 percent from the same month last year, while imports fell even more steeply, by 56.5 percent, to US$8.97 billion. The figure translated into a monthly trade surplus of US$3.4 billion, according to Ministry of Finance statistics.

Expressing support for the central bank's financial policy, Kevin Hsiao, a financial analyst at UBS AG's Taipei branch, also suggested that the bank should allow a gradual rather than steep depreciation of the local currency in order to reduce any possible side-effects.

Following the high volume of U.S. dollar selling and buying by both local exporters and foreign banks at an exchange rate of about NT$34 during the trading session Wednesday, The NT dollar is not expected to drastically depreciate in the near future, but rather it will rise to NT$32.4 gradually, a foreign exchange dealer forecast.

However, Yang Chia-yen, a research fellow at the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER), said that local currency devaluation may not necessarily boost exports, but rather would increase the cost of imports.
Yang attributed Taiwan's export slump to weaker demand triggered by the global economic recession, particularly serious shrinkage of the main export markets in the United States and China.

Sagging exports would cause difficulties for many businesses, while unemployment could increase because many industries would have to contend with fewer orders, which would lead to layoffs, sliding consumer confidence and a contraction in domestic demand, Yang said.

As for interest rates, Taiwan's central bank has six times lowered its key interest rate by 2.125 percentage points since September 2008. The benchmark discount rate, the rate the central bank charges banks for loans, now stands at 1.5 percent.

There is still room for further interest rate cuts, Kevin Hsiao said, adding that Singapore and Hong Kong posted negative gross domestic product (GDP) growth of 3.7 percent and 3.4 percent, respectively, in the fourth quarter of last year. Taiwan's GDP might post an even larger decline over the same period, given its lackluster export performance and a negative growth of 32 percent in terms of industrial production for last December, he added.
He predicted the benchmark discount rate will be slashed to 1 percent.

Despite the sagging global economy, there is still encouraging news on the market, Hsiao said. For example, the U.S. Institute for Supply (ISM) Production Index registered a higher than expected 32.1 percent in January, and the Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) of China's manufacturing sector has risen for two consecutive months. Therefore, he forecast that Taiwan's export performance would probably not deteriorate.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices drop on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices plunged Thursday, with the Taiwan stock exchange's weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 109.53 points, or 2.39 percent, to close at 4,466.42.
The local bourse opened at 4,581.3 and fluctuated between 4,594.75 and 4,466.42. A total of 3.96 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$79.96 billion (US$2.35 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile shares shedding the most at 3.8 percent, followed by foodstuff stocks at 2.9 percent, machinery and electronics stocks at 2.7 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks at 2.4 percent, cement shares at 2.3 percent, construction shares at 2.2 percent, banking and financial stocks at 2.1 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,254 to 362, with 167 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$3.94 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Museum exchanges to be based on dignity, equality: spokesman

TEXT.P: Any exchanges between Taiwan's National Palace Museum (NPM) and China's Palace Museum in Beijing will be based on dignity and equality, Executive Yuan spokesman Su Jun-pin said Thursday.
Exchanges between the museums should also be launched on the premise that Taiwan's rights and interests will not be compromised, Su said.
The planning involves not just exchanges between the two major museums across the Taiwan Strait, but also some legal issues, Su said.

The two executive agencies -- the NPM and the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) -- will therefore further discuss the matter, particularly the issue of the NPM's designation if it holds exhibitions in China, he added.
Su was referring to a recent rumor that Beijing would ask the NPM to change its official name to "Taipei Palace Museum (TPM) " for the purpose of joining exhibitions organized in China.
"The Taiwan public can be assured that the NPM and MAC authorities will work out a plan that will not compromise Taiwan's rights and dignity," Su reiterated.

An NPM delegation, to be headed by the museum's director Chou Kung-shin, is scheduled to depart for Beijing Saturday on a three-day visit, during which the NPM and its Beijing counterpart will discuss the possibility of cooperating on exhibition arrangements, publicity campaigns and publications, as well as academic and staff exchanges.
The visit will mark the first official contact between the two national museums in 60 years.

The NPM decided recently to put politics aside and discuss joint exhibitions with Beijing's Palace Museum. For starters, Chou plans to discuss with the Beijing museum the possibility of borrowing some artifacts to add to a special exhibition of the NPM's own collection on Emperor Yung-cheng -- the fourth ruler of the Ching Dynasty -- slated to open in Taiwan in October.

Chou has said that any Beijing exhibits brought to Taiwan will be guaranteed safe return under Taiwan's 1992 Statute on Encouraging and Rewarding Cultural and Art Enterprises, which stipulates that foreign art and cultural objects are exempt from seizure or any legal entanglement over ownership.
She added, however, that before any of Taiwan's treasures can be displayed in China, a similar statute would have to be put in place by Beijing to guarantee the same protection.
Representatives of the Beijing museum will pay a return visit in early March, according to Chou.
The NPM -- one of the world's most famous museums -- has the world's largest collection of Chinese historical artifacts totaling 650,000 pieces.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't to encourage drug addicts to seek rehabilitation

TEXT.P: The government will promote a new concept under which drug addicts will be treated as patients, rather than criminals, in an effort to encourage them to kick the habit, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Thursday.
Also, Liu said, the government will further integrate existing efforts to prevent substance abuse and will strengthen the training of relevant personnel to enhance the efficiency of these efforts.
The premier issued the directives at a weekly Cabinet meeting, during which the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) delivered a report on a rehabilitation program for drug addicts.
Under the program, drug addicts who take the initiative to seek rehabilitation treatment will be exempt from punishment or will be given deferred prosecution.
The MOJ is scheduled to launch the 24-hour toll-free service hotline 0800-700885 on March 1 to provide help to drug addicts.
Drug addicts will also be able to obtain assistance by visiting the Web site http://refrain.moj.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices mostly lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Thursday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for February falling 108 points to close at 4,445, with 112,010 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for March lost 114 points to finish at 4,391, with 3,057 contracts traded, while June futures drop 100 points to end at 4,343, with 31 contracts traded.
September futures fell 109 points to close at 4,1320, with 37 contract transactions, while December futures lost 109 points to finish at 4,080, with 39 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 4,553 for February, 4,505 for March, 4,443 for June, 4,241 for September and 4,189 for December.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 109.53 points to finish at 4,466.42, on turnover of NT$79.96 billion (US$2.35 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.
February TE futures fell 5.15 points to close at 178.6, with 5,498 contracts traded, while March TE futures lost 5.5 points to finish at 176.35, with 374 contracts traded.
September TE futures dropped 3.7 points to close at 163.55, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June and December.
February TF futures were down 10 points to close at 502.2, with 5,030 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures decreased 8.4 points to finish at 499, with 308 contracts traded.
June TF futures rose 7.4 points to close at 505, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for the other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, increasing NT$0.024 to close at NT$34.025.
A total of US$517 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.031 and fluctuated between NT$33.930 and NT$34.031.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2009 Taipei Game Show kicks off, targets shopping voucher spending

TEXT.P: The Taipei Computer Association (TCA) launched the 2009 Taipei Game Show at the Taipei World Trade Center Thursday, with the aim of exploiting the business opportunities associated with the government's consumption stimulation plan.

Along with the game show, a special 3C section has been created to boost sales of computers, consumer electronics and home appliances by encouraging spending of the govenrment-issued shopping vouchers, organizers said, adding that the event is especially designed to attract those who claim their coupons after the Lunar New Year holiday.

Addressing the opening of the exhibition, Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming described the TCA's idea as ingenious, and noted that more than 2 million people have already claimed their shopping vouchers since the end of the New Year holiday.
"And some NT$7.2 billion (US$212 million) worth of vouchers are yet to be claimed by the public," said Yiin.

Expressing strong support for the government's NT$85.7 billion shopping voucher program, TCA Chairman J. T. Wang said that the timing of the voucher distribution was perfect, as most people are likely to purchase new computers and game-related products during or after the Chinese New Year.
"If I am asked to grade the results of the government's voucher program, I would give it an A plus," said Wang.

Meanwhile, Wang urged game lovers and the public to take advantage of this year's game show and 3C exhibition, as participating companies are offering discounts of up to 50 percent on game related products.
Wang said that participating companies have also designed a variety of attractive deals for consumers who purchase 3C or game products with their shopping vouchers.
According to Wang, with more than 400 booths set up by 40 local and foreign companies, the five-day event is expected to attract over 300,000 visitors.
The exhibition, jointly sponsored by the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the TCA, will run through Feb. 16.
More than 90 percent of local citizens claimed their shopping vouchers before the Lunar New Year holiday and the second stage of distribution of the coupons began Feb.7.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police nab smugglers of illegal pesticides

TEXT.P: The Taichung County Police Station announced Thursday that it has detained nine suspects for smuggling and selling banned or restricted pesticides from China to local pesticide distributors and stores.
The Taichung County police made the announcement after a 49-year-old suspect, identified as Kao, and eight other persons were arrested in raids earlier in the day.

In a joint crackdown, eight prosecutors, over 200 law enforcement agents and Council of Agriculture (COA) officials searched 29 locations, including Kao's house and offices. They also raided several sites in Taichung, Yunlin, Chiayi, Taitung and Pintung in central and southern Taiwan where it was suspected that the smuggling ring was manufacturing, storing and selling the products.
The nine suspects were charged with smuggling illegal pesticides or raw materials from China by boat to Taiwan's outlying Kinmen Island before transferring them to Taiwan proper, since 2007.
They were also accused of manufacturing illegal pesticides in five townships in Taichung County in central Taiwan and selling them to pesticide stores across the country at unfairly low prices.
Police also seized large quantities of pesticides and toxic materials banned or restricted by the COA, such as fentin acetate, cyromazine, acetamiprid and bismerthiazol.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan hopes to join ASEAN labor ministers meetings

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou proposed Thursday that Taiwan be invited to take part in the labor ministers meetings of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) so as to allow the country to contribute to the resolution of regional labor issues.

Ma raised the issue while receiving Peter Favila, trade and industry secretary of the Philippines, who is in Taiwan to attend the 16th ministerial-level economic cooperation meeting between the two countries.
More than 360,000 foreign laborers are currently employed to work in Taiwan, with those from Southeast Asia forming the largest group, including some 75,000 from the Philippines.
Ma told Favila that Taiwan expects to engage in closer cooperation with the Philippines and to participate in the development of the ASEAN free trade area.

He said that Taiwan began discussions with the Philippines issues concerning the prevention of double taxation in 2002, and expressed the hope that a related agreement could be signed as soon as possible.

Noting that Taiwan is the seventh largest foreign investor in the Philippines, the president urged the Filipino government to provide wider preferential treatment for Taiwanese investors to encourage them to expand their operations in the Philippines.

Meanwhile, Ma said Taiwan has been very successful in promoting the establishment of digital opportunity centers in developing nations, under an Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum initiative to bridge the digital divide, and he offered to further work with the Philippines in this regard to help enhance its information technology capabilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA to focus more on overseas opportunities for local enterprises

TEXT.P: With President Ma Ying-jeou calling for Taiwan's diplomacy to prioritize economic issues, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that it will step up its efforts to help local enterprises explore business opportunities abroad.

Speaking at a press briefing, Shih Wen-bin, director-general of MOFA's Department of Economic and Trade Affairs, said that the ministry will strengthen the use of existing trade mechanisms in the hope of boosting the country's export volume in the face of the global economic slowdown.

The ministry will, for instance, subsidize local firms participating in business exhibitions in emerging markets and countries that have diplomatic relations with Taiwan, he said. The MOFA will also work to match domestic companies to foreign buyers at trade fairs held in promising markets such as Saudi Arabia, he added.

Meanwhile, Shih said the government will help local businesses, especially those in globally competitive industries, obtain a share of the enormous World Trade Organization's Government Procurement Agreement (GPA) market, which has an approximate value of US$390 billion a year.

In addition, the official encouraged Taiwan companies to explore business prospects linked to the government's bilateral and multilateral cooperation schemes with foreign countries or organizations such as the Asia Development Bank, with which Taiwan has investment and technical cooperation programs.

Other initiatives planned by the ministry include building stronger economic and trade relations with countries with which Taiwan has Free Trade Agreements and providing funding for local businesses to invest in countries that are Taiwan's diplomatic allies, Shih said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese pop queen crosses over to fashion design

TEXT.P: Taiwanese pop queen Jolin Tsai recently launched a line of street and club wear in New York, in cooperation with the noted L.A.M.B. Clothing, under the label of "Seventy Two Changes."

Tsai, one of the most popular Mandarin-language singers in Asia, traveled to New York recently for the launch of the new collection, which is named after one of her best-selling albums released in 2003, "See My 72 Changes -- Magic."

At a cocktail held in SOHO to launch the brand, Tsai, an English major graduate of Fu Jen Catholic University, discussed in fluent English with the media her ideas and inspiration for the new collection.
The event attracted journalists and cameramen from more than 30 media outlets and fashion magazines in New York.
Tsai said she has been taken with fashion and design since her childhood. She said that as she was too short to be a model, she tried to become a designer. "Now my dream has come true," she said.
Tsai added that any performing artists who might be interested in any of the approximately 100 items modeled at the launch of the brand may contact her and she would offer them outfits for free.

At the launch, the Seventy Two Changes clothing was modeled in four categories -- T-shirt dresses, tuxedo jackets and vests, lightweight wool plaid tops, leather leggings, and motorcycle and bomber jackets.
The brand is scheduled to hit the market in July in seven cities across the world, including New York, Shanghai and Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: Latest technology to be applied in cooperation programs: MOFA

TEXT.P: The latest information technology will be put to use in Taiwans international cooperation and aid programs, starting in Central America, in a bid to streamline the implementation of such programs, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.

Along with Taiwan's economic and technological development over the past few decades, the direction of its foreign aid programs has also shifted to more heavily utilize the country's strength in technology, said Shih Wen-bin, director-general of MOFA's Department of Economic and Trade Affairs.

Through the use of space and remote sensing as well as the Geographic Information System (GIS), he said, Taiwan will be better equipped to carry out environment-related projects, such as outdoor surveillance, post-disaster work and humanitarian relief in countries that are its diplomatic allies.
Taiwan will employ these technologies in a pilot project with Nicaragua -- one of its Central American allies -- to help strengthen environmental sustainability there, Shih added.
As the information will be directly gathered and analyzed by Taiwan's satellite, there will no need to send hardware or additional personnel to the allied country, according to the official.
The GIS has been utilized widely in areas such as urban planning, traffic management, biological conservation and even archeological research, Shih added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opposition legislator urges government to protect cypress forests

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Tien Chiu-chin urged President Ma Ying-jeou's administration Thursday to protect the country's remaining cypress forests by establishing another national park.

Speaking at a press conference at the Legislative Yuan, Tien urged the government to stop illegal cypress logging in the Chilan mountain area of northern Taiwan by establishing a Chilan cypress national park.

"The illegal cypress logging is getting worse year by year in the Chilan mountain area, but the government has done nothing about the situation, " said Tien, adding that local loggers have felled a great number of valuable 1,000 -year-old Chinese cypresses due to a lack of environmental protection in the area.

According to Tien, the government planned to establish a Chilan -- or Magaw in the aboriginal Atayal language -- national park some six years ago, but the plan was delayed indefinitely due to objections and obstructions by indigenous tribespeople for whom the area is their traditional homeland and who would be kicked off the land according to existing laws that prohibit aborigines from living in national parks.

Under the plan, the park would cover more than 53,000 acres, straddling Taipei, Yilan, Taoyuan, and Hsinchu counties. The area is home to more than 30,500 Atayal people and is famous for its primeval forests made up primarily of red and yellow cypress.
By delaying the plan indefinitely, the government has sent a message to illegal loggers that they are free to cut down as many cypress trees as they wish, Tien argued.

The establishment of a national park in the area "would be beneficial for the indigenous tribes, " according to Tien, who added that the government would grant at least NT$2 billion for the development and environmental protection of the area within five years of the park's establishment.

"The park would be able to attract at least 2 million visitors a year, " Tien speculated, adding that it would represent a significant source of income and opportunities for employment for the indigenous tribes who rely on farming as their sole source of income.
To ensure the livelihoods of local tribes, the government would have to devise schemes to foster tourism on the periphery of the park, Tien admitted.

According to Tien, the aborigines could become tour guides and investigators, and could also learn how to produce and market local specialities as well as providing lodging, food and transport to visitors.

Although the government prohibits indigenous tribes from inhabiting national parks -- causing fury among many aboriginal tribes -- those ideals have changed as time has progressed, Tien said, adding that the government must find a way to protect the environment without depriving the aboriginal tribes of their lifestyles and homes.

According to Tien, under Taiwan's National Park Law, an evaluation hearing must be conducted after five years of the establishment of a national park, in which parties can petition for the exclusion of some pre-designated pieces of land to be excluded from the park.

"If the aboriginal people are still dissatisfied with the results of the park after five years, they can petition for the exclusion of their land from the park, " said Tien, adding that if the aborigines "continue to oppose to the protection of the environment and the precious forests in the area, " they might soon lose everything to illegal loggers.

Three of Taiwan's six national parks have long been a point of contention between the government and aborigines. Indigenous tribes such as the Bunun and Atayal bemoan the fact that their ancestral lands are being violated and that they are deprived of their rights to ritual activities such as hunting.

DOC.HEADLINE: Currency devaluation bad solution to financial woes: CEPD

TEXT.P: Allowing competitive currency depreciation is not a good strategy for fighting the financial recession because local businesses' difficulties come mainly from fewer orders caused by weaker demand, the county's top economic planner said Thursday.

Chen Tain-jy made the comments after a regular Cabinet meeting in response to a call by Winston Wang, chairman of the Grace T.H.W. Group, and other business tycoons, for Taiwan's central bank to allow the new Taiwan dollar to fall to 40 against the U.S. dollar.

Expressing opposition to adopting a weaker currency policy to help boost exports, Chen said it would have a great impact in many other aspects, such as increasing the cost of imports and damping interest in investment.

Chen said that although the expansion of a host of public construction programs under a four-year NT$500 billion economic stimulus package is expected to contribute 0.97 percent of the total gross domestic product (GDP) this year, media reports have recently expressed far more optimistic views than expected about Taiwan's economic outlook.

This is probably because exports posted a significant drop in the fourth quarter of last year as the global economic slump deepened, and they therefore predicted that exports will continue to fall, Chen said.

Discounting the media speculation, Chen noted that despite the global economic recession, the drop in consumer spending in the U.S. and European economies still stands at less than 2 percent at present.

Chen described a sharp slump of 41.9 percent in Taiwan's exports in December and a 44.1 percent drop in January as short term phenomena because in this time of global economic uncertainty, many foreign buyers are not willing to place long term orders.
However, he predicted that export orders will resume to normal volumes in about three to four months.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA announces new envoys

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Thursday the appointment of several new ambassadors to Taiwan's diplomatic allies in the South Pacific, as well as representatives to two European countries.

Benjamin T.H. Ho, now deputy head of Taiwan's representative office in Singapore, will become Republic of China ambassador to Kiribati, while Jason C.H. Wan, currently serving in Canada, will be reassigned to lead the ROC embassy in the Pacific island nation of Nauru, according to the ministry.
T.S. Cheng and Abraham W.S. Chu, who attended a swearing-in ceremony earlier in the day, will head Taiwan's representative offices in Finland and Sweden, respectively, the MOFA added.

Foreign Minister Francisco H. L. Ou expressed hope at the ceremony that following President Ma Ying-jeou's call to prioritize economic issues in diplomacy, the two new delegates to the Scandinavian countries will help Taiwanese companies seek business opportunities there.

Finland and Sweden are considered among Taiwan's most important trading partners in Europe, holding the 36th and 38th positions, respectively, in the global ranking in terms of trade volume with Taiwan in 2008, according to the ministry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Matsu worshipers embark on pilgrimage to China

TEXT.P: Over 400 Taiwanese worshipers escorted the Matsu statue at the Tienhou Temple in southern Taiwan's Chiayi City to Budai Port in neighboring Chiayi County Thursday at the start of a pilgrimage to Meizhou Island in China's Fujian Province.

A long string of fireworks was set off in a token of honor to Matsu -- the Chinese goddess of the sea -- when worshipers carrying the Matsu statute in a sedan chair on their shoulders began the walk out of the temple in a traditional ritual presided over by Chiayi Mayor Huang Hui-min.
Huang expressed hope that the pilgrimage -- the largest-ever for Chiayi City -- will help advance exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

The more than 400 Taiwanese worshipers will travel directly from Budai to Meizhou by ferry -- marking the first such voyage between Chiayi and the Chinese side since direct cross-Taiwan Strait air and shipping links were opened in December last year.
Tienhou Temple on Meizhou is the ancestral temple for the large number of Matsu followers around the globe, including those in Taiwan.

A big ceremony to offer sacrifices to the sea was slated to be held at Budai later Thursday before the followers set sail. The direct trip from Budai to Meizhou will cut the travel time to about six and a half hours.

Wang Kuang-li, a Tienhou Temple manager, pointed out that previously, most Taiwanese worshipers had to sail to China via the island of Kinmen, using the "mini links, " a trip that takes at least one day.
At the same time, some 200 other Matsu worshipers were scheduled to board a flight from Kaohsiung International Airport to Fujian's Xiamen airport en route to Meizhou.

The two groups of over 600 Matsu believers from 26 temples around Taiwan will converge in Meizhou and then proceed to the Tienhou Temple in Quangzhou, Fujian Province, to worship Matsu through Feb. 18.
Matsu is one of the most important folk deities for people living in China's coastal regions and in Taiwan. It is estimated that half of Taiwan's 23 million people are Matsu believers.
According to unofficial estimates, Taiwanese make more than 100,000 visits to Meizhou's Tienhou Temple every year.

Meizhou is the native land where Matsu, whose given name was Lin Mo-liang, was born over 1,000 years ago. After her death, the people began to pray to her as they would to a deity. Matsu gradually became one of the most important folk deities for people living in China's coastal regions and Taiwan. It is believed that Matsu guides ships safely though the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: CCA pushes for law allowing tax deductions for cultural expenses

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) is pushing for legislation that would stipulate tax deductions for cultural expenses, the head of the council said Thursday.

CCA Minister Huang Pi-tuan said that under the terms of a draft bill governing the development of cultural and creative affairs, each taxpayer will be entitled to enjoy a tax deduction up to NT$12,000 per year for his or her expenses spent on cultural activities, including tickets to concerts, operas, other performance arts and public exhibitions at museums.
Expenses for books and movies are not included in the draft bill, Huang said, but she added that there is room for discussion on their inclusion.
Huang said the draft bill will be submitted to the Executive Yuan for approval before it is referred to the Legislative Yuan for legislation.

If the draft bill -- devised to encourage culture-loving people and develop a larger literati -- is passed into law by the Legislative Yuan this year, taxpayers could enjoy the tax deductions next May at the earliest, Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT to push Taiwanese food exports to China

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese trade promotion delegation to be headed by the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) is scheduled to depart for China Feb. 15 to push local foods and related products, the BOFT said Thursday.

The delegation, comprised of around 60 executives from 40 food-processing companies, is scheduled to visit the central Chinese cities of Nanjing and Wuhan Feb. 16-21, where it will promote Taiwanese food products via news conferences, talks with importers, meetings with local government officials in charge of food imports, and promotions at supermarket chainstores in the two cities.

The campaign will be the first program launched by the BOFT in a three-year, NT$8.53 billion (US$250.94 million) project called the New Zheng He Project, which is aimed at turning Taiwan's export trade from negative to positive growth this year.
Four other food-promotion delegations are planning to visit southern, eastern, western and northeastern China later this year, according to the BOFT.

Under the New Zheng He Project -- named after a Ming Dynasty Chinese explorer -- the administration will assist Taiwanese suppliers and manufacturers to produce more goods for export, with the country's entire export trade hopefully topping NT$500 billion in 2009, thus turning around the poor performance in the export sector due to the global economic recession.

The ambitious export-bolstering project will also direct Taiwanese exporters and manufacturers to emerging markets beyond China, including India, Russia, Brazil, the Middle East and countries in Southeast Asia.

Zheng He was an official who lived during the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644) . He led a giant fleet of Chinese vessels to Southeast Asia, from where they are believed to have reached as far as the west coast of Africa. He was instrumental in building China into one of the maritime superpowers between the 14th and 17th centuries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Placido Domingo to perform in Miaoli next month

TEXT.P: The Miaoli county government announced Thursday that world renowned tenor Placido Domingo has accepted an invitation to perform in the northern county next month.

County officials said with the success of a performance by Jose Carreras in the county late last year, they decided to invite another tenor in the same league to perform in the county's international music festival scheduled for March 19-21.

The officials said that to cater to all age groups, they will also invite Brian Mcknight, winner of the favorite male R&B Soul Artist in the American Music Awards, as well as Maksim, a popular pianist from Croatia.
The officials said that to upgrade the cultural level and stimulate consumption, they will sell tickets for the three performances this time around, although prices had yet to be decided.
The organizer of the Carreras performance last November gave out 40,000 free tickets, but more than 50,000 people showed up on performance night, contributing a great deal to the county's revenues.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier calls for action plans for long-term care

TEXT.P: With Taiwan's population aging rapidly, the government needs to craft a comprehensive long-term care system and improve services to those in need of help caring for disabled seniors, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Thursday.
Speaking at a weekly Cabinet meeting, Liu said he was sad to learn that four tragic cases involving exhausted family members killing their disabled parents have been reported so far this year.

On Wednesday, a 45-year-old woman surrendered herself to the police after suffocating her 71-year-old mother-in-law who reportedly had been bed-ridden and had needed assisted living for some considerable time.
"These cases indicate that long-term home care is a service urgently needed in our society and the government cannot afford to turn a blind eye to the issue," Liu said.
Noting that people aged 65 or older now make up more than 10 percent of the country's population, Liu said the ratio will soon exceed 15 percent.
"We must face up to the problems and take immediate action to deal with them if we are to maintain social stability," he added.

As a first step, the premier went on, relevant government agencies should work in concert to draw up a well-rounded plan for the establishment of a viable long-term care service system as soon as possible.

According to statistics complied by the Taiwan Association of Family Caregivers, there are about 30,000 people who need long-term care or assisted living staying in various nursing homes around Taiwan, with another 160,000 relying on family care provided by foreign caregivers and more than 400,000 others relying on care provided by their families.
A senior executive of the association said the government should offer more and better stress relieving services for those involved in family care of disabled elderly people.
According to the executive, an average of 30 to 40 cases of long-term caregivers killing the people in their care are reported in Taiwan every year.
Of the four cases reported this year, the perpetrators in the three other cases committed suicide after killing their loved ones, the executive said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sociology professor to join Cabinet

TEXT.P: Hsueh Cheng-tai, a former director of the Taipei city government's Bureau of Social Affairs, will serve as a minister-without-portfolio tasked with helping to craft a better social welfare service system, the Executive Yuan announced Thursday.
Hsueh, who is now a professor at National Taiwan University's Department of Sociology, will be the first person from the outlying Taiwan-controlled island of Kinmen to be recruited into the Cabinet.

Hsueh, who has a Ph.D. in sociology from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, will have the job of designing better social welfare service systems and action programs, the Executive Yuan said in a press statement.
His appointment will take effect next Monday, the statement added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Feb. 13, 2009

TEXT.P: 2. Event: Opposition DPP Deputy Secretary-General Chen Chi-mai paying a visit to Presidential Office Secretary-General Chan Chun-po. Date and Time: 02:30 p.m., Friday, Feb.13, 2009. Place: Presidential Office, No.122, Chongqing S. Road, Sec.1, Taipei City. Press Contact: Tel.2311-3731.
Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, increasing NT$0.024 to close at NT$34.025.
A total of US$517 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.031 and fluctuated between NT$33.930 and NT$34.031.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2009 Taipei Game Show kicks off, targets shopping voucher spending

TEXT.P: The Taipei Computer Association (TCA) launched the 2009 Taipei Game Show at the Taipei World Trade Center Thursday, with the aim of exploiting the business opportunities associated with the government's consumption stimulation plan.

Along with the game show, a special 3C section has been created to boost sales of computers, consumer electronics and home appliances by encouraging spending of the govenrment-issued shopping vouchers, organizers said, adding that the event is especially designed to attract those who claim their coupons after the Lunar New Year holiday.

Addressing the opening of the exhibition, Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming described the TCA's idea as ingenious, and noted that more than 2 million people have already claimed their shopping vouchers since the end of the New Year holiday.
"And some NT$7.2 billion (US$212 million) worth of vouchers are yet to be claimed by the public," said Yiin.

Expressing strong support for the government's NT$85.7 billion shopping voucher program, TCA Chairman J. T. Wang said that the timing of the voucher distribution was perfect, as most people are likely to purchase new computers and game-related products during or after the Chinese New Year.
"If I am asked to grade the results of the government's voucher program, I would give it an A plus," said Wang.

Meanwhile, Wang urged game lovers and the public to take advantage of this year's game show and 3C exhibition, as participating companies are offering discounts of up to 50 percent on game related products.
Wang said that participating companies have also designed a variety of attractive deals for consumers who purchase 3C or game products with their shopping vouchers.
According to Wang, with more than 400 booths set up by 40 local and foreign companies, the five-day event is expected to attract over 300,000 visitors.
The exhibition, jointly sponsored by the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the TCA, will run through Feb. 16.
More than 90 percent of local citizens claimed their shopping vouchers before the Lunar New Year holiday and the second stage of distribution of the coupons began Feb.7.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police nab smugglers of illegal pesticides

TEXT.P: The Taichung County Police Station announced Thursday that it has detained nine suspects for smuggling and selling banned or restricted pesticides from China to local pesticide distributors and stores.
The Taichung County police made the announcement after a 49-year-old suspect, identified as Kao, and eight other persons were arrested in raids earlier in the day.

In a joint crackdown, eight prosecutors, over 200 law enforcement agents and Council of Agriculture (COA) officials searched 29 locations, including Kao's house and offices. They also raided several sites in Taichung, Yunlin, Chiayi, Taitung and Pintung in central and southern Taiwan where it was suspected that the smuggling ring was manufacturing, storing and selling the products.
The nine suspects were charged with smuggling illegal pesticides or raw materials from China by boat to Taiwan's outlying Kinmen Island before transferring them to Taiwan proper, since 2007.
They were also accused of manufacturing illegal pesticides in five townships in Taichung County in central Taiwan and selling them to pesticide stores across the country at unfairly low prices.
Police also seized large quantities of pesticides and toxic materials banned or restricted by the COA, such as fentin acetate, cyromazine, acetamiprid and bismerthiazol.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan hopes to join ASEAN labor ministers meetings

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou proposed Thursday that Taiwan be invited to take part in the labor ministers meetings of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) so as to allow the country to contribute to the resolution of regional labor issues.

Ma raised the issue while receiving Peter Favila, trade and industry secretary of the Philippines, who is in Taiwan to attend the 16th ministerial-level economic cooperation meeting between the two countries.
More than 360,000 foreign laborers are currently employed to work in Taiwan, with those from Southeast Asia forming the largest group, including some 75,000 from the Philippines.
Ma told Favila that Taiwan expects to engage in closer cooperation with the Philippines and to participate in the development of the ASEAN free trade area.

He said that Taiwan began discussions with the Philippines issues concerning the prevention of double taxation in 2002, and expressed the hope that a related agreement could be signed as soon as possible.

Noting that Taiwan is the seventh largest foreign investor in the Philippines, the president urged the Filipino government to provide wider preferential treatment for Taiwanese investors to encourage them to expand their operations in the Philippines.

Meanwhile, Ma said Taiwan has been very successful in promoting the establishment of digital opportunity centers in developing nations, under an Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum initiative to bridge the digital divide, and he offered to further work with the Philippines in this regard to help enhance its information technology capabilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA to focus more on overseas opportunities for local enterprises

TEXT.P: With President Ma Ying-jeou calling for Taiwan's diplomacy to prioritize economic issues, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that it will step up its efforts to help local enterprises explore business opportunities abroad.

Speaking at a press briefing, Shih Wen-bin, director-general of MOFA's Department of Economic and Trade Affairs, said that the ministry will strengthen the use of existing trade mechanisms in the hope of boosting the country's export volume in the face of the global economic slowdown.

The ministry will, for instance, subsidize local firms participating in business exhibitions in emerging markets and countries that have diplomatic relations with Taiwan, he said. The MOFA will also work to match domestic companies to foreign buyers at trade fairs held in promising markets such as Saudi Arabia, he added.

Meanwhile, Shih said the government will help local businesses, especially those in globally competitive industries, obtain a share of the enormous World Trade Organization's Government Procurement Agreement (GPA) market, which has an approximate value of US$390 billion a year.

In addition, the official encouraged Taiwan companies to explore business prospects linked to the government's bilateral and multilateral cooperation schemes with foreign countries or organizations such as the Asia Development Bank, with which Taiwan has investment and technical cooperation programs.

Other initiatives planned by the ministry include building stronger economic and trade relations with countries with which Taiwan has Free Trade Agreements and providing funding for local businesses to invest in countries that are Taiwan's diplomatic allies, Shih said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese pop queen crosses over to fashion design

TEXT.P: Taiwanese pop queen Jolin Tsai recently launched a line of street and club wear in New York, in cooperation with the noted L.A.M.B. Clothing, under the label of "Seventy Two Changes."

Tsai, one of the most popular Mandarin-language singers in Asia, traveled to New York recently for the launch of the new collection, which is named after one of her best-selling albums released in 2003, "See My 72 Changes -- Magic."

At a cocktail held in SOHO to launch the brand, Tsai, an English major graduate of Fu Jen Catholic University, discussed in fluent English with the media her ideas and inspiration for the new collection.
The event attracted journalists and cameramen from more than 30 media outlets and fashion magazines in New York.
Tsai said she has been taken with fashion and design since her childhood. She said that as she was too short to be a model, she tried to become a designer. "Now my dream has come true," she said.
Tsai added that any performing artists who might be interested in any of the approximately 100 items modeled at the launch of the brand may contact her and she would offer them outfits for free.

At the launch, the Seventy Two Changes clothing was modeled in four categories -- T-shirt dresses, tuxedo jackets and vests, lightweight wool plaid tops, leather leggings, and motorcycle and bomber jackets.
The brand is scheduled to hit the market in July in seven cities across the world, including New York, Shanghai and Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: Latest technology to be applied in cooperation programs: MOFA

TEXT.P: The latest information technology will be put to use in Taiwans international cooperation and aid programs, starting in Central America, in a bid to streamline the implementation of such programs, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.

Along with Taiwan's economic and technological development over the past few decades, the direction of its foreign aid programs has also shifted to more heavily utilize the country's strength in technology, said Shih Wen-bin, director-general of MOFA's Department of Economic and Trade Affairs.

Through the use of space and remote sensing as well as the Geographic Information System (GIS), he said, Taiwan will be better equipped to carry out environment-related projects, such as outdoor surveillance, post-disaster work and humanitarian relief in countries that are its diplomatic allies.
Taiwan will employ these technologies in a pilot project with Nicaragua -- one of its Central American allies -- to help strengthen environmental sustainability there, Shih added.
As the information will be directly gathered and analyzed by Taiwan's satellite, there will no need to send hardware or additional personnel to the allied country, according to the official.
The GIS has been utilized widely in areas such as urban planning, traffic management, biological conservation and even archeological research, Shih added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opposition legislator urges government to protect cypress forests

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Tien Chiu-chin urged President Ma Ying-jeou's administration Thursday to protect the country's remaining cypress forests by establishing another national park.

Speaking at a press conference at the Legislative Yuan, Tien urged the government to stop illegal cypress logging in the Chilan mountain area of northern Taiwan by establishing a Chilan cypress national park.

"The illegal cypress logging is getting worse year by year in the Chilan mountain area, but the government has done nothing about the situation, " said Tien, adding that local loggers have felled a great number of valuable 1,000 -year-old Chinese cypresses due to a lack of environmental protection in the area.

According to Tien, the government planned to establish a Chilan -- or Magaw in the aboriginal Atayal language -- national park some six years ago, but the plan was delayed indefinitely due to objections and obstructions by indigenous tribespeople for whom the area is their traditional homeland and who would be kicked off the land according to existing laws that prohibit aborigines from living in national parks.

Under the plan, the park would cover more than 53,000 acres, straddling Taipei, Yilan, Taoyuan, and Hsinchu counties. The area is home to more than 30,500 Atayal people and is famous for its primeval forests made up primarily of red and yellow cypress.
By delaying the plan indefinitely, the government has sent a message to illegal loggers that they are free to cut down as many cypress trees as they wish, Tien argued.

The establishment of a national park in the area "would be beneficial for the indigenous tribes, " according to Tien, who added that the government would grant at least NT$2 billion for the development and environmental protection of the area within five years of the park's establishment.

"The park would be able to attract at least 2 million visitors a year, " Tien speculated, adding that it would represent a significant source of income and opportunities for employment for the indigenous tribes who rely on farming as their sole source of income.
To ensure the livelihoods of local tribes, the government would have to devise schemes to foster tourism on the periphery of the park, Tien admitted.

According to Tien, the aborigines could become tour guides and investigators, and could also learn how to produce and market local specialities as well as providing lodging, food and transport to visitors.

Although the government prohibits indigenous tribes from inhabiting national parks -- causing fury among many aboriginal tribes -- those ideals have changed as time has progressed, Tien said, adding that the government must find a way to protect the environment without depriving the aboriginal tribes of their lifestyles and homes.

According to Tien, under Taiwan's National Park Law, an evaluation hearing must be conducted after five years of the establishment of a national park, in which parties can petition for the exclusion of some pre-designated pieces of land to be excluded from the park.

"If the aboriginal people are still dissatisfied with the results of the park after five years, they can petition for the exclusion of their land from the park, " said Tien, adding that if the aborigines "continue to oppose to the protection of the environment and the precious forests in the area, " they might soon lose everything to illegal loggers.

Three of Taiwan's six national parks have long been a point of contention between the government and aborigines. Indigenous tribes such as the Bunun and Atayal bemoan the fact that their ancestral lands are being violated and that they are deprived of their rights to ritual activities such as hunting.

The ambitious export-bolstering project will also direct Taiwanese exporters and manufacturers to emerging markets beyond China, including India, Russia, Brazil, the Middle East and countries in Southeast Asia.

Zheng He was an official who lived during the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644) . He led a giant fleet of Chinese vessels to Southeast Asia, from where they are believed to have reached as far as the west coast of Africa. He was instrumental in building China into one of the maritime superpowers between the 14th and 17th centuries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Placido Domingo to perform in Miaoli next month

TEXT.P: The Miaoli county government announced Thursday that world renowned tenor Placido Domingo has accepted an invitation to perform in the northern county next month.

County officials said with the success of a performance by Jose Carreras in the county late last year, they decided to invite another tenor in the same league to perform in the county's international music festival scheduled for March 19-21.

The officials said that to cater to all age groups, they will also invite Brian Mcknight, winner of the favorite male R&B Soul Artist in the American Music Awards, as well as Maksim, a popular pianist from Croatia.
The officials said that to upgrade the cultural level and stimulate consumption, they will sell tickets for the three performances this time around, although prices had yet to be decided.
The organizer of the Carreras performance last November gave out 40,000 free tickets, but more than 50,000 people showed up on performance night, contributing a great deal to the county's revenues.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier calls for action plans for long-term care

TEXT.P: With Taiwan's population aging rapidly, the government needs to craft a comprehensive long-term care system and improve services to those in need of help caring for disabled seniors, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Thursday.
Speaking at a weekly Cabinet meeting, Liu said he was sad to learn that four tragic cases involving exhausted family members killing their disabled parents have been reported so far this year.

On Wednesday, a 45-year-old woman surrendered herself to the police after suffocating her 71-year-old mother-in-law who reportedly had been bed-ridden and had needed assisted living for some considerable time.
"These cases indicate that long-term home care is a service urgently needed in our society and the government cannot afford to turn a blind eye to the issue," Liu said.
Noting that people aged 65 or older now make up more than 10 percent of the country's population, Liu said the ratio will soon exceed 15 percent.
"We must face up to the problems and take immediate action to deal with them if we are to maintain social stability," he added.

As a first step, the premier went on, relevant government agencies should work in concert to draw up a well-rounded plan for the establishment of a viable long-term care service system as soon as possible.

According to statistics complied by the Taiwan Association of Family Caregivers, there are about 30,000 people who need long-term care or assisted living staying in various nursing homes around Taiwan, with another 160,000 relying on family care provided by foreign caregivers and more than 400,000 others relying on care provided by their families.
A senior executive of the association said the government should offer more and better stress relieving services for those involved in family care of disabled elderly people.
According to the executive, an average of 30 to 40 cases of long-term caregivers killing the people in their care are reported in Taiwan every year.
Of the four cases reported this year, the perpetrators in the three other cases committed suicide after killing their loved ones, the executive said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sociology professor to join Cabinet

TEXT.P: Hsueh Cheng-tai, a former director of the Taipei city government's Bureau of Social Affairs, will serve as a minister-without-portfolio tasked with helping to craft a better social welfare service system, the Executive Yuan announced Thursday.
Hsueh, who is now a professor at National Taiwan University's Department of Sociology, will be the first person from the outlying Taiwan-controlled island of Kinmen to be recruited into the Cabinet.

Hsueh, who has a Ph.D. in sociology from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, will have the job of designing better social welfare service systems and action programs, the Executive Yuan said in a press statement.
His appointment will take effect next Monday, the statement added.
