DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 13, or the 19th day of the first month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1542: Catherine Howard, wife of English King Henry VIII, is beheaded for treason.
1668: Spain recognizes the independence of Portugal under the Treaty of Lisbon.
1692: Under English orders, Robert Campbell of Glen Lyon and his 128 men carry out the Glencoe massacre in Scotland against the MacDonald clan.
1793: Austria, Britain, Holland, Prussia, Spain, and Sardinia form an alliance against France.
1858: Captain John Speke and Sir Richard Burton become the first Europeans to discover Lake Tanganyika in East Africa.
1912: Dr. Sun Yat-sen tenders his resignation to the provisional Senate which was established in Nanking on Jan. 28, 1912. He also agrees to relinquish the provisional presidency of the Republic of China to Yuan Shih-kai, who promises to establish a republican government.
1920: Switzerland is admitted to the League of Nations.
1935: A judge sentences Bruno Hauptmann to die in the electric chair after a New Jersey jury found him guilty of kidnapping and murdering flying ace Charles Lindbergh's infant son three years earlier.
1941: The wonder drug penicillin is used for the first time on a human, a policeman from Oxford, England.
1945: U.S. warplanes bomb Dresden, Germany, killing over 35,000 civilians, while allied forces capture Budapest, Hungary.
1954: Chou Lu, a veteran revolutionary leader of the Kuomintang, dies in Taipei at the age of 70.
1957: The British Defense Ministry announces the production of its first H-bomb.
1958: Taipei area records its lowest temperature (2.6 degrees Celsius) in half a century.
1960: The French test their first atomic bomb in the Sahara Desert in Africa.
1966: The list of winners of the first 10 outstanding ROC female youth awards is announced.
1971: Spiro Agnew, vice president of the United States under President Richard Nixon, hits three spectators with his golf ball during the Bob Hope Desert Classic tournament.
1971: Aided by U.S. aircraft and artillery, South Vietnamese troops enter Laos.
1973: Minister of Economic Affairs Y. S. Sun of the ROC leaves for Bangkok to attend a meeting of the board of trustees of the Asian Institute of Technology and meet with Thai government officials.
1975: The ROC Cabinet decides to ban activities of the Christian Unification Church on the grounds that it has been violating the customs of the Chinese people.
1975: The Sino-Guatemalan and the Sino-Dominican technical cooperation agreements are approved by the ROC Cabinet.
1984: The Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party elects Constantin Ustinovich Chernenko as its secretary-general.
1989: Soviet troops leave Kabul, capital of Afghanistan.
1990: Boxer James Douglas is recognized as the new world heavyweight champion after knocking out Mike Tyson in Tokyo two nights earlier.
1990: The Mainland Affairs Task Force permits performing artists from Taiwan to stage commercial performances in mainland China and to participate in activities sponsored by the Chinese communists.
1991: A U.S. missile hits an air-raid shelter crowded with civilians in Baghdad, killing more than 300 people.
1994: A ferry taking illegal Burmese workers home capsizes off Thailand. More than 150 of them are feared dead.
1998: A special convention votes to make Australia a republic and promises a referendum on replacing the queen as head of state in 1999.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man is composed and happy; a fool is always worried and full of distress."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan, Philippines ink four MOUs on closer economic ties

TEXT.P: Taiwan and the Philippines signed four memoranda of understanding (MOUs) upon the conclusion of the 16th ministerial-level economic cooperation meeting between the two countries aimed at bolstering bilateral cooperation, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Friday.

The MOUs were forged on cooperation in the fields of standardization and conformity assessment, cooperation in small- and medium-sized enterprises, cross-border information technology exchanges and cooperation in the semiconductor manufacturing industry.

During the two-day meeting, the Philippines agreed to give priority consideration to lowering import tariffs on polyester fiber from Taiwan. There is no polyester fiber processing industry in the Philippines, MOEA officials noted.

The Philippines agreed to simplify customs procedures for imports of Taiwanese goods at the Subic Bay Freeport Zone, which houses several Taiwanese companies, and at the Clark Freeport Zone north of Manila, the officials noted.
It was announced during the meeting that Spirit of Manila Airlines will offer direct flight services between the Clark Freeport Zone and Taipei from March 15.

It was also announced during the meeting that ATA carnet systems will be activated June 15 between Taiwan and the Philippines to facilitate temporary imports to each other's country. The ATA carnet operations will be implemented only for cooperation in the intellectual property area, MOEA officials said.
The Philippines is Taiwan's 14th-largest trade partner, while Taiwan is the eighth-largest trade partner of the Philippines. Bilateral trade totaled US$7.03 billion in 2008.

According to tallies compiled by the MOEA's Investment Commission, Philippines investment in Taiwan totaled 252 cases worth a combined US$1.17 billion as of last December, while Taiwanese investment in the Philippines amounted to 974 cases, worth a combined US$1.84 billion as of last June.
About 75,000 Philippines nationals are currently working in Taiwan, mostly as laborers or household helpers.

DOC.HEADLINE: 80 tons of substandard pesticides smuggled from China on market

TEXT.P: A total of 80 tons of banned or substandard pesticides smuggled from China have been identified as being on sale around Taiwan, the Council of Agriculture (COA) confirmed Friday.

The pesticides, believed to be on sale at 20 pesticide shops around the country, include long-banned fentin acetate, a lethal weapon against crop-depleting apple snails, as well as 10 other categories of counterfeit pesticides such as cyromazine, acetamiprid and bismerthiazol, according to officials from the COA Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine.
The officials said fentin acetate has been banned across the board in Taiwan since 1997 due to the harm it causes to the human central nervous system and to embryos.
The Taichung County Police Station in central Taiwan said a day earlier that it had nabbed nine suspects for smuggling and selling banned or counterfeit pesticides from China.

After raiding several sites in central and southern Taiwan, the Taichung police discovered that the smugglers have also adulterated normal pesticides with the substandard Chinese material for sale to domestic pesticide distributors or shops.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S supports closer cross-strait ties: U.S official
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/13/09 14:53:22 (By Luis Yu and C.Y. Lin)

TEXT.P: The newly appointed U.S deputy secretary of state said Thursday that the U.S. welcomes closer cross-Taiwan Strait ties and will continue through Washington's "one China" policy to support both sides' efforts to overcome their differences through peaceful means.
James. B. Steinberg made the remarks while attending the annual National Council for Visitors held in Washington, in which U.S. President Barack Obama's foreign policy was described.

Steinberg served as deputy national security adviser during the second term of former President Bill Clinton during the late 1990s, and during the 1996 Taiwan Missile Crisis, he met with Taiwan's National Security Council Secretary-General Ting Mao-shih, which later became the primary channel of communication between the two nation's national security agencies.

Asked what he thinks about the current cross-strait situation, Steinberg said the U.S. will keep a watchful eye on Taiwan-China relations, as they are one of the most important issues on Washington's foreign affairs agenda.
Both parties in the United States have a consensus about the U.S. cross-strait policy, and it has been one of the most successful in terms of U.S. foreign policy , Steinberg said.

Steinberg said the U.S. has maintained the same cross-strait policy for more than 30 years, as it has served the best interests of the parties involved and has helped maintain peace and stability in the area.

U.S. cross-strait policy under the "one-China" policy has greatly contributed to Taiwan's democracy and cross-strait economic development, and it is very important for the U.S to maintain its one-China policy in its cross-strait policy, said Steinberg, describing it as beneficial for all parties and ensuring the peace and stability of the area.

The interaction between the people, the closer economic ties and the increasing cultural exchanges between Taiwan and China are remarkable achievements for the leaders of the two sides, said Steinberg.

DOC.HEADLINE: Valentine's Day spending down amid bad economy: survey

TEXT.P: The current economic downturn, which is threatening the livelihoods of many local workers, has also dampened their mood for Feb. 14, Valentine's Day.

According to the results of a survey released Friday by the travel Web site travel.1111.com.tw, 37 percent of the respondents with a partner said they will not celebrate Valentine's Day this year, either because they are out of work, on unpaid leave or away from their lovers.
Among those not in a relationship, 60 percent said they will ignore the occasion, while another 21 percent will celebrate it on their own.
Forty-eight percent of the respondents intending to celebrate Valentine's Day said they will spend less this year than they did last year as they are on a tighter budget.
On average, the respondents said they will spend NT$2,201 on the celebration, with more than 70 percent of them setting their budget at no more than NT$2,000.
The survey was carried out between Jan. 23 and Feb. 12 among 1,489 office workers. It had a margin of error of 2.53 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to negotiate with WHO if belittled in IHR integration process

TEXT.P: The government will negotiate with the World Health Organization (WHO) if Taiwan is belittled in the WHO's International Health Regulations (IHR) integration process, Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Liu Teh-hsun said Friday.

Responding to claims in the local media that China is conspiring to belittle and jeopardize Taiwan's sovereignty while the nation is being integrated into the IHR, Liu said the government is paying close attention to the integration process and will immediately negotiate with the WHO if the nation's sovereignty is belittled in the process.

The WHO notified Taiwan in January that it has been brought under the umbrella of the IRH, a legal framework under the WHO for global infectious disease control, said Liu, adding that Taiwan is now establishing contact and interaction with the WHO as it is now part of the global epidemic disease control and health care network.

"The procedures in the integration process have nothing to do with China," said Liu, adding that Taiwan's participation in the IHR mechanism is conducted through the WHO and does not need Beijing's approval.
Things are going smoothly at the moment, Liu went on, adding that the government will protect Taiwan's sovereignty and interests at all costs in the integration process.

Liu pointed out that the IHR is only one of the many mechanisms under the WHO, and at the same time urged China not to obstruct Taiwan's participation in the World Health Assembly (WHA) -- the executive arm of the WHO -- as an observer.

"The government will continue to fight for Taiwan's right to participate in the WHA and the WHO's mechanisms and activities, " said Liu, adding that it is vital for Taiwan to protect the health and rights of its citizens.

Because of China's opposition, Taiwan had previously been excluded from the IHR, even though a "universal application" phrase was introduced in the regulations in 2005 with the firm support of the United States and Taiwan's diplomatic allies, and the encouragement of the European Union and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier apologizes to Hansen's disease sufferers

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan offered a public apology Thursday to all victims of Hansen's disease, or leprosy, and promised that the government will provide them with better nursing and medical care in the future.
Speaking at a regular weekly Cabinet meeting, Liu apologized for the unfair treatment Hansen's disease patients have suffered in the past.

The patients were forcibly quarantined at the 78-year-old Losheng Sanatorium in Sinjhuang, Taipei County under a segregation policy between 1930 and 1962. Last year, they were removed from the sanatorium to make way for a mass rapid transit depot, but some of them refused to leave and staged a protest against the government's move.
Liu said that following the enactment of the Statute on the Human Rights of and Compensation for Hansen's Disease Patients last Aug. 13, leprosy suffers can now get better care.

Under the law, the government is to recompense mistreated sufferers and provide lifelong care to the residents of Losheng Sanatorium, who were labeled infectious and who were poorly treated by previous administrations.

The premier said that previous governments did not take a proactive and effective approach to end the discrimination against Hansen's disease patients, which not only caused hurt to their dignity and human rights, but also caused them severe mental anguish.

Acknowledging the unfairness of past policies on leprosy sufferers, Liu said that the government has paid tens of millions of new Taiwan dollars in compensation to them and is working to restore their reputations and raise public awareness of the disease.
Liu also said the government will move to develop the sanatorium into a facility for the treatment of chronic disease patients and a cultural heritage site.
Also Thursday, Department of Health Minister Yeh Ching-chuan visited Losheng and offered an apology on behalf of Liu to the residents, receiving a warm welcome from some of them.

"I am happy to receive the government's apology because I have waited for so long, " said Huang Wen-chang, who has been kept at the sanatorium for 54 years since he was 20 years old. He added that he previously took part in the protests over the relocation plan but that he is now satisfied with his living conditions now that the government renovated the buildings in which he lives.
However, Yeh's apology was also rejected by many others, most of whom are unhappy about being relocated.

Lee Tien-pei, a Losheng resident and chairman of the Losheng Self-Help Organization, dismissed the apology as "an empty rhetorical statement, " adding that he has not received any hard information on what the government has done or will do for the leprosy suffers.

Taking himself as an example, Lee said he has been forcibly quarantined for half a century, but still has not seen the government come up with any concrete measures to help end discrimination against the patients and help them back into society.

"I will not accept the government's apology, " said Lan Tsai-yun, another Losheng resident, while describing how she was forcibly removed by the police from her residence last December. She recalled that the police cut the power and water when she was still living there, then cut down her door and took her away by force.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 2.2 million Taiwanese adults have never fallen in love: poll

TEXT.P: Some 2.2 million adults in Taiwan have never fallen in love or had a relationship with a member of the opposite sex, results of a public opinion poll showed Friday.

The poll, conducted by Fu Jen Catholic University on behalf of the nonprofit Mental Health Foundation, found that those who have never been in love have lower mental health scores (an average of 80.1 points), than those who have had relationships (who average 86.5 points).

Yang Tsung-tsai, a doctor with Cardinal Tien Hospital's Neuroscience Center who supervised the poll, said 13.3 percent of survey respondents indicated they have never been in love, translating roughly into 1.1 million men and 1.1 million women who have not had a relationship, Yang said.

Yen Han-wen, a sex education professor at National Normal University, attributed the large number of bachelors and spinsters in Taiwan mainly to the lack of an "environment conducive to falling in love" in Taiwanese society.
In Taiwan, if a man invites a woman out on a date, they will immediately be labeled as "a couple," a label preventing the man from attempting to get acquanted with other women, Yen said.
In Western society, he said, a private date between a man and a woman is just one of many ways of getting to know each other.
Yen also observed that young women in Taiwan often go out in groups, a situation not conducive to men getting to know one of the group members privately.

Yen suggested that both men and women should not only speak to people they are familiar with at social gatherings and said that because local society still frowns on a woman openly asking a man out, women should find less obvious or indirect ways to arrange a date with guys they like.
The poll, conducted via telephone between September and October last year, obtained 1,114 valid responses and has a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: African handicrafts to go on sale in May: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will hold an exhibition of African handicrafts for sale in May as part of its efforts to promote cultural and commercial exchanges with the continent, an official said Friday.

Shih Wen-bin, director-general of MOFA's Department of Economic and Trade Affairs, said that as Africa has suffered from the global economic slowdown along with the rest of the world, he hoped sales at the show would contribute to the economies of the participating countries.

The African countries offering handicrafts for sale will be diplomatic allies Burkina Faso, The Gambia, Swaziland and Sao Tome and Principe, and three non- allies that are friendly toward Taiwan -- South Africa, Nigeria and Libya -- Shih said.
Although some of the countries are economically underdeveloped, their craftsmanship skills rank among the best in the world, he said.

Lee Pai-po, deputy secretary-general of the International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF), a MOFA arm that provides technical and agricultural aid to foreign countries, said that in addition to the economic crisis, Taiwan is also helping its allies in Africa, Central America and the Caribbean confront the global food crisis.

Lee said the ICDF's technical teams stationed in five of the country's allies -- Burkina Faso, The Gambia, Swaziland, Nicaragua and Haiti -- will step up their efforts to carry out programs that help increase local harvests and mitigate food shortages in those countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices surge on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices rose Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, advancing 126.08 points, or 2.82 percent, to close at 4,592.50.

Recovering from a 2.4 percent fall the day before, the local bourse opened higher at 4,504.71 and fluctuated between 4,599.61 and 4,504.71. A total of 3.61 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$74.56 billion (US$2.19 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks and machinery and electronic issues both moving up by 3.2 percent, the most of any of the categories. Banking and financial shares gained 3 percent, cement issues and foodstuff stocks both rose 2.8 percent, construction shares rose 2.3 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks advanced 2.2 percent, and paper and pulp issues rose 1.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,449 to 237, with 118 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$1.64 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. reaffirms commitment to maintain cross-strait military balance
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/13/09 18:04:27 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The United States' new intelligence director reaffirmed Thursday Washington's commitment to help Taiwan maintain a military balance with China and warned that "preparations for a possible Taiwan conflict" remains a main purpose of China's military modernization.

"Taiwan should not be so defenseless that it feels that it has to do everything that China says. On the other hand, China cannot be so overwhelming that it can bully Taiwan, " said Dennis Blair, director of national intelligence under President Barack Obama, during a hearing held by the Senate Committee on Intelligence.

In an annual threat assessment delivered to the committee, Blair said that Taiwan as an area of tension in U.S.-China relations has substantially relaxed since the election of President Ma Ying-jeou in 2008.

With dialogue between Taiwan and China resumed soon after Ma's inauguration, leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait are cautiously optimistic that a new period of "less confrontational relations" has begun," Blair said.
However, many challenges remain, he said, noting that Taipei and Beijing will eventually need to confront issues such as Taiwan's participation in international organizations.
In addition, Beijing has not renounced the use of force against Taiwan, and China's leaders see maintaining the goal of unification as vital to regime legitimacy, he pointed out.
Under these circumstances, he said, the United States must continue to "make sure that military adventures are unattractive" to both sides to strike a balance in the Taiwan Strait.
According to Blair, Taiwan has to realize that its long-term security lies in "some sort of arrangement" with China, rather than in military defenses.

He said the two sides should be encouraged to resolve their differences through political and civil exchanges and proposed that they try to reach an arrangement on Taiwan's international participation.
The United States, which is committed under the Taiwan Relations Act to help Taiwan maintain a sufficient defense, has been Taiwan's most important weapons supplier.

In the latest arms deal between the two sides, the administration of former U.S. President George W. Bush approved in late 2008 the sale of a package of weapons to Taiwan, including 30 Apache attack helicopters, 330 advanced capability Patriot (PAC-3) missiles, 32 Harpoon sub-launched missiles, 182 guided Javelin missile rounds, and four E-2T system upgrades.
The move, however, drew strong protest from China, which reacted by suspending military-to-military exchanges and nonproliferation talks with the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECCT, local university launch international internship program

TEXT.P: The European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (ECCT) and Chinese Cultural University on Friday launched an "International Internship Programto give students in Taiwan a chance to work in an international environment and get practical work experience and on the job training.

Speaking at the agreement signing ceremony at the university's School of Continuing Education, ECCT CEO Guy Wittich said the program can serve as a bridge between European industrial resources and the talented Taiwanese work force.
Taiwan's competitiveness lies in its talent and this program provides a good match for Taiwan's talent with European companies, " Wittich said.

Program initiator Elias Ek, co-chairman of the ECCT's SME Center (Small and Medium-sized Enterprises Center) , told the Central News Agency that both companies and students can benefit greatly from the program.
It's a win-win situation, Ek said.Maybe it's not so much about contributing but inventing more win-win situations so we can benefit everybody.

According to Ek, the internship program is a good way for European companies in Taiwan to market themselves as good places to work and students will also get university credits, job experience and earn a little bit of money through it.
Asked how long the cooperation program will last, Ek said he sees no end to it but rather the beginning of something that he hopes will keep on going for a long time.
Rain Lee, a sophomore majoring in advertising at the university, said that she was interested in working for marketing companies.
At a time of economic recession, it's very important to have work experience, and I believe the internship program will increase my competence and my ability to speak to people,she said.

Sherry Chen, a junior in the university's Department of International Trade, expressed great interest in joining the internship program, saying that she attended the event to see what qualities foreign companies were looking for.
She was worried, however, that her poor English speaking ability might be an obstacle in gaining an internship in these companies.

In response, Jesse Arlen Smith, co-chairman of the SME Center who owns a consulting company in Taiwan, said that his company offers an on-the-job training program that will prepare interns for their work.

The program, which looks to hire 40-50 students to work part-time for several European companies in Taiwan, offers internships in fields such as business management, marketing, consulting, international trade, finance, MIS-IT and education.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP invites President Ma to national affairs conference

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) formally extended an invitation to President Ma Ying-jeou Friday to attend the opposition-organized national affairs conference slated for Feb. 21-22.
DPP Deputy Secretary-General Chen Chi-mai delivered the invitation during a 20-minute meeting with Presidential Office Secretary-General Chan Chuen-po and Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi.
Chan promised to hand the invitation to Ma but did not say whether the president will attend the conference, which is being held jointly by the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union.
Presidential spokesman Wang Yu-chi said that the government will consider whether the president should participate and in what form before responding to the DPP's invitation.

According to the DPP's Chen, Chan reiterated Ma's hope that DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen would agree to have a talk with the president in the Presidential Office, but Chen replied that the national affairs conference would be the best venue for their meeting and hoped Ma would attend to listen to public opinion.
Chen said the national convention is intended to give local people the chance to voice their views on how to tackle rising unemployment and deal with issues related to China policy.
The DPP deputy secretary added that once the president agrees to attend the conference, the party will discuss Ma's attendance schedule with the Presidential Office.
The Presidential Office reiterated, however, that an in-depth talk between Ma and Tsai would be the best and most effective means of communication between the government and the opposition party.

During the DPP's visit Friday, Chan stressed Ma was committed to finding ways to revive the economy and promoting harmony between the ruling and opposition parties, and that he attached great importance to public opinion, to the point of visiting rural areas to seek out grassroots opinion even as the meeting with DPP representatives was taking place.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most Kaohsiung schools lower lunch fees amid downturn

TEXT.P: More than 90 percent of elementary and junior high schools in the southern port city of Kaohsiung have reduced their lunch fees in an effort to mitigate the financial burden on parents amid the current economic recession, a city councilor said Friday.
According to Lien Li-chien, the city's Bureau of Education raised school lunch fees by NT$5 last autumn.

During the just-concluded winter vacation, Lien said, he conducted a field study which showed that 97 percent of the schools registered a budget surplus in the previous semester, with many posting a surplus of more than NT$1 million and one registering a surplus as high as NT$4.3 million.
Acting on the Kaohsiung City Council's request, the municipal education bureau has authorized public elementary and junior high schools to drop their school lunch fees.

According to the results of Lien's latest survey, all of the city's 91 public elementary schools have lowered their lunch fees by an average of NT$2.3. Among them, seven slashed lunch fees by NT$5 and 71 others cut their fees by NT$2.
Meanwhile, 37 of the city's 40 public junior high schools have reduced their lunch fees by an average of NT$2.6, with three lowering the fees by NT$5.

Commending the local schools' quick response to the city council's request for a lunch fee adjustment, Lien said he will continue to monitor the issue closely with a view to reducing the financial burden on parents as some of them might have lost their jobs as a result of the current economic woes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan plans to study CECA with China

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) promised Friday to study the feasibility of signing a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) with China, in response to a call by business and industrial groups for the government to hold talks with Beijing on that and other trade matters.

The MOEA stated in a press statement that it has been closely monitoring the formation of a regional economic bloc that includes the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and its neighboring trade partners of China, Japan and South Korea.
The MOEA knows that Taiwanese exporters will face tough challenges when the "ASEAN plus one" -- ASEAN and China -- free trade zone goes into operation in 2010, according to the statement.

Therefore, the government has been seeking to sign free trade agreements (FTAs) with Taiwan's major trading partners and has spared no effort to devise strategies to deal with its exclusion from the regional economic bloc, the MOEA said.

Industry and business groups in Taiwan have been pushing for the Taiwan government to forge closer economic links with China by signing a CECA, and to move quickly to liberalize cross-strait trade though actions such as the removal of tariffs.

Amid some doubt and uncertainty in Taiwan regarding the idea of signing a CECA with China, the MOEA said it will conduct a study on how such an agreement could be achieved without sacrificing the overall interests of the country's industrial sectors.

Taiwan is also concerned that ASEAN enters into an "ASEAN plus three" arrangement, which not only includes China but also Japan and South Korea -- with import duties on goods flowing between East Asia and the Southeast Asia countries will be lowered or eliminated.

This means that countries outside the economic bloc will have to contend with import duties ranging from 6.5 percent to 14.9 percent in competing with exporters from East Asia or ASEAN vying for regional markets.

Fearing they will lose their competitiveness, six of Taiwan's major business and industrial organizations -- the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, Chinese National Federation of Industries, Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association, National Association of Small and Medium Enterprises, General Chamber of Commerce of Republic of China, and Taiwan Federation of Industry -- urged the government to take action as soon as possible to deal with the looming problem.

President Ma Ying-jeou has sought to build closer economic ties and eventually ink a CECA with China, but the approach has drawn strong criticism from some quarters, including the pro-independence opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) and the Democratic Progressive Party.

TSU Chairman Huang Kun-huei argued that the proposed CECA with China will force Taiwan to follow the Hong Kong and Macau model, which will ultimately downgrade Taiwan to the level of a local government subordinate to Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tuvalu prime minister to arrive in Taiwan for state visit

TEXT.P: Tuvalu Prime Minister Apisai Ielemia and his wife will arrive in Taiwan Saturday for a five-day visit at the invitation of the Republic of China government.

Taiwan and Tuvalu will celebrate the 30th anniversary of their diplomatic relations this year. Ielemia's visit marks the close friendship between the two island states, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday in a statement.
Tuvalu is a Polynesian island nation located in the Pacific Ocean midway between Hawaii and Australia. It is composed of nine islets and has a population of around 11,000 people.
That makes it the third least inhabited independent country in the world, with only Vatican City and Nauru having smaller populations.
During his stay, Ielemia will visit President Ma Ying-jeou, Premier Liu Chao- shiuan and Minister of Foreign Affairs Francisco Ou, according to the MOFA statement.

In addition, the prime minister will be interviewed by the Taipei-based CommonWealth Magazine, which organized a "saving Tuvalu islets from global warming with green ideas" activity last Dec. 10, inviting elementary school students to draw their ideas on paper.
Ielemia has been invited to tell Taiwanese students in person how his country is faced with being inundated by rising sea levels resulting from global warming, according to the MOFA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Online version of Formosa Post to be inaugurated July 1: ex-VP

TEXT.P: Former Vice President Annette Lu said Friday the online version of the Formosa Post, or Yushan Wubao in Mandarin, is scheduled to be launched July 1, with the print version being inaugurated Oct. 25.
Lu made the remarks after meeting with Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu on the eve of the latter's departure for a visit to the United States.
According to Lu, she plans to raise NT$300 million in the coming two months to finance the Formosa Post project.

Stressing that the planned paper will reflect core values of local society and views of grassroots people, Lu said the paper will not only recruit professional journalists but will also introduce a "citizen reporter" system to facilitate realization of its goals.

Lu, who traveled to Washington, D.C., last month to attend U.S. President Obama's inauguration, said her U.S. trip has solidified her resolve to establish the Formosa Post, as Taiwan needs a newspaper to unify people who love Taiwan, so as to normalize, globalize and enrich the country.
According to Lu, the newspaper, which will go on sale at 3 p.m. daily, will focus on local and international politics, culture, and science and technology.

Lu also urged Mayor Chen to speak for Taiwan's independent sovereignty during her U.S. trip to prevent the international community from misunderstanding that all of Taiwan's people agree with the China policy of Taiwan's incumbent administration, which she said leans toward China.
Both Lu and Chen are veteran members of the opposition pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: Editor's Note
DOC.TEXT:
Re CEP Item 0011, the words "'one China' principle" in the first and seventh paragraphs should read "'one China' policy." A corrected version follows: U.S supports closer cross-strait ties: U.S official
Washington, Feb. 12 (CNA) The newly appointed U.S deputy secretary of state said Thursday that the U.S. welcomes closer cross-Taiwan Strait ties and will continue through Washington's "one China" policy to support both sides' efforts to overcome their differences through peaceful means.
James. B. Steinberg made the remarks while attending the annual National Council for Visitors held in Washington, in which U.S. President Barack Obama's foreign policy was described.
Steinberg served as deputy national security adviser during the second term of former President Bill Clinton during the late 1990s, and during the 1996 Taiwan Missile Crisis, he met with Taiwan's National Security Council Secretary-General Ting Mao-shih, which later became the primary channel of communication between the two nation's national security agencies.
Asked what he thinks about the current cross-strait situation, Steinberg said the U.S. will keep a watchful eye on Taiwan-China relations, as they are one of the most important issues on Washington's foreign affairs agenda.
Both parties in the United States have a consensus about the U.S. cross-strait policy, and it has been one of the most successful in terms of U.S. foreign policy , Steinberg said.
Steinberg said the U.S. has maintained the same cross-strait policy for more than 30 years, as it has served the best interests of the parties involved and has helped maintain peace and stability in the area.
U.S. cross-strait policy under the "one-China" policy has greatly contributed to Taiwan's democracy and cross-strait economic development, and it is very important for the U.S to maintain its one-China policy in its cross-strait policy, said Steinberg, describing it as beneficial for all parties and ensuring the peace and stability of the area.
The interaction between the people, the closer economic ties and the increasing cultural exchanges between Taiwan and China are remarkable achievements for the leaders of the two sides, said Steinberg.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's indigenous population up 2.05 percent

TEXT.P: The number of indigenous people in Taiwan totaled 494,107 as of the end of last year, up 2.05 percent from the previous year, according to statistics released by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) Friday.
MOI officials said the increase was about six times that of the 0.34 percent rate of growth of Taiwan's overall population.

Taiwan's indigenous people were also younger on average than other groups, averaging 31.93 years of age as of the end of last year, 5.23 years lower than the 37.16 years the country's population averaged as a whole.
The number of indigenous people over 65 accounted for 6.1 percent of the total indigenous population, lower than the 10.4 percent of senior citizens in the overall population.
Of the 14 tribes in Taiwan, the Amis were the most populous with 177,909 people, followed by the Paiwan and Atayal tribes.
The three tribes accounted for nearly 70 percent of the total indigenous population.
Hualien County in eastern Taiwan had the most indigenous people at 89,812, accounting for 18.8 percent of the country's total, followed by Taitung and Pingtung counties.
But Taitung County had the highest ratio of indigenous people, who accounted for 34 percent of the county's population.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former American official warns against danger of relying on China

TEXT.P: Describing China's economic growth as "false and hallow, " a former American official on Friday urged the world, including Taiwan and the U.S., to heed the danger of relying on the rising giant to ride out the global economic crisis as China has its own serious domestic problems to tackle.

Former American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairwoman Therese Shaheen, now chairman of the U.S. Asia Economic Foundation, stressed the importance of obtaining a "more authentic view of China" so as to craft correspondingly correct foreign policies.

Since politics follows economics, the current global recession, or the "economic 9-11" as she put it, has shifted the policy direction of the Barack Obama administration to focus more on economic issues.

Shaheen contended, however, that Washington's "conventional wisdom" -- that the U.S. cannot afford to anger China because it is its major banker -- on which the new emphasis is based, is "flatly untrue."

Citing the report "Fault Lines in China's Economic Terrain" conducted by the Rand Corporation on behalf of the U.S. government for a detailed look at China's development, she said that the world has been mesmerized China's double-digit economic growth.

"China's fundamental economy is unstable, " she said, mainly due to its over- dependence on foreign direct investment (FDI) and exports, and described the Chinese economy as a "spinning top," with a constant flow of FDI pouring into the country and an enormous amount of exports flowing out.

Given China's declining export volume, however, Shaheen said it was "highly improbable, if not impossible" that China would grow this year at an 8 percent rate, a level widely considered necessary to uphold Chinese social stability.

In addition, quoting Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao as saying that China's economy is "unstable, unbalanced, uncoordinated and unsustainable" following the National People's Congress in 2007, Shaheen said that "China has sailed into the crisis on a boat that its own leadership admits has been heavily burdened and listing for a long time."

Expanding on Wen's statement, she said that China was, and still is, confronted with grave problems in various areas, such as unemployment, the banking sector, income disparities, the lack of a social safety net, and over-reliance on FDI and exports.

Other issues that China has to tackle, she pointed out, include corruption, energy consumption and prices, water resources and pollution, as well as HIV/AIDS and other epidemic diseases, which altogether, had resulted in at least 60,000 riots and protests that took place across China during 2007.

In today's sluggish economic environment, Shaheen contended that there is further pressure for China to show growth by means of "however growth can be shown" so as to retain the image of strong economic growth and maintain domestic social peace.
Therefore, she concluded that although China is an important economy, it "matters less than we thought" and "will not play a major role in the solution (to the current crisis)."
She said China will progress even more slowly than Taiwan and the U.S. in today's weak global economy under its growing domestic burdens.
With this change of perception of China, she said that Washington would have a shift of attitude toward the Asian giant and lead to adjustments in its China policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Court rejects former president's appeal against detention

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court rejected an appeal Thursday by former President Chen Shui-bian that his detention be rescinded, as well as his plea that he be released on bail.

Chen is being held in custody at the Tucheng Detention Center in Taipei County, awaiting trial on charges of embezzlement, bribe- taking, money laundering and forgery. If found guilty on all the counts, he could face life imprisonment.
A panel of judges ruled that the ex-president, who served two four-year terms, still wields considerable influence, although there is no concrete evidence that he might abscond if he is released,

The judges expressed the view that the alleged money laundering by the former first family through dummy accounts was so serious that it cannot be ruled out that Chen and his family were stashing large sums of money abroad for their future use.

They also rejected the argument that Chen is unlikely to slip out of Taiwan because his activities would be monitored by the bodyguards assigned to protect him, contending that the bodyguards cannot violate Chen's free will if he insists that they do not follow him around.

Furthermore, the judges noted, in the initial stage of the investigation, Chen had instructed his former cashier, Chen Chen-hui and two former Presidential Office aides to give false testimony regarding the former first family's embezzlement of the president's state affairs fund and its money laundering activities.
Based on these considerations, the court ruled that it is necessary that the former president be kept in custody.

Chen was indicted Dec. 12 on corruption charges involving nearly half a billion Taiwan dollars, becoming the first person to have served as president in Taiwan's history to be put on trial for criminal offenses.
He was released Dec. 13 upon his own recognizance after being detained for 32 days as prosecutors prepared four cases against him.

The Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office filed an appeal Dec. 16 against the court's decision to release Chen but failed. Undaunted, the prosecutors launched a new bid Dec. 25 to detain Chen a second time on grounds that he might abscond through "secret channels."

The Taiwan High Court ordered the Taipei District Court Dec. 28 to reconsider its decision to release Chen, and on Dec. 30 the Taipei District Court finally approved the prosecutors' request to place Chen back in detention.
The former president and his wife were indicted for embezzling NT$104 million (US$3.12 million) from the president's special discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000 to 2008.

They also are accused of taking bribes worth NT$300 million in connection with a land procurement deal and another NT$90.93 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project.
The prosecutors recommended that the former president be given the harshest possible sentence for his alleged illegalities.

They also demanded severe penalties for his wife, son and daughter-in-law for their "unrepentant attitude" during the course of the investigation, while recommending commuted sentences for 10 other defendants because they had been cooperative and helpful during the probe.

The prosecutors are still investigating allegations that Chen and his wife received bribes totaling hundreds of millions of Taiwan dollars from several banks in exchange for favors granted to them during the former president's second financial reform program.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 14, or the 20th day of the first month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of importa events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1766: Thomas R. Malthus, the British economist who wrote "An Essay on the Principle of Population," is born. His 1798 work argues that populations tend to increase faster than food supplies unless the increase is checked by moral restraints or by war, famine, or disease.
1779: Captain James Cook, the British navigator and explorer who commanded three major voyages of "discovery," charting and "naming" many islands in the Pacific Ocean, is killed by a native's spear in Hawaii.
1797: British naval forces under Admiral John Jervis and Captain Horatio Nelson defeat the Spanish fleet off Portugal's Cape St. Vincent.
1859: Oregon becomes the 33rd state of the United States.
1893: Hawaii is annexed to the United States by a treaty.
1912: Arizona becomes the 48th state of the United States.
1924: Thomas John Watson, the U.S. industrialist who worked for the National Cash Register Company (now NCR Corporation) for 15 years, is made president of a company that later becomes International Business Machines Corporation (IBM).
1933: The League of Nations refuses to recognize the Japanese puppet regime known as "Manchukuo." To deflect world condemnation of their hegemony, the Japanese invaders of northern China installed the Manchukuo regime in 1932. This "land of the Manchu" proved to be no more than another stepping stone for the extension of Japanese aggression.
1939: The German battleship Bismarck is launched.
1950: The Chinese communist regime and the Soviet Union sign the "Sino-Soviet Friendly Alliance and Mutual Assistance Treaty" in Moscow.
1956: Soviet President Nikita Khrushchev denounces the policies of Joseph Stalin at the 20th Congress of the Soviet Communist Party.
1962: General Hu Chung-nan, strategic adviser to President Chiang Kai-shek, dies in Taipei at the age of 68.
1972: Mexico establishes diplomatic relations with mainland China.
1972: The Soviet Union launches its Luna 20 spacecraft to the moon.
1972: Washington relaxes trade restrictions against Beijing, putting it on the same basis as Moscow.
1973: Walter Benche Medina, newly-appointed ambassador of El Salvador, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1974: A six-member Jordanian trade mission led by S.A. Matouk, president of the Amman Chamber of Commerce, arrives in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1974: Commissioner W. Stanley Cottrill, international secretary of the Salvation Army International Headquarters, leaves Taipei after a three-day visit.
1975: The Marinas Islands in the Pacific becomes a territory of the United States.
1977: Shih Wei-liang, a noted Republic of China musician, dies in Taipei at the age of 54.
1989: Ayatollah Khomeini, Iran's religious leader, issues a "fatwa," or death sentence, against British writer Salman Rushdie for what he deemed to be blasphemy in the author's book "The Satanic Verses," sending him into years of hiding.
1999: Former Nixon White House aide John Ehrlichman dies at the age of 73. He served 18 months in prison for his role in the Watergate cover-up.
2000: President Lee Teng-hui confers the Order of the Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on Cor Boonstra, president of Royal Philips Electronics, in recognition of his company's contribution to Taiwan's economic development.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian says that he will visit Beijing and invite mainland Chinese leaders to visit Taipei if he wins the March 18 election.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Earnestness without judgment becomes pedantry; caution without judgment becomes timidity; courage without judgment leads to crime; uprightness without judgment makes men tyrannical."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
DOH to take action to address Taiwan's growing mental health issues

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yeh Ching-chuan promised Friday to come up with substantive measures to help the public cope with psychological problems amid the current economic crisis.
Yeh made the remarks after he met with the representatives of 26 mental health groups, led by Hsieh Meng-hsiung, chairman of the John Tung Foundation.
Yeh said that he would assign people to deal with the pressing problems.
"I will also submit two major projects on suicide prevention and drug prevention to the Executive Yuan," Yeh added.
He expressed the hope that the government and the private sector could work together to tide over the difficulties.
The representatives said that with the current economic slump, the government has attempted a quick fix by offering material assistance, but has largely ignored "psychological problems."
They said that since the second half of last year, the number of people seeking counseling with the Teacher Chang Foundation has surged by 20 percent.
The number of outpatients seeking mental health and psychological counseling has also increased, they added.

Hsieh and the others signed a petition that urged Yeh to integrate the resources of the government and the private sector, avoid the waste of resources and upgrade the quality of mental health services.

According to an online survey published by the John Tung Foundation in early December, the number of suicides in Taiwan has risen in the wake of the economic crisis triggered by the collapse of investment bank Lehman Brothers in September 2008.
