Citing the report "Fault Lines in China's Economic Terrain" conducted by the Rand Corporation on behalf of the U.S. government for a detailed look at China's development, she said that the world has been mesmerized China's double-digit economic growth.

"China's fundamental economy is unstable, " she said, mainly due to its over- dependence on foreign direct investment (FDI) and exports, and described the Chinese economy as a "spinning top," with a constant flow of FDI pouring into the country and an enormous amount of exports flowing out.

Given China's declining export volume, however, Shaheen said it was "highly improbable, if not impossible" that China would grow this year at an 8 percent rate, a level widely considered necessary to uphold Chinese social stability.

In addition, quoting Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao as saying that China's economy is "unstable, unbalanced, uncoordinated and unsustainable" following the National People's Congress in 2007, Shaheen said that "China has sailed into the crisis on a boat that its own leadership admits has been heavily burdened and listing for a long time."

Expanding on Wen's statement, she said that China was, and still is, confronted with grave problems in various areas, such as unemployment, the banking sector, income disparities, the lack of a social safety net, and over-reliance on FDI and exports.

Other issues that China has to tackle, she pointed out, include corruption, energy consumption and prices, water resources and pollution, as well as HIV/AIDS and other epidemic diseases, which altogether, had resulted in at least 60,000 riots and protests that took place across China during 2007.

In today's sluggish economic environment, Shaheen contended that there is further pressure for China to show growth by means of "however growth can be shown" so as to retain the image of strong economic growth and maintain domestic social peace.
Therefore, she concluded that although China is an important economy, it "matters less than we thought" and "will not play a major role in the solution (to the current crisis)."
She said China will progress even more slowly than Taiwan and the U.S. in today's weak global economy under its growing domestic burdens.
With this change of perception of China, she said that Washington would have a shift of attitude toward the Asian giant and lead to adjustments in its China policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's indigenous population up 2.05 percent

TEXT.P: The number of indigenous people in Taiwan totaled 494,107 as of the end of last year, up 2.05 percent from the previous year, according to statistics released by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) Friday.
MOI officials said the increase was about six times that of the 0.34 percent rate of growth of Taiwan's overall population.

Taiwan's indigenous people were also younger on average than other groups, averaging 31.93 years of age as of the end of last year, 5.23 years lower than the 37.16 years the country's population averaged as a whole.
The number of indigenous people over 65 accounted for 6.1 percent of the total indigenous population, lower than the 10.4 percent of senior citizens in the overall population.
Of the 14 tribes in Taiwan, the Amis were the most populous with 177,909 people, followed by the Paiwan and Atayal tribes.
The three tribes accounted for nearly 70 percent of the total indigenous population.
Hualien County in eastern Taiwan had the most indigenous people at 89,812, accounting for 18.8 percent of the country's total, followed by Taitung and Pingtung counties.
But Taitung County had the highest ratio of indigenous people, who accounted for 34 percent of the county's population.

DOC.HEADLINE: Online version of Formosa Post to be inaugurated July 1: ex-VP

TEXT.P: Former Vice President Annette Lu said Friday the online version of the Formosa Post, or Yushan Wubao in Mandarin, is scheduled to be launched July 1, with the print version being inaugurated Oct. 25.
Lu made the remarks after meeting with Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu on the eve of the latter's departure for a visit to the United States.
According to Lu, she plans to raise NT$300 million in the coming two months to finance the Formosa Post project.

Stressing that the planned paper will reflect core values of local society and views of grassroots people, Lu said the paper will not only recruit professional journalists but will also introduce a "citizen reporter" system to facilitate realization of its goals.

Lu, who traveled to Washington, D.C., last month to attend U.S. President Obama's inauguration, said her U.S. trip has solidified her resolve to establish the Formosa Post, as Taiwan needs a newspaper to unify people who love Taiwan, so as to normalize, globalize and enrich the country.
According to Lu, the newspaper, which will go on sale at 3 p.m. daily, will focus on local and international politics, culture, and science and technology.

Lu also urged Mayor Chen to speak for Taiwan's independent sovereignty during her U.S. trip to prevent the international community from misunderstanding that all of Taiwan's people agree with the China policy of Taiwan's incumbent administration, which she said leans toward China.
Both Lu and Chen are veteran members of the opposition pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: Signing of CECA should be approved by the people: opposition leader

TEXT.P: The government should not sign a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) with China without the social consensus of the Taiwanese people, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Saturday.

Tsai was responding to a newspaper report that quoted National Security Council Secretary-General Su Chi as having said that the government has come to a decision to sign a CECA with China in the future and that negotiations with China on the issue will begin through the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).
According to Tsai, the government should be "more prudent" about the issue as it would affect the country's economy and politics.
In addition, Tsai urged the government to inform and convince the public about the purpose of a CECA with China.
If the government signs a CECA without the consensus of the people, it will cause a negative impact on society, Tsai predicted.
According to Tsai, the signing of the CECA will involve delicate political issues that will cause a serious social conflict in Taiwan, if the government does not seek the approval of the people.

The discussion and evaluation of the feasibility of the signing of the CECA should be conducted in a transparent manner, said Tsai, arguing that this is the "only way" to let the Taiwanese people understand how the agreement will affect Taiwan economically, socially and politically.

Industry and business groups have been pushing for the government to forge closer economic links with China by signing a CECA and to move quickly to liberalize cross-Taiwan Strait trade through actions such as the removal of tariffs.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ambassador to Tuvalu boosts friendly ties through table tennis

TEXT.P: Republic of China Ambassador to Tuvalu Tien Chung-kwang promoted closer ties between the two nations by playing table tennis and singing karaoke with Tuvalu Prime Minister Apisai Ielemia, according to a report carried on the Ministry of Foreign Afairs' (MOFA's) Web site.
The report said the ambassador has aggressively promoted "table tennis and karaoke" diplomacy in the Polynesian island nation since he assumed office three months ago.

Tien acquired a new ping pong table in the hope of deepening the friendship between the embassy staff and Tuvalu officials after discovering that Ielemia is a table tennis lover, the report quoted staff at the ROC Embassy in Tuvalu as saying.
In addition, the report went on, karaoke equipment has become Tien's new diplomatic weapon that he uses during almost any diplomatic discussion or dealings.
The MOFA added that Ielemia will arrive in Taiwan Saturday evening for a five- day visit, a sign of his determination to further strengthen bilateral cooperation and friendship.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Japan working holiday program might be launched this summer

TEXT.P: Japan is expected to launch a working holiday program with Taiwan this summer to strengthen exchanges between young people of the two countries, according to the leader of apro-Taiwan Japanese parliamentary group that is promoting the program.
Takeo Hiranuma, head of the Japan-ROC Dietmen's Council, mentioned the possibility Thursday during a forum with a Taiwanese journalist delegation that is visiting Japan.
In addition to the working-holiday program, the council is also promoting within the Japanese government a proposal by Taiwan to open an office in the Hokkaido city of Sapporo, Hiranuma said.

Takao Fujii, another senior member of the council, told CNA that the working holiday program is aimed at allowing young people to work on a short-term basis while traveling in a foreign country and that Japan currently maintains working holiday programs with nine countries.

According to an official of the Tokyo-based Interchange Association -- a quasi-official organization authorized to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties -- like the working holiday programs with other countries, the one with Taiwan will target travelers aged under 35.
The details of the agreement will be hammered out through discussions with Taiwan, he added.
Hiranuma said his group has been working closely with Taiwan to try to solve various issues between the two sides.

For example, thanks to the council's efforts, the Japanese government granted visa-free entry to Japan by Taiwanese citizens in 2007, and the sides also recognized each other's driver's licenses that same year, Hiranuma said.
In the future, the council will also promote legislation to make possible an exhibition in Japan of artifacts from Taiwan's National Palace Museum, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait remittances through post offices to begin Feb. 18

TEXT.P: Services for wiring money from China to Taiwan and vice versa through post offices will begin Feb. 18 now that the complicated operating system has been set up, Taiwan's state-run Chunghua Post Co. announced Saturday.

It will mark the beginning of two-way remittance services across the Taiwan Strait, further promoting the cross-strait exchanges that had been blocked in many ways until President Ma Ying-jeou, who advocates closer Taiwan-China relations, was inaugurated last May.

The two sides launched direct postal links last Dec. 15 following an agreement signed last November by Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his Chinese counterpart, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits President Chen Yunlin.
The remittance services, however, could not be available at that time due to technical problems.

Chunghua Post began allowing people in Taiwan to wire money to China in 1991. Currently, there are 91 post offices around Taiwan offering the service, with the transfers in NT dollars exchanged into the Chinese yuan through Citibank before being wired to designated banks in China.
On average, NT$1.46 billion (US$42.9 million) is transferred to China from Taiwan through Chunghua Post every year
Once the direct post office-to-post office services are launched, the remittance procedure will be much shorter, although Citibank will continue to provide the currency exchanges.

Chunghwa Post Deputy General Manager Huang Shu-chien stated that the exchanges will be conducted in US dollars and that the value of each transfer from Taiwan to China will be limited to US$30,000 or less.
Huang said that despite remittances already being frequent between banks on the two sides, the new service will still be a convenient choice as there are over 37,000 post offices in China.
"Even though not all of them will offer the service, the number of places where individuals or enterprises can wire money to Taiwan will be increased," Huang noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to continue supporting cultural industry: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday that the government will continue to support the development of Taiwan's cultural and creative industries despite the recent economic slowdown.

Speaking at a Lunar New Year reception of the National Cultural Association (NCA) , Ma said he is well aware that the cultural industry has been greatly affected by the global economic downturn and he promised that the government will do everything in its power to support and promote the industry's development.

"Many cultural and artistic organizations have been forced to reduce or cancel their presentations or exhibitions due to the worsening economic situation, " said Ma, adding that Premier Liu Chao-shiuan and Vice President Vincent Siew are evaluating plans to ensure the survival and development of the industry.
According to Ma, the cultural innovation sector is one of the nation's most competitive industries, with great potential for future development in the global arena.

In addition, he said, Liu and Siew have been meeting with members and organizations of the cultural community to find feasible methods to assist the cultural industry as well as help them find ways to export their works, presentations, products and exhibitions abroad.

"With the support and assistance of the government, I am sure Taiwan's cultural industry will not only successfully ride out the global economic downturn but will also develop into one of Taiwan's most important industries," said Ma.

Ma was named chairman of the NCA last November. The organization's main mission is to promote cultural and artistic activities by integrating the efforts of the government, local enterprises, civic organizations and cultural organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to watch U.S. state secretary's Asia visit closely
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 14 (CNA) 02/14/09 18:39:52 (By Lillian Lin, Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will carefully monitor an upcoming visit to Asia by new U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and expects her to pay attention to cross-Taiwan Strait relations while in China, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Saturday.
According to MOFA spokesman Henry Chen, the fact that Clinton has made Asia the destination of her first overseas trip demonstrates the importance that the United States attaches to the region.
The government hopes the visit will lead to favorable interactions with Asian nations and help bring issues concerning regional peace and stability into the spotlight, he added.
Clinton is scheduled to depart Sunday for her visit, which will take her to Japan, Indonesia, South Korea and China.

During a speech Friday delivered to the Asia Society in New York, Clinton said she is ready to deliver to Asia "a message about America's desire for more rigorous and persistent commitment and engagement, " with issues to be addressed covering the economic crisis, climate change, clean energy and the non- proliferation of nuclear weapons.
On relations with China, Clinton said that maintaining a positive, cooperative relationship with Beijing is vital to peace and prosperity in the region and the rest of the world.

She noted that China has asserted itself in positive ways as chair of the Six- Party talks and in its participation in international peacekeeping efforts, and will also resume mid-level military-to-military discussions with the United States later this month.
"And we look forward to further improved relations across the Taiwan Strait," she added.

Beijing suspended military-to-military exchanges and nonproliferation talks with Washington late last year to protest against the latest arms sales to Taiwan by the administration of then-U.S. President George W. Bush.

The United States, which is committed under the terms of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) to help Taiwan maintain a sufficient defense capability, has long been Taiwan's most important weapons supplier.

Asked during a background briefing Friday in Washington, D.C. if the new administration of President Barack Obama will suspend arms sales to Taiwan, a senior U.S. State Department official said this will not happen because the policy "has been consistent with the TRA and the communiques (with China)."
The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said there will not be any major change to U.S. policy toward Taiwan, as it has been very successful and has helped maintain peace in the region.

The official's remarks came one day after Dennis Blair, the new director of national intelligence, reaffirmed Washington's commitment to help Taiwan maintain a military balance with China, which has been continuing its military modernization.

"Taiwan should not be so defenseless that it feels that it has to do everything that China says. On the other hand, China cannot be so overwhelming that it can bully Taiwan, " Blair said during a hearing held by the Senate Committee on Intelligence.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 2,000 plant trees in Nantou to show love for land

TEXT.P: More than 2,000 people took part in a major tree-planting activity in Nantou County, central Taiwan Saturday in a bid to show their love and care for the land.

Council of Agriculture (COA) Vice Chairman Hu Hsing-hua, speaking at the activity that was sponsored by the council and the Nantou county government, noted that "green forestation" is part of the government's ambitious "i-Taiwan 12 projects" program and is a move designed to protect the environment.
"The government expects 400 communities around the island to take part in the tree planting campaign that will continue throughout the year," Hu said.
The government is planning to plant forest on 60,000 hectares of lowlands within eight years and to establish three 1,000-hectare forest recreation areas, he added.
He urged the public to take part in the campaign to get everyone to plant at least one tree in their lifetime to help create a green homeland.
"By pooling our strength, we can soon realize the dream of a green Taiwan," he said.
Meanwhile, the Forestry Bureau under the COA said it will organize more than 20 tree sapling donation activities around the nation as part of the campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: CECA issue not on agenda of third SEF-ARATS talks: MAC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 14 (CNA) 02/14/09 20:27:09 (FTA) and a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Arrangement (CECP) (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Topics to be discussed in a planned third meeting between the heads of the two intermediary bodies on either side of the Taiwan Strait have been set, and do not include the issue of a proposed Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) between the two sides, a spokesman for the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Saturday.

MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun made the announcement Saturday after a local newspaper quoted National Security Council Secretary-General Su Chi as saying that the government has decided to sign a CECA with China at some point in the future.

Su also said that negotiations with China on the issue will begin through the intermediary Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).
Liu told CNA that forging a CECA with China was part of the election campaign platform of President Ma Ying-jeou.

Carrying out the policy is a goal that every government agency should seek to achieve, he said, describing CECA as a vital matter for the normalization of trade and economic ties between Taiwan and China.

However, an agreement of this kind covers a wide range of different subjects, so that the content and even its final designation require discussions among relevant agencies before it can be brought up in SEF-ARATS talks, Liu said.

He further said the issues on the agenda of the third round of talks between SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and ARATS President Chen Yunlin slated for later this year have been firmed up and include joint efforts by the two sides to crack down on crime, regular air and boat services, financial cooperation and the opening of Taiwan to funds from China.
Whether or not to have the CECA issue discussed in a further round of negotiations in the latter half of the year will depend on the results of the upcoming third-round talks, Liu added.

The CECA would allow the two sides to offer each other economic and trade privileges, including the lifting of tariffs on imports and non-tariff trade barriers, or to further hold existing tariff and trade policies.

According to Ma, who broached the idea during his election campaign, CECA is a third choice along with a free trade agreement like the one China signed with Hong Kong in 2003. A CECA, the government believes, would avoid the sticky "state-to-state" dispute and would also ensure that Taiwan's sovereignty was not cast into doubt.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei zoo pandas make outdoor debut

TEXT.P: The pandas at the Taipei Zoo -- Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan -- were released into their outdoor exhibition area Saturday, their first chance to enjoy the fresh air since they were brought to Taiwan last Dec. 23 after being given by Beijing in a goodwill gesture.

The female panda, Yuan Yuan, appeared slightly shocked by the voices of visitors, zoo spokesman Chin Shi-chien said, pointing out that until that day, they had been kept in a soundproof indoor enclosure since the panda hall was opened to the public Jan. 26.

The panda was not used to its new noisier environment, he noted, adding that in future, the zoo will broadcast recordings of the zoo visitors in the indoor area to allow the pandas to adapt to the noises, he added.

As the outdoor temperature was around 20 Celsius degrees -- the ideal climate for pandas -- the zoo decided to let them out into the outdoor area that has been constructed to resemble the animals' natural habitat.
According to the zoo, the pair ran back and forth in the outdoor area, appearing excited with their new living space.
More than 330,000 people have visited the pandas since they went on display for the first time over the Chinese New Year holiday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's top museum head stresses parity in cross-strait exchanges
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Feb. 14 (CNA) 02/14/09 20:37:38 (By Chou Hui-ying and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taipei-based National Palace Museum (NPM) Director Chou Kung-shin emphasized the requirement for equal standing in engagements across the Taiwan Strait Saturday as she arrived in Beijing to promote bilateral cultural exchanges.
Chou's visit marks the first formal engagement between the staff of the NPM and its Chinese counterpart, the Palace Museum in Beijing, since Taiwan and China split in a civil war 60 years ago.
As the first NPM head to visit China in six decades, Chou was circumspect toward potentially sensitive issues regarding the museum's designation and her capacity in engagements with China.

In a brief encounter with reporters at her Beijing hotel, Chou characterized the engagements as "museum to museum" -- seen as a veiled emphasis on parity in exchanges between the NPM and the Palace Museum, both of which hold part of the imperial art collection of China.
Chou also said she is hopeful that her visit will contribute to the establishment of a mechanism for wide-ranging cooperation between the two museums.
"People on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will definitely benefit greatly from cooperation between our two museums, " she told reporters.
Chou was greeted by Zheng Xinmiao, curator of Beijing's Palace Museum, who presided over a welcoming ceremony in a VIP room at Beijing Capital International Airport for Chou and her entourage.

In contrast to Taiwan's passionate attention to Chou's visit, Beijing kept a low profile toward the event, backpedaling on its previous promise to allow journalists to cover the airport welcoming ceremony for Chou and her group.
A news conference scheduled to take place Sunday after a meeting between staff members of the two museums was also canceled.

Asked about his views on the cancellation, Su Ching-feng, director of the NPM's public affairs office who is accompanying Chou on the visit, said only that the delegation respects its host's arrangement.
The delegation was scheduled to tour the Palace Museum in Beijing Sunday and to holds talks with Chinese museum curators later in the day on future cooperation projects.
High on the agenda will be the possibility of Beijing lending 29 Qing dynasty artworks for a three-month exhibition that will open at the NPM in Taipei in October.
Should that happen, it will mark the first time that the imperial Chinese art collection, is partially exhibited together again after having been divided for 60 years by war and political turbulence.
The talks will also cover cooperation in art conservation, publications and promotions.
Taipei's National Palace Museum is home to the cream of the 1,000-year Chinese art collection, while the Palace Museum in Beijing holds most of the rest of the collection.

DOC.HEADLINE: Charity walk to be held in Taichung March 8

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu and several charity organizations called Saturday for public support for a "10,000 person charity walk" scheduled for March 8.
They made the appeal at a press conference convened by the World Vision Taiwan charity and the Christian community in central Taiwan's largest city.
Saying that without a happy family there can be no happy children, they asked everyone to take part in the activity, with each participant paying a NT$100 registration fee.
"The proceeds of the charity walk will be donated to World Vision Taiwan for its work protecting abused children and caring for youngsters," an official of the charity organization said.
World Vision Taiwan officials said that its hotline providing counselling services to underprivileged families received nearly 1.5 times as many calls in 2008 compared to the number received in 2007.

Among the calls, those who needed urgent assistance for economic reasons and those who were assessed to be in need of long-term financial support nearly doubled, showing the impact of the current economic crisis.
Some churches in Taichung are also cooperating with World Vision Taiwan to provide after-school services to children from underprivileged families.
It is estimated that more than 1,300 children in greater Taichung area go to these churches every day to receive care and assistance with their homework.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Songshan Airport to host Japan-bound flights

TEXT.P: Taipei Songshan Airport, which now mainly host domestic and cross-Taiwan Strait flights, may begin hosting Japan-bound flights from next year, civil aviation officials said Saturday.

According to the officials, opening flight services between Songshan Airport in downtown Taipei and Haneda Airport in downtown Tokyo will be high on the agenda of a new round of Taiwan-Japan consultations on amending their bilateral aviation agreement that are set to take place in Tokyo next week.

Although the two sides have tentatively agreed to the opening of Songshan-Haneda flight services, the officials said the actual launch of such services will not begin until next year when a new runway construction project at Haneda Airport is completed.
In consideration of the two airports' limited capacity, the officials said each airline from both sides will be allowed to operate only one round-trip flight per day.
Other issues to be discussed at the upcoming aviation talks will include the possibility of raising the number of flights to Japan's Narita International Airport, the officials said.
On the Songshan Airport's expansion project, the officials said the airport's first terminal will be transformed into a facility hosting flights to neighboring countries in the Asia-Pacific region.

But as the Taipei city government has listed the facade of the 40-year-old Songshan Airport as a historical structure, the officials said the Civil Aeronautics Administration is still mulling how to avoid damaging the historical structure while carrying out the expansion project.

DOC.HEADLINE: Political contributions database to be open for public scrutiny

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan's political contributions database will be open for public scrutiny from Monday, staff of the country's supreme watchdog body said Saturday.

In accordance with the Political Contribution Act that took effect in April 2004, the Control Yuan has completed documentation of donors and spending of political donations for candidates running in political elections since then.

Starting Feb.16, local people interested in learning about donors and spending of political contributions to candidates running in political elections since April 2004 will be able to pore over relevant records on two computers installed at the Control Yuan's financial assets declaration department.

The Control Yuan database contains information about individual and corporate donors and amounts of contributions to election campaign hopefuls who had opened special accounts to receive political donations.
The databank also provides detailed information about how such contributions have been spent, Control Yuan staff said.

As the Political Contribution Act took effect in April 2004, the database did not have records concerning political contributions to former President Chen Shui-bian when he ran in the March 2004 presidential election.

But local people will be able to get information about who donated money to President Ma Ying-jeou in the run-up to the March 22, 2008 presidential election as well as the amount and how the money had been used, Control Yuan officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 15, or the 21st day of the first month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1564: Galileo Galilei, the Italian astronomer and physicist who was the first to use a telescope to study the stars, is born.
1748: Jeremy Bentham, English philosopher, is born. He was a pioneer of utilitarianism, an ethical doctrine which holds that the best action is one that will result in the greatest happiness and least pain for the greatest number of people.
1898: The U.S. battleship Maine, which was sent to Cuba to protect American citizens during the Cuban rebellion against Spanish rule, explodes and sinks in Havana Harbor as 260 lose their lives.
1912: Yuan Shih-kai is elected provisional president by the provisional Senate.
1922: The Permanent Court of International Justice, established by the League of Nations, holds its first session in The Hague, capital of the Netherlands.
1928: After some 70 years of efforts, the Oxford English Dictionary is published.
1933: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt escapes an assassination attempt in Miami by Italian-born anarchist Giuseppe Zangara.
1936: China's first international long-distance telephone service between Shanghai and Tokyo begins operation.
1942: Thousands of British troops in Singapore surrender to Japanese forces in World War II.
1944: The Allies begin to bomb the German-held strategic position of Monte Cassino in Italy as some 1,000 British bombers pound Berlin, Germany. Meanwhile U.S. troops recapture the Solomon Islands in the Pacific in World War II.
1945: British forces reach the River Rhine in their advance toward Berlin during World War II.
1946: The world's first computer is born at a university in the U.S. state of Pennsylvania.
1952: Greece and Turkey formally join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).
1965: Canada adopts a new national flag with red and white colors as its base and a maple leaf at the center.
1965: Mainland Chinese Foreign Minister Chen Yi says in Beijing that peaceful coexistence with the United States is out of the question.
1966: South Korean President Park Chung Hee arrives in Taipei for a four-day state visit.
1970: A Dominican Airlines DC-9 crashes into the sea, killing all 102 aboard.
1973: Henry A. Kissinger, the United States' national security adviser under President Richard M. Nixon, visits the Chinese mainland.
1973: The Republic of China and Paraguay sign an agreement on technical cooperation at Asuncion.
1974: The Chinese Petroleum Corporation signs an oil exploration agreement with two Philippine corporations.
1974: Arthur Pothuije, director of the new U.S. Trade Center in Taipei, arrives with his wife.
1974: Sheik Mohammed Aba Al-Khail, Saudi Arabian minister of state for finance and national economy, arrives in Taipei for talks on economic cooperation.
1975: Kuo Chie-hsiung of the Republic of China fires a record 6-under-par 66 for an eight-stroke victory in the Philippines Open Golf Championship.
1976: Clement C. Conger, curator of the U.S. White House and the diplomatic reception room of the U.S. State Department, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1989: The Soviet Union withdraws its remaining soldiers from Afghanistan, ending nine years of military intervention.
1994: Pyongyang agrees to open part of its nuclear program to international inspection.
1995: A fire at a restaurant in Taichung City claims 64 lives in one of Taiwan's worst fire disasters in recent years.
1999: Henry Kendall, a Nobel Prize-winning physicist, dies at the age of 72. He is considered a pioneer of the environmental movement among scientists.
2000: The two new naval patrol boats, the Chinchiang and the Hsianchiang, are formally commissioned by the ROC Navy.
2001: The sixth Japanese-Taiwan academic symposium, sponsored by the Asia- Pacific Forum of Japan, is held in Tokyo, attended by about 50 scholars and experts from the two countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In education, sentiment is called out by the study of poetry; judgment is formed by the study of the arts; and education of the character is completed by the study of music."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Songshan Airport to host Japan-bound flights

TEXT.P: Taipei Songshan Airport, which now mainly host domestic and cross-Taiwan Strait flights, may begin hosting Japan-bound flights from next year, civil aviation officials said Saturday.

According to the officials, opening flight services between Songshan Airport in downtown Taipei and Haneda Airport in downtown Tokyo will be high on the agenda of a new round of Taiwan-Japan consultations on amending their bilateral aviation agreement that are set to take place in Tokyo next week.

Although the two sides have tentatively agreed to the opening of Songshan-Haneda flight services, the officials said the actual launch of such services will not begin until next year when a new runway construction project at Haneda Airport is completed.
In consideration of the two airports' limited capacity, the officials said each airline from both sides will be allowed to operate only one round-trip flight per day.
Other issues to be discussed at the upcoming aviation talks will include the possibility of raising the number of flights to Japan's Narita International Airport, the officials said.
On the Songshan Airport's expansion project, the officials said the airport's first terminal will be transformed into a facility hosting flights to neighboring countries in the Asia-Pacific region.

But as the Taipei city government has listed the facade of the 40-year-old Songshan Airport as a historical structure, the officials said the Civil Aeronautics Administration is still mulling how to avoid damaging the historical structure while carrying out the expansion project.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Cancer-fighting drug abuser finds hope by helping others

TEXT.P: CNA staff writer

Su Kai-nung visits drug detoxification centers regularly to share his experience in kicking the habit. He frequents hospitals to cheer up cancer patients by soloing on the saxophone and he serves as a division chief at a foundation established for the welfare and wellbeing of the physically and mentally challenged.
Su -- a "veteran" drug addict suffering from late-stage lung cancer -- works like a dervish every day, but feels happy, really happy.

He has been chosen out of some 600 candidates nationwide as one of the six individuals to be conferred Feb. 21 with the prestigious Chou Ta-Kuan Award of Hope this year for his courage facing life's challenges and his fervent compassion and determination to help others.

Viewing the handsome -- even elegant -- young man playing What a Wonderful World on sax, one can hardly imagine that the 32-year-old has spent most of his life in jail, depriving him of a normal education, and that, having nearly burnt himself out thanks to the scourge of drugs, he faces his deteriorating condition alone.

Mocking his involvement in illicit narcotics during the "dark days, " Su said during a visit to a drug abuse treatment center that he could have been awarded a master's degree in drug abuse. Yet, he preaches that the scourge in one's heart is even harder to get rid of than kicking the habit. "If you think you can't do it, you won't."
Encouraging other addicts to believe that they can do it, he also exhorted them to accept help from others. "You must accept others' help, because you can't do it alone," he said.

Su recalled that he spent much of his childhood in a state of fear, dread or high anxiety. After his parents divorced, he lived with his grandmother, who became his only relative in his formative years.
He remembered that he was always the troublemaker in the eyes of his teachers in junior high school, from which he failed to graduate.

He was in jail for the first time on charges of using and possessing illicit narcotics at the age of 13. Since then, he split his time between prisons and hospitals, as he was not only a drug abuser but was also involved in street violence.

At the beginning, he said, the drugs could really calm him, make him feel carefree and forget about who he was and what he should do. Months later, he became a slave to drugs and could not live without them. A few years later, he lost both his health and his girlfriend of many years.
Su said his grandmother, who died a couple of years ago, was his first savior, adding that despite his leading a life like hell, his grandmother, a devout Christian, had never forsaken him.

He said kicking the habit is hard but not impossible. He recalled that his grandmother tried numerous times to bring him to the Lord for salvation, but in vain -- until he attended a sermon in Taipei given by an African American evangelical minister from a church in New York. Toward the end of the service, he went to the front to receive a prayer said by the minister in a bid to lead him out of darkness.
At that juncture, he said, he felt so clean inside and so happy from within that he was on his knees crying like a baby, and for the first time, he met God and he knew he was "saved."
From that day forth, Su cut all his links with the drug world and also stopped smoking, relying on God to get him through his cold turkey.

Over the past six years of being clean, Su has worked ceaselessly as a missionary of God, visiting correction centers to meet inmates, and hospitals to console patients, as well as working as a volunteer for several organizations for the disabled.
Even today, tears fill his eyes when he remembers his grandmother, who he described as spending hours on the road bringing him heavy sacks of fruit when he was in prison.
In a further cruel twist of fate, when Su found the meaning of life by helping people, as well as getting married, he was diagnosed last October to be in the late stages of his cancer.
Can the "angel" make it? If you believe in a god, you can perhaps offer him a prayer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan grants Slovenia visa-free privileges

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Sunday that effective immediately, Slovenia passport holders will no longer require visas to visit Taiwan for less than 30 days.

Anne Hung, director-general of MOFA's Department of European Affairs, said the decision was based on the friendly relations that Slovenia shares with Taiwan and the fact that the move poses no threat to Taiwan's national security.
Slovenia will become the seventh Central or Eastern European country to enjoy visa-free privileges, Hung said, following Poland, Slovakia, Hungary, Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia.
In total, 27 European Union nations have been granted visa-free privileges, with Bulgaria, Romania and Cyprus being considered for the same treatment, Hung said.

She expressed hope that the extensive inclusion of Europe's Schengen states in Taiwan's visa exemption policy, as well as a government move to issue "ePassports," or chip-embedded passports, will give Taiwan more leverage in negotiating for reciprocal treatment with the European Union (EU).
Taiwan's low visa refusal rate recorded in the EU, at less than 1 percent, will also help back up the government's efforts, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung City committed to opening penguin house by year-end

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu pledged Sunday to open a penguin house, the largest in Taiwan, late this year or early next year.

Construction of the penguin house, located within the city's traditional fish market -- which is awaiting refurbishment -- is slated to be completed in October at the earliest or early next year, Hu said.
The mayor made the remarks while answering questions from reporters at a ground- breaking ceremony for the city's tourism "fisherman's wharf," to be located adjacent to the fish market.
The Taichung city government hopes both the penguin hall the artificial wharf will become the central Taiwan city's major tourist attractions.
Once the penguin hall is completed, it will host a variety of exhibitions, specimens and research information related to the bird, Hu said.
The Taichung city is planning to lease popular king penguins from the Taipei city zoo, he went on. "Taichung's penguin house will definitely be opened before the next Lunar New Year," he added.
Within three years, the city's penguin house is projected to purchase five or six species of penguin, he said.

He also elaborated on Taichung City's decision to construct a penguin house rather than an originally planned marine life education hall, explaining that the change of mind was made on the grounds that Pingtung County in southern Taiwan already has a marine life education facility.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung City starts building tourism wharf

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu presided Sunday over a ground-breaking ceremony for a tourism fisherman's wharf to be located next to the city's traditional fish market, in an effort to build a new landmark for the central Taiwan city's tourism promotion drive.

In addition to a penguin hall that will be built within the traditional fish market, Hu said, an artificial fisherman's wharf will be constructed on a plot of 5,000 pings (1 ping equals to 3.305 square meters) next to the traditional fish market, with a budget of NT$100 billion (US$2.94 billion) earmarked for the project.
Hu expressed hope that the two projects will help forge a new image and new tourist spots for Taichung City upon their completion, slated for October or November next year.
The city government will also hold a contest to select a name for the wharf, in an effort to increase public awareness of the project.

According to fish market corp. chairman Lee Jen-teh, a retail center for fish and farm produce, as well as a restaurant, will be established at the fisherman's wharf. A ship-shaped building and a square with ponds will also be constructed.

Taichung City has a population of more than 1 million and has long been considered by many people as the most livable city in Taiwan due to its mild weather, beautiful landscape and convenient traffic network, and the penguin house and wharf are expected to provide a major tourism boost.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA order-soliciting plan begins to bear fruit

TEXT.P: A plan for an export-boosting project that was initiated by the administration late last year has already begun to bear fruit, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Sunday.

With the efforts of the Purchases and Sample Exhibitions Plan -- sponsored by the semi-official TAITRA to solicit export orders for Taiwanese exporters and manufacturers -- at least four major buyers from around the world have placed orders or have engaged in serious talks with local exporters, TAITRA Secretary- General Chao Yung-chuan said.

The plan is part of a three-year, NT$8.53 billion (US$250.94 million) project called the New Zheng He Project launched by the Ministry of Economic Affairs late last year aimed at turning Taiwan's export trade from negative to positive growth this year.

Wolseley UK, the world's No. 1 distributor of heating and plumbing products and a leading supplier of building products to the professional market, has recently placed orders worth US$8 million with Taiwanese suppliers for nuts and bolts as well as other related products, including bathroom fittings and lighting components, according to Chao.
"Wolseley is expected to place new orders worth some US$10 million with Taiwan shortly," Chao noted.
Wolseley, whose global procurement topped US$27.5 billion in 2007, is expected to make purchases in Taiwan this year to the tune of US$40 million.
Meanwhile, Chao said, two procurement representatives from Poland's TIM S.A. are scheduled to visit Taiwan Feb. 17-19 for talks on procurement of electronics and electrical engineering products.
Nearly 100 local companies have signed up to take part in the talks.
TIM S.A.'s annual business turnover has averaged US$200 million over the past several years and the company has a staff of more than 400.

It will be the first time has TIM S.A. has approached Taiwan for supplies, Chao went on, adding that deals with the company will serve as a litmus test for Taiwan's potential in cracking the vast Eastern European market.

Meanwhile, Specialty Bolt, the largest nuts and bolts dealer in the New England region of the United States, is scheduled to host a sample display workshop at TAITRA's office in the southern port city of Kaohsiung Feb. 17.
So far, over 50 companies in the area have registered to take part in the workshop, said Wu Chun-ze, head of the TAITRA Kaohsiung Office.
Specialty Bolt, an important supplier of hardware products to OEM plants in the United States, Canada and Mexico, purchases about US$18 million-worth of products from around the world every year.

According to TAITRA officials, representatives of Mexico's Grupo Tutsa, a leading nuts and bolts dealer, have been visiting central and southern Taiwan since Feb. 9 for procurement talks with local suppliers.
Wu said that since their visit began, the representatives have canceled a plan to visit Hangzhou in China.

Under the New Zheng He Project -- named after a Ming Dynasty Chinese explorer -- the administration will assist Taiwanese suppliers and manufacturers to produce more goods for export, with the country's entire export trade hopefully topping NT$500 billion in 2009, thus turning around the poor performance in the export sector due to the global economic recession.

The ambitious export-bolstering project will also direct Taiwanese exporters and manufacturers to emerging markets beyond China, including India, Russia, Brazil, the Middle East and countries in Southeast Asia.

Zheng He was an official who lived during the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644) . He led a giant fleet of Chinese vessels to Southeast Asia, from where they are believed to have reached as far as the west coast of Africa. He was instrumental in building China into one of the maritime superpowers between the 14th and 17th centuries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese medical team concludes mission to Kenya

TEXT.P: A non-government Taiwanese medical team that provided free medical services to some 5,000 people during a just concluded two-week mission to Kenya returned to Taiwan Friday.

The team, composed of 27 medical personnel from various medical centers, as well as volunteers, was organized by the Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps (TRMPC), a private non-profit organization dedicated to improving the quality of life through the provision of medical services at home and abroad.
The team arrived in Kenya late January, when the African country was plagued by massive food shortages due to a prolonged drought, according to TRMPC President Liu Chi-chun.
The team held 10 free clinics in several towns near Lake Victoria, where there are large numbers of AIDS patients, orphans and starving people, according to Liu.

Liu recalled that when an overturned gasoline tanker exploded in the town of Molo Feb. 1, leaving 113 dead and about 200 injured, his team, despite being nearby, was unable to provide aid as it was unaware of the accident.

The TRMPC has rich experience in extending emergency medical relief, such as providing post-war aid in Kosovo, providing medical treatment for victims of the South Asia tsunami and the Indonesia earthquake, Liu said, adding that if the team had learned about the explosion, it could have provided humanitarian relief.

Since February 2000, the TRMPC has arranged medical missions every year to African countries during the Chinese New Year holiday. It has provided services in Swaziland, Malawi, Ghana, Senegal, Gambia, Liberia and Somalia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport recruiting management experts

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) will recruit 16 management experts to serve on a task force that will oversee the conversion of Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport into a state-owned company, ministry officials said Sunday.

The officials pointed out that the legislature passed the Statute For Developing International Airport Park in January and that the some MOTC officials have been appointed to serve on the task force to transform the Taoyuan Airport administration into a state-owned company in line with the statute.

They added that the task force needs 16 experts in the fields of airport administration and management, aviation transportation, banking and finance, and legal counseling, all of whom will enjoy above-average salary scales.
"After the airport company is established, the 16 management experts will become the elite of its staff," said one of the officials.
The MOTC is expected to post a recruitment bulletin on its Web site soon, the officials added.

Under the conversion plan, the Taoyuan Airport administration is scheduled to become a state-owned company in 2010, and the 400 workers currently employed by the airport will be given the option to stay on or retire, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Housing subsidy scheme for young couples to open for applications

TEXT.P: A government housing subsidy program to help young couples renting property or borrowing to buy a home will open for applications Monday, the Ministry of the Interior announced Sunday.

Under the program, the government will provide 10,000 openings for a NT$2 million (US$58,823) government-subsidized home loan that will be interest-free for the first two years, and 20,000 opportunities for a rental subsidy of NT$3,600 per month for two years, according to the ministry.

Eligible applicants for the preferential home loan will include middle-and-low income earners aged 20 to 40 who got married within two years of the date of application and who are new homebuyers, or those aged 20 to 45 who have children and are seeking a new home.
Based on the income criteria set by the ministry, households whose annual incomes rank below 80 percent of wage earners in their area of residence are eligible to apply for the home loans.
Falling within this range will be households whose annual income does not exceed NT$2.31 million in Taipei City, NT$1.72 million in Kaohsiung City and NT$1.52 million in the rest of the country.

As for the rental subsidy, applicants must be couples aged 20 to 40 who were married within two years of the application date, have no their own home and whose household annual incomes fall in the bottom 60 percent of wage earners in their place of residence.

Falling within this range will be households earning no more than NT$1.70 million per year in Taipei City, NT$1.21 million per year in Kaohsiung City and NT$1.1 million per year in the rest of the country, according to the ministry.
Interested families can apply for the loans at their local household registration offices, the ministry said.

Households who are granted subsidies will be required to attend courses related to building families offered by the ministry or risk losing eligibility to claim the subsidies in the second year, the ministry noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 500 foreign companies to take part in Sourcing Taiwan 2009

TEXT.P: More than 500 companies from 60 countries around the world have registered to attend Sourcing Taiwan 2009, a function aimed at creating partnerships between Taiwanese manufacturers and foreign buyers for increased trade exchanges, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Sunday.
A total of 507 foreign companies are expected to be represented at the event slated to be held at the Taipei World Trade Center (TWTC) at the end of March, a TAITRA official said.

The number of attending companies is far greater than originally anticipated, the official noted, adding that the council originally targeted some 350 foreign companies to help shore up the country's export trade.
Of the 507 companies, 195 are major players in global trade, with annual business turnovers exceeding US$100 million, the official said.

One-on-one trade talks are slated to be held at the TWTC March 31, enabling some 2,000 Taiwanese manufacturers or exporters to meet with the foreign buyers for trade talks. TAITRA estimates that some US$120 billion (US$3.53 billion) in trade opportunities are expected to be generated from the talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese nationals deported for holding fake Taiwan IDs: official

TEXT.P: Two Chinese children nabbed at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport Saturday for holding fake Taiwanese identification were deported to China the following day, according to the National Immigration Agency (NIA).

The 16-year-old high school students, a boy and a girl, were caught in possession of bogus Taiwan passports, identification cards and fake official stamps on their boarding passes while trying to clear customs, the NIA officials said.
The officials said the children, who had arrived from Hong Kong, were caught while attempting to transfer to a flight to Guam, with the hope of later traveling on to the continental U.S.

The NIA said that a human trafficking organization might have tried to take advantage of what they perceived as a higher likelihood of the U.S. granting asylum or residency to illegal immigrants of a younger age.
After arranging the deportation, the officials said they were still seeking the mastermind behind the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president's lawyers complain about mute deposition disc

TEXT.P: Lawyers defending former President Chen Shui-bian and his wife in a series of corruption cases complained Sunday that while going through the recorded depositions of witnesses, they found a 30-minute section on one of the discs that had no sound.

Cheng Wen-lung, one of Chen's lawyers, expressed suspicion that the Special Investigation Division (SID) under the Supreme Prosecutors Office might have tampered with the recording to eradicate testimony favorable to the former president.
However, SID Director Chen Yun-nan said the prosecutors in his division would never mute a deposition on purpose and that the problem could be due to malfunctioning of the video recording equipment.

Chen Yun-nan said he had not examined the disc in question and suspected that the soundless part could simply be an intermission videotaped by a camcorder left running after the deposition was temporarily halted.

He added that his division will look into the matter and establish the cause of the problem. As for whether the disc could be considered effective evidence, he pointed out that that is up to the court to decide.

According to Chen Yun-nan, in addition to the recording on disc, the deposition was also transcribed to ensure the accuracy of the testimony. Furthermore, the lawyers of the former president can always cross-examine the witness in question -- Taiwan Cement Corp. Chairman Koo Cheng-yun, who was found by the prosecutors to have transferred NT$300 million (US$8.81 million) in 2003 as bribes to the former president and his wife for a land procurement deal in Taoyuan County.

According to the prosecutors, the former president used his position to push for the government's purchase of the land for the construction of a science park after his wife Wu Shu-jen allegedly accepted bribes through the landowner.

The land procurement scandal is one of a series of criminal cases involving the former president and his family. The charges against them in the other cases include embezzlement, money laundering and forgery.
The former president and his wife have been indicted for embezzling NT$104 million (US$3.12 million) from the president's special discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000 to 2008.
They are also accused of taking NT$90.93 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project.
Chen Shui-bian is being held in custody at a Taipei County detention center. He is Taiwan's first former president to face trial on criminal offenses and if convicted, could face a life sentence.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU plans to offer free classes for unemployed office workers

TEXT.P: The prestigious National Taiwan University is planning to offer free undergraduate and postgraduate classes to office workers who have recently lost their jobs or who are on unpaid leave as a result of the global economic recession.
According to university officials, about 1,100 courses are expected to be offered, with about 10 percent of the available spaces in each class reserved for non-NTU students.
The courses will range from electrical engineering, information technology, engineering and law to social sciences and literature, the officials said.

Students will be required to pay NT$2,000 for each course upon enrollment as a security guarantee that they will complete the course. The money will be repaid when the student completes the course and gains the requisite credits, the officials said.
Meanwhile, the NTU School of Professional and Continuing Studies is cooperating with Chunghwa Telecom to offer online classes on economics, finance and management.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government soliciting votes for Yushan listing as world wonder

TEXT.P: The Construction and Planning Administration under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) urged Taiwanese people Sunday to vote for Yushan, or Jade Mountain, in a global contest for a new listing of seven world wonders.

The 3,952 meter Yushan -- Taiwan's highest peak -- is the only site in the country with preliminary shortlisting among 261 natural heritage sites listed by New Seven Wonders, a non-profit Swiss foundation, agency officials said.

As foundation experts will nominate 21 candidate sites out of 77 selected through a second stage of public voting on the Internet before July 7, agency officials called on the public to take part in the global vote through various Web sites, including www.new7wonders.com or another Web site run by the Yushan National Park Administration in conjunction with the New Seven Wonders foundation.

Although the government and private sectors have in recent years been seeking to have Yushan listed as a world heritage site recognized by the United Nations, agency officials said the goal remains some way off due to political pressure, as Taiwan is not a member of the world body.
The officials voiced hope that the global popularity vote will help Taiwan increase its international visibility and attract foreign tourists to the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 1,300 top Japanese car salesmen on incentive tour of Taiwan

TEXT.P: The first batch of a total of 1,310 top sales representatives from Japan's Daihatsu Motor Co. Ltd. arrived in Taiwan Sunday for a four-day incentive tour, the Bureau of Tourism under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) reported that day.

The group of over 400 salesmen received a warm reception organized by the bureau that included traditional dragon and lion dancing at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport in northern Taiwan. Bureau officials also displayed banners to welcome the visitors and presented them with gifts upon their arrival.
According to bureau officials, Daihatsu chose Taiwan for the third time as the destination for its outstanding workers due to the country's delicious food, good social order and hospitality.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung harbor working to strengthen competitiveness

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau is accelerating the implementation of several construction and dredging programs at the southern harbor to enhance its competitiveness, a bureau official said Sunday.

Reeling from the effects of the global economic downturn, the harbor handled 9.67 million TEUs (twenty-foot equivalent units) last year, a drop of 5 percent from the previous year. The harbor is designed to handle 10 million TEUs per year, according to the official.

The harbor lost its place as one of the world's 10 busiest container ports due to the fall in container volume last year, the official went on, attributing this to stiff competition from other major ports in Pacific Asia, an exodus of local enterprises, China's magnetic effect and the development of China's harbor shipping industry, as well as soaring oil prices last year and lower shipping demand due to the global crisis.

In an attempt to counter these setbacks, the bureau will speed up the pace of several construction projects, including the first-phase construction of an intercontinental container center and the establishment of four new deep-water wharves slated to be completed in 2013.

After completion, the new wharves will be able to accommodate large container ships capable of carrying 10,000 TEUs and will increase the harbor's cargo- handling capacity by 2 million TEUs per year, according to the official.

The bureau will also speed up work on two dredging programs at the harbor's first and second seaway areas designed to widen the two navigation channels to 14-15 meters, allowing them to accommodate larger vessels, the official said.

Bureau officials will visit foreign shipping companies to increase their understanding of the environmental advantages of the harbor and to seek business opportunities. The bureau also plans to set up a cooperation system to attract private companies to take on the construction projects, and to relax regulations on leasing the harbor's facilities, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Fan' tours helping Taiwan's tourism: agency

TEXT.P: "Fan" tours designed for overseas followers of Taiwanese pop stars have worked their way to becoming a strong tourist draw, increasing the number of visitors to Taiwan from Japan and Korea despite the economic slowdown, a government agency reported Sunday.

The tourism industry worldwide has been battered by last year's soaring oil prices and the global sluggish economy, but Taiwan still managed to receive over 1.08 million visitors from Japan over the past year, according to the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.

The figure was a drop of 6.83 percent from the year-earlier level, and the bureau described attracting 1.08 million as "not an easy task" as the overall number of Japanese outbound travelers saw a decline of 7.6 percent compared to the previous year.

Meanwhile, the number of Korean visitors to Taiwan totaled approximately 253,000, an increase of 11.71 percent year-on-year in spite of the buffeting that country's economy took, while a significant depreciation of its currency put many Koreans off traveling abroad, the bureau said.

The bureau attributed these relatively optimistic developments to the success of tours targeting foreign fans attracted to Taiwanese singers and actors, as part of the bureau's 2008-2009 "Taiwan Touch Your Heart" campaign to attract tourists.

For instance, around 3,500 fans from seven Asian countries who gathered in Taipei earlier in the day to see the Taiwanese pop group Fahrenheit were expected to bring in NT$100 million (US$2.93 million) of business during their stays here, the bureau said.
The group has been chosen as Taiwan's "tourism ambassador" for Korea and Japan this year, the bureau added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ashes of founder of Dharma Drum Mountain Monastery buried

TEXT.P: Ashes of Buddhist Master Sheng Yen, founder of Dharma Drum Mountain Monastery in Jinshan, Taipei County, were buried Sunday in a cemetery near the monastery he founded.
His ashes were divided into five bags, and buried in five different holes at the Jinshan Cemetery as he requested before he died on Feb. 3.
The cemetery , owned by the Taipei County, was managed by the Dharma Drum Mountain Monastery.
The ceremony had drawn more than 30,000 followers of the master as well as celebrities including President Ma Ying-jeou, Vice President Vincent Siew, and former Vice President Annette Lu.

The crowd formed a line up to three kilometers along the path leading from the monastery to the cemetery where the ashes of the dead were buried beside trees in a rite advocated by Sheng Yen as "plant bury."
Born in Shanghai, eastern China in 1931, Sheng Yen became a Buddhist monk at 13, but was conscripted into the Nationalist Army as a soldier and moved to Taiwan in 1949.
He left the army and resumed his life as a Buddhist monk in 1959, and eventually became a famous Buddhist master in Taiwan.
In 1979, Sheng Yen was named the abbot of Nung Chan Monastery in Beitou, Taipei City and turned it into Taiwan's center of Chan which is a school of Buddhism.
In order to accommodate his growing followers, he began the construction of a more spacious monastery in 2000 in Jinshan, and the Dharma Drum Mountain Monastery was inaugurated in 2005.
He died in Taipei of kidney failure at the age of 78 after a long illness.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Feb. 16, 2009

TEXT.P: 2. Event: Briefing given by Government Information Office Minister Su Jun-pin on Executive Yuan's policy. Date and Time: 3 p.m., Monday, Feb. 16, 2009. Place: No. 2, TianJin Street, Government Information Office, Taipei City. Host and/or main speakers: Su Jun-pin. Organizers: Government Information Office. Press Contact: 3356-8888
