Over the past six years of being clean, Su has worked ceaselessly as a missionary of God, visiting correction centers to meet inmates, and hospitals to console patients, as well as working as a volunteer for several organizations for the disabled.
Even today, tears fill his eyes when he remembers his grandmother, who he described as spending hours on the road bringing him heavy sacks of fruit when he was in prison.
In a further cruel twist of fate, when Su found the meaning of life by helping people, as well as getting married, he was diagnosed last October to be in the late stages of his cancer.
Can the "angel" make it? If you believe in a god, you can perhaps offer him a prayer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan grants Slovenia visa-free privileges

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Sunday that effective immediately, Slovenia passport holders will no longer require visas to visit Taiwan for less than 30 days.

Anne Hung, director-general of MOFA's Department of European Affairs, said the decision was based on the friendly relations that Slovenia shares with Taiwan and the fact that the move poses no threat to Taiwan's national security.
Slovenia will become the seventh Central or Eastern European country to enjoy visa-free privileges, Hung said, following Poland, Slovakia, Hungary, Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia.
In total, 27 European Union nations have been granted visa-free privileges, with Bulgaria, Romania and Cyprus being considered for the same treatment, Hung said.

She expressed hope that the extensive inclusion of Europe's Schengen states in Taiwan's visa exemption policy, as well as a government move to issue "ePassports," or chip-embedded passports, will give Taiwan more leverage in negotiating for reciprocal treatment with the European Union (EU).
Taiwan's low visa refusal rate recorded in the EU, at less than 1 percent, will also help back up the government's efforts, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung City committed to opening penguin house by year-end

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu pledged Sunday to open a penguin house, the largest in Taiwan, late this year or early next year.

Construction of the penguin house, located within the city's traditional fish market -- which is awaiting refurbishment -- is slated to be completed in October at the earliest or early next year, Hu said.
The mayor made the remarks while answering questions from reporters at a ground- breaking ceremony for the city's tourism "fisherman's wharf," to be located adjacent to the fish market.
The Taichung city government hopes both the penguin hall the artificial wharf will become the central Taiwan city's major tourist attractions.
Once the penguin hall is completed, it will host a variety of exhibitions, specimens and research information related to the bird, Hu said.
The Taichung city is planning to lease popular king penguins from the Taipei city zoo, he went on. "Taichung's penguin house will definitely be opened before the next Lunar New Year," he added.
Within three years, the city's penguin house is projected to purchase five or six species of penguin, he said.

He also elaborated on Taichung City's decision to construct a penguin house rather than an originally planned marine life education hall, explaining that the change of mind was made on the grounds that Pingtung County in southern Taiwan already has a marine life education facility.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung City starts building tourism wharf

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu presided Sunday over a ground-breaking ceremony for a tourism fisherman's wharf to be located next to the city's traditional fish market, in an effort to build a new landmark for the central Taiwan city's tourism promotion drive.

In addition to a penguin hall that will be built within the traditional fish market, Hu said, an artificial fisherman's wharf will be constructed on a plot of 5,000 pings (1 ping equals to 3.305 square meters) next to the traditional fish market, with a budget of NT$100 billion (US$2.94 billion) earmarked for the project.
Hu expressed hope that the two projects will help forge a new image and new tourist spots for Taichung City upon their completion, slated for October or November next year.
The city government will also hold a contest to select a name for the wharf, in an effort to increase public awareness of the project.

According to fish market corp. chairman Lee Jen-teh, a retail center for fish and farm produce, as well as a restaurant, will be established at the fisherman's wharf. A ship-shaped building and a square with ponds will also be constructed.

Taichung City has a population of more than 1 million and has long been considered by many people as the most livable city in Taiwan due to its mild weather, beautiful landscape and convenient traffic network, and the penguin house and wharf are expected to provide a major tourism boost.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA order-soliciting plan begins to bear fruit

TEXT.P: A plan for an export-boosting project that was initiated by the administration late last year has already begun to bear fruit, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Sunday.

With the efforts of the Purchases and Sample Exhibitions Plan -- sponsored by the semi-official TAITRA to solicit export orders for Taiwanese exporters and manufacturers -- at least four major buyers from around the world have placed orders or have engaged in serious talks with local exporters, TAITRA Secretary- General Chao Yung-chuan said.

The plan is part of a three-year, NT$8.53 billion (US$250.94 million) project called the New Zheng He Project launched by the Ministry of Economic Affairs late last year aimed at turning Taiwan's export trade from negative to positive growth this year.

Wolseley UK, the world's No. 1 distributor of heating and plumbing products and a leading supplier of building products to the professional market, has recently placed orders worth US$8 million with Taiwanese suppliers for nuts and bolts as well as other related products, including bathroom fittings and lighting components, according to Chao.
"Wolseley is expected to place new orders worth some US$10 million with Taiwan shortly," Chao noted.
Wolseley, whose global procurement topped US$27.5 billion in 2007, is expected to make purchases in Taiwan this year to the tune of US$40 million.
Meanwhile, Chao said, two procurement representatives from Poland's TIM S.A. are scheduled to visit Taiwan Feb. 17-19 for talks on procurement of electronics and electrical engineering products.
Nearly 100 local companies have signed up to take part in the talks.
TIM S.A.'s annual business turnover has averaged US$200 million over the past several years and the company has a staff of more than 400.

It will be the first time has TIM S.A. has approached Taiwan for supplies, Chao went on, adding that deals with the company will serve as a litmus test for Taiwan's potential in cracking the vast Eastern European market.

Meanwhile, Specialty Bolt, the largest nuts and bolts dealer in the New England region of the United States, is scheduled to host a sample display workshop at TAITRA's office in the southern port city of Kaohsiung Feb. 17.
So far, over 50 companies in the area have registered to take part in the workshop, said Wu Chun-ze, head of the TAITRA Kaohsiung Office.
Specialty Bolt, an important supplier of hardware products to OEM plants in the United States, Canada and Mexico, purchases about US$18 million-worth of products from around the world every year.

According to TAITRA officials, representatives of Mexico's Grupo Tutsa, a leading nuts and bolts dealer, have been visiting central and southern Taiwan since Feb. 9 for procurement talks with local suppliers.
Wu said that since their visit began, the representatives have canceled a plan to visit Hangzhou in China.

Under the New Zheng He Project -- named after a Ming Dynasty Chinese explorer -- the administration will assist Taiwanese suppliers and manufacturers to produce more goods for export, with the country's entire export trade hopefully topping NT$500 billion in 2009, thus turning around the poor performance in the export sector due to the global economic recession.

The ambitious export-bolstering project will also direct Taiwanese exporters and manufacturers to emerging markets beyond China, including India, Russia, Brazil, the Middle East and countries in Southeast Asia.

Zheng He was an official who lived during the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644) . He led a giant fleet of Chinese vessels to Southeast Asia, from where they are believed to have reached as far as the west coast of Africa. He was instrumental in building China into one of the maritime superpowers between the 14th and 17th centuries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese medical team concludes mission to Kenya

TEXT.P: A non-government Taiwanese medical team that provided free medical services to some 5,000 people during a just concluded two-week mission to Kenya returned to Taiwan Friday.

The team, composed of 27 medical personnel from various medical centers, as well as volunteers, was organized by the Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps (TRMPC), a private non-profit organization dedicated to improving the quality of life through the provision of medical services at home and abroad.
The team arrived in Kenya late January, when the African country was plagued by massive food shortages due to a prolonged drought, according to TRMPC President Liu Chi-chun.
The team held 10 free clinics in several towns near Lake Victoria, where there are large numbers of AIDS patients, orphans and starving people, according to Liu.

Liu recalled that when an overturned gasoline tanker exploded in the town of Molo Feb. 1, leaving 113 dead and about 200 injured, his team, despite being nearby, was unable to provide aid as it was unaware of the accident.

The TRMPC has rich experience in extending emergency medical relief, such as providing post-war aid in Kosovo, providing medical treatment for victims of the South Asia tsunami and the Indonesia earthquake, Liu said, adding that if the team had learned about the explosion, it could have provided humanitarian relief.

Since February 2000, the TRMPC has arranged medical missions every year to African countries during the Chinese New Year holiday. It has provided services in Swaziland, Malawi, Ghana, Senegal, Gambia, Liberia and Somalia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport recruiting management experts

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) will recruit 16 management experts to serve on a task force that will oversee the conversion of Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport into a state-owned company, ministry officials said Sunday.

The officials pointed out that the legislature passed the Statute For Developing International Airport Park in January and that the some MOTC officials have been appointed to serve on the task force to transform the Taoyuan Airport administration into a state-owned company in line with the statute.

They added that the task force needs 16 experts in the fields of airport administration and management, aviation transportation, banking and finance, and legal counseling, all of whom will enjoy above-average salary scales.
"After the airport company is established, the 16 management experts will become the elite of its staff," said one of the officials.
The MOTC is expected to post a recruitment bulletin on its Web site soon, the officials added.

Under the conversion plan, the Taoyuan Airport administration is scheduled to become a state-owned company in 2010, and the 400 workers currently employed by the airport will be given the option to stay on or retire, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Housing subsidy scheme for young couples to open for applications

TEXT.P: A government housing subsidy program to help young couples renting property or borrowing to buy a home will open for applications Monday, the Ministry of the Interior announced Sunday.

Under the program, the government will provide 10,000 openings for a NT$2 million (US$58,823) government-subsidized home loan that will be interest-free for the first two years, and 20,000 opportunities for a rental subsidy of NT$3,600 per month for two years, according to the ministry.

Eligible applicants for the preferential home loan will include middle-and-low income earners aged 20 to 40 who got married within two years of the date of application and who are new homebuyers, or those aged 20 to 45 who have children and are seeking a new home.
Based on the income criteria set by the ministry, households whose annual incomes rank below 80 percent of wage earners in their area of residence are eligible to apply for the home loans.
Falling within this range will be households whose annual income does not exceed NT$2.31 million in Taipei City, NT$1.72 million in Kaohsiung City and NT$1.52 million in the rest of the country.

As for the rental subsidy, applicants must be couples aged 20 to 40 who were married within two years of the application date, have no their own home and whose household annual incomes fall in the bottom 60 percent of wage earners in their place of residence.

Falling within this range will be households earning no more than NT$1.70 million per year in Taipei City, NT$1.21 million per year in Kaohsiung City and NT$1.1 million per year in the rest of the country, according to the ministry.
Interested families can apply for the loans at their local household registration offices, the ministry said.

Households who are granted subsidies will be required to attend courses related to building families offered by the ministry or risk losing eligibility to claim the subsidies in the second year, the ministry noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 500 foreign companies to take part in Sourcing Taiwan 2009

TEXT.P: More than 500 companies from 60 countries around the world have registered to attend Sourcing Taiwan 2009, a function aimed at creating partnerships between Taiwanese manufacturers and foreign buyers for increased trade exchanges, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Sunday.
A total of 507 foreign companies are expected to be represented at the event slated to be held at the Taipei World Trade Center (TWTC) at the end of March, a TAITRA official said.

The number of attending companies is far greater than originally anticipated, the official noted, adding that the council originally targeted some 350 foreign companies to help shore up the country's export trade.
Of the 507 companies, 195 are major players in global trade, with annual business turnovers exceeding US$100 million, the official said.

One-on-one trade talks are slated to be held at the TWTC March 31, enabling some 2,000 Taiwanese manufacturers or exporters to meet with the foreign buyers for trade talks. TAITRA estimates that some US$120 billion (US$3.53 billion) in trade opportunities are expected to be generated from the talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese nationals deported for holding fake Taiwan IDs: official

TEXT.P: Two Chinese children nabbed at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport Saturday for holding fake Taiwanese identification were deported to China the following day, according to the National Immigration Agency (NIA).

The 16-year-old high school students, a boy and a girl, were caught in possession of bogus Taiwan passports, identification cards and fake official stamps on their boarding passes while trying to clear customs, the NIA officials said.
The officials said the children, who had arrived from Hong Kong, were caught while attempting to transfer to a flight to Guam, with the hope of later traveling on to the continental U.S.

The NIA said that a human trafficking organization might have tried to take advantage of what they perceived as a higher likelihood of the U.S. granting asylum or residency to illegal immigrants of a younger age.
After arranging the deportation, the officials said they were still seeking the mastermind behind the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president's lawyers complain about mute deposition disc

TEXT.P: Lawyers defending former President Chen Shui-bian and his wife in a series of corruption cases complained Sunday that while going through the recorded depositions of witnesses, they found a 30-minute section on one of the discs that had no sound.

Cheng Wen-lung, one of Chen's lawyers, expressed suspicion that the Special Investigation Division (SID) under the Supreme Prosecutors Office might have tampered with the recording to eradicate testimony favorable to the former president.
However, SID Director Chen Yun-nan said the prosecutors in his division would never mute a deposition on purpose and that the problem could be due to malfunctioning of the video recording equipment.

Chen Yun-nan said he had not examined the disc in question and suspected that the soundless part could simply be an intermission videotaped by a camcorder left running after the deposition was temporarily halted.

He added that his division will look into the matter and establish the cause of the problem. As for whether the disc could be considered effective evidence, he pointed out that that is up to the court to decide.

According to Chen Yun-nan, in addition to the recording on disc, the deposition was also transcribed to ensure the accuracy of the testimony. Furthermore, the lawyers of the former president can always cross-examine the witness in question -- Taiwan Cement Corp. Chairman Koo Cheng-yun, who was found by the prosecutors to have transferred NT$300 million (US$8.81 million) in 2003 as bribes to the former president and his wife for a land procurement deal in Taoyuan County.

According to the prosecutors, the former president used his position to push for the government's purchase of the land for the construction of a science park after his wife Wu Shu-jen allegedly accepted bribes through the landowner.

The land procurement scandal is one of a series of criminal cases involving the former president and his family. The charges against them in the other cases include embezzlement, money laundering and forgery.
The former president and his wife have been indicted for embezzling NT$104 million (US$3.12 million) from the president's special discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000 to 2008.
They are also accused of taking NT$90.93 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project.
Chen Shui-bian is being held in custody at a Taipei County detention center. He is Taiwan's first former president to face trial on criminal offenses and if convicted, could face a life sentence.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU plans to offer free classes for unemployed office workers

TEXT.P: The prestigious National Taiwan University is planning to offer free undergraduate and postgraduate classes to office workers who have recently lost their jobs or who are on unpaid leave as a result of the global economic recession.
According to university officials, about 1,100 courses are expected to be offered, with about 10 percent of the available spaces in each class reserved for non-NTU students.
The courses will range from electrical engineering, information technology, engineering and law to social sciences and literature, the officials said.

Students will be required to pay NT$2,000 for each course upon enrollment as a security guarantee that they will complete the course. The money will be repaid when the student completes the course and gains the requisite credits, the officials said.
Meanwhile, the NTU School of Professional and Continuing Studies is cooperating with Chunghwa Telecom to offer online classes on economics, finance and management.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government soliciting votes for Yushan listing as world wonder

TEXT.P: The Construction and Planning Administration under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) urged Taiwanese people Sunday to vote for Yushan, or Jade Mountain, in a global contest for a new listing of seven world wonders.

The 3,952 meter Yushan -- Taiwan's highest peak -- is the only site in the country with preliminary shortlisting among 261 natural heritage sites listed by New Seven Wonders, a non-profit Swiss foundation, agency officials said.

As foundation experts will nominate 21 candidate sites out of 77 selected through a second stage of public voting on the Internet before July 7, agency officials called on the public to take part in the global vote through various Web sites, including www.new7wonders.com or another Web site run by the Yushan National Park Administration in conjunction with the New Seven Wonders foundation.

Although the government and private sectors have in recent years been seeking to have Yushan listed as a world heritage site recognized by the United Nations, agency officials said the goal remains some way off due to political pressure, as Taiwan is not a member of the world body.
The officials voiced hope that the global popularity vote will help Taiwan increase its international visibility and attract foreign tourists to the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 1,300 top Japanese car salesmen on incentive tour of Taiwan

TEXT.P: The first batch of a total of 1,310 top sales representatives from Japan's Daihatsu Motor Co. Ltd. arrived in Taiwan Sunday for a four-day incentive tour, the Bureau of Tourism under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) reported that day.

The group of over 400 salesmen received a warm reception organized by the bureau that included traditional dragon and lion dancing at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport in northern Taiwan. Bureau officials also displayed banners to welcome the visitors and presented them with gifts upon their arrival.
According to bureau officials, Daihatsu chose Taiwan for the third time as the destination for its outstanding workers due to the country's delicious food, good social order and hospitality.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung harbor working to strengthen competitiveness

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau is accelerating the implementation of several construction and dredging programs at the southern harbor to enhance its competitiveness, a bureau official said Sunday.

Reeling from the effects of the global economic downturn, the harbor handled 9.67 million TEUs (twenty-foot equivalent units) last year, a drop of 5 percent from the previous year. The harbor is designed to handle 10 million TEUs per year, according to the official.

The harbor lost its place as one of the world's 10 busiest container ports due to the fall in container volume last year, the official went on, attributing this to stiff competition from other major ports in Pacific Asia, an exodus of local enterprises, China's magnetic effect and the development of China's harbor shipping industry, as well as soaring oil prices last year and lower shipping demand due to the global crisis.

In an attempt to counter these setbacks, the bureau will speed up the pace of several construction projects, including the first-phase construction of an intercontinental container center and the establishment of four new deep-water wharves slated to be completed in 2013.

After completion, the new wharves will be able to accommodate large container ships capable of carrying 10,000 TEUs and will increase the harbor's cargo- handling capacity by 2 million TEUs per year, according to the official.

The bureau will also speed up work on two dredging programs at the harbor's first and second seaway areas designed to widen the two navigation channels to 14-15 meters, allowing them to accommodate larger vessels, the official said.

Bureau officials will visit foreign shipping companies to increase their understanding of the environmental advantages of the harbor and to seek business opportunities. The bureau also plans to set up a cooperation system to attract private companies to take on the construction projects, and to relax regulations on leasing the harbor's facilities, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Fan' tours helping Taiwan's tourism: agency

TEXT.P: "Fan" tours designed for overseas followers of Taiwanese pop stars have worked their way to becoming a strong tourist draw, increasing the number of visitors to Taiwan from Japan and Korea despite the economic slowdown, a government agency reported Sunday.

The tourism industry worldwide has been battered by last year's soaring oil prices and the global sluggish economy, but Taiwan still managed to receive over 1.08 million visitors from Japan over the past year, according to the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.

The figure was a drop of 6.83 percent from the year-earlier level, and the bureau described attracting 1.08 million as "not an easy task" as the overall number of Japanese outbound travelers saw a decline of 7.6 percent compared to the previous year.

Meanwhile, the number of Korean visitors to Taiwan totaled approximately 253,000, an increase of 11.71 percent year-on-year in spite of the buffeting that country's economy took, while a significant depreciation of its currency put many Koreans off traveling abroad, the bureau said.

The bureau attributed these relatively optimistic developments to the success of tours targeting foreign fans attracted to Taiwanese singers and actors, as part of the bureau's 2008-2009 "Taiwan Touch Your Heart" campaign to attract tourists.

For instance, around 3,500 fans from seven Asian countries who gathered in Taipei earlier in the day to see the Taiwanese pop group Fahrenheit were expected to bring in NT$100 million (US$2.93 million) of business during their stays here, the bureau said.
The group has been chosen as Taiwan's "tourism ambassador" for Korea and Japan this year, the bureau added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ashes of founder of Dharma Drum Mountain Monastery buried

TEXT.P: Ashes of Buddhist Master Sheng Yen, founder of Dharma Drum Mountain Monastery in Jinshan, Taipei County, were buried Sunday in a cemetery near the monastery he founded.
His ashes were divided into five bags, and buried in five different holes at the Jinshan Cemetery as he requested before he died on Feb. 3.
The cemetery , owned by the Taipei County, was managed by the Dharma Drum Mountain Monastery.
The ceremony had drawn more than 30,000 followers of the master as well as celebrities including President Ma Ying-jeou, Vice President Vincent Siew, and former Vice President Annette Lu.

The crowd formed a line up to three kilometers along the path leading from the monastery to the cemetery where the ashes of the dead were buried beside trees in a rite advocated by Sheng Yen as "plant bury."
Born in Shanghai, eastern China in 1931, Sheng Yen became a Buddhist monk at 13, but was conscripted into the Nationalist Army as a soldier and moved to Taiwan in 1949.
He left the army and resumed his life as a Buddhist monk in 1959, and eventually became a famous Buddhist master in Taiwan.
In 1979, Sheng Yen was named the abbot of Nung Chan Monastery in Beitou, Taipei City and turned it into Taiwan's center of Chan which is a school of Buddhism.
In order to accommodate his growing followers, he began the construction of a more spacious monastery in 2000 in Jinshan, and the Dharma Drum Mountain Monastery was inaugurated in 2005.
He died in Taipei of kidney failure at the age of 78 after a long illness.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open marginally higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened marginally higher Monday, moving up 13.27 points at 4,605.77 on a turnover of NT$2.25 billion (US$66.08 million).
The weighted price index gained 126.08 points, or 2.82 percent, to close at 4,592.50 Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Monday.
The greenback was trading at NT$34.070 at 10 a.m. on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.020 from Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 16, or the 22nd day of the first month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1473: Nicolaus Copernicus, Polish astronomer, is born. He advanced the theory that the earth and other planets revolve around the sun, discrediting the Ptolemaic model of the universe.
1659: A new way of paying money without using either coinage or a letter of credit is first used in England when Mr. Nicholas Vanacker signs a "cheque" to a creditor.
1884: Robert J. Flaherty, U.S. explorer and filmmaker, is born. His works, including "Nanook of the North," were the world's first major documentaries.
1906: British labor representatives meet in London to establish the Labour Party.
1918: Lithuania, which is located in Northern Europe, proclaims its independence from Russia.
1931: The Control Yuan of the Republic of China is formally established.
1937: The synthetic material nylon, which was developed by the U.S. chemist Wallace Carothers, is patented.
1942: Kim Jong Il, North Korean leader, is born.
1944: Allied aircraft bomb a Japanese naval base at Truk in the Caroline Islands, destroying some 200 planes.
1945: The United States starts massive air raids on Tokyo as U.S. forces capture Bataan in the Philippines during World War II.
1959: Fidel Castro becomes the leader of Cuba at the age of 32.
1960: The USS Triton begins an underwater voyage around the world, becoming the first nuclear submarine to undertake such a journey.
1968: A China Air Transportation plane flying from Hong Kong to Taipei crashes in Linkuo, killing 21 and injuring 43.
1970: The Directorate General of Posts starts nighttime business operations.
1973: Robert E. Page, vice president of United Press International, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1973: The Republic of China revalues the New Taiwan dollar upward by 5 percent against the U.S. dollar. The new exchange rate is NT$38 to US$1.
1976: A new radar control system is inaugurated at Kaohsiung International Airport in southern Taiwan.
1976: Yu Hao-chang, former ROC Army commander in chief, returns to Taipei after more than a year of medical treatment in the United States.
1983: The Dutch airline Martinair inaugurates flight services to Taiwan, marking the first air link between the Netherlands and the Republic of China.
1986: A China Airlines Boeing 737 plane crashes near Makung, in Taiwan's Penghu Islands, killing all 13 aboard.
1992: OPEC member countries agree to cut oil output by 1 million barrels a day.
1994: An earthquake claims 134 lives and injures at least 550 in southern Sumatra in Indonesia.
1994: The Helenic Republic (Greece) declares an embargo on the Macedonian Republic in a conflict over the use of the name Macedonia. The two countries later reached an agreement on the use of the formal name "Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia" for the latter's entry into the United Nations.
1998: A China Airlines Airbus A-300 plane returning from Bali crashes near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, killing all 116 aboard and six people on the ground.
2000: Two destroyers of the Republic of China, the Loyang and Suiyang, are decommissioned after more than two decades of active service.
2000: The ruling Kuomintang formally files a lawsuit against independent presidential candidate and former KMT Secretary-General James Soong, accusing him of embezzling party funds.
2004: Taiwan's Government Information Office and National Geographic Channel International announce a cooperative project on documentary production aimed at introducing Taiwan's natural beauty and cultural legacy to the world.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The common people should be educated in what they ought to do; not to ask why they should do it."

DOC.HEADLINE: 45% of trash in Taiwan recycled: EPA

TEXT.P: As much as 45 percent of the trash discarded by the Taiwan public was recycled last year thanks to the government's garbage sorting policy, according to statistics released Monday by the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).

During the January-November 2008 period, each citizen in Taiwan produced an average 0.839 kilograms of garbage per day, with the trash incinerated or buried in landfills averaging 0.46 kilograms per person per day, the EPA data showed.

Since 2006, the EPA has been promoting a policy under which garbage should be sorted and separated into three categories -- ordinary garbage, recyclables and food scraps -- before being taken to the trash trucks.
Items listed as recyclables include paper, paper-based containers, plastics, glass products and metal containers.
Batteries, light bulbs, computers, television sets, refrigerators, air- conditioners and cars are also categorized as recyclable items.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma will attend 228 service, does not fear heckling: spokesman

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will make room in his tight schedule to attend a service to be held in Kaohsiung in commemoration of the 228 Incident of 1947, despite rumors that he might be heckled by the victims' relatives, Presidential Office spokesman said Monday.

Wang Yu-chi quoted Ma as saying that he would attend the 228 memorial service slated for Feb. 28 in the southern port city of Kaohsiung and would not mind if there were protests against him during the ceremony.
Ma said the country should face the mistakes of history courageously, but members of the society should seek reconciliation instead of confrontation with each other, according to Wang.

Ma understands and is willing to face any uncomfortable moments as president, Wang said. Ma has attended similar services many times over the past years, including during his tenure as Taipei city mayor and chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , and was heckled on several occasions, Wang added.
Wang said the president has decided to attend the services that will be held in Taipei and Kaohsiung Feb. 28.

As usual, the events will be sponsored by the 228 Incident Memorial Foundation, a non-profit organization founded by the Executive Yuan in April 1995 on the basis of the Compensation and Rehabilitation Act.
Wang, however, called for people at the services to express their opinions in a rational way.
He added that security will be tight during the president's attendance of the services, as the safety of the head of state is of ultimate importance.

The 228 Incident, which began Feb. 27, 1947, refers to a brutal crackdown on the local population by KMT troops in March and April of that year that reportedly led to the deaths of an estimated 28,000 people.
At the time of the incident, many innocent people, including elite members of the society, were blacklisted and consequently victimized.

DOC.HEADLINE: Trade promotion body to open four new offices in China

TEXT.P: The semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) announced Monday that it will open four new offices in China this year to help Taiwan companies explore the Chinese market in response to growing business demand.

Offices in Nanjing and Wuhan in the central Chinese provinces of Jiangsu and Hubei, Guangzhou in southern China's Guangdong Province and Dalian in Liaoning Province in northeastern China will be opened this year, TAITRA Secretary- General Chao Yung-chuan said.
TAITRA already maintains offices in Beijing, Shanghai, Chengdu, Qingdao and Xiamen.

To help China-based Taiwanese businesses tap into the mainland market, TAITRA will send delegations to China from Feb. 17 to March 6 to hold a series of briefing sessions in about 10 cities, including Qingdao, Dongguan, Xiamen, Shenzhen, Quanzhou, Chengdu, Shanghai, Nanjing and Beijing, said Wu Lee-min, director of TAITRA's information technology center.
Most Taiwan companies operating in China are export oriented businesses, which have been hit hard by the economic downturn.

From mid-February to late August, TAITRA experts will also hold a series of seminars for Taiwan businessmen in southern, central and northern China to inform them of the importance of branding and to help them gain footholds in the Chinese domestic market.

Exploring the Chinese market is a key aspect of the New Zheng He Project of the Taiwan government, which is designed to help Taiwanese enterprises boost global exports in response to the economic recession.
Zheng was an official of the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644) and the most famous Chinese navigator. He was a contemporary of Columbus.
Zheng sailed from China to the South Pacific, Indian Ocean, Taiwan, the Persian Gulf and Africa in seven epic voyages from 1405 to 1433, some 80 years before Columbus' voyages.

DOC.HEADLINE: Plan to launch cross-strait post-office wire transfers stalls

TEXT.P: Plans to launch a service Wednesday to wire money between China and Taiwan through post offices have been postponed to an unspecified date, Chunghwa Post Co. said Monday.

According to Chunghwa Post Deputy General Manager Huang Shu-chien, China's postal service authorities have informed the company that it is difficult for the Chinese side to begin the two-way remittance service as scheduled, but they did not explain why.
Chunghwa Post speculated that because of the large number of post offices in China -- more than 37,000 -- the authorities have not yet been able to work out the operational costs for wire transfers.
The state-run Chunghwa Post announced last week that two-way remittance services across the Taiwan Strait will begin Feb. 18, after the two sides launched direct postal links last Dec. 15.

The links were based on an agreement signed last November by Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his Chinese counterpart, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits President Chen Yunlin.
However, while the postal links got off the ground on the scheduled date, the remittance service was delayed due to what the two sides said were challenging technical problems.

Chunghwa Post first opened a wire transfer service in 1991 for people wishing to remit money to China. Currently, there are 91 post offices around Taiwan that offer the service, with NT dollar transfers converted to Chinese yuan through U.S.-based Citibank before being wired to designated banks in China.
On average, NT$1.46 billion (US$42.9 million) is transferred to China from Taiwan through Chunghwa Post every year.
Once the direct remittance service is launched, the process is expected to be much faster, although Citibank will continue to facilitate the currency exchange.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-China military talks will not affect Taiwan ties: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) expressed confidence Monday that U.S.-Taiwan relations would not be affected by plans between the United States and China to resume military consultations.

As these consultations had been in progress up to last year, there is no need for concern that they will affect the continuity of the smooth ties between the U.S. and Taiwan, said Harry Tseng, director-general of the MOFA's Department of North American Affairs.

Asked if the new U.S. administration might halt the weapons sales to Taiwan in view of the upcoming consultations with China, Tseng said this is unlikely, as the Pentagon since last October had notified the Congress of the proposed arms sale to Taiwan.

Tseng said he expects the U.S. would reiterate its "one China" policy if asked by Chinese leaders to comment on the Taiwan issue, since this framework has proved successful in helping to maintain peace and prosperity in the region over the past three decades.

During a speech delivered last Friday to the Asia Society in New York, new U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton said that the U.S. will resume mid-level defense consultations with China later this month.

Beijing called off high-level military exchanges and non-proliferation talks with the U.S. last October after the Pentagon notified Congress that it planned to sell a package of advanced defensive weapons to Taiwan.

However, the spokesman for China's defense ministry, Hu Changming, said last month that his country was willing to resume military cooperation with the new U.S. administration of President Barack Obama.
The United States, which is committed under the terms of the Taiwan Relations Act to help Taiwan maintain adequate defense capability, has long been Taiwan's major defensive weapons supplier.

During a hearing held last week by the Senate Committee on Intelligence, new U.S. Director of National Intelligence Dennis Blair reaffirmed Washington's commitment to help Taiwan maintain a military balance with China, which continues to modernize its military.

DOC.HEADLINE: Stray dogs on way to homes in U.S. thanks to Internet

TEXT.P: Seven young siblings of a stray dog family that were found near death due to illness and starvation off a trail in the Kenting National Park in southern Taiwan late last year have boarded a plane to new homes in the United States, thanks to the efforts of a local animal welfare group and its online supporters.

The seven two-month-old puppies -- whose mother Daisy was flown to Seattle nearly a month ago to a new home -- will be adopted by seven families in Los Angeles, according to the Kaohsiung-based Animal Rescue Team Taiwan (ARTT).

The family was rescued in early December last year thanks to a young woman from Taipei, identified only by her online user name "shing0128, " who found the litter with their mother during a hike in the national park.
Discovering that the bitch was seriously ill and that the puppies were weak, "shing0128" drove to the nearby township of Hengchun to buy dog food for the animals.

Because she could not take them home and was worried that the litter could starve to death, "shing0128" took pictures of them and noted their location using her GPS before heading home to Taipei. Once there, she posted the pictures and information about the dogs on the ARTT Web site chat room.

A second individual going by the moniker of "Little Soldier," who saw "shing0128's" information on the Internet, immediately rode his motorbike to Kenting National Park and found the litter and their sick mother.
"Little Soldier" fed the dogs and put a red collar on the mother dog before taking more pictures of the family in need, which he then posted on the ARTT Web site.
A third individual, identified as Ms. Chang from Tainan City, drove to Kenting with her boyfriend early the next morning, caught the dogs and brought them to ARTT's headquarters in Kaohsiung City.
ARTT vets treated the animals, fed them and gave them shelter.
Before long, ARTT posted the story of the rescue on the Web sites of two major animal protection organizations in the United States in the hope that the dogs could find new homes there.
Good news came soon and all the dogs -- now in good health -- found new homes in the U.S.
Ni Ching-tai, an ARTT volunteer, said he will make arrangements to make the story into a series of graphics that will serve as good educational material.
Follow-up stories about the animals can also be found on the ARTT Web site at http://www.saveDOGS.org., Ni added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shares flat on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices dropped slightly Monday, with the Taiwan stock exchange's weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 1.24 points, or 0.02 percent, to close at 4,591.26.
The local bourse opened at 4,605.77 and fluctuated between 4,607.97 and 4,575.98. A total of 3.38 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$72.4 billion (US$2.13 billion).
Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction shares advancing 1.3 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.7 percent, and machinery and electronics issues at 0.3 percent.
Paper and pulp issues remained unchanged.

Four other major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial stocks moving down the most at 1.2 percent. Textile stocks fell 0.6 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks shed 0.4 percent, and foodstuff issues lost 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 802 to 790, with 197 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$2.03 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices mixed on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mixed Monday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for February advancing 7 points to end at 4,575, with 64,270 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for March gained 11 points to finish at 4,520, with 11,751 contracts traded, while June futures dropped 3 points to end at 4,463, with 30 contracts traded.
September futures were down 29 points to close at 4,243, with 201 contract transactions, while December futures fell 2 points to end at 4,184, with 34 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 4,568 for February, 4,509 for March, 4,466 for June, 4,272 for September, and 4,186 for December.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 1.24 points to finish at 4,591.26, on turnover of NT$72.4 billion (US$2.13 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

February TE futures gained 1.65 points to close at 185.65, with 3,352 contracts traded, while March TE futures advanced 2.45 points to finish at 184.55, with 699 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.
February TF futures were down 5.6 points to close at 511.4, with 2,682 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures decreased 5.2 points to finish at 506.6 with 532 contracts traded.
September TF futures fell 5.2 points to finish at 495.2, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for June and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, increasing NT$0.23 to close at NT$34.280.
A total of US$800 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$34.050 and fluctuated between NT$34.010 and NT$34.280.

DOC.HEADLINE: Production of Taiwan's IC industry seen to fall 26.9% this year

TEXT.P: Overall production of Taiwan's IC industry is expected to suffer a year-on-year slide of 26.9 percent this year as a result of the global economic recession, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) forecast Monday.

Officials from the MOEA's Department of Industrial Technology said the overall production of IC industry -- the backbone of Taiwan's industrial growth -- totaled NT$1.34 trillion (US$39.41 billion) in 2008, down 8.1 percent year-on- year.

Production is estimated to decline even further this year, to fall below NT$1 trillion, possibly to as low as NT$984.5 billion, marking an alarming decline of 26.9 percent year-on-year, the officials said.

A breakdown compiled by the department shows that output of the IC fabrication sector -- the key player of the IC industry -- totaled NT$654.2 billion in 2008, representing a decline of 11.2 percent compared to the year-earlier level.

The output of the semiconductor manufacturing sector amounted to NT$446.9 billion last year, marking a slight decline of 1.1 percent year-on-year, while production of DRAM-related products reached just NT$207.3 billion last year, representing a whopping fall of 27.2 percent from the year-earlier level.

The output of the IC design industry reached NT$374.9 billion, down 6.2 percent year-on-year, IC packaging output totaled NT$221.7 billion, down 2.8 percent and IC testing amounted to NT$96.5 billion, down 5.7 percent year-on-year, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of Taiwan visitors transiting in Hong Kong to plummet
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Feb. 16 (CNA) 02/16/09 18:05:55 (By Mandy Wong and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The number of Taiwanese visitors making transit stops in Hong Kong this year is forecast to plummet as a result of the historic opening of direct air and sea links across the Taiwan Strait, the Hong Kong Tourism Board said Monday.

Against the backdrop of the opening last Dec. 15 of direct air and shipping links between Taiwan and China, the number of Taiwanese visitors transiting in Hong Kong is expected to shrink by 33 percent -- or 527,000 person-visits this year -- from the 1.591 million posted in 2008 to 1.064 million, the board said.
The board also predicted that arrivals by South Korean visitors in Hong Kong this year will decline 15 percent, or 136,000 person-visits year-on-year, to some 768,000.
Board officials attributed this mainly to a plunge in value of the Korean won by roughly 30 percent over the last few months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA to host regional exhibition seminar in 2010

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) announced Monday that it has won the right to host a regional seminar in 2010 to be organized by a prominent exhibition association.

Given the growing importance of the Global Association of the Exhibition Industry (UFI) , TAITRA said that bids to host the association's events have heated up over the years and that TAITRA spent months trying to beat out other candidates such as Thailand.
It will be the first time that the Paris-based UFI will be holding its open seminar for the Asian region in Taiwan, according to TAITRA.
The 2009 meeting took place in Malaysia Feb.12-13.

The UFI, with 485 members in 199 cities, is considered the most authoritative organization in the exhibition industry worldwide and offers courses that businesses in the field access for personnel training, TAITRA added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 300 firms join CLA program for workers on unpaid leave

TEXT.P: Some 310 companies have responded positively to a training program aimed at providing specialized courses for workers on unpaid leave, the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) reported Monday.

To date, 310 businesses have registered with the CLA to offer training courses in foreign languages, computer skills, business management, and research and renovation to their workers on unpaid leave.

CLA officials estimated that 5,600 companies will join the program, to the benefit of around 168,000 workers across the country. The officials forecast that some of the workers will be able to begin receiving training from March.

Under the program, the council will offer subsidies of up to NT$1.9 million (US$57,100) to each large business concern and NT$950,000 to each medium- and small-sized enterprise participating in the program.
Eligible participating workers will receive subsidies of up to NT$10,000 per month for a maximum period of six months.

The CLA reported early last week that at least 180,000 workers across Taiwan were being forced to take unpaid leave days, with those in the high-tech and financial service sectors most likely to be given extra unpaid days off.

The council said the estimate was based on reports on unpaid leave practices submitted by more than 400 companies across the country between Dec. 23 and Jan. 31, with the number of affected workers totaling around 180,000.

Meanwhile, the number of workers on full or partial unpaid leave in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan has reached over 100,000, accounting for nearly 80 percent of the park's total work force.
The Hsinchu science park in northern Taiwan, established in 1980, is the country's most representative facility of the kind.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local bankers visit Beijing to promote financial cooperation
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Feb. 16 (CNA) 02/16/09 19:51:28 (By Chou Huei-ying and Elizabebth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A delegation of the Taiwan Financial Services Roundtable (TFSR) held talks Monday with Taiwanese businessmen operating in China and Beijing officials to gain a better understanding of the current economic state of China and the kind of financial services Taiwanese businesses need.

The 40-member group, headed by TFSR Chairman Shea Jia-dong, arrived in Beijing the previous day to convey Taiwan's wish for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to accelerate their financial cooperation.

The visitors are also expected to probe the possibility of the two sides signing a memorandum of understanding on financial supervision cooperation, as the issue has been put on the planned agenda of a third meeting between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his Chinese counterpart, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits President Chen Yunlin, scheduled for May.

Shea told Taiwanese reporters before the Monday workshop that cross-strait exchanges in the financial sector have not been frequent in the past. The TFSR, therefore, wants to convey the hope that the Chinese authorities will step up their pace in opening China's financial market for cross-strait exchanges or transactions, he said.
Shea, who has previously served as minister of finance, said he hopes China will allow Taiwanese banks to open branches in China without having first to set up representative offices.
He also expressed hope that China will allow Taiwanese bank branches to deal with trading in the Chinese yuan in China.

Members of the TFSR delegation include Taiwan Business Bank Chairman Joseph N. Tsai, Mega Bills Finance Chairman Tzeng Chuei-ji, China Development Industrial Bank President Lawrence S. Liu, SinoPac Holdings President Mckinney Y.T. Tsai and Bank of Taiwan President Lo Tzer-cheng.

The delegation will visit the China Banking Regulatory Commission and the China Insurance Regulatory Commission in Beijing before traveling to Shanghai Feb. 18. It is scheduled to return to Taiwan Feb. 20.

The TFSR was founded in 2005, following the model of the U.S.-based Financial Services Roundtable with the goal of promoting the development of Taiwan's financial sector and improving its international competitiveness. It now comprises 100 members who are mostly top executives of 18 financial institutes in Taiwan

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA will not rule out possibility of extending unemployment benefits

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) is closely monitoring the unemployment situation and will not rule out the possibility of extending the existing period of unemployment benefits to all categories of jobless workers if the situation worsens, CLA Minister Wang Ju-hsuan said Monday.

However, Wang also said that the present maximum payable period of six months remains reasonable, given the fact that the average duration of unemployment in January stood at 26 weeks, or slightly more than six months.
A comprehensive extension will only be justified if the average duration of unemployment increases, she said.

According to the Employment Insurance Law, workers who lose their jobs through no fault of their own and who fail to find new ones within 14 days of registering with a government-run employment service organization can receive 60 percent of their insured wages for up to six months.

The CLA has submitted to the Legislative Yuan a proposed amendment to the law in which the maximum payable period would be extended to nine months for older workers and those with physical or mental disabilities.
Wang said that if the government does not take any steps to address the unemployment problem, the jobless rate will likely top 6 percent this year.
The government is working to control the unemployment rate within 4.5 percent by promoting various job creation programs, she said.

Among them are a "get to work" program launched last October in which businesses participating in the program will get a government subsidy of NT$10,000 per month for each unemployed worker who has been out of work three or more consecutive months prior to being hired, for a maximum period of six months.
The program has so far helped 13,106 jobless workers find employment, Wang noted.
Meanwhile, 7,312 workers had been provided short-term jobs in local government agencies as of Feb. 10, and local authorities are expected to further provide 5,517 temporary jobs this year, she said.

Due to the economic downturn that was triggered mainly by the global financial crisis, Taiwan's unemployment rate soared to 5.03 percent in December 2008, hitting the highest level since October 2003 and marking the first time in five years that the monthly jobless rate had topped 5 percent.
The average unemployment rate for 2008 was 4.14 percent, representing a four- year high.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan International Festival to kick off in Taipei

TEXT.P: The Taiwan International Festival (TIF) , slated to kick off in Taipei Friday, will feature performances that demonstrate how technology can be incorporated into the performing arts and used to expand artistic creation, the event's organizer said Monday.

The National Theater and Concert Hall (NTCH) said 12 renowned international and domestic groups will stage a series of performances at the festival, which runs until April 3, under the themevision of the future." The shows will encompass drama, music and dance.

The performances, characterized by their interactivity, display a diversity of styles that noticeably differ from those in traditional theater, allowing audiences not only to watch and listen but also to participate through special installations, NTCH Chairwoman Tchen Yu-chiou said in a statement posted on the event's Web site

NTCH Artistic Director Liu Chiung-shu explained, for instance, that lemieux.pilon 4d art from Canada combines animation and film in its production about Norman McLaren, a legendary figure in animation arts.
Also, Philip Glass'Book of Longingintermingles the poems and paintings of the Canadian singer Leonard Cohen through the use of multimedia.

Other highlights includeThe Japanese Gardenby the Italian T.P.O. Visual Theatre that uses game-like interactive devices as well as the digital version of The Rite of Spring (Le Sacre du Printemps), among others, Liu added.
Meanwhile, Tchen said that Taiwanese groups will also have a presence during the festival, including the National Taiwan Symphony Orchestra, U Theatre and the Hsiao Hsi Yuan Puppet Theater.

In addition, the three-day Open-Air International Arts Festival will take place in celebration of the now completed renovation of NTCH at its outdoor plaza from Feb. 20-22, according to the organizer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rumor on when to fill gasoline tanks proven untrue

TEXT.P: Economics officials said Monday that motorists should ignore the rumor that they will be shortchanged if they have their fuel tanks filled at service stations around noon.

The officials at the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said the results of a survey commissioned by the bureau debunked the rumor that motorists spend more on fuel at noon because the higher temperatures at that hour cause gasoline to expand.

The survey, conducted by the Industrial Technology Research Institute of Taiwan, collected 840 fuel samples through 53 fuel dispensing nozzles made by three major brands -- Tokheim, Wayne and Nuovo-Pignone -- at 10 filling stations in northern, central and southern Taiwan when temperatures were either higher than 30 degrees Celsius or lower than 20 degrees C.
Measurements of the fuel samples showed there was only a 0.055 percent difference in volume between the two groups of fuel samples as a result of the temperature variations.

The officials pointed out that most fuel at filling stations sits in underground tanks that act like big Thermos bottles, and that as a result, temperature variations within the storage tanks are minimal throughout the day.
They added that there is no need for motorists to buy fuel only early in the morning or around midnight when temperatures are cooler.

Gasoline, like any liquid, expands as its temperature increases. A 10-degree Celsius temperature increase can cause gasoline to expand by about 3.5 percent. Diesel fuel also expands and contracts over 2 percent for every 10-degree Celsius change in the temperature.

About two years ago, the same rumor spread in California, but experts explained that the fuel at gas stations stayed close to 60 degrees Fahrenheit (15 degrees Celsius) because it was stored underground and that any variations would even out over the year or be too small to matter to consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hon Hai, postal and telecom firms dubbed as charitable companies

TEXT.P: Hon Hai Precision, Chunghwa Telecom and Chunghwa Post have been voted by local office workers as Taiwan's most charitable enterprises in the manufacturing, service and financial sectors, respectively.

Trailing Hon Hai Precision in the manufacturing sector were Uni-President Group, CPC Corp. (Taiwan), Formosa Petrochemical Corp., and China Steel Corp., according to the results of the poll released by the 1111 job bank Monday.
Amid a global economic slowdown, hundreds of Taiwan-based enterprises signed a pledge late last year to endorse a call by the government not to cut jobs in this difficult time.
The companies were selected for their performance in keeping employees' jobs, fulfilling their social responsibility and promoting social activity, as well as for their management styles.
In the service sector, Chunghwa Telecom was voted as the most charitable company, ahead of Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, President Chain Store Corp., Carrefour, and Acer Corp. in that order.

Chunghwa Post, Bureau of Labor Insurance, Bank of Taiwan, Cathay Life Insurance Company and Nan Shan Life Insurance Company were the top five charitable companies in the financial sector, according to the survey.

Close to 60 percent of the office workers responding to the poll contended that the companies for which they worked were not among these compassionate businesses and 86 percent of them were considering changing their jobs, the poll found.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public pleased to see cross-strait ties eased: MAC

TEXT.P: The public is happy to see the easing of relations with China and is optimistic over the development of such ties, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) spokesman said Monday.
Liu Teh-hsun made the remarks after the MAC summarized 108 public opinion surveys related to cross-Taiwan Strait relations last year.
Since President Ma Ying-jeou assumed office May 20, the public has "felt warmer cross-strait relations" after the chilly relations under the previous administration, Liu said.
"Those who are optimistic about the development of cross-strait relations outnumbered those who are pessimistic, according to the public opinion polls," he added.

Those who said they are satisfied with the government's China policy also outnumbered those who said they are dissatisfied, and a great majority are positive about the government's efforts in improving cross-strait ties.

The polls also showed that as the government has eased relations with China, the public has had higher expectations of the government's role in managing the ties, hoping it will regulate the pace of the liberalization process, adopt complementary measures and conduct risk assessments to prevent any negative effects.

On polls on Taiwan's national status and its future, the MAC said that those who are in favor of the status quo in the broader sense, including those who are in favor of the status quo before moving toward independence or unification, those who want a status quo before deciding on unification or independence later, and those who want a permanent status quo, accounted for between 64.9 percent and 91.8 percent of the public.
The ratio was similar to the results of polls in preceding years, indicating that those who are in favor of rapid independence or unification are in the minority.

The MAC said that between 75.4 percent and 81.6 percent identify with President Ma Ying-jeou's "no unification, no independence, and no use of force" advocacy to maintain the status quo in the Taiwan Strait under the framework of the Republic of China.

The MAC also said that between 52.2 percent and 68.7 percent of respondents to the various polls said that cross-strait relations are moving toward a calmer state, with between 50.6 percent and 57.9 percent believing that the government can maintain cross-strait peace and stability.

Between 62 percent and 65 percent of the public was confident cross-strait ties would bring political stability and economic development over the next four years, and between 47 percent and 62 percent were optimistic about the overall development of cross-strait ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chairwoman opposes signing CECA with China

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is opposed to the widely- discussed idea of Taiwan signing a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) with China, said DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen Monday.

Tsai made her stance known at a press conference after meeting with the DPP's 27 lawmakers to discuss issues important to the party, including the CECA, a plan to allow Chinese students to study in universities and graduate schools in Taiwan, and the government's measures to help the jobless.

The meeting was held to form a consensus on the DPP's stands on the issues at the Legislative Yuan, which will open its first session this year Feb. 20. The DPP holds 27 seats in the 113-seat legislature, which is currently short two members who were forced to cede their seats due to legal issues.
Tsai said that debate in the legislative session will likely focus on issues related to China and economic problems.

Speaking of the CECA, an idea proposed by President Ma Ying-jeou during his election campaign to further promote economic and trade cooperation between Taiwan and China, Tsai contended that such an accord could turn Taiwan into a dependency of China.
She argued that if the government seals the agreement with China without careful consideration or a common public consensus, it could cause social conflict.
Tsai therefore urged the government to make all of its negotiations with Chinese authorities and its cross-strait policy deliberations transparent.
She suggested that an efficient monitoring mechanism should be set up either in the Legislative Yuan or among political parties to oversee the administration of the policy.

As to the plan to allow Chinese students to study in Taiwan, which some people suggest will harm the employment opportunities of Taiwanese graduates, Tsai said the DPP would refrain from commenting at present.

She said, however, that the party had its doubts about government plans to spend taxpayer funds on rescuing a minority of key industries and enterprises, such as a possible plan to bail out DRAM maker, ProMOS Technologies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung Harbor seeking to step up competitiveness

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Port is seeking to boost its competitiveness as it handled fewer containers last year than in 2007 and is likely to see its global ranking fall, the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau said Monday.

Hit by the global economic downturn and especially a dramatic fall in the country's exports in the fourth quarter of the year, the southern port handled 9.67 million TEUs (twenty-foot equivalent units) in 2008, down 5 percent from the 2007 level, bureau statistics showed.

With Kaohsiung possibly falling out of the world's top 10 container ports in 2008, the bureau is exploring ways to reverse the decline, including launching several construction and dredging projects, bureau officials said.
Four deep-sea wharfs, slated to be completed in 2013, are expected to increase the port's container handling capability by 2 million TEUs per year, according to the officials.

Improved ties with China may also provide new momentum. Since direct shipping services were established across the Taiwan Strait in mid-December, the number of containers handled by the port has increased by an average of more than 200,000 TEUs per month, they noted.

That jump has led the bureau to focus its expansion program for the port on cross-strait routes. To capitalize on the newly opened shipping links, the bureau intends to develop the port into a value added distribution center and offer incentives to foreign shippers and warehousing companies to set up facilities there.

Kaohsiung Port is Taiwan's largest deep-sea port and was once the world's third- largest container port. It was ranked as the eighth biggest container port in the world in 2007 behind Dubai and ahead of Hamburg, Germany, with 10.257 million TEUs handled.
The top five ports in the world were Singapore, Shanghai, Hong Kong, Shenzhen and Busan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ScinoPharm reports triple digit profit growth for 2008

TEXT.P: ScinoPharm Taiwan Ltd., a biotechnology company in the Tainan Science-Based Industrial Park in southern Taiwan, saw pre-tax profits grow 119 percent in 2008 on improved sales of its oncology products.
Jo Shen, president and CEO of ScinoPharm, said the company posted pre-tax income of NT$905 million, up 119 percent from NT$413 million in 2007, on revenues of NT$3.14 billion (US$91.58 million).
The reported revenues were 26 percent higher than the NT$2.49 billion in sales the company reported a year earlier.
The biotech company achieved strong growth at a time when annual results at most other hightech companies in the Tainan park suffered serious declines in 2008 because of the global economic downturn.
Shen attributed her company's success to the company's management strategy and the successful marketing of its oncology products.
ScinoPharm is a leading active pharmaceutical ingredient (API) supplier to the global pharmaceutical and biotechnology industry.

It provides a full range of API services from process development and production of early phase clinical trial material to large-scale manufacturing for commercial launches. The company currently serves more than 190 customers worldwide.
In November last year, ScinoPharm was granted a U.S. patent for its new crystalline forms of irinotecan hydrochloride, which are designed to allow for easier filtration during production processing.

The patent covers preparation methods and use of the novel molecules in the treatment of metastatic colon cancer. It is the ninth U.S. patent granted to ScinoPharm and the second patent for irinotecan hydrochloride, one of the company's high-demand oncology products.

Irinotecan hydrochloride, a cancer drug most commonly used to treat patients with metastatic carcinoma of the colon or rectum, became generic in the U.S. in February 2008. Annual sales of the drug in the US market alone were approximately US$556 million in 2007, according to IMS Health data.
In addition to irinotecan hydrochloride, ScinoPharm offers 20 other products in its oncological line, including paclitaxel and docetaxel.
ScinoPharm's patent portfolio currently consists of 11 granted patents and more than 24 patent applications in the United States and abroad for a wide range of products.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's top religious official in town

TEXT.P: China's top official on religious affairs held low key meetings with several dharma masters Monday to discuss an upcoming World Buddhist Forum.
Ye Xiaowen, head of China's State Bureau of Religious Affairs, had a very busy schedule Monday, said Kenneth Kuanlin Fan, president of the World Congress of Cultures.
Ye visited Master Wu Ming of the Faming Monastery in Shulin, Taipei County and then traveled to Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan to meet with the venerable Ching Hsin of the Chinese Buddhist Association.
Ye called on the Buddhist leaders to discuss matters related to the forum, which is scheduled to be held in Taipei and Wuxi, Jiangsu province between March 27 and April 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hotelier proposes demolition of Songshan Airport

TEXT.P: Songshan Airport in downtown Taipei should be demolished when Taiwan grows strong enough to share Hong Kong's functions or even replace it as a hub of trade and transportation services with China, a hotelier said Monday.

Stanley Yen, president of the Landis Hotels and Resorts Group who is also known as the godfather of Taiwan's hotel industry, floated the idea in a speech delivered at a monthly meeting of officials at the Presidential Office.

As the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have finally launched direct shipping and air links, Yen said Taiwan should capitalize on the opportunity to develop cross-Taiwan Strait transportation and commercial markets.
In so doing, Yen said, Taiwan will some day be able to share markets currently held by Hong Kong and even eventually beat it out.

When the time comes, Yen said, the government should have Songshan Airport torn down to make way for a New York Central Park-like recreational area and a modern town patterned after Tokyo's midtown, which incorporates green technology in its construction.

With the demolition of the airport, all limitations on the height of buildings in its surrounding areas would be eliminated. Lower structures in the area could be integrated and rebuilt into skyscrapers while leaving more space for landscaping.
In his view, Yen said only such large-scale construction opportunities could attract world-class land developers to invest in Taiwan's construction market.

By then, all flight services could be concentrated at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, which will be connected with downtown Taipei by mass rapid transit (MRT) lines now under construction, Yen said.
He even suggested that 20 to 50 years into the future, a Maglev, or magnetic levitation line, could be built to further shorten the travel time between the airport and Taipei to 12 minutes.
Meanwhile, Yen stressed the value of culture in developing taiwan's tourism industry.
"Culture is the biggest added value for tourism development and part of Taiwan's commendable soft power," Yen said.
He urged the government to incorporate culture in its diplomatic efforts, using cultural activities as a means to foster friendship, good will and cooperation in various fields, including politics.
