DOC.HEADLINE: Hon Hai, postal and telecom firms dubbed as charitable companies

TEXT.P: Hon Hai Precision, Chunghwa Telecom and Chunghwa Post have been voted by local office workers as Taiwan's most charitable enterprises in the manufacturing, service and financial sectors, respectively.

Trailing Hon Hai Precision in the manufacturing sector were Uni-President Group, CPC Corp. (Taiwan), Formosa Petrochemical Corp., and China Steel Corp., according to the results of the poll released by the 1111 job bank Monday.
Amid a global economic slowdown, hundreds of Taiwan-based enterprises signed a pledge late last year to endorse a call by the government not to cut jobs in this difficult time.
The companies were selected for their performance in keeping employees' jobs, fulfilling their social responsibility and promoting social activity, as well as for their management styles.
In the service sector, Chunghwa Telecom was voted as the most charitable company, ahead of Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, President Chain Store Corp., Carrefour, and Acer Corp. in that order.

Chunghwa Post, Bureau of Labor Insurance, Bank of Taiwan, Cathay Life Insurance Company and Nan Shan Life Insurance Company were the top five charitable companies in the financial sector, according to the survey.

Close to 60 percent of the office workers responding to the poll contended that the companies for which they worked were not among these compassionate businesses and 86 percent of them were considering changing their jobs, the poll found.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public pleased to see cross-strait ties eased: MAC

TEXT.P: The public is happy to see the easing of relations with China and is optimistic over the development of such ties, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) spokesman said Monday.
Liu Teh-hsun made the remarks after the MAC summarized 108 public opinion surveys related to cross-Taiwan Strait relations last year.
Since President Ma Ying-jeou assumed office May 20, the public has "felt warmer cross-strait relations" after the chilly relations under the previous administration, Liu said.
"Those who are optimistic about the development of cross-strait relations outnumbered those who are pessimistic, according to the public opinion polls," he added.

Those who said they are satisfied with the government's China policy also outnumbered those who said they are dissatisfied, and a great majority are positive about the government's efforts in improving cross-strait ties.

The polls also showed that as the government has eased relations with China, the public has had higher expectations of the government's role in managing the ties, hoping it will regulate the pace of the liberalization process, adopt complementary measures and conduct risk assessments to prevent any negative effects.

On polls on Taiwan's national status and its future, the MAC said that those who are in favor of the status quo in the broader sense, including those who are in favor of the status quo before moving toward independence or unification, those who want a status quo before deciding on unification or independence later, and those who want a permanent status quo, accounted for between 64.9 percent and 91.8 percent of the public.
The ratio was similar to the results of polls in preceding years, indicating that those who are in favor of rapid independence or unification are in the minority.

The MAC said that between 75.4 percent and 81.6 percent identify with President Ma Ying-jeou's "no unification, no independence, and no use of force" advocacy to maintain the status quo in the Taiwan Strait under the framework of the Republic of China.

The MAC also said that between 52.2 percent and 68.7 percent of respondents to the various polls said that cross-strait relations are moving toward a calmer state, with between 50.6 percent and 57.9 percent believing that the government can maintain cross-strait peace and stability.

Between 62 percent and 65 percent of the public was confident cross-strait ties would bring political stability and economic development over the next four years, and between 47 percent and 62 percent were optimistic about the overall development of cross-strait ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chairwoman opposes signing CECA with China

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is opposed to the widely- discussed idea of Taiwan signing a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) with China, said DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen Monday.

Tsai made her stance known at a press conference after meeting with the DPP's 27 lawmakers to discuss issues important to the party, including the CECA, a plan to allow Chinese students to study in universities and graduate schools in Taiwan, and the government's measures to help the jobless.

The meeting was held to form a consensus on the DPP's stands on the issues at the Legislative Yuan, which will open its first session this year Feb. 20. The DPP holds 27 seats in the 113-seat legislature, which is currently short two members who were forced to cede their seats due to legal issues.
Tsai said that debate in the legislative session will likely focus on issues related to China and economic problems.

Speaking of the CECA, an idea proposed by President Ma Ying-jeou during his election campaign to further promote economic and trade cooperation between Taiwan and China, Tsai contended that such an accord could turn Taiwan into a dependency of China.
She argued that if the government seals the agreement with China without careful consideration or a common public consensus, it could cause social conflict.
Tsai therefore urged the government to make all of its negotiations with Chinese authorities and its cross-strait policy deliberations transparent.
She suggested that an efficient monitoring mechanism should be set up either in the Legislative Yuan or among political parties to oversee the administration of the policy.

As to the plan to allow Chinese students to study in Taiwan, which some people suggest will harm the employment opportunities of Taiwanese graduates, Tsai said the DPP would refrain from commenting at present.

She said, however, that the party had its doubts about government plans to spend taxpayer funds on rescuing a minority of key industries and enterprises, such as a possible plan to bail out DRAM maker, ProMOS Technologies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung Harbor seeking to step up competitiveness

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Port is seeking to boost its competitiveness as it handled fewer containers last year than in 2007 and is likely to see its global ranking fall, the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau said Monday.

Hit by the global economic downturn and especially a dramatic fall in the country's exports in the fourth quarter of the year, the southern port handled 9.67 million TEUs (twenty-foot equivalent units) in 2008, down 5 percent from the 2007 level, bureau statistics showed.

With Kaohsiung possibly falling out of the world's top 10 container ports in 2008, the bureau is exploring ways to reverse the decline, including launching several construction and dredging projects, bureau officials said.
Four deep-sea wharfs, slated to be completed in 2013, are expected to increase the port's container handling capability by 2 million TEUs per year, according to the officials.

Improved ties with China may also provide new momentum. Since direct shipping services were established across the Taiwan Strait in mid-December, the number of containers handled by the port has increased by an average of more than 200,000 TEUs per month, they noted.

That jump has led the bureau to focus its expansion program for the port on cross-strait routes. To capitalize on the newly opened shipping links, the bureau intends to develop the port into a value added distribution center and offer incentives to foreign shippers and warehousing companies to set up facilities there.

Kaohsiung Port is Taiwan's largest deep-sea port and was once the world's third- largest container port. It was ranked as the eighth biggest container port in the world in 2007 behind Dubai and ahead of Hamburg, Germany, with 10.257 million TEUs handled.
The top five ports in the world were Singapore, Shanghai, Hong Kong, Shenzhen and Busan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ScinoPharm reports triple digit profit growth for 2008

TEXT.P: ScinoPharm Taiwan Ltd., a biotechnology company in the Tainan Science-Based Industrial Park in southern Taiwan, saw pre-tax profits grow 119 percent in 2008 on improved sales of its oncology products.
Jo Shen, president and CEO of ScinoPharm, said the company posted pre-tax income of NT$905 million, up 119 percent from NT$413 million in 2007, on revenues of NT$3.14 billion (US$91.58 million).
The reported revenues were 26 percent higher than the NT$2.49 billion in sales the company reported a year earlier.
The biotech company achieved strong growth at a time when annual results at most other hightech companies in the Tainan park suffered serious declines in 2008 because of the global economic downturn.
Shen attributed her company's success to the company's management strategy and the successful marketing of its oncology products.
ScinoPharm is a leading active pharmaceutical ingredient (API) supplier to the global pharmaceutical and biotechnology industry.

It provides a full range of API services from process development and production of early phase clinical trial material to large-scale manufacturing for commercial launches. The company currently serves more than 190 customers worldwide.
In November last year, ScinoPharm was granted a U.S. patent for its new crystalline forms of irinotecan hydrochloride, which are designed to allow for easier filtration during production processing.

The patent covers preparation methods and use of the novel molecules in the treatment of metastatic colon cancer. It is the ninth U.S. patent granted to ScinoPharm and the second patent for irinotecan hydrochloride, one of the company's high-demand oncology products.

Irinotecan hydrochloride, a cancer drug most commonly used to treat patients with metastatic carcinoma of the colon or rectum, became generic in the U.S. in February 2008. Annual sales of the drug in the US market alone were approximately US$556 million in 2007, according to IMS Health data.
In addition to irinotecan hydrochloride, ScinoPharm offers 20 other products in its oncological line, including paclitaxel and docetaxel.
ScinoPharm's patent portfolio currently consists of 11 granted patents and more than 24 patent applications in the United States and abroad for a wide range of products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 17, or the 23rd day of the first month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:

1943: Madame Chiang Kai-shek arrives in Washington for a visit.
1949: Chaim Weizmann is elected Israel's first president.
1952: Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce (CNAIC) is formed in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Extra Alishan train services for cherry blossom season

TEXT.P: Extra train services to the Alishan forest recreation area will be provided during the upcoming cherry blossom season, which is expected draw a large number of visitors, the train operator said Tuesday.

In addition to the regular daily service that departs at 1: 25 p.m. from the city of Chiayi in southern Taiwan, two more services -- departing at 9 a.m. and 10 a.m., respectively -- will be available every day between March 15 and April 15, according to Hungtu Alishan.
The company said online ticketing for the cherry blossom season is now available at http://ticket.ht-alishan.com.tw.

The scenic mountain in Chiayi County is one of the most popular tourist attractions in Taiwan, offering a famous breathtaking sunrise, serene mountain landscape and ancient trees. The 86-km railway leading up the mountain is said to be one of just three alpine railways remaining in existence in the world.
Among the great variety of cherry trees found in the Alishan forest area, the white-blossomed Yoshino cherry from Japan is the most famous.
The first Yoshino cherry trees grown in the area can be traced back to 1903 and were planted during the Japanese colonial period.

Planting on a large scale did not begin until 1918, when the Japanese imported over 900 Yoshino cherry saplings and grew them in the area around what is now the Chaoping train station. Three years later, the trees all blossomed at the same time, marking Alishan's first cherry blossom season.
Various varieties of cherry trees from Japan have since continued to be introduced to the area, increasing the number of cherry trees there to around 6,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Red shirt' leader will not appeal court ruling

TEXT.P: Shih Ming-teh, the former Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairman who led an anti-corruption movement against former President Cheng Shui-bian and was tried for violating the Assembly and Parade law, will sit alone in front of the Presidential Office Feb. 20 -- the day of the court ruling -- in a silent protest over the government's failure to abolish the law, his spokesman said Tuesday.

Jerry Fan, spokesman for the "anti-corruption, depose Chen" campaign, said at a news conference that Shih will start his sit-in at 3 p.m. and will continue until the ruling, which is scheduled to be announced an hour later.
"Shih has said many times that he insists that if found guilty, he will not appeal but will go to jail according to the ruling, " Fan said, describing the indictments as "extremely preposterous."

Along with 15 other campaign officials named as co-defendants, Shih, who served as DPP chairman between 1994 and 1996 before quitting the party in 2000, were indicted Aug. 3, 2007 on charges of violating the Assembly and Parade Law for staging an Oct. 10, 2006 "siege" of the Presidential Office and Chen's official residence in an attempt to disrupt National Day celebration activities.

One of Shih's co-defendants, political science professor Yao Li-ming, said at the news conference that Shih's decision to go to jail is aimed at highlighting how "unreasonable" the law is and how President Ma Ying-jeou has failed to carry out his campaign promise to abolish the law.
He noted that as the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) holds a majority in the Legislative Yuan, it should not take this long to deal with the issue.

Critics of the law say it infringes upon the freedom of expression protected by the Constitution because those wishing to demonstrate must apply for government approval before taking to the streets to champion their causes.
"Ma should only apologize when he runs for re-election rather than now, " Yao said. "What he should do at the moment is urge the ruling KMT to abolish the law."
Yao said Shih has expressed hope that the other co-defendants will not follow his example and will appeal the rulings against them because his act alone is enough to make the point.

However, former DPP member Wang Li-ping, another of the co-defendants, also said at the news conference that she will give up her right to appeal and that she believed half of the co-defendants will make the same decision.

Asked whether the anti-Chen campaign will take to the streets again in the future, Yao said it will be "merely a matter of time" if the KMT still turns a deaf ear to the calls to abolish the assembly law.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. to continue arms sales to Taiwan: U.S. state secretary
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 16 (CNA) 02/17/09 14:58:00 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton affirmed Monday that there will be no change in Washington's policy on arms sales to Taiwan under the new administration of President Barack Obama.
Clinton, who departed Sunday for a four-nation Asia visit, made the remarks in an interview during her flight to Japan, her first stop.

Clinton said U.S. policy with respect to Taiwan "remains as it has been" because it is based on Washington's long-standing "one China" policy, the three communiques with China and the Taiwan Relations Act.

"And under the Taiwan Relations Act, there is a clear provision that the United States will provide support for Taiwan's defense. And that is why there have been, over the many years, the sale of defensive materials to Taiwan," Clinton said.

Clinton said she is pleased about the decreased tension and increasing cooperation between Taiwan and China over the past months, which she said is a direction that the United States wants to support and promote.
The United States has long been Taiwan's most important weapons supplier, despite this being an irritant in U.S.-China relations.

In the latest arms deal between the two sides, the administration of former President George W. Bush approved in late 2008 the sale of a package of weapons to Taiwan, including 30 Apache attack helicopters, 330 advanced capability Patriot (PAC-3) missiles, 32 Harpoon sub-launched missiles, 182 Javelin guided missiles, and four E-2T system upgrades.
The move drew a strong protest from China, which reacted by suspending military- to-military exchanges and nonproliferation talks with the United States.
China will be the final leg of Clinton's Asia trip, which will also take her to Indonesia and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to tighten up on kumquat smuggling from China

TEXT.P: Taiwan does not allow the importation of fresh or preserved Kumquats from China, and government agencies will jointly clamp down on the smuggling of such products into the country, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Tuesday.

Chang Shu-shien, director-general of the COA's International Affairs Department, said Taiwan only allows a small amount of fresh kumquats from Japan and preserved kumquats from some Southeast Asian countries such as Thailand and Vietnam to be sold on the domestic market.
Chang made the statements in the wake of recent local media reports that substandard Chinese kumquats were being sold in Taiwan under the guise of produce from Yilan County in northeastern Taiwan.

According to Chang, about 300 hectares of land in Taiwan are used to grow kumquats, yielding about 4,000 metric tons of the fruit per year. Yilan County accounts for 90 percent of the production, with the peak harvest season being from December to February.
Twenty percent of the yield is distributed to retail markets, while 80 percent is used to make preserved snacks, she said.

Although the harvesting period for the fruit this year has almost ended, she said, COA officials will continue monitoring its retail prices on the domestic market to help guarantee the local farmers' profits.
The price of fresh kumquats in Taipei city's fruit and vegetable wholesale markets rose from NT$25.1 per kilogram in 2005 to NT$39.3 per kilogram on average in recent months.
Meanwhile, the COA has asked the customs and coastal patrol authorities to crack down more heavily on the smuggling of fresh and preserved kumquats from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Observation of Comet Lulin once-in-lifetime experience: scientists

TEXT.P: Two noted scientists urged the public Tuesday to join star gazers around the world in observing comet Lulin -- the first comet jointly discovered by astronomers on both sides of the Taiwan Strait in 2007 -- when it moves closest to the Earth on Feb. 24.

Speaking at a news conference, former National Central University (NCU) Vice President and Professor of Astronomy and Space Science Wing-huen Ip and Graduate Institute of Astronomy professor Chen Wen-ping said the approach of the comet provides a great opportunity for people to not only increase their knowledge of astronomy but also to experience the beauty of the night sky.
"It takes a kind of special destiny to be able to see a comet," said Chen.
"Given that comet Lulin's orbit takes over 20 million years to complete... this is a once-in-a-lifetime chance to see it, " Chen noted.
"This is the first and last time comet Lulin will enter the solar system," he added.
Ip said the comet allows scientists to learn about the past and explore the future.

"Astronomy sometimes is a bit like archeology, " said Ip. "Comets like Lulin, which are young and contains a lot of chemicals from the time it was created, provide us with a key to open the mysterious door of how our solar system was formed 4.5 billion years ago."
"The more we learn about the structure and functions of comets, the sooner we will be able to react when we find objects that pose a threat to the Earth," he added.

The discovery of Lulin (C/2227 N3) was part of the major achievements made in the Lulin Sky Survey project that was planned to explore the various populations of small bodies in the solar system, especially on studying objects that might present a hazard to the Earth.
It was initially described as an asteroidal object when found by Ye Quanzhi at the Sun Yat-sen University in Guangzhou, China.
Three images were obtained by Lin Chi-sheng of NCU's Graduate Institute of Astronomy July 11, 2007, using the 41-cm camera at the university's Lulin Observatory in Nantou, central Taiwan.
Noting that 2009 has been designated as International Year of Astronomy, Chen said the discovery of Lulin two years ago coincidentally makes it one of the biggest astronomy events of 2009.

The comet is moving between the constellations Scorpio and Libra and is expected to move toward Leo at an accelerating pace in late February, reaching its closest distance to the Earth on Feb. 24 -- about 61 million kilometers. It will be visible to the naked eye, according to Chen.
A series of events, including observation activities and seminars , have been organized by NCU to provide more information about the comet.

DOC.HEADLINE: Culture ministry slated for 2011: official

TEXT.P: A planned ministry of culture is slated to be inaugurated in 2011 to coincide with the 100th anniversary of the founding of the Republic of China, a Council of Cultural Affairs (CCA) official said Tuesday.

According to the Executive Yuan Organization Law Amendment, the ministry will have as many as eight departments, with seven in charge of integrated planning, humanities development, artistic development, the cultural and creative industries, international cultural exchanges, cultural resources, and media, cultural and creative development already planned, said CCA First Department Director Fang Jy-shiuh.
The CCA has sent an amendment of the organizational statute of the CCA to the Legislative Yuan so that legislation governing the new ministry can be passed next year, Fang said.

Once the ministry is established, its jurisdiction will cover the area of mass media affairs presently handled by the Government Information Office, and museum management now under the authority of the Ministry of Education.

In addition, in an effort to establish a unified regulatory authority for cultural affairs, the CCA will seek to have the ministry given jurisdiction over the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall, the National Theater Hall and the National Concert Hall, according to Fang.

To mark the country's 100th founding anniversary, the CCA will compile publications featuring Taiwanese culture by inviting outstanding people from various sectors of society to write articles pertaining to Taiwan's diversified and abundant cultural inheritance and resources, according to CCA Minister Huang Pi-twan.
In addition, the council has commissioned National Taiwan University to set up a database on national culture that will be added to its Web site, Huang said.
The council is also considering launching a series of cultural and creative products to celebrate the 100th founding anniversary, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices dropped Tuesday, with the Taiwan stock exchange's weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 99.48 points, or 2.16 percent, to close at 4,491.78.

Posting a loss for the second consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 4,572.97 and fluctuated between 4,585.28 and 4,475.17. A total of 3.13 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$63.56 billion (US$1.84 billion).
Only one of eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff stocks gaining 0.7 percent.

Seven other major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics stocks shedding the most at 2.9 percent, followed by textile shares at 2.6 percent, banking and financial stocks at 2.1 percent, cement stocks at 1.8 percent, construction stocks at 1.7 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks at 1.1 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.9 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,346 to 307, with 149 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$5.91 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, increasing NT$0.34 to close at NT$34.620.
A total of US$839 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$34.280 and closed at the day's high of NT$34.620.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's museum chief arrives in Shanghai
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Feb. 17 (CNA) 02/17/09 17:37:04 (By Chiao Hsing-hua and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The director of Taiwan's National Palace Museum (NPM) Chou Kung-hsin arrived in Shanghai Tuesday on the second leg of her historic visit to China.
The highlight of Chou's stay in Shanghai will be a visit Wednesday to the Shanghai Museum.
The main purpose of her current China trip is to discuss issues related to exchanges between the Taipei-based NPM and Beijing's Palace Museum.

According to conclusions reached during talks between Chou and Palace Museum curator Zheng Xinmiao Sunday in Beijing, the working groups set up respectively by the two sides will meet once a year to set the agenda for cooperation for the coming year, and the staff of the two museums will also exchange visits regularly.
The two sides will also exchange books and publications.
Also during the talks, the Beijing side agreed to lend Taipei 29 Qing dynasty artifacts for a three-month exhibition that will begin in October.
The meeting between Chou and Zheng marked the first formal engagement between the staff of the two museums since Taiwan and China split amid a civil war 60 years ago.

Each of the two museums holds part of the imperial artifacts of China. Beijing's loan of its collection to Taipei will make possible the first display of the imperial artifacts under one roof since they were it 60 years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Stay-at-home' economy growing despite general downturn: executive

TEXT.P: The game industry is thriving despite the worst economic downturn since the 1991 recession, with operators in the business speculating that the sector will enjoy growth of between 10 percent and 15 percent in Taiwan this year.

Wang Chun-po, CEO of the Kaohsiung-based Soft-World International Corp., said in a forum at the 2009 Taipei Game Show last week that almost all game producers have been taking in record-high revenues since the second half of last year.
He attributed this level of performance in the industry to the growing number of "new players" -- the unemployed and people on unpaid leave.

Since the growth of the industry is being driven by the development of a so- called "stay-at-home economy" in which home recreation is becoming more popular, the game businesses are worried about an economic recovery," Wang joked.

Wang's company reported record revenues of NT$736.85 million (US$21.38 million) in January, which represented a growth of 59.34 percent from the same month in 2008, and 7.56 percent from December last year.
The online game designer and producer reported revenues of NT$650 million in both November and December 2008, after the global economic storm broke.
Wang said online games are mostly designed with social functions that allow the users to make friends or let off steam without having to leave home.

In the future, there will room for Taiwan's game industry to continue to grow, he added, noting that Taiwanese players on average spend NT$457 per month on the purchase of online games, half of what buyers in South Korea spend.
Besides, there are still a lot of potential buyers among the new groups of unemployed and under-employed game players, Wang said.

According to a report released by the Council of Labor Affairs on Tuesday, as of Monday 203,000 workers at 439 companies around Taiwan had been forced to take unpaid leave days, up 10 percent from the period before the nine-day Lunar New Year holiday that ended Feb. 1.
The 2009 game show was held at the Taipei World Trade Center Feb. 12-16.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's top tourism official to visit Taiwan

TEXT.P: China's top tourism official, at the head of a 400-member delegation, will arrive in Taiwan Feb. 25 for a four-day market inspection visit.

It will be the third visit to Taiwan by Shao Qiwei, director of China's National Tourism Administration, as part of efforts to expand cross-Taiwan Strait tourism exchanges in the wake of an agreement last year between the two sides on a less restrictive tourism policy.

The delegation, the largest of its kind to ever visit Taiwan, will be composed of tourism officials and business representatives from China's major provinces. Its members will stay in Taiwan for 10 days.

They are slated to call on the Taiwan Visitors Association, the Taiwan Strait Tourism and Travel Association and visit tourist spots and facilities around the island to gain an understanding of the Taiwan market.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD raises public construction spending for 2009 to NT$150.6 billion

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) disclosed Monday that it last week adopted a special budget of NT$150.6 billion (US$4.34 billion) for 2009 as part of the government's expanded public construction program for the next four years.

The top economic policy-planning body indicated that the NT$150.6 billion budget, to be submitted to the legislature soon for screening, will be part of the four-year public construction program that will carry a price tag of NT$500 billion (US$14.46 billion).

CEPD officials said the four-year plan is expected to raise the gross domestic product (GDP) growth in real terms by 0.97 percentage points this year and increase real GDP growth by 1.22 percentage points, 1.01 percentage points, and 0.89 percentage points for 2010, 2011 and 2012, respectively.

The four-year program is projected to create between 190,000 and 220,000 jobs this year, with more new jobs to come on stream in the next three years. It is estimated that 200,000 to 230,000 jobs will be created in 2010; 160,000 to 190,000 jobs in 2011; and 120,000 to 150,000 jobs in 2012.
The officials stressed that the construction projects in the four-year plan are all necessary and urgent and will have a multiplying effect on the nation's economy.

The projects are intended to further improve Taiwan's public transportation networks, provide stable water supply to rural townships, enhance the safety of bridges, public roads and old school buildings, and strengthen the infrastructure to sharpen the nation's competitiveness.
According to the officials, some of the projects can begin as soon as the legislature passes the NT$150.6 billion budget for this year.

The legislative caucus of the ruling Kuomintang confirmed earlier this month that after the legislature's next session begins Feb. 20, the first and foremost item on the agenda will be the special budget bill for the government's expanded public construction program.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly 70% of people in Taiwan use Internet

TEXT.P: The number of Internet users in Taiwan had reached 15.8 million as of Jan. 3, representing an Internet usage rate of nearly 69 percent, according to a report released Tuesday by the Taiwan Network Information Center (TWNIC).
The survey showed that some 14.2 million Internet users, or nearly 71 percent of the Internet user population in Taiwan, were aged 12 or older.
About 13.3 million of the total Web surfers in Taiwan were broadband Internet users, which translated into a broadband prevalence rate of 66.5 percent, the poll found.

Some 68.94 percent of Taiwan's population across the age spectrum use the Internet, the survey found. In this respect, Taiwan ranks behind South Korea (73.83 percent) and Japan (73.85 percent) but higher than Hong Kong (66 percent) and Singapore (58.59 percent), the reported indicated.

The survey on the use of broadband Internet in Taiwan was conducted between Dec. 7, 2008 and Jan. 3 this year among people over the age of 12 in households that subscribe to local telephone services in 23 cities and counties around the country.
A total of 3,284 valid samples were collected for the survey. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 1.5 percentage points and a 95 percent confidence level.

According to polls conducted in the past few years, most of the people who did not use the Internet said this was because they felt no need or had no equipment to do so, said Liang Te-hsin, a professor at Fu Jen Catholic University's Department of Statistics and Information.

However, Internet access has become more widespread in Taiwan recently with the increased availability of government-funded equipment, according to Liang, who added that the matter of Internet use is a personal choice.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices mostly lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for February falling 76 points to close at 4,494, with 80,444 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for March lost 94 points to finish at 4,422, with 22,592 contracts traded, while June futures dropped 96 points to end at 4,367, with 130 contracts traded.
September futures fell 83 points to close at 4,160, with 128 contract transactions, while December futures lost 105 points to finish at 4,079, with 30 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 4,570 for February, 4,516 for March, 4,463 for June, 4,243 for September and 4,184 for December.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 99.48 points to finish at 4,491.78, on turnover of NT$63.56 billion (US$1.84 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

February TE futures fell 5.35 points to close at 180.2, with 4,333 contracts traded, while March TE futures lost 5.75 points to finish at 178.75, with 1,819 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June and December.
February TF futures were down 10.2 points to close at 501.6, with 2,624 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures decreased 9.6 points to finish at 497, with 1,369 contracts traded.
September TF futures fell 23.2 points to close at 472, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for June and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan mulls closing representative office in Bangladesh

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is considering shutting down its representative office in Bangladesh in light of its low level of performance, an official said Tuesday.

The ministry is currently conducting a comprehensive review of the effectiveness of its overseas offices with a view to maximizing its overall diplomatic resources, said MOFA's spokesman Henry Chen at a press briefing.

Closing a representative office, he explained, would involve considerations such as relations between Taiwan and the host government, the performance of the office in providing consular services and the number of Taiwanese based in the host country.
"The performance of the office in Bangladesh has so far been lackluster in this regard," he said.
However, the ministry will see whether any improvements can be achieved in the wake of the recent general elections in Bangladesh, he added.

He also stressed that the decision on whether or not to close the representative office will be fully based on Taiwan's own evaluation, and that it will not be influenced by the pressure China has exerted on Bangladesh since the office was established nearly five years ago.

The MOFA set up a representative office in India in 1995 and another in Bangladesh in 2004 -- Taiwan's only two in South Asia -- as part of its efforts to strengthen relations with countries in the region, help Taiwanese firms seek business opportunities there, and provide services for overseas Taiwanese living in those countries.

However, the Bangladesh office has encountered difficulties carrying out the functions that were initially agreed upon by the governments of Taiwan and the South Asian country due to pressure from China, according to a diplomatic source.
For example, issuing visas to Bangladeshis has been made impossible and they have had to turn instead to Taiwan's representative office in Thailand to obtain visas.
According to MOFA statistics, there were around 130 Taiwanese living in Bangladesh as of December last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Business at 100-dollar haircut shops takes off

TEXT.P: Shops that offer NT$100 (US$2.9) haircuts are seeing a sharp increase in business, as more people are trying to cut back on spending in a difficult economy.
With Taiwan caught in the tide of the global financial tsunami and people tightening their belts, personal grooming is one of expenses that is being trimmed.

Boys and men, who generally pay relatively less attention than females to hair styling, are choosing the 100-dollar haircut shops over hair salons or barbershops, giving those low-end businesses a big boost.
Business at such shops has grown by at least 10 percent with the start of the new school term, according to one shop owner surnamed Chang.
In Taichung City in central Taiwan, there is a 100-dollar haircut shop in almost every hypermart, and they offer a haircut-only service that does not include shampooing.
This type of value-for-money service has not only retained its usual clientele, but is also attracting many first-time customers.
"The number of customers started increasing slightly at the end of last year," Chang told the Central News Agency.
This could be as a result of people trying to save money or because the public is pleased with the quality of 100-dollar haircuts," he added.
Facing fierce competition from 100-dollar haircut shops, many hair salons have jumped on the bandwagon and are now offering 100-dollar haircuts in a bid to keep their customers.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA releases list of most environmentally friendly cars

TEXT.P: Eight car models were included on the Environmental Protection Administration's (EPA's) list of most environmentally friendly vehicles for 2009 released Tuesday.
Of these eight models, four were products of the world's largest automaker Toyota, namely the Corolla Altis 2.0L and the hybrid electric cars Toyota Prius, Lexus RX400H and Lexus GS450H.
The other four vehicles on the list were the Smart Fortwo, the Suzuki SX4 HB GLX, the Nissan Tiida 1.6L and the Mercedes-Benz B170.
EPA officials said the vehicles were selected for their low levels of noise, fuel consumption, and air polluting emissions

DOC.HEADLINE: 200,300 workers being given unpaid leave days: labor council

TEXT.P: More than 200,300 workers across Taiwan are having to take unpaid days off, which represents a 10 percent increase over the number recorded in a survey prior to the Lunar New Year, the Cabinet-level Council for Labor Affairs (CLA) announced Tuesday.
According to the council, the estimate is based on reports on unpaid leave practices submitted to the CLA on Jan. 16 by 439 companies across the country.

Since January, the CLA has been stipulating that local enterprises report the number of workers they ask to take unpaid leave, to better monitor the impact of falling exports on Taiwan's labor market, said Sun Pi-hsia the head of the department of labor standards of the CLA.

Starting this week, the CLA will conduct random inspections at approximately 200 local companies to check whether they obtained the consent of their employees before asking them to take unpaid leave and whether such workers are receiving at least the minimum monthly salary of NT$17,280 (US$499) as required by law, said Sun.

"The local labor bureaus will fine companies that are not paying their employees the minimum monthly wage and those employers who failed to obtain the consent of their workers before sending them on unpaid leave," he added.
As of Jan. 16, some 200,300 workers across Taiwan were being asked to take unpaid leave days, with those in high-tech sector most likely to fall victim to this practice.

Meanwhile, the number of workers on full or partial unpaid leave in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan has reached over 10,000 accounting for 77 percent of the park's total work force.
Taiwan's exports -- most of which are high-tech products -- declined due to falling demand from key markets such as China, the United States and Europe in the current global economic downturn.
Since the end of last year, many Taiwanese companies have asking their workers to take unpaid leave or face layoff, as a means of reducing operating costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma urges U.S. to grant Taiwan visa-free access

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou expressed his hope Tuesday that the U.S. government will offer Taiwanese citizens visa-free treatment, saying such treatment from Japan has helped boost passenger traffic between the two countries.
Ma made the request during his meeting at the Presidential Office with visiting U.S. Representative Shelley Berkley (D-Nevada), who is also the co-chair of the Congressional Taiwan Caucus.
Ma noted that the United Kingdom recently announced it would grant Taiwan passport holders visa-free access and said Japan launched the measure for Taiwan in 2005.

The preferential treatment encourages local tourists to travel to the countries, Ma said, with Taiwanese visitors to Japan growing to one-sixth of all foreign visitors to the country after the visa exemption for Taiwanese travelers began.
At the same time, the number of Japanese visitors to Taiwan has grown to over one-fourth of all foreign visitors to Taiwan, which Ma also attributed to visa- free access.

According to Bureau of Tourism statistics, the number of travelers between Taiwan and Japan hit a record high in 2007, with nearly 1.17 million Japanese visiting Taiwan and 1.28 million Taiwanese visiting Japan.
Berkley arrived in Taiwan Sunday for a five-day visit at the invitation of Taipei County-based Fu Jen Catholic University. She is scheduled to leave Feb. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese director to shoot remaining scenes of 'Visages' in Taipei

TEXT.P: Renowed Taiwanese film director Tsai Ming-liang said Tuesday that he and his crew are ready to shoot the remaining scenes of his latest film "Visages" in Taipei after spending four months working on the French-Taiwanese production in Paris.

Accompanied by French actress Fanny Ardant and other members of the cast, Tsai said at a press conference in Taipei that he felt very proud and happy that a Taiwanese work would be chosen to feature the Louvre Museum in Paris, and that he has done his best to show that cultural value can be preserved in a movie.
Tsai said that while the film might prove controversial, he was sure that this Taiwanese production, with French assistance, would redefine art and show that movies are also a type of culture.

"I have experienced a lot of pressure in Paris as I have continuously reminded myself that 'Visages' might be compared to the construction of the Louvre Pyramid by I.M. Pei in 1983, which is now a Paris landmark," Tsai said.

The key, however, to the creation of any unique and original work is the "return to innocence," Tsai said. "I had to make myself into a child again in order to let my imagination flow freely," he admitted.
Tsai said he was excited and anxious to shoot the rest of the film in Taipei, because "it is a great opportunity to promote Taipei City to worldwide movie viewers through filmmaking."

Expressing thanks to the Taipei City government's support and assistance, Tsai said that he is grateful that many city government officials worked hard to get the 500 tons of water needed for a vital scene of the film.

The film will include many elements of Taiwan's modern and ancient culture, such as the way Taiwanese people dump their trash, hold funerals and build houses, which Tsai says are unique compared to other cultures in the world.

Meanwhile, when asked about her experience working with Tsai, Ardant said she has communicated with the director through an interpreter, but noted that both of them could understand what each other wanted through facial expressions after working together for a while.
"Although I don't understand Chinese, the tone of the language is beautiful and sounds as if people are singing to me, " Ardant said.
In addition, Ardant said that it is great to be part of a film that can connect two cities of the world that are so different.
"I usually don't like traveling or going to places as a tourist, but I am very happy to have a chance to visit Taiwan and work on the film with Tsai," she said.

The movie, a tribute to French New Wave cinema, will be a film within a film. It tells the story of a Chinese filmmaker who heads to the Louvre to shoot a film that revolves around the myth of Salome and her request to her father Herod that St. John the Baptist be beheaded.

Financed by NT$200 million (US$5.78) in investment from Taiwan, France, the Netherlands and Belgium, the production has already been tapped as a possible hit at next year's Cannes International Film Festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to resume fishing talks with Japan after four-year hiatus

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Japan will hold their 16th round of fisheries talks late this month in Taipei to search for a solution to fishing rights issues in disputed waters, Tsai Ming-yao, secretary-general of the quasi-official Association of East Asian Relations (AEAR), said Tuesday.
"The meeting will be held in Taipei soon, and more details will be made public in the coming days, " Tsai told a news briefing at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

"Taiwan hopes to forge a consensus with Japan on settling bilateral fishery disputes and work out a joint management mechanism in disputed overlapping waters by putting aside the sovereignty controversy surrounding the Tiaoyutai Islands in the East China Sea," he said.
The Japanese call the Tiaoyutais the Senkaku Islands.
Taipei and Tokyo have held 15 rounds of fisheries talks since 1996, with the last round occurring in July 2005 in Tokyo, but sharp differences remain between the two countries.
The association was set up under the MOFA in 1972 to handle affairs relating to Japan after Tokyo switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing that same year.

DOC.HEADLINE: More people in Hualien seek counseling over the phone

TEXT.P: The number of people in Hualien County seeking counseling over the telephone increased by close to 40 percent in January this year, the county's lifeline center said Tuesday.
There were about 150 such calls to the center in January, up 36.3 percent compared to the 110 calls recorded for the same month last year, LifeLine Hualien Center chief Chiu You said.
Around one-third of the 150 telephone calls were made by people who had lost their jobs.

Chiu said that judging from the phone calls, it was easy to grasp the seriousness of the recent spate of layoffs. Most of those seeking help were unemployed workers aged between 40-50, with some 50 percent of those asking for help mentioning their intention to commit suicide.

The center received over 60 calls during the week-long Lunar New Year holidays in late January, with a majority related to problems arising from joblessness, such as poor relations between husbands and wives and between children and parents.

Last year, 60.3 percent of the calls for help to the center were made by women, and 39.7 percent by men, with the 40-49 age group accounting for the largest share of 28.6 percent, center statistics showed. Those aged between 30 and 39 accounted for 19.1 percent of the calls.
A vast majority of 79 percent of last year's calls for help did not indicate any intention to commit suicide -- a big departure from the latest trend, center officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. legislative aides learn about work of Taiwan medical group

TEXT.P: A delegation of U.S. legislative assistants paid a visit Tuesday to the Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps (TRMPC) in recognition of the non-governmental organization's humanitarian relief efforts.

Led by William Pewen, a senior health policy advisor to Republican Senator Olympia Snowe of Maine, the 13-member delegation headed to the TRMPC office in Xindian, Taipei County to gain a better understanding of the organization's work. The TRMPC is dedicated to improving the quality of life through the provision of medical services in aboriginal tribal areas in Taiwan and remote regions in foreign countries.

Speaking at a briefing, Huang Chen-wu, a TRMPC volunteer in charge of international affairs, said that the organization has held some 190 free clinics in Taiwan and in 40 countries around the world over the past 14 years. It has provided post-war aid in Kosovo, given medical treatment to victims of the South Asia tsunami and the Indonesia earthquake, and offered humanitarian assistance in the poorest areas of the world, Huang added.

The TRMPC is the first and only non-governmental organization from Taiwan to obtain a seat in the Conference of Non- Governmental Organizations in Consultative Relationship with the United Nations, according to Huang.
Several of the visiting U.S. delegates expressed concern over the health of Taiwan's aboriginal people and their migration to urban areas.

Micheleen Crowell, an aide to Democratic Congressman John Lewis, also asked about the effects of the current economic recession on the TRMPC's operations and the willingness of its volunteers to pay their own expenses while providing medical aid overseas.

Citing a recent mission to Kenya as an example, TRMPC President Liu Chi-chun said every volunteer worker paid NT$75,000 (US$2,167) for the trip during the Chinese New Year holiday with the aim of showing the world Taiwan's willingness and ability to help people in need.
The U.S. delegation will also visit the Buddhist Tzu Chi Foundation in Hualien.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exchanges of U.S. and Taiwanese fugitives difficult: MOFA

TEXT.P: A Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday it would be difficult to arrange the exchange of an American suspect recently apprehended in Taipei for Taiwanese fugitives living in the U.S. because the two countries do not have a mutual extradition agreement.

MOFA spokesman Henry Chen was responding to an opinion piece by Loh I-cheng, Taiwan's former ambassador to South Africa, who suggested that an American fugitive recently apprehended in Taiwan could be used as a bargaining chip to get the U.S. to extradite individuals living there who are wanted by Taiwan.

Loh was referring to Wang You-theng, who allegedly embezzled billions of Taiwan dollars from his Rebar Asia Pacific Group, and Huang Fang-yen, the former deputy head of the Shin Kong Memorial Hospital.
Prosecutors want to question Huang as a witness in the investigation into corruption and money-laundering allegations againt former President Chen Shui- bian and his wife.

Chen said that it would not be easy to negotiate such a deal due to the lack of an extradition treaty between Taiwan and the U.S. He pointed out, however, that the signing of such an agreement is a top priority of President Ma Ying-jeou's administration.

Ma has successfully rebuilt mutual trust between Taiwan and the U.S. since assuming office last May, Chen said, and the administration is now also focusing its efforts on getting Taiwan into the American visa waiver program and signing a free trade agreement with the U.S.
The fugitive Loh was referring to has been identified as Mark Lee Kaczmarczyk, who fled the U.S. to escape child molestation charges.

Kaczmarczyk, who is being held at the Sanhsia Alien Detention Center, was nabbed in Taipei by Taiwan's Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) Sunday after the CIB was contacted by the U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) for help in locating the suspect.
According to the CIB, Kaczmarczyk was wanted in California for allegedly molesting six children at a daycare center that he operated and could face a jail term of 48 years.

Despite the absence of an extradition treaty between the two countries, Kaczmarczyk is likely to be repatriated to the U.S. if he is not found to have committed any crimes while in Taiwan, the CIB said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Anti-gambling activists vow to oppose casinos in Penghu County

TEXT.P: The Penghu County government plans to hold 37 explanatory forums in the county's neighborhoods to enlist support for its plan to allow casinos to be set up on the Taiwan-held island group, but anti-gambling activists have turned seven of the first 10 sessions into boisterous debates.

Members of the Taiwan Anti-Gambling Alliance complained that they were not invited to the first three explanatory forums. They insisted that they had the right to attend all the remaining sessions to be held in each and every village in the lead-up to a county-wide referendum on whether casinos should be allowed in the county.

Lin Chang-hsing, a convener of the alliance, criticized the county government for painting a rosy picture of the proposed casino operations while ignoring their potential negative effects, including moral depravity, deterioration of social order, and the majority of economic benefits being reaped by foreign financial groups.
"The residents of Penghu should be allowed to hear both pros and cons of the issue. Their right to know should not be affected," he said.
Lin vowed that members of the alliance will attend each of the remaining information forums to present their opposing view.
"We surely will follow the county government officials and their invited experts like a shadow," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Czech Gems' exhibition opens in Taipei

TEXT.P: The National Taiwan Museum (NTM) launched the "Czech Gems" exhibition Tuesday, and invited art lovers to experience the outstanding achievements, modern art and beauty of the Baroque architecture of the Czech Republic.

Speaking at the opening ceremony, Chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) Huang Pi-twan said that "Czech Gems, " which was jointly planned by the Czech Economic and Cultural Office (CECO) and NTM, allows a deeper understanding of the multi-faceted value and vitality of the Czech culture.

Located in central Europe, the Czech Republic dates back to an ancient civilization, and its long history and rich culture have given birth to fine literature, art, craft and architecture that are admired all over the world, she said.
The exhibition, which will run through April 5, includes technology, music, design, modern art, sports and scenery of the Czech Republic, from ancient to modern times, she added.

The CECO Representative Jaroslav Dolecek said at the ceremony that the word "gem" does not just mean a precious stone that has been cut and polished, as it also denotes something that is prized, especially for great beauty or perfection, or someone who is in some way outstanding and unique.
"One can find such gems in every country in the world, including Taiwan," said Dolecek.

"The Czech Gems exhibition will take you on a remarkable journey through the history of the Czech Republic up to the present day, and will provide a window on a place that for some will be a distant and little-known country somewhere in Europe, " the representative said.

In addition, Dolecek said that the exhibition will offer the Taiwanese public with a great opportunity to get acquainted with the achievements, famous personalities, world-renowned inventions, the breathtakingly beautiful architecture and refreshing modern art of the Czech Republic.

"I am confident that there is something for everyone in the exhibition, something that you will find interesting, surprising or admirable, and which will bring you joy, expand your knowledge, and leave you with a positive impression of my country and its people, " said Dolecek.

According to the NTM, the "Czech Gems" exhibition will also be presented at the National Tainan Living Art Center from April 8 to June 14, the Cultural Affairs Bureau of Kaohsiung County Government from June 27 to July 26, the Taichung County Seaport Art Center from Aug. 8 to Sep. 6, and the National Taitung Living Art Center from Sep. 19 to Oct. 30.
According to Huang, the CCA in recent years has been cooperating with the Ministry of Culture of the Czech Republic to promote an international cultural exchange plan.
"In 2005, the NTM created a special exhibition 'A Thousand Faces of Formosa- the Nature and Tradition of Taiwan' in the Czech Republic's National Museum," said Huang.
This was achieved on the basis of an exchange agreement between the CCA and the Ministry of Culture of the Czech Republic, she added.

Moreover, in 2007, the NTM invited the Czech Republic's National Museum to bring the "Traditional Czech Puppets" exhibition to Taiwan, which gave the people of Taiwan a chance to appreciate one of the Czech Republic's most important traditional art forms, Huang said.

"After several years of interaction and exchange, the cooperation between Taiwan and the Czech Republic with respect to exhibitions and cultural heritage preservation has strengthened the cultural ties between the two countries," she noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chief of Taiwan's Palace Museum explains visit to Shanghai
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Feb. 17 (CNA) 02/17/09 21:34:52 (By Chiao Hsing-hua & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Chou Kung-hsin, the director of Taiwan's National Palace Museum (NPM) said Tuesday that her visit to Shanghai is "purely for academic exchanges with the Shanghai Museum" to see what collections the museums could borrow from each other and display in their respective cities.

Chou, peppered by questions from Taiwanese reporters after arriving in Shanghai from Beijing, also denied reports that the Shanghai Museum wants to borrow from the NPM an 18th-century painting, titled "Along the River During the Qingming Festival, " for the World Expo Shanghai 2010.

Shanghai Museum Director Chen Xiejun stressed it has no plans to borrow the renowned painting created by Qing Dynasty court painters as a remake of the original version generally attributed to Song Dynasty artist Zhang Zeduan (1085-1145).

Zhang's painting, kept at Beijing's Palace Museum, depicts how people living during the Song period in Bianjing -- today known as Kaifeng in Henan Province -- celebrated the Qingming, or Tomb-sweeping, Festival.
Chou had no official activities in Shanghai Tuesday, and was scheduled to visit the Shanghai Museum the following day.
Chou arrived in Beijing last Saturday for a landmark visit and met with her counterpart at Beijing's Palace Museum, Zheng Xinmiao, on Sunday.

The meeting was the first formal engagement between curators of the two museums since much of the Beijing museum's collection was removed by the Kuomintang and hidden around China before being sent to Taiwan some 60 years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Special Olympics team wins 30 medals

TEXT.P: Taiwan won a total of 30 medals -- six golds, 12 silvers and 12 bronzes -- in the week-long 2009 Special Olympics World Winter Games that concluded recently in the United States, according to the Sports Affairs Council (SAC) Tuesday.
The 36 young athletes that represented Taiwan won medals in all four events in which they participated -- speed skating, figure skating, snowshoeing and floor hockey, the SAC said.

According to the council, U.S. Vice President Joe Biden attended the Idaho games and presented awards to the Taiwanese medalist in the figure skating event. A photograph of the presentation made the front page of the biggest local newspaper, "Boise Statesman," that day, the SAC said.
Upon their return to Taiwan Tuesday, the 59-member delegation, which participated in the event under the name "Chinese Taipei," was received by President Ma Ying-jeou, the SAC added.
Taiwan won 20 gold medals, 13 silvers and 10 bronzes in the 2005 Special Olympics in the Japanese city of Nagano, the SAC recalled.
At this year's games, held from Feb. 7-13, the other events included alpine skiing, cross-country skiing and snowboarding.

Like the Olympic Games, the Special Olympics are held every four years in summer and winter. The first Special Olympics Summer Games were held in the U.S. city of Chicago in 1968, while the first Winter Games were held in 1977 in Steamboat Springs, also in the U.S.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung mayor calls for more government support for charities

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu promised during a visit to a local nursery school Tuesday to extend more aid to social welfare groups to help them cope with financial shortfalls exacerbated by the global economic slowdown.

Hu pledged that he will not sit idly by at a time when many social welfare foundations, particularly those taking care of children and the elderly, have been hit hard by financial problems as private donations to charities have shrunk since late last year.

According to the mayor, he has twice reported to President Ma Ying-jeou and once to first lady Chow Mei-ching about the seriousness of the problem, in the hope that the government could offer greater financial assistance to these social welfare organizations.

The mayor made the remarks while on a visit to the Daniel A. Poling Memorial Babies' Home -- his second visit to the nursery school in a month. He had called on the facility shortly before the Lunar New Year in late January.
The nursery school now raises 96 children, included seven babies recently deserted by their parents.
When Hu arrived at the nursery school, a 20-year-old multiple- handicapped man presented a painting featuring Hu and his wife to the mayor. The painting was done by the young man himself.

DOC.HEADLINE: Judicial Yuan chief to visit Saint Lucia as special envoy

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has appointed the president of the Judicial Yuan, Lai In- jaw, as his special envoy to celebrations marking the 30th anniversary of Saint Lucia's independence, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday in a statement.

Saint Lucian Prime Minister Stephenson King invited Ma to visit his country for the celebration slated for Feb. 22. Ma, however, could not attend because of his official duties and appointed Lai to represent him, the statement said.

Lai, heading a special delegation, will leave for the Caribbean country Wednesday. During his stay there, he will visit King and inspect a hospital for mentally ill patients built with Taiwan's support.
Taiwan resumed diplomatic relations with Saint Lucia on April 30, 2007, after the latter severed ties in 1997 in favor of Beijing.
According to the foreign ministry, the two countries have maintained a close cooperative relationship with each other since the resumption of diplomatic ties.
Former President Chen Shui-bian visited the Caribbean country in January 2008 and King visited Taiwan in June that same year.
Saint Lucia has been a staunch supporter of Taiwan's bid for access to the United Nations and the World Health Organization, the MOFA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taoyuan Aviation City plan to solicit expert views

TEXT.P: The government will invite construction consultants from other countries to attend a public forum in Taipei in mid-March to offer their views on a sketch plan for a proposed international airport park, civil aeronautics officials disclosed Monday.

Officials at the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said the CAA was working on the sketch plan, which will be used as a blueprint for the development of the proposed Taoyuan Aviation City and Taoyuan Airport Park.
The sketch plan is scheduled to be completed by the end of January 2010, and the CAA hopes the Cabinet will approve the finalized plan by the end of June next year.

Because the CAA attaches great importance to the plan, it has decided to invite construction consultants from the United States, Canada, the United Kingdom, France, Germany, the Netherlands, Australia, Japan and Singapore through their economic and trade representatives in Taipei to attend the mid-March forum.
All construction consultants interested in submitting tenders for projects under the aviation city plan in the future are welcome to offer their expert views on the design of the project
The CAA said the sketch plan will be coordinated with Taiwan's transportation and industrial development policies and focus on the park's functional role and development strategy.

The Cabinet has included the Taoyuan International Aviation City plan as one of the "i-Taiwan 12 Projects" devised to boost Taiwan's economy after the Statute For Developing International Airport Park was promulgated on Jan. 23.
The Aviation City project aims to turn the northern Taiwan airport and surrounding areas into an aviation city comprising aviation-related industries and services to boost local economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese director to shoot remaining scenes of 'Visages' in Taipei

TEXT.P: Renowed Taiwanese film director Tsai Ming-liang said Tuesday that he and his crew are ready to shoot the remaining scenes of his latest film "Visages" in Taipei after spending four months working on the French-Taiwanese production in Paris.

Accompanied by French actress Fanny Ardant and other members of the cast, Tsai said at a press conference in Taipei that he felt very proud and happy that a Taiwanese work would be chosen to feature the Louvre Museum in Paris, and that he has done his best to show that cultural value can be preserved in a movie.
Tsai said that while the film might prove controversial, he was sure that this Taiwanese production, with French assistance, would redefine art and show that movies are also a type of culture.

"I have experienced a lot of pressure in Paris as I have continuously reminded myself that 'Visages' might be compared to the construction of the Louvre Pyramid by I.M. Pei in 1983, which is now a Paris landmark," Tsai said.

The key, however, to the creation of any unique and original work is the "return to innocence," Tsai said. "I had to make myself into a child again in order to let my imagination flow freely," he admitted.
Tsai said he was excited and anxious to shoot the rest of the film in Taipei, because "it is a great opportunity to promote Taipei City to worldwide movie viewers through filmmaking."

Expressing thanks to the Taipei City government's support and assistance, Tsai said that he is grateful that many city government officials worked hard to get the 500 tons of water needed for a vital scene of the film.

The film will include many elements of Taiwan's modern and ancient culture, such as the way Taiwanese people dump their trash, hold funerals and build houses, which Tsai says are unique compared to other cultures in the world.

Meanwhile, when asked about her experience working with Tsai, Ardant said she has communicated with the director through an interpreter, but noted that both of them could understand what each other wanted through facial expressions after working together for a while.
"Although I don't understand Chinese, the tone of the language is beautiful and sounds as if people are singing to me, " Ardant said.
In addition, Ardant said that it is great to be part of a film that can connect two cities of the world that are so different.
"I usually don't like traveling or going to places as a tourist, but I am very happy to have a chance to visit Taiwan and work on the film with Tsai," she said.

The movie, a tribute to French New Wave cinema, will be a film within a film. It tells the story of a Chinese filmmaker who heads to the Louvre to shoot a film that revolves around the myth of Salome and her request to her father Herod that St. John the Baptist be beheaded.

Financed by NT$200 million (US$5.78) in investment from Taiwan, France, the Netherlands and Belgium, the production has already been tapped as a possible hit at next year's Cannes International Film Festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to resume fishing talks with Japan after four-year hiatus

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Japan will hold their 16th round of fisheries talks late this month in Taipei to search for a solution to fishing rights issues in disputed waters, Tsai Ming-yao, secretary-general of the quasi-official Association of East Asian Relations (AEAR), said Tuesday.
"The meeting will be held in Taipei soon, and more details will be made public in the coming days, " Tsai told a news briefing at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

"Taiwan hopes to forge a consensus with Japan on settling bilateral fishery disputes and work out a joint management mechanism in disputed overlapping waters by putting aside the sovereignty controversy surrounding the Tiaoyutai Islands in the East China Sea," he said.
The Japanese call the Tiaoyutais the Senkaku Islands.
Taipei and Tokyo have held 15 rounds of fisheries talks since 1996, with the last round occurring in July 2005 in Tokyo, but sharp differences remain between the two countries.
The association was set up under the MOFA in 1972 to handle affairs relating to Japan after Tokyo switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing that same year.

DOC.HEADLINE: More people in Hualien seek counseling over the phone

TEXT.P: The number of people in Hualien County seeking counseling over the telephone increased by close to 40 percent in January this year, the county's lifeline center said Tuesday.
There were about 150 such calls to the center in January, up 36.3 percent compared to the 110 calls recorded for the same month last year, LifeLine Hualien Center chief Chiu You said.
Around one-third of the 150 telephone calls were made by people who had lost their jobs.

Chiu said that judging from the phone calls, it was easy to grasp the seriousness of the recent spate of layoffs. Most of those seeking help were unemployed workers aged between 40-50, with some 50 percent of those asking for help mentioning their intention to commit suicide.

The center received over 60 calls during the week-long Lunar New Year holidays in late January, with a majority related to problems arising from joblessness, such as poor relations between husbands and wives and between children and parents.

Last year, 60.3 percent of the calls for help to the center were made by women, and 39.7 percent by men, with the 40-49 age group accounting for the largest share of 28.6 percent, center statistics showed. Those aged between 30 and 39 accounted for 19.1 percent of the calls.
A vast majority of 79 percent of last year's calls for help did not indicate any intention to commit suicide -- a big departure from the latest trend, center officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. legislative aides learn about work of Taiwan medical group

TEXT.P: A delegation of U.S. legislative assistants paid a visit Tuesday to the Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps (TRMPC) in recognition of the non-governmental organization's humanitarian relief efforts.

Led by William Pewen, a senior health policy advisor to Republican Senator Olympia Snowe of Maine, the 13-member delegation headed to the TRMPC office in Xindian, Taipei County to gain a better understanding of the organization's work. The TRMPC is dedicated to improving the quality of life through the provision of medical services in aboriginal tribal areas in Taiwan and remote regions in foreign countries.

Speaking at a briefing, Huang Chen-wu, a TRMPC volunteer in charge of international affairs, said that the organization has held some 190 free clinics in Taiwan and in 40 countries around the world over the past 14 years. It has provided post-war aid in Kosovo, given medical treatment to victims of the South Asia tsunami and the Indonesia earthquake, and offered humanitarian assistance in the poorest areas of the world, Huang added.

The TRMPC is the first and only non-governmental organization from Taiwan to obtain a seat in the Conference of Non- Governmental Organizations in Consultative Relationship with the United Nations, according to Huang.
Several of the visiting U.S. delegates expressed concern over the health of Taiwan's aboriginal people and their migration to urban areas.

Micheleen Crowell, an aide to Democratic Congressman John Lewis, also asked about the effects of the current economic recession on the TRMPC's operations and the willingness of its volunteers to pay their own expenses while providing medical aid overseas.

Citing a recent mission to Kenya as an example, TRMPC President Liu Chi-chun said every volunteer worker paid NT$75,000 (US$2,167) for the trip during the Chinese New Year holiday with the aim of showing the world Taiwan's willingness and ability to help people in need.
The U.S. delegation will also visit the Buddhist Tzu Chi Foundation in Hualien.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exchanges of U.S. and Taiwanese fugitives difficult: MOFA

TEXT.P: A Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday it would be difficult to arrange the exchange of an American suspect recently apprehended in Taipei for Taiwanese fugitives living in the U.S. because the two countries do not have a mutual extradition agreement.

MOFA spokesman Henry Chen was responding to an opinion piece by Loh I-cheng, Taiwan's former ambassador to South Africa, who suggested that an American fugitive recently apprehended in Taiwan could be used as a bargaining chip to get the U.S. to extradite individuals living there who are wanted by Taiwan.

Loh was referring to Wang You-theng, who allegedly embezzled billions of Taiwan dollars from his Rebar Asia Pacific Group, and Huang Fang-yen, the former deputy head of the Shin Kong Memorial Hospital.
Prosecutors want to question Huang as a witness in the investigation into corruption and money-laundering allegations againt former President Chen Shui- bian and his wife.

Chen said that it would not be easy to negotiate such a deal due to the lack of an extradition treaty between Taiwan and the U.S. He pointed out, however, that the signing of such an agreement is a top priority of President Ma Ying-jeou's administration.

Ma has successfully rebuilt mutual trust between Taiwan and the U.S. since assuming office last May, Chen said, and the administration is now also focusing its efforts on getting Taiwan into the American visa waiver program and signing a free trade agreement with the U.S.
The fugitive Loh was referring to has been identified as Mark Lee Kaczmarczyk, who fled the U.S. to escape child molestation charges.

Kaczmarczyk, who is being held at the Sanhsia Alien Detention Center, was nabbed in Taipei by Taiwan's Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) Sunday after the CIB was contacted by the U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) for help in locating the suspect.
According to the CIB, Kaczmarczyk was wanted in California for allegedly molesting six children at a daycare center that he operated and could face a jail term of 48 years.

Despite the absence of an extradition treaty between the two countries, Kaczmarczyk is likely to be repatriated to the U.S. if he is not found to have committed any crimes while in Taiwan, the CIB said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Anti-gambling activists vow to oppose casinos in Penghu County

TEXT.P: The Penghu County government plans to hold 37 explanatory forums in the county's neighborhoods to enlist support for its plan to allow casinos to be set up on the Taiwan-held island group, but anti-gambling activists have turned seven of the first 10 sessions into boisterous debates.

Members of the Taiwan Anti-Gambling Alliance complained that they were not invited to the first three explanatory forums. They insisted that they had the right to attend all the remaining sessions to be held in each and every village in the lead-up to a county-wide referendum on whether casinos should be allowed in the county.

Lin Chang-hsing, a convener of the alliance, criticized the county government for painting a rosy picture of the proposed casino operations while ignoring their potential negative effects, including moral depravity, deterioration of social order, and the majority of economic benefits being reaped by foreign financial groups.
"The residents of Penghu should be allowed to hear both pros and cons of the issue. Their right to know should not be affected," he said.
Lin vowed that members of the alliance will attend each of the remaining information forums to present their opposing view.
"We surely will follow the county government officials and their invited experts like a shadow," he said.

The Cabinet has included the Taoyuan International Aviation City plan as one of the "i-Taiwan 12 Projects" devised to boost Taiwan's economy after the Statute For Developing International Airport Park was promulgated on Jan. 23.
The Aviation City project aims to turn the northern Taiwan airport and surrounding areas into an aviation city comprising aviation-related industries and services to boost local economic development.
