DOC.HEADLINE: Judicial Yuan chief to visit Saint Lucia as special envoy

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has appointed the president of the Judicial Yuan, Lai In- jaw, as his special envoy to celebrations marking the 30th anniversary of Saint Lucia's independence, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday in a statement.

Saint Lucian Prime Minister Stephenson King invited Ma to visit his country for the celebration slated for Feb. 22. Ma, however, could not attend because of his official duties and appointed Lai to represent him, the statement said.

Lai, heading a special delegation, will leave for the Caribbean country Wednesday. During his stay there, he will visit King and inspect a hospital for mentally ill patients built with Taiwan's support.
Taiwan resumed diplomatic relations with Saint Lucia on April 30, 2007, after the latter severed ties in 1997 in favor of Beijing.
According to the foreign ministry, the two countries have maintained a close cooperative relationship with each other since the resumption of diplomatic ties.
Former President Chen Shui-bian visited the Caribbean country in January 2008 and King visited Taiwan in June that same year.
Saint Lucia has been a staunch supporter of Taiwan's bid for access to the United Nations and the World Health Organization, the MOFA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taoyuan Aviation City plan to solicit expert views

TEXT.P: The government will invite construction consultants from other countries to attend a public forum in Taipei in mid-March to offer their views on a sketch plan for a proposed international airport park, civil aeronautics officials disclosed Monday.

Officials at the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said the CAA was working on the sketch plan, which will be used as a blueprint for the development of the proposed Taoyuan Aviation City and Taoyuan Airport Park.
The sketch plan is scheduled to be completed by the end of January 2010, and the CAA hopes the Cabinet will approve the finalized plan by the end of June next year.

Because the CAA attaches great importance to the plan, it has decided to invite construction consultants from the United States, Canada, the United Kingdom, France, Germany, the Netherlands, Australia, Japan and Singapore through their economic and trade representatives in Taipei to attend the mid-March forum.
All construction consultants interested in submitting tenders for projects under the aviation city plan in the future are welcome to offer their expert views on the design of the project
The CAA said the sketch plan will be coordinated with Taiwan's transportation and industrial development policies and focus on the park's functional role and development strategy.

The Cabinet has included the Taoyuan International Aviation City plan as one of the "i-Taiwan 12 Projects" devised to boost Taiwan's economy after the Statute For Developing International Airport Park was promulgated on Jan. 23.
The Aviation City project aims to turn the northern Taiwan airport and surrounding areas into an aviation city comprising aviation-related industries and services to boost local economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 18, or the 24th day of first month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1517: Mary Tudor, the English queen known as "Bloody Mary" because of her relentless persecution of Protestants, is born.
1546: Martin Luther, German theologian and the 16th century Protestant reformation leader who confirmed the Augsburg Confession in 1530, effectively establishing the Lutheran Church, dies in Eisleben, Germany, at the age of 63.
1564: Michelangelo Buonarotti, Italian sculptor, painter, architect, poet, and the most brilliant representative of the Italian Renaissance who created some of the greatest works of all time, including his marble sculpture "David," the paintings on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel, and the plans for St. Peter's Cathedral, dies in Rome at the age of 89.
1678: John Bunyan, English preacher and writer celebrated for his "Pilgrim's Progress," the allegorical tale of a Christian's journey from the City of Destruction to the Celestial City, publishes the first part of his masterpiece.
1685: La Salle, a French explorer, sets up the first European settlement in Texas.
1745: Alessandro Volta, Italian physicist who invented the electric battery, is born. The volt is named in his honor.
1855: Nicholas I, the czar of Russia who suppressed the December Movement and led his country into the Crimean War, dies at the age of 59.
1915: German submarines start a maritime blockade of Great Britain.
1930: Clyde William Tombaugh, a US astronomer, is the first to see Pluto, realizing it is the Sun's ninth and smallest planet, at the Lowell Observatory in Flagstaff, Arizona.
1932: Japan announces that the "Manchukuo" regime will be installed in northeastern China. The "land of the Manchu" (Manchuria) proved to be no more than another stepping-stone for the expansion of Japanese aggression.
1943: Madame Chiang Kai-shek addresses a joint session of the US House and Senate.
1945: The battle for Iwo Jima starts in the Pacific.
1951: Prime Minister Tran Van Huu announces the formation of a new government in Vietnam.
1960: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Mexico, Paraguay, Peru and Uruguay agree to establish the Latin American Free Trade Association.
1965: The West African nation of Gambia proclaims independence.
1967: Robert Julius Oppenheimer, the American physicist known as the father of the A-bomb, dies at the age of 65.
1972: The Supreme Court of California abolishes the death penalty.
1974: Jorge Cervantes-Pinzon, outgoing charge d'affaires from Colombia, leaves Taipei for home.
1976: C.C. Yang, ROC economic affairs vice minister, and S.M. Osman, secretary- general of the Afro-Asian Rural Reconstruction Organization, sign an agreement on technical cooperation.
1984: McDonald's, the Chicago-based fast-food chain, opens its first branch in Taiwan.
1986: The Asian Development Bank votes to admit mainland China.
1988: Boris Yeltsin is ousted from the ruling Communist Party Politburo in Moscow.
1991: The US assault ship Tripoli and the guided missile cruiser Princeton are damaged by mines in the Persian Gulf during the Gulf War.
1992: A delegation from the US President's Export Council arrives in Taipei to promote bilateral trade.
1994: Lin Wen-chiang, a mainland Chinese hijacker, commandeers a Southwest Airlines passenger plane from the mainland to Taiwan.
1998: Mya Than Tint, one of Burma's most renowned and admired writers, dies at the age of 69.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man may have abilities as admirable as our Lord of Chou (the Chinese equivalent of Moses or Solomon), but if he is proud and mean, you need not consider the other qualities of his mind."

DOC.HEADLINE: Exhibition of Taiwan butterflies draws media attention in Hungary
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Feb. 17 (CNA) 02/18/09 12:12:28 (By Lin Yu-li and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Formosan butterflies, which were flown from Taiwan to Hungary in paper and styrofoam cases in their "previous life" as pupae, have stirred media interest in the eastern European country, the information division of Taiwan's representative office in Budapest reported Tuesday.
Hungarian electronic and print media outlets have widely reported a Formosan butterfly exhibition that was opened at the vintage Hungarian Natural History Museum in Budapest Tuesday.

It marked the first time since the museum's inception in 1802 that it has exhibited a large number of live insects, according to an official with the Taiwanese information division located in Budapest.
A total of 800 butterflies of various species are expected to emerge from their cocoons at the museum over the next 72 days until April 30, the last day of the exhibition, the official said.
Museum authorities anticipate that the display will draw at least 20,000 visitors over the next two months.

The Hungarian Natural History Museum has maintained close academic and ecological ties with Taiwan's museums and research institutions, including the National Taiwan Museum, the National Taiwan Museum of Natural Science, the Taiwan Forestry Research Institute and the Zoology Department of National Taiwan University.
The museum's researchers have visited Taiwan 23 times over the last 12 years for biological research or academic exchanges, according to the Taiwan official.

A similar Formosan butterfly exhibition was opened in Sweden's capital Stockholm earlier this month, also attracting large crowds. That exhibition is scheduled to run until the end of March, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Travelers to China urged to get measles vaccines for their infants

TEXT.P: The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) on Wednesday reminded people planning to travel to China with infants to make sure to have their children immunized against the measles prior to departure, following recent reports of measles infections traceable to China.

The most recent case involves a five-year-old boy from northern Taiwan, who came down with a fever and rashes early this month soon after returning from a trip to southern Taiwan during the Chinese New Year holiday, said CDC Deputy Director-General Chou Chih-hao.

An investigation found that the boy was hospitalized for other ailments for four days during his stay in southern Taiwan, sharing a room with an 11-month-old girl who was infected with the measles. He contracted the measles virus from the girl, Chou said.
The girl, whose mother is a Chinese citizen, fell ill soon after returning from a trip to China in mid-January. She had not received the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine, Chou said.
The boy, whose mother is also a Chinese citizen, had also never received the MMR vaccine, although he was given one dose of the measles vaccine in China when he was nine months old, he said.

The case follows another one reported late last year, in which a cluster of seven measles infections was traced to a 20-month-old boy from Kaohsiung who contracted the disease in China, according to Chou.
Noting that the number of measles cases reported in China has been on the rise over the past three years, Chou urged parents not to take children who have not received the MMR vaccine to China.
In Taiwan, children are normally given a first dose of the MMR vaccine when they are between 12-15 months old and a booster shot during their first year of elementary school.

In light of the high virulence of the measles virus, the CDC advised parents not to skip the MMR inoculation for their children, including those who have received the measles vaccine before reaching one year old.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Tainan County starts work on organic farm zone

TEXT.P: Tainan County began construction of a special zone for organic farming Wednesday, hoping to develop it into a textbook model for similar zones around the country and a place that will attract tourists.

Completion of the special organic zone is slated for August this year, and more than 20 farmers have already begun cultivating rice, raspberries, pomelos, pumpkins, eggplant and sweet potatoes in the compound, county officials said.
The special organic farm is located on a 40-hectare plot of land that the county government leased from the state-run Taiwan Sugar Company, county officials said.
Under the southern county's program, the land is being rented to farmers at NT$50,000 (US$1,445) per hectare per year, the officials explained.
A 1,000 square-meter sales and exhibition center will also be opened to sell produce from the zone.

DOC.HEADLINE: Labor council launches employment drive in Kinmen

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) launched a job fair on the Taiwan-held island of Kinmen Wednesday aimed at boosting employment there.

A total of 150 job opportunities were offered at the half-day fair taking place at a market located in Chincheng Township in western Kinmen, said Hsieh Yu-yueh, director of the Kinmen Office of the CLA Employment and Vocational Training Administration.
The 150 full-time job opportunities have been offered by dozens of private companies and stores around the Kinmen area, Hsieh said.
The job fair drew a big crowd, including several elderly women who were seen calling home on their cell phones to alert unemployed young people in their families to the opportunities.
According to Hsieh, a similar fair is scheduled to be held at another market in Chinhu Township in eastern Kinmen Thursday.

Meanwhile, the CLA Kinmen Office took the opportunity to screen candidates for 93 short-term jobs that several Kinmen-based public offices and schools are offering under an agreement with the CLA, Hsieh added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Elite high school student opts to transfer to less known school

TEXT.P: A student at the prestigious Taipei Municipal Jianguo High School in Taipei City has chosen to transfer to a less known high school in Taoyuan County to help his financially troubled parents.

Lin Tse-yu transferred to the private Chi-Ying Senior High School in Taoyuan earlier this month for the spring semester of his first year of study to take advantage of generous scholarships awarded by the high school to attract elite students.

Lin, who posted one of the highest scores on the high-school entrance examination, wrote two letters to Chi-Ying administrators during the winter break expressing his intention to transfer to the high school because the scholarship would help his parents, who have suffered financially because of their slumping beauty parlor business.

Chi Ying accepted Lin and decided to award him a scholarship for NT$1.66 million (US$48,823) over the next two-and-a-half years before he graduates, far beyond the actual fees and expenses he would have had to pay as a student there or at any local high school.
For his part, Lin said he was much obliged to Chi Ying for taking him on as a "transfer."

He said attending high school is just a short period of his life, and that he was glad to make the decision if the scholarship could help his parents at a time when Taiwan is in the middle of a global financial crunch.

DOC.HEADLINE: CECA will not be signed during third SEF-ARATS talks: SEF head

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China will not sign a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) during their planned third round of negotiations, the head of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation said Wednesday.

SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung told reporters at an economic cooperation forum in Taipei that the SEF and the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) will not ink a CECA, as preparations for negotiations with China concerning the issue have not yet concluded.
"The government has decided to sign a CECA with China at some point in the future, but it won't be during the third round of negotiations between the SEF and the ARATS," Chiang said.
According to Chiang, forging a CECA with China is vital for the normalization of trade and economic ties between Taiwan and China.

However, the signing of the complex agreement covering a wide range of issues requires discussions among relevant agencies of the two sides before it can be included as an issue on the agenda of future SEF-ARATS talks, he said.

Meanwhile, Chiang explained that the content and principles of a CECA and a free trade agreement are basically the same and the signing of a CECA between Taiwan and China will be consistent with the World Trade Organization's most favored nation status (MFN) principles.

"Despite many political difficulties, Taiwan needs to sign a CECA with China as soon as possible, " said Chiang, who contended that Taiwan's economy, industrial sector and export markets will be deeply impacted if it is excluded from the alliances between the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and three major East Asian economies -- China, South Korea and Japan.
Chiang warned that Taiwan will be marginalized once ASEAN members and South Korea finish signing FTAs or other forms of economic cooperation agreements with China.

Bilateral and multilateral economic cooperation and integration is an unstoppable trend in today's world economy, Chiang said, noting that there are already more than 250 FTAs registered under the WTO.
Chiang said, however, that "the majority of nations that have signed FTAs with Taiwan are from Latin America, and represents no more than 0.2 percent of Taiwan's overall export volume."

The signing of the CECA with China would prevent Taiwan from being marginalized in the international arena and would also allow the free flow of merchandise, services, and capital between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, he argued.
The SEF and the ARATS are quasi-official organizations designated by each side of the Taiwan Strait to handle cross-strait matters in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices marginally higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed marginally higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, advancing 6.59 points, or 0.14 percent, to close at 4,498.37.

Rebounding after two consecutive losing sessions, the local bourse opened lower at 4,455.75 and fluctuated between 4,520.67 and 4,428.29. A total of 3.21 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$62.89 billion (US$1.82 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues advancing 1.4 percent and machinery and electronics shares rising 0.5 percent.

The six other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues declining the most at 0.7 percent. Foreign investors were net buyer of shares worth NT$1.04 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Academics to launch silent commemoration of the 228 Incident

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Association of University Professors (TAUP) will commerorate the 228 Incident on Feb. 28 by sitting in silence, said TAUP Chairman Chen Yi-sheng Wednesday.
Speaking at a press conference held in Taipei, Chen urged all Taiwanese citizens, regardless of their political leaning, to participate in the activity.

"We hope to reveal the historical truth of the massacre that occured some 62 years ago in a peaceful manner, " said Chen, adding that the 228 Incident was a historical tragedy that has affected all of society.

According to Chen, during the "Never Forget the 228 Incident" event to be held at the National Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei, 1,246 participants will sit on the ground and spell out the Chinese characters for "never forget 228."
In addition, Chen said the activity will remain calm and peaceful as there will be no speeches or slogans.
"We will only play a pre-recorded tape of the events that happened during the 228 massacre," said Chen.

Chen said the historical truth of the 228 Incident has been clouded by the ongoing political conflict between the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , adding that politicians from both parties have used the incident for electoral purposes.
"The truth has been distorted as both parties have exploited the incident come election time," Chen said.

Asked if the vast majority of individuals and organizations that hope to uncover the truth of the 228 Incident are supporters of the pro-independence DPP, Chen said that the TAUP will reflect on the issue.

"Despite past stereotypes, we welcome with open arms all Taiwanese citizens who wish to participate in this event, because the 228 Incident is a historical tragedy that has shaken the lives of all Taiwanese citizens regardless of their ancestry or political leaning," noted Chen.
The 228 Incident was an anti-government uprising in Taiwan that began Feb. 28, 1947 and was violently suppressed by the KMT government.
An estimated 10,000 to 30,000 people were killed during the Incident and in ensuing violent crackdowns by the KMT administration in March and April 1947.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

DOC.HEADLINE: Yilan tour operators seek extension of lantern festival

TEXT.P: Tourism operators asked Yilan County Magistrate Lu Guo-hua Wednesday to extend the ongoing 2009 Taiwan Lantern Festival in Yilan City, northeastern Taiwan, which is scheduled to end Feb. 22.

Chang Ching-lai, an executive member of the Taiwan Leisure Farming Development Association, along with several representatives of recreational farming and lodging businesses, paid a call on Lu at the county hall earlier in the day and requested the extension, saying that the event has been drawing many visitors and trade opportunities.

Chang noted that Yilan's tourism usually drops to a "super-low" season after the Lunar New Year festival. However, he said, thanks to the Taiwan Lantern Festival, which was held in Yilan this year for the first time in history, the occupancy rate at his hotel has increased five fold compared with the same period last year.
He added that the 10-plus foreign tour groups from Hong Kong and Singapore staying at his hotel have all listed the lantern festival, which began Feb. 9, as a must see.
"Several foreign tourists have even said they wished their tour schedule allowed them more hours at the festival, " Chang said.

In response to the request, Lu said that an extension of the festival would involve negotiating the many contracts that the organizers signed with performing groups. However, if this issue can be worked out and the MOTC agrees to the proposal, then he would be delighted to see the event prolonged, the county magistrate said.

The Taiwan Lantern Festival, jointly organized by the Bureau of Tourism under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) and the Yilan County government, has attracted tens of thousands of visitors every day since it opened.

Because of the large number of people traveling to Yilan City for the festival, most of the major roads between the city and the surrounding townships have been frequently congested, with the worst traffic conditions occurring over the last two weekends.
The Toucheng toll station on the Taipei-Yilan Freeway recorded some 74,000 vehicles on the highway on Valentine's Day Feb. 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cherry blossoms highlight opening of Yangmingshan flower season

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government said visitors to this year's Yangmingshan National Park flower festival, which opens Friday and lasts until March 22, will be treated to spectacular cherry blossoms.

Kao Tao-han, deputy director of the city Parks and Street Lights Office, said Wednesday that cherry trees on Yangmingshan are in full bloom and the red of their blossoms is the richest in years thanks to the big gap between temperatures during the day and those at night.

Aside from cherry blossoms, many other flowers, including different kinds of azaleas and daffodils, are flourishing in the scenic park, which covers 11,455 hectares of mountainous land in the northern suburbs of the city, Kao added.
Details in Chinese on the festival and traffic information are available at the Web site http://2009yms.com.tw/page0.html.

DOC.HEADLINE: Central Bank announces new interest rate cut

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of the Republic of China announced Wednesday that it will further lower its key interest rates by 0.25 percentage points as part of its efforts to boost exports and encourage investment.

After the adjustments that will take effect Thursday, the benchmark discount rate -- the rate the central bank charges on loans to commercial banks -- will stand at 1.25 percent, while the rate on accommodations with collateral will fall to 1.625 percent and the rate on accommodations without collateral will be 3.5 percent.
The latest cut marks the bank's seventh downward rate adjustment since September 2008. The previous six cuts slashed the key interest rates by a total of 2.125 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government lowers GDP forecast to -2.9% for 2009

TEXT.P: Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) will contract by an estimated 2.97 percent in 2009 after the economy shrunk by 8.36 percent in the fourth quarter of 2008, the largest quarterly decline in history, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) announced Wednesday.

It was the first time the government agency has forecast negative growth for Taiwan in 2009, and follows even more pessimistic predictions by foreign investment firms that foresee the country's economy contracting by between 6 percent and 11 percent.
Preliminary statistics show that GDP grew by 0.12 percent in 2008, the lowest since 2001, the DGBAS said.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Steel likely to post a loss in the first quarter

TEXT.P: China Steel Corp., Taiwan's largest steel maker, confirmed Wednesday that it is likely to post an operating loss in the first quarter of the year, mainly because of retroactive discounts to customers.

Chung Lo-min, executive vice president of China Steel, said that as a result of retroactive discounts totaling NT$4 billion (US$115.2 million) in the first quarter, China Steel will likely register a decline in revenues for the January to March period.
If Chung's forecast is accurate, it will be the second quarterly loss in a row for the steel maker, which is 23 percent owned by the government.

China Steel suffered its first quarterly loss in its nearly 40-year history in the fourth quarter of 2008, reporting a loss of NT$18.62 billion, which reduced its income for that year to NT$30.2 billion, down 50 percent from 2007.

In late November it decided to lower the prices of its steel products by an average of 22.56 percent, or an average of NT$7,058 per metric ton, for the first quarter of 2009 to help relieve the plight of mid- and downstream steel factories in Taiwan suffering from the global economic downturn.

On Tuesday, China Steel announced a further average price reduction of 14.03 percent, or NT$3,353 per metric ton, for the domestic market in April and May, with the prices for June to be determined separately in the future.

The new prices will be retroactive to the first three months of the year and are expected to cost the company NT$4 billion in first quarter revenue, sending revenues lower for the second consecutive quarter, Chung said.
The quoted prices for April and May are as follows:
--Steel plates: NT$4,166 per metric ton;
--Steel rod and wire products: NT$3,500 per ton;
--Hot-rolled steel coils: NT$3,000 per ton;
--Cold-rolled steel coils: NT$2,691 per ton;
--Electro-galvanized steel coils: NT$4,000 per ton;
--Electrical steel coils: NT$4,500;
--Hot-dipped galvanized steel coils: NT$2,869 per ton.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government's economic focus remains boosting domestic demand: CEPD

TEXT.P: The government will not only help exports but will also continue its efforts to expand domestic demand to help revive the slumping economy, the nation's top economic planner said Wednesday.
"Rising unemployment is also a major government concern, " said Chen Tien-jy, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), at a gathering of entrepreneurs.
The jobless rate hit 5.03 percent in December and is generally expected to rise even further after the announcement of January's jobless rate later this month, Chen said.

On public calls for the government to issue a new round of shopping vouchers to help stimulate consumption, Chen said the council will wait until September to assess the results of the first round of the program.
He noted that there is still a Dragon Boat Festival, a traditional festival which falls on June 27, that could spark a wave of spending between now and September when the vouchers must be used.
The government distributed around NT$85 billion in vouchers to spur consumption on the island and boost Taiwan's ailing retail sector. Each citizen was given NT$3,600 in vouchers.
Chen said that if exports decline by 20 percent and imports also decline, it will affect gross domestic product by around 2 percentage points.
But Chen indicated that the major factor behind the local economy's contraction in the fourth quarter was the 30 percent decline in private investment.
Chen would not comment on the recent sharp depreciation of new Taiwan dollar, which has helped exporters but hurt importers.
The new Taiwan dollar closed at NT$34.650 to the U.S. dollar Wednesday. (By Lilian Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: Demining work on Kinmen to resume March 2

TEXT.P: A project to clear landmines in the Mashan area of the Taiwan-controlled island of Kinmen off China's Fujian province is scheduled to begin March 2 and last for four months, the Kinmen Defense Command reported Wednesday.

The Mashan demining operations will be carried out by the Singaporean Explomo Technical Services Pte Ltd. over an area of 140,000 square meters in three stages over a four-month period, the defense command said.

Explomo, which won the demining contract in an open bid last year, will clear landmines in six minefields in Kinmen covering 214,900 square meters during the whole year, while the demining team of the Army Engineers Corps will clear 21 minefields over a total area of about 389,900 square meters, the command said.

Speaking at a news conference held at a borough office in Chinsha Township, an Explomo project manager Huang Jou-li said that the first stage of the Mashan demining operations will be highly dangerous because it involves mainly manual jobs in shallow minefields mostly in the beachside casuarina woods.
Traffic controls will be put in place around the Mashan area daily, during the periods 5:30 a.m. to 9:30 a.m. and 3:30 p.m. to 5:30 p.m., in the first month of operations, Huang said.

Huang also gave the assurance that Explomo operators will mark the graves in the area and will not disturb them. Any human remains found in the demining process will be collected and stored for interment in a shrine that will be built in Kinmen later, he said.

Last December, the Kinmen Defense Command gave an order for demining operations over a 20-hectare area in Kuningtou village to be suspended, pending consultations with the island's residents who had complained that the demining work had destroyed nearly 1,000 graves of their ancestors.
Kuningtou was the site of a 1949 battle in which Republic of China forces defeated two invading regiments of China's People's Liberation Army.
The shores of Kinmen -- Taiwan's farthest outpost in the military standoff with China -- were carpeted with landmines during the peak hostilities between the two sides in the 1950s.
More than 70,000 mines were believed to have been left in more than 150 minefields on the island.
In the 1950s and 1960s, many civilians were killed or maimed when they accidentally stepped on the explosive devices.

The move allowed the island to open up to tourism, prompting the need to clear the landmines from areas no longer under military control.

DOC.HEADLINE: Market forces will set Taiwan dollar's value: vice president

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew said Wednesday that the local currency's value, which has lost ground against the U.S. dollar in recent days, will be decided by market forces.

Although Taiwan's central bank has been closely monitoring the New Taiwan dollar's exchange rate against the U.S. greenback, Siew said it is natural that the local currency has lost ground against the U.S. currency, as the South Korean won and the Chinese yuan have also depreciated against the greenback in recent weeks.
In Taiwan's open foreign exchange market, Siew said, as foreign traders see other currencies depreciating, they are likely to sell the local currency as well, driving down its value.

Siew made the remarks while answering questions from reporters concerning the continued depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar at the Taipei World Trade Center, where an annual fair organized by the Taiwan Optical Importers Association was being held.

Driven by the sharp depreciation of the Korean won, the local unit slipped by NT$0.34 to a nearly six-year low of NT$34.62 against the U.S. dollar Tuesday from the previous level of NT$33 early this year.

Chang Pen-tsao, chairman of the ROC General Chamber of Commerce, predicted that the New Taiwan dollar might fall below the 35 mark against the greenback as the Korean won has lost more than 30 percent of its value against the U.S. currency over the past six months.
Although a weakening local currency should help boost exports, Chang said it also might affect the prices of goods in the domestic market.

Taiwan's economy is likely to register negative growth in the first half of this year, but some investors are hopeful it will return to positive growth later in the year, boosted by an increase in electronic product exports during the high- tech peak season.

Lai Cheng-i, chairman of the private Council for Industrial and Commercial Development, said later Wednesday, however, that it would not be advantageous if the local currency fell below the psychologically important 35 barrier.
Although a cheap Taiwan dollar might bolster exports, it could also deal a serious blow to importers and domestic consumption, Lai suggested.
A sharp depreciation might also deter some people's plans to wire their money back to Taiwan, negating the government's long-term efforts to lure Taiwanese capital back home from abroad, he warned.

For instance, he said, a depreciating won has largely slashed South Koreans' spending power, as seen through the number of South Koreans staying at his hotel, the upscale Lalu overlooking Sun Moon Lake in central Nantou County.
He said the hotel now receives only about 15 guests from that country per month, a sharp drop-off from the 200 it averaged per month in the past.

DOC.HEADLINE: Examination Yuan rules out pay cut for civil servants

TEXT.P: Examination Yuan President John Kuan ruled out Wednesday the possibility of the government reducing public servant salaries in the current economic climate, even as he renewed a proposal to reform the civil service by weeding out poorly performing employees.

Kuan made the remarks during an interview with the Central News Agency in response to a question on whether Taiwan planned to follow in the footsteps of Singapore, which will cut the salaries of its senior civil servants and ministers by up to 19 percent this year to reflect a decline in the country's gross domestic product (GDP).

Kuan said Singapore's situation is different from Taiwan's, in that senior civil servants there are offered very high salaries and a percentage of their annual salary is linked to GDP growth, while Taiwan's civil servants are not particularly highly paid and their salaries are fixed.
The current recession should not affect the salaries of civil servants in Taiwan because government expenditure for personnel is lower than 1 percent of the GDP, Kuan said.
Most importantly, the government's fiscal status remains sound, with the country maintaining very high foreign exchange reserves and remaining free from foreign debt, Kuan added.
According to Kuan, ensuring a stable livelihood for government employees allows them to perform their duties without worry, which is fundamental to social stability.
However, while they have this type of job security, government employees must ensure that their performance meets expectations, he said.
"You should be prepared to be weeded out if you do not do your job to the best of your ability," he cautioned civil servants.

Reaffirming his resolve to reform and modernize the civil service system, Kuan said that within one year the Examination Yuan will come up with a draft amendment to the law governing the civil service performance evaluation system and submit it to the Legislative Yuan for review by next February.

On the four-level scale -- from "A" to "D" -- used to rate the performance of government employees, more than 99 percent of them are now getting an "A" or a "B," he said. "But their reputation among the public is obviously not as good."

Over the past decade, only around 0.02 percent of government employees have been given an annual "C" rating, and fewer than five persons have gotten a "D," which indicates that the evaluation system is not serving its true purpose, Kuan said.

He suggested that specific criteria be set out to encourage civil servants to keep upgrading their performance to earn a favorable rating, and to help them realize that the civil service is not an "iron rice bowl."

Pointing to the example of Japan, which uses a five-level scale to rate the performance of its civil servants, Kuan said around 5 percent of government employees in Japan get a "D" or "E" rating each year, which usually results in retraining, dismissal or transfer to the private sector.

Meanwhile, Kuan said a resolution will be hammered out in the first half of this year to address a situation in which a preferential 18-percent interest rate on deposits by retired civil servants allow them to earn more than they did when they were employed.

While promoting reform, the government will ensure that retirement benefits to entry-level and mid-level personnel are sufficient to support basic living standards, and that the benefits to senior personnel do not grossly exceed what is required to maintain basic living standards, according to Kuan.
The Examination Yuan is the government branch responsible for civil service recruitment and management.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei to host international ballroom dancing contest

TEXT.P: Competitors from 20 countries will participate in the 2009 Taiwan International Dancesport Open Championship (TIDOC), which will be held at the Taipei Arena on Feb. 28, the head of the Taiwan Dancesport Development Association (TDDA) announced Wednesday.

Speaking at a press conference in Taipei, TDDA President Wang Hsueh-fu said that with the assistance and support of the Taipei city government and other government agencies, the 2009 TIDOC has attracted the participation of professionals from around the world.
"The annual TIDOC is the biggest event for Taiwan's dancesport community," said Wang.

More than 300 couples from 20 countries, including the U.S., Italy, Russia, Australia, Europe, New Zealand, Japan, Korea, China, Singapore, Thailand, the Philippines and Malaysia, have signed up for this year's TIDOC, Wang added.

As dancesport has been thriving in Taiwan over the past decade, ballroom dance enthusiasts no longer have to go to England's Black Pool to experience the exciting environment of international competitions, said Wang.

"We have gone out of our way to provide the best environment possible for the participants, despite the global economic downturn," said Wang, adding that the organizing committee will provide free accommodation, meals and transportation for all foreign participants.

In order to attract more professional participants, the organizing committee is also covering the round trip airfares of competitors who have won major international dancesport championships in the past, Wang said.
The committee has invited the number one couple in sportsdance in the U.S., Riccardo Cocchi and Yulia Zagoruychenko, to perform at this year's TIDOC, he added.
Meanwhile, Wang said that in order to give more Taiwanese a chance to learn about and experience the beauty of ballroom dancing, the organizing committee is offering 3,000 free tickets.
"The Taipei Arena will issue 1,200 free tickets starting from Feb. 21, while the TDDA will hand out 1,800 free tickets to charity organizations around the country," said Wang.
According to the organizers, the winners in the professional and amateur categories of this year's TIDOC will receive prizes of NT$30,000 (US$865) and NT$8,000, respectively.
Ticket prices for the event range from NT$600 to NT$8,000 and can be obtained through the TDDA, the organizers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: More elderly people in Taiwan suffering spinal compression fractures

TEXT.P: The incidence of spinal fractures caused by pressure on fragile bones has been on the rise among people in Taiwan aged 65 and over, increasing by 60,000 patients per year, a doctor at National Cheng Kung University Hospital in southern Taiwan said Wednesday.

Citing health statistics, Hung Yu-chang, a neurological surgeon, said that half a million people in the over-64 age group in Taiwan suffer from osteoporosis -- a disease characterized by reduced bone density and increased risk of fracture.

Hung added that in Taiwan, 30 percent of women over 64 years of age are affected by osteoporosis, and that one in every four people in that age group have suffered an osteoporotic compression fracture of the spine.

According to Hung, NCK University Hospital has been treating about 19 such cases per year, with the patients ranging from 42 to 108 years of age. The treatment method used by the hospital is called vertebroplasty -- a procedure that stabilizes the spinal compression fracture by injecting bone cement into the damaged vertebra.
The method was developed by interventional neuroradiologists in France in 1987, but the earliest procedures were performed through open back surgery.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA vows to spur exports amid economic slump

TEXT.P: Alarmed by gloomy economic records registered in the previous quarter, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Wednesday it will take effective strategies to help prod up sagging exports, the prime mover of Taiwan's economic growth.

The ministry issued the statement after the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported earlier in the day that the country's gross domestic product (GDP) posted a marginal 0.12 growth for 2008, the lowest growth rate since 2001.
The latest DGBAS report also showed that the country's GDP contracted 8.36 percent in the last quarter of 2008, marking the largest quarterly decline in history.

Alarmed by the spate of lackluster economic records, the DGBAS adjusted downward its forecast of the country's GDP growth for 2009 to negative 2.97 percent and the Central Bank of the Republic of China also decided to further lower its key interest rates by 0.25 percentage points from Thursday.
For its part, the MOEA said in the press statement that it has launched a "New Zheng He" project aimed at expanding exports of Taiwan-made products, particularly sales to emerging markets.

Moreover, the statement said the ministry's Industrial Development Bureau has worked out a package of guidelines for structural adjustments of the manufacturing sector in order to sharpen its competitive edges in the global market.
Meanwhile, MOEA officials said the recent currency depreciation is expected to help enhance Taiwan's export competitiveness.
Noting that the manufacturing sector accounts for about 30 percent of the annual GDP growth, the officials said currency depreciation will definitely contribute to the country's exports.

Even though currency depreciation will increase import costs of major raw materials, commodity prices are not expected to rise substantially given the sluggish demand amid the current global economic recession, the officials predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's 2009 economic forecast bleak

TEXT.P: The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) cut its economic forecast for Taiwan Wednesday, predicting that the country's gross domestic product (GDP) for 2009 will shrink by 2.97 percent, in what it said will be the country's worst economic performance in history.
According to the DGBAS, the economy will fall for three straight quarters, shrinking 6.51 percent in Q1, 6.85 percent in Q2, and 2.67 percent in Q3, before showing growth of 4.5 percent in Q4.
If the DGBAS predictions are correct, it means the GDP would drop for five quarters in a row, from Q3 in 2008 to Q3 in 2009.
The latest DGBAS tallies show that the GDP shrank 8.36 percent in Q4 2008 in its biggest quarterly decline in history.
The agency revised its outlook for the economy at a press conference hosted by DGBAS Director-General Shih Su-mei and Tsai Hung-kun, chief of the agency's third department.
Previously, the DGBAS had forecast that the economy would grow by 2.12 percent this year.

However, at the press conference, Shih said that if the government had not intervened with measures like the shopping voucher and expanded public works programs, the outlook would have been even more grim, as the GDP would have fallen 5.74 percent this year.
The government's economic stimulus efforts are estimated to help cut the slide by 2.77 percentage points, she said.
Shih also forecast that exports will shrink by 20 percent and imports by 26.2 percent in 2009 due to an overall recession that has resulted in growing unemployment and a decline in consumption.

According to the latest DGBAS forecast, the consumer price index (CPI) will fall by 0.82 percent this year, while the gross national product (GNP) will reach NT$12.4975 trillion (US$359.928 billion) , and the per capita GNP will stand at US$15,957.
Taiwan's GDP grew by 0.12 percent in 2008, its worst performance since 2001 when the economy contracted by 2.17 percent due to the Internet bubble, DGBAS said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese claims he's stranded in Shenyang, appeals for help

TEXT.P: A 32-year-old Taiwanese man who says he is stranded in Shenyang in China's northeastern Liaoning Province is seeking help to return to Taiwan, claiming that he lost all his money and travel documents during a tour of China.
Yeh Shu-cheng told the Central News Agency Wednesday by phone from a local help center in Shenyang that he has been stranded in the Chinese city since Feb. 13 and wants to return to Taiwan.
Yeh said he was waiting for an ID document from a police station in Taiwan's Sinjhuang City to verify his citizenship.

According to Yeh, he embarked on a tour of the mainland last year after traveling from Taiwan to China on May 28. However, he lost all of his money, travel documents, luggage and cell phone on Jan. 1 this year while traveling on a train from Guanzhou in Guandong Province to Wenzhou in Zhejiang Province, he claimed.

Yeh said he sought assistance from local Chinese officials in charge of Taiwan affairs when he was in Zhejiang Province's Hangzhou and in Jiangsu Province's Nangjing, but that nothing could be done because he could not produce any documents to verify his status.
Yeh said he arrived in Shenyang via several other cities with assistance provided by help centers, each of which bought him train tickets to the next destination.

"Thanks to some kindhearted people in Shenyang and to a local evening newspaper that ran a story about my adventure, I was able to contact the Chungping police station in Sinjhuang City," he said. "The Sinjhuang police in Taipei County have promised to fax my personal information to Shenyang."
He said that while many people thought he was lying, he did not have the slightest motive to do so.
"Why would I lie to make myself miserable?" he asked.
Yeh said he was confident that he would make it back to Taiwan, but said he would need help because he is now penniless.
"I have no money or travel documents. I am itching and hurting all over, and my head is swollen like a pig's. I need help to return to Taiwan," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: University opens marine life research center in Tainan

TEXT.P: National Cheng Kung University in Tainan established a Marine Life, Whale and Dolphin Research Center on its campus in Annan District Wednesday.
Huang Hwung-hweng, vice president of NCK University, and Tainan Deputy Mayor Hung Cheng-chung jointly presided over the inauguration of the center.

Speaking at the ceremony, Huang said that the center, located close to the sea, will focus on research on marine life in the waters around southern Taiwan -- unlike Academia Sinica, National Taiwan University and National Taiwan Ocean University, whose research programs are centered on marine life in waters around northern Taiwan.

Wang Chien-ping -- a marine biologist, professor at the university and director of the center -- said the center will not only serve as a museum to display the bones of marine mammals and other specimens, it will also conduct research on marine life and conservation.
Noting that whales and dolphins often become stranded on the coasts of Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung, Wang said the center will also play a role in the rescue of these creatures.
Statistics compiled by Wang's research team show that about 25 percent of the whales and dolphins beached on Taiwan's coastlines were found in these areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Central bank governor warns of deflation risks in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Taiwan could face a deflation crisis in the wake of a government forecast that the consumer price index will move down by 0.82 percent this year, the governor of the Central Bank of the Republic of China warned Wednesday.
In response to media questions, Perng Fai-nan said the bank will remain alert to the possible crisis, and that he hopes the deflation will not last long if it does occur.
Perng said that demand has been dropping amid the global downturn, and that since crude oil prices have fallen, the pressure for consumer prices to rise has eased.
As a result, major industrial economies, including the United States, have predicted a drop in their consumer prices, he said.
Perng said there are risks of deflation in the U.S. and Taiwan, but not in the Euro zone, Indonesia or the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Palace Museum to cooperate with Shanghai Museum
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Feb. 18 (CNA) 02/18/09 23:44:26 (By Chiao Hsing-hua and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's National Palace Museum (NPM) will engage in substantive cooperation with the Shanghai Museum without touching on the sensitive designation and legal issues.
NPM Director Chou Kung-shin made the announcement in Shanghai Wednesday at a news conference held after her meeting with senior Shanghai Museum officials.

Chou, who arrived in Shanghai Tuesday on the second leg of her historic visit to China, told reporters that her current visit is based on the principle of parity and described the engagements as museum-to-museum exchanges.
As the Taipei-based museum bears the word "national" in its name, Chou said all the exchanges with the Shanghai Museum will avoid the designation issue.
The exchanges will also not touch on the legal issues concerning the possibility of Chinese authorities seizing the NPM artworks should they be loaned to China for exhibition, Chou added.

The NPM in suburban Taipei is home to the cream of the 1,000-year Chinese art collection, while the rest of the collection is held by several Chinese museums, particularly the Palace Museum in Beijing.

On other agreements reached in her talks with Shanghai Museum staff, Chou said the two sides agreed to establish a cooperative mechanism, with NPM Deputy Director Feng Ming-chu and Shanghai Museum deputy chief, Chen Kelun, holding regular teleconferences or making exchange visits to discuss feasible cooperative programs and steps to execute them.
The two museums will also cooperate in art conservation, publications and promotions.
Chou and other NPM officials are scheduled to conclude their landmark visit and return to Taipei Thursday.

During the delegation's visit to Beijing on the first leg of its China visit, Chou held talks with the city's Palace Museum curator Zheng Xinmiao in the first formal engagement between the staff of the two museums since Taiwan and China split in a civil war 60 years ago.
As a result of the talks, the Palace Museum in Beijing has agreed to lend its Taiwan counterpart 29 Qing dynasty artifacts for a three-month exhibition that will begin in October this year.
Beijing's loan of its collection to Taipei will make possible the first display of the imperial artifacts under one roof since they were split six decades ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Steel likely to post a loss in the first quarter

TEXT.P: China Steel Corp., Taiwan's largest steel maker, confirmed Wednesday that it is likely to post an operating loss in the first quarter of the year, mainly because of retroactive discounts to customers.

Chung Lo-min, executive vice president of China Steel, said that as a result of retroactive discounts totaling NT$4 billion (US$115.2 million) in the first quarter, China Steel will likely register a decline in revenues for the January to March period.
If Chung's forecast is accurate, it will be the second quarterly loss in a row for the steel maker, which is 23 percent owned by the government.

China Steel suffered its first quarterly loss in its nearly 40-year history in the fourth quarter of 2008, reporting a loss of NT$18.62 billion, which reduced its income for that year to NT$30.2 billion, down 50 percent from 2007.

In late November it decided to lower the prices of its steel products by an average of 22.56 percent, or an average of NT$7,058 per metric ton, for the first quarter of 2009 to help relieve the plight of mid- and downstream steel factories in Taiwan suffering from the global economic downturn.

On Tuesday, China Steel announced a further average price reduction of 14.03 percent, or NT$3,353 per metric ton, for the domestic market in April and May, with the prices for June to be determined separately in the future.

The new prices will be retroactive to the first three months of the year and are expected to cost the company NT$4 billion in first quarter revenue, sending revenues lower for the second consecutive quarter, Chung said.
The quoted prices for April and May are as follows:
--Steel plates: NT$4,166 per metric ton;
--Steel rod and wire products: NT$3,500 per ton;
--Hot-rolled steel coils: NT$3,000 per ton;
--Cold-rolled steel coils: NT$2,691 per ton;
--Electro-galvanized steel coils: NT$4,000 per ton;
--Electrical steel coils: NT$4,500;
--Hot-dipped galvanized steel coils: NT$2,869 per ton.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government's economic focus remains boosting domestic demand: CEPD

TEXT.P: The government will not only help exports but will also continue its efforts to expand domestic demand to help revive the slumping economy, the nation's top economic planner said Wednesday.
"Rising unemployment is also a major government concern, " said Chen Tien-jy, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), at a gathering of entrepreneurs.
The jobless rate hit 5.03 percent in December and is generally expected to rise even further after the announcement of January's jobless rate later this month, Chen said.

On public calls for the government to issue a new round of shopping vouchers to help stimulate consumption, Chen said the council will wait until September to assess the results of the first round of the program.
He noted that there is still a Dragon Boat Festival, a traditional festival which falls on June 27, that could spark a wave of spending between now and September when the vouchers must be used.
The government distributed around NT$85 billion in vouchers to spur consumption on the island and boost Taiwan's ailing retail sector. Each citizen was given NT$3,600 in vouchers.
Chen said that if exports decline by 20 percent and imports also decline, it will affect gross domestic product by around 2 percentage points.
But Chen indicated that the major factor behind the local economy's contraction in the fourth quarter was the 30 percent decline in private investment.
Chen would not comment on the recent sharp depreciation of new Taiwan dollar, which has helped exporters but hurt importers.
The new Taiwan dollar closed at NT$34.650 to the U.S. dollar Wednesday. (By Lilian Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: Demining work on Kinmen to resume March 2

TEXT.P: A project to clear landmines in the Mashan area of the Taiwan-controlled island of Kinmen off China's Fujian province is scheduled to begin March 2 and last for four months, the Kinmen Defense Command reported Wednesday.

The Mashan demining operations will be carried out by the Singaporean Explomo Technical Services Pte Ltd. over an area of 140,000 square meters in three stages over a four-month period, the defense command said.

Explomo, which won the demining contract in an open bid last year, will clear landmines in six minefields in Kinmen covering 214,900 square meters during the whole year, while the demining team of the Army Engineers Corps will clear 21 minefields over a total area of about 389,900 square meters, the command said.

Speaking at a news conference held at a borough office in Chinsha Township, an Explomo project manager Huang Jou-li said that the first stage of the Mashan demining operations will be highly dangerous because it involves mainly manual jobs in shallow minefields mostly in the beachside casuarina woods.
Traffic controls will be put in place around the Mashan area daily, during the periods 5:30 a.m. to 9:30 a.m. and 3:30 p.m. to 5:30 p.m., in the first month of operations, Huang said.

Huang also gave the assurance that Explomo operators will mark the graves in the area and will not disturb them. Any human remains found in the demining process will be collected and stored for interment in a shrine that will be built in Kinmen later, he said.

Last December, the Kinmen Defense Command gave an order for demining operations over a 20-hectare area in Kuningtou village to be suspended, pending consultations with the island's residents who had complained that the demining work had destroyed nearly 1,000 graves of their ancestors.
Kuningtou was the site of a 1949 battle in which Republic of China forces defeated two invading regiments of China's People's Liberation Army.
The shores of Kinmen -- Taiwan's farthest outpost in the military standoff with China -- were carpeted with landmines during the peak hostilities between the two sides in the 1950s.
More than 70,000 mines were believed to have been left in more than 150 minefields on the island.
In the 1950s and 1960s, many civilians were killed or maimed when they accidentally stepped on the explosive devices.
As cross-strait tensions eased, the government lifted the wartime regulations in 1992 and ended Kinmen's status as a combat zone.
The move allowed the island to open up to tourism, prompting the need to clear the landmines from areas no longer under military control.

"The Taipei Arena will issue 1,200 free tickets starting from Feb. 21, while the TDDA will hand out 1,800 free tickets to charity organizations around the country," said Wang.
According to the organizers, the winners in the professional and amateur categories of this year's TIDOC will receive prizes of NT$30,000 (US$865) and NT$8,000, respectively.
Ticket prices for the event range from NT$600 to NT$8,000 and can be obtained through the TDDA, the organizers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: More elderly people in Taiwan suffering spinal compression fractures

TEXT.P: The incidence of spinal fractures caused by pressure on fragile bones has been on the rise among people in Taiwan aged 65 and over, increasing by 60,000 patients per year, a doctor at National Cheng Kung University Hospital in southern Taiwan said Wednesday.

Citing health statistics, Hung Yu-chang, a neurological surgeon, said that half a million people in the over-64 age group in Taiwan suffer from osteoporosis -- a disease characterized by reduced bone density and increased risk of fracture.

Hung added that in Taiwan, 30 percent of women over 64 years of age are affected by osteoporosis, and that one in every four people in that age group have suffered an osteoporotic compression fracture of the spine.

According to Hung, NCK University Hospital has been treating about 19 such cases per year, with the patients ranging from 42 to 108 years of age. The treatment method used by the hospital is called vertebroplasty -- a procedure that stabilizes the spinal compression fracture by injecting bone cement into the damaged vertebra.
The method was developed by interventional neuroradiologists in France in 1987, but the earliest procedures were performed through open back surgery.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA vows to spur exports amid economic slump

TEXT.P: Alarmed by gloomy economic records registered in the previous quarter, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Wednesday it will take effective strategies to help prod up sagging exports, the prime mover of Taiwan's economic growth.

The ministry issued the statement after the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported earlier in the day that the country's gross domestic product (GDP) posted a marginal 0.12 growth for 2008, the lowest growth rate since 2001.
The latest DGBAS report also showed that the country's GDP contracted 8.36 percent in the last quarter of 2008, marking the largest quarterly decline in history.

Alarmed by the spate of lackluster economic records, the DGBAS adjusted downward its forecast of the country's GDP growth for 2009 to negative 2.97 percent and the Central Bank of the Republic of China also decided to further lower its key interest rates by 0.25 percentage points from Thursday.
For its part, the MOEA said in the press statement that it has launched a "New Zheng He" project aimed at expanding exports of Taiwan-made products, particularly sales to emerging markets.

Moreover, the statement said the ministry's Industrial Development Bureau has worked out a package of guidelines for structural adjustments of the manufacturing sector in order to sharpen its competitive edges in the global market.
Meanwhile, MOEA officials said the recent currency depreciation is expected to help enhance Taiwan's export competitiveness.
Noting that the manufacturing sector accounts for about 30 percent of the annual GDP growth, the officials said currency depreciation will definitely contribute to the country's exports.

Even though currency depreciation will increase import costs of major raw materials, commodity prices are not expected to rise substantially given the sluggish demand amid the current global economic recession, the officials predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's 2009 economic forecast bleak

TEXT.P: The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) cut its economic forecast for Taiwan Wednesday, predicting that the country's gross domestic product (GDP) for 2009 will shrink by 2.97 percent, in what it said will be the country's worst economic performance in history.
According to the DGBAS, the economy will fall for three straight quarters, shrinking 6.51 percent in Q1, 6.85 percent in Q2, and 2.67 percent in Q3, before showing growth of 4.5 percent in Q4.
If the DGBAS predictions are correct, it means the GDP would drop for five quarters in a row, from Q3 in 2008 to Q3 in 2009.
The latest DGBAS tallies show that the GDP shrank 8.36 percent in Q4 2008 in its biggest quarterly decline in history.
The agency revised its outlook for the economy at a press conference hosted by DGBAS Director-General Shih Su-mei and Tsai Hung-kun, chief of the agency's third department.
Previously, the DGBAS had forecast that the economy would grow by 2.12 percent this year.

However, at the press conference, Shih said that if the government had not intervened with measures like the shopping voucher and expanded public works programs, the outlook would have been even more grim, as the GDP would have fallen 5.74 percent this year.
The government's economic stimulus efforts are estimated to help cut the slide by 2.77 percentage points, she said.
Shih also forecast that exports will shrink by 20 percent and imports by 26.2 percent in 2009 due to an overall recession that has resulted in growing unemployment and a decline in consumption.

According to the latest DGBAS forecast, the consumer price index (CPI) will fall by 0.82 percent this year, while the gross national product (GNP) will reach NT$12.4975 trillion (US$359.928 billion) , and the per capita GNP will stand at US$15,957.
Taiwan's GDP grew by 0.12 percent in 2008, its worst performance since 2001 when the economy contracted by 2.17 percent due to the Internet bubble, DGBAS said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese claims he's stranded in Shenyang, appeals for help

TEXT.P: A 32-year-old Taiwanese man who says he is stranded in Shenyang in China's northeastern Liaoning Province is seeking help to return to Taiwan, claiming that he lost all his money and travel documents during a tour of China.
Yeh Shu-cheng told the Central News Agency Wednesday by phone from a local help center in Shenyang that he has been stranded in the Chinese city since Feb. 13 and wants to return to Taiwan.
Yeh said he was waiting for an ID document from a police station in Taiwan's Sinjhuang City to verify his citizenship.

According to Yeh, he embarked on a tour of the mainland last year after traveling from Taiwan to China on May 28. However, he lost all of his money, travel documents, luggage and cell phone on Jan. 1 this year while traveling on a train from Guanzhou in Guandong Province to Wenzhou in Zhejiang Province, he claimed.

Yeh said he sought assistance from local Chinese officials in charge of Taiwan affairs when he was in Zhejiang Province's Hangzhou and in Jiangsu Province's Nangjing, but that nothing could be done because he could not produce any documents to verify his status.
Yeh said he arrived in Shenyang via several other cities with assistance provided by help centers, each of which bought him train tickets to the next destination.

"Thanks to some kindhearted people in Shenyang and to a local evening newspaper that ran a story about my adventure, I was able to contact the Chungping police station in Sinjhuang City," he said. "The Sinjhuang police in Taipei County have promised to fax my personal information to Shenyang."
He said that while many people thought he was lying, he did not have the slightest motive to do so.
"Why would I lie to make myself miserable?" he asked.
Yeh said he was confident that he would make it back to Taiwan, but said he would need help because he is now penniless.
"I have no money or travel documents. I am itching and hurting all over, and my head is swollen like a pig's. I need help to return to Taiwan," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: University opens marine life research center in Tainan

TEXT.P: National Cheng Kung University in Tainan established a Marine Life, Whale and Dolphin Research Center on its campus in Annan District Wednesday.
Huang Hwung-hweng, vice president of NCK University, and Tainan Deputy Mayor Hung Cheng-chung jointly presided over the inauguration of the center.

Speaking at the ceremony, Huang said that the center, located close to the sea, will focus on research on marine life in the waters around southern Taiwan -- unlike Academia Sinica, National Taiwan University and National Taiwan Ocean University, whose research programs are centered on marine life in waters around northern Taiwan.

Wang Chien-ping -- a marine biologist, professor at the university and director of the center -- said the center will not only serve as a museum to display the bones of marine mammals and other specimens, it will also conduct research on marine life and conservation.
Noting that whales and dolphins often become stranded on the coasts of Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung, Wang said the center will also play a role in the rescue of these creatures.
Statistics compiled by Wang's research team show that about 25 percent of the whales and dolphins beached on Taiwan's coastlines were found in these areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Central bank governor warns of deflation risks in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Taiwan could face a deflation crisis in the wake of a government forecast that the consumer price index will move down by 0.82 percent this year, the governor of the Central Bank of the Republic of China warned Wednesday.
In response to media questions, Perng Fai-nan said the bank will remain alert to the possible crisis, and that he hopes the deflation will not last long if it does occur.
Perng said that demand has been dropping amid the global downturn, and that since crude oil prices have fallen, the pressure for consumer prices to rise has eased.
As a result, major industrial economies, including the United States, have predicted a drop in their consumer prices, he said.
Perng said there are risks of deflation in the U.S. and Taiwan, but not in the Euro zone, Indonesia or the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Palace Museum to cooperate with Shanghai Museum
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Feb. 18 (CNA) 02/18/09 23:44:26 (By Chiao Hsing-hua and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's National Palace Museum (NPM) will engage in substantive cooperation with the Shanghai Museum without touching on the sensitive designation and legal issues.
NPM Director Chou Kung-shin made the announcement in Shanghai Wednesday at a news conference held after her meeting with senior Shanghai Museum officials.

Chou, who arrived in Shanghai Tuesday on the second leg of her historic visit to China, told reporters that her current visit is based on the principle of parity and described the engagements as museum-to-museum exchanges.
As the Taipei-based museum bears the word "national" in its name, Chou said all the exchanges with the Shanghai Museum will avoid the designation issue.
The exchanges will also not touch on the legal issues concerning the possibility of Chinese authorities seizing the NPM artworks should they be loaned to China for exhibition, Chou added.

The NPM in suburban Taipei is home to the cream of the 1,000-year Chinese art collection, while the rest of the collection is held by several Chinese museums, particularly the Palace Museum in Beijing.

On other agreements reached in her talks with Shanghai Museum staff, Chou said the two sides agreed to establish a cooperative mechanism, with NPM Deputy Director Feng Ming-chu and Shanghai Museum deputy chief, Chen Kelun, holding regular teleconferences or making exchange visits to discuss feasible cooperative programs and steps to execute them.
The two museums will also cooperate in art conservation, publications and promotions.
Chou and other NPM officials are scheduled to conclude their landmark visit and return to Taipei Thursday.

During the delegation's visit to Beijing on the first leg of its China visit, Chou held talks with the city's Palace Museum curator Zheng Xinmiao in the first formal engagement between the staff of the two museums since Taiwan and China split in a civil war 60 years ago.
As a result of the talks, the Palace Museum in Beijing has agreed to lend its Taiwan counterpart 29 Qing dynasty artifacts for a three-month exhibition that will begin in October this year.
Beijing's loan of its collection to Taipei will make possible the first display of the imperial artifacts under one roof since they were split six decades ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foot-and-mouth disease cases reported in central Taiwan

TEXT.P: Taiwan will not be eligible to apply for listing as a foot-and-mouth- disease(FMD) -free country until the latter half of 2011 at the earliest after sporadic FMD cases were reported in two counties in central Taiwan earlier this month, an official said Wednesday.

Huang Kuo-ching, deputy director of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine (BAPHIQ) under the Council of Agriculture (COA), told an evening news conference that 15 pigs in a small ranch in Yunlin County were found Feb.4 to have developed blisters in their mouths and feet, suspected of falling victim to FMD infection.
"All of the 68 hogs in the farm have been culled," Huang said.

On Feb.9, 23 pigs in a large-scale farm in neighboring Changhua County were also detected to have similar symptoms, Huang said, adding that all of the 609 pigs kept under the same roof have been culled and the remaining 5,503 hogs raised in the farm have received anti-FMD shots to prevent spread of the highly contagious viral disease that mainly affects cloven-hoofed animals, including pigs, cattle and sheep.

Quoting laboratory testing reports released Feb.17, Huang said the viruses detected in the two hog farms were same as the O-type virus that originated in pigs smuggled from China in 1997 and caused an outbreak in Taiwan in March that year.
"The viruses found in the Yunlin and Changhua ranches were not new strains and unlikely to infect humans, " Huang said, adding that locally produced pork remains safe to eat.

Moreover, he went on, hog farms within a 3-km radius of the two farms, 44 in Yunlin and 31 in Changhua, have all been put under close monitoring, Huang said, adding that his bureau will pull out all the stops to contain any possible outbreak.

According to Huang, all of the infected pigs had not received anti-FMD injections for some time in line with the country's plan to apply with the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) for an FMD-free status.

"We were originally scheduled to come up with the application next year, but the plan has to be postponed to the latter half of 2011 at the earliest because of the latest cases in Yunlin and Changhua," Huang said.
After the first FMD case broke out in Taiwan on March 20, 1997, Huang said Taiwan has been trying to stamp out the disease as quickly as possible.
Since then, he said, all pig farms and slaughter houses around Taiwan have continuously conducted disinfections to maintain a clean environment and prevent the spread of viruses.

At the same time, the percentage of pigs at nationwide hog farms receiving anti- FMD vaccine injections has dropped from 50 percent last November to the current level of less than 10 percent on average at each farm, moving toward a zero injection rate so as to meet the OIE's requirements, Huang said.
According to the OIE's regulations, a country is entitled to apply for an FMD- free status if no fresh suspicious FMD cases are reported within one year after suspension of anti-FMD vaccination.
The COA originally planned to file such an application in May next year, but now the application has to be delayed for at least one-and-a-half years, Huang said.

Taiwan used to raise as many as 12 million pigs per year in the peak years, with 7 million exported to Japan annually, according to COA statistics. Taiwan now raises only about 6.4 million pigs ayear, mainly for local consumption.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 19 (CNA) 02/19/09 10:33:01 (EMBARGOED FOR RELEASE AT 16:00 GMT SUNDAY, FEB. 18)
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 19, or the 25th day of the first month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1473: Nicolaus Copernicus, the Polish astronomer who advanced the theory that the Earth rotates daily on its axis and, with the other planets in the solar system, revolves around the Sun, is born.
1800: Napoleon Bonaparte proclaims himself First Consul of the newly established French dictatorship.
1861: Tsar Alexander II signs a proclamation setting free 20 million serfs, almost a third of Russia's population.
1878: Thomas Edison, the U.S. inventor who once described genius as "1 percent inspiration and 99 percent perspiration," is granted a patent for his phonograph.
1909: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th U.S. president, who won the 1906 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese War and was an avid big-game hunter, calls for a world conference on conservation.
1915: A French-British fleet begins shelling Turkish fortifications along the strategic Dardenelles waterway in a bid to defeat Turkey and reopen the critical Black Sea supply route to Russia.
1927: The Chinese Nationalists extract a reduction of concessions from Britain at Hankow and Kiukiang.
1932: The United States refuses to recognize the Japanese puppet state of "Manchukuo" (State of Manchuria).
1934: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National Military Council of the Republic of China, launches the "New Life Movement" in Nanchang, Kiangsi Province.
1942: Japanese forces invade Bali in Indonesia and make their first raid on the Australian mainland when they bomb the Northern Territories port of Darwin.
1945: U.S. forces launch an invasion of the island of Iwo Jima, killing most of the 22,000 occupying Japanese troops and eventually taking the Pacific island on March 26 at the cost of 6,821 American lives.
1951: Andre Gide, the French writer who won the 1947 Nobel Prize for literature and was noted for his diaries and novels such as "The Immoralist" and "Lafcadio's Adventures," dies at the age of 82.
1953: The ROC and the Kingdom of Spain sign the Sino-Spanish Friendship Treaty in Madrid.
1955: The Southeast Asian Treaty Organization (SEATO) is established, with eight countries participating.
1958: The ROC Navy sinks three Chinese communist warships and damages three others in a battle off the Min River estuary.
1959: Britain, Greece and Turkey guarantee the independence of the island of Cyprus.
1963: U.S. President John F. Kennedy announces that the Soviet Union has agreed to pull out several thousand of its troops from Cuba by March 15.
1964: The Sungshan International Airport terminal in Taipei is inaugurated.
1972: Japan establishes diplomatic relations with the Mongolian People's Republic.
1973: Guatemalan Vice Foreign Minister Ing Afredo Obiols Gomez leaves for home after a weeklong tour of Taiwan.
1974: The presiding bishop of the American Episcopal Church, the Most Rev. John Hines, arrives for the Thanksgiving and Holy Communion Service on the 20th founding anniversary of the Taiwan Episcopal Church.
1976: Four Beijing opera stars leave Taipei for Hong Kong to participate in the Hong Kong Festival of Arts.
1977: Representatives of the disabled celebrate their first "Torch-Light Day" at the Taipei New Park.
1985: A Spanish Airlines Boeing passenger plane crashes in a mountainous area, killing 142 people aboard.
1990: The Liberal Democratic Party under Toshiki Kaifu wins the general election in Japan.
1991: Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian Federation, urges Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to resign, accusing him of sacrificing reform for "absolute personal power."
1997: Mainland China's paramount leader Deng Xiaoping, who ruled from 1978 until his retirement from his last official post in 1990, dies in Beijing at the age of 93.
2003: Adm. Ni Yue-si, a strategy adviser to the president, dies in Taipei at the age of 90.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who educates himself for three years without improvement is seldom to be found." ENDITEM 2007.02.19.TODAY IN HISTORY
