The government's economic stimulus efforts are estimated to help cut the slide by 2.77 percentage points, she said.
Shih also forecast that exports will shrink by 20 percent and imports by 26.2 percent in 2009 due to an overall recession that has resulted in growing unemployment and a decline in consumption.

According to the latest DGBAS forecast, the consumer price index (CPI) will fall by 0.82 percent this year, while the gross national product (GNP) will reach NT$12.4975 trillion (US$359.928 billion) , and the per capita GNP will stand at US$15,957.
Taiwan's GDP grew by 0.12 percent in 2008, its worst performance since 2001 when the economy contracted by 2.17 percent due to the Internet bubble, DGBAS said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Locally developed device offers hope for aortic dissection patients

TEXT.P: A 58-year-old man surnamed Chen was rushed to a hospital in Taiwan recently complaining of severe chest pains and shortness of breath.
A chest X-ray and CT scan showed that his aorta, the main artery that connects the heart to the rest of the body, had split open and then ruptured, resulting in massive internal bleeding.
Surgeons cut open his chest and tried to suture an artificial vascular graft onto the damaged aorta, but Chen continued to lose blood during the long procedure and died on the operating table.

Chen's death was not a statistical aberration. Some 28.5 percent of patients with the condition -- known as aortic dissection -- who make it to surgery die, but Chen's life may have been saved had his surgeons had access to a device developed by a local surgical team that cuts operating times and limits the loss of blood.

The team's head, Dr. Jeng Wei, director of the Heart Center at the Cheng Hsin Rehabilitation Center in Taipei, said he has used the NT$34,000 (US$1,000) device, called the vascular ring connector (VRC), with positive results on a total of 20 patients, including 10 since it was approved by the Department of Health (DOH) in August 2008.
Wei was given the go ahead by the DOH on a case-by-case to use the device on the other 10 patients before getting formal approval.

In 2006, the VRC became the first implanted cardiovascular device developed by Taiwanese researchers to be approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) , and Wei and his team then submitted the device for approval in Taiwan before using it successfully on patients.
The aorta, the biggest artery in the body with a thickness of between 2 mm and 3 mm, contains three layers in its wall that allows seven tons of blood to pass through it every day, Wei explained.

Aortic dissection is a condition in which a tear occurs in the aorta's inner lining, often caused by a sudden surge in blood pressure. Blood then flows between the wall's layers and forces them apart.
If the dissection ruptures all three layers of the aorta, massive and rapid blood loss occurs -- an emergency situation that requires immediate surgery.
Statistics show that aortic dissections resulting in rupture have an 80 percent mortality rate, with 50 percent of patients dying before they even reach a hospital.

For those who make it to a medical facility, or those with chronic dissection, in which the aorta could rupture at any time, the VRC lowers the operating risks compared to the conventional treatment in which the damaged section of the aorta is surgically replaced with an artificial graft, often made of dacron, said Wei.
"The surgical risks of the suturing method are very high due to the fragility of the dissected aorta," he noted.

During surgery, the aorta and the graft are sutured together, but friction from the sutures on the fragile inner layer of the aorta often causes secondary tears that can lead to uncontrollable bleeding and eventual death.
"That is the nightmare for every surgeon treating aortic dissection patients," he said.
The patients are at further risk because they are forced to undergo a potentially 8-12 hour operation during which blood circulation may be interrupted several times for up to 30 minutes at a time.
Wei and his team began to develop the VRC about a decade ago, based on a sutureless graft introduced in the United States in the 1980s.

Wei's metallic ring, made of titanium and shaped a bit like a section of water pipe, differs from the U.S. design in that it has two furrows that make it easier to secure the tube to the vascular graft and the aorta.

Wei's technique involves first inserting the ring inside the graft and suturing the two together. The graft and ring are then placed inside the aorta and joined together surgically (a process called anastomosis) with nylon tapes tied tightly outside the aorta.
"The VRC allows surgeons to do a quick sutureless anastomosis in less than two minutes, compared with the conventional suture technique that generally takes more than 30 minutes," he said.

"Also, the risk of bleeding during the entire surgical procedure is much less (less than 500 c.c. of blood is lost on average) than with conventional suture techniques, " he added, although he acknowledged that inserting any foreign body into a patient still entails a degree of risk.

Dr. Chu Tong-wei, director of Cardiosurgery Department at Lotung Poh-Ai Hospital in Yilan County, northeastern Taiwan, who used to be a member of Wei's team, said he would recommend the VRC to any aortic dissection patients.
"The VRC significantly reduces surgery time and the complications induced by the heart-lung machine, such as brain ischemia (insufficient oxygen) and kidney failure," he said.

Wei's trailblazing device has yet to be widely accepted by Taiwan's conservative medical community, but Chu expects fellow cardiovascular surgeons to begin using it when the short-, mid- and long-term results of its use on patients have been published in prestigious medical journals.

Dr. Kuan-ming Chiu, director of the Cardiovascular Center at the Far Eastern Memorial Hospital, is one of those who would like to see the longer term prognosis of patients with the device before giving it his full support.
"If the ring is proved to be as trustworthy as the artificial heart valve ring, which has been in use for decades, then any lingering doubts will be put to rest," Chiu said.
Exposing any patient to a foreign body carries risks, Chiu went on, adding that it is not yet clear if the VRC, when exposed to blood, will trigger tissue reaction or biocompatibility issues.
The VRC might also lead to blood clots, possibly caused by wear to the ring's titanium surface, Chiu said.

But he stressed that if compatibility and wear questions are addressed, then the VRC will prove to be of great help to surgeons at smaller hospitals and give their patients a better chance of survival.

Wei, who has already obtained patents for the VRC in Taiwan, China and Japan, said he "would welcome the use of the VRC by local and foreign medical institutions, " hoping that it could benefit more patients like Tu Hsing-hwa, a 56-year-old freelance graphic designer who had the device inserted last December.
Tu experienced terrible back pain Oct. 29, 2008, which he described as like "being stabbed from behind,' and the pain quickly spread to his chest.
Diagnosed at a city hospital with aortic dissection, he was later told by a bigger hospital that the survival rate from surgery was only 20 percent.

Instead of operating, the hospital gave Tu medication to control his blood pressure and discharged him, but he knew the aorta could rupture at any time and sought out Wei, who also found he had coronary artery blockage.

Tu underwent surgery Dec. 24 and was able to get out of bed the very next day. With nearly two months having passed without incident since the operation, Tu said he felt happy about gaining a new lease on life.

"It gave me a big shock when I found out I was so close to death, " recalled Tu. "I'm grateful to Dr. Wei and his life-saving device." ENDITEM/Is ***** ***** captions 1. The vascular ring connector is seen inserted into the artificial graft. The pieces of tape to the side are used to tie the aorta and the graft and ring together. CNA Photo Feb. 19, 2009 2. The vascular ring connector developed by Dr. Jeng Wei, director of the Heart Center at the Cheng Hsin Rehabilitation Medical Center, and his team can significantly improve the survival rate of aortic dissection patients. CNA Photo Feb. 19, 2009 3. Dr. Jeng Wei, director of the Heart Center at the Cheng Hsin Rehabilitation Medical Center, holds the vascular ring connector next to a model of the heart, the ring would be connected to the aorta (in red). The yellow part is fat tissue. CNA Photo Feb. 19, 2009

DOC.HEADLINE: CECA with China no solution to Taiwan's economic woes: scholars

TEXT.P: Several scholars slammed the government Thursday over its decision to sign a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) with China, saying that the Ma Ying-jeou administration should take charge of rescuing Taiwan's sliding economy rather than putting all its hopes on China.
The scholars made the remarks at a seminar titled "The Myths and Disasters of Signing a CECA," which was hosted by Taiwan Advocates, a think tank set up by former President Lee Teng-hui.

The possibility of signing a CECA with Beijing has been widely discussed over the past few months, and has spurred criticisms from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, which fears that the issue will involve delicate political issues that will give rise to serious social conflicts in Taiwan.

Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the quasi-official Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF), said a day earlier that while the Taiwan government has decided that it will sign a CECA with China at some point in the future, the SEF and its counterpart in Beijing, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), will not ink such an accord during their upcoming third round of negotiations.
However, the scholars at Thursday's forum warned that there is more at stake than just the removal of cross-Taiwan Strait trade barriers.

The CECA would be tantamount to "de facto unification" of Taiwan and China because no matter what name the agreement is given, it is aimed at removing restrictions for the cross-strait movement of commercial products, personnel and capital, said Kenneth Lin, a National Taiwan University economics professor.

After inking a CECA with Beijing, the only thing that would be left for the ruling Kuomintang to do is to forge an accord with the Communist Party of China to end civil war of their own and realize the goal of "de jure unification" of the two sides, Lin said.
He contended that Ma should take the lead to rescue Taiwan's slumping economy instead of depending on China.

The Ma administration should integrate government agencies into its plan to expand domestic demand, instruct the Central Bank to help small- and medium- sized enterprises by granting them loans, and give assistance to industries such as renewable energy and the highly innovative sectors, he suggested.

Hong Tsai-lung, an associate research fellow at Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, shared this view, saying at the forum that there are too many myths about the value of a CECA with China, and describing the possible agreement as "a rose with thorns."

Some of the myths are that the CECA would facilitate the normalization of cross- strait economic and trade relations and that it would create a good foundation for Taiwan to ink free trade agreements (FTAs) with the United States and Japan, he said.
"The CECA will extend far beyond economic and trade normalization, " Hong said. "It will deepen Taiwan's dependence on China, and we definitely should not put all our eggs in one basket."
"Unlike individual businessmen or companies, a government cannot talk only about economic interests and avoid political issues," he said.

Hong contended that a CECA with Beijing should be considered only on condition that Beijing agrees to stop boycotting Taiwan's efforts to sign FTAs with other countries and that China does not insist on prerequisites such as recognition of its one-China principle.

DOC.HEADLINE: Keelung-Xiamen-Magong ferry service to be launched

TEXT.P: A cargo and passenger ferry, Ocean LaLa, is slated to begin service on the Keelung-Xiamen-Makong route in April, an official with the Kaohsiung Harbor Administration's Magong office said Thursday.

The Taipei-based Excalibur International Marine Corp., which owns Ocean LaLa, has filed an application with the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to operate on the route, according to Han Chi-yang, vice chief executive of the company.

If the application is approved as expected, the Ocean LaLa will begin service in April, sailing every Tuesday, Wednesday, Saturday and Sunday from Keelung Harbor in northern Taiwan, to Xiamen in China's southeastern Fujian Province, then to Magong in Taiwan's outlying island of Penghu and returning to Keelung the same day, said Chang Ya-fu, director of the Magong office of the Kaohsiung Harbor Administration.
The previously Spain-registered Ocean LaLa was built in Singapore in 2004, and plied the Spain-Morocco route before Excalibur International bought it for NT$770 million (US$22.32 million).
The 2,292-ton Ocean LaLa can accommodate 540 passengers, 54 private vehicles and six tour buses.
Excalibur International began operating a passenger and cargo ferry route between Taichung and Magong Oct. 29, 2008, but later suspended the service.

The Ocean LaLa is expected to offer visitors between Taiwan and China a new travel option, which will include a transit stop in Penghu -- about 41 kilometers off the southwest coast of Taiwan proper -- and thus give the offshore island a chance to develop as a logistic hub in East Asia, Chang said.
The owner of another cargo vessel has filed an application to ply the Chiayi- Magong-Xiamen route, which if approved, would also help to expand shipping services on Penghu Island, Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei to host cross-strait travel industry forum

TEXT.P: Travel industry representatives from both sides of the Taiwan Strait will gather in Taipei for the first time from Feb. 26-27 to discuss market development and to allow greater familiarity with the Taiwan market, a spokesman for the Travel Quality Assurance Association (TQAA) said Thursday.
The TQAA, which organized the 12th Cross-Strait Travel Industry Forum, is hoping that more than 1,000 representatives will participate in the meeting, said TQAA Secretary-General Chen I-chuan.
"As most of the restrictions on visits to Taiwan by Chinese tourists have been lifted, we hope to introduce the Taiwan travel market to our Chinese counterparts," explained Chen.

According to Chen, Shao Qiwei, chairman of China's National Tourism Administration, will attend the forum in his capacity as chairman of the Cross- Strait Tourism Exchange Association and is scheduled to meet with his Taiwanese counterpart, Janice Lai, director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.
Shao will be accompanied by delegates from 16 Chinese provinces, autonomous regions and municipalities, and more than 400 members of China's travel industry, Chen added.
Taiwan will be represented by officials from 13 city and county governments and 400 delegates from the local travel industry, he said.
The TQAA will arrange for the Chinese delegation to travel to scenic areas around Taiwan to get firsthand look at Taiwan's tourism resources before they return to China March 4, Chen added.

In the past, similar meetings of travel industry representatives from both sides of the Taiwan Strait have been held in different provinces in China so that the Taiwanese delegations could gain a better understanding of the vast Chinese market which typically attracts large numbers of Taiwan tourists each year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier urges high alert against foot-and-mouth-disease

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan has directed the Council of Agriculture (COA) to collaborate with local governments in dealing with the outbreak of two cases of foot-and-mouth-disease (FMD) in central Taiwan earlier this month, Government Information Office Minister Su Jun-pin said Thursday.
The COA confirmed Wednesday that FMD had broken out on two hog farms, one in Yunlin County and the other in Changhua County.
According to Su, the animals that fell ill had not been vaccinated against FMD.

Premier Liu has directed the COA to investigate whether the virus found on the two farms was the same as the one that swept the island in 1997, Su said. Liu also urged the relevant government agencies not to let down their guard against the disease, Su added.
The 1997 epidemic prompted Taiwan to cull 3.8 million pigs and delivered a heavy blow to Taiwan's pork exports.
The COA promised to keep a close watch on the latest developments and to take action to prevent diseased pork from reaching the market.
The new outbreak will delay by at least 18 months Taiwan's application to the World Organization of Animal Health to obtain FMD-free status, COA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices slightly higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed marginally higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, advancing 30.50 points, or 0.67 percent, to close at 4,528.87.

Posting a gain for the second consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 4,475.16 and fluctuated between 4,571.31 and 4,433.43. A total of 3.39 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$70.52 billion (US$2.03 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics stocks moving up the most at 1.4 percent, followed by cement issues at 0.7 percent, textile shares at 0.3 percent, and construction stocks at 0.2 percent.

The other four major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff shares dropping the most at 0.6 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues as well as banking and financial stocks at 0.5 percent, and plastics and chemicals issues at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 944 to 665, with 214 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net seller of shares worth NT$676 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF head resolves to streamline financial management

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) has crafted a plan to sharpen the administration's "financial management efficiency, " with the aim of boosting revenues in the national coffers, Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der said Thursday.

Speaking at a regular Executive Yuan meeting chaired by Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, Lee said that in order to realize the plan, the MOF will take the lead with initiatives to "save money, look for money and make money."
"Governments in the past spent money to govern, but efficient governments govern without spending too much, and the most efficient governments govern and make money," Lee said.
To save money, the administration must embrace the concept of "cost efficiency," he said.
To look for money, the government must streamline its managerial strategies and efficiently administer financing, he suggested.
To make money, the government must adapt and develop innovative financial and monetary policies, he added.
"We hope that we can boost government revenues based on a paradigm of 'doing the best job with the fewest resources, '" Lee reiterated.

More specifically, Lee said, government-owned assets nationwide are currently worth about NT$7.45 trillion (US$218.97 billion), with about NT$4.44 trillion coming from lands. This is an area in which government agencies can hone their new skills in financial management, he added.
He expressed hopes that public offices and state-controlled enterprises would change their passive mindset, and instead, manage the government's assets in active and innovative ways.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, increasing NT$0.025 to close at NT$34.675.
A total of US$730 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$34.651 and fluctuated between NT$34.6 and NT$34.699.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices mostly higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Thursday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for March advancing 44 points to end at 4,468, with 118,683 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for April gained 36 points to finish at 4,431, with 318 contracts traded, while June futures rose 75 points to end at 4,409, with 71 contracts traded.
September futures gained 16 points to close at 4,146, with 52 contract transactions, while December futures fell 7 points to end at 4,091, with 35 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 4,424 for March, 4,395 for April, 4,334 for June, 4,130 for September, and 4,098 for December.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index rose 30.50 points to finish at 4,528.87, on turnover of NT$70.52 billion (US$2.03 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

March TE futures gained 2.95 points to close at 182.5, with 5,953 contracts traded, while April TE futures advanced 4.3 points to finish at 181.4, with 26 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.
March TF futures fell 0.6 points to close at 488.8, with 4,707 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures increased 6.2 points to finish at 484.4, with 14 contracts traded.

June TF futures dropped 19.6 percent to close at 468.6, with one contract traded, while September TF futures fell 26.2 points to finish at 459, with three contracts changing hands. No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: Creative ideas sought to transform power plant chimney into art

TEXT.P: The state-run Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) is offering NT$5 million (US$144,508) in its search for a creative image to transform the chimney of a power plant on the outlying Matsu Islands into a piece of installation art, Matsu authorities said Thursday.
In compliance with government regulations, Taipower must allocate 1 percent of its total construction budget on the Jushan Power Plant on Matsu's Nankang Islet for installation art works.
Construction of the power plant, which carries a price tag of NT$500 million, started in 2003 and is slated to be completed soon.

Taipower has submitted to the Matsu authorities a plan to transform the plant's 40-meter tall chimney into a piece of art work, with public bidding for the art project slated for May, Matsu officials said.

One percent of the NT$500 million construction budget, or NT$5 million, has been earmarked to pay the winning bidder to creatively transform the chimney into a prominent landmark on the Nankang Islet, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Demand still healthy on part-time employment market: job bank

TEXT.P: More than 30,000 college students per day have been seeking part-time jobs since the start of the new semester, with an average 5.5 students competing for one such job opportunity, according statistics provided by a local online job bank on Thursday.

Despite the economic slowdown in Taiwan, there is still healthy demand on the part-time job market in areas such as restaurants and beverage shops, the food processing industry, shopping centers, garment accessory stores, leisure and travel businesses, beauty parlors, and in education, the job bank Minijob.com said.
For college students, there are greater opportunities for part-time work at cram schools, in restaurants and in supermarket product promotion services, the job bank said.
It recommended that college freshmen, sophomores and juniors seek high paying part-time jobs, noting that unlike college seniors they are not faced with the pressure of finding full-time jobs.
Although most part-time jobs pay around NT$100 (US$2.88) per hour, a raise is likely after a two-month probation period and the pay could go up to NT$20,000 per month plus a bonus, the job bank said.
There are also part-time jobs that pay NT$330 to NT$500 per hour for work such as English and math tutoring of elementary school students, it added.
College students should invest their time prudently in order to achieve the maximum results, as most of them who have part-time jobs also have to attend classes, the job bank advised.
Minijob.com specializes in providing information to job seekers, employers and recruitment firms.

DOC.HEADLINE: Aborigines protest dismantling of communities

TEXT.P: With tears in their eyes, some indigenous elders shaved their head during a demonstration in front of the Executive Yuan Thursday to protest against a local government's demolition plan that will leave more 100 aborigines homeless.

Scores of other residents of the same communities -- Sa'owac and Kan Chin located under the Wuling Bridge in Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan -- also joined the protest and urged the county government to halt the plan, which they described as "forced relocation."

The protesters, mainly from the Amis tribe, reiterated their right to housing, saying that all they want is a piece of land on which they can live permanently and observe their traditional way of life.
The communities under the bridge consist of about 100 people, most of whom are vegetable farmers, in 41 households.
The county government has ordered the demolition of the illegal structures, saying that they are in protected waterway area that has been earmarked for a bicycle path.
However, it promised to provide housing subsidies and employment assistance to aborigines affected by the demolition plan.
But according to one of the protest organizers, Banai Wang, no concrete details of the offer were given by the county government at a public hearing on Feb. 6 to discuss the relocation plan.

The protesters said they have been relocated three times over the past 30 years, and claimed that their plight highlights the unequal distribution of the country's social resources and the inequity of the government's land development policy.
This has left the first-generation of "urban" aborigines homeless and the second generation jobless, they said.

Deputy Minister of the Cabinet-level Council of Indigenous Peoples Wang Chin-fa, who came out of the Executive Yuan building to accept a petition from the protesters, said that the central administration would have to respect the local government's decision as it was based on the Water Act regulations.
He, however, promised to hold discussions with the county government on possible alternative solutions.
The protesters said that they will hold another demonstration in front of the Presidential Office if the dispute is not settled.

DOC.HEADLINE: World renowned tenor to perform at Miaoli music festival

TEXT.P: Placido Domingo, one of The Three Tenors, will perform at the Miaoli International Music Festival slated for March 19-21 in the north-central county of Miaoli, county officials said Thursday.

Following early successes on the operatic stage, Domingo became a central figure in a new era of tenors -- along with the late Luciano Pavarotti and Jose Carreras -- late last century. The three singers reinvented classical music in 1990 when they appeared together for the first time at the football World Cup opening as The Three Tenors, thrilling millions of people worldwide.
Domingo is expected to perform March 21 at the third concert of the Miaoli music festival, the Miaoli county government said.
Brian McKnight, a multiple music award winner, and Maksim, a popular Croatian pianist, are also scheduled to perform at the concert "to cater to all age groups," county officials said.
The Brian McKnight concert will be free, while tickets to the Maksim and Domingo concerts will be sold at charity prices, although the exact costs are yet to be decided.

Encouraged by the success of the Jose Carreras' concert in the county last year, the officials decided to invite another tenor in the same league to perform at the international music festival, the first of its kind to be held in Miaoli County.
The organizer of the Carreras concert last November gave out 40,000 free tickets, but more than 50,000 people showed up on performance night, which help to boost the county's revenues.
Carreras thrilled the packed audience in the kind of show that was rarely seen in the predominantly agricultural county.

The county government spent NT$20 million (US$597,000) to organize the Carreras concert, on the initiative of Magistrate Liu Cheng-hung who once said that it makes his heart ache to see Miaoli County, long considered a "cultural desert, " left out each time a major cultural event is held in Taiwan.
The rare concert, open to all, also lured many visitors from outside the county to spend money in Miaoli, a development that Liu had anticipated.

The free tickets to the Carreras concert were a treat to Miaoli residents, paid for from an NT$100 million (US$2.89 million) prize that Liu and his administration won from the central government in an investment inducement competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: Spirit of 228 Incident key to Taiwan's future: 228 foundation

TEXT.P: The state-funded Memorial Foundation of 228 announced Thursday that it will hold a national-level ceremony in the southern city of Kaohsiung on Feb.28 to commemorate the 62nd anniversary of the 228 Incident of 1947.

This and related events would raise public awareness of the incident and teach the younger generation about its spirit and significance, thus helping to safeguard Taiwan's longterm survival, the foundation said.

The 228 Incident, which began Feb. 28, 1947, refers to the brutal crackdown on the local population by Kuomintang (KMT) troops in March and April of that year. This led to perhaps as many as 28,000 people being killed. Many other innocent people, including many elite members of the society, were blacklisted and suffered victimization.

Speaking at a news conference, Chen Ching-huang, president of the foundation, said the theme for this year's series of 228 commemorative events would beTaiwan's Second Start -- Justice, Peace and 228.
Only by studying and learning from the incident could people safeguard Taiwan's identity and its long-term survival, he added.

Regarding a rumor that members of some victimsfamilies were planning to throw shoes at President Ma Ying-jeou when he attended the ceremony, Chen said he was trying to persuade them not to since it should be a peaceful event.
Nevertheless, Chen warned that Ma's reliance on China to save Taiwan's stagnant economy was "wrong and dangerous."
Such a policy was reminiscent of Taiwanese people's hopes of KMT rule after the ROC government gained control of the island in 1945 after 50 years of Japanese rule, Chen claimed.
Excessive China fever might put Taiwan into eternal damnation with no return,he warned.
The crisis we are facing now is double what it was before because, back then, we were only fighting the Communist Party of China (CPC) , while now we are facing both the KMT and the CPC, he argued.

Meanwhile, Kaohsiung Deputy Mayor Lee Yung-te said it was sad that today's younger generation had little idea about the 228 Incident and little interest in learning about it, which was why the Kaohsiung city government fully supported the event.
The 228 Incident is a historical tragedy, and if knowledge of it is not passed down from generation to generation, it will be detrimental for future development and a great shame,Lee said.
Chang Yen-hsien, director-general of the 228 Incident Care Association, said the national-level ceremony had a three-fold significance.

It would be Ma's first speech about the incident as president, it would provide a great chance to educate the younger generation about that particular period of history, and it was an opportunity to pass on the spiritual legacy of fighting against authority, Chang explained.

In addition to the ceremony scheduled for Feb.28 in Kaohsiung, there would also be an international film festival on human rights, 228-themed art exhibition, memorial concert and a seminar, according to the foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Songshan-Haneda flights slated for October 2010

TEXT.P: Two-way flights between Taipei Songshan Airport and Tokyo's Haneda Airport are projected to begin in October 2010, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.
Civil aviation officials from the two countries reached agreement on the proposal raised by Taiwanese officials at a recent meeting in Tokyo, the MOFA official said.

The two airports would begin exchanging flights in October next year, once construction of a fourth runway at the Tokyo airport has been completed, he said. By that time, four aviation companies based in Taiwan and Japan would offer regular flights between the two destinations, he added.
The Japanese side hoped Taipei's Songshan Airport could also expand its runways so as to accommodate airplanes capable of carrying over 200 passengers, according to the official.
Tokyo's Haneda Airport serves alomost all domestic flights and a limited number of international flights, while Taipei's Songshan airport serves domestic and cross-Taiwan Strait flights at present.

Japan Airlines (JAL) President and CEO Haruka Nishimatsu, who was visiting Taiwan, was quoted as being keen to welcome Songshan-Haneda flights as they would reduce travel time between the two cities, according to the MOFA official.

JAL currently operates eight regular daily flights between Taiwan and Japan, carrying more than 900,000 passengers between the two countries in 2008. China Airlines (CAL) , Taiwan's largest carrier, transported about 1.6 million travelers between Taiwan and Japan over the same period.
Establishment of two-way flights between Taipei Songshan Airport and Tokyo Haneda Airport was one of President Ma Ying-jeou's campaign promises before he assumed office in May last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese real estate commercials prohibited in Taiwan: MAC

TEXT.P: Chinese real estate commercials would remain prohibited in Taiwan, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun said Thursday following careful evaluation and discussions between the Cabinet-level council and the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).
According to Liu, the MOI has extensively discussed the issue with executives of local real estate and land developers associations.
Most of the representatives disagreed with the proposal of lifting the ban on Chinese real estate commercials at this time of economic hardship, Liu said.

As the government is trying to boost the nation's economy by stimulating domestic spending, Liu said, realtors would not like to give the wrong idea that they are encouraging the Taiwanese public to invest in China's real estate market.
Liu said this was the best policy at the present since Taiwan was facing a great challenge to survive the economic downturn.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hsinchu mayor urges citizens to carry canteens

TEXT.P: Hsinchu City Mayor Lin Junq-tzer launched a campaign Thursday urging the public to carry canteens instead of buying bottled water, so as to save resources.

Lin's call on students and office employees to carry their own canteens and thereby support the city's environmental protection drive was supported by a wide cross section of people attending his press conference.
Every liter of bottled water wastes resources equivalent to consumption of 17.5 liters of water, Lin argued.

The mayor said he would ask the city's education and environmental protection bureaus to take charge of promoting the campaign in the hope that each citizen would do his or her share to cherish the planet by gradually quitting the habit of drinking bottled water.
Tu Chi-shian, deputy director-general of the Hsinchu Science Park Administration, and Yip Ming-chuen, vice president of National Tsinghua University, also attended the news conference.
Hsinchu City, a high-tech stronghold in northern Taiwan, is one of the country's most prosperous cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Russian institute joins Taiwan hydrologic research

TEXT.P: Seven researchers from the prestigious Russian Academy of Sciences have joined a hydrologic research project sponsored by National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) in southern Taiwan's Tainan City, the NCKU said in a statement Thursday.

The research project covering surveying, analysis and management of undersea water in areas surrounding Taiwan would be jointly conducted by NCKU's Tainan Hydraulics Laboratory and the P.P. Shirshov Institute of Oceanology under the Russian Academy of Sciences over a span of three years, the statement said.
Researchers from the two sides completed the project's initial water sampling Feb. 12-17 in an offshore area between Donggang and Linbian townships of Taiwan's southernmost county of Pingtung.

The scientific study of the properties, distribution, effects, and management of undersea water in the Taiwan area was expected to help the country better manage its undersea water resources and contribute to the development of methodology of research on oceanographic physics, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Inking of CECA key to normalization of economic ties: MAC

TEXT.P: The government's policy of signing a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) with China is key to normalization of trade and economic ties across the Taiwan Strait, and China, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chiarman Liu Te-shun said Thursday.

Even though Taiwan's Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF) and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) would not negotiate the signing of a CECA at the next round of cross-strait talks later this year, relevant government agencies on both sides were doing their best to conclude the discussions and evaluations relating to the issue, Liu said.
"Once details concerning the issue are completed, negotiations with China will begin through the SEF and ARATS, " Liu added.
As the CECA is vital for normalization of trade and economic ties between Taiwan and China, carrying out this policy is a goal every government agency should pursue, Liu argued.

Responding to concerns raised by Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, that most Taiwanese people do not understand the content of the CECA, Liu said the MAC would do its best to inform the public and the legislature about the content and benefits of signing a CECA with China.
In addition, Liu said the MAC would keep the legislature well informed about the content and progress of the third round of cross-strait negotiations.

As the content and principles of a CECA and a Free Trade Agreement are basically the same, the signing of a CECA with China will allow the free flow of merchandise, services, and capital between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official organizations designated by their respective governments to handle cross-strait matters in the absence of official ties. The MAC supervises SEF operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: No zero interest rate in Taiwan despite rate cuts: central bank

TEXT.P: Taiwan will not witness a zero interest rate, Perng Fai-nan, governor of the Central Bank of the Republic of China, reiterated Wednesday while announcing a further cut of 0.25 percentage point on the bank's key interest rates.

The announcement came after the government revealed that Taiwan's economy contracted 8.36 percent in the fourth quarter of 2008. It also adjusted downward its economic forecast, predicting that the country's economy would shrink by 2.97 percent in 2009.
From Thursday, the benchmark discount rate would be lowered to 1.25 percent, the secured loans rate to 1.625 percent, and the unsecured loans rate to 3.5 percent, the bank said.

The interest rate cut was the seventh cut since Sept. 25, 2008. Despite the consecutive cuts totaling 2.375 percentage points, Perng said that Taiwan had no plans to reduce interest rates all the way to zero percent.

Perng said the rate-cut decision was made to help boost domestic demand, given that the economic growth rate was expected to fall as a result of a sharp drop in exports due to the worldwide economic slump.

According to the latest government forecast, the consumer price index (CPI) would fall by 0.82 percent this year, while domestic interest rates would remain in the positive territory, Perng said, adding that consequently Taiwan would not enter an era of zero interest rate.
He noted that Taiwan's one-year deposit interest rate was still higher than Singapore's 0.65 percent, Hong Kong's 0.45 percent, and Japan's 0.25 percent per annum.
With the interest rate cuts, depositors would see their interest income shrink, but borrowers would see their interest payment burden eased, Perng added.

Meanwhile, monetary analysts forecast Taiwan's central bank would further cut its benchmark discount interest rate to between 0.5 percent and 1 percent in the middle of this year in line with the looser monetary policy adopted by the bank.

Fu Ming-tsai, a financial analyst at the Taiwan branch of Standard Chartered Bank, predicted that the benchmark discount interest rate will be lowered to 1 percent in mid-2009 as the government would continue its looser monetary policy in a bid to stimulate the economy.
Nonetheless, Kevin Hsiao, head of UBS Wealth Management Research in Taiwan, forecast Taiwan would see a benchmark discount interest rate of 0.5 percent later in the year.

Fu said that Taiwan's economy was weaker than the market expected, due mainly to a steep fall in exports, a problem with exports inventory adjustment, sluggish domestic demand, and low interest by the private sector to invest.

Fu forecast that a government-initiated public infrastructure construction program package -- particularly a NT$500 billion economic stimulus project -- and domestic consumption would be key to Taiwan's economic recovery in the second half of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Palace museums from cross strait reach 9-point consensus

TEXT.P: Taiwan's National Palace Museum (NPM) and the Palace Museum in Beijing have reached a nine-point consensus on closer cooperation and exchange, NPM Director Chou Kung-shin said Thursday.

Speaking at a news conference at Taoyuan International Airport upon returning from China, Chou said that, without touching on sensitive designation and legal issues, the two museums reached a consensus on academic, archive and art- conservation exchanges, as well as on publication and exhibition cooperation.
"The two museums also agreed to strengthen museum-to-museum exchanges based on the principle of parity and to engage in in-residence visit exchanges," Chou said.
"Yet we have not signed any agreements for the cooperation and exchange programs. There were only meeting minutes," she explained.
Chou labeled her just-concluded visits to the Palace Museum in Beijing and Shanghai Museum as fruitful and rewarding despite tight schedules.

Responding to a foreign wire-service journalist's question as to whether and when valuable NPM artworks would be transported across the Taiwan Strait to be exhibited in China, Chou said she had initiated the "first stage" mission, and the "second stage" mission should be done by people upstairs.
"I would not speculate on it. There is no timetable for this matter because there are national policies involved," she continued.

Chou led an NPM delegation to visit Beijing Feb. 14-16, during which she met with Beijing Palace Museum's curator Zheng Xinmiao, marking the first formal engagement between the staff of the two museums since Taiwan and China split following the civil war 60 years ago.
Chou visited Shanghai Museum Feb. 17-18, where she also met top officials and discussed feasible cooperative programs and steps to execute them.
The NPM in suburban Taipei is home to the cream of the 1,000-year Chinese art collection, while the rest is held by several Chinese museums, particularly the Palace Museum in Beijing.
The Palace Museum in Beijing has agreed, on a case-by-case premise, to lend its Taiwan counterpart 29 Qing dynasty artifacts for a three-month exhibition that will begin in October this year.
Beijing's loan of its collection to Taipei will make possible the first display of the imperial artifacts under one roof since they were split up six decades ago.
ENDITE/mark

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of foreign laborers lower than caregivers in Kaohsiung

TEXT.P: In yet more evidence of the economic slowdown, the number of foreign laborers in the manufacturing sector in the southern port city of Kaohsiung fell below that of foreign caregivers in January for the first time, the city's Bureau of Labor Affairs said Thursday.
At around 6,380, the number of foreign laborers made up only 49 percent of the citys entire alien working population which stood at 12,900 last month, bureau statistics showed.

The bureau attributed the decline to premature rescissions of contracts by Taiwanese manufacturers starting last October due to decreasing demands from industry. Meanwhile, an increasing need for caregivers providing long-term assistance reflected its own growth.

With a high domestic unemployment rate, the bureaus chief secretary, Li Huan- hsun, said that opinions remained varied regarding whether hiring foreign workers would affect job opportunities for Taiwanese citizens.

As part of the efforts to avoid possible negative consequences, however, the labor bureau has imposed stricter measures when examining foreign worker applications so that opportunities are only given to those who will complement the particular needs of domestic industries on a dynamic basis, bureau officials said.
The number of foreign workers in Kaohsiung City has averaged around 13,700 in recent years, according to official statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese real estate commercials prohibited in Taiwan: MAC

TEXT.P: Chinese real estate commercials would remain prohibited in Taiwan, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun said Thursday following careful evaluation and discussions between the Cabinet-level council and the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).
According to Liu, the MOI has extensively discussed the issue with executives of local real estate and land developers associations.
Most of the representatives disagreed with the proposal of lifting the ban on Chinese real estate commercials at this time of economic hardship, Liu said.

As the government is trying to boost the nation's economy by stimulating domestic spending, Liu said, realtors would not like to give the wrong idea that they are encouraging the Taiwanese public to invest in China's real estate market.
Liu said this was the best policy at the present since Taiwan was facing a great challenge to survive the economic downturn.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hsinchu mayor urges citizens to carry canteens

TEXT.P: Hsinchu City Mayor Lin Junq-tzer launched a campaign Thursday urging the public to carry canteens instead of buying bottled water, so as to save resources.

Lin's call on students and office employees to carry their own canteens and thereby support the city's environmental protection drive was supported by a wide cross section of people attending his press conference.
Every liter of bottled water wastes resources equivalent to consumption of 17.5 liters of water, Lin argued.

The mayor said he would ask the city's education and environmental protection bureaus to take charge of promoting the campaign in the hope that each citizen would do his or her share to cherish the planet by gradually quitting the habit of drinking bottled water.
Tu Chi-shian, deputy director-general of the Hsinchu Science Park Administration, and Yip Ming-chuen, vice president of National Tsinghua University, also attended the news conference.
Hsinchu City, a high-tech stronghold in northern Taiwan, is one of the country's most prosperous cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 20, or the 26th day of the first month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1437: James I, King of Scotland, is assassinated by a group of nobles seeking to place a rival on the throne. He was 42.
1694: Voltaire, French philosopher, writer and moralist who waged a lifelong campaign against intolerance and injustice, is born.
1707: Aurangzeb, the sixth and perhaps last of the great Mogul emperors of India, dies at the age of 88. He seized the throne at Agra from his father, Shah Jahan, 49 years earlier, killing two of his brothers and jailing the third to secure his succession.
1811: Austria declares itself bankrupt.
1904: Alexei Kosygin, Soviet prime minister from 1964 to 1980, is born.
1915: The Panama-Pacific Exhibition, in celebration of the opening of the Panama Canal between the Atlantic and Pacific oceans, opens in San Francisco.
1916: The Battle of Verdun begins after Chief of the German General Staff Falkenhayn chooses to attack the French city of Verdun, despite his belief that France will defend it to the last man.
1919: Afghan head of state Habibullah Khan is assassinated. He was succeeded by one of his sons, Amanullah Khan.
1922: Hong Kong police fire on striking workers, killing two and severely injuring seven.
1933: The U.S. House of Representatives passes an act to abolish the law prohibiting the consumption of alcohol in the United States.
1938: British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden resigns in protest against Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's policy of appeasement of Italy's Fascist dictator Benito Mussolini and German's Nazi dictator Adolf Hitler.
1942: Portugal protests to Japan after Japanese troops invade Portuguese Timor.
1946: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China declares the Yalta Secret Agreement not binding in the case of China.
1952: A meeting on the Treaty of Peace between the Republic of China and Japan is held in Taipei.
1960: The third plenary session of the first ROC National Assembly opens in Taipei.
1962: Astronaut John Glenn circles the Earth three times in less than five hours, becoming the first U.S. citizen to orbit the planet.
1966: Chester William Nimitz, admiral of the U.S. Pacific Fleet during World War II, who halted Japanese expansion and ultimately destroyed the Japanese fleet with a strategy based largely on the use of aircraft carriers, dies at the age of 81.
1967: President Sukarno surrenders all executive power to General Suharto, keeping only the title of president of Indonesia.
1971: Major-General Idi Amin Dada heads the new government of Uganda as president after the Uganda Army overthrows Apollo Milton Obote.
1972: Radio telephone service between Taipei and Madrid is inaugurated.
1974: A six-member South Korean Parliamentary Mission led by Oh Joon Suk arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1976: International Monetary Fund experts and representatives of the ROC Ministry of Finance begin their annual meeting with ROC Vice Minister Wang Shao- yu and the IMF Asia Department's consultant Andreas Abadjis as co-chairs.
1976: Gen. Wego Chiang, president of the Armed Forces University, and 30 foreign cadets studying war techniques in the ROC visit the offshore island of Kinmen.
1979: Mount Sinira erupts in Indonesia, claiming 175 lives.
1988: Torrential flooding in Rio de Janeiro leaves 500 dead and 10,000 homeless.
1997: Washington refuses to recognize the World Trade Organization's authority in its dispute with the European Union over trade with Cuba.
2000: ROC@opposition Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian stresses that only political party rotation can maintain Taiwan's administrative neutrality and achieve independence of the government's judicial branch.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who is not in office in the government of a country, should never give advice as to its policy."
