DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
CECA will comply with statute governing cross-strait relations: MAC

TEXT.P: The government's plan to sign a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) with China complied with the country's law governing the development of cross Taiwan Strait relations, Taiwan's top China-policy planner said Friday.

Signing a CECA with China -- which aims to allow free flow of merchandise, services, and capital between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait -- conformed with stipulations of the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said in answer to journalists' questions at the Legislative Yuan.

One day earlier, MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun said that since the CECA is vital for normalization of trade and economic ties between Taiwan and China, bringing this plan to fruition was a goal every government agency should pursue.

At present, there is no timetable for the signing of such an agreement, and it is not expected to be broached at the next round of negotiations between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), scheduled for later this year.
The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official organizations designated by their respective governments to handle cross-strait matters in the absence of official ties. The MAC supervises SEF operations.

As to concerns raised by opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen that most Taiwanese people do not understand the content of the CECA, Lai said that the MAC and other governmental agencies had been assessing the impacts of signing a CECA with China, and would streng those efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to seek resumption of pork exports to Singapore

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) pledged Friday to seek to negotiate with Singapore for resumption of pork exports, which were suspended in the wake of the latest foot-and-mouth outbreak in Taiwan.

Singapore's Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority (AVA) announced Thursday its decision to suspend the import of pork and pork products from Taiwan in the wake of the report of FMD infections in two hog farms in the central Taiwanese counties of Yunlin and Changhua earlier this month.

COA Vice Minister Wang Cheng-teng confirmed that Taiwan had informed the Singaporean authorities of the FMD outbreak and that pork exporters had also taken the initiative to withhold exports to Singapore.
Wang said chances were good that exports could be resumed in the future, as Singapore does not raise hogs of its own but relies on imports.
Singapore last banned Taiwanese pork imports in 1997 following a previous FMD outbreak and only lifted the ban in 2007.
AVA data shows that Singapore imported 999 metric tons of pork and pork products from Taiwan in 2008, which accounted for less than 1 percent of Singapore's pork and pork product market.

Nevertheless, Singapore is a significant market for Taiwan's farmers with more than half of annual exports of around 1,400 metric tons of fresh or frozen pork going to the island state in recent years, COA figures show.

Before the 1997 outbreak of FMD -- a highly contagious viral disease that mainly affects cloven-hoofed animals -- Taiwan raised as many as 12 million hogs per year, with the meat from 7 million being exported to Japan, according to the COA.
Taiwan now raises about 6.4 million hogs a year, mainly for domestic consumption.

The latest FMD outbreak occurred just as Taiwan was working toward the goal of being listed as a fully FMD-free country, after having been recognized by the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) as an "FMD-free country with vaccination" thanks to its efforts to eliminate the disease over the past decade.
According to OIE regulations, a country is entitled to apply for FMD-free status if no fresh FMD cases are reported within one year after suspension of anti-FMD vaccination.
The COA originally planned to file such an application in May next year, but now the application will have to be delayed for at least 18 months.
As a result of the outbreak, the wholesale price of hogs in Taiwan dropped from NT$60.89 per kilogram Wednesday to NT$57.25 per kilogram Thursday.
In a bid to stabilize hog prices, hog farmers agreed Thursday to reduce pork production by 5 percent after discussing the issue with the COA.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT invites renowned U.S. artists to the 2009 Taiwan Int'l Festival

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan ( AIT) said Friday that it has invited three renowned American artists to participate in the 2009 Taiwan International Festival (TIF) , which will host 12 productions from around the world.
Opening on Friday and running until April 3, the first TIF has the slogan "Vision of the future" and encompasses drama, music, and dance performances.

"The AIT is pleased to co-sponsor the 2009 Taiwan International Festival, organized by the National Chiang Kai-shek Cultural Center," the AIT said in a press release, adding that it has invited respected theater director Robert Wilson, cellist Maya Beiser and composer Philip Glass to the event.
Calling Wilson as an "internationally acclaimed figure in the theater world," the AIT said that his production of "Orlando" will be performed from Feb. 21 to March 1 at the National Theater.

Wilson is "a towering figure in the world of experimental theater and an explorer in the uses of time and space on stage. Transcending theatrical convention, he draws in other performance and graphic arts, which coalesce into an integrated tapestry of images and sounds," the AIT quoted the New York Times as saying.

Noting that "Orlando" is the adaptation of an influential 1928 novel by Virginia Woolf, the Wilson's production stars actress Wei Hai-ming, one of Taiwan's most acclaimed performers of Beijing opera, as Orlando, according to the AIT.
The play will be presented in Mandarin Chinese, with Chinese and English subtitles. Detailed program information can be found on the TIF's Web site http://event.ntch.edu.tw/2009/tif/en/index.html.
The AIT serves as the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan in the absence of official diplomatic relations between the ROC and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: Garment makers want CECA with China

TEXT.P: Despite the political difficulties currently faced by the government, Taiwan's garment manufacturers hope that President Ma's administration will sign a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) with China as soon as possible, a garment makers leader said Friday.

Chairman of the Taiwan Garment Industry Association (TGIA) Laurence Tsai told reporters that local industries should take the initiative to cooperate and exchange opinions with their Chinese counterparts to help facilitate the government's efforts toward inking the CECA.
According to Tsai, leading garment manufacturers have cooperated with their Chinese counterparts since 1992.
"Taiwan's garment industry has successfully signed a memorandum of cooperation with the China Textile Industry Association last Dec. 12," said Tsai.

The memorandum concerns cooperation in the areas of technological innovation, brand development, and trade, explained Tsai, adding that other local industries should follow TGIA's model so as to pave the road for the signing of a CECA with China.

"Since the signing of a complex agreement like the CECA requires a long process of discussion, evaluation, and negotiation between the two sides, Taiwan's industries should aggressively seek closer cooperation and communication to help accelerate the process, " urged Tsai.

Furthermore, Tsai said that although discussion of the CECA is not on the agenda for the next round of negotiations between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , members of the two quasi-official organizations could still discuss the issue in an informal manner.

Meanwhile, Tsai warned that if Taiwan does not ink the CECA before Japan, China, South Korea and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) eliminate mutual tariffs next year, Taiwan's export competitiveness will be jeopardized, as the nation's exports will be subject to higher tariffs in ASEAN member nations.

According to the SEF, the principals and contents of a Free Trade Agreement (FTA) and a CECA are basically the same, and are also consistent with the principles of the Most Favored Nations Status (MFN) in the World Trade Organization (WTO), so the signing of a CECA will allow the free flow of merchandise, services, and capital between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, Paraguay ties remain close: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that bilateral ties between the Republic of China on Taiwan and its South American diplomatic ally of Paraguay remained close and cordial.

"Our close ties will not change, and the various cooperative programs that are being implemented will either be extended or enlarged, " Ma said during a meeting at the Presidential Office with visiting Paraguay Chamber of Deputies Speaker Enrique Salyn Buzarquis Caceres.

Ma said that the ROC and Paraguay have maintained very close ties in economics, agriculture, military and many other fields, adding that he visited Paraguay in person last August to attend President Fernando Lugo's inauguration.

He said decades-old close ties between the two countries were not being altered even after the transition of political power in Paraguay last year with the election of President Lugo. Lugo's win in the 2008 presidential election marked the first power transition in decades in Paraguay.

Ma also reiterated that Taiwan chose not to engage in a dogfight with China on the international diplomatic arena, hoping rather that neither side would attempt to lure away diplomatic allies but would collaborate with and respect each other.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former President Lee declines to attend national affairs meeting

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui has turned down an invitation to attend an opposition-backed national affairs conference slated for this weekend.

The conference, which is being jointly organized by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), is expected to focus on the current economic crisis facing the country.
DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen and TSU Chairman Huang Kun-huei visited Lee -- the TSU's spiritual leader -- at his Taipei residence Friday to invite him to take part in the event.

According to sources with knowledge of the meeting, the 86-year-old Lee told Tsai and Huang that he has no intention of joining the conference because of his age and that it was time to allow young people to take over the responsibility of leading the country.

On Taiwan's economy, Lee said he believes the industrial sector should look back to Taiwan's historical economic development to find a direction for its future development and help the country build an independent economy.
The DPP and the TSU have also extended an invitation to President Ma Ying-jeou for him to attend the meeting, but the Presidential Office has not yet indicated if Ma will accept the invitation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices moved down Friday, with the Taiwan stock exchange's weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 91.93 points, or 2.02 percent, to close at 4,436.94.

Suffering a drop after the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell below the 7,500 threshold overnight, the local bourse opened lower at 4,483.91 and fluctuated between 4,513.99 and 4,436.94. A total of 3.05 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$59.85 billion (US$1.72 billion).
Seven of eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks falling the most of any category, losing 2.9 percent.

Construction shares fell 2.6 percent, banking and financial stocks lost 2.3 percent, machinery and electronics stocks shed 2.1 percent, plastics and chemical shares were down 1.7 percent, paper and pulp issues fell 1.0 percent, and foodstuff stocks declined 0.5 percent.
Textile stocks remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,386 to 258, with 155 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$9.98 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Thailand ink MOU on accreditation

TEXT.P: Taiwan's leading accreditation body has inked a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with its Thai counterpart aimed at bolstering bilateral cooperation and exchanges, the government announced Friday.

The deal between the Taiwan Accreditation Foundation (TAF) and the Department of Science Service (DSS) under the Thai Ministry of Science and Technology is another indication that Taiwan's accreditation system is used as a model by developing countries, said Chen Jay-san, director-general of the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
Taiwan's certification system has also been adopted by Japan, Saudi Arabia and Malaysia in the past, Chen added.
After the signing of the MOU, Chen said the TAF and DSS will jointly certify common client bodies and begin exchanges of accreditation skills in areas of shared interest.

Taiwan established its own accreditation system, referred to as CNLA at the time, in 1990. The CNLA later became among the first signatories of the Asia Pacific Laboratory Accreditation Cooperation's mutual recognition arrangement.
It switched its name to the current TAF in 2003.

As the only national accreditation body in Taiwan, TAF recognizes and promotes organizations by assessing, based on international standards and criteria, their competence in providing specific types of certification, calibration, testing, inspection and proficiency testing program services, according to the TAF.

DOC.HEADLINE: Court clears ex-DPP chief and 15 'Red Shirt' demonstration leaders

TEXT.P: Shih Ming-teh, the former chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), was found not guilty Friday of charges that he led an unapproved parade against then-President Chen Shui-bian in Taipei in October 2006.
Also cleared by the Taipei District Court were 15 other leaders of the demonstration, known as the Red Shirt campaign because the movement's participants all donned red shirts.
Shih had previously vowed that he would not appeal the ruling if he were found guilty.

Shih, who served as the DPP's chairman from 1994 to 1996, later had a falling out with the party he once headed and in August 2006 organized a movement that pushed for Chen to step down from office over corruption allegations.
A demonstration to unseat the president, which took place in the square in front of the Presidential Office, was launched in early September and lasted for more than one month.

On Oct. 10, 2006, Shih staged a parade in Taipei without the authorities' approval that attempted to surround the Presidential Office as Chen was presiding over a celebration of the country's national day.
He, as well as 15 co-leaders, were later indicted for illegal assembly.

The veteran politician, who spent a total of 25 years in jail as a political dissident, said he would rather go to jail than appeal any guilty ruling against him to highlight the injustice of the assembly law, which he claims restricts people's right to protest.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Hong Kong should have official communication conduit: SEF
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Feb. 20 (CNA) 02/20/09 17:16:01 (By Stanley Cheung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Hong Kong should maintain an official, or at least semi-official, communication channel to ensure better exchanges between the people from the two sides, the deputy chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , Kao Koong-lian, said Friday.
Kao, who also doubles as secretary-general of the quasi-official SEF, said that presently, Taiwan and Hong Kong seem to have no channel through which they can communicate normally.

Speaking during a seminar with a group of representatives of civic groups in Hong Kong and members of Hong Kong's business sector, Kao said that although the Hong Kong Trade Development Council (HKTDC) has set up an office in Taiwan, it has been operated as a private company focused solely on business and trade affairs.
"The office's functions are quite different from what Taiwan had originally envisioned," Kao said.

"We think that existing liaison offices between Taiwan and Hong Kong should be upgraded to official or semi-official levels because if these offices are purely private, they are actually redundant, since there are plenty of private organizations in Taiwan, China, Hong Kong and Macau that are in contact with each other, " Kao said.
As business and trade between Taiwan and Hong Kong grows, trade disputes will inevitably occur, necessitating official intervention if the problems are to be solved, he added.
Kao argued, therefore, that Hong Kong's liaison office in Taiwan should not only collect trade information, but also collect information and relay opinions to governments of both sides.

He added that the Constitutional and Mainland Affairs Bureau, Hong Kong's governmental agency in charge of Taiwan affairs, has interacted with Chung Hwa Travel Service, Taiwan's official liaison office in Hong Kong, in the past, but only in a private or unofficial manner.
Meanwhile, Kao said, the government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region has not established an office in Taiwan.

"The HKTDC office in Taiwan has been authorized only to handle business and trade activities, rather than solve problems facing Hong Kong residents staying in Taiwan, such as the loss of travel documents or identification papers," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung launches 'learn mother tongue' drive

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung City Government launched a drive Friday to encourage the public to speak their mother tongues on the eve of the International Mother Language Day.

The city government's Bureau of Education, Commission of Indigenous Affairs, and Commission of Hakka Affairs held a news conference to promote the "2009 International Mother Language Day, Speak One's Mother Tongue Loudly" drive.
Hakka elementary school students as well as their peers from indigenous Amis, Paiwan and Rukai tribes, also sang songs in their own mother tongues to the delight of the spectators.

"In the past, people stressed that language is a communication tool, overlooking the cultural value of their mother language, " and some mother tongues have vanished because of this, said Kaohsiung Deputy Mayor Lee Yung-te.

To create a pluralistic environment for students to learn their mother languages, Lee noted that Mayor Chen Chu has instructed that even if there is only one student who wishes to learn a mother tongue, the school will be required to offer a class to teach it.
Lee also expressed the hope that mother languages will not only be "classroom" languages, but languages that are actually used in daily life.

DOC.HEADLINE: No FMD cases reported from outside of Yunlin, Changhua: COA

TEXT.P: The chairman of the Council of Agriculture (COA) said only two counties -- Yunlin and Changhua -- have reported outbreaks of foot-and-mouth-disease (FMD) as of Friday and that the council is closely monitoring the outbreak.
Answering reporters' questions at the Legislative Yuan, Chen Wu-hsiung said most pig farms around Taiwan are clean.
The recent FMD outbreak, he said, resulted from a few pig farmers failing to wipe out the O-type virus that was blamed for triggering the first FMD outbreak in Taiwan in 1997.

Taiwan launched a program beginning in 2007 to stop giving pigs anti-FMD vaccines in a bid to apply to the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) to be given FMD-free status. A zero-vaccine environment is one of the requirements.
Through the program, the proportion of pigs in Taiwan not receiving vaccines rose from 10 percent in 2007 to 90 percent as of August 2008, and today, most pigs do not get the injections.
"It means most pig farms are safe," Chen said.
The outbreak that occurred early this month came at pig farms that had stopped giving pigs the vaccination.

The incident will delay the country's application to the OIE for FMD-free status by at least 18 months and has led Singapore, the one country that still imports pork from Taiwan, to temporarily suspend pork purchases from the country.

Meanwhile, Nantou County, which neighbors the FMD-affected areas, is on alert, with over 100 pig farms in the county asked to reinforce sterilization procedures and exercise strict controls on the entrance and exit of vehicles and people.

The head of the county's agricultural department, Chen Chao-wang, said there are some 90,000 pigs being raised on the mostly small and medium scale farms situated primarily in Shueili, Puli and Yuchih townships.
The 1997 epidemic prompted Taiwan to cull 3.8 million pigs and delivered a heavy blow to Taiwan's pork exports.

Taiwan once raised as many as 12 million pigs per year at its peak, with 7 million exported to Japan annually, according to COA statistics. Taiwan now raises only about 6.4 million pigs a year, mainly for local consumption.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, increasing NT$0.133 to close at NT$34.808.
A total of US$680 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$34.675 and hit the day's high of NT$34.850.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market dropped Friday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for March falling 108 points to close at 4,363, with 105,134 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for April lost 111 points to finish at 4,320, with 392 contracts traded, while June futures dropped 147 points to end at 4,262, with 113 contracts traded.
September futures fell 95 points to close at 4,051, with 29 contract transactions, while December futures lost 92 points to finish at 3,999, with 75 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 4,471 for March, 4,431 for April, 4,409 for June, 4,146 for September and 4,091 for December.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 91.93 points to finish at 4,436.94, on turnover of NT$59.85 billion (US$1.72 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

March TE futures fell 4.85 points to close at 177.6, with 4,998 contracts traded, while April TE futures lost 5.15 points to finish at 176.25, with 69 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June and December.
March TF futures were down 10.6 points to close at 478.2, with 4,377 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures decreased 11.4 points to finish at 473, with 35 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City urges schools to assist poor students

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Hau Lung-bin urged schools in his city Friday to help 55 students who have dropped out of school due to their families' economic woes return to class.
"Not one student should drop out of school just because their families can't afford tuition, " Hau said at a meeting of Taipei City secondary school principals.

Promising that the Taipei city government will do everything in its power to help the needy students, Hau stressed that teachers should take the initiative to understand the financial situations of their students so that the city's Bureau of Education can provide the necessary assistance.
According to Hau, 55 students, including 47 in high school, failed to return to school or have dropped out of school in Taipei City because of their families' financial predicaments.

"Teachers should immediately notify the city's Bureau of Education when they find that a student might be forced to drop out of school due to their families' financial difficulties, " Hau said, and he pledged that the city government would support the students under any condition.

Meanwhile, Hau said the city government has launched a number of programs, including the recent distribution of food vouchers and the opening of the power education program, to assist financially challenged families or individuals who have been affected by the global economic downturn to stay afloat.
All students have the right to go to school, and the city government will do its best to give students the best educational environment possible, Hau said.
Urging teachers and principals to pay more attention to the needs of their students, Hau said that helping people in need is far more effective and honorable than praying to God or going to church.
School principals and teachers are the "front line commanders" in the education sector, and they should take the initiative to try to change the lives of the students, Hau said.
Such an action would not only be regarded as a great achievement but would also be respected by the public, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA to sponsor 10 more poor foreign children this year

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will sponsor another 10 disadvantaged foreign children through World Vision Taiwan this year as part of the ministry's foreign aid program, ministry officials said Friday.

The foreign ministry has sponsored seven children since 1998, and this year it will donate NT$84,000 (US$2,435) to World Vision Taiwan to help 10 more children from seven countries: El Salvador, Honduras, Guatemala, Haiti, the Dominican Republic, Swaziland and Malawi, the officials said.
Of the seven, only Malawi is not one of Taiwan's diplomatic allies.

In addition, the MOFA will also earmark NT$1.5 million to subsidize a program engineered by the Eden Social Welfare Foundation, in which a total of 515 wheelchairs, 150 pair of underarm crutches, and 10 white canes will be donated to charity organizations in Laos, Vietnam, the Philippines and Sri Lanka, the officials said.

Another NT$1.5 million will be used to finance a program organized by the Field Relief Agency of Taiwan to provide education and medical services in remote areas of Cambodia, and NT$1 million will be offered to the Chinese Association for Human Rights for a program aimed at promoting community development and improving care for disadvantaged children in northern Thailand, they said.

In terms of medical services, the MOFA will commission the International Cooperation and Development Fund to send 20 medical missions to 15 of Taiwan's diplomatic allies this year, according to the ministry.
Although Taiwan's foreign aid resources are limited compared with those of advanced countries, the efforts will nevertheless help enhance Taiwan's international image, MOFA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Meal-offering charity needs donations desperately

TEXT.P: A charitable organization in Nantou County that has distributed meals to needy senior citizens since a devastating earthquake hit central Taiwan in 1999 is now desperately in need of donations to keep it alive.

The Long-Yan-Lin Welfare Association, based in Jhongliao township's Longan village, has distributed over 1 million free boxed meals to the elderly since the devastating magnitude 7.3 earthquake rattled Taiwan on Sept. 21, 1999, said Chen Teh-an, president of the Taichung Sungchu Rotary Club.
Operations of the association, however, may soon be suspended because of financial difficulties, Chen said.

Chen's Rotary Club chapter donated NT$100,000 (US$2,890) to the association Friday, hoping that it will lead to a larger stream of donations from around the country, particularly from the business community, to enable the association to continue helping people in need.

Welcoming the donation, Long-Yan-Lin Welfare Association Chairman Chen Hsiu-fu said the association lacks contacts with big businessmen, and its growing financial shortfalls since the onset of the global financial crunch have made it increasingly difficult for the group to distribute meals for free.
Chen said the association is now considering launching money-making businesses to raise money for the meals, which cost more than NT$5 million a year.

In addition to distributing free meals, Chen said, the association has also initiated other charitable or social programs, such as offering financial aid to children from disadvantaged families, providing daytime nursing home services for the elderly and promoting community development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Palauan president to arrive in Taiwan for state visit

TEXT.P: Palauan President Johnson Toribiong will arrive in Taiwan Sunday for a six-day visit at Taiwan's invitation, according to a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) statement Friday.

During Toribiong's seven-year tenure as Palau's ambassador to Taiwan, he pledged Taiwan would be the first foreign destination he would visit if he were to win the presidency, a sign of the close friendship between the two island states, the foreign ministry said.
Toribiong visited Taiwan briefly in mid-November 2008, one week after winning his country's presidential election.
Since establishing diplomatic ties in 1999, Taiwan and Palau have launched many cooperation programs in the areas of agriculture, health, tourism and culture, according to the MOFA statement.
Also, Palau has staunchly supported Taiwan's various bids to gain membership or observer status in international organizations such as the United Nations and the World Health Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourism Bureau launches plans to attract Muslim tourists

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Tourism Bureau wants to position the country as a pleasant and convenient tourist destination for Muslim tourists, saying Friday that it will provide the necessary assistance to local hotels and restaurants on how to host Muslims.
Wayne Hsi-lin Liu, director of the Tourism Bureau's International Affairs Division, made the remarks at a seminar aimed at enticing Muslim tourists to Taiwan.
He was joined by some 150 representatives from hotels, restaurants, recreational farms and the local Muslim community.
Today's seminar is just the start of a series of efforts that the Tourism Bureau will make to tap into the huge Muslim tourist market,Liu said.

Taiwan may be rich in culture and history and have stunning natural beauty and a friendly people, but Liu acknowledged that the country lacks the knowledge of how to welcome Muslim visitors and does not have any Halal-certified restaurants to accommodate them.

To help Taiwan become a more viable destination for the world's more than 1 billion Muslims, the Tourism Bureau intends to educate local tourism operators about Islamic culture and assist hotels, recreation areas and restaurants in acquiring Halal certification, Liu said.

In addition to inviting international Muslim clerics and experts to carry out on-site inspections and plan special itineraries for Muslim tourists, the Chinese Moslem Association in Taiwan is also planning to launch a Halal certification system so that every Muslim visitor can rest assured that they are eating foods consistent with their beliefs in Taiwan.

Malaysia, with a population that is 60 percent Muslim, is the initial target of the bureau's campaign because Malaysians enjoy 30-day visa-free entry to Taiwan, Liu said, while India, Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand and Vietnam will also be important target markets.
In line with theTour Taiwan Years 2008-2009program, the bureau hopes to attract tour groups with 2,000 Muslim visitors this year -- 10 times the annual average, he added.
Taiwan's government launched theTour Taiwan Years 2008-2009 program Feb. 15, 2008, investing NT$1 billion (US$28.73 million) to boost foreign tourist arrivals.
The program's goal was to attract 4 million international arrivals in 2008 and 4.25 million in 2009, but only 3.84 million visitors arrived in Taiwan in 2008.
The shortfall, however, was mostly due to fewer people coming to Taiwan to do business, as tourist arrivals rose 7.7 percent in 2008 to 1.78 million people.
Taiwan is home to more than 50,000 Muslims and has six mosques in Taipei, Taoyuan, Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health authorities to list PMEA as class-3 controlled drug

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) is planning to ban the use of para-methoxy- ethylamphetamine (PMEA) as police reports indicate that local youths are abusing it in increasing amounts.

The DOH gave advance notice Friday of its intention to control the drug's circulation by designating PMEA as a class-3 controlled drug, which means it cannot be used or traded by people who are not physicians, dentists and veterinarians.

According to the Criminal Investigation Bureau, laboratory checks of 30 batches of MDMA (3,4-methylenedioxy-N-methamphetamine) -- more commonly known by its street name Ecstasy -- seized during police raids last year found that some of the pills contained PMEA, which can cause organ failure and is blamed for causing a death in Japan in 2005.
Lin Jie-liang, head toxicologist at the Linkou branch of Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, said PMEA has no known medical use and is produced in illegal laboratories overseas.
PMEA, which is related to para-methoxyamphetamine (PMA) , has similar effects to PMA and can paralyze the nervous system of abusers or kill them if large enough doses are ingested, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumer group urges bus fare increase plan to be reviewed

TEXT.P: The Consumers' Foundation urged Friday that a proposal to raise bus fares approved by the Directorate General of Highways (DGH) Feb. 13 be reviewed and that the reasons justifying an increase be clearly explained.

Bus fares will rise by 20 percent if the Ministry of Transportation and Communications gives the green light to the proposal, which Consumers' Foundation Chairman Hsieh Tien-jen charged would increase the financial burden of commuters at a time when the economy is struggling.
Bus fares are generally adjusted based on 18 factors, including passenger occupancy rates, gasoline prices, personnel costs, vehicle maintenance expenditure and vehicle depreciation, Hsieh said.
This time, however, the 20 percent increase in fares proposed by bus companies was based mainly on dwindling passenger numbers, because all other costs have only increased by an estimated 10 percent.
Low passenger volumes have kept prices on long distance west coast routes depressed, with tickets between Taipei and Taichung costing only NT$80, far less than the approved fare price of NT$318.
But a ticket on the heavily traveled Taipei to Keelung route is about NT$55, close to the approved fare price of NT$58, Hsieh noted.
He said increasing fares dramatically because of low passenger occupancy rates on the west coast routes would be unfair to those commuting on more popular runs.

Hsieh cited a survey conducted by the foundation that aside from residents of Taipei City and Taipei County, 80 percent of commuters in the rest of the country use private vehicles as a means of transportation because of the lack of public transportation, its high cost, and the amount of time wasted.
He said people who use private vehicles spend an average of NT$809 a month on transportation, while those using public transportation spend an average of NT$1,703 per month, according to the survey.
Taiwan is a democratic country, Hsieh said, and any information related to adjusting bus fares should be made transparent.

He dismissed claims by bus companies that a substantial fare rise was needed to reflect the increasing cost of natural rubber RSS3, saying that its price had soared to NT$3,100/ton in July 2008 from NT$1,800/ton in 2006, but had dropped back to NT$1,500/ton recently.

Bus companies have long enjoyed privileges and benefits by operating their routes under franchise agreements, Hsieh said, and with such advantages they should be required to fulfill their social responsibility.

Rather than seeking government subsidies or requesting fare increases to attract more passengers, bus operators should strive to improve their service to get through difficult financial times, Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Vision ambassador calls for assistance to help Ethiopia

TEXT.P: World Vision Taiwan's "Love Ambassador" Sylvia Chang, just back from her second visit to Ethiopia, said Friday she was "truly amazed" at the improvement Taiwan's help had brought to people's livelihoods there, and she urged local residents to continue to support the group's efforts.

Chang, a performing artist-turned-filmmaker, said that compared to her first visit to the African country in 1993, she felt comforted to discover that skin disease and malnutrition observed among local children at that time had declined significantly.

Also, with World Vision's technical assistance and irrigation program, some Ethiopian families have become able to sustain themselves by planting fruit trees, vegetables and other crops, she observed.
Taiwan-assisted papayas, for example, were two to three times bigger than those normally found in the country, and therefore could bring higher profits to the farmers, she said.

Although there have been considerable improvements, she urged more people to provide financial support, as problems such as the lack of clean water, drought, and increased food prices still threaten Ethiopia and could eventually hurt the entire world.
She said her recent visit made her rethink the relationship that human beings have with the earth and the definitions of "poverty" and "wealth."

The organization's National Director Hank Du, another member of the delegation that made the trip, said the visit was especially meaningful because 2009 marks the 20th year since the foundation launched its food aid program worldwide.

The NT$3.5 billion (US$1 billion) the organization has collected since 1989 has been used to help over 50 million needed people living in 85 countries, mainly on the African continent, to gain access to nutrition as well as re-establish their communities, he said.

In the face of the domestic and global economic slowdown, he requested more people to participate in the charity to assist people facing economic difficulties and spread love to every corner of society and the world "like a candle in the darkness."

DOC.HEADLINE: Clean energy not a liability but an opportunity: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew said Friday that the development of the nation's green energy industry and the promotion of environmental awarareness in the country is no longer a liability but a great opportunity that will contribute to the nation's sustainable development.

Siew made the remarks while attending the Olive Mountain Forum of Taipei's Young Women's Christian Association (YWCA) , which was held to address the topics of environmental protection and green energy.

"The achievement of sustainable development requires the integration of a nation's economic, environmental and social components at all levels, " said Siew, who argued that the government could turn the current economic recession into an opportunity by investing in the development of green energy.

According to Siew, the development of green industries is the most important issue on the government's national development agenda, followed by cultural innovation, tourism, medical care and upscale agriculture.

Taiwan should protect the environment and develop sustainable energy sources as problems such as global warming, air and water pollution, ozone layer decay and the disappearance of species are worsening at a rapid rate, he said.

To help develop green energy sources and solve these problems, the government needs to provide incentives to the public and related industries, Siew said, and he warned that people should not ignore the issue simply because oil prices have fallen dramatically since hitting historic highs last July.

"Japan is the perfect example, " Siew said. While inflation reached 3.5 percent in Taiwan and 7 percent in most Asian countries when oil prices soared to US$140 per barrel, Japan's inflation remained stable at 1.2 percent, he said.

A country with as few resources as Japan did not suffer from the spike in oil prices because it had already developed sustainable energy sources and were not so heavily dependent on overpriced oil, Siew said.
In addition, he stressed that the idea of green energy and environmental protection awareness should be promoted through education.
"We need to let the future leaders of our country understand the importance of environmental protection and the development of green energy industry," he said.
Siew stressed that the government and local industry should not only help develop the green energy sector for economic purposes.
"By switching the dependency on conventional sources of energy to clean energy, we'll have a chance to allow our future generation to inherit a 'green island' instead of a polluted one," Siew said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President not to attend weekend conference on national affairs

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will not attend a conference on national affairs to be sponsored by two opposition parties, Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said Friday.

Wang said that after the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers repeatedly boycotted Friday's legislative proceedings, "the significance of the president attending the meeting no longer exists."
He said that Ma was scheduled to visit Hsinchu Saturday, but had considered postponing the visit to Sunday and had "in fact decided to attend the weekend conference."

But the Presidential Office "regretted" the development in the Legislative Yuan Friday afternoon when DPP lawmakers converged in front of the podium to prevent Premier Liu Chao-shiuan from giving his administrative report.

The public expects the government to do everything it can to address the country's economic woes, but the DPP had hampered the government's s efforts on the issue, and the DPP "should bear full responsibility," Wang said.

He argued that a "responsible political party which is sincere in seeking a reconciliation" should not on one hand invite President Ma to attend the conference and at the same time boycott legislative proceedings to prevent the premier from fulfilling his legal responsibility and delivering his report to the public.
Asked whether the Presidential Office will send an envoy to attend the conference, Wang said that "there is no such plan."
He also stressed, however, that President Ma has not given up on the possibility of meeting with DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen to help ease the confrontation between the ruling and opposition parties.
"The door to communicate with Tsai remains open," Wang added.
In response, the DPP said Ma's declining of the invitation based on the legislative fracas "was simply an excuse to cover his cowardice in facing public voices."

Cheng Wen-tsang, director of the DPP's Department of Culture and Information, said the government has been erratic, arrogant and deaf to public voices in unveiling a spate of what he called "inefficient" strategies.
The two-day meeting, sponsored by the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union, will forge private views on the crisis, Cheng said.
Ma's administration should not forge policy behind closed doors, and Liu's Cabinet should not continue its bad economic policy, Cheng said.
Premier Liu said he would not attend the conference because of other commitments, but he would encourage other Cabinet ministers to attend and listen to the views for the Cabinet's reference.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier urges opposition party to be 'rational'

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Friday that disrupting legislative sessions would not help the country's competitiveness and urged lawmakers of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to be "rational" in fulfilling their duties.

DPP lawmakers refused to allow Liu to deliver his administrative report earlier in the day unless he apologized for the country's contracting economy, which the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics predicted Wednesday would shrink by 2.97 percent this year.
Guarded by Kuomingtang legislators who formed a circle around him, Liu eventually gave a shortened version of his report amid an uproar from DPP lawmakers.

Responding to questions from DPP Legislator Ker Chien-ming after delivering his report, Liu said he would apologize if the opposition party helps accelerate the review of the government's NT$500 billion four-year economic stimulus package focusing on increasing public works.
"I will make the apology as many times as requested as long as you (lawmakers) fulfill the people's expectations," Liu said.
Friday was the first day of the Legislative Yuan's first session of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign direct investment plunges in January

TEXT.P: Taiwan's inbound foreign direct investment (FDI) plunged in January compared to a year earlier, just the latest sign of the worsening economic climate in the region, according to statistics released Friday by the Investment Commission.

Approved FDI in January totaled US$145 million, down 73 percent from a year earlier, while the total number of approved foreign and overseas Chinese investment projects fell 61 percent to 72, the commission said in a statement.

Taiwan's investment in foreign countries also dropped sharply in January, with outbound investment falling 82.39 percent year-on-year to US$89.91 million and the number of projects filed falling to 17, from 47 a year earlier, the statement said.

Outbound investment to China also plunged, with the value of approved investments falling 56.31 percent to US$283 million and the number of approved projects dropping from 72 to 23, the statistics showed.

The dismal January figures for inbound FDI were somewhat exaggerated by the long Lunar New Year holiday break, a commission official said, but the first half of February showed signs of a rebound, with Taiwan receiving US$380 million in FDI through Feb. 17.

The FDI inflows of many Asian countries, including Japan, South Korea and Hong Kong, fell dramatically in 2008 due to the global economic downturn, according to a commission official. Taiwan was no exception, with FDI falling 46 percent in 2008 to US$8.23 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor will donate 10% of salary to help needy people

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin announced Friday that he will donate 10 percent of his monthly salary to help those in need of emergency help amid the current global economic slump.
Hau made the announcement after attending a ceremony launching the 2009 flower season on scenic Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei.

Saying he agrees with the South Korean government's strategy to have its senior officials, military officers and university heads return 10 percent of their annual salaries to national coffers from February to help disadvantaged people ride out the present economic storm, Hau said he will follow suit.
Hau acknowledged, however, that such a strategy remained utterly inadequate to cope with today's weakened economy, describing it as pouring a cup of water on a burning cart of firewood.
It would be more effective for the government to come up with a well-rounded economic stimulus package, Hau stressed.

For instance, he said, the Taipei city government has launched a series of programs, including issuing food vouchers, opening vocational training classes and other courses to help disadvantaged families cope with the economic downturn, acquire vocational skills and obtain short-term jobs.

Following the lead of Singapore, which announced it would cut the salaries of top government officials by 12 percent to 20 percent in January, the South Korean government announced a similar program Thursday.

It said that senior public servants, including officials at the deputy minister level and higher, three-star lieutenant generals and above and university presidents will return 10 percent of their monthly salaries to national coffers starting in Feburary for one year, with the funds used to help disadvantaged families hit by the current economic downturn.

For failing to deliver on his campaign promise of achieving a high economic growth rate, South Korean President Lee Myung-bak aready announced last year he will donate his entire salary to help the underprivileged during his five-year tenure.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2009 Yangmingshan Flower Festival opens

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin opened the 2009 Yangmingshan Flower Festival Friday in Yangmingshan National Park in suburban Taipei.

The annual festival will run 31 days until March 22 and give visitors the opportunity to see various flowers in full bloom, including the Taiwan cherry, the Kwanzan cherry -- a popular variety of flowering cherries originating in Japan -- and multicolored azaleas and camellias.

According to Fang Chan-jung, a section chief of the Parks and Street Lights Office under the Taipei City government's Public Works Department, the theme for this year's flower festival is "Grass Mountain Nostalgia." The Grass Mountain, or Caoshan, was the original name of Yangmingshan.
The park will present several forms of entertainment, including concerts featuring classic songs, to bring back people's memories of old times.

According to Fang, because of the good condition of the flowers and the fine weather expected in the coming weeks, the number of visitors to the flower festival is expected to surpass the 1.19 million recorded during the 2008 festival.

The Yangmingshan Flower Festival is one of five major flower shows in Taipei every year. It will be followed by the calla lilly season from March 27 to April 26 in the Zhuzi Lake valley -- also located in Yangmingshan National Park.

The event is expected to attract over 700,000 visitors to 12 hectares of calla lily fields, which produce some 3 million flowers a year, accounting for 90 percent of Taiwan's total calla lily production.
Visitors can enjoy the fun of heading to the fields and picking for themselves the flowers they wish to buy.
To accommodate people who want to go to Yangmingshan National Park to admire the flowers, two city bus companies have added seven new bus routes leading to the park during the two festivals.

DOC.HEADLINE: 53% confident of government's performance over next 12 months

TEXT.P: Fifty-three percent of the people surveyed are confident about the government's performance over the next 12 months, according to a public opinion survey released by the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission Friday.
The survey was released to coincide with the completion of President Ma Ying- jeou's first nine months in office. Ma was inaugurated on May 20, 2008.
The survey also found that approval ratings for both President Ma and Premier Liu Chao-shiuan were on the rise, while their disapproval ratings fell.

Ma had an approval rating of 43.7 percent, an increase of 0.5 percentage points compared to the previous poll conducted in November, while Premier Liu Chao- hsiuan had a 41.4 percent approval rating, 3.7 percentage points higher than the last survey.
President Ma had a disapproval rating of 43.2 percent, and Premier Liu had a disapproval rating of 41.3 percent, down 7.4 percentage points and 12.2 percentage points, respectively.

But when asked if Premier Liu will perform better than he has to date, 38.9 percent of respondents said he would, down 10 percentage points from the 48.9 percent who felt that way in the previous poll.
Overall, 41.9 percent of the public is satisfied with the Cabinet's performance, up 1.7 percentage points from the previous survey.
On the performance of Ma's administration over the next year, 53.4 percent said they are confident, down 3.6 percentage points from the previous survey.

More people were satisfied than dissatisfied with the Ma administration's performance on issues such as cross-strait and diplomatic relations, transportation development, tax reform, care for the underprivileged, the promotion of energy conservation, upgrading government integrity, environmental protection and the handling of natural disasters.
The reverse was true on the issues of investment solicitation, social order, educational reform and consumer price stability.
The latest survey was conducted Feb. 16-17 by calling 1,078 adults, with 168 refusing to answer questions. The survey had a margin of error of plus or minus 2.98 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Indigenous lawmakers call for preservation of tribal languages

TEXT.P: Aboriginal lawmakers of different political stripes unanimously urged the government Friday to take more active steps to preserve their tribal languages, which have all been listed by the United Nations as on the brink of extinction.

According to an investigative report released recently by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) , the languages of all 14 of Taiwan's officially recognized indigenous tribes are threatened with extinction.

Legislator Chen Ying of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said the education system adopted by the ruling Kuomintang during its uninterrupted hold on power from 1945 through May 2000 was the number one culprit in the disappearance of Taiwan's aboriginal languages.
Even though the government has begun efforts to protect indigenous tribal languages in recent years, Chen said it has not done enough to reverse the trend.

She suggested that the government should ease accreditation requirements for tribal language teachers so that more people speaking indigenous languages can be allowed to teach aboriginal children their mother tounges at elementary schools.
Tutoring fees for those teachers should also be raised to encourage younger indigenous people to study their own languages, she suggested.
Legislator Kung Wen-chi of the ruling Kuomintang said the government should enact an indigenous languages development law to better protect tribal languages.

Legislator Kao Chin Su-mei of the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union said many factors have contributed to the decline of tribal languages, including the ban on the use of tribal lanuguages during the 50 years of Japanese colonial rule and the ensuing KMT government's biased attitude toward them.
In her view, Kao Chin said the current government should devote more resources to encourage the study of indigenous tribal languages.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 21, or the 27th day of the first month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1673: Jean Baptiste Poquelin Moliere, the French playwright whose sophisticated comedies include "Tartuffe" and "The Misanthrope," is buried in secret in a Paris cemetery.
1795: Holland surrenders Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) to Britain.
1858: Edwin Holmes of Boston installs the first electric burglar alarm.
1866: August von Wasserman, the German bacteriologist who invented a test to detect syphilis, is born.
1911: The United States and Japan sign a treaty limiting the flow of Japanese workers into the United States.
1916: Massed German artillery begin a furious bombardment of a crucial 13-kilometer sector of the French line at Verdun in the middle of the Western Front.
1917: Modern China's founding father Dr. Sun Yat-sen completes "The Fundamental Knowledge in Democracy," a book dealing with the procedures of parliamentary rule.
1944: General Hideki Tojo, prime minister of Japan, replaces Field Marshall Hajime Sugiyama as chief of the Imperial Army general staff.
1957: Israel defies a U.N. resolution and holds on to the Gaza Strip.
1963: Moscow warns Washington that an American attack on Cuba would mean world war.
1969: King Hassan of Morocco is granted a patent by the U.S. Patents Office for his device to monitor the function of the human heart.
1970: A cargo plane belonging to Taiwan's Far East Air Transport Corp. crashes on top of Fushoushan in suburban Taipei, killing its two pilots.
1972: U.S. President Richard Nixon visits mainland China.
1973: Forty-six manufacturers attend the second European Industrial Machinery Exhibition in Taipei.
1973: Lt. Gen. Robert R. Williams, acting commander of the U.S. Army, Pacific, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: Swaziland Vice Prime Minister Z.A. Khumalo arrives in Taipei for a week- long tour.
1974: The Buenos Aires University Club rugby team, champions of South America, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: The Taiwan Shipbuilding Corporation begins construction of a fifth 100,000-ton tanker for the Chinese Petroleum Corporation.
1986: Mainland Chinese air force pilot Chen Baozhong defects to South Korea in a MiG-19 fighter.
1986: Shigechiyo Izumi, the world's oldest man, dies in Japan at the age of 120.
1989: Czech writer Vaclav Havel is imprisoned for initiating a demonstration. Havel later became president of Czechoslovakia.
1990: Hun Sen, premier of Cambodia, holds peace talks with his rival, Prince Ranaridh Sihanouk, in Bangkok.
1990: Salvadorean President Alfredo Cristiani visits the Republic of China.
1992: Mainland China welcomes foreigners back to its stock market in Shanghai for the first time since 1949.
1998: The U.S. government advises its citizens to leave Iraq, in anticipation of new airstrikes.
2000: ROC Defense Minister Tang Fei arrives in Singapore to attend a five-day Asian Aerospace Show.
2000: Liberian President Charles Ghankay Taylor arrives in Taipei for a six-day official visit.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Appearance of high spirits without integrity, of dullness without humility, of simplicity without honesty -- of such men I really do not know what to say."
