DOC.HEADLINE: President calls economic meeting to address economic decline

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou met with economic officials Saturday to seek solutions to the country's economic downturn, which is more serious than expected.

The meeting took place three days after the release of the latest economic data by the Directorate General of Budge, Accounting and Statistics, which showed that Taiwan's economy shrank by 8.36 percent in the fourth quarter of 2008 and is expected to decline by 2.97 percent in 2009.

Ma said he is very concerned about the "unusual" situation and thinks that it is necessary for the government to review its existing economic measures and figure out if there are better ways to boost the economy.

Ma noted that since his inauguration last year, his administration has introduced a series of measures, such as expanding domestic demand, reducing taxes, issuing consumption vouchers and introducing a stimulus package, in an effort to prop up the economy.
Had it not been for these measures, the economic decline would have been even worse, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opposition calls for Cabinet reshuffle over economic slump

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged President Ma Ying-jeou Saturday to replace the premier and reshuffle the Cabinet in order to rescue the country's flailing economy.
DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen insisted that Premier Liu Chao-shiuan owes the public an apology for failing to honor his promise of reversing the economic downturn.
Liu's failure is evident from the fact that the economy actually declined by 8.36 percent in the fourth quarter of 2008 and is expected to shrink by 2.97 percent in 2009, she said.
Tsai argued that a reshuffle is urgent because "the economy would be hopeless unless the Cabinet is replaced."

Tsai made the remarks while addressing the opening of a national affairs conference jointly held by the DPP and the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union, one day after DPP legislators blocked the premier's policy report to the legislature to pressure him to apologize for the country's bad economic situation.

The two parties had invited President Ma to attend the conference, which focused on economic issues, but Ma declined. Instead, the president called a meeting with economic officials the same day to discuss ways to boost the economy.

At the conference, former Vice President Annette Lu offered to accept a cut this year of NT$500,000 (US$14,705) in her annual retirement benefits, which currently amount to NT$3.5 million, so that the government could use the money to help the disadvantaged.
Lu also called on her "former colleagues" to follow her lead, saying that it is time for the Taiwan society to develop a social conscience to uphold equity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan mulling cutting or waiving visitor visa fees

TEXT.P: The government is studying whether to reduce or waive visa fees in a bid to attract more foreign visitors to Taiwan, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Saturday.
Lo Yu-chung, director-general of MOFA's Bureau of Consular Affairs, said that the matter is expected to be decided by the end of March.

He made the remarks amid reports that Thailand, which has seen a sharp decline in tourist arrivals due to its political conflicts and the world financial crisis, is planning to waive visa fees for tourists with effect from March.
"Not only Thailand, but Taiwan also is studying a slate of ideas for preferential visa treatment to attract more foreign visitors and stimulate domestic consumption," Lo said.
The proposals under consideration include reducing or waiving visa fees for visitors from certain countries, and expanding the visa-free and landing visa programs to include more countries.
Currently, most foreign visitors to Taiwan are required to apply for a tourist visa at a cost of US$50.

Lo noted that visitors from 38 countries, including Australia, the United States and Switzerland, as well as travelers from India, Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand and Vietnam who have permanent residence status in the United States or Canada currently are entitled to visa-free entry for tourism purposes.

The government is considering expanding the program to include more countries and visitors from Southeast and South Asia who hold long-term visas for the United States, Canada, the European Union and Japan, he added.

"In the future, the government will widen its preferential visa treatment program, but at the same time will guard against social problems that could stem from an influx of foreign visitors," he said, citing as examples the problems of people working illegally in Taiwan or overstaying their visas.
"The MOFA will work closely with the National Immigration Agency under the Ministry of the Interior to devise measures to avoid any possible negative impact of the plan," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Incentive program helps conserve 2.84 billion kwh of electricity

TEXT.P: An incentive program introduced by the state-owned Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) to encourage energy conservation has helped decrease household electricity consumption by 2.84 billion kilowatt-hours (kwh) over the past eight months, company officials said Saturday.

The reduction means that carbon dioxide emissions were down by 1.79 million metric tons and that the discount to consumers on electricity bills amounted to NT$14.2 billion between July 2008 to January 2009, the officials said.
The incentive program, which took effect in July 2008, allows consumers a discount of up to 20 percent if they use the same amount or less electricity compared with the previous year.

Also, during the period Oct. 1 to Feb. 11, the government subsidized the purchase of more than 148,000 energy-efficient electrical appliances by local consumers, with the subsidies totalling NT$300 million.

Meanwhile, the energy consumed by Taipower decreased by 321,100 kiloliters of crude oil equivalent in 2008, saving NT$1.7 billion in energy costs, thanks to its energy conservation efforts, the officials said.
The efforts include cutting the heat consumption of the company's generators, its use of electricity and its circuit rate loss, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma asks for industrial development plan within three months

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou directed the Executive Yuan Saturday to come up with concrete plans within three months for improving Taiwan's industrial output and boosting exports amid the global economic downturn.

Ma gave the directive at a meeting with Premier Liu Chao-shiuan and the Cabinet members in charge of economic and financial affairs, in a brainstorming session convened by the president to discuss how the country can survive the current worldwide recession.
At the meeting, Ma reiterated that seeking the normalization of economic and trade relations between Taiwan and China is at the core of his administration's cross-Taiwan Strait policy.
Taiwan should take seriously the reality of the economic and trade situation in the region and try to forge a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) with China, he said.

The president, who floated the idea of a CECA during his election campaign last year, asked the country's economic officials to solicit public opinion on issues related to the inking of such an agreement.
He also directed them to invite the opposition parties to participate in the public discussions on the issue so as to gain the broadest possible consensus.
Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chih recounted the president's instructions at a press conference held after the meeting.
Asked about opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen's call for a complete reshuffle of the Cabinet, Wang said "there is no such a plan at present."
Wang told the media that the president was cognizant of the executive branch's efforts over the past nine months to deal with the country's economic problems.

Furthermore, Ma has praised the Cabinet for its handling of the dramatic global economic changes, in particular the measures it took to help stimulate the economy and lower the unemployment rate, Wang related.

However, Ma urged the officials to speed up the implementation of his administration's economic stimulus plans, and expressed the hope that the legislature will give priority to the NT$500 billion (US$14.36 billion) budget for a four-year public construction program, Wang added.
The president is unwilling to see the government's economic rescue programs delayed, Wang said.

The officials at the meeting were also directed by the president to devise ways of prompting manufacturing industries to diversify and brand their products and to acquire new techniques and technology, according to Wang.
In addition, Ma gave instructions for more government resources to be injected into tourism, medical services, biotech and "exquisite agriculture" industries to give them added value, Wang said.

However, the president stressed that although the government plans to invest heavily in public projects, private investment should also be encouraged through less restrictive laws and preferential taxation, Wang said.

Ma believes that Taiwan must discover its competitive edges and plan projects for the its long-term economic development before the global economy begins to recover so as to take the lead in international competition in the future, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Cycling for Matsu blessing' draws heavy participation

TEXT.P: A cycling event that traced the renowned Dajia Matsu pilgrimage route across four central and south-central counties in Taiwan drew a large number of cycling fans Saturday, according to organizers.

The annual event was organized by the Cabinet-level Sports Affairs Council as part of a government publicity campaign to raise public awareness of the importance of conserving energy and cutting greenhouse gas emissions by promoting the bicycle as a green mode of transportation.

Speaking at the start of the event, SAC Minister Tai Hsia-ling said the cycling tour was also aimed at encouraging local people to exercise regularly and engage more in outdoor recreational activities for physical fitness and health.

To spur public interest, the cycling event began three years ago to follow the annual Dajia Matsu Pilgrimage Procession route that usually winds through Taichung and Changhua counties in central Taiwan and the neighboring Yuling and Chiayi counties in the south.

Dubbed "Cycling for Matsu Blessing, " the tour started from the Dajia Stadium near the centuries-old Jenlan Temple in Dajia township in Taichung County -- a religious mecca that is dedicated to the Chinese goddess of the sea, more commonly known as Matsu.

Every lunar March, the Matsu statue that is worshipped in the Jenlan Temple is carried on a pilgrimage to the Fengtien Temple in Chiayi County's Singang township, in what is known locally as the Dajia Matsu Pilgrimage Procession. It usually draw hundreds of thousands of pilgrims who worship and honor the goddess of the sea.

Led by Tai, the cyclists started the bike tour at 7 a.m. Saturday, and as of 3 p.m. some 2,284 of them had reached the final destination at the Fengtien Temple -- breaking the 2008 record of 2,152 finishers.

Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen, who turned up at the square near the Fengtien Temple to greet the participating cyclists, praised them for the stamina and perseverance they showed in completing the 130-km journey in eight hours or less -- a journey that takes the Matsu pilgrims eight days and seven nights on foot.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former Philippine president arrives in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Former president of the Philippines Fidel Ramos arrived in Taiwan Saturday for a four-day visit.

Ramos said he is visiting at the invitation of a Taiwanese businessmen's association in the Philippines and that he hopes the trip will help promote bilateral relations in the areas of economics, trade, culture and sports.

During his stay in Taiwan, Ramos said, he will meet with President Ma Ying-jeou to congratulate him on his inauguration and will also visit some old friends, such as honorary chairman of the ruling Kuomintang, Lien Chan, Vice President Vincent Siew and Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung.
Ramos will also call on Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin to discuss issues related to urban development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan charity group donates books to South African children
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Feb. 20 (CNA) 02/21/09 20:59:42 (By Chu Lu-sheng & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The United States branch of the Taiwan Buddhist Tzu Chi Foundation will ship 9,072 kilograms of supplies -- mostly books and stationery -- from Los Angeles to South Africa Sunday for youths and children there.

According to the Taiwan-based foundation, the donations include 30,000 used books, 30,000 sets of new stationery, over 1,000 stuffed toys and thousands of greeting cards written by students at Tzu Chi Chinese schools around the United States.
The shipment is scheduled to arrive in South Africa at the end of March for distribution in high schools, as well as in elementary schools and day-care centers founded by Tzi Chi.
It is expected that more than 2,500 local youth and children will benefit from the donations, said Lin Yi-wen, a liaison staff member of the Tzu Chi branch.
Lin noted that Tzu Chi has founded seven elementary schools and three day-care centers in South Africa to educate children from destitute families.
One of the world's largest charity organizations, the Tzu Chi Foundation has offices in more than 20 countries and has been providing services worldwide to people in need for over 30 years.
It is a non-profit organization founded by Buddhist Master Cheng Yen in 1966 in Hualien, eastern Taiwan, and is dedicated to social and community services, medical care, education and humanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Chinese medicine standards seen as model for U.K.

TEXT.P: Taiwan can serve as a role model for the United Kingdom and can play an important role in lifting the profile of traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) in the Western world, as it has a high standard of TCM education and advanced production technology, a group of experts from the U.K. said Saturday.

In an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency, Tony Booker, president of the U.K. Register of Chinese Herbal Medicine, said that he was amazed by the high level of quality control in producing TCM products and the expertise of TCM practitioners in Taiwan.
He was part of a 13-member group of TCM practitioners, leading research scientists and experts from the U.K. and Ireland, who were in Taiwan to observe and study its practice of Chinese medicine.

During their stay Feb. 16-21, the group visited the Department of Health's Committee on Chinese Medicine and Pharmacy, China Medical University, Taipei Chinese Medical Association, Chang Gung Memorial Hospital and Sun Ten Pharmaceutical Company.

"I'm particularly impressed with the care and attention Taiwanese take in the production and the quality of Chinese medicine, putting an enormous amount of investment into quality assurance, which is very good," Booker said.
"That's something we really need to try and copy in the U.K.," he added.

Brooker, a member of the advisory board for the British government 's Herbal Medicine Regulation Working Group (HMRWG), said Taiwan's regulations on Chinese medicine can also serve as reference for the U.K. and that he will report to Westminster about this.

In recent years, Western nations have been gradually becoming more open-minded about traditional medicines and TCM has been receiving great attention worldwide. However, despite the growing popularity, there are no statutory regulations on herbal medicine, acupuncture and TCM practitioners in the U.K., and herbal medicine was identified as posing risk to public health due to poor practice.

For this reason, the committees of HMRWG and the Acupuncture Regulation Working Group (ARWG) were set up in 2002 by the British Department of Health to coordinate some 15,000 U.K. herbal practitioners of all traditions and to consider how regulation of acupuncture and herbal medicine could best be achieved.
Brooker said that in addition to Taiwan's high standard of education in scientific Chinese medicine, its regulations in the discipline can also serve as a good model for the U.K.
There are some areas, such as student exchanges and training programs, in which Taiwan and the U.K. can work together for mutual benefit, he added.

Noting that he has been working on some exchange programs with local universities and hospitals, Cheng Ming-zhao, a member of the HMRWG and the head of Middlesex University's Chinese Medicine Program, told the CNA that Taiwan's standard of education and quality control in TCM are the advantages that can be used to raise the profile of TCM internationally.

"Taiwan can play an important role in the globalization of Chinese medicine, Cheng said, adding that instead of having just bilateral collaboration between Taiwan and the U.K., Taiwan, China and Europe can all work together to achieve this goal.

Michael Heinrich, head of the Centre for Pharmacognosy and Phytotherapy at London School of Pharmacy, said that Taiwan has great potential in terms of Chinese medicine research and it will benefit from stronger international collaboration.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourism bureau to launch hotel star rating system

TEXT.P: A five-star rating system will be formally introduced in Taiwan for hotel classification as part of the government's all-out efforts to promote and upgrade the local tourist industry, tourism officials said Saturday.

The Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications has already publicized rating guidelines and regulations and will begin to accept applications for assessment in April, according to the officials.

If all goes well, the officials said, the first batch of local hotels to join the assessment program will be eligible to put up their formally certified star rating signs in the middle of the year at the earliest.

Taiwan has so far not formally introduced a star rating system and many self- proclaimed four-star or five-star hotels are rated based on discretion rather than official authorization, the officials said.

The rating system will not be mandatory, as hotels are free to decide whether they want to join the classification program, but only those with "tourist hotel" or "hotel" licenses are eligible to apply for rating, the officials said.
The assessment will cover two stages, with architecture and facilities evaluated in the first stage and service quality in the second stage.
Only those that pass the first stage of assessment with a score of at least 301 out of 1,000 points may decide whether to proceed to the second stage of rating.
Hotels that get 301 points to 600 points will be assigned a three-star rating.
Those that enter the second stage of appraisal but fail to get a total score of 600 points will still be classified as three-star hotels.
Hotels that want to obtain a four-star or higher rating must take part in both hardware facility and software service quality assessment and obtain a total score of more than 600 points.
The star rating will remain valid for only three years, after which hotels must again be evaluated.
To spur the hotels' interest, the Tourism Bureau will foot the bill for the first-ever rating assessment, but in the future, participating hotels will be required to pay the costs.

Tourism Bureau officials said they expect at least 500 of Taiwan's more than 4,000 hotels to take part in the assessment in the first year and that more than half of the local hotels will be certified under the star rating system within three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Late priest's wish to establish home for disabled adults comes true

TEXT.P: The wish of the late Father Francis Burkhardt to set up a home for the seriously disabled adults was realized Saturday with the inauguration of the Sacred Heart- Francis Home in Chiayi County, southern Taiwan.
The NT$380 million facility in Putze City, Chiayi, is designed to house 200 seriously disabled people.

Former Premier Chang Chun-hsiuung, former Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya, Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen, Chiayi County Council Speaker Yu Cheng- ta, Legislator Chang Hwa-kuan, Cardinal Paul Shan Kuo-hsi and Chung An-chu, Catholic bishop of the Chiayi Parish, attended the ribbon-cutting ceremony.
"The priest dedicated all his life to service in Taiwan and he was truly a most beautiful and valuable Taiwanese," Chang Chun-hsiung said.
"The inauguration of the home will bring the society a ray of sunshine, hope and happiness," Chang said.

Chiayi Magistrate Chen said the construction of the home cost about NT$380 million, and that there was a shortfall of NT$50 million. He urged the public to donate generously to help make up the shortage in funds to fully complete the facility.
Burkhardt was born in Basel City, Switzerland. He originally served in China, spreading the Christian gospel there. He moved to Taiwan in 1959.
The Catholic priest gave half a century of dedicated service to the Taiwan people before he passed away in 2003 at the age of 101.
He founded the Scared Heart Home in 1990 in Tungshih township, Chiayi County to accommodate disabled individuals aged 5-50.

However, concerned that the disabled would have no place to go when they grew older, the priest said at his 100th birthday celebrations that he wished to build a home for the seriously disabled adults.
After he died at age 101, some who were inspired by his compassion and love continued his mission, and a ground breaking for the Sacred Heart-Francis Home was held in 2004.
Former Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and former Interior Minister Chang Po-ya offered assistance to buy the land for the project from the state-owned Taiwan Sugar Company, which once owned the land.
Around 100 occupants of the Sacred Heart Home are now relocating to the Sacred Heart-Francis Home, as the original facility is being renovated and the work is expected to take more than a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president's hunger strike not to affect court's schedule

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian's hunger strike is not expected to affect a three-day pretrial session scheduled to start Feb.24 to settle technical details regarding trial of corruption and money laundering charges against him, prosecutors said Saturday.

They made the remarks after Lee Ta-chu, deputy director of the Taipei Detention Center, confirmed earlier in the day that Chen, who has been kept behind bar since Dec.30, 2008, has not eaten anything for two days.

According to Lee, Chen only drank water while declining to eat anything. He also refused to have his blood pressure and pulse measured, Lee said, adding that the detention center will pay extra attention to his situation.
Chiang Chih-ming, secretary of Chen's office, said Friday that Chen stopped eating two days ago in protest against what he called continued judicial persecution against him.

Chen, who left office in May 2008 due to term limits, has been charged with embezzling, taking bribes, money laundering, influence peddling and extortion in the case, which also implicated his family.

Chen insisted on his innocence when he appeared in the court Jan. 19 to defend himself in a pretrial hearing. At his lawyers' request, a collegial panel of judges at the Taipei District Court agreed at the time to postpone the Jan.20-21 pretrial session to Feb.24-26.
Prosecutors investigating the case said Saturday they see no reason for any further postponement of the pretrial hearings.
Even if Chen's health is not good due to his refusal to eat, prosecutors said, the court hearing can proceed with Chen's attorneys answering questions on his behalf.

Chen, who served as president between 2000 and May 2008, suffered a fresh blow Friday as the Taiwan High Court rejected his appeal to replace the presiding judge in his corruption and money laundering trial.
Chen had demanded through his lawyers the removal of judge Tsai Shou-hsun, who was ordered by the Taipei district court to take over his case last December.
Some legal experts voiced concerns over the move, particularly after Tsai reversed an earlier ruling granting Chen bail on the grounds that he could flee the island or destroy evidence.
The High Court said in a statement that it stood by the appointment.
"The district court followed relevant legal procedures in assigning the case," the high court said in a statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Feb. 22, 2009

Road, Sec.3, Taipei City. Host and/or main speakers: DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen and TSU Chairman Huang Kun-huei. Organizers: Democratic Progressive Party and Taiwan Solidarity Union. DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 22, or the 28th day of the first month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1512: Amerigo Vespucci, Italian navigator and "discoverer" of the South American coast, dies at the age of 58. America was named in his honor.
1732: George Washington, the first U.S. president, is born.
1784: The Empress of China, the first trading ship sent to China from the United States, sets sail from New York.
1788: Arthur Schopenhauer, German philosopher who saw the ideal state of man as one of contemplative freedom achieved through art, is born.
1810: Frederick Chopin, Polish-born French composer and pianist of the romantic era, is born. His music was noted chiefly for its expressiveness.
1857: Robert Baden-Powell, British hero of the siege of Mafeking in the Boer War and founder of the Boy Scouts, is born.
1819: Spain cedes the state of Florida to the United States.
1879: U.S. storekeeper Frank W. Woolworth, thinking centralized purchasing will help keep prices down and profits up, opens the new F.W. Woolworth Co. Five- and-Ten Cent Store in Lancaster, Pennsylvania.
1924: Calvin Coolidge becomes the first U.S. president to broadcast from the White House.
1932: Edward Kennedy, U.S. senator and younger brother of John F. Kennedy, is born.
1934: Nicaraguan guerrilla leader General Augusto Sandino is executed by his rival, General Anastasio Somoza, commander of the National Guard.
1940: The 14th Dalai Lama is enthroned in Lhasa, Tibet.
1946: Dr. Selman Abrahams announces he has discovered streptomycin, an antibiotic which can be used to treat tuberculosis and bacterial infections.
1948: More than 20,000 students demonstrate against the Yalta Secret Agreement and call for the Soviet Union to withdraw its forces from China.
1967: Indonesian President Sukarno announces the end of his rule and transfers political power to Gen. Suharto.
1967: U.S. forces and South Vietnamese troops launch Operation Junction City, attacking communist forces in Tayninh Province north of Saigon.
1973: Gordon T. Wallis, chairman of the Irving Trust Company of New York, arrives to open a Taipei branch.
1974: Minister of Finance K.T. Li, Minister of Economic Affairs Y.S. Sun and Sheik Mohammed Aba Al-Khail, Saudi Arabian minister of finance and national economy, issue a joint communique on financial and economic cooperation.
1979: The Caribbean island of St. Lucia announces independence from Britain.
1990: The last statue of Joseph Stalin topples in Ulan Bator, capital of Mongolia.
1991: U.S. President George Bush gives Saddam Hussein 24 hours to quit Kuwait or face an all-out ground war against allied forces.
1993: The Taiwanese film "The Wedding Banquet" wins a Golden Bear Award for Best Picture at the 43rd Berlin International Film Festival.
1996: Russia and the International Monetary Fund reach a deal on a loan of more than US$10 billion.
1996: The French government announces the abolition of conscription and the adoption of a voluntary system for military service.
2000: Chien Wen-hui successfully receives a piece of his wife's liver in an operation performed at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Kaohsiung, marking the first wife-to-husband live-donor liver transplant ever conducted in Taiwan.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian is accused of taking bribes from a Malaysian business tycoon.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In education, study always as if you have not yet reached your goal and as though apprehensive of losing it."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Use of paper cups drops steeply: environmental agency

TEXT.P: As part of an eco-friendly drive initiated by the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) , public agencies and schools have cut down on the use of paper cups by over 90 percent over the past year and a half, the EPA reported Sunday.

Since July 1 2007 until the end of 2008, the number of paper cups used by government agencies and schools was 3.71 million, a steep drop of 90.19 percent from 2006 when the number was 37.82 million, EPA statistics showed.
The drive, which was launched in July 2007, resulted in a reduction of 273 metric tons of waste, calculated on an average weight of 0.008 kilograms per paper cup, EPA officials said.
EPA officials attributed the success of the initiative to regulations limiting the use of paper cups in schools and public agencies to certain occasions and setting goals for a reduction in use.

According to EPA figures, the use of sealed cups of water and the consumption of bottled water in government agencies and public schools in 2008 were down by 80.69 percent and 78.47 percent, respectively, from the 2006 levels. This is an indication that non- disposable cups are being used instead of paper cups, the agency said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ireland mulling visa waiver treatment for Taiwanese visitors
DOC.DATELINE: London, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/22/09 16:18:37 (By Jennifer Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The government of Ireland is mulling following the United Kingdom's lead in offering visa free treatment to Taiwan passport holders, an Irish judiciary source said Saturday.

Because of the Common Travel Area between Ireland and the U.K., it is important the Irish and British visa lists cohere in all practical respects within the bounds of immigration concerns, an official with the Irish Department of Justice said.
This being the case, "Ireland must take serious account of any alterations in the U.K. visa regime," the official said.

"Full and immediate consideration will be given to the issue of Taiwan and to whether a relaxation of the current regime is desirable based on the approach now being followed by our U.K. colleagues," the official said.
It is hoped that this process will be completed before the new U.K. arrangements take effect, the official added.
The U.K. announced Feb. 9 that it will waive the visa requirements for Taiwan passport holders for visits of less than six months, with effect from March 3.

The Irish official, however, noted that the visa system in Ireland is different from that in the U.K. It operates on the basis that, depending on his or her nationality, the visitor is either visa required or they are not, irrespective of the length of their stay or its purpose.
According to the Irish government, the number of applications by Taiwanese passport holders for entry to Ireland is around 1,200 per annum.
The Republic of China government allows Ireland passport holders 30-day visa free stay in the country.

Lan Kuo-yu, a London-based Taiwanese travel agency operator, welcomed the plan by Ireland, saying that if it follows in the U.K.'s footsteps and offers visa free treatment for short-term Taiwanese visitors, this would definitely help to lure more Taiwanese tourists to Ireland.

DOC.HEADLINE: Construction to begin on Taipei section of airport MRT line

TEXT.P: Construction of three projects on a mass rapid transit (MRT) line that will connect Taipei and Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport in northern Taiwan will start Monday in Taipei County.

The Ministry of Transportation and Communications' (MOTC's) Bureau of High Speed Rail is scheduled to hold a ground-breaking ceremony for the construction of several stations and related facilities in Sanchung, Hsinchuang, and Taishan in Taipei County on the MRT line.

The projects include three elevated stations in Sanchung, Wugu, and Hsinchuang to be built by Da Cin Construction Co.; two elevated stations in Taishan to be constructed by Hwang Chang General Contractor Co.; and a 2.5 km elevated bridge and two tunnels -- one 0.7 km and the other 136 meters -- which will be constructed by Fu Tsu Construction Co., a bureau official said Sunday.

According to the bureau's plan, there will be 22 stations along the MRT line, seven underground and 15 elevated. Extended airport services will be provided at Taipei Main Station, Wugu Industrial Park Station and Taiwan High Speed Rail's Taoyuan Station to allow for airline passenger and luggage check-in at those points, according to the official.

The MRT line will be 51.03 kilometers long, with 10.92 km underground and 40.11 km elevated. The construction of the section linking Sanchung to Chungli in the Taoyuan County is scheduled to be completed in June 2013 and the entire line to be opened in October 2014, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: President pledges NT$1.5b to fund 228 foundation

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou promised Sunday that the government will provide NT$1.5 billion (US$41 million) to the state-funded 228 Memorial Foundation over the next few years so that it can continue its operations.

Ma said that in order to raise public awareness of the 228 Incident of 1947 and help the younger generation to understand its significance, the administration will donate NT$300 million to the 228 Foundation each year until the foundation has NT$1.5 billion which should be able to generate enough interest to finance its operations.
"If the interest the foundation earns from the annual allocations is not enough to fund its operations, then the Executive Yuan will be asked to appropriate more money to help it function," Ma said.
Ma made the remarks during a meeting at the Presidential Office on major national and economic issues.

On the issue of whether the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall should be renamed, Ma said the Ministry of Education has been asked to sponsor a series of civic forums on the matter and to inform the public of its decision before July this year.
Ma said that in addressing sensitive ethnic issues, the process is just as important as the conclusion.

Therefore, on matters pertaining to the 228 Incident and the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, the relevant decision makers had better adopt the "decision by consensus" approach, instead of voting on the issues, he advised.
"In a vote, there is always a winner and a loser," the president said. "This means that some people may be forced to swallow their dissatisfaction, which could later become seeds of conflict."

He said that the government should deal patiently with ethnic issues, and that the relevant officials should listen carefully to the people -- some of whom might be harboring misunderstandings, prejudices or strong feelings that could be difficult to discern.

Ma noted that although the government has tried hard over the past decades to tell the people the truth and compensate the families of the victims of the 228 Incident, some research organizations remain relentless in their efforts to uncover the facts surrounding the incident.
The president commended these organizations for their tenacity, saying that without truth, there can be no trust or peace, and that the hatred derived from distrust can be hard to dispel.

The 228 Incident, which began Feb. 28, 1947, refers to the brutal crackdown on citizens by the then Kuomintang troops in March and April of that year, which led to an estimated 28,000 deaths. Many innocent people, including many elite members of the society, were blacklisted and victimized.

DOC.HEADLINE: Investment immigration regulations to be relaxed: agency

TEXT.P: Taiwan will relax its immigration rules from the end of February to make it easier for foreign investors to obtain permanent residency in the country, as part of the government's efforts to attract investment and boost employment, the National Immigration Agency (NIA) said Sunday.

When the amended regulations take effect, the minimum requirement for foreign investors who wish to apply for permanent residency in Taiwan will be an investment of NT$15 million (US$430,900) and the provision of three local jobs for at least five years, the NIA said.
Currently, the minimum investment under this category of applications for an alien permanent residency certificate (APRC) is NT$30 million.
Foreign investors are also eligible to apply for permanent residency if they put NT$30 million into the NIA's "investment immigration fund" for five years, the agency said.

The NIA grants alien residency permits (ARC) to foreign investors in several different categories based on the amount invested. Such investors who hold ARCs for a minimum of five consecutive years and have remained in Taiwan for at least 183 days of each of those years may apply for APRCs.
At present, 330 foreign investors in Taiwan hold ARCs, while 52 hold APRCs, according to the NIA.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT chairman to promote party diplomacy on visit to Southeast Asia

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung will depart Feb. 23 for a visit to the Philippines, Malaysia and Singapore to promote party diplomacy and meet with Taiwanese expatriates in the three countries, KMT spokesman Lee Chien-jung said Sunday.

Building on the Republic of China's close economic and trade relations with the three Southeast Asian nations, Wu will meet with political figures in the three countries to discuss closer bilateral ties and regional cooperation, according to Lee.

Wu is slated to exchange views with leaders of the People's Action Party of Singapore and the Malaysian Chinese Association on further development of political parties and greater interaction among them, Lee added.

Meanwhile, Wu will brief Taiwanese expatriates in those countries on the major policies adopted by the Taiwan government since the KMT returned to power last May and will thank them on President Ma Ying-jeou's behalf for their support of the new administration, Lee added.
Wu is scheduled to return to Taiwan March 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: Enterprises sponsor Taipei educational trip for 500 poor students

TEXT.P: Eight government agencies and enterprises have joined a program to sponsor an educational trip to Taipei for 500 underprivileged students in central and southern Taiwan.
The program was initiated by Chang Chia-chun, a legislator of the ruling Kuomintang. Chang represents Yunlin County, and at 28 is the youngest lawmaker in the current legislature.

Chang told reporters Sunday that she launched the program because she knows that many students from poor families in remote areas of central and southern Taiwan have never had an opportunity to see what life is like in a metropolis like Taipei.

The educational program would allow 500 pupils from poor families to visit various establishments in Taipei, including Taipei Zoo, where a pair of giant pandas from China and other rare animals, such as koala bears and King Penguins, have become major attractions.

Three government agencies -- the Children's Bureau under the Ministry of the Interior, the Ministry of Education, and the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration -- have pledged their support for the program. Four enterprises -- Chunghwa Post Co., Taiwan Power Co., CPC Corporation Taiwan, China Steel Corp., and Taiwan Water Corp. -- have followed suit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung City to provide dentures for low, mid-income seniors

TEXT.P: The public Taichung Hospital announced Sunday that elderly people from low- and mid-income families in the city may apply for a city government subsidy to help cover the cost of dentures.

In an effort to ensure the oral health of the city's elderly, the Taichung city government launched a program Feb. 3 under which economically disadvantaged people aged 65 and over are entitled to a subsidy of up to NT$40,000 (US$1,150) to cover the cost of dentures, according to Lu Yu-hsiu, a dentist at the hospital.

While nutrition is the key to good health among the elderly, most of them do not get adequate nutrition because of eating problems associated with bad teeth, therefore, oral health is very important, Lu said.

Citing as an example a 72-year-old man, 176 cm tall, who lives alone, Lu said he once weighed 90 kg but he lost weight and was in poor physical condition because his bad teeth made it difficult for him to chew and he therefore became malnourished. The problem was that he could not afford to pay for dentures, Lu added.
However, by taking advantage of the subsidy program, the elderly man can now eat any kind of food he wants, he added.
Missing teeth and tooth decay can not only lead to poor nutrition, but can also affect social interaction and communication among the elderly, Lu noted.
He urged eligible seniors to first go to the hospital, which has a contract with the city government, and apply for an assessment and verification of their condition by Oct. 30.
Once the applicants receive the verification report, they can send it to the Taichung City Dental Association for approval and await further notification by the city government, he said.
Under the program, each person can obtain a subsidy of up to NT$40,000 to help cover the cost of a full set of dentures, or NT$20,000 for removable partial dentures.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung City, food bank aid poor in Taichung City

TEXT.P: Taichung City in central Taiwan and a mobile food bank run by the non-profit Hsingshih Foundation distributed food packages to low-income families and homeless people Sunday at a local activity center.

It was the first time that the city and the foundation were teaming up to make use of the mobile food bank service. Some 380 food packages were distributed to members of 100 underprivileged households and 120 cooked meals were handed out to homeless people.

According to Taichung City Deputy Mayor Hsiao Chia-chi, most of the people who received the food packages were from single-parent or impoverished households. Each package contained meat, canned food, rice noodles, fruit and vegetables in a quantity equivalent to one month's supply for a single person.
"The city government will make the distribution process more convenient and flexible if this is done again," Hsiao said.

He made the comment after observing that in some cases the packages were collected by children whose parents were at work and after learning that some people had come a long way from other districts to obtain the packages from the food bank, which was parked near an activity center in the city's north district.

The Shingshih Foundation set up Taiwan's first mobile food bank in Taichung City in 2002 to provide aid to the underprivileged. The food bank helps poor people and avoids waste by delivering to them packages of adequate but not excessive amounts of food.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan envoy meets with St. Lucia prime minister
DOC.DATELINE: Castries, St. Lucia, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/22/09 19:33:17 (By C. Y. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Judicial Yuan President Lai In-jaw, in his capacity a special envoy of President Ma Ying-jeou, called on St. Lucia Prime Minister Stephenson King Saturday on the occasion of the Caribbean nation's 30th anniversary of independence.

Lai delivered a letter from Ma and relayed the president's greetings to King. Lai thanked St. Lucia for its support for Taiwan's bid to join international organizations and invited King to visit Taiwan.
In response, King expressed appreciation for Taiwan's assistance to his island country in the areas of infrastructure, aqua culture, orchid cultivation and e-government.
He reiterated St. Lucia's firm support for Taiwan and asserted that his country will continue to back Taiwan's bid to participate in international organizations, including the United Nations.
Lai also met with St. Lucia Foreign Minister Rufus Bousquet and Industry and Commerce Minister Tessa Mangal over lunch.

Accompanied by Taiwan's Ambassador to St. Lucia Tom Chou and St. Lucia's Agriculture Minister Ezechiel Joseph, Lai later in the day visited a mental hospital, a telecommunications technology center and a model farm -- all cooperative ventures established by the two countries.
According to Chou, Taiwan and St. Lucia resumed diplomatic ties in April 2007, after a ten year break during which the Caribbean country maintained ties with China.

With the resumption of diplomatic links, Taiwan dispatched technical teams to St. Lucia in July 2007 to help the Caribbean country with its production of orchids, vegetables, fresh water fish and shrimp and to build its information technology sector, he said.

Two weeks ago, the two countries jointly held an orchid exhibition in Castries, at which thousands of orchid plants from Taiwan were sold out, Chou said. This prompted the St. Lucia agriculture ministry to step up its efforts to expand the input of Taiwan expertise into orchid cultivation in the Caribbean country, he added.
On Saturday, Lai also paid a call on St. Lucia Governor General Pearlette Louisy, who highly praised the close cooperation between the two countries.
Lai left Taiwan last Wednesday at the head of an official delegation that traveled to St. Lucia for its independence celebrations.
Former President Chen Shui-bian visited the country in January 2008 and King visited Taiwan in June that same year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local economist challenges foreign counterpart's forecast for Taiwan

TEXT.P: A recent forecast by an economist with British Economist Magazine on Taiwan's economic prospects for 2009 was challenged Sunday by a local economist as "too pessimistic."

Yang Chia-yen, director of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research's (TIER's) Research Division VI, said Kil Dosanjh's forecast that Taiwan's economy will post a negative growth of 9 percent this year, with no recovery in sight until 2013, is like saying that it will take five years for the U.S. economy to begin to recover.

Yang said various authoritative economic think-tanks have differing opinions on whether and when the U.S. economy will bottom out, but that a prediction of five years before the U.S. economy begins to rise would be "too pessimistic."

Yang quoted a Global Insight forecast two weeks ago as indicating that the global economy will post a negative growth of 1.2 percent this year, while the U. S. economy will post a negative growth of 2.7 percent, and Taiwan's will record a negative 2 percent growth.

He also cited an International Monetary Fund forecast one month ago that stated the global economy will grow by 0.5 percent this year, while the U.S.' will show negative 1.6 percent and Asia's Four Little Dragons' will record negative 3.9 percent.

He said Dosanjh's forecast of a negative 9 percent growth in Taiwan's economy for 2009 was too far removed from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) prediction last week of a negative 2.97 decline growth.

The DGBAS forecast should be considered by think tanks as one of the important references, Yang contended, adding that it would be "too biased" if researchers thought that all official statistical agencies are being manipulated by their governments.

Yang, nevertheless, cautioned that Taiwan will not emerge from the current global financial tsunami unscathed. Taiwan's export oriented economy has been hard hit by the global downturn, particularly as a result of the trade protection polices adopted by the United States, one of Taiwan's major export markets, he said.

In an interview with the Central News Agency Saturday, Dosanjh, the senior economist with the London-based Economist Intelligence Unit, said that Taiwan's economic growth will hit negative 9 percent in 2009 as a result of the global economic recession and a sharp decline in demand in the world's electronics and high-tech markets.
Dosanjh forecast that some 1.1 million people in Taiwan will be jobless as of the end of this year, with the country's unemployment rate soaring to 10 percent.
Forecasting that 2009 will be the "worst" year for the Taiwan economy, Dosanjh said the tide will not begin to turn until late 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: Buddhist NGO to establish U.N. representative office
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/22/09 21:24:11 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Jian Chen)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-based Buddhist non-governmental organization will become the first Taiwanese civic group to set up a representative office to manage its affairs with the U.N. in New York, a leader of the organization said Saturday.

Venerable Master Yung Ku, deputy secretary-general of the Buddha's Light International Association (BLIA), expressed hopes that with the establishment of the office in May, the BLIA will forge cordial ties with the American mainstream society.

The office will occupy two floors in a building, with one floor to be used as a tea house in which BLIA-related publications will be displayed, while the other level will be used for office work by the BLIA and other NGOs, he said.

Taiwan officials stationed abroad said that the plan reflects the keen interest of the country's civic groups to take part in U.N. activities in the areas of religion, human rights, culture, arts and women's rights.
The BLIA was invited last year to an annual conference in France organized by the U.N.'s Department of Public Information (DPI) and attended by affiliated NGOs.

Several other civic groups from Taiwan are registered with the U.N. as NGOs, including the Confederation of Asia-Pacific Chambers of Commerce and Industry (CACCI), the World League for Freedom and Democracy, the SimplyHelp Foundation and the Tzu Chi Foundation.

However, the CACCI is the only Taiwanese organization affiliated with the U.N. that has listed Taiwan as its place of registration, despite the fact that it has headquarters in both Taipei and New York. The other groups have registered through their overseas branches.

A number of Taiwan women groups and scholars are also involved in the U.N.'s NGO-Commission on the Status of Women (CSW) and have been active in CSW annual meetings and forums at the U.N. headquarters in recent years.
In 2003, the BLIA was granted special consultative status with the U.N.'s Economic and Social Council and NGO association status with the DPI.
Apart from its headquarters in Taipei and New York, the BLIA also has more than 170 branches in some 80 countries around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chunghwa Post to launch Visa debit card service

TEXT.P: Chunghwa Post Co. will launch a broad range of financial products and services this year, including Visa debit cards, an official of the state-run postal service said Sunday.
At present, the automatic teller machine (ATM) card service offered by the company only allows customers to make cash withdrawals using ATM cards.

To offer customers greater convenience, the company plans to roll out a Visa Debit card service, which can be used like any Visa card except that the funds will be debited from the card holder's deposit account when a purchase is made at home or abroad, according to the official.
With the number of savings accounts at the Chunghwa Post totalling approximately 10 million, the company plans to issue about 10 million cards at the first half of this year, the official said.
The postal company is inviting interested parties to participate in the public bidding for the production of the cards.
The company will also provide brokerage services this year to allow access to a wide variety of offshore mutual funds.
Moreover, the company and its counterpart in China are slated to start two-way remittance services across the Taiwan Strait on Feb. 26, according to the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: Industry leaders, top government officials to discuss economy

TEXT.P: Local industry leaders will hold a breakfast meeting with Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung and heads of a number of government agencies Monday to find feasible solutions to the ailing economy, the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce (CNAIC) said Sunday.

Chairman of the CNAIC Theodore M. H. Huang said that as President Ma Ying-jeou is making great efforts to reverse the country's economic downturn, the CNAIC and local industrial leaders wish to share their ideas with the government.

"As Taiwan's industry leaders are greatly concerned about the worsening economy, the CNAIC has arranged this meeting for local entrepreneurs to put forward their recommendations to the government," said Huang.

More than 40 local industry leaders have signed up for the meeting, including Chairman of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Morris Chang and Chairman of AU Optronics Corp. Lee Kuen-yao, Huang said.

The issues to be discussed will include a proposal by Ma for Taiwan to sign a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) with China, and the implementation of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) New Cheng Ho Project.

The MOEA's NT$9 billion project is aimed at salvaging Taiwan's rapidly falling exports by focusing on emerging markets and Southeast Asian nations, as orders from the United States and China have slowed down considerably.

The depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar will also be high on the meeting's agenda, as business leaders were alarmed by the fact that the exchange rate dropped to NT34.9 to the US dollar on Feb. 20, Huang said.

Vice Chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission Lee Jih-chu, and the heads of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, the Central Bank of Taiwan, the Ministry of Finance, and the Council of Labor Affairs, and the MOEA will all attend the meeting, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Name of Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall to be restored in July

TEXT.P: The Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, which was renamed the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall in May 2007 by the then Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government, will have its original title restored in July, Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said Sunday.

Wang told a press conference after a Presidential Office meeting that one of the decisions made at the meeting was that the government should act in accordance with the law and replace the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall name plaque above the main entrance with the original name plate.

Wang said the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall name plaque may still be useful, as the Ministry of Education will try to find a new location for the display of exhibits that portray the development of democracy in Taiwan.
He noted, however, that the word "memorial" in the title may be inappropriate because democracy in Taiwan is not dead, but rather has continued to grow from strength to strength.

As to whether the plaza around the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall will retain the name, Freedom Square, as it was called by the DPP government, Wang said that will be determined by consensus reached through public forums.

In April 2007, the then DPP government used an executive order to scrap the Provisions Governing the Organization of the CKS Memorial Hall Administration Office -- a law passed by the legislature in 1975 and promulgated a year later.

Opposition lawmakers at the time pointed out that the move was illegal because according to the nation's Constitution, only the legislature has the right to pass, amend or invalidate a law. But the DPP government insisted that it did not need the legislature's approval to change the name of the CKS Memorial Hall.

The name change was part of a campaign spearheaded by then Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng from 2005 to remove from public places vestiges of Chiang Kai- shek, who ruled Taiwan for 25 years until his death in 1975.
Although many people saw the campaign as politically motivated in the run-up to the legislative and presidential elections, the DPP government intensified the campaign it started in late 2005.

Without consulting the public or holding public hearings, the DPP government also removed Chiang's statues from public places across the island, deleted his name from the international airport in Taoyuan, and closed his mausoleum in Taoyuan County that had attracted over 1 million visitors a year.
The DPP later lost overwhelmingly in both elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT official warns of dire consequence if CECA is not achieved

TEXT.P: If Taiwan and China fail to sign a comprehensive economic cooperation agreement (CECA), the consequences for Taiwan will be dire, Chang Jung-kung, vice secretary-general of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) warned Sunday.

Chang, who doubles as head of the KMT's mainland affairs department, said in a statement that a CECA between Taiwan and China would be an accord to achieve mutual benefits within the framework of the current political situation where the two sides are under separate rule.

Chang also lashed out at the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), saying that they are intimidating the Taiwan people by quoting a Chinese scholar who stated Feb. 21 in the Washington Post that a Taiwan-China CECA would open the way for eventual unification between the two sides.

TSU Chairman Huang Kun-huei threatened Sunday to initiate a vote in the Legislative Yuan to recall President Ma Ying-jeou if Taiwan inks a CECA with China and if the government gives permission for Chinese students to study in Taiwan.

Chang said the two opposition parties' attempts to block economic cooperation across the Taiwan Strait would only lead to Taiwan's marginalization, given East Asia's planned economic integration, and will ruin the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo.
Under the eight-year rule of the DPP, which ended in May 2008, Taiwan had become an outcast in the region as a result of its anti-China policy, he said.

The CECA proposal was a campaign promise by President Ma before he assumed office in May last year, therefore, it is time for the government to honor that promise, as it won a mandate from the people with Ma's election, he asserted.

Due to the global financial crisis and the planned opening in 2010 of a regional free trade market that will include China and the member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, many prominent business leaders have been urging the government to forge a CECA with China in response to a six-point overture made by Chinese President Hu Jintao, he said.

Although China has not eased its political stance regarding Taiwan, he said, Taiwan must not abandon its efforts to maintain the cross-strait status quo through sound economic exchanges and a pragmatic approach that does not broach either independence or unification.

The opposition parties' objection to a CECA with China is meant to promote independence for Taiwan by turning a deaf ear to the real demands of the people, which in turn could incite China to step up its suppression of Taiwan and jeopardize Taiwan's interests, he warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opposition calls for resignation of financial, economics chiefs

TEXT.P: Participants at a national affairs conference organized by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) called Sunday for the country's economics and financial chiefs to resign.

The participants at the Taiwan Citizen Conference on National Affairs said that minister of the finance, minister of the economic affairs and the chief of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) under the Executive Yuan should step down.
They claimed that the minister of finance and the chief of the DGBAS had failed in their duty to hold firmly the strings of the country's purse.

They also criticized Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming for causing disruption on the stock market by misleading local investors into believing that the government would bail out a cash-strapped DRAM manufacturer.
The calls for the officials' resignation were made in a 10-point conclusion reached at the end of the two-day meeting Sunday noon.

The participants also urged President Ma Ying-jeou's administration to push Beijing to end its discriminatory treatment of Taiwan businessmen operating in China and to stop its politically motivated interference in their business.
They cautioned the administration not to unreservedly open up trade and economic exchanges with China.

Their other recommendations to the administration included extending unemployment subsidies from six months to one year; offering more soft loans to small- and medium-sized enterprises, and reviewing it policy of tax cuts for entrepreneurs.
The participants also warned the administration against proceeding with its proposal to sign a comprehensive economic cooperation agreement with China before securing public consensus on the plan.
The meeting was the first phase of a national affairs conference that will include a second meeting on a yet unspecified date in March and a third in April.

The organizers had invited tens of thousands people to attend the meeting, but more people than expected showed up at the venue Sunday and some of them had to be seated in an adjoining room to watch the proceedings on closed-circuit TV.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dharma Drum Buddhist College to waive tuition for new students

TEXT.P: Dharma Drum Buddhist College announced Sunday that students admitted to its undergraduate and graduate programs this spring semester will not have to pay tuition.

Executives of the college, located in Chinshan township in Taipei County, said if the new students are monks or nuns, their attendance at the college will be completely free, and that if they are lay people, they will need to pay only sundry fees, as all tuition will be waived.

They explained that the school made the decision in consideration of the fact that the adverse conditions caused by the global economic downturn might deprive many potential applicants of a chance to enroll in the Buddhist college.

Interested students have until March 16 to submit their applications to the college's admission office. Dharma Drum Buddhist College was founded in 2007, and it has become the first religious institution in Taiwan to be accredited by the Ministry of Education.
The college is located on the same campus as the Dharma Drum Sangha University, which is for monks and nuns only.

TEXT.P: 2. DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan public should be aware of China's 'Red Terror': academics

TEXT.P: Before supporting the government's policy of pursuing closer ties with China, the Taiwanese people should be aware that China has never stopped its inhumane treatment of dissidents and unapproved religious groups, a group of academics said Sunday.

Speaking at a press conference in Taipei organized by the Northern Taiwan Society to discuss China's "Red Terror," Laogai Research Foundation (LRF) Director Liao Tien-chi said that the Taiwan public should not be fooled by China's propaganda and should be aware of China's extensive system of forced- labor prison camps.

Liao stressed that as citizens of a democratic country, the Taiwan public should be aware of the human violations that have been committed by the Communist Party of China (CPC), before deciding to support closer ties with China dictated by economic expediency.

According to Liao, China and the Chinese have lived in "Red Terror" since Peng Pai and Mao Zedong launched the rascal-proletariat peasant movements in 1927. Peng Pai once claimed that communist law would be simply the execution of landlords once they were caught.
"The Communist Party of China never stopped its bloody terror campaigns since its inception, and its claws can be seen in the most recent crackdowns on Falun Gong practitioners, " said Liao.
Despite China's impressive economical development in the past two decades, the CPC has continued its systematic violation of human rights, he added.

"Public executions, the harvesting of organs from executed prisoners, the coercive enforcement of China's 'one-child' policy, and the persecution of religious believers are proof of what the CPC is capable of when it comes to the protection of its ideals, " said Liao.
China's Laogai, which means reform through labor, refers to a vast system of forced-labor prison camps in China established under Mao Zedong and modeled on the Soviet Gulag, Liao explained.
He said that although ordinary criminals and dissidents alike are imprisoned within the Laogai, it is not a normal penal system as the Chinese government claims.
"It functions as a brutal mechanism to suppress dissents and generate economic profits for China's totalitarian regime and is the source of many of its most egregious human rights abuses," said Liao.
As citizens of a free and democratic nation, Taiwanese should help expose and end China's human right violations, Liao said.

Meanwhile, a committee member of the Taiwanese Youth Anti-Communist National Salvation Corps, Paul Lin, said that Taiwan should not fall in to China's trap by accepting its one-China principle and it "one country, two systems" formula, as Hong Kong did in 1997.
Unlike Hong-Kong, Taiwan was ruled by the Kuomintang for more than half a century, and has a great number of pro-unification citizens who would eventually be brainwashed by the CPC, said Lin.
According to Lin, Hong Kong managed to remain somewhat democratic compared to other parts of China because of the democratic views of its residents.

"Because Hong Kong was ruled by the British for more than 150 years, its political system and government agencies have done an acceptable job of fending off many of Beijing's political agendas," said Lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opposition parties vow protests if government inks CECA with China

TEXT.P: The signing of a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) with China will jeopardize Taiwan's sovereignty and pave the way for the unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, therefore, the opposition parties will stage nationwide protests if the government continues to pursue such an agreement, said a former chairman of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party Su Tseng- chang Sunday.
Citing a Feb. 21 report in the Washington Post, leaders of the opposition party said a CECA would possibly be a step toward unification of China and Taiwan.

On the second day of a weekend conference on national affairs, Su said that the Ma Ying-jeou administration has "used the wrong medicine to treat the ailing economy" and that a CECA with China would be unwise.
Su said that the Ma administration has been arrogant and useless in its efforts to rescue the nation's economy, and the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) has failed to listen to the opinions of the people.

"If the KMT continues to make unilateral decisions concerning the economic and political development of the nation, it would force the opposition parties to gather the power of the people and take to the streets," said Su.

Ma's administration should immediately stop all attempts to sign a CECA with China, he urged, adding that it would be most unfortunate if the opposition parties were forced to stage a nationwide protest over this issue.
Meanwhile, DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen agreed that if the government seals a CECA with China without careful consideration or public consensus, it could cause social unrest.

Local industry and business groups have been pushing for the government to forge closer economic links with China by signing a CECA and to move quickly to liberalize cross-Taiwan Strait trade through actions such as the removal of tariffs.

More than 40 local industry leaders have signed up for the meeting, including Chairman of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Morris Chang and Chairman of AU Optronics Corp. Lee Kuen-yao, Huang said.

The issues to be discussed will include a proposal by Ma for Taiwan to sign a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) with China, and the implementation of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) New Cheng Ho Project.

The MOEA's NT$9 billion project is aimed at salvaging Taiwan's rapidly falling exports by focusing on emerging markets and Southeast Asian nations, as orders from the United States and China have slowed down considerably.

The depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar will also be high on the meeting's agenda, as business leaders were alarmed by the fact that the exchange rate dropped to NT34.9 to the US dollar on Feb. 20, Huang said.

Vice Chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission Lee Jih-chu, and the heads of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, the Central Bank of Taiwan, the Ministry of Finance, and the Council of Labor Affairs, and the MOEA will all attend the meeting, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Name of Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall to be restored in July

TEXT.P: The Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, which was renamed the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall in May 2007 by the then Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government, will have its original title restored in July, Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said Sunday.

Wang told a press conference after a Presidential Office meeting that one of the decisions made at the meeting was that the government should act in accordance with the law and replace the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall name plaque above the main entrance with the original name plate.

Wang said the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall name plaque may still be useful, as the Ministry of Education will try to find a new location for the display of exhibits that portray the development of democracy in Taiwan.
He noted, however, that the word "memorial" in the title may be inappropriate because democracy in Taiwan is not dead, but rather has continued to grow from strength to strength.

As to whether the plaza around the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall will retain the name, Freedom Square, as it was called by the DPP government, Wang said that will be determined by consensus reached through public forums.

In April 2007, the then DPP government used an executive order to scrap the Provisions Governing the Organization of the CKS Memorial Hall Administration Office -- a law passed by the legislature in 1975 and promulgated a year later.

Opposition lawmakers at the time pointed out that the move was illegal because according to the nation's Constitution, only the legislature has the right to pass, amend or invalidate a law. But the DPP government insisted that it did not need the legislature's approval to change the name of the CKS Memorial Hall.

The name change was part of a campaign spearheaded by then Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng from 2005 to remove from public places vestiges of Chiang Kai- shek, who ruled Taiwan for 25 years until his death in 1975.
Although many people saw the campaign as politically motivated in the run-up to the legislative and presidential elections, the DPP government intensified the campaign it started in late 2005.

Without consulting the public or holding public hearings, the DPP government also removed Chiang's statues from public places across the island, deleted his name from the international airport in Taoyuan, and closed his mausoleum in Taoyuan County that had attracted over 1 million visitors a year.
The DPP later lost overwhelmingly in both elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT official warns of dire consequence if CECA is not achieved

TEXT.P: If Taiwan and China fail to sign a comprehensive economic cooperation agreement (CECA), the consequences for Taiwan will be dire, Chang Jung-kung, vice secretary-general of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) warned Sunday.

Chang, who doubles as head of the KMT's mainland affairs department, said in a statement that a CECA between Taiwan and China would be an accord to achieve mutual benefits within the framework of the current political situation where the two sides are under separate rule.

Chang also lashed out at the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), saying that they are intimidating the Taiwan people by quoting a Chinese scholar who stated Feb. 21 in the Washington Post that a Taiwan-China CECA would open the way for eventual unification between the two sides.

TSU Chairman Huang Kun-huei threatened Sunday to initiate a vote in the Legislative Yuan to recall President Ma Ying-jeou if Taiwan inks a CECA with China and if the government gives permission for Chinese students to study in Taiwan.

Chang said the two opposition parties' attempts to block economic cooperation across the Taiwan Strait would only lead to Taiwan's marginalization, given East Asia's planned economic integration, and will ruin the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo.
Under the eight-year rule of the DPP, which ended in May 2008, Taiwan had become an outcast in the region as a result of its anti-China policy, he said.

The CECA proposal was a campaign promise by President Ma before he assumed office in May last year, therefore, it is time for the government to honor that promise, as it won a mandate from the people with Ma's election, he asserted.

Due to the global financial crisis and the planned opening in 2010 of a regional free trade market that will include China and the member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, many prominent business leaders have been urging the government to forge a CECA with China in response to a six-point overture made by Chinese President Hu Jintao, he said.

Although China has not eased its political stance regarding Taiwan, he said, Taiwan must not abandon its efforts to maintain the cross-strait status quo through sound economic exchanges and a pragmatic approach that does not broach either independence or unification.

The opposition parties' objection to a CECA with China is meant to promote independence for Taiwan by turning a deaf ear to the real demands of the people, which in turn could incite China to step up its suppression of Taiwan and jeopardize Taiwan's interests, he warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opposition calls for resignation of financial, economics chiefs

TEXT.P: Participants at a national affairs conference organized by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) called Sunday for the country's economics and financial chiefs to resign.

The participants at the Taiwan Citizen Conference on National Affairs said that minister of the finance, minister of the economic affairs and the chief of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) under the Executive Yuan should step down.
They claimed that the minister of finance and the chief of the DGBAS had failed in their duty to hold firmly the strings of the country's purse.

They also criticized Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming for causing disruption on the stock market by misleading local investors into believing that the government would bail out a cash-strapped DRAM manufacturer.
The calls for the officials' resignation were made in a 10-point conclusion reached at the end of the two-day meeting Sunday noon.

The participants also urged President Ma Ying-jeou's administration to push Beijing to end its discriminatory treatment of Taiwan businessmen operating in China and to stop its politically motivated interference in their business.
They cautioned the administration not to unreservedly open up trade and economic exchanges with China.

Their other recommendations to the administration included extending unemployment subsidies from six months to one year; offering more soft loans to small- and medium-sized enterprises, and reviewing it policy of tax cuts for entrepreneurs.
The participants also warned the administration against proceeding with its proposal to sign a comprehensive economic cooperation agreement with China before securing public consensus on the plan.
The meeting was the first phase of a national affairs conference that will include a second meeting on a yet unspecified date in March and a third in April.

The organizers had invited tens of thousands people to attend the meeting, but more people than expected showed up at the venue Sunday and some of them had to be seated in an adjoining room to watch the proceedings on closed-circuit TV.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dharma Drum Buddhist College to waive tuition for new students

TEXT.P: Dharma Drum Buddhist College announced Sunday that students admitted to its undergraduate and graduate programs this spring semester will not have to pay tuition.

Executives of the college, located in Chinshan township in Taipei County, said if the new students are monks or nuns, their attendance at the college will be completely free, and that if they are lay people, they will need to pay only sundry fees, as all tuition will be waived.

They explained that the school made the decision in consideration of the fact that the adverse conditions caused by the global economic downturn might deprive many potential applicants of a chance to enroll in the Buddhist college.

Interested students have until March 16 to submit their applications to the college's admission office. Dharma Drum Buddhist College was founded in 2007, and it has become the first religious institution in Taiwan to be accredited by the Ministry of Education.
The college is located on the same campus as the Dharma Drum Sangha University, which is for monks and nuns only.
