DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan public should be aware of China's 'Red Terror': academics

TEXT.P: Before supporting the government's policy of pursuing closer ties with China, the Taiwanese people should be aware that China has never stopped its inhumane treatment of dissidents and unapproved religious groups, a group of academics said Sunday.

Speaking at a press conference in Taipei organized by the Northern Taiwan Society to discuss China's "Red Terror," Laogai Research Foundation (LRF) Director Liao Tien-chi said that the Taiwan public should not be fooled by China's propaganda and should be aware of China's extensive system of forced- labor prison camps.

Liao stressed that as citizens of a democratic country, the Taiwan public should be aware of the human violations that have been committed by the Communist Party of China (CPC), before deciding to support closer ties with China dictated by economic expediency.

According to Liao, China and the Chinese have lived in "Red Terror" since Peng Pai and Mao Zedong launched the rascal-proletariat peasant movements in 1927. Peng Pai once claimed that communist law would be simply the execution of landlords once they were caught.
"The Communist Party of China never stopped its bloody terror campaigns since its inception, and its claws can be seen in the most recent crackdowns on Falun Gong practitioners, " said Liao.
Despite China's impressive economical development in the past two decades, the CPC has continued its systematic violation of human rights, he added.

"Public executions, the harvesting of organs from executed prisoners, the coercive enforcement of China's 'one-child' policy, and the persecution of religious believers are proof of what the CPC is capable of when it comes to the protection of its ideals, " said Liao.
China's Laogai, which means reform through labor, refers to a vast system of forced-labor prison camps in China established under Mao Zedong and modeled on the Soviet Gulag, Liao explained.
He said that although ordinary criminals and dissidents alike are imprisoned within the Laogai, it is not a normal penal system as the Chinese government claims.
"It functions as a brutal mechanism to suppress dissents and generate economic profits for China's totalitarian regime and is the source of many of its most egregious human rights abuses," said Liao.
As citizens of a free and democratic nation, Taiwanese should help expose and end China's human right violations, Liao said.

Meanwhile, a committee member of the Taiwanese Youth Anti-Communist National Salvation Corps, Paul Lin, said that Taiwan should not fall in to China's trap by accepting its one-China principle and it "one country, two systems" formula, as Hong Kong did in 1997.
Unlike Hong-Kong, Taiwan was ruled by the Kuomintang for more than half a century, and has a great number of pro-unification citizens who would eventually be brainwashed by the CPC, said Lin.
According to Lin, Hong Kong managed to remain somewhat democratic compared to other parts of China because of the democratic views of its residents.

"Because Hong Kong was ruled by the British for more than 150 years, its political system and government agencies have done an acceptable job of fending off many of Beijing's political agendas," said Lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opposition parties vow protests if government inks CECA with China

TEXT.P: The signing of a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) with China will jeopardize Taiwan's sovereignty and pave the way for the unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, therefore, the opposition parties will stage nationwide protests if the government continues to pursue such an agreement, said a former chairman of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party Su Tseng- chang Sunday.
Citing a Feb. 21 report in the Washington Post, leaders of the opposition party said a CECA would possibly be a step toward unification of China and Taiwan.

On the second day of a weekend conference on national affairs, Su said that the Ma Ying-jeou administration has "used the wrong medicine to treat the ailing economy" and that a CECA with China would be unwise.
Su said that the Ma administration has been arrogant and useless in its efforts to rescue the nation's economy, and the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) has failed to listen to the opinions of the people.

"If the KMT continues to make unilateral decisions concerning the economic and political development of the nation, it would force the opposition parties to gather the power of the people and take to the streets," said Su.

Ma's administration should immediately stop all attempts to sign a CECA with China, he urged, adding that it would be most unfortunate if the opposition parties were forced to stage a nationwide protest over this issue.
Meanwhile, DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen agreed that if the government seals a CECA with China without careful consideration or public consensus, it could cause social unrest.

Local industry and business groups have been pushing for the government to forge closer economic links with China by signing a CECA and to move quickly to liberalize cross-Taiwan Strait trade through actions such as the removal of tariffs.

The weighted price index lost 91.93 points, or 2.02 percent, to close at 4,436.94 Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 23, or the 29th day of the first month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1743: Meyer Rothschild, a German banker who founded a bank at
Frankfurt am Main, is born. His sons, most notably Salomon and Nathan Meyer, established branches of the bank throughout Europe.
1792: Sir Joshua Reynold, British painter and first president of
the Royal Academy, dies at the age of 69. He is considered one of the most important figures in the history of English painting.
1836: The siege of the Alamo begins in San Antonio, Texas. The siege ended March 6 with all the Texans killed by Mexican troops.
1848: John Quincy Adams, the sixth president of the United
States, who helped formulate the Monroe Doctrine, dies at the age of 81.
1863: British explorers John Speke and J.A. Grant announce that they have "discovered" Lake Victoria to be the source of the Nile.
1898: Emile Zola, the French writer and critic who was a leading
proponent of naturalism in fiction, is imprisoned for the publication of his letter "J'accuse, " which accused the French government of anti-Semistism and of wrongly imprisoning Captain Alfred Dreyfus.
1905: Paul P. Harris, a lawyer in Chicago, establishes Rotary International. There are now about 24,500 Rotary clubs in 167 countries, with about 1.1 million members.
1906: Johann Hoch is imprisoned in Chicago for murdering six of
his 13 wives.
1924: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president of the United
States and the winner of the 1919 Nobel Peace Prize, dies at the age of 68. His administration was marked by World War I and the introduction of prohibition.
1933: Japanese forces occupy Chinese territory north of the Great
Wall of China.
1942: Australia, Britain, New Zealand and the United States sign
the Master Mutual Aid Agreement.
1942: A Japanese submarine shells an oil refinery near Santa
Barbara, California.
1944: Joseph Stalin dissolves the Chechen republic and forces 1
million Chechens into exile, accusing them of collaboration with Nazi Germany.
1945: U.S. Marines plant the Stars and Stripes on Mount Suribachi of Iwo Jima, a strategic island 750 miles from Tokyo, after 74 days of bombardment and four days of a bitter ground battle.
1955: The first meeting of the Southeast Asian Treaty
Organization (SEATO) is held in Bangkok, Thailand.
1957: Republic of China Major-General Chiang Wei-kuo weds Helene B. Chiu in Tokyo, Japan.
1958: Taiwan's first Cobalt 60 medical instrument for treating
cancer arrives in Keelung from the United States.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with Cameroon.
1969: Chang Chun-li, chairman of the China Democratic Socialist
Party, dies in San Francisco at the age of 83.
1970: British Guinea ends its association with Britain and sets
up the Republic of Guyana.
1976: The Association of East Asian Relations and Japan's
Interchange Association open a two-day economic and trade conference.
1990: Prince Sihanouk returns to Cambodia after 11 years in
exile.
1991: The National Unification Council holds its fifth meeting
and passes the Guidelines for National Unification, which are now the highest directives governing the ROC's mainland policy. Its long-term goal is to establish a democratic, free and equitably prosperous China.
1991: Thailand's Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhaven is arrested
after the armed forces seize power in a bloodless coup.
1995: U.S. President Bill Clinton voices support for a united Canada in a speech to Canada's parliament.
1997: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes an amendment to Article 4
of the February 28 Incident Disposition and Compensation Act, stipulating that February 28, named "Peace Memorial Day," be deemed a national holiday.
2000: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang
adopts a proposal that Adolfo Sun should succeed Kuo Kang to become the ROC's ambassador to the Dominican Republic.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "How toweringly high and surpassingly great in moral grandeur was the way by which the ancient Emperors Shun and Yu came to the government of the Empire, and yet they themselves were unconscious of it."

DOC.HEADLINE: CECA plan purely an economic issue: official

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung said Monday that Taiwan's plan to sign a comprehensive economic cooperation agreement (CECA) with China is purely an economic issue that is not necessarily directly related to politics.

Chiu said the CECA plan, which comes under the portfolio of the the Ministry of Economic Affairs, is aimed mainly at enabling Taiwan to meet the challenges that would arise from the ASEAN Plus China agreement set to take effect in 2010.
He said extended regional economic blocs, such as ASEAN Plus One (China) and ASEAN Plus Three (China, Japan, South Korea), will have a tremendously adverse impact on Taiwan.
"That is the reason why the administration is pushing for the signing of a CECA with China," Chiu said.
According to a report by the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, when the ASEAN Plus Three agreement takes effect, it will indirectly result in the loss of 110,000 jobs in Taiwan.

Chang Ping-chao, chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China, urged the Taiwan public to look clearly at the matter, adding that signing a CECA with China will not compromise Taiwan's sovereignty. "Is it likely that Taiwan will become a second Hong Kong or Macau if it signs a CECA with China? " he asked.

Painting the CECA as crucially important to Taiwan, Chang said if Taiwan does not sign the agreement -- which aims to allow free flow of merchandise, services, and capital between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait -- Taiwan will be a "dead meat, " because its tariffs would be too high to allow it to compete with other countries in the region.
Meanwhile, Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said Sunday that Taiwan's plan to sign a CECA with China is purely an economic matter and does not involve national sovereignty issues.

Lai said if Taiwan is to enter into negotiations with China over issues involving national sovereignty, the administration would first have to solicit the opinions of the nation's 23 million people and obtain their consent through national referendum.
But it would be unnecessary to hold a referendum on issues such as the CECA that have nothing to do with politics, Lai added.

She made the remarks at a news conference called late Sunday in response to a threat by opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman Huang Kun-hui earlier in the day to launch a joint effort with the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to recall President Ma Ying-jeou if Taiwan signs a CECA with China.
Also on Sunday, ruling Kuomintang Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung said that the question of whether and how Taiwan should sign a CECA with China should be open for discussion.
"Taiwan should sign the CECA on condition that its sovereignty and international status are not compromised (in the process) , " Wu stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: President welcomes Palauan counterpart with full military honors

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou welcomed Palau President Johnson Toribiong to Taiwan Monday with full military honors at a formal ceremony that included a 21-gun salute.

At the ceremony held at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall plaza, Ma said that Palau is Taiwan's "closest ally" and that the two countries have maintained cordial ties since they established diplomatic relations 10 years ago. This is evidenced by the fact that Toribiong, one month after taking office, has chosen Taiwan for his first state visit, Ma said.
Ma noted that following closely on Taiwan's second peaceful transfer of power last May, Palau also elected a new president last November.
However, in a democracy, "government policies enjoy a continuity that extends the trust placed in and promises made to its allies, " the president said.

Taiwan has participated in several construction and development projects in Palau over the last decade, Ma said, pledging that Taiwan will continue to contribute to the Pacific island nation's growth under the existing framework of cooperation.

He also thanked the Palau government and people for their staunch support of Taiwan's efforts to become more involved in the international community, and expressed the hope that Palau will continue in this vein.

For his part, Toribiong, who served as Palau's ambassador to Taiwan from 2001-2008, said that the "unwavering and insurmountable support and assistance" from Taiwan has helped his country immensely over the years.
He expressed the hope that Taiwan will continue to work closely with Palau as the young Pacific republic tries to attain its national goal of sustainable economic growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Yunlin County pushes carbon tax to pressure government

TEXT.P: Yunlin County has approved a local carbon tax that it hopes will pressure the central government into reconsidering how it allocates funds to local governments.

Yunlin County Magistrate Su Chih-fen on Monday said the county's carbon tax measure was not proposed to punish companies but rather to compel the central government to reconsider its "unfair" allocation of funds to local governments.
The south-central county is home to the Formosa Plastics Group's petrochemical industrial park, one of the world's biggest, centered around its sixth naphtha cracker plant.
The complex generates slightly over one-quarter of Taiwan's carbon dioxide emissions and has long been the target of environmentalists proposing a carbon tax.

Yunlin County believes it is being shortchanged by the central government, which, according to county calculations, collects NT$47 billion (US$1.36 billion) in business taxes from Formosa Plastics Group companies operating in the Mailiao complex but only returns NT$500 million in disbursements to the county government.
The county estimates it could collect NT$9 billion a year from the complex if its local carbon tax were imposed.

The Yunlin County Council recently passed a bill drafted by the county government to levy a carbon tax, but the feasibility of the bill was reportedly questioned by the Ministry of Finance and the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Su questioned why the administration said Yunlin County "might not be permitted" to take the initiative to impose the tax, and urged the central government to reconsider its "unfair" distribution of funds to local governments.
She also appealed to President Ma Ying-jeou to fulfill his campaign pledge to address the idea of a tax on carbon dioxide emissions.
If the central government is not currently interested in imposing such a tax nationwide, Su said, the administration should allow the county to impose its local carbon tax on a trial basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-China economic pact tantamount to FTA: economics minister

TEXT.P: A comprehensive economic cooperation agreement (CECA) expected to be signed between Taiwan and China is tantamount to a free trade agreement (FTA) that will function based on the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO) , Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming said Monday.
Yiin said that it is a government policy to sign a CECA with China, but emphasized that the agreement will be politics-free and will operate under the WTO framework between two member economies.
He was speaking following a breakfast meeting with a group of business leaders sponsored by the Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce.

Yiin said it is necessary for Taiwan to sign a CECA with China to save Taiwan's industries which are facing a critical juncture. Reaching such an agreement with China could mean Taiwanese firms would enjoy lower or zero tariffs when trading with the mainland.

Maintaining or increasing Taiwanese companies' competitiveness by signing the agreement is especially important as China and the 10 member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) are planning to open a regional free trade market in 2010, Yiin noted.
"How could Taiwan's petrochemical industry survive if Taiwan's exports to China are levied a 6.5 percent customs tariff after the formation of 'ASEAN plus one'?" he asked.
Without revealing whether there is a timetable for the two sides to reach a CECA agreement, Yiin nonetheless called the task "an urgent matter."

The government's plan to clinch a Taiwan-China CECA has sparked grave concern from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), which fear such an agreement could erode Taiwan's sovereignty.

TSU Chairman Huang Kun-huei threatened Sunday to initiate a vote in the Legislative Yuan to recall President Ma Ying-jeou if Taiwan inks a CECA with China and if the government gives permission for Chinese students to study in Taiwan.
Huang accused the government of seeking to open the way for eventual unification with China through the pact.

In response to the opposition parties' objection, the Ministry of Economic Affairs stressed later Sunday that the two sides will conduct exchanges based on parity and dignity under the WTO framework and that Chinese workers will not be allowed in Taiwan, if a CECA is signed.

Apart from a Taiwan-China CECA, the MOEA said it is also planning to sign FTAs with the United States, Japan and Singapore to help Taiwan companies boost their globalization amid increased economic integration in East Asia and to lure foreign investment and create job opportunities for Taiwan's people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shares higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Monday, with the Taiwan stock exchange's weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 40.8 points, or 0.92 percent, to close at 4,477.78.
The local bourse opened at 4,420.43 and fluctuated between 4,485.36 and 4,371.02. A total of 2.86 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$57.38 billion (US$1.66 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares advancing at the most at 1.9 percent. Cement stocks rose 1.6 percent, textile issues moved up 1.1 percent, and plastics and chemicals stocks gained 0.8 percent.

Four other major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial stocks moving down the most at 1.9 percent. Construction stocks fell 1.3 percent, paper and pulp issues shed 0.4 percent, and foodstuff issues lost 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 857 to 746, with 203 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$536 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, falling NT$0.18 to close at NT$34.628.
A total of US$1.03 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$34.808 and fluctuated between NT$34.600 and NT$34.862.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices mostly higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Monday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for March advancing 61 points to end at 4,426, with 102,515 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for April gained 61 points to finish at 4,381, with 446 contracts traded, while June futures rose 46 points to end at 4,308, with 14 contracts traded.
September futures gained 60 points to close at 4,111, with 26 contract transactions, while December futures rose 54 points to end at 4,053, with 66 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 4,365 for March, 4,320 for April, 4,262 for June, 4,051 for September, and 3,999 for December.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index rose 40.84 points to finish at 4,477.78, on turnover of NT$57.38 billion (US$1.66 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

March TE futures gained 4.05 points to close at 181.55, with 5,540 contracts traded, while April TE futures advanced 3.65 points to finish at 179.9, with 30 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.
March TF futures fell 6.6 points to close at 472, with 4,353 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures lost 7 points to finish at 466, with 19 contracts traded.
June TF futures dropped 8.8 percent to close at 456, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: First reference book on classical Taiwan literature released

TEXT.P: National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) in southern Taiwan introduced Monday the world's first reference book on literature in Taiwan, titled "Chronology of Classical Literature in Taiwan: The Ming and Qing Dynasties."
The 800-page book was published last November after seven years of work by the two NCKU professors, Shih Yi-lin and Liao Mei-yu, and 27 researchers.

It traces the development of classical literature in Taiwan from 1651-1895 under five headings -- "writers events, " "literary and education events, " "significant events in Taiwan, " "significant events in the Qing Dynasty" and "significant events in the world."

In a report on the NCKU Web site, Shih said that the development of classical literature in Taiwan should have a place in history and should be examined within the context of significant events of the time to understand the meaning and value of the literati, works and literary activities during specific periods.
Taiwan literature was not regarded as an independent subject to be taught formally in universities until the middle of the 1990s, Shih stated.
She said that when she was teaching a course called "History of Classical Literature in Taiwan" in 2002, she became aware of a dearth of information on the subject.

Shih indicated that she was driven to write the book based on this observation and on the belief that there was a link between the development of classical literature in Taiwan and the politics and social events of past eras.

Readers will discover that while the rise and fall of the dynasties in China hinged on wars, it was literature that reflected the people's lives, social phenomena of the times and the state of the physical environment, Liao said in an interview with the Central News Agency.

Historical records show that Sheng Kuang-wen (1613-1688) was the first writer and scholar from China to move to Taiwan -- in 1651, late in the Ming dynasty -- and thus the development of Taiwan literature began.
By the late Qing period, Taiwan literature had developed to a level almost on par with China's, Shih said.

However, the Kuomintang government, which relocated from China to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a civil war, did not place any great importance on Taiwan literature, and it was not until the 1970s that native literature began to gain a footing, she said.
The study of Taiwan literature as a formal course began in the late 1980s after martial law in Taiwan was lifted.

The book offers a vast amount of data for research on Taiwan literature, Shih said, adding that she hopes to chronicle the development of Taiwan literature in the Japanese colonial era between 1895 and 1945 and that in the post-War World II period after 1945.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China to cohost 2nd World Buddhist Forum in March

TEXT.P: Buddhist organizations in Taiwan, China and Hong Kong will jointly hold the second World Buddhist Forum, which will open March 28 in Wuxi in China's Jiangsu province and conclude in Taipei on April 1.

The forum is organized by the Buddha's Light International Association in Taiwan, the Hong Kong Buddhist Association, the Buddhist Association of China, and the China Religious Culture Communication Association.

According to the organizers, about 2,000 participants from Buddhist circles in 60 countries will attend the forum when it opens. They include Buddhist leaders and academics from the United States, the United Kingdom, Sri Lanka, Thailand, India, South Korea, and Japan.

The theme of the forum is "A Harmonious World, A Synergy of Conditions." There will also be 16 subthemes, including "Opportunities and Challenges for Buddhist Education, " "The Reflection and Construction of Buddhist Practice System, " "Buddhism and Science, " and "Buddhist Charity and Care, " and "Inter- Sectarian Harmony in Buddhism."
On March 30, some 1,000 of the participants will move the forum to Taipei to continue their discussion on eight subthemes before concluding the meeting on April 1.
Five exhibitions will take place in conjunction with the forum to display Buddhist historical relics, photographs, ceramic masterpieces, handicrafts, Chinese paintings and calligraphic works.

The first World Buddhist Forum was held in April 2006 in Hangzhou city and Zhoushan city in China's Zhejiang province. Over 1,000 participants from 37 countries took part in that forum to discuss the theme, "A Harmonious World Begins in the Mind."

According to the organizers, the second forum aims to set up a high-level platform of open dialogue in the spirit of equality and pluralism for those who love the world, care for all sentient beings, accept Buddhism, and have a loving heart to conduct exchanges and collaboration. EDNITEM/cs

DOC.HEADLINE: Director of Beijing's Palace Museum to visit Taiwan

TEXT.P: The director of Beijing's Palace Museum will pay a reciprocal call to Taiwan next month, Taipei's National Palace Museum (NPM) said Monday.
Zheng Xinmiao will come to Taiwan March 1 for a four-day visit, and his itinerary is now being arranged, NPM deputy director Fung Ming-chu said.

An NPM official said that a delegation led by NPM Director Chou Kung-shin received VIP treatment during a recent "ice-breaking" visit of Beijing's Palace Museum, visiting sites that are off limits to the average visitor.
"The NPM is now arranging to give the same preferential treatment to Zheng and is even considering opening up the vaults that store valuable treasures to him," the official added.

The official said that Chou reached a nine-point consensus on closer cooperation and exchanges during her recent visit in China, making breakthroughs without touching on the sensitive issues of name and governing laws.

The cooperative ventures agreed to include long-term and short-term exchanges of personnel for up to one year. Researchers from Beijing's Palace Museum will also be able to come to Taiwan for special research projects starting in 2010.
The official said there were also breakthroughs on exhibition exchanges and cooperation.

He said that while an October exhibition in Taipei on Emperor Yongzheng of the Qing Dynasty could not be sponsored by the two museums due to name and regulation problems, Beijing still promised to lend 29 artifacts to Taiwan, including a set of 13 portraits of the long-serving ruler.
The official also said that there will be links between the two museums on the Internet, but issues involving names and regulations will be left for higher- level officials to deal with.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan dollar rate acceptable at present level: AU Optronics head

TEXT.P: The chairman of Taiwan's biggest exporter of TFT-LCD panels said Monday that the Taiwan dollar's level of 34.8 to the U.S. dollar was acceptable and would help boost the country's plunging export volume.

Lee Kun-yao, chairman of AU Optronics, the world's third largest flat-panel display vendor, said, "it's OK" when he was asked by a fellow businessman at a breakfast meeting whether the Taiwan dollar, which has lost value in recent weeks, was now at a level that would make Taiwan-exported goods competitive.
The NT dollar has depreciated 6 percent against the U.S. dollar since the beginning of the year, and has fallen from NT$33.749 to the greenback on Feb. 2 to NT$34.850 Feb. 20.

The breakfast meeting was organized by Theodore Huang, the chairman of the Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, to solicit opinions on the local currency's recent depreciation from local business leaders and the Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan).

According to Huang, CBC Deputy Governor Chou A-Ting said at the meeting that the local currency's value has been decided by market forces, although the CBC has also taken currency rate fluctuations in neighboring countries, such as South Korea, into consideration when assessing daily rates.

Huang said Chou also cited a CBC research report as indicating that South Korea's exports have not plunged as dramatically as Taiwan's, mainly because, unlike Taiwan, South Korea has a diversity of industries, such as steel, shipbuilding, and oil refining, that receive long-term export orders.
In contrast, the report said, Taiwan exports were mostly high-tech goods with customers concentrated in the United States, leaving its exports more vulnerable to the global economic downturn.
South Korea's currency was not mentioned as a key factor, even though the Korean won has lost around 30 percent of its value against the greenback over the past six months.

According to Huang, Chou also called for people in Taiwan to refrain from speculating irrationally on the prospects of the local currency, saying that some have even speculated that the local currency depreciate further to NT$38 or NT$40 to the U.S. dollar in the near future.
"This speculation lacks a theoretical basis, " Chou was quoted by Huang as saying.

Meanwhile, Minister of Econmic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming also analyzed the reasons behind Taiwan's steep drop in export volume. Yiin agreed with CBC report, saying that Taiwan's big export categories are too heavily concentrated in information technology (IT) and that too many of Taiwan's goods go to the United States.
Taiwan's exports fell by a record 44.1 percent in January and are expected to fall 10 percent for all of 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese travel industry to promote Taiwan golf tour packages

TEXT.P: More than 50 representatives of the Chinese travel industry will visit golf courses around Taiwan during the upcoming Cross-Strait Travel Industry Forum slated for Feb. 25 to design Taiwan golf tour packages, said Taiwan's Travel Agent Association (TAA) on Monday.

TAA Secretary-General Roger K.C Hsu said that as most of the restrictions on visits to Taiwan by Chinese have been lifted, the travel industries from both sides wish to develop and design new travel packages.
Close to 50 members of the Chinese delegation will visit golf courses located mainly in the western part of the island to design golf tour packages that will later be promoted in China, said Hsu.
"We hope to attract more Chinese golfers to Taiwan in the future as the local green fee is in many cases cheaper than those in Chinese golf courses," said Hsu.

In addition, Hsu said that as the climate in central and southern Taiwan is suitable for golf all year round, the island has already received numerous groups of Chinese golf players in the past few months.

Although Taiwan's golf tour market is still relatively small compared to other Asian countries, with the recent opening of direct transportation links between China and Taiwan, Taiwan's travel industry is expecting a rapid increase in the number of Chinese golf lovers in Taiwan, said Hsu.

According to Hsu, travel industry representatives from both sides of the Taiwan Strait will gather in Taipei for the first time on Feb. 25 to discuss market development and to help mainland industry professionals become more familiar with the Taiwan market.

Meanwhile, Hsu said that delegates from 30 Chinese provinces, autonomous regions and municipalities, and more than 450 members of China's travel industry are expected to attend this year's cross-strait travel forum.

Serving as this year's organizer, Taiwan's Travel Quality Assurance Association (TQAA) has arranged an eight-day trip for the Chinese delegation to travel to scenic areas located on the eastern and western parts of Taiwan to get a firsthand look at Taiwan's tourism resources, said Hsu.

According to the TQAA, Shao Qiwei, chairman of China's National Tourism Administration, will attend the forum in his capacity as chairman of the Cross- Strait Tourism Exchange Association and is scheduled to meet with his Taiwanese counterpart, Janice Lai, director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.

However, the TQAA said that Shao will only remain in Taiwan for four days, adding that the vice chairman of China's National Tourism Administration Du Jiang will lead the Chinese delegation for the remaining four days of the evaluation trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nantou plans to attract Chinese tourists with 'shopping vouchers'

TEXT.P: The Nantou County government is planning to distribute "shopping vouchers" to Chinese tourists to encourage them to visit the central Taiwanese county.

Nantou County Magistrate Lee Chou-ching told a county government meeting Monday that the program will be modeled after the one launched by Hangzhou City in China, which wants to distribute 1 million yuan (NT$5 million) in shopping vouchers to tourists from Nantou County.
Those who travel to Hangzhou may shop with the vouchers, which are actually a kind of discount coupons, Lee said.
For example, shoppers only need to pay 30 yuan for a product that is priced at 40 yuan with the Hangzhou-version shopping vouchers, which means they enjoy a discount of 25 percent, Lee elaborated.
The discount coupons are valid from March 15 to June 15.
Lee praised Hangzhou's tourism-stimulus measure as a good idea worthy of being copied by his county.

There have been close exchanges between Nantou and Hangzhou City of the Zhejiang province in recent years since they began discussing a plan to "marry" the scenic Sun Moon Lake in Nantou and West Lake in Hangzhou in an attempt to boost tourism, trade and other exchanges between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should sign CECA with China as soon as possible: KMT caucus

TEXT.P: Taiwan should ink a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) with China as soon as possible, on the condition that Taiwan's sovereignty is preserved, to prevent the country from becoming economically marginalized, a leading Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker said Monday.

Yang Chiung-ying, the KMT legislative caucus' secretary-general, said Taiwan should stop limiting itself in the international arena, as such an action will only convert the nation into a "frog in a well," a reference to holding a parochial world view.

Yang said Taiwan should abandon what she described as the "closed door policy" of the Democratic Progressive Party, which governed Taiwan from 2000-2008, and sign a CECA with China as soon as possible under the principle of no sacrifice of Taiwan's sovereignty.

Fellow KMT lawmaker Hsiao Ching-tien said that according to the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, an extra 110,400 local workers are likely to lose their jobs after China, South Korea and Japan enter into a free trade agreement with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).

Signing an economic cooperation agreement with China could offset some of the job losses by giving Taiwanese products exported to China the same import duty treatment as products from ASEAN competitors or South Korea and Japan.
"Taiwan's economy and society will be deeply impacted if the government fails to sign a CECA with China," Hsiao warned.
He argued that the CECA negotiations should be conducted in a fast and decisive manner and should not be affected by the political leanings of legislators and the people.

"We should not let political considerations cloud the real meaning of signing a CECA with China," Hsiao said. "We will lose many business opportunities if the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) continues to boycott the inking of a CECA with China."

The DPP has suggested that such a trade deal with China would jeopardize Taiwan's sovereignty, but Hsiao said such accusations are premature, as details of the CECA have not yet been discussed with China.
KMT Legislator Lo Shu-lei suggested Taiwan would lose its competitiveness if it fails to sign a CECA with China.

"Even more people would lose their jobs and have no way to support themselves if the DPP continues to object to the signing of the agreement with China as Taiwanese products would lose their competitiveness in the international market," she argued.

The CECA would allow Taiwan and China to offer each other economic and trade privileges, including the elimination of import duties and the lifting of non- tariff trade barriers, as well as maintaining preferential tariff and trade policies already in place.

According to Taiwan's Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , there is no timetable for the signing of such an agreement, and it is not expected to be broached at the next round of negotiations between quasi-official organizations representing Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan takes action to streamline government's structure

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan decided Monday to fold the Sports Affairs Council into the Ministry of Education as part of a plan to improve administrative efficiency.
The Executive Yuan revealed the decision after an internal meeting on organizational reform.

It also decided to merge the Atomic Energy Council with the National Science Council, and integrate the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission into the Council for Economic Planning and Development.
The Executive Yuan's goal is to cut the number of Cabinet-level agencies from the current 37 to approximately 27. A complete streamlining plan is expected to be ready by mid-March.
Any organizational restructuring plan approved by the Executive Yuan will have to be submitted to the Legislative Yuan for approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan explores foreign affairs involvement through art

TEXT.P: Taiwan will showcase selected works that explore the methods and possibilities of the island becoming involved inforeign affairs-- the theme Taiwanese artists have chosen to explore in the upcoming Venice Biennale in Italy, a local museum announced Monday.

Four distinguished creators, whose pieces represent the current development of Taiwans trend in contemporary art, will use contemporary art to reflect on the countrys identity issue, according to Hsieh Hsiao-yun, director of the Taipei Fine Arts Museum (TFAM), in a press conference.
The artists will allow the world to understand the country's "soft power," said Hsieh.

TFAMs Biennial and International Office Director Chang Fang-wei explained that through observations, documenting or direct involvement, the artists interact, or even clash, with their own chosen region.
The art pieces will be displayed in the forms of photography, video installations and other special devices, she added.

For instance, Chen Chieh-jen, renowned for his reflective works on the relations between image and authority, will introduce his new film productionImperial Borders Iin Venice, whose idea originates from the review mechanism that Taiwanese people must face when applying for U.S. visas. The piece also takes on the issue of how modern empires exert their superiority over other places through intricate manipulation, Chang said.

Meanwhile, an architect artist, Hsieh Ying-chun, will display his eco-friendly construction projects at the exhibition, Chang said. Through the projects, he attempted to assist minority or underprivileged groups in countries such as China, Indonesia and Taiwan who suffered from natural disasters.

In addition, Chang Chien-chi, who has tracked illegal Chinese immigrants striving to survive in New York over the years via documentary photography, extends his focus on their families who still remain in China as well as their offsprings now living in the U.S., Chang said.

Also, a young, promising artist, Yu Cheng-ta, will explore the role of languages in communication and interaction in his Ventriloquistsseries, Chang said, adding that he is Taiwans only artist who addresses issues faced by foreigners living in Taiwan.
The 2009 Venice Biennale is slated to kick off on June 7 and will come to an end on Nov. 22, according to TFAM.

DOC.HEADLINE: More communication channels with China needed: MAC

TEXT.P: With bilateral relations between Taiwan and China improving rapidly in recent months, the two sides need to establish more communication channels to deal with the growing number of issues facing them, a Mainland Affairs Council official said Monday.

Speaking at a reception held by the Foundation on Asia-Pacific Peace Studies, MAC Deputy Minister Chao Chien-min said that since relations with China have entered to a new era, both sides need to establish more unofficial communication channels to further facilitate cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation.

Business leaders and nongovernment organizations in Taiwan and China should take the initiative to establish such channels to help solve some of the many problems hindering cross-strait economic cooperation, Chao said.
"The number of issues concerning cross-strait economic and cultural cooperation is only going to increase in the future, " Chao said.

Chao stressed that Taiwan's Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF) and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- the quasi-official bodies representing the two sides in the absence of formal ties -- cannot negotiate and solve all the problems and issues that have accumulated during the past few decades.

Asked about U.S.Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's visit to China, Chao said the Barack Obama administration has shown great support for Taiwan's efforts to lower cross-strait tensions, and that in the future the MAC will continue to help promote peace and stability in the area as it is beneficial for all parties involved.

As for the inking of a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement with China, Chao said that while there is no timetable for the signing of such an agreement, carrying out the policy is vital for Taiwan's economic survival.

The signing of a CECA with China will prevent Taiwan from being marginalized in the international community once South Korea, China and Japan set up a free trade area with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taoyuan airport hit hard by plunging trade volume

TEXT.P: Hit hard by the global economic tsunami, Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport only handled 72,213 tons of cargo in January, less than half its level in peak years, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) reported Monday.
Continuing a severe decline that began late last year, CAA officials said the week-long Lunar New Year holiday in late January also contributed to the plunge in volume.
Taiwan's largest airport handled 85,278 tons of cargo in December, the first time the airport's monthly volume had fallen below 100,000 tons since February 2003.
The airport handled 1.493 million tons of cargo for the whole of 2008, a fall from 1.606 million tons in 2007, CAA statistics showed.
Due to the economic downturn, Taiwan's two largest carriers -- China Airlines and EVA Airways Corp. -- have grounded five of their 36 cargo planes.
At its peak in 2005, the airport handled 1.705 million tons of cargo for the year, an average of nearly 150,000 tons per month. The annual volume fell by less than 10,000 tons in 2006.

Airport authorities had hoped that the opening of nonstop cross-Taiwan Strait cargo charter services in mid-December would boost the amount of cargo handled, but volume has fallen short of expectations.

China opened Shanghai and Guangzhou airports to exchange cargo charter services with the airport in Taoyuan in January, but carriers from neither side operated all 30 cargo charters they were allowed to fly during the month, CAA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: More men show interest in becoming caregivers: local center

TEXT.P: Taiwan's growing legion of unemployed men are now looking for jobs in traditionally women-dominated sectors, with many males responding to a growing demand for local caregivers, the head of a local home care center said Monday.

Huang Kuo-ta, chairman of the Taichung Home Care Services Association, said the increasing demand for caregivers, resulting from the government's focus in 2009 to expand care to the country's minorities, has attracted more men to sign up for the association's professional training courses.
Men comprised 20 percent of the 30 participants in recent courses, he said, with some of them young and highly-educated.
Among them, Huang said, was a young man who used to work in the technology sector but has not been able to find a job since being laid off last year and has now decided to change course.
Another participant, a 63-year-old man named Chang Ting-jung, headed a car repair factory but was forced to close the business because of the sluggish economy.
Huang said he has regained the courage to move on with his life and improved his finances after taking on several caregiver jobs.

While Huang sees local caregiving as a promising market, he reminded men interested in giving it a shot that they need to work harder to shatter society's conventional stereotypes and gain acceptance, as women are still more welcomed in the sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: Some 12,000 Amway workers in China to visit Taiwan

TEXT.P: Some 12,000 people working for direct sales company Amway in China will be coming to Taiwan on cruises this spring, with a portion of the 12,000 scheduled to arrive in March and April on six separate sailings, Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) officials confirmed Monday.
The MOTC has received an application submitted by cruise line Royal Caribbean International to bring the first group of Amway workers on six separate cruises to Taiwan in March and April.
Each cruise will accommodate between 1,000 and 2,000 passengers, according to officials of the MOTC's Department of Aviation and Navigation.
The cruises will first stop at Keelung Harbor in northern Taiwan and then proceed to Hualien Harbor in eastern Taiwan and to Taichung Harbor in central Taiwan.

The MOTC has yet to receive an application from the second cruise line handling the Amway employees -- Costa Crociere Cruise Line -- which will bring the remaining Amway employees to Taiwan on three separate cruises.
The trips are overseas incentive tours arranged by Chinese Amway (China) Co., Limited for its workers, who will arrive in Taiwan from Shanghai.
Taiwan limits the arrival of Chinese tourists on its shores to 3,000 a day, but the MOTC said it convinced the Mainland Affairs Council not to include the Amway workers in the count.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former marquee player to help Taoyuan's baseball development

TEXT.P: The Taoyuan County government hired one of Taiwan's greatest baseball players Monday to help develop the game in the county.
County Magistrate Eric Liluan Chu disclosed that he decided to hire Li Chu-ming, known in Taiwan as "Mr. Baseball" because of his 1,000 hits in his professional baseball career.

Chu invited Li to his office after learning from news reports that he had been jobless for more than two months after the Brother Elephants, one of Taiwan's four professional teams, let him go. Li had served as the team's hitting coach since 2004.
Chu said that Taoyuan County has 140 baseball teams, more than any other county or city in Taiwan, and that Li is the right talent the county needs to develop the game.

The magistrate indicated that in the initial stage, Li will serve as a consultant on the county's project to build an international-caliber baseball stadium, which began in December, and that he will begin to train baseball teams starting in the fall.

Li, 40, was a player on the Brother Elephants when it, along with the President Lions, the Mercuries Tigers, and the Wei Chuan Dragons, launched the Chinese Professional Baseball Legaue (CPBL) in 1990.
He left the Brother Elephants in 1999 to join the Taipei Gida in the rival Taiwan Major League (TML), which was established in 1997.

In 2003, when the TML terminated operations, two of its four teams were merged with the CPBL, returning professional baseball to a single market. But the merger included a "traitors clause" that barred players who had jumped to the TML from returning to the expanded CPBL.

Left without a job in baseball, Li opened a coffee shop, but his business was unsuccessful. The Brother Elephants rehired him as a hitting coach in 2004, but last year, under the strain of the slumping economy, the team fired him and three other coaches to cut operating costs.
Li made headlines after news media found him unemployed. The Taoyuan County magistrate, who attaches great importance to baseball, contacted him directly and offered him the job.

His first challenge will be to help shape the new NT$836.3 million (US$24.16 million) baseball stadium, which the county is building on a 9.7-hectare site near the Taiwan High Speed Rail's Taoyuan Station.
The stadium will have 12,000 infield seats, with room for future construction of outfield stands.
After the stadium's completion by the end of 2009, Taoyuan County will be able to host national and international baseball tournaments.

DOC.HEADLINE: Facelift for Taoyuan Airport Terminal 1 to be completed in 2011

TEXT.P: A facelift of Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport's Terminal 1 will be completed by the end of 2011, a year earlier than originally planned, the head of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Monday.

CAA Director-General Lee Long-wen made the remarks after Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo instructed a speedy completion of the renovation, which is one of the government's new 10 major construction projects.
The facelift is needed, Lee said, because the 30-year-old terminal building and its related facilities are rundown and its space is inadequate to comfortably handle passenger traffic.

He said that the CAA had originally planned to renovate the airport area by area, which will take about three-and-a-half years. To speed up the process, the CAA also considered the possibility of closing Terminal 1 and moving all arrivals and departures to Terminal 2.

After evaluating the situation, the CAA decided to close half of the Terminal 1's arrival and departure areas for renovation and then close the other half when the first part of the project is completed.
The total cost of the renovation will be NT$2 billion (US$57.47 million), Lee added.
He said that after the completion of the work, the terminal will be able to handle 15 million passengers per year, up from the current 12 million.
That total, added to Terminal 2's capacity of 17 million passengers, will enable Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport to handle a total of 32 million passengers per year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shanghai Museum director to visit Taiwan

TEXT.P: Shanghai Museum director Chen Xiejun will lead a four-member group to Taiwan for a reciprocal visit of the National Palace Museum (NPM), an NPM official said Monday.
The official said that the group will arrive in Taipei Thursday and return to Shanghai on March 1.
Chen's group will also call on the Taipei City government, which will take part in the World Expo Shanghai 2010, the official added.
Due to the group's limited time in Taiwan, it will not visit other places or institutions outside Taipei.

NPM director Chou Kung-shin visited Beijing's Palace Museum and the Shanghai Museum during her "ice-breaking" visit of China in mid-February, reaching a consensus with her counterparts on closer exchanges and cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan to present streamlining plan in March

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has decided to eliminate around 10 of its 37 agencies and fold their functions into other bodies, Yeh Kuang-shi, vice minister of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) said Monday.

Yeh noted that in the government's preliminary reorganization plan, the Executive Yuan will be composed of 13 ministries, eight councils and commissions, three independent institutions, and four other bodies.
The complete restructuring plan will be unveiled in March, and Yeh said the government hopes it will take effect in 2011.

Yeh made the announcement at the conclusion of the Monday meeting of the Executive Yuan's organizational reform promotion task force, which focused on a draft amendment to the Organization of Central Administrative Agencies Basic Law and the provisional draft statute for the reorganization.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT chairman arrives in Manila for visit

TEXT.P: Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung has reaffirmed his party's resolve to defend the sovereignty of the Republic of China in a speech delivered at a dinner given in his honor Monday by Taiwanese expatriate groups in Manila, according to a press statement release by the party's Taipei headquarters.
Wu arrived in Manila earlier in the day on the first leg of his current three- country Southeast Asian tour that will also take him to Malaysia and Singapore.

Quoting Wu's speech, the statement said Wu told Taiwan expatriates in the Philippines that Taiwan's mainstream opinion does not support de jure Taiwan independence and also believes the time is not yet ripe for unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

In his speech, the statement said, Wu further told the expatriates that the ROC government plans to merge the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Overseas Compatriots Affairs Commission as part of its efforts to devote more resources to upgrade services for overseas expatriates while promoting diplomatic work.
During his stay in Manila, Wu will also meet with local political figures to discuss closer bilateral ties and regional cooperation, the statement said.
Wu is scheduled to return to Taiwan March 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait postal remittance services to begin Feb. 26

TEXT.P: The long-heralded postal remittance service between Taiwan and China will begin Thursday, the Department of Posts and Telecommunications under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications confirmed Monday.

Officials at the department said they had received a notice from postal authorities in China that the cross-Taiwan Strait postal remittance service will definitely become operational beginning Feb. 26.

The two-way remittance service was originally scheduled to begin Feb. 18, but Taiwan's state-run Chunghwa Post Co. was informed that the date had to be postponed because the Chinese side needed more time to sort out problems.

The launching of the service is based on one of four agreements signed Nov. 4 last year in Taipei between Taiwan's semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation and its Chinese counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits -- that allows Taiwan and China to begin direct mail and postal remittance services.
Direct cross-strait mail service began Dec. 15.
Taiwan's post offices have provided services for outward remittances bound for China through Citibank New York since 1991, but have not accepted inward remittances from China.
From Feb. 26, the postal remittance service between the two sides will work in both directions, with Citibank New York continuing to provide currency settlement services.

According to Chunghwa Post, the Postal Savings Bank of China will join the Bank of China and the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China as a newcomer among the Chinese banks at which remittances can be made.
All remittances will be made in U.S. dollars, with each transfer limited to US$30,000. The service charge in Taiwan will be NT$500 for each wire transfer and NT$400 for each mail transfer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Some 12,000 Amway workers in China to visit Taiwan

TEXT.P: Some 12,000 people working for direct sales company Amway in China will be coming to Taiwan on cruises this spring, with a portion of the 12,000 scheduled to arrive in March and April on six separate sailings, Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) officials confirmed Monday.
The MOTC has received an application submitted by cruise line Royal Caribbean International to bring the first group of Amway workers on six separate cruises to Taiwan in March and April.
Each cruise will accommodate between 1,000 and 2,000 passengers, according to officials of the MOTC's Department of Aviation and Navigation.
The cruises will first stop at Keelung Harbor in northern Taiwan and then proceed to Hualien Harbor in eastern Taiwan and to Taichung Harbor in central Taiwan.

The MOTC has yet to receive an application from the second cruise line handling the Amway employees -- Costa Crociere Cruise Line -- which will bring the remaining Amway employees to Taiwan on three separate cruises.
The trips are overseas incentive tours arranged by Chinese Amway (China) Co., Limited for its workers, who will arrive in Taiwan from Shanghai.
Taiwan limits the arrival of Chinese tourists on its shores to 3,000 a day, but the MOTC said it convinced the Mainland Affairs Council not to include the Amway workers in the count.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former marquee player to help Taoyuan's baseball development

TEXT.P: The Taoyuan County government hired one of Taiwan's greatest baseball players Monday to help develop the game in the county.
County Magistrate Eric Liluan Chu disclosed that he decided to hire Li Chu-ming, known in Taiwan as "Mr. Baseball" because of his 1,000 hits in his professional baseball career.

Chu invited Li to his office after learning from news reports that he had been jobless for more than two months after the Brother Elephants, one of Taiwan's four professional teams, let him go. Li had served as the team's hitting coach since 2004.
Chu said that Taoyuan County has 140 baseball teams, more than any other county or city in Taiwan, and that Li is the right talent the county needs to develop the game.

The magistrate indicated that in the initial stage, Li will serve as a consultant on the county's project to build an international-caliber baseball stadium, which began in December, and that he will begin to train baseball teams starting in the fall.

Li, 40, was a player on the Brother Elephants when it, along with the President Lions, the Mercuries Tigers, and the Wei Chuan Dragons, launched the Chinese Professional Baseball Legaue (CPBL) in 1990.
He left the Brother Elephants in 1999 to join the Taipei Gida in the rival Taiwan Major League (TML), which was established in 1997.

In 2003, when the TML terminated operations, two of its four teams were merged with the CPBL, returning professional baseball to a single market. But the merger included a "traitors clause" that barred players who had jumped to the TML from returning to the expanded CPBL.

Left without a job in baseball, Li opened a coffee shop, but his business was unsuccessful. The Brother Elephants rehired him as a hitting coach in 2004, but last year, under the strain of the slumping economy, the team fired him and three other coaches to cut operating costs.
Li made headlines after news media found him unemployed. The Taoyuan County magistrate, who attaches great importance to baseball, contacted him directly and offered him the job.

His first challenge will be to help shape the new NT$836.3 million (US$24.16 million) baseball stadium, which the county is building on a 9.7-hectare site near the Taiwan High Speed Rail's Taoyuan Station.
The stadium will have 12,000 infield seats, with room for future construction of outfield stands.
After the stadium's completion by the end of 2009, Taoyuan County will be able to host national and international baseball tournaments.

DOC.HEADLINE: Facelift for Taoyuan Airport Terminal 1 to be completed in 2011

TEXT.P: A facelift of Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport's Terminal 1 will be completed by the end of 2011, a year earlier than originally planned, the head of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Monday.

CAA Director-General Lee Long-wen made the remarks after Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo instructed a speedy completion of the renovation, which is one of the government's new 10 major construction projects.
The facelift is needed, Lee said, because the 30-year-old terminal building and its related facilities are rundown and its space is inadequate to comfortably handle passenger traffic.

He said that the CAA had originally planned to renovate the airport area by area, which will take about three-and-a-half years. To speed up the process, the CAA also considered the possibility of closing Terminal 1 and moving all arrivals and departures to Terminal 2.

After evaluating the situation, the CAA decided to close half of the Terminal 1's arrival and departure areas for renovation and then close the other half when the first part of the project is completed.
The total cost of the renovation will be NT$2 billion (US$57.47 million), Lee added.
He said that after the completion of the work, the terminal will be able to handle 15 million passengers per year, up from the current 12 million.
That total, added to Terminal 2's capacity of 17 million passengers, will enable Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport to handle a total of 32 million passengers per year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shanghai Museum director to visit Taiwan

TEXT.P: Shanghai Museum director Chen Xiejun will lead a four-member group to Taiwan for a reciprocal visit of the National Palace Museum (NPM), an NPM official said Monday.
The official said that the group will arrive in Taipei Thursday and return to Shanghai on March 1.
Chen's group will also call on the Taipei City government, which will take part in the World Expo Shanghai 2010, the official added.
Due to the group's limited time in Taiwan, it will not visit other places or institutions outside Taipei.

NPM director Chou Kung-shin visited Beijing's Palace Museum and the Shanghai Museum during her "ice-breaking" visit of China in mid-February, reaching a consensus with her counterparts on closer exchanges and cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 24, or the 30th day of the first month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1500: Charles V, the Holy Roman emperor and King of Spain as Charles I, who summoned the Diet of Worms and the Council of Trent, is born.
1815: Robert Fulton, the American engineer who developed the first useful submarine and torpedo and invented the steamboat, dies at the age of 50.
1868: Andrew Johnson, the 17th president of the United States, becomes the first president to have impeachment proceedings brought against him by the House of Representatives. He was acquitted by one vote.
1885: Chester Nimitz, American admiral of the Pacific Fleet during World War II, is born. He halted Japanese expansion and ultimately destroyed the Japanese fleet with a strategy based largely on the use of aircraft carriers.
1891: The Ching court pays an indemnity to Russia for the return of Ili Valley in northwest China.
1909: The world's first color movie is shown in England.
1920: The Nazi Party, or the National Socialist German Workers Party, announces its program to set up the Third Reich.
1920: American-born Nancy Astor becomes the first woman to speak in Britain's House of Commons.
1933: The League of Nations votes 40 to one to pass a resolution refusing to recognize "Manchukuo," a puppet regime installed by the Japanese in China. Japan walks out of the international organization after the vote.
1945: U.S. forces liberate Manila from Japanese occupation.
1945: Ahmed Maher Pasha, premier of Egypt, is shot dead in parliament just after declaring war on the Axis powers.
1946: Juan Peron is elected president of Argentina.
1948: The Labor Union of Taiwan Province is established.
1950: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China holds its first meeting in Taipei.
1962: Dr. Hu Shih, the president of Taiwan's Academia Sinica, who proposed that literature be written in the vernacular rather than in the classical style, dies in Taipei at the age of 72.
1966: Ghana's President Kwame Nkrumah is overthrown in an army coup while he is visiting communist China. He was forced into exile in the Republic of Guinea.
1968: U.S. and South Vietnamese troops recapture the old Vietnamese imperial city of Hue after a fierce battle.
1969: A passenger plane of Taiwan's Far East Air Transport Corp. crashes in Kuijen village, Tainan County, killing all 36 people on board.
1972: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with Malta.
1974: Pakistan officially recognizes Bangladesh as an independent nation.
1976: A nine-member economic mission of Japan's Sankei Shimbun newspaper led by Nobutaka Shikanai, president of the newspaper, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1977: U.S. President Jimmy Carter cuts off U.S. aid to Argentina, Uruguay and Ethiopia because of human rights violations.
1978: Construction of the first-phase of the Taiwan Railway Administration's railway electrification project is completed and opened to traffic.
1989: Funeral rites for Japanese Emperor Hirohito, who had reigned since 1926, are held in Tokyo. His son, Akihito, becomes the new emperor.
1990: Malcolm Forbes, American tycoon, escort of Elizabeth Taylor and owner of "Forbes Magazine," dies.
1997: A fire at a Hindu pilgrim encampment in eastern India claims more than 200 lives and injures over 500 people.
2000: Chung Jung-chi, a minister without portfolio and a key member of the Kuomintang's election machine, announces his resignation from public office and also from the party in a "consciousness-raising" move.
2004: A Taiwan-developed hybrid car powered by an internal combustion engine and an electric motor is unveiled.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I do not now see a man who can love moral worth in man as he loves beauty in woman."

DOC.HEADLINE: Former president summoned to pre-trial hearing

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian was summoned by the Taipei District Court to a pre-trial session Tuesday to pave the way for his trial on corruption and money laundering charges.
The session is scheduled to last three days. Tuesday's hearing is expected to focus on Chen's role in a land deal between the Hsinchu Science Park and Dayu Development Corp.

The former president and his wife Wu Shu-jen are accused of siphoning off NT$104 million (US$3.01 million) from a special Presidential Office discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000 to May 2008.

They are also charged with accepting bribes worth a total of NT$300 million in connection with the land procurement deal and another NT$90.93 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project. They allegedly wired and stashed the funds overseas secretly through various intermediaries.
The couple is still being probed on suspicion of helping several financial conglomerates acquire financial holding companies in return for "political contributions."

Chen, who has been in custody since Dec. 30, began a hunger strike last week to protest against what he called continued judicial persecution against him. However, he ended the strike after a visit by his wife Monday.
