DOC.HEADLINE: Some 12,000 Amway workers in China to visit Taiwan

TEXT.P: Some 12,000 people working for direct sales company Amway in China will be coming to Taiwan on cruises this spring, with a portion of the 12,000 scheduled to arrive in March and April on six separate sailings, Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) officials confirmed Monday.
The MOTC has received an application submitted by cruise line Royal Caribbean International to bring the first group of Amway workers on six separate cruises to Taiwan in March and April.
Each cruise will accommodate between 1,000 and 2,000 passengers, according to officials of the MOTC's Department of Aviation and Navigation.
The cruises will first stop at Keelung Harbor in northern Taiwan and then proceed to Hualien Harbor in eastern Taiwan and to Taichung Harbor in central Taiwan.

The MOTC has yet to receive an application from the second cruise line handling the Amway employees -- Costa Crociere Cruise Line -- which will bring the remaining Amway employees to Taiwan on three separate cruises.
The trips are overseas incentive tours arranged by Chinese Amway (China) Co., Limited for its workers, who will arrive in Taiwan from Shanghai.
Taiwan limits the arrival of Chinese tourists on its shores to 3,000 a day, but the MOTC said it convinced the Mainland Affairs Council not to include the Amway workers in the count.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nantou County moving ahead with Hohuan Mountain cable car project

TEXT.P: The Nantou County government is moving ahead with a Hohuan Mountain cable car project scheduled to be completed in 2011, in the hope of promoting the mountain areas of county's Jenai township as a world famous scenic destination, Magistrate Lee Chao- ching said Monday.

At a meeting hosted by the county government earlier in the day, the company responsible for planning the project gave a briefing on the legal, financial, and environmental aspects of the project and on matters pertaining to construction techniques, marketing and implementation.
According to the plan, the mountain cable car system will be constructed at a cost of NT$2.35 billion (US$67.92 million) over a span of more than eight kilometers, with three stations along the way.

After the briefing, Lee said that Hohuan Mountain is the most famous spot in Taiwan for people seeking to enjoy snow scenes and activities. He said he hopes that when the cable system is completed it will help to improve transportation up and down the mountain and reduce carbon dioxide emissions.
Lee said that the central government has approved the feasibility study for the project, which will be constructed under the Build-Operate-Transfer model.

Also present at the briefing were representatives of the Taroko National Park Administration, the Council of Agriculture's Forestry Bureau, National Taiwan University's (NTU's) Highland Experimental Farm, and Jenai township office.
The NTU representatives expressed interest in operating the stations and helping to develop a high mountain botanical garden to boost tourism in the township.
Lee said that that after the cable car system becomes operational, the mountain areas of Jenai township will become another notable tourist attraction in Nantou County, apart from Sun Moon Lake.

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls for closer ties with Southeast Asia

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday he hopes to see progress in Taiwan's relations with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) following the recent improvement of the country's ties with China.
Ma raised the issue while receiving former President of the Philippines Fidel Ramos, who is on a visit in Taiwan.
Ma suggested that Ramos, who is board director of the Boao Forum for Asia, wield his influence to help Taiwan improve its relations with ASEAN.

Ma noted that Taiwan and the Philippines are not only very close to each other geographically, but also maintain deep substantial relations, with more than 90,000 Filipino nationals currently working in Taiwan.
"During my eight years in office as mayor of Taipei City, I realized that if all those 90,000 people took leave of absence on the same day, part of the city could be paralyzed," Ma said.

The large number of Filipino workers in Taiwan has helped promote friendship between the two sides, he said, recalling that during a trip to Manila, he once met a Taiwanese couple who was there to visit their Filipino domestic helper.

Although the number of foreign workers in Taiwan is expected to decrease because of the current economic downturn, Ma expressed confidence that the situation will revert to normal after the economy recovers.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA denies plan to provide subsidies for LCD television purchase

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Tuesday that it has not been authorized by the Executive Yuan to design a plan for the government to subsidize domestic purchases of LCD television sets.

Denying local media reports that the MOEA is planning to provide NT$2,000 (US$57.56) in subsidies to individuals who purchase LCD televisions, the ministry said it has not had any discussions or done any studies on such an idea.
It stated in a press release that the LCD TV subsidy proposal was raised by entrepreneurs during a Feb. 23 breakfast meeting between top government officials and industry leaders.
"Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung agreed only to consider and evaluate the issue," the MOEA said, adding that Chiu did not make any other promises during the meeting.

As for the issue of encouraging the public to replace their analog televisions with the more modern digital LCD sets, the MOEA said that the government and relevant agencies are still discussing and evaluating that idea.

DOC.HEADLINE: 437 Taipei City families eligible for food vouchers: mayor

TEXT.P: A total of 437 families in Taipei City are eligible to each receive NT$5,000 (US$144) in the first batch of food vouchers to be issued by the city government March 1 to households in urgent need, Taipei City Mayor Hau Lung-bin announced Tuesday.

After city officials and social workers interviewed 531 families, 437 households, or 82.3 percent of those interviewed, were approved by the municipal Bureau of Civil Affairs to receive the food vouchers in the first delivery of its kind, Hau said at a news conference following a municipal meeting.
According to Hau, a total of 1,134 families applied to claim the subsidy after the Taipei city government unveiled the plan Jan. 22 to help families hard hit by the economic downturn.

The bureau is planning to deliver NT$5,000 worth of food vouchers to each of 10,000 households in the initial stage of the program that will last until Dec. 31 this year, bureau officials said. In the follow-up stages, more families experiencing financial difficulties could be included, they added.

Families residing in Taipei City, but not necessarily with household registrations here, will be eligible to receive the food vouchers, as long as they are identified by their local borough chiefs as being in need of assistance and recommended by the city officials and social workers conducting the interviews.

The coupons will be a one-time handout and can only be spent on food such as lunch boxes, bread and rice balls, at Family Mart convenience stores. They cannot be used to purchase cigarettes, alcoholic beverages or magazines.
The economic downturn has resulted in many people in Taiwan losing their jobs, with parents of school-aged children being the worst affected.

DOC.HEADLINE: Civil group calls for debate on proposed economic pact with China

TEXT.P: The Alliance of Referendum for Taiwan (ART) demanded Tuesday that the chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chiang Pin-kung participate in a public debate on the government's plan to sign a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) with China.

More than 40 members of the ART made the call during a demonstration staged in front of the SEF building in Taipei to protest against the CECA proposal and to urge the government to hold a referendum on the issue.
An ART representative Tsai Tin-kue said that if Taiwan signs a CECA under the one-China principle, the agreement will symbolize Taiwan's surrender to China.

"The signing of such an agreement will be an act of betrayal of the Taiwanese people," said Tsai, adding that the CECA will not only compromise Taiwan's sovereignty, but will also jeopardize its economic and political interests.
According to Tsai, the public should decide, by national referendum, whether or not Taiwan should sign a CECA with China.
"The SEF and other government agencies have no right to make that decision without public consensus," said Tsai.
"If Chiang has the determination and courage to sign a CECA with China, then he should have the courage to participate in a public debate on the issue," Tsai said.
After being notified of the protest, an SEF official came out of the building to accept a written petition from the ART members.

DOC.HEADLINE: 18 arrested in Chiayi City for abusing foreign workers

TEXT.P: Tainan City police announced Tuesday that they have arrested 18 people in Chiayi City for allegedly abusing eight Indonesian women after getting them into Taiwan under false pretexts.

Tainan City police said they arrested the suspects, who worked for a labor brokerage firm in Chiayi City, after receiving information that the company got women from Indonesia into Taiwan under the pretext of getting married with Taiwanese men and then put them to work for low wages.

A preliminary investigation discovered that the brokers seized the women's passports and marriage certificates upon arrival and forced them to sign illegal contracts in which the women accepted to be paid only NT$2,000 (NT$58) of their nominal NT$24,000 monthly salary, police said.
The brokers also threatened the women not to go outside on their own. At least eight Indonesian women fell victim to the scheme, police said.
Many women from Southeast Asian countries are imported into Taiwan through illegal means to work here, with many of them forced into prostitution by criminal rings.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan pursuing free trade pacts with ASEAN states

TEXT.P: Taiwan is pushing for bilateral free trade agreements with individual Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) members as a more feasible way for the country to participate in regional economic integration, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.

Because Taiwan is neither an ASEAN dialogue or development partner, it will be more difficult for the country to forge a free trade pact with the association as a whole than taking a bilateral approach, said Frances Lee, deputy director- general of MOFA's Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, in a press briefing.
With ASEAN countries looking to set up a free trade zone with China, Japan and South Korea as early as 2010, Taiwan is afraid of being economically marginalized in the region.
If it is left behind in the integration process, its goods sold to countries in the region will face higher duties than those offered by its main competitors.

Taiwan is currently focusing its efforts on negotiating with ASEAN countries that have greater trade ties with Taiwan, including Singapore, Malaysia and Thailand, as bilateral free trade deals with those countries would be mutually beneficial, Lee said.
Taiwan may also try to work out special arrangements with individual ASEAN nations to lower tariffs in specific industries, which would have a similar impact as a free trade deal, she said.

Lee stressed that Taiwan already has close economic ties with ASEAN states, as overall trade with the association's 10 members totaled US$63 billion last year. Taiwan is also among the top three sources of foreign investment in Thailand, Malaysia, Vietnam and Cambodia.

Meanwhile, around 2 million people traveled between Taiwan and ASEAN countries in 2008, while there were approximately 357,000 migrant workers from Southeast Asia employed in Taiwan as of the end of last year, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Next round of cross-strait talks might include economic pact proposal

TEXT.P: The proposal for Taiwan and China to sign a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) can be discussed in the third round of high-level talks between the intermediaries of the two sides, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Vice Chairman Kao Koong-lian said Tuesday.

Kao was referring to the next round of dialogue between SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , which is expected to take place in the first half of this year.
According to Kao, Taiwan should adopt a step-by-step approach in promoting the signing of the agreement, and the Chiang-Chen dialogue can be a platform for preliminary discussions on related issues.

Kao reassured the public that future CECA negotiations with China will be carried out under the principles of parity and dignity and that Taiwan will never accept the one-China principle as a precondition for the negotiations.

He also dismissed concerns that the establishment of a CECA with China would downgrade Taiwan's status to that of a special administrative region like Hong Kong or Macau, both of which signed a closer economic partnership arrangement (CEPA) with China in 2003.

Kao explained that a CECA is similar to a free trade agreement and will function under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO), in which Taiwan's membership status is totally different from that of Hong Kong.

While Hong Kong entered the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in 1986 as a British colony, Taiwan gained accession to the WTO in 2002 as the "Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu," he said.

The pro-independence opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) have strongly objected to the proposed Taiwan-China CECA, arguing that such an agreement would undermine Taiwan's sovereignty and pave the way for unification with China.

The DPP has unveiled a plan to stage nationwide demonstrations against the possible signing of the agreement, and the TSU has threatened to initiate a vote in the Legislative Yuan to recall President Ma Ying-jeou if the agreement is inked.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices moved down Tuesday, with the Taiwan stock exchange's weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 47.60 points, or 1.06 percent, to close at 4,430.18.

Suffering a decline after the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell overnight to its lowest close since May 7, 1997, the local bourse opened lower at 4,407.95 and fluctuated between 4,452.96 and 4,394.76. A total of 2.84 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$56.47 billion (US$1.63 billion).
All eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks falling the most of any category, losing 3.2 percent.

Plastics and chemical shares fell 1.7 percent, cement stocks dropped 1.2 percent, foodstuff issues as well as machinery and electronics stocks declined 1.1 percent, paper and pulp stocks fell 0.9 percent, construction issues shed 0.5 percent, and banking and financial stocks lost 0.3 percent. Losers outnumbered gainers 1,129 to 443, with 224 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$8.31 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung MRT passenger volume hits new high in January

TEXT.P: The passenger volume on the Kaohsiung Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) system hit a monthly record high of 4,367,000 in January, increasing 640,000 from the previous month, according to statistics released Tuesday by the city's MRT bureau.
The figure translated into a total of NT$120 million in business revenue, up 20 percent month-on-month, the bureau's director Lee Cheng-pin said at a city government meeting.

Attributing the increase in MRT passenger volume to the nine-day Chinese New Year holiday that began Jan. 25, Lee said that during that period, many people visited the southern port city for sightseeing purposes or for the Kaohsiung Lantern Festival.

A total of 320,000 passengers took the Kaohsiung MRT on Jan. 28, setting a daily record high, according to Lee, adding that the average daily passenger volume during the Chinese New Year holiday was between 250,000 and 300,000.

However, the passenger volume on shuttle buses to and from Kaohsiung MRT stations did not increase in proportion to the rise in MRT passenger volume, Lee noted, adding that some 283,000 passengers took the shuttle buses in January, a decrease of 37,000 compared with last December.
Lee said this was probably because most MRT passengers were from outside Kaohsiung and were therefore not familiar with the shuttle bus service.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, increasing NT$0.169 to close at NT$34.797.
A total of US$722 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$34.628 and rose to the day's high of NT$34.80.

DOC.HEADLINE: Export orders post record fall of 41.67% in January

TEXT.P: Taiwan received only US$17.68 billion worth of export orders in January, marking a record annual decline of 41.67 percent, according to the statistics released Tuesday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

The figure was in line with the ministry's previous estimate that January's export orders were to be valued at under US$20 billion, as there were only 17 working days for the full month because of the long Chinese New Year holiday, according to the ministry.

Among industries, the value of orders for electronics products in January decreased by US$2.71 billion, or 38.85 percent, from a year earlier, due mainly to a decline in demand for consumer electronics.
The value of orders for information technology (IT) and communication products dropped by US$1.91 billion, or 30.47 percent, because of the sizable shrinkage in demand for notebook computers.
Precision devices posted a decline of US$1.63 billion, or 61.13 percent.
January's drop in orders, an indication of shipments in the next one to three months, came after a 33 percent drop in December following November's 28.51 percent plunge.

DOC.HEADLINE: No timetable for signing economic pact with China: premier

TEXT.P: The government has not set a timetable for the signing of a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) with China, because this will depend partly on the progress of negotiations between the two sides, Premier Liu Chao- shiuan said Tuesday.
Liu said the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Mainland Affairs Council are currently trying to integrate their efforts to promote the agreement.
The premier made the remarks while fielding questions about the issue during an interpellation session in the Legislative Yuan.
Liu was also asked to comment on a claim by opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman Huang Kun-huei that China is working to unify with Taiwan by 2016.
Liu, however, said Taiwan has not set any such timetable and that he has no idea where Huang obtained that information.

The pro-independence TSU and Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) have strongly objected to the proposed Taiwan-China CECA, arguing that such an agreement would undermine Taiwan's sovereignty and pave the way for unification with China.

The DPP has unveiled a plan to stage nationwide demonstrations against the possible signing of the agreement, and the TSU has threatened to initiate a vote in the Legislative Yuan to recall President Ma Ying-jeou if the agreement is inked.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market fell Tuesday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for March declining 46 points to close at 4,381, with 83,683 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for April lost 47 points to finish at 4,333, with 249 contracts traded, while June futures fell 42 points to end at 4,266, with 52 contracts traded.
September futures fell 44 points to close at 4,067, with 46 contract transactions, while December futures lost 52 points to finish at 4,001, with 44 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 4,427 for March, 4,380 for April, 4,308 for June, 4,111 for September and 4,053 for December.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 47.6 points to finish at 4,430.18, on turnover of NT$56.47 billion (US$1.63 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.
March TE futures fell 2.3 points to close at 179.2, with 3,689 contracts traded, while April TE futures lost 2.2 points to finish at 177.7, with 28 contracts traded.
September TE futures lost 4 points to end at 165, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for June and December.
March TF futures were down 4.8 points to close at 467.2, with 5,050 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures fell 3 points to finish at 463, with 26 contracts traded.
September TF futures dropped 3 points to end at 447 points, with six contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for June and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier hints at resignation if stimulus package fails

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan hinted Tuesday that he would consider resigning if a special four-year NT$500 billion (US$14.45 billion) public works expansion package the Cabinet has proposed fails to pull Taiwan out of its current economic slump.

"If the project falls short of its target, I would acknowledge the failure and fully assume responsibility, " Liu said in answer to a question from an opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker on what the premier would do if Taiwan's economy contracts by more than 5 percent rather than the 2.97 percent forecast by the government.
He said he would know whether to stay on or step down.
Liu also said that the local economy's performance must be measured in comparison to other countries.
"A negative 5 percent economic growth rate might be a relatively good performance by that time," he suggested.

According to Liu, the four-year NT$500 billion special budget will help create 190,000 to 220,000 job opportunities in 2009 and push Taiwan's gross domestic product higher by 0.97 percent this year and 1.02 percent in 2010, 2011 and 2012.
"Taking the 0.97 percent into consideration, Taiwan's GDP will still contract by 2.97 percent in 2009," he asserted.

In its weekly meeting Feb. 12, the Executive Yuan approved the NT$500 billion budget to fund a stimulus package that it believes will help mitigate the impact of the global economic slowdown, and it now hopes the Legislative Yuan will pass it as soon as possible.

The package contains 20 prime investment projects and 64 plans to serve six major goals: to upgrade the transportation network, build a safe and anti- disaster environment, enhance cultural and living standards, strengthen national competitiveness and infrastructure, improve transport facilities on outlying islands, and foster high-end talent and stabilize the job market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Indigenous tribes to form united front for sovereignty over land

TEXT.P: Indigenous tribes around Taiwan will simultaneously light fires in their communities on Feb. 28, using the resulting "smoke signals" to send a message to the government that they are sovereign owners of their land, a spokesman for an indigenous rights group said Tuesday.

According to the Taitung County-based Smoke Motion Union, it will be the second time in a year that indigenous tribes, including the Pinuyumayan, Amis and Bunun, will act in unison to spread their message in the same way their ancestors once communicated with the sky and the spirit of the nature.

Last Feb. 28, dense smoke rose simultaneously from dozens of tribal villages around the island, conveying the angry voices of indigenous peoples over the government's ignorance of their natural hunting and fishing rights on their own land.

The campaign was formed after a group of Pinuyumayan hunters from the Katatipul tribe in Taitung City were obstructed by forest police from their annual sacred hunting ceremony in late 2007 in what they claimed was a rough and disrespectful manner.

The incident triggered protests by the Katatipul people, which then developed into a joint call among indigenous tribes around Taiwan for the government to respect their natural rights and indigenous sovereignty, said Mateli Sawawan, a spokesman for the Smoke Motion Union.
The call turned into a protest rally held by indigenous people from around the country in front of the Presidential Office on March 8, 2008.
The call, however, has never been properly answered since then, the union argued, which is why it is preparing a second round of protests on Feb. 28, the spokesman said.

Asked why the group chose that day, Mateli Sawawan explained that Feb. 28 is a day on which justice has been upheld after the government made a public apology for the 228 Incident, also known as the 228 Massacre, in 1947.
The incident was an anti-government, anti-Chinese uprising in Taiwan violently suppressed by the then-Kuomintang government.
In its Feb. 28 activity, the indigenous group will advocate forming a constitution of the Taiwan indigenous nation that stipulates it is equal with the Republic of China regime.

It will also promote the establishment of a nongovernment organization to handle incidents where it believes indigenous people have been mistreated by the Republic of China regime, according to the union.
Mateli Sawawan said the tribes that join the activity will also make public their separate calls for government action through the release of smoke.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung metro to grant free rides to jobless, underprivileged

TEXT.P: Jobless people and underprivileged students living in the southern port city of Kaohsiung and neighboring Kaohsiung County will soon be able to ride the city's metro for free, the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) announced Tuesday.

The KRTC said it has worked with China Steel Corp. to set aside a NT$30 million (US$862,468) fund to help relieve the financial burden of the unemployed and students of low-income families by allowing them to apply for a free stored value card worth 1,000 points -- enough for them to ride the city's metro system for about six months.

The KRTC will accept applications for the card from March 2 to May 31, and those applying must submit documents from local government departments certifying that they are currently receiving unemployment benefits or are students in low-income families.
The stored value cards will be valid for six months from their date of issue but will not be valid for use on city buses or Kaohsiung harbor ferry rides, according to KRTC officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police should use handcuffs more discriminately: Taipei County head

TEXT.P: Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei on Tuesday instructed the police force in his county to avoid the unnecessary use of handcuffs while enforcing the law.

Chou told a county government meeting that he regretted a recent incident in which police in Danshuei township arrested and handcuffed two Tamkang University coeds working part-time at a video and comic book store after discovering pornographic DVDs there.
"The use of handcuffs should be the exception, not the rule," Chou said at the meeting, attended by police chiefs.
Chou added that in the case of the arrest of the two coeds, the use of handcuffs by the police was unnecessary because there was no danger that the coeds would attempt to escape.
The handcuffing of the two university students followed another incident in Taichung County in which police handcuffed a woman whom they arrested for picking two flowers from the side of a road.
Media reports were critical of the police in both incidents for unnecessarily intimidating and humiliating offenders.

The Taipei County magistrate acknowledged that handcuffing is sometimes necessary for legitimate security reasons, but stressed that any restraint of suspects' movements when they are arrested must be commensurate with their offenses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gambling fever sends Penghu land prices soaring

TEXT.P: The price of land in Houliao in the island county of Penghu has soared since Taiwan's legislature legalized gambling on Taiwan held islands Jan. 12, local sources said Tuesday.

Sung Sen-hu, a tour business operator in Penghu, told the Central News Agency that land in Houliao has attracted considerable interest since the county government designated the small village -- about 20 kilometers north of Penghu's capital city of Makong -- as the main location for casino-oriented tourism.
Sung said the price of land along main roads has risen the most, rising from NT$12,000 (US$346) per ping to between NT$30,000 and NT$40,000. One ping equals 3.3057 square meters.
"The price tripled in less than one and a half months, " he said.

On Tuesday, the government of the island county that lies off Taiwan's southwestern coast held a presentation in Houliao to lobby local residents for support of its plan to have international gaming operators build luxurious resorts with casinos in the village.

The 150 villagers attending the event seemed to welcome the plan, and some confirmed that land speculation is on the rise. Recent records on farming land transactions showed the price has risen to between NT$5,000 and NT$6,000 per ping.

Although the legislature passed a law legalizing the operation of casinos on Taiwan-held islands in January, any move to promote the construction of casinos on the islands must be approved by island residents in a referendum.
The Penghu County government has been holding forums to sell the idea, but groups opposing the proposal are also making their voices heard.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Israel ties will remain unchanged: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) expressed confidence Tuesday that the cordial relations between Taiwan and Israel will remain unchanged given that a majority of the Israeli parliamentarians friendly toward Taiwan were re-elected in a recent general election.

Speaking in a press briefing, Antonio Chen, director-general of MOFA's Department of West Asian Affairs, said that 23 members of the Taiwan Friendship Group of the Israeli Parliament continue to hold their seats in the Knesset after the Feb. 10 election.
Eighty percent of the parliamentarians in the friendship group won re-election, Chen said, and as a result, support for Taiwan in the Middle Eastern country's parliament will continue to be strong.

DOC.HEADLINE: MNF to investigate abandoned tombs discovered in Papua New Guinea: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MNF) will send experts later this week to investigate abandoned tombs accidentally discovered in the deep jungles of Papua New Guinea that belonged to Republic of China soldiers, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.

While the MNF is the authority in charge of the handling of the issue, the ministrys representative office in the Pacific country will provide assistance on the side, said Frances Lee, deputy director-general of the MOFA's East Asian and Pacific Affairs, in a press briefing.
She said a plan to visit the tombs at the end of January was disrupted due to a volcanic eruption there which caused the local airport to be shut down.

According to a local media report in December, three deserted tombs were discovered near the Papua New Guinea city of Rabaul, with one of them unrecognizable and the rest identified as belonging to R.O.C. Army Captain Wu Kun and Sergeant First Class Kung Hsien-chang, who died in 1945.

During World War II, over 1,600 R.O.C. soldiers seized by the Japanese army were sent by the Japanese government to the South Pacific region to work as slaves. Around 650 died there and never got to return home, according to the report. The remaining estimated 1,000 others were sent back to China by the United States after the Japanese were defeated in the war.

Indigenous people from Taiwan were also forced by the Japanese army to go to the South Pacific to work as soldiers during the war. Efforts by well-known aborigines to seek redress on behalf of the victims have not been successful.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rents to be halved in Pingtung agricultural park

TEXT.P: The government plans to halve rental and management fees charged companies operating in the Pingtung Agricultural Biotechnology Park to help them ride out the current economic slump, Vice President Vincent Siew said Tuesday during a visit to the park.

Speaking at a meeting with representatives from park businesses, Siew said agriculture is one of Taiwan's promising economic sectors and one the country should count on to develop and expand both domestic demand and exports.

He said that by creating value through innovation and biotechnology, the park is expected to take the leading role in the agricultural sector over the next 10 years, just as the Hsinchu Science Park drove growth in the science and technology sector in the years following its launch.

During the meeting, park businesses suggested that rents on land, factory buildings and dormitories as well as management fees in the park be cut in half for the next three years, and Siew asked Council of Agriculture Deputy Minister Hu Hsing-hua to respond.
Hu said the Executive Yuan has already approved a plan to halve the park's rental and management fees this year and that it would be reviewed at the end of 2009.

Responding to others suggestions, Siew said he will direct relevant government agencies to study the possibility of establishing a valuation mechanism to allow developed technologies to be valued as assets, helping the companies get greater access to financing.
Hu added that the COA will ask the Agricultural Bank of Taiwan to provide loans at preferential interest rates for firms operating in the park.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should never forget the 228 incident: President Ma

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that Taiwan's people should never forget the 228 Incident and promised that his administration will continue to contribute to the search for the historical truth of the tragedy.

Speaking at the Lunar New Year Reception of the Taipei 228 Incident Association held in Taipei, Ma expressed his sympathy for victims of the incident and promised to step up efforts to promote reconciliation and harmony in Taiwanese society.

Ma said the government and the people should learn from past mistakes and that the events that occurred during the 228 Incident should be emphasized in school textbooks to prevent future generations from allowing similar tragic events to occur.
"We can forgive what people have done in the past, but we can never forget what happened," Ma said.

The president promised that the government will continue to provide financial assitance to the 228 Memorial Foundation through the Ministry of Education and will establish the legal foundation for the construction of the National Taiwan 228 Museum as soon as possible.

Meanwhile, the founder of the Taipei 228 Incident Association, Liao Ji-bin, said that Ma has demonstrated sincerity in promoting reconciliation of the chasms among people caused by the incident since he became mayor of Taipei in 1998.
"I have no doubt in my mindtthat Ma will do even more for the family members of the 228 Incident now that he is president of the nation," Liao said.
He urged politicians, however, to stop manipulating the tragedy in order to monopolize the issue in a bid to win more votes in every major election.

The 228 Incident refers broadly to an uprising beginning at the end of February 1947 that culminated in the killing of tens of thousands of dissidents, elites, and others in Taiwan by Chinese Nationalist troops.
An estimated 10,000 to 30,000 people were killed during the Incident and in ensuing violent crackdowns by the KMT administration in March and April 1947.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH on guard against measles outbreak

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) is monitoring the conditions of individuals who have had contact with a child who was infected with the measles after traveling to China, a DOH official said Tuesday.

Chou Jih-haw, deputy director of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control, said that although no one has been infected after coming into contact with the baby boy, the DOH will not let down its guard until mid-March.
The 15-month-old baby boy who lives in central Taiwan, caught the measles while he was hospitalized for diarrhea while traveling with his mother in Hunan, China, Chou said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Locally produced pork safe: Yunlin County

TEXT.P: The Yunlin County government and its meat market co-sponsored a fair Tuesday, inviting the public to taste dishes prepared with locally produced pork to dispel fears over pork safety prompted by reports that foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) hit a local pig farm recently.

Lu Cheng-chang, head of the county's agricultural affairs bureau, urged Taiwan's consumers not to worry about consuming pork produced in the county, as local authorities will closely scrutinize the production process to guarantee quality.
The meat from the Yunlin pork market, Taiwan's largest, is distributed to over 150 distribution points around the country.

Last year, the market's slaughterhouse culled 402,378 pigs and auctioned 607,271 pigs. As of Feb. 21 this year, 93,443 pigs had been sold at the Yunlin meat market and 57,843 pigs had been slaughtered at its facility.

Lee Mou-jen, vice manager of the Yunlin meat market, said the central government has stationed 14 veterinarians at the market to ensure that the pork processed by the market meets strict quality control standards.
Last week, two cases of foot-and-mouth disease that broke out at pig farms in Yunlin and Changhua counties in central Taiwan earlier this month were brought to light by the local media.

Huang Kuo-ching, deputy director of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Council of Agriculture (COA) , said Feb. 19 that 15 pigs in a small farm in Yunlin County were found Feb. 4 to have developed FMD symptoms. "All of the farm's 68 hogs were culled," he said.
Huang further pointed out that on Feb. 9, 23 pigs in a large-scale farm in neighboring Changhua County were also detected to have similar symptoms.

The remaining 609 pigs raised under the same roof as the pigs that fell ill were culled, while the 5,503 other pigs on the farm received anti-FMD shots to prevent the spread of the highly contagious viral disease, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public urged to help consume glut of Taichung County tangerines

TEXT.P: A member of the Taichung County Council urged the public Tuesday to help ease the tangerine glut in the county.

According to Chang Feng-sheng, an agriculture official with the Taichung County government, the county has 2,400 metric tons of tangerines stored in refrigerated warehouses.
Chang said that overproduction, the early arrival of the Lunar New Year holiday, and the economic downturn contributed to the tangerine glut.
Although the government has agreed to purchase some of the tangerines at a price of NT$6 per kilogram, the measure is not sufficient to relieve the farmers' plight, he said.
The caterers who serve lunches to Taichung County's elementary and junior middle schools pledged to use tangerines instead of other fruits as part of their meals.
Hsieh urged all consumers in the county to buy tangerines for themselves or to send to relatives and friends as a gift to help farmers survive during this period of excess supply.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president lashes out at prosecutors, politicians during hearing

TEXT.P: Ex-president Chen Shui-bian sent ripples through political circles in Taipei Tuesday by launching accusations at prominent politicians and prosecutors handling his case during a hearing in his trial on money laundering and corruption charges.

In his appearance at the Taipei District Court, the former president suggested that President Ma Ying-jeou is gay and that former President Lee Teng-hui received between NT$200 million (US$5.74 million) and NT$300 million (US$8.61 million) from Beijing.

He made the remarks during a one and a half hour defense, in which he also claimed that the eight prosecutors from the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office who led the probe into his case are politically biased against him.

In an apparent attempt to cast doubt on the prosecutors' integrity, the former president said one of the prosecutors, Chu Chao-liang, withheld evidence that shows that Lee Teng-hui received aid from Beijing.
He said Chu did not investigate Lee because he is a leader of the "pan-blue forces, " referring to the ruling Kuomintang and its political allies.

But Chu later responded that the evidence Chen referred to was provided by Chen himself while he was under investigation and was just part of a spate of legal complaints Chen filed with prosecutors against Lee Teng-hui.
Chu said prosecutors were looking into the evidence against Lee that Chen provided.

The former president also claimed that another prosecutor, Wu Wen-chung, prevented a woman from passing a disk to Frank Hsieh, the Democratic Progressive Party's 2008 presidential candidate, that recorded her former husband's intimate relations with then-KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou.

The woman, Chang Wei-jin, previously gained notoriety for lining up a meeting between Chen and Wu at the funeral of a Buddhist master in Miaoli that exposed Wu as having contact with an individual he was investigating.
Chen also alleged at the hearing that a third prosecutor, Yueh Fang-ju, asked him while he was still president to pardon a former Ma Ying-jeou aide.
The aide was sentenced to one year in prison for using the invoices of others to claim reimbursement from a fund set aside for Ma's use while he served as mayor of Taipei.

After Chen refused the prosecutor's request, which he said was relayed to him through DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, Chen said Yueh indicted five former ministers under the DPP administration for misappropriating public funds.
DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan backed up Chen's accusations against Yueh.
Cheng said Yueh asked Tsai to relay his request to Chen while questioning Tsai in March or April last year over her usage of a special fund during her term as vice premier.
Tsai conveyed Yueh's request to Chen in April that year, according to Cheng.
Chen Yun-nan, the director of the Special Investigation Division, denied, however, that Yueh asked Chen to pardon Ma's aide.
"As to the former president's claims about Wu Wen-chung, it has nothing to do with the case for which he is being tried, " Chen Yun-nan said.

Wu Wen-chung said he did dissuade Chang, who is a friend of both the former president and him, from making public the disk on the eve of the 2008 presidential election "because the competition was already chaotic enough."
He said, however, that he had no power to stop Chang from doing it and that he had never seen the alleged disk, nor did he have any idea whether its content was true or not.
The Presidential Office didn't respond to Chen's claims about President Ma Tuesday, but KMT legislative leader Chang Sho-wen dismissed Chen's claims as groundless.
"Chen should pursue a career as a script writer rather than a political figure," Chang said.

Lin Chih-jia, secretary-general of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, which consists of Lee's political followers and usually speaks for him, said his party was busy with helping people weather the current economic slump and would not dignify Chen's claims against Lee with a response.

Chen Shui-bian was indicted on Dec. 12, 2008 along with 13 family members and former aides for allegedly siphoning off NT$490 million (US$14.12 million) in public funds, and stashing part of them in overseas bank accounts.

He is the only one of the defendants being held in custody as prosecutors continued to probe alleged irregularities in the former president's handling of his government's second round of financial reform.

In a related development Tuesday, Government Information Minister Su Jun-pin said the Ministry of Justice is studying how to deal with Financial Times correspondent Robin Kwong, who interviewed Chen Shui-bian in his cell Feb. 18 without the approval of the detention center's authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Feb. 25, 2009

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: No timetable for signing economic pact with China: premier

TEXT.P: The government has not set a timetable for the signing of a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) with China, because this will depend partly on the progress of negotiations between the two sides, Premier Liu Chao- shiuan said Tuesday.
Liu said the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Mainland Affairs Council are currently trying to integrate their efforts to promote the agreement.
The premier made the remarks while fielding questions about the issue during an interpellation session in the Legislative Yuan.
Liu was also asked to comment on a claim by opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman Huang Kun-huei that China is working to unify with Taiwan by 2016.
Liu, however, said Taiwan has not set any such timetable and that he has no idea where Huang obtained that information.

The pro-independence TSU and Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) have strongly objected to the proposed Taiwan-China CECA, arguing that such an agreement would undermine Taiwan's sovereignty and pave the way for unification with China.

The DPP has unveiled a plan to stage nationwide demonstrations against the possible signing of the agreement, and the TSU has threatened to initiate a vote in the Legislative Yuan to recall President Ma Ying-jeou if the agreement is inked.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market fell Tuesday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for March declining 46 points to close at 4,381, with 83,683 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for April lost 47 points to finish at 4,333, with 249 contracts traded, while June futures fell 42 points to end at 4,266, with 52 contracts traded.
September futures fell 44 points to close at 4,067, with 46 contract transactions, while December futures lost 52 points to finish at 4,001, with 44 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 4,427 for March, 4,380 for April, 4,308 for June, 4,111 for September and 4,053 for December.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 47.6 points to finish at 4,430.18, on turnover of NT$56.47 billion (US$1.63 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.
March TE futures fell 2.3 points to close at 179.2, with 3,689 contracts traded, while April TE futures lost 2.2 points to finish at 177.7, with 28 contracts traded.
September TE futures lost 4 points to end at 165, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for June and December.
March TF futures were down 4.8 points to close at 467.2, with 5,050 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures fell 3 points to finish at 463, with 26 contracts traded.
September TF futures dropped 3 points to end at 447 points, with six contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for June and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier hints at resignation if stimulus package fails

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan hinted Tuesday that he would consider resigning if a special four-year NT$500 billion (US$14.45 billion) public works expansion package the Cabinet has proposed fails to pull Taiwan out of its current economic slump.

"If the project falls short of its target, I would acknowledge the failure and fully assume responsibility, " Liu said in answer to a question from an opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker on what the premier would do if Taiwan's economy contracts by more than 5 percent rather than the 2.97 percent forecast by the government.
He said he would know whether to stay on or step down.
Liu also said that the local economy's performance must be measured in comparison to other countries.
"A negative 5 percent economic growth rate might be a relatively good performance by that time," he suggested.

According to Liu, the four-year NT$500 billion special budget will help create 190,000 to 220,000 job opportunities in 2009 and push Taiwan's gross domestic product higher by 0.97 percent this year and 1.02 percent in 2010, 2011 and 2012.
"Taking the 0.97 percent into consideration, Taiwan's GDP will still contract by 2.97 percent in 2009," he asserted.

In its weekly meeting Feb. 12, the Executive Yuan approved the NT$500 billion budget to fund a stimulus package that it believes will help mitigate the impact of the global economic slowdown, and it now hopes the Legislative Yuan will pass it as soon as possible.

The package contains 20 prime investment projects and 64 plans to serve six major goals: to upgrade the transportation network, build a safe and anti- disaster environment, enhance cultural and living standards, strengthen national competitiveness and infrastructure, improve transport facilities on outlying islands, and foster high-end talent and stabilize the job market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Indigenous tribes to form united front for sovereignty over land

TEXT.P: Indigenous tribes around Taiwan will simultaneously light fires in their communities on Feb. 28, using the resulting "smoke signals" to send a message to the government that they are sovereign owners of their land, a spokesman for an indigenous rights group said Tuesday.

According to the Taitung County-based Smoke Motion Union, it will be the second time in a year that indigenous tribes, including the Pinuyumayan, Amis and Bunun, will act in unison to spread their message in the same way their ancestors once communicated with the sky and the spirit of the nature.

Last Feb. 28, dense smoke rose simultaneously from dozens of tribal villages around the island, conveying the angry voices of indigenous peoples over the government's ignorance of their natural hunting and fishing rights on their own land.

The campaign was formed after a group of Pinuyumayan hunters from the Katatipul tribe in Taitung City were obstructed by forest police from their annual sacred hunting ceremony in late 2007 in what they claimed was a rough and disrespectful manner.

The incident triggered protests by the Katatipul people, which then developed into a joint call among indigenous tribes around Taiwan for the government to respect their natural rights and indigenous sovereignty, said Mateli Sawawan, a spokesman for the Smoke Motion Union.
The call turned into a protest rally held by indigenous people from around the country in front of the Presidential Office on March 8, 2008.
The call, however, has never been properly answered since then, the union argued, which is why it is preparing a second round of protests on Feb. 28, the spokesman said.

Asked why the group chose that day, Mateli Sawawan explained that Feb. 28 is a day on which justice has been upheld after the government made a public apology for the 228 Incident, also known as the 228 Massacre, in 1947.
The incident was an anti-government, anti-Chinese uprising in Taiwan violently suppressed by the then-Kuomintang government.
In its Feb. 28 activity, the indigenous group will advocate forming a constitution of the Taiwan indigenous nation that stipulates it is equal with the Republic of China regime.

It will also promote the establishment of a nongovernment organization to handle incidents where it believes indigenous people have been mistreated by the Republic of China regime, according to the union.
Mateli Sawawan said the tribes that join the activity will also make public their separate calls for government action through the release of smoke.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung metro to grant free rides to jobless, underprivileged

TEXT.P: Jobless people and underprivileged students living in the southern port city of Kaohsiung and neighboring Kaohsiung County will soon be able to ride the city's metro for free, the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) announced Tuesday.

The KRTC said it has worked with China Steel Corp. to set aside a NT$30 million (US$862,468) fund to help relieve the financial burden of the unemployed and students of low-income families by allowing them to apply for a free stored value card worth 1,000 points -- enough for them to ride the city's metro system for about six months.

The KRTC will accept applications for the card from March 2 to May 31, and those applying must submit documents from local government departments certifying that they are currently receiving unemployment benefits or are students in low-income families.
The stored value cards will be valid for six months from their date of issue but will not be valid for use on city buses or Kaohsiung harbor ferry rides, according to KRTC officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police should use handcuffs more discriminately: Taipei County head

TEXT.P: Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei on Tuesday instructed the police force in his county to avoid the unnecessary use of handcuffs while enforcing the law.

Chou told a county government meeting that he regretted a recent incident in which police in Danshuei township arrested and handcuffed two Tamkang University coeds working part-time at a video and comic book store after discovering pornographic DVDs there.
"The use of handcuffs should be the exception, not the rule," Chou said at the meeting, attended by police chiefs.
Chou added that in the case of the arrest of the two coeds, the use of handcuffs by the police was unnecessary because there was no danger that the coeds would attempt to escape.
The handcuffing of the two university students followed another incident in Taichung County in which police handcuffed a woman whom they arrested for picking two flowers from the side of a road.
Media reports were critical of the police in both incidents for unnecessarily intimidating and humiliating offenders.

The Taipei County magistrate acknowledged that handcuffing is sometimes necessary for legitimate security reasons, but stressed that any restraint of suspects' movements when they are arrested must be commensurate with their offenses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gambling fever sends Penghu land prices soaring

TEXT.P: The price of land in Houliao in the island county of Penghu has soared since Taiwan's legislature legalized gambling on Taiwan held islands Jan. 12, local sources said Tuesday.

Sung Sen-hu, a tour business operator in Penghu, told the Central News Agency that land in Houliao has attracted considerable interest since the county government designated the small village -- about 20 kilometers north of Penghu's capital city of Makong -- as the main location for casino-oriented tourism.
Sung said the price of land along main roads has risen the most, rising from NT$12,000 (US$346) per ping to between NT$30,000 and NT$40,000. One ping equals 3.3057 square meters.
"The price tripled in less than one and a half months, " he said.

On Tuesday, the government of the island county that lies off Taiwan's southwestern coast held a presentation in Houliao to lobby local residents for support of its plan to have international gaming operators build luxurious resorts with casinos in the village.

The 150 villagers attending the event seemed to welcome the plan, and some confirmed that land speculation is on the rise. Recent records on farming land transactions showed the price has risen to between NT$5,000 and NT$6,000 per ping.

Although the legislature passed a law legalizing the operation of casinos on Taiwan-held islands in January, any move to promote the construction of casinos on the islands must be approved by island residents in a referendum.
The Penghu County government has been holding forums to sell the idea, but groups opposing the proposal are also making their voices heard.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Israel ties will remain unchanged: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) expressed confidence Tuesday that the cordial relations between Taiwan and Israel will remain unchanged given that a majority of the Israeli parliamentarians friendly toward Taiwan were re-elected in a recent general election.

Speaking in a press briefing, Antonio Chen, director-general of MOFA's Department of West Asian Affairs, said that 23 members of the Taiwan Friendship Group of the Israeli Parliament continue to hold their seats in the Knesset after the Feb. 10 election.
Eighty percent of the parliamentarians in the friendship group won re-election, Chen said, and as a result, support for Taiwan in the Middle Eastern country's parliament will continue to be strong.

DOC.HEADLINE: MNF to investigate abandoned tombs discovered in Papua New Guinea: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MNF) will send experts later this week to investigate abandoned tombs accidentally discovered in the deep jungles of Papua New Guinea that belonged to Republic of China soldiers, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.

While the MNF is the authority in charge of the handling of the issue, the ministrys representative office in the Pacific country will provide assistance on the side, said Frances Lee, deputy director-general of the MOFA's East Asian and Pacific Affairs, in a press briefing.
She said a plan to visit the tombs at the end of January was disrupted due to a volcanic eruption there which caused the local airport to be shut down.

According to a local media report in December, three deserted tombs were discovered near the Papua New Guinea city of Rabaul, with one of them unrecognizable and the rest identified as belonging to R.O.C. Army Captain Wu Kun and Sergeant First Class Kung Hsien-chang, who died in 1945.

During World War II, over 1,600 R.O.C. soldiers seized by the Japanese army were sent by the Japanese government to the South Pacific region to work as slaves. Around 650 died there and never got to return home, according to the report. The remaining estimated 1,000 others were sent back to China by the United States after the Japanese were defeated in the war.

Indigenous people from Taiwan were also forced by the Japanese army to go to the South Pacific to work as soldiers during the war. Efforts by well-known aborigines to seek redress on behalf of the victims have not been successful.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rents to be halved in Pingtung agricultural park

TEXT.P: The government plans to halve rental and management fees charged companies operating in the Pingtung Agricultural Biotechnology Park to help them ride out the current economic slump, Vice President Vincent Siew said Tuesday during a visit to the park.

Speaking at a meeting with representatives from park businesses, Siew said agriculture is one of Taiwan's promising economic sectors and one the country should count on to develop and expand both domestic demand and exports.

He said that by creating value through innovation and biotechnology, the park is expected to take the leading role in the agricultural sector over the next 10 years, just as the Hsinchu Science Park drove growth in the science and technology sector in the years following its launch.

During the meeting, park businesses suggested that rents on land, factory buildings and dormitories as well as management fees in the park be cut in half for the next three years, and Siew asked Council of Agriculture Deputy Minister Hu Hsing-hua to respond.
Hu said the Executive Yuan has already approved a plan to halve the park's rental and management fees this year and that it would be reviewed at the end of 2009.

Responding to others suggestions, Siew said he will direct relevant government agencies to study the possibility of establishing a valuation mechanism to allow developed technologies to be valued as assets, helping the companies get greater access to financing.
Hu added that the COA will ask the Agricultural Bank of Taiwan to provide loans at preferential interest rates for firms operating in the park.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should never forget the 228 incident: President Ma

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that Taiwan's people should never forget the 228 Incident and promised that his administration will continue to contribute to the search for the historical truth of the tragedy.

Speaking at the Lunar New Year Reception of the Taipei 228 Incident Association held in Taipei, Ma expressed his sympathy for victims of the incident and promised to step up efforts to promote reconciliation and harmony in Taiwanese society.

Ma said the government and the people should learn from past mistakes and that the events that occurred during the 228 Incident should be emphasized in school textbooks to prevent future generations from allowing similar tragic events to occur.
"We can forgive what people have done in the past, but we can never forget what happened," Ma said.

The president promised that the government will continue to provide financial assitance to the 228 Memorial Foundation through the Ministry of Education and will establish the legal foundation for the construction of the National Taiwan 228 Museum as soon as possible.

Meanwhile, the founder of the Taipei 228 Incident Association, Liao Ji-bin, said that Ma has demonstrated sincerity in promoting reconciliation of the chasms among people caused by the incident since he became mayor of Taipei in 1998.
"I have no doubt in my mindtthat Ma will do even more for the family members of the 228 Incident now that he is president of the nation," Liao said.
He urged politicians, however, to stop manipulating the tragedy in order to monopolize the issue in a bid to win more votes in every major election.

The 228 Incident refers broadly to an uprising beginning at the end of February 1947 that culminated in the killing of tens of thousands of dissidents, elites, and others in Taiwan by Chinese Nationalist troops.
An estimated 10,000 to 30,000 people were killed during the Incident and in ensuing violent crackdowns by the KMT administration in March and April 1947.

The Presidential Office didn't respond to Chen's claims about President Ma Tuesday, but KMT legislative leader Chang Sho-wen dismissed Chen's claims as groundless.
"Chen should pursue a career as a script writer rather than a political figure," Chang said.

Lin Chih-jia, secretary-general of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, which consists of Lee's political followers and usually speaks for him, said his party was busy with helping people weather the current economic slump and would not dignify Chen's claims against Lee with a response.

Chen Shui-bian was indicted on Dec. 12, 2008 along with 13 family members and former aides for allegedly siphoning off NT$490 million (US$14.12 million) in public funds, and stashing part of them in overseas bank accounts.

He is the only one of the defendants being held in custody as prosecutors continued to probe alleged irregularities in the former president's handling of his government's second round of financial reform.

In a related development Tuesday, Government Information Minister Su Jun-pin said the Ministry of Justice is studying how to deal with Financial Times correspondent Robin Kwong, who interviewed Chen Shui-bian in his cell Feb. 18 without the approval of the detention center's authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH on guard against measles outbreak

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) is monitoring the conditions of individuals who have had contact with a child who was infected with the measles after traveling to China, a DOH official said Tuesday.

Chou Jih-haw, deputy director of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control, said that although no one has been infected after coming into contact with the baby boy, the DOH will not let down its guard until mid-March.
The 15-month-old baby boy who lives in central Taiwan, caught the measles while he was hospitalized for diarrhea while traveling with his mother in Hunan, China, Chou said.
He returned to Taiwan Feb. 5, and developed a bad fever the following day. He was diagnosed as having the measles and stayed in the hospital for six days.

Chou noted that since December, there have been four imported measles cases, adding that recently a baby girl was found to have contracted measles after returning to Taiwan, and a baby boy in the same ward was infected, while five others are suspected of being infected.
Taipei and Taoyuan counties are now tracing those who have had contact with the baby girl and vaccinated those children who had yet to receive measles shots.

Chou noted that the outbreak of measles in China over the past three years have become more serious, with the number rising from 100,000 to 130,000 over that time. Some 4,600 people have been infected with the disease in China since January.
"Those who travel to China with their young children should be on high alert," Chou warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: Locally produced pork safe: Yunlin County

TEXT.P: The Yunlin County government and its meat market co-sponsored a fair Tuesday, inviting the public to taste dishes prepared with locally produced pork to dispel fears over pork safety prompted by reports that foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) hit a local pig farm recently.

Lu Cheng-chang, head of the county's agricultural affairs bureau, urged Taiwan's consumers not to worry about consuming pork produced in the county, as local authorities will closely scrutinize the production process to guarantee quality.
The meat from the Yunlin pork market, Taiwan's largest, is distributed to over 150 distribution points around the country.

Last year, the market's slaughterhouse culled 402,378 pigs and auctioned 607,271 pigs. As of Feb. 21 this year, 93,443 pigs had been sold at the Yunlin meat market and 57,843 pigs had been slaughtered at its facility.

Lee Mou-jen, vice manager of the Yunlin meat market, said the central government has stationed 14 veterinarians at the market to ensure that the pork processed by the market meets strict quality control standards.
Last week, two cases of foot-and-mouth disease that broke out at pig farms in Yunlin and Changhua counties in central Taiwan earlier this month were brought to light by the local media.

Huang Kuo-ching, deputy director of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Council of Agriculture (COA) , said Feb. 19 that 15 pigs in a small farm in Yunlin County were found Feb. 4 to have developed FMD symptoms. "All of the farm's 68 hogs were culled," he said.
Huang further pointed out that on Feb. 9, 23 pigs in a large-scale farm in neighboring Changhua County were also detected to have similar symptoms.

The remaining 609 pigs raised under the same roof as the pigs that fell ill were culled, while the 5,503 other pigs on the farm received anti-FMD shots to prevent the spread of the highly contagious viral disease, he added.
Adjacent areas within a 3-kilometer radius of the two farms, are all being closely monitored.

Taiwan used to raise as many as 12 million pigs per year at the industry's peak, with 7 million exported to Japan annually, according to COA statistics. Taiwan now raises only about 6.4 million pigs a year, mainly for local consumption.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 25, or the first day of the second month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1901: John P. Morgan, one of the greatest financiers in the United States, founds the United States Steel Corp.
1913: The U.S. Congress passes the 16th amendment to the Constitution, paving the way for an income tax levying system.
1950: Members of the Control Yuan, the highest watchdog body of the Republic of China, file a proposal to impeach acting President Lee Tsung-jen.
1956: Nikita Khrushchev, secretary-general of the Soviet Union Communist Party, slams former Soviet Union leader Joseph Stalin at a party meeting.
1957: The Japanese Cabinet of Nobusuke Kishi is formed.
1981: Chuan Doo Huan is elected president of the South Korea.
1986: Corazon Aquino replaces Ferdinand E. Marcos as president of the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: International orchid show slated to open March 6

TEXT.P: The Taiwan International Orchid Show and Conference 2009, slated to open March 6 in Tainan County, is likely to outdraw last year's show despite the floundering global economy, the Tainan County government said Wednesday.

As of Feb. 24, buyers from 29 countries have registered to visit the show, more than the 24 countries represented at the 2008 show, which generated NT$2.4 billion (US$77.67 million) in orders, the Tainan County Department of Agriculture said.
Of the foreign groups, Thailand's contingent of more than 100 buyers will be the largest, department officials said.

An international symposium on orchid cultivation will also be held on the first day of the event, which will run from March 6-16 and is being co-sponsored by the Taiwan Orchid Growers Association based in Tainan County's Houbi Township.

Kuo Yi-ping, director of the department, said this year's show is even bigger than last year's -- which attracted 2,000 foreign visitors -- with the exhibition space expanded by 3,300 square feet, and a vast orchid nursery added as an exhibition venue.

Aside from Thailand, most foreign buyers attending this year's show will be coming from the United States, Japan and Europe. Other buyers from Latin American countries and territories, such as Ecuador and Puerto Rico, will be visiting Taiwan for the first time, Kuo said.

Orchids are one of Taiwan's major exports, accounting for over 50 percent of the total value of the country's horticultural exports, with the show playing an important role in Taiwan's increasing orchid exports each year.
Taiwan is known as the "Kingdom of the Butterfly Orchid" because it is the world's largest exporter of the flower. About half the world's butterfly orchid varieties are bred in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Lu knocks off Hewitt, shows form ahead of Davis Cup

TEXT.P: Seeded in an ATP Tour event for only the second time in his career, Taiwan's Lu Yen-hsun lived up to the billing by knocking out a big name.

Lu, seeded eighth in the 32-player draw, overcame Australia's Lleyton Hewitt 7-5, 2-6, 6-2 Tuesday to advance to the second round of the Delray Beach International Tennis Championships in southern Florida.

The victory deprived Hewitt, who turned 28 Tuesday, of a planned on-court birthday celebration after the match and marked Lu's continuing run of good form that has seen him defeat Andy Murray at last August's Beijing Olympics and world No. 11 David Nalbandian at the Australian Open in January.
Last seeded in an ATP Tour in Chennai, India in 2005, the world No. 59 Taiwanese appeared to have been hit with an unfavorable draw this week.

Although Hewitt has fallen out of the top 100 after having hip surgery in August, he reached the semifinals of a tournament in Memphis last week before losing to Andy Roddick in three sets and seemed on the road to recovering his place among the world's elite players.
"I never thought I would win today, " Lu acknowledged after the match, saying he handled the wind blowing in from the nearby Atlantic Ocean better than the Australian.
After losing the tightly contested first set on a double fault, Hewitt threw Lu off by playing more defensively and relying heavily on a slice backhand in the second set.

"I was in too much of a hurry to attack, and that led to a lot of unforced errors, " Lu said. He quickly rebounded, however, breaking Hewitt three times in the third set and running off its last three games to clinch the match.
Lu will next face 32-year-old Austrian Stefan Koubek, who won the event in 2000 when he was ranked as high as 20th in the world but has since fallen out of the top 200.
With Taiwan's next Davis Cup tie set for March 6-8 against India in Kaohsiung, Lu's good form is well timed.

Lu missed the Davis Cup tie against Kazakhstan earlier this month with a bad knee, but Wang Yeu-tzuoo, who was sidelined for much of 2008 with a wrist injury, filled in admirably, winning both of his singles matches in Taiwan's 4-1 victory.

The pain in Wang's wrist resurfaced after the two matches, however, and after consulting with doctors, Wang decided to have surgery Feb. 26 to repair ligament damage that will keep him out of action for at least five months.

Without Wang, it will be up to Lu and Chen Ti in singles, and probably Yang Tsung-hua and Yi Chu-huan in doubles, to take on an Indian team featuring Leander Paes and Mahesh Bhupathi, both ranked in the world's top 10 in doubles, and Somdey Dewarman and Rohan Bopanna.
A victory would put Taiwan one win away -- probably against Australia and Lleyton Hewitt in mid-July -- from reaching the World Group playoffs for the first time in history.

The March 6-8 tie will be played at Kaohsiung's Yang Ming Tennis Center, and Taiwan's tennis association is taking the unprecedented step of charging admission. A one-day pass will cost NT$400 and a pass for all three days will be NT$1,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen wants access to Chinese tap water

TEXT.P: Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng urged the Cabinet Wednesday to allow the outlying island to introduce tap water from China to solve its water shortage problem.
The method would also provide an alternative to local water resources, which have long been criticized for their poor quality, Lee said.

Lee made the call while presiding over the inauguration of one of several facilities installed by the Kinmen County Waterworks to remove iron and manganese from potable water in Kinmen and improve its quality.

He raised the issue ahead of a planned Council for Economic Planning and Development meeting next week to discuss the matter and review an assessment of the feasibility of introducing tap water from China to Kinmen completed by the Water Resources Agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs on Jan. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: President praises late peasant movement leader for selfless love

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Wednesday praised Chien Chi, who led peasant movements in 1926 during the Japanese colonial era and after the 228 Incident in 1947, for his selflessness in helping exploited farmers.

"Chien's selfless love and devotion to Taiwan by choosing to stand with helpless peasants is the main reason why he is remembered, " Ma said at the opening ceremony of an exhibition titled "Taiwan Agriculturist Movement -- Revolutionist Chien Chi" being held at the National Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall.
Chien established the "Taiwanese Federation of Farmers' Unions" in 1926 to counter the exploitation of local farmers by Japan, which colonized Taiwan from 1895-1945.
After the 228 Incident occurred in 1947, Chien formed the "self-governing allied forces" to fight against the then ruling Kuomintang (KMT) troops. He was arrested and sentenced to death in 1950.

The 228 Incident refers to an uprising that began on Feb. 28, 1947, and resulted in a brutal crackdown by Kuomintang (KMT) troops in March and April of that year led to the deaths of as many as 30,000 people.
Many other innocent people, including many elite members of society, were blacklisted and suffered victimization.
"By thrusting himself to fight against injustice in society, Chien showed extraordinary passion and courage," Ma said.

Speaking at the same occasion, Chien Ming-ren, Chien's youngest son and president of the CGCH Foundation For Education, said that Ma's attendance at the event showed the government's respect for the people and regret over the 228 Incident.

"Only by unearthing the historical truth and restoring the historical status and clearing the names of those who sacrificed for the country and people can we soothe the pain of the past and march toward a peaceful future," he said.

People today might not understand the feeling of living under fear, but the happiness that people enjoy now was the result of efforts made by those who fought the authortarian regime years ago, he said.

The exhibition, which is being organized by the National Cultural Association, the National Dr. Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall, and the CGCH Foundation For Education, will run from Feb. 25 to March 5 and feature photographs of Chien Chi and Taiwan's agricultural movements.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT seeks act incriminating holders of assets with unknown source

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) Clean Government Committee (CGC) is pushing for the early enactment of an amendment to the Anti-Corruption Act that would incriminate public office holders holding assets whose sources cannot be identified.

The CGC resolved Tuesday to invite Lin Yi-shih, the executive director of the KMT's Central Policy Committee, to brief the KMT anti-corruption committee in March on the progress made in pushing the amendment through the Legislative Yuan.
Lin said he hopes the amendment can be passed in this legislative session so that it can quickly take effect.
At Tuesday's meeting, CGC member Wu Tung-ming proposed that the KMT put more pressure on the legislature to get the amendment passed as soon as possible.

Noting that the measure has been pending in the legislature for years, Wu said the corruption and money-laundering scandal involving former President Chen Shui-bian and his family could probably have been avoided if such a statute were in place years ago.
The amendment would hold public officials criminally liable if they could not identify the sources of or account for dubious assets in their possession.

The former first family has been indicted by prosecutors on charges of embezzling or taking bribes worth a total of nearly NT$500 million, with the sources of some the family's financial holdings still being questioned.
Chen and his wife contend the funds were all political contributions to finance his election campaigns.
