DOC.HEADLINE: Unemployment situation worse than realized: DPP

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) warned Wednesday that the unemployment situation in Taiwan may be worse than most people realize, with the actual number of people out of work more than double the official figure.

According to DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang, the results of a recent survey conducted by the DPP showed that the country's unemployment rate stands at 9.47 percent, with the number of jobless workers totalling 1.25 million.

The figures are significantly higher than the latest data released Jan. 22 by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) , which revealed that the unemployment rate was 5.03 percent in December, with 549,000 people out of work then, Cheng said.

The DPP survey, which was carried out Feb. 17-18 among 1,238 people, adopted the same criteria as the DGBAS to define "unemployed, " namely the respondents were out of work, looking for jobs and ready to assume employment immediately, he said.
The survey found that half of the unemployed respondents lost their jobs involuntarily.
It is estimated that 590,000 people were laid off by their employers and another 130,000 first-time job seekers failed to land a job, while 520,000 gave up their jobs voluntarily, Cheng said.
Among those who still hold a job, 10 percent have had a pay cut, and 4.7 percent have been forced to take unpaid leave.

The results of another DPP survey conducted Feb. 17-18 among 1,140 adults revealed that 63.3 percent of those who are jobless do not think the government's measures will help solve the worsening unemployment problem.

Slightly more than 74 percent of the respondents said they believe the government's economic policy emphasizes only short-term effects, while 72.9 percent disagreed with President Ma Ying-jeou's prediction that the economy will begin to improve in the second quarter of this year.

Also Wednesday, Wu Jui-ying, operations manager of the online employment broker 1111 Job Bank, said 350,000 people are currently looking for jobs through the job bank, but there are only 150,000 openings up for grabs.
Wu predicted that the unemployment situation will worsen in June, when 300,000 fresh college graduates are expected to enter the job market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shares higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Wednesday, with the Taiwan stock exchange's weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 63.56 points, or 1.43 percent, to close at 4,493.74.

Buoyed by gains on Wall Street overnight, the local bourse opened higher at 4,498.91 and fluctuated between 4,549.32 and 4,488.07. A total of 3.58 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$71.13 billion (US$2.05 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most 4.3 percent. Plastics and chemicals shares rose 1.3 percent, textile stocks and construction issues both gained 1.2 percent, machinery and electronics shares and paper and pulp issues both advanced 1.1 percent, and cement stocks were up 0.5 percent.
Foodstuff issues lost ground, decreasing 1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,155 to 483, with 191 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$343 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sale proceeds from book written by Penghu inmates go to charity

TEXT.P: The proceeds from the sale of a book written by inmates on Taiwan's outlying island of Penghu were donated to two charitable organizations Wednesday, according to a source from Penghu's Tingwan Prison.

A total of NT$100,000 (US$2,882) was donated in two equal parts to the Penghu Catholic St. Camillus Opportunity Center and the Penghu branch of the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families at a ceremony held at the Tingwan Prison.

At the ceremony, prison warden Chan Che-feng said he is proud that the new book, titled Penghu's Literary Accounts, has been selling like hot cakes since it was published last December and it has raised NT$120,000 in that short time.
After deducting NT$20,000 for payment to the book's writers, the prison was pleased to donate the remaining NT$100,000 to the two charitable organizations, Chan said.
The Penghu prison began a writing class in 1997 and so far 13 books written collectively by inmates of the prison have been printed, Chan added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Breeding station helping keep local paradise fish species alive

TEXT.P: The paradise fish -- a small freshwater fish once commonly found in rivers and creeks around Taiwan -- is nearly extinct in the wild in Taiwan, but one fish breeding station has been successfully breeding the species in captivity.

Lin Hung-kuei, the director of Hualien County's Fish Breeding Propagation Station, said that pollution and competitive immigrant fish have driven the native fish from their natural breeding places and have made it nearly impossible to reintroduce it to the wild and replenish its stocks.

After the fish was designated by the government as a protected species in August 1990, however, the station began studying ways to help revive it and has successfully breeded the fish in controlled environments and preserved the species of the fish endemic to Taiwan.
The station's breeding technique is now being passed on to schools for use as an educational tool in their experimental ponds, Lin said.
Paradise fish (Macropodus opercularis) are approximately 6 centimeters in length and live in shallow freshwater environments where the water flow is gentle and slow.

According to the fish breeding propagation station, although they are rarely seen in the wild, paradise fish with their green-blue and light red stripes are popular in the aquatic species market for display in private fish tanks.
Lin said that most of the paradise fish traded in the market are bred artificially, while some are imported from Malaysia.

Apart from being appreciated for its appearance, the fish can also be used to eradicate mosquitoes because it eats mosquito larva. According to Lin, a paradise fish can swallow over 300 larvae in a day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan extends period of temporary stay for HK, Macau citizens

TEXT.P: Citizens of Hong Kong and Macau can now stay up to 30 days on each entry to Taiwan, under a new regulation that took effect Wednesday, the National Immigration Agency (NIA) said.

Beginning Feb. 25, Hong Kong and Macau citizens are being permitted to remain for a maximum of 30 days instead of 14, as was previously stipulated, whenever they enter Taiwan for temporary visits, NIA officials said.

NIA officials said the new regulation was implemented mainly to allow victims of cross-Taiwan Strait human smuggling crimes to remain in Taiwan for longer periods to facilitate investigations into such cases.
The new regulation was also introduced to allow visiting residents of Hong Kong and Macau to engage in religious activities, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yunlin farmers to target Northeast Asia market with Japan trip

TEXT.P: Yunlin County Deputy Magistrate Lee Ying-yuan announced Wednesday that he will lead a group of local farmers to Japan next month to promote the county's farm produce and hopefully chalk up more than NT$100 million (US$2.97 million) in business deals.

Speaking at a news conference held at the county headquarters, where some of the county's farm products were also displayed, Lee said he hopes the trip will pave the way for locally produced goods to break into Northeast Asian markets, apart from the Chinese and Southeast Asian markets.

Lu Cheng-chang, director of the county's agricultural affairs, said a Yunlin delegation will depart for Japan on March 3 and will take part in the 34th Food and Beverage Exhibition in Tokyo that will kick off on the same day and last through March 6.
The delegation will exhibit farm and fishery produce cultivated in the county to the Japanese public.

As part of its efforts to push local farm produce to go international, Yunlin County has been actively organizing promotion tours to various countries since last year. It sent a delegation to Singapore in December, one to China's Fujian Province in September, as well as one to Beijing in July and one to Macau in April.
Since the county launched the promotion campaign last year, locally produced soy sauce, duck meat as well as vegetables and fruits have been exported to various countries and regions.
The agriculture-based Yunlin County in southern Taiwan produces mainly fruits and vegetables.

DOC.HEADLINE: Anti-unemployment measures to show results in three months: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan expressed confidence Wednesday that the measures introduced by the government to combat unemployment will produce better results in the coming two or three months.
Liu pledged that the government will work to control this year's unemployment situation "within acceptable limits."

Taiwan's unemployment rate soared to 5.03 percent in December 2008, hitting the highest level since October 2003 and marking the first time in five years that the monthly jobless rate topped 5 percent. The average unemployment rate for 2008 was 4.14 percent, which represented a four-year high.
The premier addressed the issue during a meeting with personnel officials, in which he urged government employees to do their jobs to the best of their ability so as to put themselves over the top.

Liu said the government may be a bit optimistic by forecasting that Taiwan's gross domestic product will shrink only by 2.97 percent this year, but he stressed the forecast is not based on "blind optimism."

Liu said he is confident in the government's ability to get things done, pointing to the growth in government investment in the fourth quarter of last year and the fact that as many as 53 percent of the government's stimulus package to boost domestic demand have been implemented over the past five months.

He argued that the recent decrease in bank lending does not mean a failure of the government's policy to encourage banks to provide financing boldly to healthy businesses, but reflects a fall in demand.
For example, he said, Taiwan's export volume has decreased by NT$200 billion due to a contraction in global market demand.
At present, the government's most urgent tasks are to look for new export markets and stimulate investment and exports, Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Central Taiwan's surplus tangerines to be turned into compost

TEXT.P: The government began to purchase surplus ponkan tangerines from farmers in Taichung County's Dongshih township Wednesday and turn them into compost in an attempt to stabilize the market for the fruit.

Officials from the Agriculture and Food Agency under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture said they will buy 500 metric tons of second-grade ponkan tangerines at NT$6 per kilogram before March 6 and send the fruit to another Taichung County township, Wufeng, to have it processed into green fertilizer.
Dongshih township head Yeh Yu-chin said it pained him to see the fruits of the farmers' year of labor being carried away by the truckload, knowing they will be scrapped.

An elderly woman among the onlookers kept sighing and calling it "such a waste." She said there was nothing wrong with the tangerines, which were sweet and succulent, except that they were only a bit smaller than top grade fruit.

According to Taichung County agriculture officials, the county still has 2,400 metric tons of tangerines stored in refrigerated warehouses. They attributed the glut to overproduction, the early arrival of the Lunar New Year holiday, and the ongoing economic downturn.
Dongshih ponkan tangerines are one of the most famous fruits in Taiwan. They are sweet, fragrant and succulent and full of vitamins A and C.

The fruit is harvested from late September to late December and can be stored for several months. Farmers usually sell a portion of their harvest on the market while keeping the rest wrapped in individual plastic bags and stored in refrigerated warehouses until January or March of the following year to fetch better prices.

Local agriculture officials, who fear that the central government's bulk purchase is not enough to relieve the farmers' plight, have launched a campaign to call on the public to consume more tangerines to ease the glut and help the farmers.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA promises to review policy on PVC use
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb.25 (CNA) 02/25/09 19:34:49 (EPA) pledged Wednesday to review the use of polyvinyl chloride (PVC) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration in manufacturing and packaging applications because of environmental concerns.

The agency was responding to calls by environmental groups to ban the widely used plastic in food packaging and medical accessories because of its detrimental effect on the environment throughout its life cycle, from production to disposal.

Hsieh Ho-lin, secretary-general of the Taiwan Watch Institute, a private group dedicated to protecting Taiwan's natural environment, said the plasticizing and stabilizing agents in PVC -- such as DEHP, DOP, cadmium and lead -- may harm people's kidneys or reproductive systems or lower their intelligence.
Those toxic substances can be released from PVC articles not just at high temperatures but also at normal room temperatures, Hsieh said.

He therefore urged the government to immediately ban the use of PVC in food packaging, phase out PVC water pipes and bar the recycling of PVC waste in incinerators to reduce the accumulation of dioxin in the environment.
Other environmental groups also urged the government to ban the use of the widely used plastic in medical accessories, such as blood bags and gloves.

Addressing the appeals, Ho Shun-chin, director-general of the EPA's Solid Waste Management Bureau, said the EPA had canvassed the opinion of medical professionals and found they opposed a ban of the material in the medical field because of the lack of readily available substitute materials.

As to the use of PVC in water piping for construction applications, Ho said PVC remains the optimal material because of its good ductability and suggested that a ban on its use in piping also might not be feasible.
As for food packaging, Ho said the EPA will conduct an overall review and seriously evaluate the possibility of prohibiting PVC use in food packaging and the production of food containers.
At present, Ho said, the EPA collects higher recycling fees from manufacturers of PVC containers than from those making non-PVC products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourism head arrives in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Shao Qiwei, director of China's National Tourism Administration, arrived Wednesday in Taiwan for a visit at the head of a delegation of tour industry representatives.
It is Shao's third visit to Taiwan to try to expand cross-Taiwan Strait tourism in the wake of an agreement last year between the two sides on a less restrictive tourism policy.

The full delegation, the largest of its kind to ever visit Taiwan, will be composed of tourism officials and travel industry representatives from China's 30 major provinces, who were scheduled to arrive in Taiwan in various groups starting from Wednesday.

The top Chinese tourism official was warmly greeted by Taiwan's Tourism Bureau Deputy Director-General David W. J. Hsieh and Taiwan Visitors Association Chairman S. L. Chang, upon arrival at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport on the outskirts of Taipei.

Consequently, some of the patients, including 10 percent to 30 percent of diabetic patients, have to undergo limb amputation, he added.
Wang explained that some of the bacteria that cause bedsores have already developed resistance to antibiotics, which makes it difficult to heal the lesions.
He disclosed that NCK University Hospital plans to offer a special treatment program in March for chronic lesions in the hope of increasing the healing rate.

The Taiwanese skipper accused the Japanese patrol of deliberately ramming his boat and demanded that Japan compensate him for the damage to his vessel.
The incident touched a nerve in the sensitive sovereignty issue, as the Tiaoyutai Islands in the East China Sea are claimed by Taiwan, China, and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Manufacturing sectors' sales volume fell 2.46% in 2008: ministry

TEXT.P: The sales volume of Taiwan's manufacturing sector shrank to NT$2.36 trillion (US$67.9 billion) in the fourth quarter of 2008, marking a year-on-year drop of 29.39 percent due to the worldwide economic downturn, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Wednesday.
In the Q4, domestic sales fell 30.67 percent from the same period the previous year to NT$1.14 trillion, while export sales dropped 28.15 percent to NT$1.22 trillion.
The accumulated sales volume of the country's manufacturing sector fell to NT$12.06 trillion in 2008, marking a year-on-year decline of 2.46 percent, the MOEA statistics showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: ICP11 mimic protein might be anti-cancer drug: Taiwan scientists

TEXT.P: A DNA mimic protein discovered by Taiwan scientists in their research into a disease in crustaceans a year ago holds the potential for the development of a cancer treatment, leaders of the research team said Wednesday.

Lo Chu-fang, dean of the College of Life Science of National Taiwan University, and Andrew H.-J. Wang, research fellow and vice president of Academia Sinica, told reporters that their nine-member team discovered ICP11 -- the most highly expressed nonstructural gene of the white spot syndrome virus -- when they tried to find the cause of a disease that was affecting crustaceans worldwide.
The research results were published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America in April 2008.
Lo and Wang said the research team has found that ICP11, one of a handful of presently known "mimic proteins," has the ability to destroy cells, leading to their programmed demise.
Lo said because of this particular function, the DNA mimic holds great potential for cancer treatment.

He said more research is needed to study the effect of ICP11 on cancer cells in clinical experiments, and if the mimic protein is as good as the researchers believe it is, the world will have a new approach to cancer treatment.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-Poland engagement does not violate 'one China' principle: Ma

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that engagements between Poland and the Republic of China are not in violation of the "one China" principle because it is upheld by both sides of the Taiwan Strait, despite their divergence over its definition.
Ma made the remarks during a meeting with Stefan Niesiolowski, deputy speaker of the lower house of the Polish parliament.

During the meeting, Ma conferred the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on Niesiolowski in recognition of his outstanding contribution to the promotion of friendship and cooperation between the two countries over the past years.

Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties, relations between Taiwan and Poland have been growing stronger since Taiwan opened a representative office in Warsaw in 1992 and Poland reciprocated in 1995.

Although Poland formally recognizes China, its engagement with Taiwan does not violate Beijing's "one China" principle since Taiwan's Constitution is also based on the "one China" framework, Ma explained, adding that Taiwan's "one China" refers to the Republic of China.

Ma further said that since his inauguration last May, his administration has been promoting pragmatic diplomacy, an approach it has been using to maintain close ties with its diplomatic allies, while at the same time improving relations with China.
"Our pragmatic efforts have won wide recognition in the international community as evidenced by the improvement in our relations with the European Union, " Ma said.
Britain's recent decision to grant Taiwanese tourists visa-free treatment for stays of up to six months is a good example of the progress achieved, he added.
If more EU countries follow suit, Ma said, civilian exchanges between Taiwan and EU member states will definitely increase in the future.
On Taiwan-Poland ties, Ma said he looks forward to continued expansion of bilateral exchanges in the fields of tourism, trade, culture and education.

For his part, Niesiolowski said Taiwan and Poland have had similar experiences in the development of democracy. Saying that he admires Taiwan's success in democratization and economic development, the Polish lawmaker added that he believes that with perseverance and ingenuity, Taiwan will be able to ride out the current economic storm.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tibetans in Taiwan hold vigil to mark Losar

TEXT.P: Tibetan expatriates and their friends in Taiwan held a vigil at Liberty Square in downtown Taipei Wednesday to commemorate the Tibetans who were killed in last year's demonstrations against Chinese authorities.
The vigil coincided with Tibetan New Year, known as Losar, which falls on Feb. 25 this year.

Losar is one of the most important Tibetan festivals. Tibetans in China launched a campaign to hold vigils for those who were killed during a series of protests against China last year and for those who have been jailed in China for their participation in those activities.
Tibetan exiles, including those in Taiwan, responded to the call by their compatriots in China by holding vigils in the countries where they live.
About 70 people took part in the Taipei vigil. Led by Tibetan lamas, the participants recited Tibetan Buddhist scriptures to commemorate Tibetans who have died for seeking freedom.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yunlin farmers to target Northeast Asia market with Japan trip

TEXT.P: Yunlin County Deputy Magistrate Lee Ying-yuan announced Wednesday that he will lead a group of local farmers to Japan next month to promote the county's farm produce and hopefully chalk up more than NT$100 million (US$2.97 million) in business deals.

Speaking at a news conference held at the county headquarters, where some of the county's farm products were also displayed, Lee said he hopes the trip will pave the way for locally produced goods to break into Northeast Asian markets, apart from the Chinese and Southeast Asian markets.

Lu Cheng-chang, director of the county's agricultural affairs, said a Yunlin delegation will depart for Japan on March 3 and will take part in the 34th Food and Beverage Exhibition in Tokyo that will kick off on the same day and last through March 6.
The delegation will exhibit farm and fishery produce cultivated in the county to the Japanese public.

As part of its efforts to push local farm produce to go international, Yunlin County has been actively organizing promotion tours to various countries since last year. It sent a delegation to Singapore in December, one to China's Fujian Province in September, as well as one to Beijing in July and one to Macau in April.
Since the county launched the promotion campaign last year, locally produced soy sauce, duck meat as well as vegetables and fruits have been exported to various countries and regions.
The agriculture-based Yunlin County in southern Taiwan produces mainly fruits and vegetables.

DOC.HEADLINE: Anti-unemployment measures to show results in three months: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan expressed confidence Wednesday that the measures introduced by the government to combat unemployment will produce better results in the coming two or three months.
Liu pledged that the government will work to control this year's unemployment situation "within acceptable limits."

Taiwan's unemployment rate soared to 5.03 percent in December 2008, hitting the highest level since October 2003 and marking the first time in five years that the monthly jobless rate topped 5 percent. The average unemployment rate for 2008 was 4.14 percent, which represented a four-year high.
The premier addressed the issue during a meeting with personnel officials, in which he urged government employees to do their jobs to the best of their ability so as to put themselves over the top.

Liu said the government may be a bit optimistic by forecasting that Taiwan's gross domestic product will shrink only by 2.97 percent this year, but he stressed the forecast is not based on "blind optimism."

Liu said he is confident in the government's ability to get things done, pointing to the growth in government investment in the fourth quarter of last year and the fact that as many as 53 percent of the government's stimulus package to boost domestic demand have been implemented over the past five months.

He argued that the recent decrease in bank lending does not mean a failure of the government's policy to encourage banks to provide financing boldly to healthy businesses, but reflects a fall in demand.
For example, he said, Taiwan's export volume has decreased by NT$200 billion due to a contraction in global market demand.
At present, the government's most urgent tasks are to look for new export markets and stimulate investment and exports, Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Central Taiwan's surplus tangerines to be turned into compost

TEXT.P: The government began to purchase surplus ponkan tangerines from farmers in Taichung County's Dongshih township Wednesday and turn them into compost in an attempt to stabilize the market for the fruit.

Officials from the Agriculture and Food Agency under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture said they will buy 500 metric tons of second-grade ponkan tangerines at NT$6 per kilogram before March 6 and send the fruit to another Taichung County township, Wufeng, to have it processed into green fertilizer.
Dongshih township head Yeh Yu-chin said it pained him to see the fruits of the farmers' year of labor being carried away by the truckload, knowing they will be scrapped.

An elderly woman among the onlookers kept sighing and calling it "such a waste." She said there was nothing wrong with the tangerines, which were sweet and succulent, except that they were only a bit smaller than top grade fruit.

According to Taichung County agriculture officials, the county still has 2,400 metric tons of tangerines stored in refrigerated warehouses. They attributed the glut to overproduction, the early arrival of the Lunar New Year holiday, and the ongoing economic downturn.
Dongshih ponkan tangerines are one of the most famous fruits in Taiwan. They are sweet, fragrant and succulent and full of vitamins A and C.

The fruit is harvested from late September to late December and can be stored for several months. Farmers usually sell a portion of their harvest on the market while keeping the rest wrapped in individual plastic bags and stored in refrigerated warehouses until January or March of the following year to fetch better prices.

Local agriculture officials, who fear that the central government's bulk purchase is not enough to relieve the farmers' plight, have launched a campaign to call on the public to consume more tangerines to ease the glut and help the farmers.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA promises to review policy on PVC use
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb.25 (CNA) 02/25/09 19:34:49 (EPA) pledged Wednesday to review the use of polyvinyl chloride (PVC) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration in manufacturing and packaging applications because of environmental concerns.

The agency was responding to calls by environmental groups to ban the widely used plastic in food packaging and medical accessories because of its detrimental effect on the environment throughout its life cycle, from production to disposal.

Hsieh Ho-lin, secretary-general of the Taiwan Watch Institute, a private group dedicated to protecting Taiwan's natural environment, said the plasticizing and stabilizing agents in PVC -- such as DEHP, DOP, cadmium and lead -- may harm people's kidneys or reproductive systems or lower their intelligence.
Those toxic substances can be released from PVC articles not just at high temperatures but also at normal room temperatures, Hsieh said.

He therefore urged the government to immediately ban the use of PVC in food packaging, phase out PVC water pipes and bar the recycling of PVC waste in incinerators to reduce the accumulation of dioxin in the environment.
Other environmental groups also urged the government to ban the use of the widely used plastic in medical accessories, such as blood bags and gloves.

Addressing the appeals, Ho Shun-chin, director-general of the EPA's Solid Waste Management Bureau, said the EPA had canvassed the opinion of medical professionals and found they opposed a ban of the material in the medical field because of the lack of readily available substitute materials.

As to the use of PVC in water piping for construction applications, Ho said PVC remains the optimal material because of its good ductability and suggested that a ban on its use in piping also might not be feasible.
As for food packaging, Ho said the EPA will conduct an overall review and seriously evaluate the possibility of prohibiting PVC use in food packaging and the production of food containers.
At present, Ho said, the EPA collects higher recycling fees from manufacturers of PVC containers than from those making non-PVC products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Thursday, moving up 54.79 points at 4,548.53 on a turnover of NT$2.07 billion (US$59.57 million).
The weighted price index gained 63.56 points, or 1.43 percent, to close at 4,493.74 Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 26, or the second day of the second month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1531: An earthquake rocks Portugal, killing more than 20,000 people.
1791: The Bank of England issues the first-ever pound note.
1802: Victor Marie Hugo, the French writer who wrote such novels as "The Hunchback of Notre Dame" and "Les Miserables" and went into exile after Napoleon III seized power in 1851, is born.
1815: Napoleon Bonaparte escapes from exile on the island of Elba.
1901: Chi Hsui and Hsu Cheng-yu, leaders of the "Righteous Harmony Fist" uprising, or the Boxer Rebellion, are publicly beheaded by a court executioner in Peking (Beijing), ending two years of unrest over the presence of foreigners in China.
1906: Angered by an incident in which a French missionary stabbed and injured the magistrate of Nanchang County in Kiangsi Province, Nanchang citizens kill a total of nine English and French missionaries in the county.
1935: Sir Robert Alexander Watson-Watt, a Scottish electronics engineer and inventor, demonstrates for the first time, at Daventry in England, the radar he helped develop.
1936: An army revolt to establish a more nationalistic government fails, but three leading members of the civilian government are killed during the uprising, and Japan's military leaders gain a firm control of the government.
1936: German Chancellor Adolf Hitler opens the first factory for the production of the Volkswagen, literally the "People's Car," in Saxony.
1946: U.S. Secretary of State James Byrnes denies knowledge of a Big Three Agreement authorizing the USSR to remove machinery from Manchuria.
1951: The 22nd Amendment to the United States Constitution is passed, limiting presidents to two four-year terms in office.
1952: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill announces that Britain has developed an atomic bomb and will test it in the Australian desert.
1964: The ROC Air Force receives a number of F-104G jet fighters from the United States under a military aid program.
1970: The Executive Yuan decides to go ahead with construction on the North- South Freeway.
1974: Members of the International Academy of Trial Lawyers arrive for their 1974 conference in Taipei.
1975: The Republic of China and South Africa sign a trade agreement in Taipei.
1976: Spain gives up control of the Spanish Sahara, and the region comes to be called the Western Sahara, which is divided into two parts under the separate control of Morocco and Mauritania, respectively.
1979: Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan is formally opened.
1980: The Ministry of Finance approves the opening of Taipei branches by five European banks: Grindlays Bank (Great Britain), the European Asia Bank (West Germany), the Societe Generale (France), the Banque de Paris et des Pays-Bas (France), and Hollandsche Bank-Unie, N.V. (the Netherlands).
1981: A French super-high-speed train connecting Paris with several cities in France travels at a top speed of 380 kph, a new world record.
1982: An ancient tomb dating back to the Han dynasty (206 B.C.-8 A.D.) is unearthed in Mawangtui, in suburban Changsha City, Hunan Province.
1990: President Lee Teng-hui and El Salvadoran President Alfredo Felix Cristiani Burkard sign a joint communique for closer bilateral cooperation.
1990: Vaclav Havel, Czechoslovakia's new president, announces in Moscow that all Soviet troops will leave his country by July, ending 21 years of armed occupation.
1991: Saddam Hussein orders Iraqi troops to retreat from Kuwait and declares a great victory.
1993: Two mainland Chinese basketball teams arrive in Taiwan to play exhibition matches against local teams, marking the first time in four decades that athletes from Taiwan and the mainland will compete in Taiwan.
1995: Communist China and the United States sign an agreement mandating Chinese respect for copyrights, trademarks and patents.
1995: Barings, the London finance house, collapses after suffering losses run up in Singapore by trader Nick Leeson.
2000: ROC Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Minister Chiao Jen-ho holds a ribbon-cutting ceremony to mark the completion of 49 newly-built brick houses in a village in northern Thailand for Nationalist veterans.
2003: The world's oldest Asian elephant living in captivity Lin Wang dies at the Taipei City Zoo at age 86.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Youth should be respected. How do we know that their future will not be as good as we are now? Only when a man is forty or fifty without having done anything to distinguish himself, does he then cease to command respect."

DOC.HEADLINE: Elections for local chiefs, councilors slated for Dec.5

TEXT.P: The year-end elections for city/county chiefs, councilors and township heads will be held Dec.5 and the polls will be open from 7 a.m. through 5 p.m., a Central Election Commission (CEC) official announced Wednesday.

CEC Secretary-General Teng Tien-yow said the polls will stay open for two hours longer than usual to give voters enough time to vote in the elections for city mayors/county magistrates, city/county councilors and township chiefs that day.
Prior to 1995, Teng said, the polling time for various public elections was 8 a.m. to 5 p.m., but since 1995 the polls have been closing an hour earlier at 4 p.m.
"For the year-end 'three-in-one' elections, it will be the first time ever in Taiwan that polling will start as early as 7 a.m.," Teng said.

According to the current Public Officials Election and Recall Law, Teng said, the three elections should be completed before Dec.10 in line with the requirement that the election of public officials should be finalized 10 days before the incumbents' terms of the office expire.
"The CEC commissioners unanimously selected Dec.5 so that there will be no big time gap between the polls and the inauguration of the winning candidates," Teng said.

In the past, the elections were traditionally held on either the second or the fourth Saturday of the month, both of which are known as "big weekends" when most private businesses are closed for vacation, Teng said.

As Dec. 5 this year does not coincide with that time, Teng said, the CEC decided to keep the polls open for an additional two hours to accommodate those who have to work and cannot adjust their schedules.

Since the longer polling day might add to the workload of local election workers, the CEC will step up communications with city and county election commissions to seek their support for the plan, Tseng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Manufacturing sectors' sales volume fell 2.46% in 2008: ministry

TEXT.P: The sales volume of Taiwan's manufacturing sector shrank to NT$2.36 trillion (US$67.9 billion) in the fourth quarter of 2008, marking a year-on-year drop of 29.39 percent due to the worldwide economic downturn, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Wednesday.
In the Q4, domestic sales fell 30.67 percent from the same period the previous year to NT$1.14 trillion, while export sales dropped 28.15 percent to NT$1.22 trillion.
The accumulated sales volume of the country's manufacturing sector fell to NT$12.06 trillion in 2008, marking a year-on-year decline of 2.46 percent, the MOEA statistics showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: ICP11 mimic protein might be anti-cancer drug: Taiwan scientists

TEXT.P: A DNA mimic protein discovered by Taiwan scientists in their research into a disease in crustaceans a year ago holds the potential for the development of a cancer treatment, leaders of the research team said Wednesday.

Lo Chu-fang, dean of the College of Life Science of National Taiwan University, and Andrew H.-J. Wang, research fellow and vice president of Academia Sinica, told reporters that their nine-member team discovered ICP11 -- the most highly expressed nonstructural gene of the white spot syndrome virus -- when they tried to find the cause of a disease that was affecting crustaceans worldwide.
The research results were published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America in April 2008.
Lo and Wang said the research team has found that ICP11, one of a handful of presently known "mimic proteins," has the ability to destroy cells, leading to their programmed demise.
Lo said because of this particular function, the DNA mimic holds great potential for cancer treatment.

He said more research is needed to study the effect of ICP11 on cancer cells in clinical experiments, and if the mimic protein is as good as the researchers believe it is, the world will have a new approach to cancer treatment.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-Poland engagement does not violate 'one China' principle: Ma

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that engagements between Poland and the Republic of China are not in violation of the "one China" principle because it is upheld by both sides of the Taiwan Strait, despite their divergence over its definition.
Ma made the remarks during a meeting with Stefan Niesiolowski, deputy speaker of the lower house of the Polish parliament.

During the meeting, Ma conferred the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on Niesiolowski in recognition of his outstanding contribution to the promotion of friendship and cooperation between the two countries over the past years.

Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties, relations between Taiwan and Poland have been growing stronger since Taiwan opened a representative office in Warsaw in 1992 and Poland reciprocated in 1995.

Although Poland formally recognizes China, its engagement with Taiwan does not violate Beijing's "one China" principle since Taiwan's Constitution is also based on the "one China" framework, Ma explained, adding that Taiwan's "one China" refers to the Republic of China.

Ma further said that since his inauguration last May, his administration has been promoting pragmatic diplomacy, an approach it has been using to maintain close ties with its diplomatic allies, while at the same time improving relations with China.
"Our pragmatic efforts have won wide recognition in the international community as evidenced by the improvement in our relations with the European Union, " Ma said.
Britain's recent decision to grant Taiwanese tourists visa-free treatment for stays of up to six months is a good example of the progress achieved, he added.
If more EU countries follow suit, Ma said, civilian exchanges between Taiwan and EU member states will definitely increase in the future.
On Taiwan-Poland ties, Ma said he looks forward to continued expansion of bilateral exchanges in the fields of tourism, trade, culture and education.

For his part, Niesiolowski said Taiwan and Poland have had similar experiences in the development of democracy. Saying that he admires Taiwan's success in democratization and economic development, the Polish lawmaker added that he believes that with perseverance and ingenuity, Taiwan will be able to ride out the current economic storm.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tibetans in Taiwan hold vigil to mark Losar

TEXT.P: Tibetan expatriates and their friends in Taiwan held a vigil at Liberty Square in downtown Taipei Wednesday to commemorate the Tibetans who were killed in last year's demonstrations against Chinese authorities.
The vigil coincided with Tibetan New Year, known as Losar, which falls on Feb. 25 this year.

Losar is one of the most important Tibetan festivals. Tibetans in China launched a campaign to hold vigils for those who were killed during a series of protests against China last year and for those who have been jailed in China for their participation in those activities.
Tibetan exiles, including those in Taiwan, responded to the call by their compatriots in China by holding vigils in the countries where they live.
About 70 people took part in the Taipei vigil. Led by Tibetan lamas, the participants recited Tibetan Buddhist scriptures to commemorate Tibetans who have died for seeking freedom.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Centuries-old village wins battle to preserve historic houses

TEXT.P: It was a small victory hardly mentioned by Taiwan's mainstream media, but in the opinion of residents of Taiwan's outlying archipelago Penghu, a giant step toward saving an important piece of history.

On Dec. 23 last year, the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) agreed to list a cluster of old coral-built houses in Chungshe village, Penghu's Wanan islet as an "important settlement, " after several decades of efforts by local residents to obtain government protection of the centuries old homes.

The quiet Chungshe village, which locals call by its ancient name Hua Zai, or "Flower Village, " is believed to have existed as a settlement since Han Chinese from mainland China began settling there three centuries ago.

The new designation for Hua Zai may finally bring about much-needed government support for the challenging work of preserving the houses in the village, which is considered the largest and most well-preserved early Han settlement in Taiwan.

"Chungshe residents have waited for more than 20 years for this moment, " said Tzeng Ching-hsin, secretary-general of the Taiwan Hua Zai Settlement Preservation Association -- a civic group founded by local residents and homeowners in 2005.

The central government's move comes as Taiwan is desperately trying to attract more tourists to boost its lagging economy and as local governments are increasingly recognizing that what tourists want to see are not tall new buildings, but traditional houses that teach them something about the local culture and history.
Over the past two decades, residents have made repeated requests to government offices seeking government restrictions against destroying the homes and funding to preserve them - but to no avail.

While waiting for government protection over the years, Hua Zai has paid the price, Tzeng said, as more than half of the village's approximately 150 old houses were either damaged inadvertently or intentionally destroyed by some residents who prefer to build new homes with modern conveniences. Although some 50 structures still remain intact, the landscape has partly been marred by the new buildings.

Harsh weather has also taken a toll on the houses. In the summer of 2008 alone, three powerful typhoons badly damaged the village, as many of the dwellings' holed roofs provided little protection against rainfall.
Yet the settlement is fertile ground for renovation because most of the houses, which date back 75 to 150 years, have not been modified and reflect designs handed down from early Han settlers.

In a 2006 survey of the village, the Tainan-based nonprofit Foundation of Historic City Conservation and Regeneration Foundation (FHCCR) found that of the village's 158 buildings, 73 percent had not been changed in any way.
Ironically, the village's remote location and exodus of people looking for work in more populated areas have been critical to preserving its unique identity.
"A serious population outflow is the reason why Chungshe has been able to keep its original appearance, " said Yen Hsin-hsiung, chairman of the Taiwan Hua Zai Settlement Preservation Association.
Even today, some of the remaining 100 villagers -- mostly senior citizens and children -- live the same way their ancestors did, fishing, collecting seaweed and growing their own food.
"They take what nature offers, " said the FHCCR's Chang. "It is the old wisdom of living in harmony with nature that is valuable, and deserves to be preserved, protected and passed on. "

Despite the settlement's long history, the houses' unique architectural features and historical significance were not appreciated until Lin Huei- cheng, now a professor in Taipei National University of the Arts' Graduate School of Architecture and Historic Preservation, stumbled upon them in the late 1970s.

"I was amazed by their architectural structure and their abundant cultural significance when I first caught sight of the settlement 30 years ago, " Lin said, adding that he immediately began what was to become a lifetime study of the houses.
Lin measured every house, recorded details of their decoration and analyzed the skillful way the coral stones were stacked and held together by a lime and mud mortar.

Coral was the main building material used in the old days because of the lack of trees or other natural resources on the islet and residents inability to afford imported wood. Even then, villagers only had access to coral that washed up on beaches after storms.

The houses typically consist of a main building with two wings adorned with elegant bell-shaped roofs. The main building, called the "toa chuh sin" -- meaning "big house" in Taiwan's mainstream ethnic dialect Hoklo -- is the most important part of the U-shaped enclosure.

Skillful architectural techniques ensured that the houses were built to withstand the notoriously strong howling winds in Penghu. Small windows blocked by cement bars and attachable wood panels kept the wind out. The structures were also environmentally friendly -- warm in the winter and cool in the summer.

Preservationists tried for years to get formal recognition for these architectural marvels before succeeding in having the settlement put on the 2004 World Monuments Watch List of the 100 most-endangered sites by the New York-based World Monuments Funds (WMF) , a private nonprofit organization dedicated to saving the world's most treasured places.
Being listed by the WMF reinforced Hua Zai residents' determination to preserve the old houses and also prompted the central government's recognition of the place as an "important settlement."
Yet even the newly-won designation may be an empty victory.

Under Taiwan's Cultural Heritage Preservation Law, the relevant authorities are only obliged to subsidize 60 percent of the cost of preserving and restoring the old houses, with the rest to be footed by local residents.

In other words, the residents still must take the initiative to maintain the settlement, and if through negligence it loses its unique character, it might be stripped of the designation, a Penghu County official said.

"Our biggest hope now is for the government to set regulations on how to preserve and restore the old houses and prevent tourists from disturbing the lives of the people who still live there," Tzeng said.

He also urged the government to amend rules that would help bypass the tangled ownership histories of the houses that have made getting approval for renovation projects cumbersome. Time, he said, is of the essence.
"We hope the Council for Cultural Affairs will act quickly, " Tzeng said, expressing concern that by the time the government finally begins to take action, there might be nothing left to protect.

DOC.HEADLINE: Freedom of press, speech upheld in Taiwan: U.S. report
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 25 (CNA) 02/26/09 13:26:24 (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government commended Taiwan's efforts in upholding freedom of speech and of the press in its annual human rights reports released Wednesday, despite criticism that civil liberties were being suppressed under the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou.
According to the 2008 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices published by the U.S. State Department, the press in Taiwan remained vigorous and active last year.

Shortly after taking office in May 2008, President Ma announced that the authorities should not attempt to influence the political process through the media, that the budget for official advertising should be evenly distributed among media outlets and the two major political parties, and that the military should not get involved in media operations, the reports said.

In July, Taiwan extended the maximum stay of Chinese journalists from 30 days to three months and decided to allow up to five Chinese regional news outlets to station journalists in Taiwan, in addition to the five Chinese national outlets already allowed, the reports pointed out.

However, the Hong Kong-based Phoenix Satellite Television expressed frustration over the denial of its request to broadcast in Taiwan, and both the International Federation of Journalists and Reporters Without Borders were concerned about alleged government interference in the Taiwan media, the reports said.

Also, the reports stated, opposition groups and student demonstrators complained that police violated their right to free expression during protests against the visit of Chen Yunlin, who as president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits acts as China's chief negotiator with Taiwan.
Other problems mentioned in the report on Taiwan were corruption by officials, violence and discrimination against women, trafficking in persons, and abuses of foreign workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: CECA will be free lunch for big businesses paid for by workers: TSU

TEXT.P: Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman Huang Kun-hui said Thursday that signing a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) with China would be like giving a "free lunch" to big businesses, while the majority of laborers would have to pay the price.
"There is no such a thing as free lunch, " Huang said. "(President) Ma Ying-jeou should explain and clarify exactly what a CECA is and how it will affect Taiwan's industries and laborers."
Huang made the remarks at a press conference at which he raised 11 questions related to the CECA that he would like Ma to answer in his scheduled television interview Friday.

The possibility of signing a CECA with Beijing has been widely debated over the past few months, and has spurred fierce criticisms from the opposition parties, which fear that it will involve delicate political issues that will give rise to serious social conflicts in Taiwan.

Huang said that instead of scaring the public with the argument that the economic situation for Taiwan will be dire if it fails to ink a CECA with Beijing, Ma should once and for all clarify the concept, content, and consequences of signing such an agreement.

The TSU head argued that the content of the agreement should be discussed with the Legislative Yuan before being put on the negotiation table with China and should be subject to legislative review and a referendum before a deal is signed with Beijing.

"In light of China's ultimate goal to annex Taiwan -- not so much a conspiracy or anything -- a referendum is necessary, since this is a matter of the long- term survival and development of the entire Taiwanese society," Huang said.

One question Huang would like Ma to answer is that what type of industries would benefit from a CECA with China, and to what extent. The TSU head would also like to know how much the government would have to spend to help those enterprises that would suffer as a result of the agreement.
A CECA should be signed only if China promises to resolve the numerous cases involving problems experienced by Taiwanese businesses that have investments in China, he argued.

Moreover, noting that the Ma administration keeps comparing the proposed CECA to the economic integration of the European Union and has said that it has nothing to do with political issues and sovereignty, Huang suggested that Ma follow the example of the EU and hold a referendum on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan grants conditional visa waiver to citizens of 5 Asian nations

TEXT.P: Nationals of India, Thailand, the Philippines, Vietnam and Indonesia who meet certain criteria will be permitted to travel to Taiwan without a visa starting March 1, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Thursday.

The criteria are that the travelers hold a valid Schengen visa to any European Union nation, or a visa to the United States, Canada, Japan, the United Kingdom, Australia or New Zealand. They will also be eligible for visa waiver treatment if they are permanent residents of any of the countries mentioned above, according to the MOFA.
However, the criteria rule out citizens of the five Asian countries who have previously been employed in Taiwan as blue-collar workers.
The ministry said the program is aimed at attracting high-income nationals of the five Asian countries to travel to Taiwan, in a bid to boost Taiwan's tourism industry.

Travelers who meet the criteria are required to register their personal data online through the National Immigration Agency Web site prior to their departure for Taiwan, in order to obtain a certificate proving their visa-free status. They will be required to show the certificate when checking in for their flights to Taiwan and at the immigration counter upon arrival in Taiwan, the MOFA said.
At the Taiwan immigration counter, the travelers must also show their visas to or permanent resident cards issued by any of the countries mentioned, the MOFA added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC pushing for passage of refugee law

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) is pushing for the Legislative Yuan to pass a refugee law in the hope that asylum seekers from China, Hong Kong, Macau and Tibet will be able to stay legally in Taiwan, a MAC spokesman said Thursday.

Although the regulations on refugee matters fall under the the Ministry of the Interior, the MAC is very concerned about the law, because over the past few years, most alien citizens seeking asylum and assistance in Taiwan have been from China, according to MAC spokesman Liu Teh-hsun.
If the law clears the legislative floor, it would provide a legal basis for the government to handle affairs related to refugees and give local people a clear concept of refugee issues, Liu said.

Currently, most refugees seeking asylum in Taiwan are from Tibet or are descendants of the remnants of a Kuomintang force that was stranded in northern Thailand while trying to follow the KMT government to Taiwan at the end of the Chinese civil war in 1949.
Apart from these refugees, two Chinese pro-democracy activists, Cai Lujun and Wu Yalin, have also sought sanctuary in Taiwan, Liu added.

Cai, sneaked into Taiwan last year and was held for six months at the Hsinchu detention center for illegal Chinese immigrants, while Wu sought political asylum after he arrived in Taiwan last year as a tourist, Liu said. Both of them have now obtained temporary resident status in Taiwan, he added.
The two men came under the media spotlight last September when they scaled the wall of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) compound to ask for political asylum in the United States.

As Taiwan does not have a political refugee or asylum law, the government has not been able to grant political asylum to the two Chinese political activists, but they have been allowed to remain in Taiwan temporarily based on humanitarian considerations, Liu said.

The MAC is providing a monthly stipend of between NT$10,000 and NT$20,000 to help with their living expenses because they are not allowed to work in Taiwan, Liu said, adding that this will continue to be a financial burden on the agency as it is an additional expenditure.
The MAC hopes that the law will soon be passed to allow political asylum seekers to gain resident status and work in Taiwan once they are certified as refugees, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shares higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Thursday, with the Taiwan stock exchange's weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 24.82 points, or 0.55 percent, to close at 4,518.56.

Posting a gain for the second consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 4,548.53 and fluctuated between 4,556.82 and 4,492.70. A total of 3.07 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$58.83 billion (US$1.69 billion).

Five of eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks as well as machinery and electronics shares advancing the most at 0.9 percent. Cement stocks rose 0.6 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks gained 0.3 percent, and foodstuff issues were up 0.2 percent.

Three other major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial stocks moving down the most at 0.7 percent. Paper and pulp issues shed 0.5 percent, and construction issues lost 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 802 to 715, with 284 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$1.01 billion.

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Thursday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for March advancing 9 points to end at 4,477, with 89,413 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for April gained 13 points to finish at 4,433, with 523 contracts traded, while June futures rose 20 points to end at 4,366, with 91 contracts traded.
September futures gained 9 points to close at 4,154, with 37 contract transactions, while December futures rose 19 points to end at 4,096, with 29 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 4,468 for March, 4,420 for April, 4,346 for June, 4,145 for September, and 4,077 for December.

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier promotes hotline service for drug addicts

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan urged drug addicts Thursday to kick the habit by seeking assistance through a 24-hour toll-free hotline service that will be activated March 1.
Speaking at an event to promote the hotline 0800-770885, Liu said that with one percent of the population, or 230,000 people, in the grips of drug addition, the country is facing a serious problem.
He encouraged drug addicts make good use of the hotline to access the government's rehabilitation service and set themselves on the path to a new life.
Liu said that substance abuse not only causes a host of public health and social problems, but also contributes to an escalation in crime rates and leads to the spread of communicable diseases.

Given that most drug addicts in Taiwan are young people and the rate of relapse among recovering addicts is 90 percent, the problem has had a huge negative impact on the nation's work force, according to Liu.
The premier said that there is ample room for a revision of the country's anti- drug policies and programs, as there are very few signs that the drug abuse problem in the country is easing.

Therefore, the Ministry of Justice, in collaboration with the Department of Heath, has been promoting a new policy under which drug addicts will be treated as patients rather than as criminals, under a a rehabilitation program launched earlier in the month, Liu said.
Under the program, drug abusers who take the initiative to seek rehabilitation will be exempt from punishment or will be given deferred sentences, according to Liu.

Starting March, drug addicts will be able to obtain assistance by calling the hotline without identifying themselves, Liu said. Professionals at various drug prevention and control centers around the country will be available for consultations and will offer suggestions on medical treatment, schooling and employment, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: New law would allow junk e-mail recipients to claim compensation

TEXT.P: The Cabinet finalized Thursday a draft law that would allow Internet users bombarded with junk e-mail to claim up to NT$2,000 (US$58) per mail in compensation from the senders.

The bill, which is pending final approval by the Legislative Yuan, would also require senders of commercial e-mail to inform their recipients that they do not need to reply if they have no wish to receive further mail.

According to Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, it is becoming popular for countries around the world to try to control the delivery of junk e-mail by law, and Taiwan should also enact a law as soon as possible to protect the rights of Internet users.
Before the law is enacted, Internet service providers should strengthen their capabilities in blocking junk e-mail to help reduce the circulation of the junk, Liu said.

Kao Fu-yao, head of the legal affairs department under the National Communications Commission, said the problem of junk e-mail is becoming worse in Taiwan, with the 10 major Internet service providers receiving a total of 105.3 billion junk e-mail in 2008.
Although 87 billion of the mail were blocked through filtering technology, junk mail remained a headache for most Internet users, Kao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 40% of Taiwanese companies in China plan to return to Taiwan: SEF

TEXT.P: Over 40 percent of the Taiwanese companies that maintain business operations in China will consider returning part of their investments to Taiwan in two years' time, the intermediary Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Thursday.

Twenty-two Taiwanese companies operating in China said in a recent survey conducted by the SEF that two years down the road they probably would channel funds back to Taiwan for new investment projects.
The figure represented 41.51 percent of the total number of China-based Taiwanese companies that responded to the SEF survey conducted in January.
Nine other Taiwanese companies, or 16.98 percent of the respondents, said they plan to channel funds back to Taiwan within one or two years to start new investments.

"This indicates that Taiwanese businesses have started to rethink their investment strategies since the changes in China's investment climate and regulations, " said Lin Chen-yen, director of Chung Yuan Christian University's Office of Research and Development.

SEF officials conducted the survey when they visited Taiwanese companies based in Guangdong and Jiangsu provinces in January. Among the respondents, 34 percent were manufacturers of electronics or electrical parts, while the others were manufacturers of plastic products and companies in the financial and service sectors.
On China's gross domestic product (GDP), most of the respondents speculated that it would grow this year by 4-6 percent or 6-8 percent, while a few said it would reach 8 percent or higher.
"This indicates that the Taiwanese businessmen do not have much faith in the Chinese authorities' forecast that the country's economic growth will top 8 percent for 2009," Lin said.

The poll found that most of the respondents were apathetic about China's efforts to bolster economic growth by expanding domestic demand, as they believe that they would have little chance to capitalize on the plan, Lin said.

Most of the Taiwanese companies said they would consider upgrading their products and manufacturing process as well as hiring more managerial-level professionals in order to survive in China's harsher investment environment, Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: European trade offices issue practical guide on Taiwan market

TEXT.P: The European Economic and Trade Office (EETO) and the French Institute in Taipei announced Thursday that they will issue a business brochure to raise awareness in Europe about Taiwan's market potential and to better facilitate bilateral economic and trade relations between Taiwan and the European Union.

EETO head Guy Ledoux told the Central News Agency in an exclusive interview that while there are already quite a few European international companies doing businesses in Taiwan, the new initiative targets small and medium sized companies (SMEs) in Europe and is intended to spur their interest in Taiwanese market.

The business guide, titled "A Practical Guide to the Taiwanese Market -- How to export or invest in Taiwan, " is a collaborative effort by the EETO, the French Institute in Taipei and other European trade offices in Taiwan, he added.

Starting Friday, 6,000 copies of the brochure will be given to the European trade councilors and representatives based in Taiwan for distribution to the SMEs at various events held by European business communities and regional chambers of commerce, Ledoux said.

"If it's properly distributed and if it's accompanied by direct stimuli by European trade councilors and representatives, it will have a big impact," said the de facto European Union ambassador to Taiwan.

Emmanuel Ly-Batallan, head of the economic and commercial section of the French Institute in Taipei, told the CNA that the brochure is very concise and contains all the basic information that European businesses would need to understand the Taiwan market.

With a population of merely 23 million, Taiwan is the world's 15th largest importer, with imports totalling 150 billion euros (US$192 billion) in 2007, ahead of India's 149 billion euros, Ly-Batallan noted, saying that this is a good indicator of Taiwan's market potential. Added to that is the fact the consumption level in Taiwan is high, with the purchasing power parity per capita being US$30,000, he said.
Moreover, the quality of infrastructure and the regulatory environment make Taiwan an attractive market, according to Ly-Batallan.
"If you look at international markets in general, the quality of the legal environment in Taiwan is very strong," Ly-Batallan said, adding that a highly skilled workforce is another asset.

Describing Taiwan as a market "underestimated by European companies, " the brochure states that since taking office May 20, 2008, President Ma Ying-jeou has adopted numerous economic and financial measures to improve relations with China, which present new opportunities for not only Taiwanese but also foreign businesses.

Therefore, Taiwan can serve as the launch pad for businesses to begin their "Chinese success story" because operating from Taiwan enables European companies to benefit from Taiwans privileged links to China while taking advantage of Taiwan's developed legal and business environment, it adds.
