Detailed information regarding the practical guide will be posted on the EETO Web site at www.deltwn.ec.europa.eu and on the Web site of the European Commissions Directorate-General for Trade by next week, according to Ledoux.

DOC.HEADLINE: Real earnings hit by worst contraction in 29 years

TEXT.P: The real earnings of Taiwanese workers shrank by 3.37 percent in 2008, marking the worst contraction since 1980, mainly due to a high inflation and an economic slump, according to statistics released Thursday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
During the same period, real regular earnings -- which include only base salary plus fixed subsidies or bonuses -- decreased by 3.13 percent, also the worst performance since 1980.

The statistics showed that in 2008, the average monthly earnings per employee in the industrial and service sectors increased by just 0.03 percent from the previous year to NT$45,125 (US$1,300), and the average regular earnings per employee rose by 0.28 percent to NT$36,867.
However, a 3.52 percent rise in the consumer price index during the year more than offset any nominal gains in earnings.

According to Huang Chien-chung, deputy chief of the DGBAS's Fourth Department in charge of census and sampling surveys, although inflation moderated in October, there was a sharp decrease in regular earnings in November and December, owing to a drop in work hours as a result of many workers being forced to take unpaid leave amid sluggish business.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's jobless rate reaches record high in January

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate soared to 5.31 percent in January, marking a record high for January since the first official unemployment survey was launched in 1978, according to a report released Thursday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
Last month, the actual number of people out of work in Taiwan topped 578,000, also marking a record high in 31 years, DGBAS said.

The 5.31 percent jobless rate was the fourth highest in history for all months, trailing only the 5.35 percent posted in August 2001, 5.33 percent in October 2001 and 5.32 percent in September 2002, said Huang Chien-chung, a deputy chief of the DGBAS's Fourth Department in charge of census and sampling surveys.
Of the 578,000 jobless workers in January, 291,000 lost their jobs because of business closure or downsizing, up 41,000 from December 2008, and marking the highest monthly level since 1978, he added.

Huang said the January jobless increase rate, a month-on-month increase of 0.28 percentage points, was relatively mild compared to that posted in December 2008, which soared by 0.39 percentage points as compared with the November level.

He attributed the relatively "milder" increase to the growth in demand for temporary workers in January during the Chinese New Year holiday and the historic distribution of shopping vouchers nationwide.

The number of employed workers in Taiwan totaled 10.30 million in January, marking a month-on-month decline of 51,000 from December 2008 and a year-on-year fall of 88,000 from January 2008, hitting the greatest monthly decline since 1991, Huang said.

"It indicates that the growth dynamic of the country's overall workforce has lost steam, mainly as a result of the current economic recession, which has triggered a wave of layoffs across the country," said Huang.

Meanwhile, Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung said later in the day that the government is planning to create some 341,000 jobs this year, which will hopefully contribute to controlling the country's unemployment rate to under 4.5 percent for the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shanghai museum head arrives in Taiwan for visit

TEXT.P: A four-member delegation from the Shanghai Museum arrived in Taiwan Thursday for a return visit to the country's National Palace Museum (NPM), bringing what an NPM official described assurprisesto a museums planned exhibition.

Speaking at a press conference, Shanghai Museum Director Chen Xiejun, who heads the delegation, announced that his museum would lend one set, or two items, of its colored enamel porcelains from the period of the Qing Dynasty's Emperor Yongzheng to be displayed at the NPMs exhibition on the emperor to be held in October.

He said, however, that since the two museums did not formally discuss the feasibilities of lending the NPMs artifacts to be exhibited at the Shanghai World Expo 2010 when NPM Director Chou Kung-shin visited his city last week, they will not touch on the issue either as his current visit to Taipei is a purely reciprocal one.

Chou said Thursday that during Chen's visit, the two museums will work on details on the implementation of the nine-point consensus reached on her recent visit to China. The consensus involved building closer cooperation and exchanges in areas such as academics, archive and art conservation, as well as publication and exhibition arrangements.
She added that the set of porcelains mentioned by Chen are unique because their colored drawings are uncommonly influenced by the western painting style.

The NPM plans to showcase 138 sets, or around 180 items of Yongzheng-related artifacts in its October exhibition, said Chou, with around 27 sets borrowed from the Beijing-based Palace Museum and one set from the Shanghai Museum.

Chou described her recent visit to China assuccessfulbecause it has drawn intensive publicity in Chinas media even continuing until now, which has made the NPM a household name in China and would motivate more mainland Chinese to visit Taiwan.

While the Shanghai delegation will leave Taiwan on March 1, another Chinese delegation headed by the director of Beijing's Palace Museum is slated to arrive in Taiwan on the same day for a reciprocal four-day visit.
Chou visited the Palace Museum in Beijing and the Shanghai Museum during her "ice-breaking" trip to China in earlier this month.

The National Palace Museum in Taiwan holds more than 600,000 pieces of treasures, from paintings to jades, representing the best collection of Chinese cultural artifacts in the world. The items were taken from the Beijing Palace Museum to avoid the collection falling in the hands of the Japanese invading army during World War II. They were later shipped to Taiwan when the Nationalists in China lost a civil war to the Communists in 1949.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung working to create bilingual transportation environment

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government is working to have 2,000 bus stop signs in the city replaced with bilingual ones and more LED display devices installed along the Kaohisung metro system, as part of its preparations for the 2009 World Games, an official said Thursday.

Speaking at the inauguration of 81 full-color LED intelligent information display panels at all the stations on the Kaohsiung Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) system's Red Line, Wang Kwo-tsai, director of the city's Transportation Bureau said that the devices are aimed at providing passengers with real time travel information.
Another 35 of this type of LED display panels will also be installed at stations along the Kaohsiung MRT's Orange Line before the World Games opens in July, according to Wang.

Wang added that the panels featuring Chinese and English bilingual markings were designed to quickly familiarize hordes of foreign tourists who will flow into the city during the World Games with the city's public transport system.
Already, the bureau has received an average of 10,000 phone calls per day for bus information, according to Wang.

He added that he hopes that by rolling out the bilingual signage systems to provide easier access to transportation information, more foreign tourists would be lured into visiting the city during the World Games.
Each LED display panel costs NT$100,000 (US$2,870), while the 2,000 bilingual bus stop signs would cost NT$3 million, according to bureau official Chang Su- chuan.

As another part of its efforts to provide a more friendly environment for foreigners, the city government is also offering English language courses for bus and taxi drivers to enhance their English conversation ability so that they can communicate with foreign tourists and help answer questions the visitors may have.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourism head proposes expanding cross-strait tourism

TEXT.P: Chinese authorities will take measures to boost tourist arrivals to Taiwan in the shortest period possible and to promote an integration of tourism resources between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Shao Qiwei, director of China's National Tourism Administration, said Thursday.

Shao said Taiwan and China should jointly craft diverse and fresh products to lure tourists and study the possibility of devising tours that could take Chinese tourists to various stops in Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau in one trip, such as on cruises.
The two sides should cooperate closely to minimize the impact of the global economic crisis on the cross-strait tourism market, Shao said.
It is also important to set up a cross-Taiwan Strait information exchange and monitoring center to deal with emergencies that might arise, he added.
Shao made the remarks at the opening of the 12th Cross-Strait Travel Industry Forum, held for the first time in Taipei by the Taipei-based Travel Quality Assurance Association (TQAA).
TQAA Chairman Lin Chin-jung, meanwhile, said he was hopeful that the number of Chinese tourist arrivals to Taiwan would break the daily mark of 1,000 in April.

Since Taiwan relaxed restrictions and opened its doors to more Chinese tourists in July last year, a total of 89,988 tourists from mainland China have come to Taiwan -- with an average of 300 people per day in 2008 and 600 people per day in 2009, Lin said.

Zuo Yixiang, deputy director of Jiangsu Province's tourism association, who was also traveled to Taiwan for the forum, said the province has launched a drive promoting tours to Taiwan and the first batch of some 10,000 Jiangsu tourists will arrive on Friday.

Shao arrived Wednesday in Taiwan at the head of a large delegation of tourism officials and travel industry representatives from China's 30 major provinces. The trip is organized to help them gain a better understanding of the Taiwan market.
The visit is Shao's third to Taiwan to try to expand cross-Taiwan Strait tourism.

The entire 485-member delegation was the largest of its kind to ever visit Taiwan. Delegation members are to arrive in Taiwan in various groups starting from Wednesday. Shao is slated to meet Taiwan's Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai while here.
The TQAA will arrange for the Chinese delegation to travel to scenic areas around Taiwan to get a firsthand look at Taiwan's tourism resources before the members return to China on March 4.

On March 1, more than 300 of the visiting Chinese tour operators will head for Alishan, a noted mountain resort in southern Taiwan's Chiayi County, which is one of the most popular destinations among Chinese tourists to Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Taiwan tour operators also said they are optimistic that the number of Chinese tourist arrivals will soon surpass 1,000 per day, but expressed concern that a price war might ruin the market.

Although Taiwan's Tourism Bureau has stipulated that local tour agencies must take on each Chinese tourist at the minimum price of US$80 per day, to ensure the quality of the tours, tour operators complained that some of Taiwan's operators have begun offering cheaper packages at a price of US$30 or US$40 per day.
In response to the charge, Tourism Bureau officials said the US$80 requirement must be complied with and that they will step up checks against those breaching the regulation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of foreign laborers in Taiwan expected to drop by 30,000

TEXT.P: The number of foreign blue-collar workers employed in Taiwan is expected to drop by 30,000 this year as a result of the global economic recession and government measures to combat soaring unemployment, a ranking Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) official said Thursday.

The CLA passed an amendment Thursday, suspending the import of foreign laborers by manufacturers operating three shifts and lowering the cap on foreign workers allowed to work for major manufacturers from 30 percent to 20 percent of the companies' total work force, said Chen Yi-min, director-general of CLA's Employment and Vocational Training Administration.
The amendment is slated to be promulgated and put into force next week, Chen said.

Chen said the CLA proposed the amendment on the grounds that domestic workers are now more willing to work night-shift jobs in the face of rising unemployment and that the import of foreign laborers -- a supplementary measure -- should not affect the rights of domestic workers.

He noted that due to declined orders received by domestic manufacturers as a result of the global economic recession, the number of foreign workers employed in Taiwan had reduced by 8,400 and 9,000 in December 2008 and January, respectively.
As a result of these factors, the number of foreign workers employed in Taiwan's manufacturing sector is expected to fall by 30,000 this year after the amendment takes effect, Chen added.
According to CLA statistics, the number of foreign laborers in Taiwan totaled 365,000 at the end of December 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of people on the dole might increase to 90,000

TEXT.P: The number of people on the dole in Taiwan might exceed 90,000 by the end of February with a soaring unemployment rate, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) predicted Thursday.

More than 20,000 people who have recently lost jobs became first-time claimants of unemployment subsidies in February, at a time when the country's jobless rate soared to 5.31 percent in January, a 31-year high, according to the CLA.
Over 30,000 people claimed the welfare payments last December, representing an unprecedented onefold increase, with 26,773 claimants succeeding in receiving benefits, CLA officials said.
As of the end of December 2008, the CLA has approved unemployment payments for 63,251 people in the country, the officials said.
The figure was between 20,000 and 30,000 in January and February, respectively, they added.

Sun You-lien, secretary-general of the civic group Taiwan Labor Front, called for the administration to convene a national conference on unemployment soon to review and integrate governmental resources for disbursements to help the jobless ride out financial difficulties.

DOC.HEADLINE: CECA and FTAs should go hand-in-hand: ex-SEF head

TEXT.P: A former head of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Thursday that Taiwan's economic interests would be better served if negotiations with China on a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) go hand-in- hand with those with other countries on free trade agreements (FTAs).

Speaking at a press conference, Hong Chi-chang, who headed the quasi-official intermediary body in exchanges with China in the absence of official ties during the late years of the previous Democratic Progressive Party administration, said that while negotiating a CECA with China, Taiwan should try to push for the signing of FTAs with nations with which Taiwan has close trade relations, such as members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations' (ASEAN).
That way, he said, Taiwan could resist further economic dependence on China, which would happen if only the CECA is signed.

The government is proposing signing the agreement with China, largely to ensure Taiwan enjoys preferential treatment in trade like other countries that reach trade agreements with China. But critics warn such an agreement could make Taiwan too economically dependent on China and could hurt Taiwanese businesses.

Although the CECA could slow down the process of Taiwan being marginalized in the ongoing regional economic integration, Hong said it should not be viewed as the ultimate solution to the countrys sluggish economy.

Meanwhile, the government should inform the public of the details of the agreement in a transparent manner and conduct thorough evaluations on its potential positive and negative impacts on different sectors, as well as Taiwans economy as a whole, Hong said.

In addition, Hong called on the government to first map out a comprehensive economic development strategy, instead of pushing for a CECA simply in response to the calls of a few particular industries.

Hong stressed that he was opposed to the CECA negotiations being carried out by the SEF, which is in charge of negotiations with China in the absence of official relations, and the China-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) , because the two bodies' previous negotiations on four agreements that were signed last year had proven non-transparent and had jeopardized the public's trust.

Negotiations on the CECA should be conducted by the National Security Council, Hong proposed, adding that Taiwan should also negotiate with China as two World Trade Organization members, which would put Taiwan on an equal footing with China.
Additionally, he stressed that the legislature should be allowed participation in the negotiation processes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourist arrivals post record growth: MOTC report

TEXT.P: Overseas travelers made a total of 3.845 million visits to Taiwan in 2008, marking a record 3.5 percent year-on-year growth, according to statistics released Thursday by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.

Of the total, 46.2 percent were tourists or holidaymakers, up 7.7 percent from the 2007 level, the report said. It added that the increase in tourists had helped offset a 5.3 percent decline in the number of business travelers amid the global economic recession.

By areas, the number of travelers from Hong Kong and Macau posted the largest gain in 2008, up 25.9 percent year-on-year; and the number of tourists from South Korea also registered an 11.7 percent increase.
In contrast, the number of visitors from Japan suffered the biggest slump of 6.8 percent, followed by travelers from the United States, down 2.7 percent from the 2007 level.
Meanwhile, the MOTC said the number of Taiwan visitors to Japan continued to rise to 1.31 million in 2008, from 1.28 million a year ago, marking a 2.3 percent year-on-year growth.

However, local people made fewer visits to most other areas, with the number of visitors to Macau registering the biggest decline of 22.5 percent. The numbers of visits to the United States and Hong Kong dropped 12.3 percent and 5.9 percent, respectively, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Feb. 27, 2009

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

Meanwhile, Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung said later in the day that the government is planning to create some 341,000 jobs this year, which will hopefully contribute to controlling the country's unemployment rate to under 4.5 percent for the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shanghai museum head arrives in Taiwan for visit

TEXT.P: A four-member delegation from the Shanghai Museum arrived in Taiwan Thursday for a return visit to the country's National Palace Museum (NPM), bringing what an NPM official described assurprisesto a museums planned exhibition.

Speaking at a press conference, Shanghai Museum Director Chen Xiejun, who heads the delegation, announced that his museum would lend one set, or two items, of its colored enamel porcelains from the period of the Qing Dynasty's Emperor Yongzheng to be displayed at the NPMs exhibition on the emperor to be held in October.

He said, however, that since the two museums did not formally discuss the feasibilities of lending the NPMs artifacts to be exhibited at the Shanghai World Expo 2010 when NPM Director Chou Kung-shin visited his city last week, they will not touch on the issue either as his current visit to Taipei is a purely reciprocal one.

Chou said Thursday that during Chen's visit, the two museums will work on details on the implementation of the nine-point consensus reached on her recent visit to China. The consensus involved building closer cooperation and exchanges in areas such as academics, archive and art conservation, as well as publication and exhibition arrangements.
She added that the set of porcelains mentioned by Chen are unique because their colored drawings are uncommonly influenced by the western painting style.

The NPM plans to showcase 138 sets, or around 180 items of Yongzheng-related artifacts in its October exhibition, said Chou, with around 27 sets borrowed from the Beijing-based Palace Museum and one set from the Shanghai Museum.

Chou described her recent visit to China assuccessfulbecause it has drawn intensive publicity in Chinas media even continuing until now, which has made the NPM a household name in China and would motivate more mainland Chinese to visit Taiwan.

While the Shanghai delegation will leave Taiwan on March 1, another Chinese delegation headed by the director of Beijing's Palace Museum is slated to arrive in Taiwan on the same day for a reciprocal four-day visit.
Chou visited the Palace Museum in Beijing and the Shanghai Museum during her "ice-breaking" trip to China in earlier this month.

The National Palace Museum in Taiwan holds more than 600,000 pieces of treasures, from paintings to jades, representing the best collection of Chinese cultural artifacts in the world. The items were taken from the Beijing Palace Museum to avoid the collection falling in the hands of the Japanese invading army during World War II. They were later shipped to Taiwan when the Nationalists in China lost a civil war to the Communists in 1949.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung working to create bilingual transportation environment

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government is working to have 2,000 bus stop signs in the city replaced with bilingual ones and more LED display devices installed along the Kaohisung metro system, as part of its preparations for the 2009 World Games, an official said Thursday.

Speaking at the inauguration of 81 full-color LED intelligent information display panels at all the stations on the Kaohsiung Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) system's Red Line, Wang Kwo-tsai, director of the city's Transportation Bureau said that the devices are aimed at providing passengers with real time travel information.
Another 35 of this type of LED display panels will also be installed at stations along the Kaohsiung MRT's Orange Line before the World Games opens in July, according to Wang.

Wang added that the panels featuring Chinese and English bilingual markings were designed to quickly familiarize hordes of foreign tourists who will flow into the city during the World Games with the city's public transport system.
Already, the bureau has received an average of 10,000 phone calls per day for bus information, according to Wang.

He added that he hopes that by rolling out the bilingual signage systems to provide easier access to transportation information, more foreign tourists would be lured into visiting the city during the World Games.
Each LED display panel costs NT$100,000 (US$2,870), while the 2,000 bilingual bus stop signs would cost NT$3 million, according to bureau official Chang Su- chuan.

As another part of its efforts to provide a more friendly environment for foreigners, the city government is also offering English language courses for bus and taxi drivers to enhance their English conversation ability so that they can communicate with foreign tourists and help answer questions the visitors may have.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourism head proposes expanding cross-strait tourism

TEXT.P: Chinese authorities will take measures to boost tourist arrivals to Taiwan in the shortest period possible and to promote an integration of tourism resources between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Shao Qiwei, director of China's National Tourism Administration, said Thursday.

Shao said Taiwan and China should jointly craft diverse and fresh products to lure tourists and study the possibility of devising tours that could take Chinese tourists to various stops in Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau in one trip, such as on cruises.
The two sides should cooperate closely to minimize the impact of the global economic crisis on the cross-strait tourism market, Shao said.
It is also important to set up a cross-Taiwan Strait information exchange and monitoring center to deal with emergencies that might arise, he added.
Shao made the remarks at the opening of the 12th Cross-Strait Travel Industry Forum, held for the first time in Taipei by the Taipei-based Travel Quality Assurance Association (TQAA).
TQAA Chairman Lin Chin-jung, meanwhile, said he was hopeful that the number of Chinese tourist arrivals to Taiwan would break the daily mark of 1,000 in April.

Since Taiwan relaxed restrictions and opened its doors to more Chinese tourists in July last year, a total of 89,988 tourists from mainland China have come to Taiwan -- with an average of 300 people per day in 2008 and 600 people per day in 2009, Lin said.

Zuo Yixiang, deputy director of Jiangsu Province's tourism association, who was also traveled to Taiwan for the forum, said the province has launched a drive promoting tours to Taiwan and the first batch of some 10,000 Jiangsu tourists will arrive on Friday.

Shao arrived Wednesday in Taiwan at the head of a large delegation of tourism officials and travel industry representatives from China's 30 major provinces. The trip is organized to help them gain a better understanding of the Taiwan market.
The visit is Shao's third to Taiwan to try to expand cross-Taiwan Strait tourism.

The entire 485-member delegation was the largest of its kind to ever visit Taiwan. Delegation members are to arrive in Taiwan in various groups starting from Wednesday. Shao is slated to meet Taiwan's Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai while here.
The TQAA will arrange for the Chinese delegation to travel to scenic areas around Taiwan to get a firsthand look at Taiwan's tourism resources before the members return to China on March 4.

On March 1, more than 300 of the visiting Chinese tour operators will head for Alishan, a noted mountain resort in southern Taiwan's Chiayi County, which is one of the most popular destinations among Chinese tourists to Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Taiwan tour operators also said they are optimistic that the number of Chinese tourist arrivals will soon surpass 1,000 per day, but expressed concern that a price war might ruin the market.

Although Taiwan's Tourism Bureau has stipulated that local tour agencies must take on each Chinese tourist at the minimum price of US$80 per day, to ensure the quality of the tours, tour operators complained that some of Taiwan's operators have begun offering cheaper packages at a price of US$30 or US$40 per day.
In response to the charge, Tourism Bureau officials said the US$80 requirement must be complied with and that they will step up checks against those breaching the regulation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of foreign laborers in Taiwan expected to drop by 30,000

TEXT.P: The number of foreign blue-collar workers employed in Taiwan is expected to drop by 30,000 this year as a result of the global economic recession and government measures to combat soaring unemployment, a ranking Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) official said Thursday.

The CLA passed an amendment Thursday, suspending the import of foreign laborers by manufacturers operating three shifts and lowering the cap on foreign workers allowed to work for major manufacturers from 30 percent to 20 percent of the companies' total work force, said Chen Yi-min, director-general of CLA's Employment and Vocational Training Administration.
The amendment is slated to be promulgated and put into force next week, Chen said.

Chen said the CLA proposed the amendment on the grounds that domestic workers are now more willing to work night-shift jobs in the face of rising unemployment and that the import of foreign laborers -- a supplementary measure -- should not affect the rights of domestic workers.

He noted that due to declined orders received by domestic manufacturers as a result of the global economic recession, the number of foreign workers employed in Taiwan had reduced by 8,400 and 9,000 in December 2008 and January, respectively.
As a result of these factors, the number of foreign workers employed in Taiwan's manufacturing sector is expected to fall by 30,000 this year after the amendment takes effect, Chen added.
According to CLA statistics, the number of foreign laborers in Taiwan totaled 365,000 at the end of December 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of people on the dole might increase to 90,000

TEXT.P: The number of people on the dole in Taiwan might exceed 90,000 by the end of February with a soaring unemployment rate, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) predicted Thursday.

More than 20,000 people who have recently lost jobs became first-time claimants of unemployment subsidies in February, at a time when the country's jobless rate soared to 5.31 percent in January, a 31-year high, according to the CLA.
Over 30,000 people claimed the welfare payments last December, representing an unprecedented onefold increase, with 26,773 claimants succeeding in receiving benefits, CLA officials said.
As of the end of December 2008, the CLA has approved unemployment payments for 63,251 people in the country, the officials said.
The figure was between 20,000 and 30,000 in January and February, respectively, they added.

Sun You-lien, secretary-general of the civic group Taiwan Labor Front, called for the administration to convene a national conference on unemployment soon to review and integrate governmental resources for disbursements to help the jobless ride out financial difficulties.

DOC.HEADLINE: CECA and FTAs should go hand-in-hand: ex-SEF head

TEXT.P: A former head of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Thursday that Taiwan's economic interests would be better served if negotiations with China on a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) go hand-in- hand with those with other countries on free trade agreements (FTAs).

Speaking at a press conference, Hong Chi-chang, who headed the quasi-official intermediary body in exchanges with China in the absence of official ties during the late years of the previous Democratic Progressive Party administration, said that while negotiating a CECA with China, Taiwan should try to push for the signing of FTAs with nations with which Taiwan has close trade relations, such as members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations' (ASEAN).
That way, he said, Taiwan could resist further economic dependence on China, which would happen if only the CECA is signed.

The government is proposing signing the agreement with China, largely to ensure Taiwan enjoys preferential treatment in trade like other countries that reach trade agreements with China. But critics warn such an agreement could make Taiwan too economically dependent on China and could hurt Taiwanese businesses.

Although the CECA could slow down the process of Taiwan being marginalized in the ongoing regional economic integration, Hong said it should not be viewed as the ultimate solution to the countrys sluggish economy.

Meanwhile, the government should inform the public of the details of the agreement in a transparent manner and conduct thorough evaluations on its potential positive and negative impacts on different sectors, as well as Taiwans economy as a whole, Hong said.

In addition, Hong called on the government to first map out a comprehensive economic development strategy, instead of pushing for a CECA simply in response to the calls of a few particular industries.

Hong stressed that he was opposed to the CECA negotiations being carried out by the SEF, which is in charge of negotiations with China in the absence of official relations, and the China-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) , because the two bodies' previous negotiations on four agreements that were signed last year had proven non-transparent and had jeopardized the public's trust.

Negotiations on the CECA should be conducted by the National Security Council, Hong proposed, adding that Taiwan should also negotiate with China as two World Trade Organization members, which would put Taiwan on an equal footing with China.
Additionally, he stressed that the legislature should be allowed participation in the negotiation processes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourist arrivals post record growth: MOTC report

TEXT.P: Overseas travelers made a total of 3.845 million visits to Taiwan in 2008, marking a record 3.5 percent year-on-year growth, according to statistics released Thursday by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.

Of the total, 46.2 percent were tourists or holidaymakers, up 7.7 percent from the 2007 level, the report said. It added that the increase in tourists had helped offset a 5.3 percent decline in the number of business travelers amid the global economic recession.

By areas, the number of travelers from Hong Kong and Macau posted the largest gain in 2008, up 25.9 percent year-on-year; and the number of tourists from South Korea also registered an 11.7 percent increase.
In contrast, the number of visitors from Japan suffered the biggest slump of 6.8 percent, followed by travelers from the United States, down 2.7 percent from the 2007 level.
Meanwhile, the MOTC said the number of Taiwan visitors to Japan continued to rise to 1.31 million in 2008, from 1.28 million a year ago, marking a 2.3 percent year-on-year growth.

However, local people made fewer visits to most other areas, with the number of visitors to Macau registering the biggest decline of 22.5 percent. The numbers of visits to the United States and Hong Kong dropped 12.3 percent and 5.9 percent, respectively, according to the report.

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open little changed

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened little changed Friday, moving up 5.0 points at 4,523.56 on a turnover of NT$1.32 billion (US$37.88 million).
The weighted price index gained 24.82 points, or 0.55 percent, to close at 4,518.56 Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 27, or the third day of the second month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
285: Constantine I, Emperor of Rome known as "Constantine the Great," is born. He adopted the Christian faith and suspended the persecution of Christians.
1782: The British Parliament votes to abandon the American War of Independence.
1844: The Dominican Republic gains its independence from Haiti.
1861: Rudolf Steiner, the Austrian philosopher, educationalist, and founder of anthroposophy, is born.
1879: Constantin Fahlberg, a chemist at Johns Hopkins University, announces the discovery of saccharine, a synthetic sweetener.
1910: Dr. Sun Yat-sen sets up a U.S. headquarters in San Francisco after organizing the Revolution Alliance in Tokyo in 1905 to sponsor an entire network of revolutionaries inside China.
1922: Dr. Sun Yat-sen issues a proclamation at a "harangue-the-troops" ceremony in Guilin, Guangxi Province, before a military expedition northward to eradicate various feuding warlords in central and northern China.
1932: British physicist Sir James Chadwick discovers the neutron, a subatomic particle which is used by scientists to render various elements radioactive.
1933: Japanese troops invade Jehol Province in northeastern China.
1933: Chancellor Adolf Hitler calls for a "God-given signal" that the communists should be crushed, as a mysterious fire guts Berlin's Reichstag, or Parliament.
1942: Japanese forces sink three Allied destroyers and a cruiser in the first phase of the Battle of the Java Sea.
1948: The Czechoslovakian Communist Party seizes power in Prague with communists given all the top jobs in the new Cabinet.
1952: The United Nations convenes its first session in its new permanent headquarters in New York.
1962: Two mutinous Republic of Vietnam Air Force planes bomb the presidential office in Saigon. President Ngo Dinh Diem escapes unscathed.
1973: Governor Yu Kuo-hwa of the Central Bank of China leaves for Saigon to sign a US$5 million loan contract with the Vietnamese government.
1973: Ronald H.C. Ho assumes office as president of the Bank of Taiwan.
1974: Osamu Itagaki, chairman of the Sino-Japan Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei for talks on ROC-Japan civil aviation relations.
1975: The ROC and Saudi Arabia sign an air agreement in which Saudi Airlines will offer flight services from Jeddah or Riyadh to Taipei or Kaohsiung and China Airlines will offer flight services from Taipei or Kaohsiung to Jeddah or Riyadh via Hong Kong.
1976: ROC President Yen Chia-kan receives Dennis Theike, commander of Pacific Areas of the U.S. Veterans of Foreign Wars.
1980: Taiwan Power Co. signs a syndicated loan of US$100 million with ten foreign banks to finance development projects.
1981: Beijing strongly protests against the Dutch government's decision to sell two submarines to the ROC, with both sides recalling their respective envoys.
1993: Taiwan Provincial Governor Lien Chan succeeds Hau Pei-tsun as premier of the ROC following his confirmation by the Legislative Yuan.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party candidate Chen Shui-bian promises to create 100,000 jobs to benefit 100,000 families and one million people if he is elected president on March 18.
2001: Kuomintang Chairman Lian Chan meets with People First Party Chairman James Soong, with the two agreeing to bolster future cooperation.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If you speak to a man in the strict words of the law, he will probably agree with you; but the important point is that he should so profit by what you say to him as to change his conduct. If you speak to a man in parables, he will probably be pleased with your story; but the important point is that he should apply the moral to himself."
