DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Friday.
The greenback was trading at NT$34.915 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.065 from Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
More people becoming interested in funeral business: poll

TEXT.P: The funeral business was once a field of work that most people tried to avoid, but this has changed as many are struggling to stay afloat in the current economic storm.

According to the results of an open poll released Friday by www.ejob.gov.tw, an employment service Web site run by the Council of Labor Affairs, obtaining a license as a funeral professional was the fifth most popular choice among the respondents who were given 10 fields to choose from as their second choice of profession.
The poll, which was launched Feb. 1, had drawn 7,242 participants as of Feb. 26, 11.53 percent of whom indicated that they were interested in entering the funeral business.
This was a more popular choice than financial services, which has been on the downturn as result of the global financial crisis.

In the poll, funeral services ranked fifth behind computer software and hardware work, which drew 18.02 percent of the vote; restaurant and bakery business, with 16.64 percent; child care services, with 15.21 percent; and employment services, with 11.95 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma pitches for cross-strait economic cooperation framework

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou advocated Friday the signing of a cross-strait economic cooperation framework, saying that it would be part of Taiwan's global positioning efforts.
"If we don't do it today, we'll regret it tomorrow, " Ma said during an exclusive interview with the local cable TV ERANews.

Ma said that the proposed agreement between Taiwan and China for closer economic cooperation would be beneficial not just to China. Rather, he said, it is part of Taiwan's efforts to better position itself in the world economic landscape.
It was the president's first specific public comment this year on the proposed pact, which has given rise to much debate and political bickering over the past weeks.
In an attempt to calm opponents of the proposal, Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung said earlier this week that it is purely an economic issue that is not necessarily directly related to politics.

Chiu said the proposed agreement, which comes under the portfolio of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, is aimed mainly at enabling Taiwan to meet the challenges that would arise from the ASEAN Plus China agreement set to take effect in 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's top tourism official visits Penghu Island

TEXT.P: Leading a 10-member Chinese delegation, China's top tourism official arrived in the Taiwan's outlying island of Penghu Friday for a half-day visit.
Shao Qiwei, director of China's National Tourism Administration, and his group first boarded a motor boat to cruise waters north of Penghu, which lies off Taiwan's southwestern coast.

The group then visited other tourist attractions in the archipelago, including the big ancient banyan tree in the Tungliang area, the Penghu Cross-sea Bridge, a museum showcasing the island group's unique geology, the Waian Lighthouse and the Hsitai Castle.

Shao arrived in Taiwan Wednesday at the head of a large delegation of tourism officials and travel industry representatives from China's 30 major provinces to attend the 12th Cross-Strait Travel Industry Forum, held for the first time in Taipei by the Taipei-based Travel Quality Assurance Association (TQAA).
Members of the 485-member Chinese delegation have begun to visit other tourist attractions around Taiwan in separate groups in order to gain a better understanding of the country's tourism market.

Shao and his group are scheduled to proceed to the Taiwan-held island of Kinmen Saturday, from where he will head back to China on a passenger ferry sailing between Kinmen and China's southeastern port city of Xiamen.

Since Taiwan relaxed restrictions and opened its doors to more Chinese tourists in July last year, nearly 90,000 tourists from China have come to Taiwan -- at an average of 300 per day in 2008 and 600 per day in 2009 -- according to TQAA Chairman Lin Chin-jung.
It is hoped that the number of Chinese tourist arrivals to Taiwan will surpass a daily average of 1,000 in April this year, Lin said Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Transnational marriage rate drops amid economic downturn

TEXT.P: The rate of transnational marriages between Taiwan citizens and foreign nationals has been declining in recent years as a result of a stricter immigration interview system and the effects of a weak economy, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) and observers said Friday.

The rate of cross-border marriages had climbed from 15.69 percent in 1998 to 31.86 percent in 2003, according to MOI statistics. The 2003 figure translated into about one out of every three marriages in the country, with 50 percent of the cross-border marriages involving a Chinese spouse, the statistics showed.

However, after 2003, the rate of transnational marriages began declining and by 2008 had dropped to 14 percent, with one out of seven marriages in the country being transnational, the statistics indicated.
The biggest decline, 16 percent, was recorded for marriages between Taiwanese and Chinese spouses, followed by a 13 percent drop in legal unions between Taiwanese and Southeast Asian spouses.

The MOI attributed the drop in the cross-border marriage rate to a tighter immigration interview system introduced by the government and a comparative improvement in the economy of the home countries of most potential foreign spouses.
The National Immigration Agency has put in place a system under which Chinese spouses are interviewed upon entry into Taiwan, in an attempt to close the fake marriage loophole.

All foreign spouses from Southeast Asian countries are interviewed both in their home countries and at the point of entry into Taiwan, in accordance with the Taiwan Ministry of Foreign Affairs' regulations.
"Taiwan's sluggish economy has probably also contributed to the decline in the number of cross-border marriages, " said Wang Shi-hou, an international marriage broker.

"In this time of economic recession, Taiwan men are showing less interest in marrying foreign women, " Wang said, citing the fact that it costs about NT$300,000 to arrange a marriage with a Vietnamese bride through a marriage broker.
"Therefore, many people are deferring their plans to marry," Wang added.
Meanwhile, the economic downturn is also dampening the enthusiasm of foreign women to marry Taiwanese men, as they fear that they would not be able to make ends meet, according to Wang.

Moreover, with the growth of China's economy in recent years, many Chinese women are no longer seeing Taiwan as a top choice for finding a husband, but rather are turning their attention more to Japan and South Korea, he said.

According to MOI statistics for last year, 66.7 percent of the Taiwanese men who married non-nationals chose women from China, Hong Kong and Macau, while 22 percent married Vietnamese wives, and 4.4 percent tied the knot with Indonesian women.
Also in 2008, some 869 Taiwanese women married Japanese men, 621 married men from China, Hong Kong and Macau, and 521 tied the knot with Americans, the statistics showed.

The statistics are in line with the so-called "marriage gradient theory" that men tend to marry women slightly below their own levels of achievement, in terms of education, income, and career, and social and economic status, according to Wang Yun-tung, an assistant professor of Social Work at National Taiwan University.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan donates computers to African ally to combat epidemics: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan recently donated computers to Sao Tome and Principe, one of the country's diplomatic allies in Africa, with an aim to help the nation establish a more effective epidemic control mechanism, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Friday.
The donation consisted of nine desktop computers and two portable ones, the ministry said.
Since computer networking would facilitate higher reporting efficiency of epidemic cases, MOFA officials believe the donation could prevent the spread of diseases such as malaria in the country.
The year 2009 marks the sixth year of joint collaboration between Taiwan and Sao Tome and Principe to combat malaria, which Taiwanese officials said has so far proven fruitful and successful.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shares higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Friday, with the Taiwan stock exchange's weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 38.59 points, or 0.85 percent, to close at 4,557.15.

Posting a gain for the third consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 4,523.56 and fluctuated between 4,564.32 and 4,507.39. A total of 3.30 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$68.84 billion (US$ 1.97 billion).

Five of eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares advancing the most at 1.4 percent. Paper and pulp issues gained 0.4 percent, textile shares and plastics and chemicals stocks gained 0.2 percent, and banking and financial stocks were up 0.1 percent.
Construction issues remained unchanged.
Two other major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff stocks falling 0.4 percent and cement issues losing 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,132 to 454, with 245 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$1.64 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Content of pact needs to be approved by legislature: MAC head

TEXT.P: If Taiwan signs a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) with China, it would not take effect unless the legislature approves it, Taiwan's top China-policy planner reiterated Friday.

In response to questions from opposition Democratic Progressive Party lawmakers, Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan gave her assurances that the Legislative Yuan would have to screen the agreement as required in Article 5 of the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.

According to Lai, the process of negotiating and signing a CECA -- which in theory will allow the free flow of merchandise, services, and capital between Taiwan and China -- will be conducted under the statute's legal guidelines.

In addition, Lai said the CECA would be purely economic in nature and not have any implications for Taiwan's sovereignty, adding that the government would not make any arrangements that would jeopardize the country's sovereignty.

Meanwhile, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan reiterated Friday that there is no timetable for the signing of such an agreement, but he said it is not expected to be broached at the next round of negotiations between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), scheduled for later this year.
The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official organizations designated by their respective governments to handle cross-strait matters in the absence of official ties. The MAC supervises SEF operations.

Liu promised that all related government agencies will do their best to assess the benefits and impact of signing a cross-strait economic cooperation framework with China and bringing this plan to fruition is a goal every government agency should pursue.

As to concerns raised by DPP legislators that most people are unclear about the content of a potential agreement, Liu pledged that the government would inform the public and lawmakers of the content and meaning of the cooperation framework before inking such an agreement with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan seeks visa-free treatment from Ireland, Thailand

TEXT.P: Countries that Taiwan's people enjoy visiting are those the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will try to convince to give local tourists visa-free treatment, with Thailand and Ireland high on the list, a MOFA official said Friday.

According to the ministry, Ireland may follow the United Kingdom's recent move to give all Taiwan passport holders six-month visa-free privileges to visit Britain for business or pleasure beginning March 3.
Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs Andrew Hsia said Ireland's consideration of the issue is because Ireland and Britain belong to a "common travel zone."

As to Thailand, which has recently promised all foreign travelers including those from Taiwan exemptions from paying visa fees from March 5 to June 3, Hsia said the ministry will continue efforts to persuade Thailand to grant Taiwanese travelers visa-free treatment.

The MOFA on Thursday welcomed Thailand's announcement of its temporary move not to charge for visas and expected it would boost the number of Taiwanese tourists visiting the Southeast Asian country and boost already extensive bilateral ties.
In 2008, Thailand attracted 330,000 visits by Taiwanese travelers, according to government figures, and economic relations have also been close.

Bilateral trade between Taiwan and Thailand reached US$8.8 billion in 2007, and as of the end of that year, Taiwanese companies had investments in Thailand worth US$12.1 billion, making Taiwan the third largest foreign investor there.
In addition, Thailand is the 13th largest source of Taiwan's imports and the ninth largest market for Taiwan's exports.
There are also 80,000 Thais currently working in Taiwan, making Thailand the fourth largest source of Taiwan's migrant workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan travel sector hopes to get Chinese on local links

TEXT.P: Travel industry representatives from Taiwan and China participated in a cross- strait travel industry golf tournament in northern Taiwan Friday to strengthen contacts and lay the groundwork for Chinese to visit Taiwan on golfing vacations.

David Hsieh, deputy director-general of Taiwan's Tourism Bureau, teed off first at the Miramar Golf & Country Club to open the one-day competition, being held for the fifth consecutive year but the first time in Taiwan.

Travel Agent Association (TAA) Chairman Yao Ta-kuang said that with the Cross- Strait Travel Industry Forum, and consequently the golf tournament, being held in Taiwan, the TAA and the Taipei-based Travel Quality Assurance Association (TQAA) will do their best to promote the integration of tourism resources between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

With most restrictions on visits to Taiwan by Chinese nationals having been lifted, the travel industries in both Taiwan and China are seeking to develop and design new travel packages in Taiwan, including packages with golf themes, Ya said.

He added that the TAA and the TQAA have arranged for close to 50 members of the 485-member Chinese delegation in Taiwan for the forum to visit golf courses in the western part of the island to help them design golf packages that will be promoted in China.
The director of China's National Tourism Administration, Shao Qiwei, and the Chinese delegation, arrived Feb. 25 in Taiwan to gain a better understanding of Taiwan's market.
The full delegation, the largest of its kind ever to visit Taiwan, is composed of tourism officials and travel industry representatives from China's 30 provinces.

Attending this year's forum in his capacity as chairman of the Cross-Strait Tourism Exchange Association, Shao is scheduled to meet with his Taiwanese counterpart, Janice Lai, director-general of the Tourism Bureau, before returning to China.

According to the TQAA, Shao will only remain in Taiwan until Feb. 28, and the deputy director of China's National Tourism Administration, Du Jiang, will lead the Chinese delegation for the remaining four days of its stay.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices mostly higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Friday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for March advancing 32 points to end at 4,510, with 73,628 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for April gained 32 points to finish at 4,464, with 594 contracts traded, while June futures rose 19 points to end at 4,385, with 43 contracts traded.
September futures gained 27 points to close at 4,181, with 25 contract transactions, while December futures rose 31 points to end at 4,127, with 31 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 4,478 for March, 4,432 for April, 4,366 for June, 4,154 for September, and 4,096 for December.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index rose 38.59 points to finish at 4,557.15, on turnover of NT$68.84 billion (US$1.97 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
March TE futures gained 2.35 points to close at 185.25, with 4,101 contracts traded, while April TE futures advanced 2.4 points to finish at 184, with 44 contracts traded.

June TE futures fell 1.1 percent to end at 178.45, with four contracts traded, while September futures dropped 1.15 points to finish at 166, with one contract changing hands. No transactions were recorded for December.
March TF futures fell 0.2 points to close at 491.4, with 4,965 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures advanced 3.2 points to finish at 485.2, with 23 contracts traded.
September TF futures fell 5.2 points to end at 463.8, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, increasing NT$0.100 to close at NT$34.950.
A total of US$1.03 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$34.85 and rose to the day's high of NT$35.008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese cabbage hit Beijing's supermarket shelves
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/27/09 18:34:22 (By Chou Hui-ying and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A batch of fresh cabbage from Taiwan has hit supermarket shelves in the Chinese capital Beijing recently, marking the first of its kind to appear in northern China since direct cross-Taiwan Strait shipping links were opened last December.

Nearly 8,000 kgs of the cabbage, which arrived in Beijing after 10 days of transportation, including several days aboard a ship, have been sold to retailers around Beijing in the past two days, said Lu Ching-liang, owner of afruit and vegetable co-operative based in southern Taiwan's Chiayi County, where the cabbage originated.
They were part of a total 50 tons of cabbage shipped to Beijing by the co- operative over the last several days.

It is the beginning of what Taiwan's government and farmers hope will be a new market for Taiwan's farm produce, which in the past did not make a huge impact on the mainland China despite the proximity, due to the lack of direct flights and shipping links, which made transportation costs high and reduced the shelf life of the produce.

Speaking at a sales promotion, Lu said although the retail price of Taiwanese cabbage is about 67 percent higher than that of the round Chinese cabbage produced locally near Beijing -- 5 yuan per kg against 3 yuan per kg -- the new arrival was welcomed and hotly sought after.
At the promotion, a man, after sampling stir-fried Taiwanese cabbage, said "it's crisp and tasty, " and a woman, after sampling another cabbage dish, said "it's tastily tender."
Compared to Taiwanese fruits, which have been exported to Beijing and sold at "prohibitively high" prices, Taiwanese cabbage's retail price is relatively more affordable and "down to earth," Lu said.
"With its high quality and taste, Taiwanese cabbage is not expensive," Lu stressed.
According to Lu, a total of 50 tons of cabbage have been shipped to Beijing this time for a trial sale and another 60 tons will probably be shipped to Shanghai for sale in the near future.

An official with the Taiwan External Trade Development Council, which has helped push import of Taiwanese cabbage in Beijing, said increased exports to China will help alleviate price contraction of Taiwan-produced vegetables, particularly during the winter when production of vegetables is seasonably massive in Taiwan, inevitably driving down the retail prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: Statute benefiting single fathers to take effect March 1

TEXT.P: An amendment that was passed into law in January will benefit low-income single fathers and families with grandparents as the sole providers when it takes effect March 1, the Executive Yuan reported Friday.
From March 1, families in which the father is a single parent or grandparents are the sole providers will be entitled to government subsidies, Executive Yuan officials said.
The benefits will include emergency daily allowances for families, medical subsidies, stipends for legal proceedings, allowances for children and their education, and loans to start up a business.

The amendment revised the Statute on Assisting the Families of Women in Difficult Circumstances, which already enabled families in difficult circumstances headed by single mothers to qualify for the welfare benefits.

The revised version of the statute allowed fathers who are single parents or victims of domestic violence and grandparents acting as the sole guardians of their grandchildren to also become eligible for the benefits.

The statute also stipulated that education subsidies for children or grandchildren from these disadvantaged families studying at the university level or higher be raised from the current 30 percent of a student's tuition to 60 percent.

There were roughly 540,000 single-parent families in Taiwan in 2004, with 54 percent of the families headed by a single mother and 45 percent headed by a single father, according to the Ministry of the Interior.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's fourth largest LCD panel maker seeking loan extensions

TEXT.P: Chunghwa Picture Tubes Ltd, Taiwan's fourth-largest maker of liquid crystal display (LCD) panels, said Friday it was negotiating with creditors to postpone the repayment of NT$40 billion (US$1.1 billion) in loans but insisted it was not seeking financial relief from the government.

Responding to media reports that the cash-strapped company was seeking a government handout, Chief Financial Officer James Wu said Chunghwa Picture Tubes still had cash reserves but wanted to keep more working capital to weather the global economic downturn, which could last another year or two.

According to Wu, Chunghwa Picture Tubes will need to soon repay NT$10 billion in one-year loans and over NT$30 billion over the longer term to several banks, including the state-owned Bank of Taiwan, Land Bank of Taiwan and Taiwan Cooperative Bank.
Wu said Chunghwa Picture Tubes would like to repay part of the loans while asking its creditors to allow the company to extend repayments of the remaining loans by up to two years.
Chunghwa Picture Tube and other major panel makers in Taiwan have suffered from shrinking market demand and slipping panel prices due to the global economic recession.
The company posted a loss of NT$11.98 billion in the fourth quarter of 2008 and a net loss of NT$11.68 billion for the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait economic pact non-political: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou reassured the public Friday that the proposed economic cooperation agreement with China is non-political and will not involve the issue of unification and independence, as he stressed the urgency of reaching the agreement to maintain Taiwan's economic competitiveness.
With China and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) set to form a free trade area in 2010, a Taiwan-China economic agreement has now become imperative, Ma said.

After the establishment of the China-ASEAN free trade area, Taiwan's petrochemical, electronics, textile and machine tool exports to China, which are subject to a 6.5 percent import duties, will face unfavorable competition from those from ASEAN members states, he said.

Ma warned that the situation is likely to trigger a business exodus to Southeast Asia, leading to the loss of 114,000 jobs in Taiwan and a decrease of one percentage point in Taiwan's gross domestic product.

The president addressed the issue during an interview with the local cable television network ERANews, after the opposition Democratic Progressive Party and Taiwan Solidarity Union voiced strong objection to the proposed comprehensive economic cooperation agreement (CECA), which they argued would downgrade Taiwan's status and pave the way for unification with China.

The opposition is concerned that the CECA, though carrying a different name, is similar to the closer economic partnership arrangement (CEPA) signed in 2003 between China and the special administrative regions of Hong Kong and Macau.

Ma, however, said the agreement that Taiwan wants to sign with China is "certainly not a CEPA." It would also be different from an ordinary FTA, although it would be signed under the WTO framework and function similarly as an FTA, he added.
"The situation between Taiwan and the mainland is very special, which allows for the existence of certain specialities in bilateral agreements, " he said.

According to Ma, the agreement would cover a wide range of economic issues, such as tariffs, non-tariff measures, investment protection, prevention of double taxation, intellectual property right protection and the establishment of a mechanism for dispute mediation.
As the two sides are unlikely to reach consensus on all these issues at the same time, Ma suggested that the two sides sign separate agreements on each of the issues.

Ma reiterated that the agreement would not lead to the opening of Taiwan's market to Chinese laborers or further opening to Chinese agricultural products, stressing that the government will make sure that any liberalization measures toward China are in the interests of Taiwan and its people.
Instead of calling the proposed pact a CECA, Ma proposed during Friday's interview that the pact be renamed an "economic cooperation framework agreement."
Ma noted that various kinds of free trade agreements (FTAs) called by seven different names are now registered with the World Trade Organization (WTO), including CECA and CEPA.

The president also argued that with China's isolation against Taiwan in the international community, the signing of the cross-strait economic agreement would facilitate Taiwan's efforts to ink FTAs with other WTO members.
He pointed out that since Taiwan gained accession to the WTO in 2002, the country has so far only succeeded in signing five FTAs, all of which are with its diplomatic allies in Latin American.

Among Taiwan's major trade partners, the United States, Japan and Southeast Asian nations are all expecting Taiwan to seal an agreement with China first before they would begin FTA talks with Taiwan, Ma said.

Ma promised the agreement with China will be signed in accordance with the principles of parity, reciprocity and dignity, and that authorities concerned will deliver a report to the Legislative Yuan before negotiating with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung City blood drive draws 1,000 people

TEXT.P: More than 1,000 people in Taichung City turned out for a blood drive launched by a local restaurant Friday as stocks in the country's blood banks have run low.

With only four days of blood stocks left, a steak house in the central city held the blood drive aimed at bringing together 1,000 people to roll up their sleeves and donate blood, according to restaurant executive Chen Li-teng.

To encourage more people to pitch in, the restaurant provided NT$5 million worth of giveaways as rewards, Cheng said. Each of the first 1,000 blood donors was to be given a meal voucher and a coupon giving a dinner party of four a 10 percent discount.
The drive drew the participation of crowds of university students.
"It's good to act in the interest of others and get a free meal voucher in the process, " said a National Chung Hsing University student, surnamed Luo, who showed up in the early morning.

"I never thought an economic recession would reduce people's willingness to donate blood, but blood donations in the country have actually fallen 40 percent during the recent downturn, " said Lin Kuo-sin, chairman of the Taiwan Blood Services Foundation.
Friday's blood drive collected an estimated 1,000 bags, or 250,000 cc of blood, Lin said, which should help temporarily mitigate the blood shortage the foundation is facing, Lin said.

Each of the foundation's blood donation vehicles have been collecting an average of less than 60 bags of blood per day in recent months, compared to the 100 bags per day averaged last year, according to Lin.

Because of the smaller amounts collected, the foundation's chairman said it only had about four days' worth of supplies, short of the standard seven-day safety reserve, before Friday's activity took place.
Lin estimated that all six of its blood centers would be facing acute shortages up until the end of March, especially for type O and type A blood.

DOC.HEADLINE: American pop singer Jason Mraz to hold concert in Taipei

TEXT.P: American pop singer and songwriter Jason Mraz will perform in Taipei Saturday in front of a packed house as he promotes his latest album, "We Sing. We Dance. We Steal Things, " concert organizers said Friday.
"All tickets were sold out weeks before Mraz even departed for Asia, " the organizers said when asked if any tickets were left for his performance at the National Taiwan University Sports Center.

The sellout is not surprising giving Mraz's recent success. "We Sing. We Dance. We Steal Things," released in May 2008, was nominated for "Best Non-Classical Engineered Album" at the 2009 Grammy Awards, while "I'm Yours, " the first single from the album, was nominated for Song of the Year and Best Male Pop Vocal Performance.
"I'm Yours" also became Mraz's first top 10 hit on the Billboard Hot 100 in September 2008, and as of Oct. 14, 2008 his album had sold over 500,000 copies in the United States alone.
At a press conference Friday, Mraz said he has been preparing hard for the concert since arriving in Taiwan and therefore had little time to see the country.
"The concert is not mine but the ticket holders', " said Mraz, explaining that he wanted to be in perfect shape to give a spectacular performance in Taipei.
Asked if his songs and on-stage performing style will satisfy the Taiwanese public's taste, Mraz said music has no boundaries and that his songs are written to embrace life and connect people.
"Political and cultural borders are only thoughts in people's minds and good music can break all boundaries and connect people from different cultures," he said.
As Asian fans tend to be more shy and conservative, Mraz said he would do his best to inspire them with his music and "get people awake within themselves."
"I don't want my fans to sit there and stare at me while I perform. It would be better if they can sing with me during the concert," he said.

Asked about his 5-acre avocado farm in San Diego, Mraz said that now that he has his "own patch of earth to care for, " he has payed more attention to the issue of environmental protection and how people can save natural resources by reducing waste and recycling energy.

Mraz is currently on the third leg of an Asian tour that has already taken him to South Korea and Japan. After leaving Taiwan, Mraz will head to Hong Kong, Malaysia, Singapore and Indonesia, the organizers said.
He will then fly to Europe, where he will tour more than 20 cities, and Australia before heading back to the United States.

Mraz attended The American Musical and Dramatic Academy in New York City, for a short time, studying musical theater, before moving to San Diego. His stylistic influences include reggae, pop, rock, folk, jazz, and hip hop.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese survivor in Turkish plane crash returns home

TEXT.P: The only Taiwanese passenger on the Turkish Airlines airplane which crashed in Amsterdam earlier this week said Friday that he feels lucky to be alive.

Chen Shi-yin, an engineer at a high-tech company based in Jhubei, Hsinchu County in northern Taiwan, arrived at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport Friday from Holland where he survived the accident which has killed nine people.
Recalling his narrow escape from death Wednesday, Chen told reporters that when the crash happened, his first thought was "So this is what a plane crash is."

The Boeing 737-800 airplane, with 135 people on board, crashed on landing at Amsterdam's Schiphol international airport, killing nine people and injuring 84, six critically, according to wire reports from Amsterdam Thursday.
Chen said his job needed him to travel frequently overseas. He took the mishap plane in Istanbul destined for Holland en route home after finishing work in Turkey.
Chen recalled that the flight became rough several seconds before the crash. Then the plane suddenly dropped for one or two seconds and he sensed the captain tried to pull it up.
In no time the aircraft hit the ground and the passengers started to scream.
"I feel I am very lucky" after knowing many people died in the crash, Chen said.
The plane crashed in a field near a motorway and broke into three pieces.
"Because I am the only Oriental on the plane, I got the attention of Chinese media after being sent to a nearby hospital," Chen added.
Chen flew back to Taiwan on a China Airlines flight.

Upon arriving at the Taoyuan airport, he was observed wearing worn shoes and having a scrape on his forehead. He only had his passport and a plastic bag with him because his luggage was left at the scene of the crash.
Asked whether he fears taking flights again, Chen said he feels safer taking Taiwanese airlines' flights.
The first thing he wants to do after returning to Taiwan is go home to his wife and five-year-old child, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most voters reject vote-buying: poll

TEXT.P: Taiwan's electorate is growing increasingly resistant to vote-buying, with less than one percent of voters willing to accept bribes from candidates and vote for them, according to the results of a public opinion poll unveiled by the Central Election Commission (CEC) Friday.
The results were found in the first large-scale public opinion poll on graft practices conducted by a polling company commissioned by the CEC.
Most of those surveyed said the practice of vote-buying in the presidential election in 2008 was slight, but that vote-buying in the city and county council member elections were serious.
In other words, the more localized the election and the smaller the constituency, the more rampant vote-buying was.

The survey found that only about five percent of those polled found vote-buying was serious in the 2008 presidential election, while nine percent said the legislative elections in early 2008 and the city and county chief elections in late 2005 were serious.
But 13 percent said vote-buying in the last elections for township and city leaders was worrisome.

Less than one percent of those polled said that they would take bribes from candidates and vote accordingly, while 12 percent said they would take the bribes without voting for the candidates. Eleven percent said they would accept the bribes and make their own judgment in choosing who to vote for.
The survey also found that new approaches to bribe voters have made it hard to tell whether it is bribery or not.
Over 80 precent of the people surveyed would recognize that handing out cash, coupons, sponsored trips or pilgrimages or subsidies for taking part in promotional rallies were vote-buying.
But only 75 percent said free banquets for constituents constituted vote-buying, and only 70 percent said that subsidizing the activities of civic groups was vote-buying.
The poll also found that most people do not think that the practice of entertaining voters with free pleasure trips or banquets is illegal.
The survey was conducted between Dec. 17-20 on 2,011 people over age 20, with a margin of error of plus or minus 2.2 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: NPM and Shanghai Museum officials detail consensus

TEXT.P: Officials of Taiwan's National Palace Museum (NPM) and China's Shanghai Museum provided details in Taipei Friday on the nine-point consensus reached during the NPM director's recent visit to China and said that closer cooperation and exchanges would be of mutual benefit.
NPM Deputy Director Fung Ming-chu reiterated that the two museums have agreed to cooperate in substantive ways without touching on sensitive designation and legal issues.

She said, for instance, that the two museums will set up a strategic partnership to exhibit foreign collections in both museums while the collections are in Asia to reduce expenses such as loan fees, insurance, and transportation costs.

The two museums will also develop a reciprocal sales system to enable souvenirs to be sold at each other's museum, Fung said. Officials from the two museums will also visit each other on a yearly basis.

Meanwhile, Shanghai Museum Director Chen Xiejun formally announced that his museum will lend one set of its treasures -- colored enamel porcelains from the period of the Qing Dynasty's Emperor Yongzheng -- to supplement the NPM's exhibition on the emperor to be held in October.

In the area of exchanges in cultural and creative industries, he said that both museums could take advantage of local competitive edges -- Taiwan's research and creativity combined with China's relatively lower manufacturing costs -- to produce creative products.

The four-member delegation from the Shanghai Museum is currently visiting Taiwan following NPM Director Chou Kung-shin's recent ice-breaking trip to China, which also included a stopover at the Palace Museum in Beijing.
Chou's historic visit to the NPM's counterpart in China marked the first official contact ever between the two museums.
The National Palace Museum in Taiwan holds more than 600,000 works of art, from paintings to jades, and is recognized as having the leading collection of Chinese art in the world.

The items were removed from the Beijing Palace Museum in the 1930s to prevent the collection from falling in the hands of the invading Japanese army. They were later shipped to Taiwan when the Nationalists lost China's civil war to the Communists in 1949.

DOC.HEADLINE: Court invalidates lawmaker's election

TEXT.P: A court invalidated the election of Legislator Chiang Lien-fu, a member of the ruling party Kuomintang from Taichung County, Friday on the grounds that he engaged in vote buying.

The Taichung District Court ruled that Chiang, who was caught on a video tape offering NT$50,000 (US$1,431) to a local voter, Chen Lien-ji, before the legislative election on Jan. 12, 2008, intended to buy Chen's vote with money.

The court dismissed Chiang's argument that he was set up by his political rivals and the money was meant for Chen to organize campaign rallies for him, rather than as a reward for his personal ballot.
The court's ruling was made in a case initiated by Chiang's Democratic Progressive Party rival in that election, Chien Chao-dung.
Chien made public the tape on Dec. 18, 2007 and requested the prosecutors initiate a probe.

As a result, Chiang was indicted by prosecutors on Jan. 29, 2008 for violating the election law and for forgery, but was found not guilty by a panel of judges of the Taichung District Court on April 30.
Prosecutors had already appealed against the ruling in that case to the Taiwan High Court.
Chiang has vowed to appeal the court's decision Friday.
He is one of five lawmakers whose election on Jan. 12, 2008 were challenged by their political rivals.

Among them only Lee Yi-ting a KMT member from Miaoli County has been stripped of his legislator's status so far. His election was invalidated by the Taiwan High Court, which has the final say in such cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: 238 fugitives arrested in crime sweep around Taiwan

TEXT.P: A two-day crime sweep on Feb. 24-25 around Taiwan has led to the arrests of 238 fugitives wanted by police, the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) under the National Police Agency said Friday.

Officers at the CIB's investigation division said that during the two-day operation, launched across Taiwan against illicit drugs and firearms, police also charged 1,084 suspects with drug-related offenses and 33 others with the illegal possession of firearms.

Altogether, 10,375 police officers joined the sweep. They obtained 878 search warrants from various district courts and checked 7,873 places, including 4,653 crime-ridden locations, according to statistics released by the CIB.
Of the suspects detained for drug-related offenses, 863 were subjected to urine tests.
The statistics also showed that the operations seized 16.2 kilograms of various narcotics, 30 firearms and 132 rounds of ammunition.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA grants visa fee waiver to Thai nationals

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Friday that it would wave visa fees for Thailand passport holders for three months, effective early March, reciprocating similar treatment offered earlier this week by the Southeast Asian nation.
Thai nationals who wish to visit Taiwan for less than 90 days will not be required to pay the normal NT$1,600 (US$46) visa fee between March 5 and June 4, according to the MOFA statement.
As April is the peak season for Thais to travel abroad, the ministry expects that the measure will lure more Thai visitors to Taiwan.
More than 30,000 Thai tourists visit Taiwan annually, a mere fraction of the 300,000 Taiwanese who visit Thailand every year.
Thailand announced Wednesday that it would exempt the fee for tourist visa applications for all visitors, including those from Taiwan, between March 5 and June 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hit by recession, high-speed rail firm to cut service, executive pay

TEXT.P: Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC), hit hard by the local recession, announced plans Friday to streamline its operations, with 126 rides per week to be suspended and chairwoman Nita Ing opting not to collect her monthly salary.

Beginning March 16, weekly services will be reduced from 942 rides to 816 rides, a cut of 13.37 percent. The move represents the first time the company has reduced service since the high speed rail line was inaugurated Jan. 5, 2007, THSRC said.
Under the plan, two-way train service will be cut from 130-142 rides to 106-134 a day, according to a THSRC statement.

Meanwhile, Ing will stop collecting her salary from this month because the company's pay day falls at the end of a month. Beginning in March, monthly salaries for 110 top executives will be cut by between 10 percent and 20 percent.
The company said it currently has no plans to ask workers to take unpaid leave but will conduct an overall review of its personnel structure before making necessary moves to downsize its staff.

DOC.HEADLINE: High court revokes ruling on ex-president's detention

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court revoked Friday a lower court's ruling keeping former President Chen Shui-bian in custody before and during his trial on corruption and money laundering charges and demanded that the lower court deliver a new ruling in the case.
Chen, who has been detained since Dec. 30, appealed his case to the high court last Friday after the Taipei District Court rejected his request to repeal its decision to detain him.
Taipei District Court spokesman Chen Chun-ming said that once the court receives the high court ruling, a panel of judges will decide when to open a new hearing on the case.

In revoking the district court's ruling to detain Chen, the high court stated in its verdict that only those highly suspected of having committed major crimes and show signs of fleeing the country or tampering with evidence as stipulated in Article 101 of the Criminal Procedure Law should be detained prior to trial.

In the former president's case, the verdict said the district court failed to provide sufficient evidence to back its argument that Chen Shui-bian was very likely to be involved in major cirmes and might flee Taiwan.
Chen and his wife have been indicted on charges of siphoning off NT$104 million (US$3.12 million) from a special Presidential Office discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000 to May 2008.
They are also charged with accepting bribes in connection with a land procurement deal and receiving kickbacks by helping a contractor win the tender for a government construction project.

The high court said the nature and reimbursement procedures of the Presidential Office's discretionary fund remain unclear and require further examination before it can be determined if Chen broke the law.

As to Chen's role in the Lungtan land procurement deal, the high court said prosecutors did not provide concrete evidence to prove their claim that Chen collaborated with Lee Chien-mu, a former head of the Hsinchu Science Park Administration who has confessed to taking bribes in striking the deal.

Based on these arguments, the high court said the district court violated rules of logic in reasoning that there was a strong suspicion that Chen committed major crimes to justify its decision to keep Chen behind bars.
The high court also questioned prosecutors' arguments that Chen had to be detained because he was a flight risk.

Prosecutors contended in their previous appeals seeking Chen's detention that Chen might flee Taiwan because he had served as president for eight years, had wired money abroad and might possessed a large sum of assets that have not yet been confiscated, and many foreign leaders in similar cases had fled abroad to evade prosecution.
The high court ruled, however, that such arguments were not enough to prove that Chen could flee Taiwan if remaining free.
The high court also said the district court needs to further investigate whether prosecutors' accusations that Chen could tamper with or destroy evidence were true.

Chen was first taken into custody Nov. 12 as prosecutors prepared their case against him. He was released after being indicted Dec. 13, but was jailed again Dec. 30 when a new judge assigned to the case in the Taipei District Court agreed with a prosecutors' request to hold him in custody.
The Taiwan High Court had previously revoked lower court rulings to free Chen without bail.
The district court began a new round of pretrial sessions earlier this week.

DOC.HEADLINE: Film director-composer, wife return to Taiwan to face law

TEXT.P: Renowned film director Liu Jia-chang and his wife -- a former movie actress under the stage name Chen Chen -- voluntarily returned to Taiwan from Hong Kong Friday to face the law, as the two have been wanted on suspicions of embezzling funds from two private art companies.
Liu and his wife, Chang Chia-chen, have been on the wanted list since May 2007. Immigration records show that they left Taiwan in 2001 for Hong Kong, with their whereabouts unknown ever since.

According to the National Immigration Agency, the couple informed judicial authorities that they would return to Taiwan Friday to cooperate with prosecutors' investigation regarding their involvement in a joint investment case that ended with their partners accusing them of siphoning funds from their two art companies.

Liu, accompanied by his wife, showed up at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport with an expired Republic of China passport. They were questioned by immigration officials at the airport and then transferred to the Public Prosecutors Office of the Taipei District Court for further questioning concerning their alleged offenses.
Liu said that he and his wife decided to come back to face the law because Taiwan's judicial system had returned to normal.
He added that he and his wife's return to Taiwan is proof that they have full confidence in the judiciary.

According to the prosecutors, Liu and his wife raised NT$619.92 million (US$17.71 million) from shareholders of two private art companies in August 1999 under the pretext of increasing the companies' paid-in capital.
A month later, however, Liu used NT$693 million of the companies' funds to buy a property worth only NT$388 million from his wife and wired the money to his wife's foreign bank account.
The transaction harmed the interests of Liu's partners and he had been subpoenaed repeatedly by the prosecutors office to be questioned on the breach of trust allegations.
After repeated attempts to summon the couple to appear in court failed, the Taipei District Court issued a warrant for their arrest, which was to remain valid until Dec. 25, 2018.
Liu, 68, was a well-known music composer before becoming a film director. He has written nearly 2,000 songs, including 200 that became popular hits in the 1970s and 1980s.
His wife, 60, was an award-winning actress who divorced her first husband of two years -- a movie actor in Hong Kong -- in 1976 and married Liu in 1978.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Japan agree to emergency notification mechanism

TEXT.P: The 16th round of fishery talks between Taiwan and Japan reached a consensus on several issues, including an agreement to set up an emergency notification mechanism to handle fishery disputes, an official of the quasi-official Association of East Asian Relations (AEAR) said Friday in Taipei.
Tsai Ming-yao, AEAR secretary-general, made the remarks after Friday's conclusion of this round of talks, the first since July 2005.

He said that both sides also agreed to set up a private consultation channel, with Taiwan's Provincial Fisherman's Association and Japan Fisheries Association acting as the organizations handling civilian cases, such as collisions at sea, the impounding of fishing vessels and the tangling of fishing nets.
He noted that Taiwan came to the negotiating table determined to safeguard the sovereignty of its territory and jurisdiction over its territorial waters.

"Both sides adopted a pragmatic attitude during the talks, " Tsai said, adding that the talks had "focused on how to mitigate fishery disputes between Taiwan and Japan and enhance information exchanges."
The talks did not touch on the sensitive issue of the disputed waters near the Tiaoyutai Islands, known as the Senkaku Islands in Japan, in the East China sea, Tsai said.
Both sides agreed that the fishery disputes should be handled in a rational and peaceful way without compromising the long-standing friendly and cooperative relations between the two, he said.
"To continue to advance friendly bilateral ties and mutual trust and narrow the perception gap between the two, both sides also agreed to hold further consultations if needed," he added.

To efficiently handle a crisis, both sides agreed to set up an emergency notification mechanism, Tsai said, noting that such notification would normally pass through the AEAR and Japan Interchange Association.
But both sides agreed to set up other notification channels -- the Naha branch of Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Japan, and Japan's Fisheries Agency.
Taipei and Tokyo have held 15 rounds of fisheries talks since 1996, with the last round occurring in July 2005 in Tokyo, but sharp differences remain between the two countries.
In June last year, a Taiwanese recreational fishing boat, the Lienho, based in Taipei County, collided with a Japan Coast Guard (JCG) vessel in the disputed waters near the Tiaoyutai Islands.
The Lienho sank after it collided with the JCG patrol vessel that was allegedly trying to chase it out of the disputed Tiaoyutai waters.

The Taiwanese skipper and his two crew members were detained by Japanese authorities for questioning after they and 13 Taiwanese recreational fishermen who were on board the boat were rescued by the JCG officers.
The Taiwanese skipper accused the Japanese patrol of deliberately ramming his boat and demanded that Japan compensate him for the damage to his vessel.
The incident touched a raw nerve in the region, as the Tiaoyutai Islands in the East China Sea are claimed by Taiwan, China, and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 28, or the fourth day of the second month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1784: John Wesley, the British religious leader who founded Methodism in 1738, signs the "deed of declaration" formalizing the establishment of the Wesleyan faith.
1825: Russia and Britain sign a treaty settling the border between Canada and Alaska, then a Russian possession.
1854: U.S. opponents of slavery, meeting at Ripon, Wisconsin, agree to form a new political party. The Republican Party was born later in 1854.
1900: The British Labour Representation Committee, which later would become the Labour Party, is founded with Ramsay MacDonald as its secretary.
1909: Linus Pauling, the American chemist and physicist who won the Nobel Prize for chemistry in 1934 and the Noble Peace Prize in 1962, is born.
1921: Russian sailors of the Baltic Fleet and workers at Kronstadt naval base rise up against the communist government.
1922: Britain declares Egypt's independence, while it retains control of the Suez Canal.
1942: Japanese troops land in Java, Indonesia after the Japanese sink two more Allied ships on the second day of the Battle of Java Sea.
1946: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Shih-chieh and French Ambassador to China Jacques Meyrier sign the "Sino-French Treaty Regarding the Revocation of French Extraterritorial Jurisdiction and Related Privileges in China" in Chungking.
1947: Rioting breaks out in Taipei, following an incident in which an old woman was brutally beaten by police for violating the tobacco monopoly by selling untaxed cigarettes.
1951: The Republic of China Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Dr. Chien Shih-liang as president of National Taiwan University.
1956: Indonesia and India sign a mutual aid treaty.
1967: American editor and publisher Henry Robinson Luce dies at the age of 69. He co-founded Time in 1923 and later founded Fortune in 1930 and Sports Illustrated in 1954.
1973: Forty-four additional members of the ROC Legislative Yuan are sworn in.
1976: Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, the Philippines and Thailand sign a treaty of friendship and cooperation.
1987: President Corazon Aquino of the Philippines announces full and complete amnesty to communist rebels who lay down their weapons.
1992: The ROC and the Philippines sign an official investment guarantee agreement to protect Taiwan businesspeople investing in the Philippines.
1992: The United Nations Security Council approves a peacekeeping force for Cambodia.
1995: ROC President Lee Teng-hui gives an apology to the families of the victims of the Feb. 28 Incident in 1947 during a ceremony at Taipei's New Park, where a monument commemorating the tragedy was built with government sponsorship.
1996: Russia becomes the 39th member of the Council of Europe.
1996: Britain's Princess Diana agrees to divorce her estranged husband Prince Charles.
1997: An earthquake hits western Pakistan, claiming more than 35 lives, while another earthquake in Iran destroys over 20 villages and kills nearly 1,000 people.
2000: The Philippine government urges Taipei to return to the negotiating table to resolve the fresh aviation dispute between the two sides and proposes that the talks be reopened in Manila between March 1-2.
2000: Chen Li-an, former president of the Control Yuan, formally makes known his intention to support Vice President Lien Chan, the presidential candidate of the ruling Kuomintang.
2001: Taipei and Shanghai authorities agree to further bolster sisterhood exchanges between the two mucipalities, beginning with a student exchange program.
2004: More than 1 million people held hands together to form a human chain that stretched the length of Taiwan from Hoping Island in the northern tip to Pingtung County near the island's southern tip to demonstrate their love for Taiwan and their desire for peace.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When I find a man agrees with me in what I say without being able to profit by it by changing his conduct, or one who is pleased with my parable without being able to apply the moral to himself -- I can do nothing for such a man."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
High court revokes ruling on ex-president's detention

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court revoked Friday a lower court's ruling keeping former President Chen Shui-bian in custody before and during his trial on corruption and money laundering charges and demanded that the lower court deliver a new ruling in the case.
Chen, who has been detained since Dec. 30, appealed his case to the high court last Friday after the Taipei District Court rejected his request to repeal its decision to detain him.
Taipei District Court spokesman Chen Chun-ming said that once the court receives the high court ruling, a panel of judges will decide when to open a new hearing on the case.

In revoking the district court's ruling to detain Chen, the high court stated in its verdict that only those highly suspected of having committed major crimes and show signs of fleeing the country or tampering with evidence as stipulated in Article 101 of the Criminal Procedure Law should be detained prior to trial.

In the former president's case, the verdict said the district court failed to provide sufficient evidence to back its argument that Chen Shui-bian was very likely to be involved in major cirmes and might flee Taiwan.
Chen and his wife have been indicted on charges of siphoning off NT$104 million (US$3.12 million) from a special Presidential Office discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000 to May 2008.
They are also charged with accepting bribes in connection with a land procurement deal and receiving kickbacks by helping a contractor win the tender for a government construction project.

The high court said the nature and reimbursement procedures of the Presidential Office's discretionary fund remain unclear and require further examination before it can be determined if Chen broke the law.

As to Chen's role in the Lungtan land procurement deal, the high court said prosecutors did not provide concrete evidence to prove their claim that Chen collaborated with Lee Chien-mu, a former head of the Hsinchu Science Park Administration who has confessed to taking bribes in striking the deal.

Based on these arguments, the high court said the district court violated rules of logic in reasoning that there was a strong suspicion that Chen committed major crimes to justify its decision to keep Chen behind bars.
The high court also questioned prosecutors' arguments that Chen had to be detained because he was a flight risk.

Prosecutors contended in their previous appeals seeking Chen's detention that Chen might flee Taiwan because he had served as president for eight years, had wired money abroad and might possessed a large sum of assets that have not yet been confiscated, and many foreign leaders in similar cases had fled abroad to evade prosecution.
The high court ruled, however, that such arguments were not enough to prove that Chen could flee Taiwan if remaining free.
The high court also said the district court needs to further investigate whether prosecutors' accusations that Chen could tamper with or destroy evidence were true.

Chen was first taken into custody Nov. 12 as prosecutors prepared their case against him. He was released after being indicted Dec. 13, but was jailed again Dec. 30 when a new judge assigned to the case in the Taipei District Court agreed with a prosecutors' request to hold him in custody.
The Taiwan High Court had previously revoked lower court rulings to free Chen without bail.
The district court began a new round of pretrial sessions earlier this week.
